title: Hey, Stell-Lahhh! Where's That Rattletrap Streetcar?

With what Tennessee Williams described as ''faintly hysterical humor,'' she recalls her journey: ''They told me to take a streetcar named Desire, and then transfer to one called Cemeteries and ride six blocks and get off at -- Elysian Fields!''

title: New Jersey High School Is Winner of Fed Contest
description: A team of students from Montclair High School in New Jersey won first prize and $40,000 today in the sixth annual Fed Challenge, a national competition that tests economic wits.

title: Defense Rests in African Embassy Bombings Trial
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are expected to begin closing arguments today in the trial of four men charged with joining a terrorism conspiracy led by the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden, which prosecutors say included the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa.

title: National Briefing/ROCKIES: COLORADO: EVALUATION FOR ANTARCTICA DOCTOR
description: Doctors at Swedish Medical Center in Englewood began examining Dr. Ronald Shemenski, who was flown on Sunday to Denver from a research station at the South Pole, where he was the only physician. Doctors are trying to determine how they might treat a gallbladder problem. Ramonna Tooley, a hospital spokeswoman, said doctors would know by Wednesday whether Dr. Shemenski would need surgery, which she called a common procedure. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing/Asia: China: Airline Alliance
description: Six state-owned Chinese airlines said they had formed an alliance to compete against three large state-owned airline groups being formed through a state-mandated consolidation. The six carriers said their alliance would allow them to negotiate lower rental fees and fuel costs and give them economies of scale in operating sales networks. China is trying to narrow the number of airlines without forcing any into bankruptcy. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing/NEW JERSEY: JERSEY CITY: APPEAL BY FORMER MAYOR
description: Gerald McCann, the convicted felon and former mayor who was barred by state courts from seeking his old job, will file an appeal in Federal District Court in Newark and will run for a State Senate seat in the meantime, his lawyer said yesterday. The State Supreme Court refused to hear Mr. McCann's final appeal on Friday, after an appellate panel reversed a trial judge's ruling that would have allowed him to run. In 1992 Mr. McCann was convicted of bank fraud unrelated to his official duties and removed as mayor. His lawyer, Samuel R. DeLuca, said he would file a petition to succeed State Senator Edward T. O'Connor, a Democrat representing the 31st Legislative District, who is stepping down.

description: President Bush marked his first 100 days in office with a White House luncheon today to which all 535 members of Congress were invited. But only about a third of them showed up, and the political parties ended up squabbling over the value of what had been billed as a bipartisan outing.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS CANADA: ECONOMY STALLS Canada's economy stalled in February, as output dropped 0.1 percent after a 0.3 percent rise in January, but the decline was only half as bad as economists had predicted. Manufacturing led gross domestic product down, with a 0.9 percent drop, and production of electrical and electronic equipment fell 9.1 percent, the worst reversal in 40 years. "Major customers, primarily from the United States, continued to curtail spending, sparking significant production cutbacks and layoffs by key Canadian producers," said Statistics Canada, the government's reporting agency. Gains in construction, mining and forestry partly offset the decline in manufacturing.

title: Reports Show Gains in March In the Economy
description: Personal incomes and spending rose in March, and manufacturing in the Midwest showed signs of emerging from a slump, government and private reports showed today.

title: World Business Briefing/Europe: Britain: Sales Up at Online Concern
description: A European online travel agency, ebookers.com, said its sales nearly doubled in the first quarter, setting off a gain of 19 percent in its share price. For the three months ended March 31, ebookers.com recorded consolidated sales of $48.7 million, compared with $24.9 million a year earlier. Before accounting for taxes and stock options, ebooker.com lost $11.9 million, compare with the $10 million it lost a year earlier. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: CALPERS WILL INVEST $122 MILLION IN SPORTS BUSINESSES
description: The California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest pension fund, agreed to pay $122 million to J. P. Morgan Chase for a stake in a firm that invests in sports-related businesses. The system, known as Calpers, will get 15 percent of the firm, Sports Capital Partners L.P., which is partly owned by IMG, the sports marketing firm that represents the athletes Tiger Woods and Wayne Gretzky. The investment is the latest by the $160 billion fund to extend its interests in venture capital firms.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Bush committed the United States today to building a missile defense system for a world in which cold-war thinking is outmoded and the Soviet Union is fading into memory.

title: The Rewards, and the Roadblocks, of Medical Sleuthing
description: The rewards of epidemiologic investigations include identifying new ways that old diseases can be transmitted, recognizing new health hazards and finding new ideas for reducing the incidence of preventable diseases. And although epidemiologists solve many outbreaks, they are stumped by others, or hampered in other ways, like hospital lawyers who do not allow them to interview affected patients.

title: 8 Palestinians and 1 Israeli Die in Surge Of Violence in West Bank and Gaza
description: Seven Palestinians were killed today in the West Bank and Gaza, some from bombs that may have been intended for Israelis.

title: Monster.com Ends Suits on Ex-Workers
description: Monster.com and its corporate parent, T.M.P. Worldwide, have dropped 20 lawsuits they filed a little over a month ago against Monster.com's former president, William Warren, and 18 other former Monster.com employees who now work at WOWemployers, an online recruiting company founded by Mr. Warren.

title: World Briefing/AFRICA: ZIMBABWE: TRIAL SET FOR OPPOSITION LEADER
description: The leader of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, Morgan Tsvangirai, will stand trial next week for a statement that government officials say could have led to the overthrow of the government. The charges stem from a speech last year in which Mr. Tsvangirai warned President Robert Mugabe that if he did not leave power peacefully he would be removed violently. If convicted, Mr. Tsvangirai could be sentenced to life in prison.

title: Ferrer to Go to Puerto Rico to Join Protest of Navy Bombings
description: With the Rev. Al Sharpton at his side, Fernando Ferrer said yesterday that he would go to Puerto Rico later this week to protest the United States Navy bombings on the island of Vieques. But Mr. Ferrer, a Democratic candidate for mayor, said he would not join other protesters in attempts to be arrested.

title: Parliament In Indonesia Votes Censure Of President
description: An angry Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to censure President Abdurrahman Wahid, moving one big step closer to impeachment proceedings and heightening calls for his resignation.

title: Using X-Rays to Measure the Elusive Spin of a Black Hole
description: By studying the rapidly varying X-ray emissions from an object 10,000 light-years from Earth, an astronomer believes he has measured the spin of a black hole for the first time, scientists said today at a meeting of the American Physical Society here.

title: World Briefing/EUROPE: GREECE: PATRIARCH NOT WELCOME
description: Greek Orthodox church leaders, who have led protests against Pope John Paul II's visit to Athens on Friday, have pressed the Vatican not to include in the papal entourage Cardinal Ignace Moussa Daoud, who is the church's official in charge of relations with the Eastern Churches and is the Patriarch of the Syrian Catholic Church. The Syrian church follows Eastern rites but is loyal to Rome. Cardinal Daoud is expected to rejoin the pope in Syria on Saturday. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: When Smoking Is a Matter of Money
description: Getting people to quit smoking may be hard, but discouraging them from starting, at least when they are young, may be as simple as raising the taxes on cigarettes.

title: Metro Briefing/CONNECTICUT: HARTFORD: NURSING HOME STRIKE TODAY
description: The first wave of a strike by unionized nursing-home workers at 40 homes is scheduled to begin at 6 a.m. today, union officials said yesterday. At 7 of the 40 homes, members of District 1199 of the New England Health Care Employees Union will begin their walkout, followed by union workers from 9 other homes tomorrow, union officials said. On Thursday, workers from 24 more homes are to go on strike. Officials at District 1199 estimated the cost to the state of increasing staff levels and wages among workers at $13.3 million over the next two years. A spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland called that amount unrealistically low.

title: Addenda: Ferrari Chooses AG Worldwide
description: Ferrari North America in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has named AG Worldwide in New York, part of the Draft Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies ( news/quote ), to handle brand development and marketing communications for the North America account of Maserati. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: World Business Briefing/Europe: European Union: Trade Deficit
description: The external current account deficit of the 15-member European Union rose to 15 billion euros in the fourth quarter of last year from 8.6 billion euros in the previous quarter, and from 1.9 billion euros a year earlier, the European Commission statistics office, Eurostat, said. The balance in trade of services fell to a deficit of 3.2 billion euros from a surplus of 1.9 billion euros in the third quarter of 2000. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing/NEW YORK: BUFFALO: MORTGAGES FOR MINORITIES
description: A total of $200 million in low-cost mortgages will be offered over the next five years to new immigrants and minorities in Erie and Niagara Counties, officials announced yesterday. Fannie Mae, the federally chartered mortgage lender, and CitiMortgage, a subsidiary of Citigroup, have jointly committed to marketing the program and lending the money to promote homeownership in the two upstate counties, said Aulin G. Bridges, a Fannie Mae spokeswoman. The National Urban League and other groups are to inform potential borrowers.

title: More Good News For Seton Hall
description: It is coming in trickles, but there was more good news yesterday for the new Seton Hall men's basketball coach, Louis Orr, who announced that the freshman point guard Andre Barrett would not transfer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, ANN KERR
description: FRANKLIN-Ann Kerr. The Board of Trustees and the Director of the Nassau County Museum of Art mourn the passing of Mrs. Ann Kerr Franklin, dedicated Board Member. Appointed to the Board in 1989 as a founding member, Mrs. Franklin helped establish the museum as a successful entity. Giving selflessly of her time as Director in charge of the museum's bookshop, she will be greatly missed by the Board of Trustees and the entire museum family.

title: A Top Sinn Fein Leader Says He Was No. 2 in I.R.A.
description: Martin McGuinness, a top leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, disclosed today his role as second in command of the I.R.A. on ''Bloody Sunday'' in 1972, when 14 Roman Catholic civil rights demonstrators were killed by British Army soldiers.

title: With Merger Deal Gone Sour, EMI Must Count on Its Stars
description: LONDON, May 1  When the EMI Group and BMG abandoned their talks to create a music industry giant today, Eric Nicoli, the EMI chairman, found himself once again having to talk up the company's prospects as a stand-alone entity.

title: Second Brush Fire in 2 Days Disrupts Turnpike Traffic
description: Firefighters in East Rutherford, N.J., battled a brush fire in the Meadowlands yesterday that sent plumes of smoke several miles into the sky and disrupted commuter traffic for several hours in one of the country's busiest transportation corridors. A similar grass fire had had much the same effect on Sunday.

title: In a push for ratings, a TV sitcom about the 70's plans to rerun ads from the disco decade.
description: VERY week, the Fox Broadcasting Company turns back the clock with ''That 70's Show,'' a sitcom set in the decade of pet rocks, Pop Rocks, ''Saturday Night Fever'' and the Saturday Night Massacre. Tonight, as a one-time stunt, the network will also turn back the clock for Madison Avenue, running commercials from the 1970's during an episode of the show.

title: Metro Briefing/NEW YORK: YONKERS: DEALER IN FAKE BADGES HELD
description: Investigators arrested a police memorabilia dealer yesterday after confiscating more than 5,000 authentic-looking police badges from his Yonkers home. Police officials said the dealer, Elliot Sash, 44, sold the mock badges, left, by mail for $75 each. It is legal to make and sell mock badges unless they resemble the real thing so closely that they could be used to impersonate an officer, officials said. ''The average person would not know the difference,'' Lt. John Zerillo, commander of the Police Impersonation Unit for the New York Police Department, said of Mr. Sash's badges. Officials said Mr. Sash had played bit parts in the television program ''Law and Order.'' Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing/AFRICA: ETHIOPIA: HIJACKERS FACE DEATH
description: Five Ethiopians who hijacked an Ethiopian military airplane last week will face trial: and possibly the death sentence: in Sudan, where the plane landed. A Sudanese official called the hijackers terrorists. Ethiopian officials said they had failed in their effort to extradite the hijackers, who they said were cadets. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS WARNS OF SOFTER EARNINGS THIS QUARTER
description: Pier 1 Imports Inc. said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter profit might fall because shoppers were buying discounted or lower-priced goods, setting off a 24 percent decline in its share price. Profit in the quarter ending June 2 will be 12 cents to 16 cents a share, down from the 17 cents Pier 1 earned a year ago, the company said. Analysts' average estimate was 18 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. The company, which is based in Fort Worth, said sales at stores open at least a year would fall or be unchanged this month, and would be unchanged or rise 2 percent during the quarter.

title: National Briefing/SCIENCE AND HEALTH: TEENAGE DRINKING AND DRIVING DROPS
description: Teenagers are drinking and driving less in states with stricter blood-alcohol limits for people under 21, a study published in the American Journal of Public Health has found. The study by Alexander C. Wagenaar of the University of Minnesota, which surveyed high school seniors in 30 states, showed that once the new laws went into effect, there was a 19 percent decrease in cases of teenagers driving after drinking alcohol. (NYT)

But the unrest has another source: the long-frustrated demands of black residents for a share of Cincinnati's prosperity.

title: Corrections

He is Wahid Abdel Maguid, deputy director of Al Ahram Center for Strategic Studies.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an erroneous map appeared in some copies on Saturday with an article about the Peruvian town on the Amazon where missionaries gathered for a memorial service. The map had been prepared for an article a day earlier about the oldest city in the Americas, in Caral, Peru, close to Lima. In copies printed later, the map correctly showed the missionaries' town, Iquitos.

title: A League of Their Own
description: Women's soccer, that suburban grass-roots phenomenon, has gone pro. The eight-team Women's United Soccer Association held its inaugural game on April 14 before 34,148 fans at Robert F. Kennedy stadium in Washington. If successful, the league could join the W.N.B.A. as a much-needed source of inspiration for millions of girls across the country. Female professional athletes as role models, particularly in team sports, have been in short supply over the years.

title: Judge Approves Settlement in F.B.I. Bias Lawsuit

title: Old Guard Digs In Heels As Koizumi Seeks Change
description: The goals set out by Junichiro Koizumi, Japan's heretical new prime minister -- rewrite the Constitution, realign the political system, overhaul Japan Inc. -- suggest nothing short of revolutionary transformation in a country where putting advertising on municipal buses has incited bitter complaints.

title: Rwandans on Trial
description: Seven years after a state-orchestrated genocide claimed the lives of more than half a million ethnic Tutsi in Rwanda, the world is still struggling to establish a measure of accountability for the mass killings. In a courtroom in Brussels this month, four Rwandan Hutu are being tried on charges of complicity in the 1994 slaughter. The trial marks the first time that a jury of civilians from one country is being asked to judge people accused of war crimes committed in another. By expanding the doctrine of universal jurisdiction for crimes against humanity, the case opens a promising new frontier in the evolution of international criminal law.

title: Technology Briefing/Hardware: Infineon Unit of Siemens Buying Catamaran
description: Infineon Technologies, a leading German chip maker, said it would buy Catamaran Communications, a private American manufacturer of integrated circuits for optical networks, for $250 million in stock. Catamaran, based in San Jose, Calif., will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Infineon. Infineon is the semiconductor unit of Siemens of Germany and is based in Munich. Catamaran designs integrated circuits for 10-gigabit optical networks and the so-called next-generation network, 40 gigabits. Shares of Infineon gained 46 cents, to $42.66. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Gone With the First Amendment
description: The constitutional protection of copyrights was not meant to trump the First Amendment. That is a principle missing from a federal judge's ruling in Atlanta to stop publication of ''The Wind Done Gone,'' a retelling of ''Gone With the Wind'' from a slave's point of view. The right to produce comic parodies of prior works is well established in law. The estate of Margaret Mitchell is arguing that this new work is not a parody but an unauthorized sequel appropriating characters covered under its copyrights.

title: Ratings Continue To Decline in N.H.L.
description: National Hockey League ratings continue to decline.

title: Men's Retailer Moe Ginsburg Is to File for Bankruptcy
description: Moe Ginsburg, the Flatiron district institution long known as a no-frills retailer of quality men's clothing, plans to seek bankruptcy protection today, its president, Paul Ginsburg, said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the arrest of Christopher Rocancourt, a fugitive accused of fraud in the Hamptons, misstated the locations of Oak Bay, the town in Canada where he was arrested, and Whistler, a ski resort where he had been spotted earlier. Oak Bay is about 70 miles south of Vancouver (not 10 miles west of it). It is on Vancouver Island near the city of Victoria, the capital of British Columbia; it is not on Victoria Island. Whistler is in the Coast Range of British Columbia, not near Victoria.

title: For China-Born U.S. Citizens, Visiting Homeland Has Risks
description: Over the last six months, the State Security Ministry has started detaining American citizens born in China and questioning them about their affairs in China in what diplomats believe is a worrisome change in government policy.

title: Opening A Window On Therapy
description: You are taught, when you train to be a psychiatrist, not to give advice. Instead, you must explore with patients their motives, needs and wishes and let them arrive at their own conclusions. Thus goes the professional credo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIMMEL, SARAH LEVINE
description: KIMMEL-Sarah Levine. On April 28, 2001 in her 99th year. Beloved wife of the late Samuel J. Devoted sister of the late Benjamin. Cherished mother of Tobi (Gene) Nadel and the late Philip (Maryln). Adored grandmother and great grandmother. She will be remembered lovingly for her spontaneous warmth, her caring heart and the manner in which she embraced the joys of life.

title: Free Rides Are Now Pass On Information Highway
description: There never was such a thing as a free lunch over the Internet. But for a while a determined freeloader could find a Web site that would pick up the tab for all sorts of other goods and services, from computer keyboards to photo developing, in return for little more than looking at a few ads.

title: Man in Attacks On 7 Women In Central Park Gets 2 1/2 Years
description: A man convicted of being part of a riotous mob and attacking seven women in Central Park last summer was sentenced yesterday to a minimum of two and a half years in prison for his role in the assaults, which followed the National Puerto Rican Day Parade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARR, JUNE O.
description: STARR-June O. Funeral service will be held May 1, 2 PM, at Temple Isaiah, 1404 Stony Brook Road, Stony Brook, NY. Call 631751-8518 for directions.

title: Barry Smith, Greenwich, Conn., April 4, 2001
description: his couple bought the property, but they weren't thrilled with the house, so they wanted to tear it down to build a new, bigger house. They said the bedrooms were a little small and there wasn't a lot of closet space. Only in Greenwich does someone buy a house for a million just to smash it. I don't know what these people are thinking. You should have seen the hardwood floors inside! I would have loved to live in that house. The house I own would fit inside it. I've been doing this for about 10 years, a couple times a month in the summertime. It's good because it's work for everybody including me. And after all, it's the homeowner's choice. But sometimes I wonder. If my boss tells me we are taking a house down, I go by and look first. It's got all the landscaping, it's beautiful and it's just going down. You feel a little bit bad about it. But in another way, it's fun, a lot of fun. Ask any kid why."

description: LIFSCHUTZ-Rabbi Emanuel L. age 93 of Milwaukee. Passed away on April 29, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Deborah (nee Steinberg). Loving father of Shelley (Herman) Bruch, Berkeley, CA, Dr. David H. and Jonathan S. Lifschutz, New York, NY. Devoted grandfather of Mia & Elizabeth Bruch, Mariel Grace, Debra and Michael Lifschutz. title: Public Interests; The Children's Crusade
description: One of President Bush's twin daughters was cited for possession of alcohol last weekend. This revives the ever-popular question of how the media should cover White House children. The Bush girls, after all, are 19-year-old adults, old enough to vote or go to war or pilot a plane or run for Texas county sheriff.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Circuits on April 5 about removable data storage products gave an incomplete list of the device types that can use the Microdrive, a miniature hard drive made by International Business Machines. In addition to portable music players and desktop, laptop and hand-held computers, they include digital still cameras.

description: GOLDSTONE-Mortimer. It is with profound sorrow and a great sense of loss that we mourn the passing of our beloved partner, Mortimer Goldstone. He was a selfless, patient teacher and a caring human being whose professional abilities were extraordinary. His goodness and sense of humor will always be an inspiration. He left an imprint on all our hearts. We will forever be enriched by having had him as a partner. The Partners and Staff of Frendel, Brown & Weissman

description: You have probably seen it. And like the people on the F train platform last week, you probably stopped and stared and tried to squint through the windows at the people inside it, their faces bathed in a blue computer glow.

Monsignor Arpie served on the Executive Committee. James G. Nugent, President Douglas W. Wyatt, Vice President & Lincoln Hall Board of Managers

title: Jets Continue to Tap The Hofstra Pipeline
description: Hofstra University may be a suburban school nestled in the heart of Nassau County, but it has given the Jets two of their signature players -- John Schmitt, a center during the 1960's and 1970's, and Wayne Chrebet, their current No. 1 receiver.

description: NEWS

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The euro dropped as expectations dimmed that the European Central Bank will reduce interest rates to spur growth. In New York, the euro settled at 88.79 cents, down from 89.10 cents on Friday.

title: Meyer Friedman, 'Type A' Theorist, Dies at 90
description: Dr. Meyer Friedman, an originator of the theory linking heart attacks to impatient, angry ''Type A'' behavior, died on Friday in San Francisco. He was 90, and until a few weeks before his death continued to do research at an institute that he had founded and that was named for him at the Mount Zion Medical Center, part of the University of California at San Francisco.

title: Rent Board Chief Resigns With Attack on the Mayor
description: Facing ouster by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the chairman of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board quit yesterday and unleashed a scathing attack on the mayor.

title: National Briefing/SOUTHWEST: TEXAS: HEALTH COVERAGE FOR TEACHERS
description: The State House of Representatives unanimously passed a bill that took a first step toward a statewide health insurance plan for teachers. The bill, sponsored by Representative Paul Sadler, chairman of the House Public Education Committee, would provide state money to create a mandatory insurance pool for rural and poor school districts, some of which have not been able to afford health coverage for their employees. The statewide plan for teacher health insurance has been among the most contentious issues of the legislative session because of the potentially large pricetag. The Senate must now consider the bill. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: Progress in Special Education
description: The federal government has long criticized New York State for segregating too many children with alleged learning disabilities -- especially black and Latino children -- in special education classes, where they learn little and rarely graduate. The state responded by creating an early-intervention program for children with learning disabilities and revised a funding formula that had rewarded districts for isolating special-needs children in segregated classes. Data released by the State Department of Education show some encouraging signs that the new policy is starting to take hold.

title: Metro Briefing/NEW YORK: MANHATTAN: UNION PROTEST AT MET OPERA
description: More than 100 union supporters held a rally last night across the street from Lincoln Center as the American Ballet Theater held its spring gala at the Metropolitan Opera House. The Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union is seeking to unionize 95 restaurant workers employed by the Met's food contractor, Restaurant Associates. The contractor says a secret-ballot election should be used to determine whether the workers want a union, but union officials say recognition should be granted once a majority of the workers sign cards saying they want a union. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, REV. WILLIAM JOSEPH
description: FARRELL-Rev. William Joseph, S.J. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Rd., Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 11:30 AM. (For information, contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500).

title: Ferrari Chooses AG Worldwide
description: Ferrari North America in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has named AG Worldwide in New York, part of the Draft Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle brand development and marketing communications for the North America account of Maserati. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENGUALID, RACHEL
description: BENGUALID-Rachel. The Board of Trustees of Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, an affiliate of Yeshiva University, is saddened by the passing of a highly respected member of the Sephardic community, beloved mother of our Trustee Henri Bengualid. YU Guardians and RIETS Fellows, he and his late wife, Sylvia, established the Jacob S. Knafou Memorial Scholarship for Sephardic Students at RIETS. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Henri and Jacob (and Margot) Bengualid; grandchildren, Dr. Victoria Bengualid (and Gabe) Goldstein and Marc (and Beth) Bengualid; great-grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Min hashamayim tenuhamu. Dr. Norman Lamm, President, YU and RIETS Julius Berman, Chairman, RIETS Board

description: To the Editor:

title: Camby Rejoins the Knicks and Focuses on Game 4
description: There were no full-contact five-on-five drills today, so Marcus Camby did not get the chance to elevate quickly to snatch a rebound or reject a shot. But Camby's actions during the Knicks' light practice and brief film session at SUNY-Purchase were enough to convince his teammates that he was returning to form.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LAYOFFS AT DAILY NEWS
description: Executives at The Daily News said yesterday that the paper planned to lay off about 40 employees as a part of a cost-cutting effort to counter the downturn in advertising. The executives, who spoke only on the condition that they not be named, said that every department at the newspaper would face layoffs but that it was unclear where all of the reductions would come from. The cuts should reduce The Daily News's work force, which is estimated by Standard & Poor's to be 2,000, by 2 percent. ''There is an unfortunate trend going on right now,'' said one Daily News official. ''I think it is hard to find a media company that is not in some kind of retrenchment mode right now, and relatively speaking, our layoff numbers are pretty low.'' The officials said they did not anticipate being forced to make additional cuts in coming months and there were no plans to cut back on the free afternoon newspaper that The Daily News started last September, The Daily News Express.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENACH, HENRY
description: BENACH-Henry. Passed away peacefully in his home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. on April 29, 2001 surrounded by his loving family. He is survived by his wife Shirlee, his children Douglas and Sue, Michele and Wayne, his five grandchildren, Jay, Stacey, Melissa, Erin and Stuart, and his sister Annette. While he has lived the last few years in Frenchmans Creek, North Palm Beach, he will be laid to rest at Westchester Hills, near his longtime home in Scarsdale, N.Y. At age 83, loved by many, he completed his life's work with great strength and courage. Contributions in his memory may be made to Columbia University, Department of Urology, Dr. Olsson Research Fund, or Dr. Daniel Petrylak Prostate Cancer Research Fund also at Columbia University. Graveside service Tuesday, 2 PM, Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, NY

title: Kerrey, Diallo And Heroes
description: HIS name is Phillip C. Arterbury. On May 10, 1968, he was Specialist Arterbury, assigned to the 25th Infantry Division in Cu Chi, South Vietnam. That day, he received the Silver Star, one of the military's highest awards for valor.

title: Goodyear Cuts Jobs In Mexico
description: Gonzalo Ugalde Gmez, a 68-year-old union leader whose right eye hunkers down into a mean slit during moments of brutal honesty, took the lectern before a smoke-filled auditorium of 1,357 Goodyear tire makers to deliver bad news.

title: Philippine President Declares State of Rebellion in Manila
description: MANILA, Philippines, May 1  Hours after a mob of protesters stormed the gates of her palace  resulting in three deaths and hundreds of injuries  President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo today began rounding up opposition leaders whom she accused of conspiring to topple her fledgling government.

title: Files Suggest Profiling of Latinos Led to Immigration Raids
description: Before immigration agents raided Al's Deli on Seventh Avenue in Midtown Manhattan four years ago, they considered several factors. One was an anonymous tip alleging simply that 10 of the 20 or so workers were illegal Mexican immigrants. Another was their own surreptitious observations about the employees.

title: Atlanta Company Offers to Buy Petroleum Exchange in London
description: IntercontinentalExchange, an online commodities trading company based in Atlanta, has offered to buy the International Petroleum Exchange in London, the world's second-largest oil futures market, in a bid to computerize it, the companies said today.

title: Hepatitis C Poses New Threat to Many With AIDS
description: Gerald Moreno was thrilled when his doctor told him he was responding wonderfully to his H.I.V. drug cocktail, which included a powerful new protease inhibitor.

title: 100 Days: A Time for Soundings
description: To the Editor:

title: Stevens Angry at Lack of Ice Time Down the Stretch
description: Scott Stevens was still seething today, two days after the Devils had somehow survived a third-period collapse to win Game 2 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: National Briefing/NORTHWEST: WASHINGTON: DISCOVERY OF DRUG LAB CLOSES FOREST
description: State officials have temporarily closed most of a 26,000-acre state forest preserve near Mount Rainier National Park, after a conservation officer found a large methamphetamine laboratory hidden among the fir trees there. The state Department of Natural Resources said it might take several days or even a few weeks to conduct an investigation and clean up hazardous chemicals at the site, spread over nearly two acres in the Tahoma State Forest. A 19-year-old Tacoma woman was arrested. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Laboratory Ducks Are Stolen, And It's a Case for the F.B.I.
description: Nearly 250 ducklings were stolen over the weekend from a remote research laboratory on eastern Long Island, and the authorities said today that they suspected an underground animal rights group that has claimed responsibility for other crimes in the area.

title: Metro Briefing/NEW YORK: BROOKLYN: GANG 'GODMOTHER' SENTENCED
description: A woman whom the authorities called the godmother of a violent Brooklyn street gang was sentenced yesterday to life in prison for the 1995 murder of a rival gang member. The woman, Joanna Pimentel, was a ranking member of the Netas, a street gang that has its roots in Puerto Rico, the authorities said. Ms. Pimentel and other Netas members were convicted this year of killing Galliat Santiago, the leader of another Netas chapter. The Netas operated around 4920 Sixth Avenue in Sunset Park, federal prosecutors said. Several of the members were charged in December with operating a bazaar for the sale of drugs, guns and explosives. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: 3.4 Million Multi-Use Baby Seats Are Being Recalled
description: The federal government will announce today the recall of a combination infant carrier and car seat that has injured 97 children, the latest in a series of product failures that is prompting worry among consumer advocates that multipurpose baby products may sometimes compromise safety.

title: Led by Big Drop at Chrysler, Auto Sales Fell 10% in April
description: DETROIT, May 1 - Automakers reported today that sales fell in April, providing the first important indicator of the American economy's condition early in the second quarter and a sign that weakening consumer confidence is beginning to affect spending on high-priced products.

title: A Solo Requiem for America's Mozart
description: George Gershwin was just 38 when he died of a brain tumor in 1937, having produced a prodigious legacy. ''George Gershwin Alone,'' Hershey Felder's stage biography, makes a great case for his subject as the American Mozart.

title: The World of Science Becomes a Global Village; Archive Opens a New Realm of Research
description: Lubos Motl, an undergraduate physics student at Charles University in Prague, was not feeling very cheerful over the Christmas holidays in 1996. His family was shaken by instability, he was suffering chronic stomach pain and he had just been hospitalized after a serious accident at home. And no one at the university knew much about his scientific passion, a highly abstract and mathematical area of physics called string theory.

title: In a Sculpture Garden, Beauty as Strangeness
description: The opening image of ''Behind Resonance,'' a new dance piece by Shen Wei, a 32-year-old Chinese choreographer who is attracting increasing attention, is striking.

title: Computer Associates Officials Stand By Their Accounting Methods
description: Computer Associates said yesterday that its accounting conformed to standard rules and that it had not inflated its results, a day after The New York Times reported that former employees and analysts had raised serious questions about the company's financial statements.

title: World Briefing/AMERICAS: MEXICO: REBELS SAY NO MORE TALKS
description: The Zapatista rebels, calling an Indian rights law passed over the weekend an ''offense to the Indian people,'' suspended all talks with President Vicente Fox's government. The law granted new powers of autonomy to Mexico's 10 million indigenous people, but the Zapatistas say key language was changed to give state governments more control over Indians. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: City Cycling -- Biking Events
description: Biking events, from Bike New York to moonlight rides in Central Park.

title: Technology Briefing/E-Commerce: Evineyard Takes Over Larger Rival
description: The Internet wine retailer eVineyard, based in Portland, Ore., has acquired its competitor, Wine.com, for an undisclosed amount. The acquisition represents a victory for eVineyard's business model: securing legal licenses to sell wine directly to residents of 27 states, as opposed to going through distributors or other retailers to avoid legal issues involving shipping alcohol across state lines. It is also a triumph of frugality: eVineyard, which is privately held, has raised slightly more than $20 million, compared with Wine.com's $200 million in investments. But eVineyard stands to benefit from access to Wine.com's 400,000 customers, who represented $28 million in sales last year, almost triple eVineyard's sales of $10 million. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing/Americas: Canada: Economy Stalls
description: Canada's economy stalled in February, as output dropped 0.1 percent after a 0.3 percent rise in January, but the decline was only half as bad as economists had predicted. Manufacturing led gross domestic product down, with a 0.9 percent drop, and production of electrical and electronic equipment fell 9.1 percent, the worst reversal in 40 years. ''Major customers, primarily from the United States, continued to curtail spending, sparking significant production cutbacks and layoffs by key Canadian producers,'' said Statistics Canada, the government's reporting agency. Gains in construction, mining and forestry partly offset the decline in manufacturing. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Mets Land Back Home, And None Too Soon
description: Less than a week ago, the same move backfired on Manager Bobby Valentine. Choosing to pinch-hit for Steve Trachsel with the Mets facing a one-run deficit in Milwaukee, Valentine watched his pinch-hitter fail. Later, his bullpen did the same.

title: 20% Increase in 911 Calls Is Seen As a Result of Cellular Phone Use
description: Even as crime in New York City has declined, the number of 911 emergency telephone calls has increased by 20 percent over the last two years, police officials told a City Council hearing yesterday. The officials attributed the increase to the proliferation of cell phones, which they said has meant that an emergency like a car accident is often reported not once or twice, but many times by people with cell phones as they drive by.

title: World Briefing/AFRICA: SENEGAL: ELECTION BOLSTERS PRESIDENT
description: The party of President Abdoulaye Wade appears to have won a parliamentary majority, according to partial results of the election last Sunday. After years as the main opposition leader, Mr. Wade was elected president last year in one of the few peaceful transfers of power in West Africa. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, EVELYN
description: FRIED-Evelyn. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Evelyn Fried. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Editor at Hollywood Paper Quits in Dispute Over Article
description: Anita M. Busch, editor of The Hollywood Reporter, resigned today in a dispute involving the publisher's initial refusal to print an article accusing the paper's gossip columnist of accepting favors from movie producers.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: National Briefing/NEW ENGLAND: MASSACHUSETTS: TOUGHENING WELFARE LAW
description: Gov. Jane M. Swift wants to toughen welfare laws requiring that some recipients spend part of their week on the job. Massachusetts is the only state to exempt welfare recipients with children under 6 from work. Ms. Swift is proposing a measure that would force recipients with children ages 2 to 5 to work at least 20 hours a week. The work requirement would be increased to 30 hours a week from 20 for parents of older children. Part of the bill would make it easier for welfare recipients to fulfill their weekly work quota by counting hours spent in job training and education classes toward the work-for-benefits requirement. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Brazil Bounding Forward As Genomics Powerhouse
description: It has no laboratories or research teams of its own, only a modest administrative staff working out of a nondescript building in a residential neighborhood here. But through canny management and careful choices, the Research Support Foundation of the State of So Paulo is rapidly becoming a powerhouse in genomics and a model for scientific investigation in the third world.

title: More at a Wall Street Firm Are Investigated on I.P.O.'s
description: Several more employees of Credit Suisse First Boston are under investigation in a broad federal inquiry into how Wall Street investment banks doled out shares in offerings of new stocks, according to regulatory filings and people inside and outside the firm.

title: Rich Pardon Reportedly Followed Pledge to Charity of Former Wife
description: Shortly before they received pardons from President Bill Clinton, Marc Rich and his business partner promised to donate $1 million a year to a cancer charity run by Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise Rich, lawyers familiar with the arrangement say.

title: Major Senior Tourney Headed to New Jersey
description: Since joining the Senior Tour, Doug Tewell has won two of the five major championships that he has played.

title: River's Power Aids California And Enriches the Northwest
description: Doing something nice for California has never been a priority here in the Columbia River Basin, where high-voltage power lines lope across irrigated fields of alfalfa, potatoes and wheat.

title: Attacks Were Up Last Year, U.S. Terrorism Report Says
description: The number of international terrorist attacks increased by 8 percent last year, largely because of a surge in bombings by two rebel groups in Colombia and attacks by paramilitary groups operating there, the State Department said today.

title: To Live Another Day in the Arena League
description: It was the first Arena Football League game played at Nassau Coliseum and Commissioner David Baker was fretting. The New York Dragons and Toronto Phantoms were scoreless through the first three minutes of their game last month. Concern creased Baker's face. What was wrong?

title: World Briefing/ASIA: MALAYSIA: JAIL FOR EX-POLICE CHIEF
description: Calling his action ''despicable and inhuman,'' a judge sent the former chief of Malaysia's national police force, Rahim Noor, to jail for two months for punching former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim and giving him a black eye when he was arrested in September 1998. Mr. Anwar is now serving 15 years in prison after being convicted of corruption and sodomy. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing/Africa: South Africa: Anglogold Gains
description: The world's biggest producer of gold, Anglogold, said that it earned $42 million in the first quarter, reversing a year-earlier loss of $17 million. Excluding one-time items, profit rose to $54.8 million, an increase of 1.6 percent over a year earlier. The rise in profit was attributed to cost-cutting and higher gold prices, which were negotiated when the price of gold was higher. Henri Cauvin (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 23 recalling the lessons of the television writers' strike of 1988, as background to the current negotiations, misstated the timing of the debuts of two unscripted programs that gained popularity then. NBC introduced ''Unsolved Mysteries'' as a special program before the introduction of the Fox series ''America's Most Wanted,'' not after. ''Unsolved Mysteries'' later became a series.

title: World Business Briefing/Europe: Switzerland: Roche Reviews Costs
description: Roche Holding said it planned a major review of its operations and would take steps to reduce its operating costs. The company said it would announce its plans this month or next but declined to comment on a report that it was considering layoffs. With few new products coming to the market recently, the Basel-based drugs giant posted flat sales in the first quarter, while rivals posted double-digit growth. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Barking Far and Wide
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs; Low-Tech Democracy
description: The information revolution has come to Africa, and last December it had a direct impact on bringing about the first-ever peaceful transition from one elected civilian government to another in Ghana. This was a hugely important political event for West Africa, but it got lost in America's post-election ruckus. Ghana's turnabout would not have happened, though, without the information revolution here. Thank the Lord for the information revolution. You gotta love technology. Oh, I'm not talking about the Internet. I'm talking about FM radio.

title: Consumers to Get a Choice on Insurers' Sharing of Data
description: New York residents have begun receiving notices that they may prevent their insurance companies from sharing their personal financial information and health records with other companies. In Connecticut, a similar notice covers the sharing of financial records.

title: Deal for Oil Search Innovator
description: The Halliburton Company, an oil services concern, agreed yesterday to buy Magic Earth Inc., a company that specializes in the three-dimensional imaging of oil and gas deposits, for $100 million in stock.

title: Metro Briefing/NEW YORK: WHITE PLAINS: ALLERGY LABELING PROPOSED
description: Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Westchester County Democrat, called yesterday for tighter restrictions on food labeling to better protect people with allergies. She plans to introduce a bill that would require labels to reveal, in plain language, whether a product contains any form of the most common allergy-causing foods: peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, eggs, milk, soy and wheat. In addition, labels would have to include additives and a telephone number for the food manufacturer.

title: Conquering Europe, Word for Word
description: For Europeans uneasy with the social and economic changes being wrought in the name of continental unity, a new specter is haunting Europe: the specter of English. National identities are shaken, mutual antipathies threaten to spread, the governments of great European nations contemplate increasingly drastic measures as language police sift through newspapers and monitor television programs for contraband English.

title: Brainy Dolphins Pass the Human 'Mirror' Test
description: With brains second only to those of humans in relative size, superb memories, sonar systems more sophisticated than any navy's, and complex social structures, dolphins are often considered geniuses of the seas.

description: In percent

title: It's Early, but the Mets Must Find an Identity
description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine sauntered toward a group of reporters at Shea Stadium last night like an eager gunfighter, a small smile creasing his face. ''I'm ready for you,'' Valentine bellowed. When a reporter chuckled, Valentine feigned incredulity and said, ''You sound like you don't believe me?''

title: World Briefing/ASIA: SRI LANKA: ANOTHER BID FOR PEACE
description: A Norwegian peace envoy, Erik Solheim, arrived to consult with President Chandrika Kumaratunga after the government and Tamil rebels reverted to their warring ways. The rebels ended their cease-fire last Tuesday and the government mounted an offensive the next day. The military gained no territory, but said 221 of its soldiers had been killed and 800 wounded. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: National Briefing/WEST: CALIFORNIA: SQUID FISHING LIMITED
description: State officials concluded a three-year study of squid fishing by recommending the first limits on the number of boats permitted to catch the generally plentiful creatures. Until now commercial fishing for squid has been unregulated, but the state is now proposing that just 82 boats be allowed to catch squid in California waters, which would freeze the fleet at its current size. State officials said they hoped to protect not only squid, but also the many other animals that dined on them, from the endangered brown pelican to salmon and tuna. The new rule requires approval from the Legislature. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YASGUR, FLORENCE FISHMAN
description: YASGUR-Florence Fishman. Beloved wife of Harold for 51 years. Devoted mother of Rabbi Benjamin and Barbara Yasgur, Rabbi Jordan Yasgur, Sharie and Dr. Ezra Sofair. Cherished sister of Sandra Dickstein. Loving grandmother, dear aunt and good friend to many. Service today, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York. Interment Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: The Devils' 'A Line' Searching for 'A' Game
description: Most of the Devils were already in the dressing room after practice today, but the linemates in the green shirts stayed on the ice for extra work. They were Jason Arnott, Patrik Elias and Petr Sykora, the highest-scoring line on the National Hockey League's highest-scoring team in the regular season. But they are fighting a slump in the Stanley Cup playoffs, and trying to find a way out of it.

title: World Briefing/AFRICA: SOUTH AFRICA: MANDELA BACKS MBEKI
description: Former President Nelson Mandela said he believed that President Thabo Mbeki deserved a second term. Speaking in London, Mr. Mandela was addressing concerns about the South African government's decision to investigate three senior members of the African National Congress, the governing party, on charges of trying to oust Mr. Mbeki. The inquiry has been described as politically motivated because two of the three men are considered potential rivals of Mr. Mbeki. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

Ryan of FL. Daughter-in-law Michelle M. Ryan of Princeton, N.J., grandchildren Kelly K. Trani of Lawrenceville, N.J., Richard T. Ryan of Princeton, N.J. and Christopher D. Ryan of Clinton, Md. title: Newspaper Circulation
description: The circulation of the nation's largest newspapers -- USA Today, The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times -- grew slightly, while circulation shrank for most of the other dailies in the 250,000-plus group, according to the latest tally of the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

description: ''I'm fine,'' Vince Carter said tersely.

title: CHENEY PROMOTES INCREASING SUPPLY AS ENERGY POLICY
description: Vice President Dick Cheney said today that oil, coal and natural gas would remain the United States' primary energy resources for ''years down the road'' and that the Bush administration's energy strategy would aim mainly to increase supply of fossil fuels, rather than limit demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSMENTIER, MILTON
description: POSMENTIER-Milton. Died at the age of 91 on April 30, 2001. Milton was a World War II veteran, and a retired architect of the N.Y.C. Housing Authority and the New York State Division of Housing. Loving husband of Sophie (nee Rauch). Devoted father of Loveleen and Erick Posmentier, and Lynn and John Evansohn. Cherished grandfather of Raoul, Fred, Sonya, Michael and Inka. Great grandfather of Rivka, Eidel and Dovid. Also survived by his dear brother Jess Posmentier and fond sister-in-law Sally. Funeral service will be held Tuesday, 11:30AM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Procession to Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale to follow.

title: Lemony Snicket Says, 'Don't Read My Books!'
description: Who is this mysterious and unlikely sounding Lemony Snicket, creator of the best-selling books called "A Series of Unfortunate Events," and what has kept him from showing up at his own scheduled author appearance? What does he look like and where, exactly, is he from? (His author photo, which changes from book to book, is always a blurry shot taken from the back, in which he is walking away from the camera, or staring out a window or down at a book.) And why are the wildly tongue-in-cheek, neo-gothic stories he spins about the miserable lives of the terrorized but resourceful Baudelaire orphans -- 14-year-old Violet, who is a whiz at inventing things; her bookwormish brother, Klaus; and baby Sunny -- always dedicated to the late but still longed-for Beatrice? (From "The Ersatz Elevator": "For Beatrice -- When we met, my life began. Soon afterward, yours ended.")

description: Karen Akers

title: Sports of The Times; The Missing Maple Leaf Is Adjusting
description: HIS name was on the Maple Leafs' ticket list last Saturday night: Bryan Berard. Unobtrusively, he watched the Devils' 6-5 overtime victory and mentioned that he might be in Toronto for tonight's resumption of the Eastern Conference semifinals in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Contracts to Pataki's Neighbor Prompt Inquiry by Comptroller
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall began an investigation today into contracts that New York State awarded to an architect with close ties to Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Apple Aims at Schoolrooms With Latest Portable Computer
description: CUPERTINO, Calif., May 1  Seeking to recapture its fading leadership in the educational computer market, Apple Computer Inc. today introduced a more compact and less expensive version of its iBook consumer-oriented portable computer.

title: Memorial Day in London
description: Memorial Day is made for long weekend trips, and for those willing to go a long way, there's Virgin Atlantic Vacations' three-night package to London. It includes round-trip air fare on Virgin Atlantic, with departure May 24; three nights in the Thistle Landaster Gate Hotel, which overlooks the Royal Parklands of Kensington Gardens and Hyde Park, and daily breakfast. Prices start at $599 a person, based on double occupancy, and hotel taxes are included, as are airport transfers in London. Departures are from Kennedy, Newark and Boston airports; other cities cost extra. Information: (888) 937-8474 and www.virgin-atlantic.com/vacations .

title: Bush Calls Allies in Advance of Missile Speech
description: President Bush began paving the diplomatic path today for his missile defense system and the possibility of renouncing the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. He called leaders of several major European and Asian allies in preparation for a speech about missile defense on Tuesday, telling them he wanted to begin consultations on a new nuclear strategy.

title: Top Court Rejects Appeal to Overturn 1997 Rape Conviction
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court today rejected an appeal to overturn the conviction of Alex Kelly, a former Darien High School wrestler who received a 20-year prison sentence in 1997 for raping a 16-year-old neighbor girl.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The aim here is efficiency, not austerity. Conservation may be a sign of personal virtue, but it is not a sufficient basis for a sound, comprehensive energy policy.''

title: Illegal Immigrants Race Against Clock to Get Through a Small Window of Opportunity
description: Some arrived as early as Saturday night, with sleeping bags, reclining chairs, even dining room chairs to make the wait more bearable. By today, when the immigration office here opened at 6 a.m., the crowd had swelled to several thousand, and many more were on the way.

description: This is the time of year in television when writers like Paul Attanasio grow nervous.

title: German Media Company's Loss Surpasses Forecast
description: EM.TV and Merchandising, which nearly collapsed after buying the Muppets and control of the Formula One racing organization last year, gave dispirited investors another jolt today by announcing that it lost 2.8 billion marks ($1.27 billion) in 2000.

title: Dean of Law School Is Said To Be Choice to Lead N.Y.U.
description: New York University is likely to name its law school dean, John Sexton, as its next president next week, according to people close to the search process.

title: City Cycling -- Biking in the City
description: Bicycle lovers can roll along about 150 miles of bicycle paths spread throughout New York City's five boroughs. The paths, which are maintained by the New York City Department of Transportation, run both on city streets (designated by signs or markings on the pavement) and on off-street paths (that are physically separated from traffic).

title: P.&G. Earnings Increase 19%, Exceeding Wall St. Estimates
description: Procter & Gamble reported earnings today that were higher than Wall Street had expected, but the company said sales declined in its third fiscal quarter and its executives promised that they would do more to increase the market share for P.& G.'s consumer brands.

title: Save a Child's Brain: Require a Helmet
description: A few months ago, a representative of an organization that calls itself Right of Way urged me to ''question the ongoing clampdown on children's mobility and autonomy in the name of safety.'' The writer was objecting to a New York City Council proposal to require children 14 and younger to wear helmets while riding those now-popular scooters.

title: London Journal; To Get the Underground Up to Par, Call on a Yank
description: Even the British caricature that portrays Americans as boorish, loud, blind to nuance, deaf to irony or just plain weird usually includes a grudging good word for their native ability to go out and get the job done.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIESS, ROGER C.
description: BRIESS-Roger C. On April 25. Beloved husband of Monica. Loving and devoted father of Colin and Craig. A true gentleman of tremendous integrity and honor. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him, especially, Zoroaster and Gobi. Friends may visit Tuesday, 4-8 PM at the family's residence. Funeral service Wednesday, May 2, 9:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the charity of your choice.

title: Knoblauch Gets Closer To the Boos in Left Field
description: Booing Chuck Knoblauch has been a favorite pastime in the Metrodome since he forced the Minnesota Twins to trade him before the 1998 season. Now, with his shift to left field, Knoblauch has become a much more tempting and accessible target for derision, and fans fired away tonight, with words and coins and plastic bottles.

title: Iraq Is Undermining Aid Projects by Blocking Visas, U.N. Says
description: The government of President Saddam Hussein is slowing crucial aid work in Iraq by refusing to issue visas to international experts, United Nations officials said today.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From a recipe for spicy French fries to where to shop on the Web for wine refrigerators, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: National Briefing/WEST: CALIFORNIA: CITY TO PAY FOR SEX CHANGES
description: The San Francisco Board of Supervisors voted to provide city employees with health benefits that include sex change operations. The 9-to-2 vote makes San Francisco the first city in the nation to offer medical benefits for transgender procedures. The benefits include hormone therapy, hysterectomies, mastectomies and male-to-female transsexual surgeries. Psychotherapy and other treatment for complications are included. The benefits will be offered as a pilot program for the first year with a maximum of $50,000 to cover most of the cost of sex change operations. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUCIE, MARTIN P.
description: SOUCIE-Martin P. Age 46, a former Ridgewood civic and political leader, on April 14, 2001. Visitation on Friday, May 4 from 2 to 5 and 7 to 9 at Schawaroch Funeral Home, 58-34 Catalpa Avenue, Ridgewood, New York, 718-821-1131.

title: World Briefing/MIDDLE EAST: ISRAEL: GUILTY EX-OFFICIAL AVOIDS PRISON
description: Yitzhak Mordechai, a former Israeli military chief of staff, defense minister and transportation minister, was given an 18-month suspended sentence for sexual assault. Mr. Mordechai, 56, had been convicted of trying to use force to molest two women subordinates. The judges said the conviction was punishment enough given Mr. Mordechai's years of service to the state; a female judge dissented. Deborah Sontag (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKSTAVER, NELSON D., D.D.S.
description: BOOKSTAVER-Nelson D., D.D.S. Age 77 of Haworth died April 30, after a fierce battle with lymphoma. Beloved husband of Mimi (Synes), adored father of Bobbi (George Barunas) and Julie and the late Douglas. Cherished grandpa of Michelle and Lauren. Respected brother of Dr. Paul Bookstaver and Nita Cohn, and the late Dr. Julian. Brother-in-law of Dr. Bertram and Janice Synes Weissman and Lillian Rose Bookstaver. Son of the late Anna (Bocker) and Dr. Barnet Bookstaver. A graduate of Teaneck High, U. of Maryland Dental School and graduate of orthodontic department at Columbia U. School of Dental Medicine. A veteran of U.S. Navy during W.W. II and Korea, serving as a dentist aboard the USS Missouri. He had been an ass't prof. of orthodontics in the the graduate school of dentistry at F.D.U., and had an orthodontic practice for over 40 years in Bergenfield. title: Germans Offer Plan to Remake Europe Union
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's governing party proposed a far-reaching plan today to turn the European Union into a more centralized federal system, a plan that would give much more power to the European Parliament but will raise national anxieties in countries like Britain and France.

title: Hanes Advertising Undergoes Review
description: The Sara Lee Branded Apparel division of the Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its Hanes and Hanes Her Way lines of apparel. The account has been handled for almost 20 years by Mullen/LHC in Winston-Salem, N.C., formerly Long Haymes Carr.

title: A PROPERTY BROKER LOWERS ITS 2001 FORECASTS AGAIN
description: Trammell Crow, citing a slowing real estate market, said yesterday that it expected its first-quarter results to fall short of analysts' estimates and cut its profit outlook for the year for the second time in less than three months. Earnings for the first quarter will be at or near break even, below analysts' estimates of 4 cents a share, said Derek McClain, chief financial officer. Trammell Crow, a broker and property manager based in Dallas, said it expected to post earnings, excluding one-time gains, of $1.15 a share to $1.25 a share for the year. The company first lowered its outlook for 2001 in February, when it cut its earnings estimates to $1.85 a share from $2 a share.

title: World Briefing/MIDDLE EAST: IRAN: 'GUARDIANS' BAR CANDIDATES
description: The Council of Guardians, a board that screens political candidates, barred 145 of the 356 people seeking to run for parliamentary seats in the June 8 election. Reformists in the camp of President Mohammed Khatami said the council had singled out virtually all the president's supporters to minimize his influence in the legislature. The board said it had rejected the candidates for reasons ranging from suspected ties to a violent opposition group to un-Islamic behavior like drinking alcohol. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: National Briefing/ROCKIES: COLORADO: GUN CONTROL'S COATTAILS
description: A ballot initiative in Colorado that would require background checks for those who buy guns from unlicensed dealers has such strong support that at least one Democrat is hoping to ride its coattails to victory. The Democrat, Ken Toltz, is challenging Representative Tom Tancredo, a conservative Republican, in the Sixth District, which includes Columbine High School, where 15 people died in a shooting rampage two years ago. Guns have been a big issue in the race, which remains tight. Mr. Tancredo opposes new gun control measures, but Mr. Toltz, a businessman making his first run for office, favors them and is counting on the ballot measure to swing support his way. Mr. Tancredo holds a slight lead in the polls.

title: Metro Business Briefing; INTERNET JOB CUTS
description: Harris Interactive Inc., an Internet market research firm based in Rochester, dismissed about 70 workers, or 12 percent of its work force, as its fiscal third-quarter loss widened because of the slowing economy in the United States. Besides the layoffs, Harris also said it was consolidating office space, reducing database development costs and scaling back telephone-center operations as part of a cost-cutting program expected to save the company about $4.5 million a year. A number of Harris's major clients held off on research commitments as the economy slowed, Gordon Black, the chief executive, said in a statement.

Dearly loved father of Joanna Lewis Cole, and father-in-law of Jonathan R. Cole. Adored and adoring grandfather of Daniel L. Cole and Susanna (Nonnie) D.L. Cole. Born in New York City, he was graduated from Lehigh University and the Law School of Columbia University. A Life Master of the American Contract Bridge League, he was also a seventyyear member of the 63rd Street YMCA. Memorial contributions may be made to the Law School of Columbia University or to the Cabrini Hospice Center of New York City. A gathering in memory of George will be held at The Lotos Club, 5 East 66th Street, on Monday, May 14, at 2 PM.

title: World Business Briefing/Asia: South Korea: Prices Rise
description: Consumer prices rose 5.3 percent in April from April 2000, the biggest monthly increase in 29 months, the finance ministry said. At the same time, the consumer price index for April was 0.6 percent higher than in March, three times the rise government economists had forecast. The finance ministry cited rising food prices and a 4.5 percent increase in petroleum prices as major factors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Compromise Is Reached on Budget Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  Republican negotiators from Congress and the White House agreed today on a compromise budget plan that would allow $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years. It is less than what President Bush proposed but still by far the largest tax reduction in the last 20 years.

description: A few weeks ago, a federal judge walked through the doors of the Morgan County Jail in this tidy riverfront city and observed firsthand what happens when 256 inmates are crammed into a jail built for 96.

description: WASHINGTON, May 1 — F.B.I. Director Louis J. Freeh said today that he would resign in June, two years short of completing his term, after a tenure in which he expanded the Federal Bureau of Investigation's reach around the world, but warred continuously with Bill Clinton, the president who appointed him in 1993.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BANK FOR SMALL BUSINESSES
description: Signature Bank, a new financial institution that seeks to provide personalized services to small-business owners and others with about $250,000 in assets, opened in New York yesterday, with four branches in Midtown Manhattan, one near Wall Street and one on Court Street in Brooklyn. The bank, a subsidiary of Bank Hapoalim of Israel, will handle its customers' personal and business banking and brokerage needs, said Joseph DePaolo, the president and chief executive. ''We're not going after the Rockefeller family's business,'' Mr. DePaolo said. ''Our customer is the person who's built up his business over the years.''

title: One Awful Night in Thanh Phong
description: Senator Bob Kerrey's hands trembled slightly as he began to read six pages of documents that had just been handed to him. It was late 1998; the papers were nearly 30 years old. On the face of it, they were routine "after action" combat reports of the sort filed by the thousands during the Vietnam War. But Kerrey knew the pages held a personal secret -- of an event so traumatic that he says it once prompted fleeting thoughts of suicide.

title: National Briefing/SOUTH: LOUISIANA: MAYOR TRIES TO OVERTURN TERM LIMITS
description: Mayor Marc H. Morial of New Orleans says he has collected enough signatures to hold a referendum on amending the city charter to allow him to run for a third term. Mr. Morial needed 10,000 signatures and claimed in a statement released yesterday to have collected more than 11,000. If he succeeds in the referendum later this year, he will be able to run next year. Kevin Sack (NYT)

description: In recent years, a product known as a nasal dilator has become popular among professional and recreational athletes who believe that by improving their breathing, they will improve their performance.

title: World Briefing/EUROPE: ITALY: PREMIER SUPPORTS HUNGER STRIKER
description: As doctors expressed concern for the health of Emma Bonino, a leader of the small Radical Party who went on a hunger strike on Friday to protest insufficient news coverage of her party's top issues, Prime Minister Giuliano Amato asked TV networks to give more coverage to the party, which is anti-Vatican and argues that the abortion pill should be legal. Ms. Bonino, a former European Union human rights commissioner, has lost 7 pounds, 6 percent of her former weight of about 116 pounds. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing/E-Commerce: Stamps.Com Acquires E-Stamp Rights
description: Stamps.com has acquired patents and other intellectual property rights from E-Stamp, including the E-Stamp name and Internet domain. Financial terms were not disclosed. In a news release yesterday, Stamps.com said the portfolio of 31 patents and trademarks largely related to Internet-based postage printing and management. E-Stamp.com said in November that it would exit the Internet-based postage industry to focus on shipping and logistics.

The map had been prepared for an article a day earlier about the oldest city in the Americas, in Caral, Peru, close to Lima. In copies printed later, the map correctly showed the missionaries' town, Iquitos.

description: Explorations by British sea voyagers from the 17th to the 19th centuries produced some of the most important discoveries in the history of scientific exploration and transformed ideas about the biological diversity of the world. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBACH, RT. REV. MONSIGNOR JOSEPH F.
description: MARBACH-Rt. Rev. Monsignor Joseph F. Age 83 died April 28th at his home in West Palm Beach, FL. He was a graduate of Regis High School and Holy Cross College and was ordained in 1943. Msgr. Marbach received his doctorate in Canon Law and served for a few years on the Church Court in New York. He was then made Vicar General to Cardinal Spellman as Chancellor of the Military Ordinariate in charge of all Catholic chaplains in the U.S. Armed Forces around the world and served for over 30 years until his retirement in 1993. Msgr. Marbach is survived by his brothers, the Hon. John, Dr. Bernard, Jerome, Mrs. Anthony (Mary) Marano. He is predeceased by his brothers Robert, Francis and Lt. Paul J. Marbach. Visiting hours Tuesday (May1) 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains. title: Lemony Snicket Says, 'Don't Read My Books!'
description: Who is this mysterious and unlikely sounding Lemony Snicket, creator of the best-selling books called "A Series of Unfortunate Events," and what has kept him from showing up at his own scheduled author appearance? What does he look like and where, exactly, is he from? (His author photo, which changes from book to book, is always a blurry shot taken from the back, in which he is walking away from the camera, or staring out a window or down at a book.) And why are the wildly tongue-in-cheek, neo-gothic stories he spins about the miserable lives of the terrorized but resourceful Baudelaire orphans -- 14-year-old Violet, who is a whiz at inventing things; her bookwormish brother, Klaus; and baby Sunny -- always dedicated to the late but still longed-for Beatrice? (From "The Ersatz Elevator": "For Beatrice -- When we met, my life began. Soon afterward, yours ended.")

title: Barry Smith, Greenwich, Conn., April 4, 2001
description: his couple bought the property, but they weren't thrilled with the house, so they wanted to tear it down to build a new, bigger house. They said the bedrooms were a little small and there wasn't a lot of closet space. Only in Greenwich does someone buy a house for a million just to smash it. I don't know what these people are thinking. You should have seen the hardwood floors inside! I would have loved to live in that house. The house I own would fit inside it. I've been doing this for about 10 years, a couple times a month in the summertime. It's good because it's work for everybody including me. And after all, it's the homeowner's choice. But sometimes I wonder. If my boss tells me we are taking a house down, I go by and look first. It's got all the landscaping, it's beautiful and it's just going down. You feel a little bit bad about it. But in another way, it's fun, a lot of fun. Ask any kid why."

title: National Briefing  South: Arkansas: A Fight Over Land For Library
description: Eugene Pfeifer III, a Little Rock property owner, asked the State Supreme Court to prohibit the city from turning over his land to a foundation that is building former President Bill Clinton's presidential library. The city offered $400,000 for Mr. Pfeifer's 2.9 acres, which it plans to acquire by eminent domain along with 25 other acres for the library site near downtown. Mr. Pfeifer argues that the library is not a legitimate public purpose in which the city should be involved, and said a public referendum should have been held. A lower court ruled against him last year and library officials say the selection of Little Rock was contingent upon the city paying for the land. David Firestone (NYT)

title: MINDARROW, A SOFTWARE CONCERN, RESUMES TRADING
description: MindArrow, a California software company, resumed stock trading yesterday, nearly three months after it was halted when the company said that many of its shares had been counterfeited. Shares fell $2.65, to $1.85. ''With the events that happened, I'm not surprised there would be some selling,'' said Michael R. Friedl, the company's chief financial officer. Trading in the company's stock was halted on Feb. 5 after the company discovered that its former transfer agent, which subsequently went out of business, had issued more than one million fraudulent shares. The company, based in Aliso Viejo, Calif., provides software to deliver and track multimedia communications through e-mail.

title: Reckonings; Dodging the Bullet
description: Things are getting worse more slowly -- let's celebrate! Any score less than 50 indicates that the managers surveyed see deteriorating conditions, and the index for April was only 43.2. But the index was up slightly from March -- as I said, things are getting worse more slowly -- and as the day went by investors seem to have concluded that this was good news.

The United States Committee on Foreign Investment, which considers national security issues when foreign companies buy into the American market, has reviewed the deal and will not take further action, the companies said. The Federal Communications Commission approved the $34 million purchase of VoiceStream last week, saying the combined companies would benefit the public by providing better service.

title: World Business Briefing  Asia: Singapore: Paper Concern Delinquent
description: A unit of the Asia Pulp and Paper Company missed an April 30 interest payment on $500 million in convertible notes, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said. The failure of the unit, APP Finance (VII) Mauritius Ltd., to make the $8.8 million payment prompted S.& P. to cut its rating on the notes to D, or default. The notes are guaranteed by Asia Pulp, which stopped repaying its $12.2 billion of debt in March. The parent company, the largest pulp and paper company in Asia outside Japan, is trying to reschedule its debts, according to its creditors.

description: American Appliance, a chain of home appliance stores based in Pennsauken, N.J., that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Friday, is not likely to reopen for business, a lawyer for the company said. The company filed for bankruptcy protection after closing its 24 stores in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware. The lawyer, Neal D. Colton, said the stores may hold going-out-of-business sales. The company has not determined what will happen to orders placed but not delivered, Mr. Colton said.
