title: Metro Business Briefing  Layoffs At Vindigo
description: Vindigo, a wireless-technology company based in New York, said yesterday that it had laid off some employees because of its failure to meet revenue projections, which it attributed to the economic slowdown in the technology sector. Vindigo is a privately held company backed by General Atlantic Partners and Flatiron Partners. The company is best known for its free Vindigo software, which allows users to find restaurants, stores and entertainment in 20 major cities. Jason Devitt, the chief executive and a founder of Vindigo, said that the job reductions will not mean the elimination of any services. Mr. Devitt, who declined to reveal the number of jobs being eliminated, called the layoffs ''unfortunate'' but necessary because of the slowdown. ''I don't know any company that has not been affected by this,'' he said. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: National Briefing  New England: Maine: No Deposit On Cigarette Butts
description: Maine, one of the first states to require deposits on bottles, decided against becoming the only state to do the same with cigarette butts. Fearing that smokers would drive to neighboring states to buy cigarettes, the House voted 107 to 29 against legislation that would have offered a 5-cent return for every cigarette butt, similar to the way beverage cans and bottles are redeemed. Representative Joseph Brooks, the Democratic sponsor of the bill, had said it would bring in millions of dollars in revenue for the state, as well as clean up business areas and shorelines. title: Metro Briefing  New Jersey: Toms River: Tigers Can Stay
description: A judge has denied a state request for an emergency order to seize the two dozen Bengal tigers owned by Joan Byron-Marasek of Jackson Township. The State Division of Fish and Wildlife sought to close Ms. Byron-Marasek's Tigers Only Preservation Society and move the animals to Texas when she failed to meet state standards for keeping the cats. But Judge Eugene Serpentelli of State Superior Court said he was concerned that the tigers might be harmed if moved. He ruled on Monday that the animals could remain in Ms. Byron-Marasek's custody while an appeals court considered the question of whether the state had the authority to shut down her preserve. title: Virtual Reality and Fine Wine
description: WHEN Vinopolis: City of Wine opened in July 1999, it had the makings of a promising and profitable museum, including a stunningly refurbished Victorian building on London's up-and-coming South Bank, home of the new Tate Modern museum and the giant London Eye Ferris wheel. But within a few months it became clear that something was missing: visitors. Consultants had predicted a first-year attendance of 460,000. Instead, only 320,000 people showed up, and just 120,000 of them went on the much-vaunted multimedia virtual tour of the world's wine regions - billed as the main event in the 100,000-square-foot museum. Major losses in its first year did little to cheer the 550 impatient shareholders who had put up $39 million. Duncan Vaughan-Arbuckle, the founder and president of Vinopolis, said the museum's problems have been part marketing misfire, part misunderstanding by industry insiders. ''Nobody knows what we are, or who we are for, and our marketing campaigns have not helped,'' he said. ''People saw our first campaign, with the tag line 'Taste. Explore. Enjoy,' and thought we were elitist.'' In truth, Vinopolis is clearly designed to entertain the masses. In addition to a lively audio guide, there are atmospheric videos about winemaking around the world; olfactory kiosks that teach visitors to use their nose to tell corked from moldy, and chardonnay from chenin blanc; a hair-raising virtual ride through the Chianti region of Italy; and of course, plenty of wine to sniff, swirl, sip, spit or swallow. Indeed, Vinopolis may be one of the few museums where visitors grow merrier as they walk through: the $16 admission includes five glasses of wine. Happily, thanks to improved pedestrian access and the new Jubilee Line subway station nearby, there is no need to designate a driver. Vinopolis, 1 Bank End, London SE1. (011) 44-207-940-8300; www.vinopolis.co.uk.

description: KLEIN-Morton. The faculty and staff of the Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science of Columbia University deeply mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Morton Klein. Professor Klein was one of the first scholars to apply the analytical methods of operations research to industrial engineering. He was the driving force behind the development of the field of operations research and the creation of the Department of Industrial Engineering and Operations Research at Columbia, where he taught for forty-five years. He was extraordinarily devoted to his Department and the thousands of students whose lives he touched during his long career. His legacy at Columbia will be long lasting. description: ESPIONAGE is a serious, even deadly business, but that does not mean it cannot be fun -- at least from Hollywood's point of view. After all, spies had access to all those great gadgets, gizmos and decoder rings that made the cold war so cool.

description: LEFKOWITZ-Charles S. Loving husband of Dr. Ruth Samson Lefkowitz, beloved father of Judith R. Marcus (Ivan) and Jeremy S. Lefkowitz (Judith), devoted grandfather of Yuval (Elizabeth), Magen, Sasson, and Ehud Marcus and Lisa and Joshua Lefkowitz. Adoring great grandfather of Talia and Nathaniel Marcus. Dear brother of Ann Linsey and Rubin Lefkowitz and the late Harry, Max, Ben and Rose. Funeral services, Wednesday, May 2, 2001 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street. Mount Vernon, New York at 1:45 PM.

title: Military Analysis: Grand Plan, Few Details
description: WASHINGTON, May 1  President Bush sketched out his vision of a brave new world today in which the United States is protected by a multifaceted antimissile shield, nuclear arsenals are slashed and Washington and Moscow work together.

title: World Briefing  Africa: Benin: Trafficking In Children
description: Thirteen passengers on a ship that had been suspected of carrying up to 250 child laborers were victims of child traffickers, according to the government and Unicef. Families reportedly received money for the children, who were to work in Gabon. A search for the ship last month ended with officials finding that most of its passengers were economic migrants from West Africa. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: To Unearth the Secrets of Moviemaking, Take the BMT
description: ASTORIA, Queens, seems separated from Hollywood by more than just the width of a continent.

title: Chefs Win Beard Awards
description: PATRICK O'CONNELL of the Inn at Little Washington in Washington, Va., was named the country's best chef by the James Beard Foundation at its annual awards ceremony in Manhattan on Monday night. Campanile in Los Angeles won the award for top restaurant.

title: Tastings; Cast Changes in Languedoc
description: FORGET fame. Forget status. For red wines that are both delicious and good values, look to Languedoc, the large, rapidly improving wine-growing region in the South of France that runs inland along the Mediterranean west of Provence. While more established areas draw the attention and drain the wallet, Languedoc is quietly producing a wealth of satisfying bottles, many for under $15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORRESTER, MICHAEL G.
description: FORRESTER-Michael G. On April 30, 2001. Beloved husband of Grace Maria (nee D'Ambrosio). Loving father of Michelle. Devoted son of Irene & the late Gerald. Loving brother of Susan, Stephen, Kathleen and Jerry. Devoted sonin-law of Armando and Ginger. Director of Public Finance Ratings for Standard & Poor's Corp at 55 Water St., New York City, NY, employed there for 21 years. Viewing Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 and 7-10PM, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Avenue, Wantagh, New York, 516-731-5550. Funeral Mass Friday, St. James RC Church, at 10 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGELMAN, SHIRLEY
description: SIEGELMAN-Shirley. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck. Mordecai Waxman, Rabbi George N. Abrahams, President

title: Museums
description: What is it like having the curator's job that everyone in the art world thinks he or she could do better? Deborah Solomon profiles Lawrence Rinder of the Whitney, who is quickly finding out.

title: Article 2001050291449578144 -- No Title
THE CHEF
description: IT is a great triumph for me if a dish I make is both delicious and beautiful. Most of my cooking has a rustic visual appeal but is not exactly poised for a photo shoot.

title: On Free Trade, Castro Sees U.S. Guile and Latin Dupes
description: Fidel Castro denounced the proposed Free Trade Agreement of the Americas today as a ploy by the United States to manipulate its allies politically and to dominate the hemisphere commercially.

title: National Briefing  South: Florida: Appointments Criticized
description: The sister and wife of two of Gov. Jeb Bush's top aides have been given jobs in the State Department of Education, and the governor is reacting strongly to criticism of the appointments. ''I don't get it,'' Mr. Bush said. ''What's the point?'' The education commissioner, Charlie Crist, a Bush ally who took office four months ago, hired Mary Laura Openshaw, the sister of Mr. Bush's campaign manager, Sally Bradshaw, for a $77,000-a-year job. Mr. Crist also hired Sara Struhs, the wife of the state's top environmental regulator, David Struhs, and sister of the White House chief of staff, Andrew H. Card, for a part-time job that pays $35,000 a year. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Joseph's 42 Saves One Short For Leafs
description: For the second straight game, the puck bounced past goaltender Curtis Joseph in overtime, the wrong way for the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Would-Be Entrepreneurs Shun Dot-Coms
description: Financial markets are fickle, and business school students are nothing if not attentive to markets. Last year, the students tried to persuade investors to buy into trendy, but ultimately doomed concepts like DesignAjewel.com. This year, they are pushing more mundane ideas like the Shrimp Factory.

title: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING  Telecommunications: Starbucks To Use Compaq Devices
description: In its effort to add the wireless Internet to its menu, the Starbucks Coffee Company announced a five-year, $100 million agreement with the Compaq Computer Corporation. Starbucks will equip its Seattle headquarters with Compaq computers, servers and storage systems, and make Compaq's hand-held computer, the iPaq, available for Starbucks customers to try the new high-speed wireless network in coffeehouses. The network, which Starbucks announced in January, uses a wireless technology called 802.11b. It will be available in coffeehouses in Seattle, San Francisco and Dallas this summer and in 70 percent of the company's North American stores within a year, Starbucks said. A spokeswoman said Starbucks would offer some content free, but might charge customers for more extensive use. Microsoft, through its online service, MSN, will create content and services intended for Starbucks customers. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing  Australia: Australia: Lamb Trade Dispute
description: The World Trade Organization rebuffed an appeal by the United States to an earlier ruling voiding its restrictions against imports of Australian and New Zealand lamb. A trade organization dispute panel found in December that tariffs imposed by the United States on lamb imports in 1999 violated free trade regulations. The Clinton administration had taken the action after the International Trade Commission found that the imports could harm American producers. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing  New York: Albany: Negligence Finding Upheld
description: A state administrative review board has upheld a finding that a New York neurosurgeon, Ehud Arbit, was grossly negligent in his care of a spinal surgery patient. Dr. Arbit, who was accused of operating on the wrong side of a patient's brain and botching other operations, was found culpable in only one case in January by the state's Office of Professional Medical Conduct, which ordered that he serve three years of probation. Dr. Arbit wanted the finding overturned, while the State Department of Health sought a harsher penalty. The board rejected both pleas. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENGUALID, RACHEL
description: BENGUALID-Rachel. The National Jewish Outreach Program (NJOP) mourns the passing of Rachel Bengualid, beloved mother of Henri Bengualid and grandmother of Dr. Victoria Bengualid (and Gabriel) Goldstein, and Marc (and Beth) Bengualid, distinguished supporters of NJOP, who have played a crucial role in NJOP's efforts to assure a vibrant future for American Jewry. Yehi Zichrah Baruch. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir

title: Coming to America With British Baggage
description: Mark Knopfler

title: Two Breeds of Survivor: Gulf Shrimp and Texas Shrimpers
description: FOR the better part of the last century, they billed this little port near Corpus Christi as ''the shrimp capital of Texas.'' As a matter of fact, it was one of the shrimp capitals of the United States, working flat-out to help satisfy the nation's ravenous appetite for its favorite shellfish.

title: Qantas to Absorb Competitor As Fare War Takes a Victim
description: A bruising airline fare war in Australia has had a major casualty: the insurgent airline that started it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Duke Energy Seeks Deal To End California Inquiries

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANT, S. JACK, ESQ.
description: BRANT-S. Jack, Esq. Quietly, after a long illness. Beloved husband, for 51 years, of Lorraine. Devoted father of Stacy. Fatherin-law of Marvin. A much respected attorney for 58 years. Service Thursday, May 3rd, 11AM at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: 2 Beat the Odds Before the Derby
description: When you own racehorses, you've got to brace for bad news. John Fort received his last spring when a veterinarian told him his prize 2-year-old colt was gravely ill and had withered to a life-threatening 500 pounds. In fact, his insurance company had offered to make good on a policy if the colt were euthanized.

title: Billy Mitchell, 74, Saxophonist Who Played in Top Jazz Bands
description: Billy Mitchell, a bebop tenor saxophone player who matured in the Detroit jazz scene of the 1950's and played in the bands of Woody Herman, Dizzy Gillespie and Count Basie, died on April 18 at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 74.

title: 'State of Rebellion' Declared After Siege at Manila Palace
description: President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a ''state of rebellion'' in the Philippine capital today and ordered the arrests of opposition leaders whom she accused of conspiring to topple her fledgling government.

title: BUSH SEEKS A MISSILE SHIELD ALONG WITH NUCLEAR CUTS; CALLS '72 TREATY OUTDATED
description: President Bush called today for sweeping changes in security strategy, including a new relationship with Russia, that would build an expansive missile defense system and cut ''to the lowest possible number'' the nuclear arsenals that both sides assembled in the cold war.

title: World Business Briefing  Europe: Britain: Phone Stake Talks
description: The Vodafone Group and British Telecommunications confirmed that they were discussing the possible acquisition by Vodafone of the British Telecom stake in Japan Telecom, and its J-Phone subsidiary. The companies said the discussions also included the purchase of British Telecom's stake in Airtel, a Spanish mobile phone company, by Vodafone, but cautioned that the talks might or might not lead to a deal. British Telecom has been trying to sell assets to reduce some 30 billion in debt used to finance the development of new services. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A President at Dinner

title: Faith-Based Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: Ups and Downs? A Place To Put It in Perspective
description: WHILE the questions nowadays are usually more sophisticated than the old standby ''How many people jumped to their deaths in the Great Crash of '29?,'' in these bearish times it is comforting to know that the Museum of American Financial History, just off Wall Street, has an answer: not many. (The economist John Kenneth Galbraith researched the matter and determined that there was no increase in the suicide rate that year.)

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A President at Dinner

title: Honor for Rapper Is Called Unlikely
description: A move to designate a Bronx street ''Big Pun Place'' to honor Christopher Rios, the rapper who died last year, does not have enough support in the City Council, one of the proposal's legislative sponsors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MODELL, MICHAEL
description: MODELL-Michael. The Board and staff of the Greater New York Chapter, Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America (CCFA), are devastated by the tragic and untimely loss of its beloved Board Member and friend, Michael S. Modell. Following in the tradition of his parents, CCFA's esteemed CoFounders and Board Members, Shelby and William D. Modell, Michael embraced the goals of the Foundation and, with fierce determination and skill, championed its cause to find a cure for Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. With passion and inspired leadership he served as a Trustee for over eighteen years-seven as Vice President of Fundraising. Taking over the reins from his parents in 1993, Michael and his wife Abby chaired the Chapter's Annual Dinner and Journal, the Foundation's most financially successful event. For the past three years Michael fought his illness valiantly and with great strength. He taught us all the meaning of dignity and extraordinary courage. We loved, admired and respected Michael and will forever miss his indomitable spirit and friendship. We extend our love and heartfelt sympathy to Michael's beloved family-wife Abby, children Ashley, Andrew and Alexander, parents Shelby and Bill, sister Leslie, brother Mitchell and sister-in-law Robin. May they derive comfort in the knowledge that they are in our hearts and prayers. Greater New York Chapter, CCFA Nancy Brown President Judy Saphir Chairwoman Joan Telley Executive Director Ed Munoz Director of Finance & Operations

title: Sales and Unease Ahead, Auction Houses Seek Buyers
description: With their sleek new headquarters, glossy catalogs and aggressive advertising campaigns, Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips appear to be pillars of strength and prosperity. But as their twice-yearly evening sales of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art begin in Manhattan next week, the mood within could best be described as jittery.

title: Con Ed Is Planning To Fire Up a Plant Known as a Polluter
description: Consolidated Edison plans to restart the most polluting power plant in New York City, a small, dormant generator in Brooklyn. State regulators, eager to increase the city's power supply, have tentatively agreed to let it resume operation without an environmental review.

title: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING  Telecommunications: Nextel Cuts Jobs As Loss Widens
description: Nextel Communications said yesterday that it would cut 800 jobs, or 5 percent of its United States work force, after its loss widened in the most recent quarter. The company, a wireless carrier focused mainly on the business market, said it lost $372 million, or 56 cents a share, in the first quarter, compared with a loss of $279 million, or 45 cents, a year earlier. Even though revenue in the quarter rose 48 percent, to $1.74 billion, Nextel lost more customers than expected during the quarter because of fierce price competition among wireless carriers. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: National Briefing  Northwest: Washington: Teachers Walk Off Job
description: Nearly 5,000 public-school teachers in Seattle and four other school districts staged a one-day walkout, hoping to pressure state lawmakers to expand state education spending. Teachers received automatic cost-of-living raises under an initiative passed by voters last fall, and voters also passed a measure to reduce class sizes. But the teachers say the budget that lawmakers are considering undermines both initiatives. Students across Seattle had the day off, with the time to be made up at end of the school year next month. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Seizing of Tigers Is Blocked
description: Ajudge in New Jersey has denied a state request for an emergency order to seize the two dozen Bengal tigers owned by a Jackson Township woman.

title: Water Main Break Disrupts Service Across 6 Counties
description: An overnight break here in a five-foot-wide water main serving a cluster of central New Jersey communities left up to a half-million people with low water pressure or no water at all this morning and prompted school closings in six counties, from Piscataway south to Princeton Junction.

title: All Praise The Chicken, A Delight To Both Eye And Mouth
description: Chicken is on a pedestal in more ways than one in ''The Artful Chicken'' by Linda Arnaud (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $29.95). There are mother hen milk-glass serving pieces, rooster-headed salt-and-pepper sets, chickens on weavings and rugs, ceramic plates, posters, folk art and Faberg eggs. The bird's role in history is explained, and illustrated with chickens on an ancient Greek vase and in a Roman fresco.

title: Grand Plan, Few Details
description: President Bush sketched out his vision of a brave new world today in which the United States is protected by a multifaceted antimissile shield, nuclear arsenals are slashed and Washington and Moscow work together.

title: Genome Feud Heats Up as Academic Team Accuses Commercial Rival of Faulty Work
description: The rivalry between the two teams that decoded the human genome has erupted again, with some academic biologists contending that Celera, their commercial rival, used a method that failed and in fact relied on the academic consortium's method to assemble its own version of the genome.

title: National Briefing  Midwest: Wisconsin: Former Governor Fined
description: State ethics officials fined Tommy Thompson, the Health and Human Services secretary, $3,000 for not reporting an investment he made while he was governor. The error was noticed after Mr. Thompson filed his federal financial disclosure statements. State law requires officials to disclose any investments over $5,000 or if they own at least a 10 percent interest in the company. Mr. Thompson invested $9,000 in the Riverwood 2000 Corporation, a land development project, in 1994 and another $40,000 in 1997. Mr. Thompson said that he owned less than 10 percent of the project in 1994 and that he did not know that state law required him to report the investment. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Tax-Cut Deal in Washington
description: President Bush savored the agreement yesterday for a $1.35 trillion tax cut over 11 years by declaring that it represented ''the most tax relief in a generation.'' But the tax cut was significantly smaller than his original package of $1.64 trillion and marked a yielding to political reality. In our view, a tax cut of $1.35 trillion is still excessive. It would use too much of the federal surplus and leave too little for domestic programs. But the $1.35 trillion package does not jeopardize federal solvency the way Mr. Bush's initial proposal did. Congress must now write legislation to distribute the tax relief more fairly.

title: Bush's Bipartisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Restarting the Nuclear Race
description: President Bush said yesterday that ''we must move beyond the constraints of the 30-year-old ABM treaty'' and establish defenses against nuclear missiles. His proposals deserve close analysis, especially with respect to their likely effectiveness and costs. They should also be subject to public debate, of which there has been stunningly little to date.

title: World Business Briefing  Americas: Peru: Consumer Prices Fall
description: Peru's consumer prices declined in April, surprising analysts, as steep drops in vegetable, fish and cooking-gas prices more than made up for rising transportation and education costs. Prices fell 0.4 percent in April, the National Statistics Institute said, after a 0.5 percent rise in March. Analysts had expected an increase of 0.4 percent. It was the first monthly deflation in Peru since October 1999, when consumer prices slipped 0.1 percent.

title: President to Name Panel On Social Security Plan
description: President Bush plans to set in motion his effort to overhaul Social Security on Wednesday by naming a commission heavily stocked with members of both parties who favor his proposal to create private investment accounts for all workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHLE, ROBERT VINTON
description: KAHLE-Robert Vinton and his wife, Annabella Schafer Kahle of Caracas, Venezuela died in a private plane accident Saturday, April 28, 2001 in Middletown, RI. They lived in Newport, RI and Caracas Venezuela. Robert was born in Tampico, Mexico on December 6, 1932. Second brother of three, Robert grew up in Mexico, Venezuela and Tulsa, OK. He graduated second in his engineering class at Cornell in 1955. He married Margaret Mary Lurton in 1955 and raised 2 children. After serving in the Air Force at Wright Patterson Air Force Base he joined Esso Research as an engineer. Working with the early computers of the 1950's he pioneered refinery optimization using Operations Research techniques. Decades after his father helped establish Esso's presence in Venezuela, Robert negotiated the reparations from the nationalization of the resulting Venezuelan oil industry. Robert went on to manage Esso's relationship with Venezuela. He married Annabella Schafer in 1983. They enjoyed living in Venezuela, and spending time in Newport, RI. Hilda Annabella Schafer Kahle was born in Caracas, Venezuela on August 9, 1942. Annabella was schooled in Spain, Barbados, and Venezuela in the arts, and at the New York University. Annabella, an internationally exhibited artist received the Venezuelan National Arts of Fire award for her work in ceramics. They found in each other and in Newport, RI what they dreamed of-a private plane, an active artist community, and the sea. Their compassion, understanding, love and generosity towards their families and their community will be greatly missed. Robert is survived by his mother Helen (Herr) Kahle formerly of Essex, CT. currently of Advance, N.C., a son Brewster Lurton Kahle of San Francisco, CA and a daughter Alison Lurton Kahle of Delaware, OH, two brothers, Loren Frederick Kahle of Austin, TX and Richard Allan Kahle of Arlington, TX. Annabella is survived by two daughters Carolina Rosenberg Agurto and Diana Rosenberg Diez both of Caracas, Venezuela, four brothers Herman Schafer, Alfonso Schafer, Johann Schafer and Hans Schafer, all of Caracas, Venezuela, and sister Astrid Schafer also of Caracas, Venezuela. A Memorial Service will be held Thursday, May 3 at 3:00PM in the home of Robert and Annabella Kahle, 3 Cherry Creek Place, Newport.

title: Moscow Asserts It Is Eager for Talks on Missile Shield
description: MOSCOW, May 2  Russia responded today to President Bush's call for the deployment of a missile defense shield, saying it was eager to begin a new strategic dialogue with the United States in a bid to find a common approach to new missile threats and further reduce nuclear arsenals.

title: Mr. Bush's Nuclear Blueprint
description: President Bush erased any lingering doubts yesterday about his determination to develop a missile defense system and to discard the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty. But in outlining his plans in a speech at the National Defense University, Mr. Bush signaled a willingness to approach these fateful steps with some caution and a recognition of the diplomatic and technological barriers that he faces in trying to overhaul longstanding principles about the management of nuclear weapons. Only by acting in that spirit can he possibly engineer the changes he favors. If his commitment to work with Washington's allies and with Russia proves evanescent, he could well start a dangerous and expensive new arms race.

title: Pentagon Says It Suspended Military Contacts With China
description: The Pentagon announced today that it was suspending military contacts and programs with China, following Beijing's failure to release a United States Navy surveillance plane that landed on Hainan island a month ago after colliding with a Chinese jet fighter.

title: World Briefing  Africa: Congo: Aid Workers Mark Killings
description: Aid groups in eastern Congo temporarily suspended their work yesterday and Monday to mark the killings of six workers from the International Committee of the Red Cross who were shot and hacked to death last week. The groups said only emergency operations would be carried out until today ''to express our solidarity with I.C.R.C., our outrage and our need to mourn.'' The six -- a Swiss nurse, a Colombian aid worker and four Congolese workers -- were ambushed north of the city of Bunia, which has been torn for two years by tribal conflict and political infighting. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: With Camby Due Back, Knicks Go for Clincher
description: Their reputation as dogged warriors who can summon strength under the most adverse circumstances is flattering, even heroic at times. But there is another label affixed to the Knicks, and it is not so complimentary: when they appear to be headed for smooth sailing, they find a way to crash.

title: No Longer Modest in Newark
description: IN 1923, John Cotton Dana reflected that Newark's ''modest general museum'' should not try to compete with ''America's greatest museums of art, history and science'' on the other banks of the Hudson River. In 2001, the director of the Newark Museum, Mary Sue Sweeney Price, brushes off the word ''modest'' as if an annoying fly.

title: Moving In: Munch, Serra And Hot Dogs and Fries
description: MUSEUMS are always looking to expand their holdings, whether it's to fill a hole in a current collection or begin a new one, or because an irresistible work is donated or even -- surprise, surprise -- for sale at a price the museum can afford.

title: Democrats Snub Albany Budget Panel Hearing, Calling It a Republican Stunt
description: The state budget impasse descended into farce today as Senate Republican leaders called for a conference committee hearing to iron out differences, knowing that their Democratic counterparts in the Assembly would not show up.

title: Now Showing: Something Dazzling
description: TAKE a deep breath,'' says the disembodied voice of Tom Hanks as the planetarium audience gapes at the projected stars overhead. ''No, I'm serious,'' Mr. Hanks continues. ''Really, everybody, do it. Every atom of oxygen you just inhaled was made deep inside a star.''

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Jails Ex-General

title: Spotlight on Black Design
description: ONE of the most famous seamstresses of the 19th century was Elizabeth Keckly, who saved money as a slave to free herself and her son, and then moved to Washington, where she became dressmaker (and confidante) to Mary Todd Lincoln.

title: Metro Business Briefing  Newhouse Re-elected to A.P.
description: The Associated Press's board of directors re-elected Donald E. Newhouse as chairman for a fifth consecutive one-year term on Monday. Mr. Newhouse is president of Advance Publications Inc., which owns Cond Nast Publications and, through the Newhouse Newspapers subsidiary, 26 daily newspapers, including The Staten Island Advance and The Star-Ledger of Newark. The board also re-elected Louis D. Boccardi as A.P.'s president and chief executive.

title: Circumscribed by the law, tobacco companies look for new ways to get their message across.
description: CIGARETTE companies, bound by the terms of the $206 billion agreement that they reached with 46 states in 1998, cannot market or sell their products to young people, nor can they sponsor events where there are significant numbers of teenagers in attendance. They are not supposed to use cartoon characters, like Joe Camel, in their ads anymore. They can't even use billboards, or ads on public transportation, or sell clothing with their logos, even to adults. And, of course, TV and radio have been out of the question for decades.

title: Inquiry Focuses on Scientist Employed by Prosecutors
description: Her testimony cut through the fog of doubt with the hard clarity of science. From 1980 to 1993, Joyce Gilchrist was involved in roughly 3,000 cases as an Oklahoma City police laboratory scientist, often helping prosecutors win convictions by identifying suspects with hair, blood or carpet fibers taken from crime scenes.

title: Folk Art In Vermont Gets a New Address
description: THE Shelburne Museum a complex of 38 historic houses on 45 acres on the shores of Lake Champlain -- has long been known as Vermont's Smithsonian for its distinguished collection of American folk art.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday with an article about demographic shifts since 1990 in the 100 largest cities mislabeled the figures in the column headed ''Decline 1990-2000,'' showing the change in non-Hispanic white populations. The figures denoted percentage points, not actual percentages.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: A Draft of History

title: Business Travel; The corporate jet business is booming, even as the airlines complain about a softening economy.
description: THREE weeks ago, Warren Buffett, Richard Santulli and a bunch of our senior management people, we visited seven cities in Europe in three days,'' Kevin Russell said yesterday afternoon, describing what for most of us would have been the Business Trip From the Black Lagoon.

title: More Women and Minorities Entering Ranks of Business Ownership
description: More women, blacks and Hispanics are choosing a workplace where they call the shots, according to results from a census of businesses. The number of businesses owned by women, blacks and Hispanics grew at a faster rate than that of all businesses in the mid-1990's, continuing a trend seen in previous years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MICHAEL
description: DAVIS - Michael. Of Atlantic Beach, NY. Died peacefully at the age of 91 on April 30 after a long illness. Devoted and loving husband of Lillian. Beloved father of Dr. Barbara (Robert) Rosenberg and Robin (Martin) Mevorach. Dearest grandfather of Shari (Steven) Brown; Alexandra (Douglas) Wald; Stacey (Jeffrey) Herman; Haley (Michael) Simon; and Billie (Scott) Chaleff. ''Papa, you cut the challah at all our weddings.'' Adored great grandfather of Matthew, Jordan, Lauren, Joshua, Robin, Emily and Joseph. Mike loved his family and he loved life... and he knew how to live it. He will be missed by all who had the good fortune to be touched by his smile. Services will be held on Wednesday, May 2 at 11:30AM at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., NY.

title: Auto Sales Were Down Last Month
description: Auto sales fell in April, providing the first important indicator of the economy's condition early in the second quarter and a sign that weakening consumer confidence is beginning to affect spending on high-price products.

title: States' Plans To Deregulate Get 2nd Look
description: Fearful of the blackouts and price spikes that have afflicted California, most other states expect to slow or even halt efforts to deregulate their electricity markets, according to a survey of utility regulators that is to be released late this week.

title: A Couple of Political Pros (and on the Same Side)
description: BLAME their obsession with politics (without it, horrors, they wouldn't be here), but there are no plants and, except for a stuffed white chicken on the mantel that clucks on command (a goofy him-to-her anniversary gift), no pets in the Greenwich Village duplex shared by Josh D. Isay and Cathie M. Levine. Pagers, yes. Pets, no. And dinner arrives courtesy of the ubiquitous white cardboard Chinese takeout box, a nondescript bottle of white wine, and plenty of Diet Coke (they're a caffeinated couple).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, HELEN
description: ADELMAN-Helen. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the passing of Helen Adelman, beloved mother of our esteemed member Stanley Adelman. Mr. Adelman is chair of the Data Processing Committee. Our deepest sympathies go to Stanley, his wife, Evelyn, and their sons, Eric, William, and Jason. May you be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING  Internet: Site for Teenagers Draws Fire
description: The Children's Advertising Review unit of the Council of Better Business Bureaus in New York said it had asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate a Web site aimed at teenagers operated by Goosehead.com in Studio City, Calif. The review unit said the site failed to comply with the federal Children's Online Privacy Protection Act as well as the unit's own interactive guidelines. The unit said Goosehead was not screening computer users for age or requiring parental notification and consent before personal information was collected. A telephone call seeking comment from Goosehead executives was not returned. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

title: Undoing Time's Ravages, but Gently
description: ON a cloudy spring morning, Mark Aronson sits with his back to the wall of windows in the conservation studio of the Yale University Art Gallery, rolling a homemade cotton-tipped swab. Propped on an easel in front of him is ''Love Bound by Maidens,'' a late- 15th-century Italian painting by Girolamo di Benvenuto that is worn and abraded in so many places that its beauty is all but obscured.

title: The Silent Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKERS, MATTHEW LOVE
description: AKERS-Matthew Love. April 30, 2001 in Water Mill, N.Y. Beloved friend of Phyllis Horton Obermeyer. Cherished father of Christopher and Geoffrey. Service Saint Anne's Episcopal Church, Bridgehampton, N.Y. May 5th, 11:30AM.

title: Midtown Elegance, One Floor Down
description: NEW YORK has noisy chefs and quiet chefs. The really noisy ones, like Mario Batali and Bobby Flay, add color to the dining scene. They come across well on television. They can cook, but they also know how to get the public excited about food. The press loves them.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Questions over the sale of a credit card operation cloud a deal to merge banks.
description: WHEN the Wachovia Corporation agreed to a $13 billion merger with the First Union Corporation on April 16, it threw into limbo a deal Wachovia had reached a week earlier to sell its credit card portfolio to the Bank One Corporation.

title: Inflation Creates a New Breed of Movers and Shakers
description: WITH only days before the opening of a group show, P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center had a 12-ton problem. The 25-foot swimming pool from Tuscany had arrived on schedule, but the outhouse from Rotterdam and the life-size ceramic elephant from Rome were held up at Port Elizabeth, N.J., because of a snowstorm.

title: Metro Business Briefing  Web Designer Seeks Protection
description: Worldwide Xceed Group, a Web design company based in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday and said that it had sold all the assets of its Arizona and Colorado offices. The filing came as company officials were fighting to prevent their stock from being delisted by the Nasdaq exchange. The filing was made under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, which allows a company to pay its creditors under a reorganization plan. Xceed started as a holding company with a medical-supplies and corporate travel business and turned into a Web design business in 1998. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing  New York: Manhattan: Battery Building Renovation
description: The New York Economic Development Corporation is seeking proposals to renovate the historic Battery Maritime Building at the foot of Whitehall Street. The 140,000-square-foot building, which has spectacular views of Manhattan and New York Harbor, will undergo $36 million in exterior and roof renovation work, to be completed in 2003, to make it more attractive to prospective developers.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose after the prime minister of Japan won record support in opinion polls, fueling optimism that his economic policies will be adopted. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.17 yen, down from 123.60.

title: John O'Brien, 66, Dies; Unraveled a Disease
description: Dr. John S. O'Brien, who identified the gene that causes Tay-Sachs disease and helped develop screening tests for the rare but fatal disorder among infants, died on Feb. 1 at his home in San Diego. He was 66.

title: Profit Rises 19% at P.& G. Despite a 3% Drop in Sales
description: Procter & Gamble reported quarterly earnings yesterday that beat Wall Street expectations, but sales declined and executives promised that they would do more to increase market share for P.& G.'s consumer brands.

title: Raptors Remain Collected for Game 4
description: There was no great pep rally at midcourt, no ultraintense scrimmage. Few of the Toronto Raptors even sounded off about possibly being eliminated in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs for the second straight season.

title: PEPSICO IS EXPECTED TO VOTE ON SUCCESSION PLAN
description: Acting two months earlier than expected, the board of Pepsico is expected to vote today on an accelerated succession plan for the company's departing chief executive. Roger Enrico, the chief executive who stripped Pepsico of its restaurants and its bottling business to concentrate on the beverages and snack foods that have revived the company's fortunes in recent years, has said for months that he will retire only after finishing the $13.4 billion purchase of Quaker Oats. The acquisition is not expected to be completed until the end of June. But, if the board approves it, the transition could happen as early as today at the company's annual shareholder meeting in Plano, Tex. Greg Winter

title: Corrections

He is Antonio Homem, not Michael. The article also misstated the maximum number of apartments. It is nine, not seven.

description: It costs more than $40,000 in public money for a mentally ill person to be homeless for a year in New York City, nearly as much as it costs for the same person to live in supportive housing, said a University of Pennsylvania study to be released today.

title: Driving Home
description: When Frank K. Spain began collecting classic cars in the mid-1970's, he had no long-term goals; he just liked them. ''I wound up haphazardly with about 20 to 25 cars early on,'' he said. ''Then I decided that I needed some direction.''

title: A Singer From the Prairie Wows the Germans
description: Based on Willa Cather's appealing tale of a prairie girl who becomes an opera star, ''The Song of the Lark'' chugs along like the Little Engine That Couldn't. Shaped by Alison Elliott's charming performance as Thea Kronborg, whose ambition is too big for her hometown of Moonstone, the film is punctuated by lovely moments. But whenever it seems about to reach a higher level, it slides back into sincere, prettily photographed blandness. The third installment of ''Masterpiece Theater's American Collection,'' this unadventurous PBS work brings the series's spotty first year to a close.

title: Mrs. Rudolf Hess's Jewish Gardener
description: Toward the conclusion of ''The Gardens of Frau Hess,'' as distant explosions herald the end of the Third Reich and the future seems to hold the prospect of coexistence for a aristocratic German and her Jewish gardener, she warns him, ''Try not to forget whose house this is.''

title: Roasted Mushrooms, Disguised as Ravioli
description: The porcini ravioli from Signor Ravioli, the pasta company owned by the Serafina restaurants, could seem less than a bargain at $10 a pound, but they may be the most delicious in the city. The flavor is so intense that it suggests truffles, and the filling, made from freshly roasted mushrooms, has real texture.

title: '61*' Produces 9.7 Rating on HBO
description: 61*,Billy Crystal's movie about the 1961 home run race between Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, generated a 9.7 Nielsen cable rating last Saturday night on HBO, which equals about 3.2 million households.

title: New Report Cites Concerns Over City Foster Care
description: Though the number of foster children in New York has declined by 24 percent since 1996, credible reports of maltreatment in foster care more than doubled during that period, according to a report released yesterday by the public advocate's office.

title: Roman Treasures of Spain
description: D. Tours Travel, in Larchmont, N.Y., is discounting $400 a person from the price of its 13-night Roman Treasures of Spain tour, June 3 to 16. Led by Prof. Robert Knapp of the University of California-Berkeley, a leading expert on Roman Spain, it stops at Roman antiquities as well as Madrid, Granada, Seville and Barcelona. With the discount, it is $2,945 a person. That includes all hotels and breakfasts, eight lunches and eight dinners, all ground transport and sightseeing, a Flamenco show and three presentations on Roman sites. Information: (914) 833-9411 or www.dtourstravel.com .

title: Toward a Global AIDS Fund
description: The public attention given in recent months to Africa's AIDS crisis has not been matched with money. Last year the world spent about $1 billion on AIDS in developing countries -- a sum that will not even buy adequate prevention campaigns, much less health infrastructure, care for AIDS orphans and necessary medicines for the sick. But in a series of international meetings over the next few weeks, world leaders will be turning their attention to financing these urgent programs. The speech last week by Secretary General Kofi Annan of the United Nations at the African AIDS conference in Nigeria lays out a solid basis for a global attack on AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria.

title: A Clinic Just as Busy As the Runways; 40,000 J.F.K. Medical Visits a Year
description: It is remarkable, really, the number of bones, tendons and ligaments that endure a smashing each week at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Metro Briefing  New Jersey: Wildwood Crest: Beach Off Limits To Humans
description: For the second consecutive year, federal wildlife officials will close a stretch of beach that serves as a nesting ground for the endangered piping plover, a small shore bird whose numbers along the East Coast have declined to 1,400 pairs. Two-Mile Beach in the Cape May National Wildlife Refuge will be off limits to fishermen, swimmers and sunbathers until Sept. 30. In addition to one piping plover nest, researchers with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service counted 6,000 shore birds on Two-Mile Beach one day last summer. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: World Briefing  Europe: Belarus: Economic Deal With Iraq
description: United largely by their anti-American leanings, Belarus and Iraq sought to broaden their ties by signing an economic cooperation pact. Belarus's deputy prime minister, Vladimir Zametalin, who signed the accord in Baghdad, said Belarus's goal is to strengthen links with Iraq in all fields ''despite the efforts of certain countries to block this cooperation.'' Among the first fruits of the pact, said Iraq's official news agency, may be regular air service between Minsk and Saddam International Airport in Baghdad. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING  Hardware: Micron Electronics Dumps Pc Unit
description: After trying but failing to sell its $1-billion-a-year PC sales unit to focus on its Web site operating business, Micron Electronics said that the Gores Technology Group would acquire the assets and liabilities of the money-losing unit, Micron PC. Micron Electronics will contribute $70 million to Gores toward working capital and could share in the profit if Gores sells Micron PC within three years. In its second-quarter earnings, released March 23, Micron reported the PC business as a discontinued operation, accounting for an estimated loss of $147 million. The privately held Los Angeles-based Gores specializes in acquiring technology-related business and selling them at a profit. ''For the first six months, we'll try to focus on operations, restructuring, and getting it stabilized quickly,'' said Alec Gores, the Gores chairman.

description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Chives Just Cry Out For a Buzz Cut
description: ANY time but now, chives are wallflowers in the herb garden, waiting around for the right baked potato. Cooks ignore them except as a flash of green for a garnish; recipe indexes skip directly from chili to chocolate. Even produce markets put more stock in assertive herbs like rosemary, basil and dill.

title: Major Address on Missiles Buoys Republicans, but Fails to Win Over Bush's Opponents
description: President Bush's pledge today that he will consult with allies as he moves forward with missile defense did not quiet many detractors. They said they feared that the president had already made up his mind to scrap the Antiballistic Missile Treaty, alter the global strategic balance and develop costly and unproven military technology.

title: The Good Times (Make That Not-So-Bad Times) Still Roll
description: IT remains to be seen how long the downturn in the economy will last, but museum directors seem to be prepared for the worst. Big donors have deep pockets, major art institutions say, and tend to keep giving regardless of swings in the market. Yet a recession mentality inevitably infects charitable giving.

title: Shocking! Amazing! Sensational!
description: HERE'S the deal. You come to the American Dime Museum in Baltimore, just north of downtown -- a remarkable collection of sideshow and circus arcana -- sure that you cannot be ''humbugged.'' But by the time the proprietors, Dick Horne and James Taylor, are through, your perspective on what is real, or not, is up for grabs.

description: Seeking to recapture its fading leadership in the educational computer market, Apple Computer Inc. introduced a more compact and less expensive version of its iBook consumer-oriented portable computer today.

Plant half a dozen seeds half an inch deep, with about one-quarter inch between the seeds. Keep the soil constantly moist but not soggy.

title: Up on a Hill: The Getty Learns to Weather the Crowds
description: IT sits on its hillside in solitary splendor, not so much the Tuscan town of its architect's imagining as a Shangri-La and Starship Enterprise rolled into one. It may never be as emblematic as the Hollywood sign, and by virtue of its comparative isolation in a mountain pass, accessible only by a three-car tram or a brisk uphill walk of 15 minutes, it can never be a truly serendipitous destination in a city full of such.

title: World Briefing  Europe: The World: International Criminal Court Advances
description: Thirty nations have now ratified the treaty creating the International Criminal Court, half the 60 needed to make the court functional. The court would be the first permanent tribunal to handle cases of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity. The United States signed the treaty in the waning days of the Clinton administration but chances of ratification are slim since Bush administration officials say they will not send it to the Senate for action. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing  New York: Albany: Crime Figures' Appeal Is Rejected
description: The state's highest court yesterday rejected an appeal by two imprisoned members of the Colombo organized-crime family. The decision by the Court of Appeals means that James Besser, also known as James Zerilli, will continue to serve 15 years to life in prison, and that Jerry Ciauri will continue his sentence of 12 1/2 to 25 years. According to court records, Mr. Ciauri and Mr. Besser were involved in a failed conspiracy to kill Vic Orena, acting head of the Colombo family, in 1991.

title: An Undeclared Pataki Warns of Attacks in 2002 Campaign
description: Even before making any official declaration of whether he will run for a third term, Gov. George E. Pataki has told his supporters to expect an assault from the Democratic contenders in next year's gubernatorial race, predicting attack ads that distort his policy record.

description: Roger Clemens and the other Yankees will visit the White House on Friday, but unlike his teammates, he knows President Bush. Clemens knows his father better -- played horseshoes with him -- but sure, Clemens knows George W. Saw him last in Kennebunkport, Me., on the day a group of hardline Communists attempted a coup against Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: World Briefing  Asia: Pakistan: 'No Political Activity'
description: Thousands of security forces were deployed in Karachi to block a May Day rally against military rule and hundreds of people were arrested. The police used water tankers and buses to seal off streets leading to the park where the gathering was to take place. Gen. Pervez Musharraf, who took power in a coup in October 1999, said in Islamabad, ''Once we have said there will be no political activity, there will be no political activity.'' Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

description: The Senate voted to begin debate today on the first major education bill in years, but a number of conservatives in Congress complained that President Bush's signature campaign issue was being seized by Democrats and stripped of Republican ideas.

title: Ethnic Pride or Bug Fancy: Great Collections' Many Roots
description: DOROTHY DEMBY remembers when she first saw the ceremonial gazelle headdress in Dakar, Senegal, where she was working for the Peace Corps. It had two sweeping horns fashioned from a single piece of wood. "It attracted me," she said. She bought it.

description: Assisi, the medieval hill town that was badly damaged by a 1997 earthquake, is experiencing new tremors over a city ordinance to allow some automobile traffic in front of the Basilica of St. Francis of Assisi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTER, RITA
description: HUNTER-Rita. The Metropolitan Opera deeply mourns the death of the distinguished soprano Rita Hunter. She sang 33 performances during her five seasons with the company, appearing most notably as Bruennhilde in ''Die Walkuere'' and ''Goetterdaemmerung,'' ''Norma'', and ''Aida''. We extend our sincerest sympathies to her daughter, Mairwyn. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: No Cooperation On Missing People
description: Iraq reiterated its refusal to cooperate with the United Nations in determining the fate of about 600 Kuwaitis and citizens of other countries reported missing since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990. The United Nations appointed Yuli Vorontsov, a Russian diplomat, to discuss the issue with Iraq, but President Saddam Hussein has not permitted him to visit. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Central Asia Braces to Fight Islamic Rebels
description: In the foothills of the majestic Pamir Mountains and in the ageless villages of the Fergana Valley, spring brings warm days, new leaves in the apricot orchards and deep fears about another season of violence and tension.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Water Plan Is Delayed
description: The state put off until next year a decision on a plan that would have allowed billions of gallons of untreated, partly contaminated water to be injected into underground aquifers as a hedge against drought. The decision by Gov. Jeb Bush was a surprise turnaround on the initiative. Mr. Bush did not give up on the measure, but he said he was not ready to ask his allies in the Legislature to cast votes in favor of the plan, saying he wanted to protect them for now from taking a stand that might be ''grossly distorted'' by environmentalists. Douglas Jehl (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the arrest of a retired Israeli general suspected of having divulged state secrets misstated the date of the war of independence in which he fought. It was 1948, not 1947.

description: In a blow to conservatives, Democrats today succeeded in stripping the House education bill of a provision that would permit children in persistently failing public schools to use tax dollars to attend private schools.

title: INDICTMENT NAMES TWO EX-CHAIRMEN OF AUCTION HOUSES
description: A. Alfred Taubman, former chairman of Sotheby's, and Sir Anthony Tennant, his one-time counterpart at Christie's, were indicted yesterday on federal antitrust charges stemming from a conspiracy in which the two giant auction houses fixed commission fees charged to more than 130,000 customers over six years.

title: SODEXHO BUYS AMERICAN AFFILIATE FOR $1.08 BILLION
description: Sodexho Alliance of France said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the rest of its United States affiliate, Sodexho Marriott Services, to expand its catering business after it raised its offer to $1.08 billion. Sodexho Alliance, which now owns 48 percent of Sodexho Marriott, said it would pay $32 a share, an 8.5 percent premium to Tuesday's closing price and 18.5 percent more than the bid of $27, or $900 million, that it made in January. Shares of Sodexho Alliance fell as much as 5.4 percent.

title: Poetry and Lyrics From One Deep Well; Paul McCartney Publishes His First Book of Verse
description: Some years ago, Paul McCartney, famous musician and fledgling poet, took a deep breath and showed a selection of his poetic works in progress to his old friend Allen Ginsberg.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Life Insurer to Raise Funds
description: Friends Provident Life Office, a British insurer founded by the Quakers in 1832, said it planned to raise as much as 1.4 billion ($2 billion) when it sells shares to the public July 9. The chairman, David Newbigging, said the company would use the proceeds for expansion, which could include acquisitions of fund-management companies. According to Merrill Lynch, Friends Provident's financial adviser, the company would have had a market value of 3.7 billion to 4.2 billion on April 25, making it Britain's No. 6 insurer. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Delta Union's Governing Board Forwards Pact to Pilots
description: After five days of tense deliberations and a failed attempt to seek more concessions from management, the governing board of the union representing pilots at Delta Air Lines voted late yesterday to approve a tentative contract with the carrier.

title: Manila Moves Incite Talk of 'Dark Side of People Power'

description: Laid out on the kitchen table, the snapshots of 10-year-old Megan Cahanin make a grim collage. They are not of her sweet face, but of her bare behind. There are 12 in all, taken, her mother says, day by day as the doughnut-shaped bruises on each cheek faded from a mottled purple to a dirty gray.

title: Accounts

title: $1.7 Billion Deal Seen for Liberty Financial Units
description: Sun Life Financial Services of Canada Inc. has agreed to buy the Liberty Financial Companies' annuities business, the Keyport Life Insurance Company, as well as the Independent Financial Marketing Group, Liberty's distribution arm, for about $1.7 billion, executives close to the deal said late yesterday.

title: 5 Power Generators Sued in California
description: Opening another front in California's war against electricity generators, the lieutenant governor and a state assemblywoman sued five of the largest ones today, charging that they had illegally gouged the state by billions of dollars.

title: Internet Finds From Paris Flea Markets
description: Some American dealers are getting their Paris flea market finds on the Internet. Michael Bruno, a 37-year-old American in Paris, posts items he has found on his Web site, www.1stdibs .com, begun six months ago for the trade. ''Our goal is to present items as close as possible to the moment they hit the market,'' Mr. Bruno said. The 1930's table (left) by Alfred Porteneuve is $4,814, plus shipping; a 1960's sun gilt-wood mirror (right) is $825; a pair of 1940's armchairs attributed to Etienne Kohlmann (far right) is $3,438 on the Web. Anyone can check the home page for the 40 most recent finds. ''If they send us an e-mail request, we would be glad to help them find a decorator or recommend someone we work with,'' Mr. Bruno said.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: New Law On Bullying
description: Gov. Bill Owens signed legislation that requires all state school districts to carry out a program that prevents bullying. An outgrowth of the 1999 shootings at Columbine High School, where 15 people died, the law allows districts to develop their own programs but includes no penalties if they do not. The bill reached Mr. Owens despite vocal opposition among some state lawmakers who characterized it as little more than a feel-good measure. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Baffert Hopes Outside Is the Right Side
description: As expected, Point Given was installed as the overwhelming 9-5 favorite today for the 127th Kentucky Derby, and his stablemate, Congaree, was made the 5-1 second choice. By virtue of post position in the field of 17, the two horses will give their trainer, Bob Baffert, an inside and an outside chance to capture his third Derby in five years.

title: After-School Success Story
description: An ambitious effort to create new high-quality after-school programs in the New York City schools has made impressive strides in the three years since it began, but needs City Council action to expand. The effort was initiated by George Soros, the philanthropist, who pledged to contribute up to $25 million a year for five years if other public and private sources chipped in three dollars for every one of his.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 'Police State' Seen In Karachi
description: Hundreds of political workers remained in jail after security forces rounded up peaceful participants in a pro-democracy rally in Karachi. The military government's latest crackdown on dissent prompted the province's High Court Bar Association president, Rashid Rizvi, to say that the city had been turned into a ''police state.'' Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Before the Pictures Got Small
description: For film fans of a certain age, Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts pale alongside the likes of Greta Garbo, Douglas Fairbanks Sr., Charlie Chaplin, Marlene Dietrich and even Rin Tin Tin. The work of these actors and many other actors, directors and writers from the silent film era is celebrated at The Silents Majority (www.mdle.com/ClassicFilms).

title: Corrections
description: An editorial yesterday erred in saying that the 10-year tax cut President Bush agreed to would cost $1.25 billion. The cost would be $1.25 trillion.

The series, in its third year, offers excerpts from 11 new operas, performed by the company's singers, conductors and orchestra.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Volunteer Admits Rape
description: A volunteer for the Coalition for the Homeless pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he raped a homeless woman after she took him up on an offer to spend the night at his apartment, officials said. Willie Eaddy, 42, of Far Rockaway, faces six years in prison after admitting he raped the 43-year-old woman in November 1999, after meeting her at the coalition's Manhattan offices, said Betsy Herzog, a spokeswoman for the Queens district attorney's office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tobacco Concern Considers China
description: British American Tobacco said it might open a factory in China, which has 300 million smokers, or one-third of the world's total, after declining sales in the United States contributed to a drop in first-quarter profit. The company, the maker of Lucky Strike and Dunhill, said income before one-time items fell 23 percent, to 191 million ($274 million), compared with a restated 247 million a year earlier. B.A.T. and other cigarette makers are trying to expand into countries like China, where smoking is still on the rise. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: North Korea Will Extend Moratorium on Missile Tests
description: SEOUL, May 3  North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, promised high-ranking visiting European officials today that he would extend a moratorium on test-firing missiles until 2003, but he avoided any commitment to visit South Korea for a new summit meeting with President Kim Dae Jung, the European officials said.

Morel, who left to become chairman and global chief executive at Impiric, New York, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Sanctions Loom For Liberia
description: President Charles Taylor of Liberia faces the imposition of Security Council sanctions on Monday after a report from Secretary General Kofi Annan concluded that Mr. Taylor had not met the council's requirement to sever all ties with the rebel Revolutionary United Front in neighboring Sierra Leone. Mr. Taylor is widely believed to be at the center of the illegal trade in diamonds from Sierra Leone, which has fueled a brutal civil war. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Party Leader Still Won't Eat
description: Emma Bonino, the leader of the small Radical Party who has been on a hunger strike for five days to protest the lack of news coverage of her party's platform, said she would continue until ''actions follow words.'' Italy's prime minister and other politicians have urged Italian television to give in to her demands. Doctors in Milan, where Ms. Bonino is hospitalized, said they may have to intervene. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: French Smart-Card Maker Reports a Loss
description: The maker of smart cards, Gemplus of France, reported a first-quarter loss of 7 million euros, or $6.2 million, sending its share price plummeting 12 percent before recovering later in the day to close down 4 percent, at 4.68 euros. Gemplus, which had a profit of 14 million euros in the period last year, said it would take a second-quarter charge of 35 million euros, more than $30 million, to reorganize, including a production cutback and closing a factory in Germany, with 200 employees. Gemplus is the latest victim of the sharp fall in demand for cell phones; roughly half of its revenue comes from sales of chip-embedded cards for wireless handsets. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Highway Plan Presented
description: Gov. Gary Locke released a plan for financing highway and mass transportation improvements with a gas-tax increase of 7 cents per gallon, a new 2 percent excise tax on car sales and increases of up to 50 percent in some commercial vehicle fees. The 10-year, $17 billion plan is intended to address transportation woes, including traffic congestion in the Seattle area. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

description: The Laborers International Union of North America yesterday endorsed James E. McGreevey for governor. The union, which has about 20,000 members statewide, said it endorsed Mr. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate, for his emphasis on economic development and his proposal to upgrade the state's transportation infrastructure. title: Early Modernists Clean Up the Home
description: BUILT-IN furniture is nothing new. The Arts and Crafts movement in England, the Shakers in the United States and Japanese craftsmen have all looked for ways to streamline interiors. But the early, efficiency-minded Modernists tackled the woodwork of a home with the greatest zeal. ''Modernists had to have everything visually clean,'' said Donald Albrecht, a curator of the exhibition ''Russel Wright: Creating American Lifestyle,'' which opens in November at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum.

title: Technology Briefing | Health: Chips for Cancer Analysis
description: Scientists at Emory University will work with I.B.M. and NuTec Sciences, a privately held scientific computing company, to develop a system that would allow doctors to tailor drugs for cancer patients by quickly analyzing patients' genetic makeup. Such genetic analysis could spare patients from ineffective chemotherapy that would nonetheless cause severe side effects, said Jonathan W. Simons, director of the Winship Cancer Institute at Emory. Emory will use so-called gene chips to determine which of thousands of genes are turned on and off in a patient's tumor cells and try to predict responses to particular drugs based on that information, Dr. Simons said. While such an analysis would take months or years on a normal computer, NuTec's supercomputer will make it possible to get the answer in a day or so, he said.

title: KRAFT HOPES TO REAP $8.7 BILLION IN I.P.O.
description: Kraft Foods, the unit of the Philip Morris Companies that makes Oreo cookies and Oscar Mayer products, expects to raise as much as $8.7 billion in an initial public offering of stock, which would make it the second-largest such offering ever. Kraft, based in Northfield, Ill., plans to sell 280 million Class A common shares for $26 to $31 apiece, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The sale would raise $7.3 billion to $8.7 billion. Philip Morris, based in New York, would retain 49.5 percent of Kraft's publicly traded Class A shares, plus all outstanding Class B shares, to retain 97.7 percent of voting control, the filing said. The April 2000 offering by AT&T Wireless, which raised $10.26 billion, is the largest I.P.O. ever.

description: France's sixth-biggest bank by assets, Crdit Lyonnais, said profit in the first quarter dropped significantly compared with last year because of slowing growth in the United States and Europe. The chairman, Jean Peyrelevade, told a shareholder meeting that the first quarter of last year had been exceptionally strong thanks to booming global equity markets. The profit warning set off a 4 percent decline in share price. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Profit at Satellite Concern
description: PT Indonesian Satellite posted better-than-expected first-quarter earnings, but a gloomy short-term outlook held its share price down. The company said its profit rose 24 percent, to 538.5 billion rupiah ($48 million), for the three months to March 31, from 433.4 billion rupiah a year earlier. Revenue was up 2.7 percent, to 730 rupiah. Indosat's shares were unchanged, and analysts said the improved profit failed to support its stock because Indosat's bottom line was shored up largely by foreign exchange gains instead of operating profits.

One of the women, Farah Khosravi, a junior civil servant, said women should have the right to run since they have the right to vote. The last such attempt was rejected. But it just so happens that as a young umpire, Morrison worked the infamous Disco Night in Chicago, in 1979, when fans stormed the field and caused a forfeit.

He served pulpits in the New York area, Pennsylvania and Ottawa before assuming the position of community chaplain for the Jewish Chaplaincy Service of the Milwaukee Jewish Welfare Fund in 1962 until 1977, when he became a chaplain at VA Hospital in Milwaukee. We express our deepest condolences to his children, Shelley Bruch, Dr. David H. and Jonathan S. Lifschutz and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. title: Another Bomber Goes to Jail
description: In the spring of 1963, after months of demonstrations, the Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, a Birmingham, Ala., civil rights leader, said the city had reached ''an accord with its conscience'' with regard to desegregating downtown department stores. But on a deeper level, Birmingham's conscience and that of the nation have been haunted by an event that occurred a few months later, on Sept. 15. A bomb planted by members of the Ku Klux Klan at the 16th Street Baptist Church killed four black girls -- Denise McNair, Carole Robertson, Addie Mae Collins and Cynthia Wesley -- during Sunday services. After decades of delay, justice and conscience moved more closely into accord on Tuesday, when a Birmingham jury convicted Thomas Blanton Jr. of murdering those children.

title: House Panel Blocks Order Linking Money to Abortion
description: A House panel handed President Bush a defeat today, though possibly a short-lived one, when it voted to overturn an executive order that the president signed soon after taking office to restrict overseas groups from receiving federal financing if they perform or promote abortions.

title: Chains of Art
description: The artist Philippe Bradshaw, a member of the ''Brit Pack'' who lives in London, links together colored anodized aluminum chains to make curtains with images of masterpieces by artists like Warhol, Manet and Fragonard. Parisian interior designers have discovered his recent one-man show at the Thaddaeus Ropac Gallery in Paris. There the designer Chahan bought Bradshaw's Mondrian-patterned curtain (right and above). ''I plan to use it in a large room, facing the sea, opposite a mirrored wall so you will also see the curtain's reflection,'' Chahan said. The curtains arrive in New York this weekend at the Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street (Wooster Street), (212) 343-7300, through June 30. Prices range from $15,000 for a smaller piece to $50,000 for a room-size installation.

title: Communism, Meet Capitalism
description: Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect who designed Brasilia and worked with Le Corbusier on the United Nations Building in New York, said the headquarters he designed for the Communist Party in Paris was ''a piece of work which will constitute in this city, I am sure, an example of contemporary architecture, and even, permit me to say, a tourist attraction.'' In June 1980, as the building was being completed, he would never have imagined adding, ''party spot for hire to fashion victims.'' But there they were, 2,000 of them dancing to the electronic music of Daft Punk at a bash sponsored by the Italian fashion company Prada. Louis Vuitton and Dior have used the building as a backdrop for ad campaigns. Design aficionados make it a must when visiting Paris. Mr. Neimeyer, 94, who won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1988, is a true modernist, recognized for the sensuality of his curvaceous forms. His buildings are often composed inside and out of glass, cement, ceramics and steel. The main conference room with metal slates hanging vertically on the walls (above) is situated below ground level and has Niemeyer desks and chairs. The room's dome (left) is on the lawn in front of the curved six-story main building, sheathed in glass. The Communist Party Headquarters, on Place Colonel Fabien in the 18th Arrondissement, is open Monday through Friday from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.; tours by appointment by can be arranged by e-mail at vbenoit@pcf.fr or at 011-33.1.40.40.12.12.

State officials and lobbyists reached agreement on a bill after Gov. Tony Knowles, a Democrat, rejected an earlier version as a ''license to pollute.'' title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Warnings On Bears
description: After two summers in which bears have become ever more brazen, searching for food in Aspen, city officials have stepped up efforts to cite businesses and home owners who do not keep their garbage cans locked. After issuing no more than eight citations all of last year, Brian Flynn, the city's environmental ranger, said he had issued more than 50 so far this year. A third offense can bring the offender a maximum fine of $1,000 and 90 days in jail. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Pirro Seeks Death Penalty
description: Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, said yesterday that she would seek the death penalty against a Yonkers man accused of murdering his girlfriend and two of her children in September. It is the first capital punishment case in Westchester since the death penalty was reinstated in New York in 1995. Dennis Salvador Alvarez-Hernandez, 22, a construction worker with a history of domestic violence, was indicted on charges that he used a pen knife to repeatedly stab Patricia Torres and two of her children. In six previous first-degree murder cases, Ms. Pirro has sought life in prison without parole; a 1996 double-murder case in Eastchester is pending. David W. Chen (NYT)

The company reported $1.9 million in profits on more than $30.6 million in net revenues in the first quarter of 2001, compared with a loss of approximately $990,800 on net revenues of $8.3 million in the first quarter of 2000. Register earned 4 cents per share; analysts surveyed by Thompson/First Call had estimated that the company would earn only 1 cent per share in the first quarter. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker Profits
description: Serono, Europe's largest biotechnology company, posted a first-quarter profit of $72 million, up 37.2 percent, with sales up 13.5 percent. The company's strong start was driven by increased sales of its multiple sclerosis drug, Rebif. The Swiss company said the results of Rebif's head-to-head trials with the rival Avonex drug from Biogen Inc. would be announced May 8. Sales of its Gonal-F fertility drug also increased. The company took a $7.7 million charge to cover a voluntary recall of Crinone, an infertility treatment. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFBERG, WILLIAM EMANNUEL
description: HOFFBERG-William Emannuel, 77. Engineer, President and coowner of AIW-Alton Iron Works, Windsor, Connecticut, a specialty military parts manufacturing company originally founded by his father in New York in 1930. Mr. Hoffberg was born in The Bronx, New York in 1923, graduated Brooklyn Polytechnic in 1941 and was awarded a degree in mechanical engineering from Pratt Institute in 1947. He served in the Navy during both World War II and the Korean Conflict. He is survived by his wife of over fifty years, Rina R. Hoffberg, two sons, three grandsons, a sister and a brother. Services will be held on Thursday, May 3, 2001 at 12:30 PM, at Schwartz-Jeffer, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York with burial to follow at Mt. Zion Cemetery in Long Island City.

title: Millionaires in Space
description: Dennis Tito, the multimillionaire pension fund manager who is now circling the globe on the international space station, may have invented the most offensively elitist form of eco-tourism yet devised by earthlings. By paying a reported $20 million to hitch a ride with the cash-starved Russian space program, he has bulled his way onto the station over the objections of the other partner nations and is now realizing the dream of a lifetime while the professional astronauts aboard slow their work schedule to serve as baby sitters.
