title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: An End To Baptizing Jews
description: After a request by the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has promised to remove the names of more than 200 Jews, including Albert Einstein and Israel's first prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, from the church's genealogical records. The church lists names as a way to offer a choice, in after-life, of accepting or rejecting the Mormon religion. Church officials said that after a 1995 agreement with Jewish organizations, the names of several hundred thousand Holocaust victims had been removed from its genealogical database. But others remained. ''It's insulting,'' said Rabbi Marvin Hier of the Wiesenthal Center. ''What they're saying is that without baptism we won't have salvation.'' Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: These Demons Are Not Your Father's Devils
description: In an earlier era, even when winning the Stanley Cup, the Devils were as colorful as Lou Lamoriello's starched white shirts and solid dark suits. Watching their neutral-zone trap was like watching tractors plow farm fields. In interviews, the players would reveal only their names, positions and uniform numbers before entering the witness-protection sector of the dressing room. For hotels during the playoffs, their first choices were monasteries and minimum-security prisons.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Koch Endorses Vallone

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, MAX G.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Max G. Educator, at home on May 2, 2001, age 94. Dear husband of the late Sadie Rubinstein, father of Robert and Daniel, their wives Barbara and Janice, he also leaves six grandchildren and one great grandchild. Graduate of CCNY 1928 where he captained their basketball team under Nat Holman and was named to the college basketball Hall of Fame, he became Principal of Cooper Jr High in Harlem, and the first Principal of Riverdale Jr. High in the Bronx. He served as Assistant Superintendant of Schools in Queens until his retirement, at which time his friend and classmate Eugene Maleska created a NY Times crossword puzzle in his honor. With his wife Sadie, Max served many years as President of the New York City chapter of The City of Hope, to which contributions would be gratefully received. Funeral services May 3rd, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Metro Business Briefs
description: CALMING FEARS AFTER MERGER The head of the company that owns Electric Boat in Groton, Conn., took pains yesterday to reassure employees that a merger with Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. would not result in job losses, and could even lead to gains. Electric Boat's parent company, General Dynamics Corporation , announced the acquisition of Newport News last week. Electric Boat engineers are wrapping up design of the Virginia-class submarine, and instead of facing a layoff will probably help Newport News on the next class of aircraft carrier, said Nicholas Chabraja, chairman of General Dynamics. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: It's Conrad vs. Duchamp, With Plenty of Writhing
description: The choreographers chosen for ''France Moves'' by the festival's artistic director, Yorgos Loukos, range from the well known to experimentalists new to New York. One of the best known is Angelin Preljocaj. But Mr. Preljocaj is poorly served by ''Paysage Aprs la Bataille'' (''Landscape After the Battle''), performed by Ballet Preljocaj on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Prosecutor Says Sketches Link Suspect to Bombings
description: A federal prosecutor in Manhattan said yesterday that sketches of the American Embassy in Nairobi that the authorities found in the remote Kenyan home of a defendant in the embassy bombings trial clearly linked him to the planning of the attack, despite his denials of involvement.

Devoted grandfather of Sarah, Naomi, Allison, Bennjamin and Pamela Mishkin. Funeral service at 12 noon, May 3, 2001 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Doing a Guitar Solo With the Web as the Teacher
description: DURING a particularly hectic workday, Dee LaBorte likes nothing more than to take a break and pound on some drums. And she does just that, right in her home office in Coronada, Calif., where she keeps a conga. She logs onto Drumlesson.com, and with a few clicks, the room pulsates with the beats of a marcha rhythm, offering her a virtual playing partner.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I2 President Is Promoted
description: I2 Technologies, a maker of business-to-business software, said Gregory A. Brady, left, its president since 1994, had been named chief executive. He replaces Sanjiv Sidhu, i2's founder, who remains chairman. Mr. Brady, who worked for Oracle and J. D. Edwards, orchestrated i2's successful 1996 initial public offering and is credited with leading much of the company software effort. I2 has cut more than 600 jobs since it announced revamping plans a month ago. Its shares jumped $2.26, or 12.7 percent, to $20.03. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From dining in Paris to retiring in Australia, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: COMPANIES PLAN $1.7 BILLION GAS LINE TO SERVE CALIFORNIA
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners and the Calpine Corporation plan to build a $1.7 billion pipeline that could deliver natural gas to energy-short California as soon as 2003, the companies said yesterday. The line, which would require federal approval, would be able to move 750 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, and might eventually be expanded to move a billion cubic feet, the companies said. Calpine, a power plant developer and operator based in San Jose, Calif., has committed itself to ship 400 million cubic feet of gas a day on the line for 20 years, the companies said. The pipeline would begin in Northern New Mexico and end just east of San Francisco, the companies said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORENSON, DR. WAYNE R.
description: SORENSON-Dr. Wayne R. Age 74, of Mendham, New Jersey on May 1, 2001 at home. He was the developer of the commercial process for Nomex used in fire fighters' protective apparel, and for Kevlar used in bullet proof vests; as well as co-author of ''Preparative Methods of Polymer Chemistry''. He was the loving husband of Pat; father of the late Patricia Cox. Loving father of Dr. Joan Sorenson and Gail Blake & grandfather of five. Memories will be shared at Dangler Funeral Home, 600 Speedwell Avenue, Morris Plains, New Jersey 07950, on Friday, May 4th from 2-4 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages yesterday about the winner of the New York Public Library Helen Bernstein Book Award for Excellence in Journalism referred imprecisely to the publisher of the winning entry, ''Persian Mirrors: The Elusive Face of Iran,'' by Elaine Sciolino. It was the Free Press, a unit of Simon & Schuster, not the parent publisher.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Calming Fears After Merger
description: The head of the company that owns Electric Boat in Groton, Conn., took pains yesterday to reassure employees that a merger with Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. would not result in job losses, and could even lead to gains. Electric Boat's parent company, General Dynamics Corporation, announced the acquisition of Newport News last week. Electric Boat engineers are wrapping up design of the Virginia-class submarine, and instead of facing a layoff will probably help Newport News on the next class of aircraft carrier, said Nicholas Chabraja, chairman of General Dynamics. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNOFF, BERNARD
description: KRASNOFF - Bernard. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Loving father of Barbara and Neal. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 1:30 PM Friday, May 4th. Interment, Beth David Cemetery.

description: Imagine a basketball coach stripping off his suit and tie, pulling on a jersey and shorts, and stepping onto the court to run a few plays. Something akin to that happened today in the Assembly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENACH, HENRY
description: BENACH-Henry. Dear Henry-one of a kind. Former Chairman of the Board of Starrett Corporation. Your friends and associates at Starrett Corporation and HRH Construction will miss you-your sage advice, your extraordinary humanity, your caring and your great heart. Starrett Corporation HRH Construction

title: Judge Cancels The Firing Of an Officer In a Sex Case
description: A judge has overturned the Police Department's firing last year of an officer who was caught having sex with a prostitute in a women's restroom at the Manhattan district attorney's office.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF TAKES OVER AT PEPSICO
description: PepsiCo said yesterday that Steve Reinemund replaced Roger Enrico as chairman and chief executive, effective immediately. Mr. Reinemund's appointment was part of a succession plan announced last year after PepsiCo said it would buy the Quaker Oats Company. Mr. Enrico, 56, has become vice chairman, a position he will share with Quaker Oats' chief executive, Robert Morrison, once the purchase is completed. Mr. Reinemund, 53, had been president and chief operating officer of PepsiCo. PepsiCo, based in Purchase, N.Y., also raised its quarterly dividend to 14.5 cents a share from 14 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELTZ, DORIS M.
description: SELTZ-Doris M., 68. On May 1 in Worcester, MA. Widow of David Seltz. She is survived by her son David of Tyngsboro, MA, two daughters, Ann of Worcester, MA and Laura of Binghamton, NY; also her sister Barbara Silverstone of New York and two granddaughters. Services will be held Friday, 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell (the funeral chapel), 1076 Madison Avenue, corner of 81 St. Interment to follow at the Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to benefit the homeless.

title: Battered by the economy, Hook Media, an online agency, files for bankruptcy protection.
description: THE faltering advertising economy has claimed another victim. Hook Media Inc., a leading online agency, has filed for bankruptcy protection and is preparing to sell most of its assets to a division of Havas Advertising.

title: U.S. Agencies in California Will Be Energy Conscious
description: President Bush is planning to order all federal facilities in California to keep thermostats at 78 degrees and shut down escalators during electricity shortages this summer, part of a broader effort by the administration to show that it is serious about addressing the state's power crisis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Brothers Arrested In Drug Inquiry
description: The authorities announced conspiracy charges yesterday against two brothers suspected of leading the New York arm of one of the largest drug trafficking organizations in the country. Eight others tied to the ring, which law enforcement officials said used fruit trucks to smuggle thousands of pounds of marijuana, were also arrested by federal, state and city authorities working with the city's office of the special narcotics prosecutor. Officials said that the brothers, Alberto and Ruben Polanco, ran the organization for at least a decade before the authorities charged them. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Nasdaq Up for a 4th Day Amid Optimism on Technology
description: The Nasdaq composite index rose for a fourth day, reaching its highest close in nearly two months, as investors snapped up technology shares on optimism that the worst of the profit slowdown had passed.

title: Trinidad Likes Being A Middleweight
description: Felix Trinidad may be fighting for the first time as a middleweight when he faces the two-time World Boxing Association middleweight champion William Joppy on May 12, but Trinidad does not expect he will ever again enter a boxing ring at a lower weight class. The undefeated four-time world champion, who has fought primarily as a welterweight and a superwelterweight, said yesterday that he was comfortable fighting at the 160-pound middleweight limit.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Los Angeles: Con Artist Pleads Not Guilty
description: Kenneth Kimes, the con artist convicted last year with his mother of killing a Manhattan woman, pleaded not guilty yesterday to murder charges in the 1998 shooting death of David Kazdin, a friend and business associate. Mr. Kimes, 26, and his mother, Sante Kimes, who is also charged in Mr. Kazdin's death, are serving life sentences for the 1998 killing of Irene Silverman, 82. Mrs. Kimes is fighting extradition to Los Angeles, where she and her son could face the death penalty if convicted of murdering Mr. Kazdin, 64, whose body was found in a trash bin near Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Barry Smith, Greenwich, Conn., April 4, 2001
description: his couple bought the property, but they weren't thrilled with the house, so they wanted to tear it down to build a new, bigger house. They said the bedrooms were a little small and there wasn't a lot of closet space. Only in Greenwich does someone buy a house for a million just to smash it. I don't know what these people are thinking. You should have seen the hardwood floors inside! I would have loved to live in that house. The house I own would fit inside it. I've been doing this for about 10 years, a couple times a month in the summertime. It's good because it's work for everybody including me. And after all, it's the homeowner's choice. But sometimes I wonder. If my boss tells me we are taking a house down, I go by and look first. It's got all the landscaping, it's beautiful and it's just going down. You feel a little bit bad about it. But in another way, it's fun, a lot of fun. Ask any kid why."

title: Writers and Studios Take Negotiations to Next Level
description: Talks between Hollywood writers and production executives quietly slipped past Tuesday's midnight deadline until, about 3 a.m. today, weary negotiators decided it was time to take a break, get some sleep, consider the offers that had just been placed on the table and then resume talks at noon, which they did.

title: Florida Passes Electoral Reforms
description: TALLAHASSEE, Florida, May 3 - With only two days left in a hectic legislative session, the two chambers of the Florida legislature have hammered out a bill ending the use of punch-card ballots and introducing other reforms to the voting procedure.

title: Knoblauch Is a Fixture in Left
description: Chuck Knoblauch's defense in left field has improved rapidly in the eyes of Yankees Manager Joe Torre, who has told Knoblauch that he won't be replaced in the late innings anymore.

title: The News Is Good on Leiter
description: The Mets yesterday received what would normally be good news: Al Leiter's left elbow was pain free for the first time since his last start on April 20. But Leiter and the Mets were unsure when he would be ready to rejoin the rotation.

title: You've Got to Come Back a . . . You Know
description: There's nothing like precision tap-dancing to turn a New York audience into a lab full of case studies for Dr. Pavlov. Throw us a big bunch of twinkly youngsters doing the same noisy step at the same moment, and we're beating our flippers together like the seals at feeding time. It's a conditioned reflex as old as the first chorus line.

title: Creating a Sun Block For Young Boat Builders
description: BY the end of summer, when the sun beats down on Pier 84 on the Hudson River, there will be a way for the high school students using the pier as home port to get some relief: shade provided by a 50-by-70-foot polyvinyl tensile structure.

title: Blair Says Britain Is Near End of Foot-and-Mouth Fight
description: LONDON, May 3  Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that Britain was in the "home straight" of its race to contain an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease, prompting widespread forecasts that he would call a June general election early next week.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Students Protest Budget Cuts
description: Nearly 2,000 students marched on the Capitol in Raleigh to protest sharp budget cuts to the University of North Carolina. The Legislature, facing a steep drop in tax revenue, has told the university to expect a 7 percent cut, which could result in a loss of 700 faculty positions and an increase in class sizes as many courses are cut. Similar reductions are also likely at public colleges in several other Southern states. The students marched through downtown Raleigh and then sought out individual legislators to make their case for smaller cuts. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Dr. Morton Klass, 73, Anthropologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Morton Klass, an anthropologist and a writer who focused on the people of South Asia and their descendants in the West Indies, died Saturday at his home in Washington Heights in Manhattan. He was 73.

title: U.S. Fails to Secure Seat on U.N. Rights Commission
description: The United States was voted off the United Nations Human Rights Commission today, losing the seat that it has held since the commission's creation in 1947.

title: New Yorker Sets Record At Magazine Awards
description: The New Yorker magazine set a record and several lesser-known magazines staged an upset yesterday at the National Magazine Awards, which were handed out before about 1,400 editors and magazine executives at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: President's Party Defies Court
description: Defying a court order, President Frederick Chiluba's Movement for Multiparty Democracy expelled 23 senior party members, including the country's vice president, Christon Tembo. Mr. Chiluba, near the end of his second five-year term, is moving to sideline leaders opposed to his bid to change the Constitution to allow a third term. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Reassessing Mitterrand's Legacy : Of Monuments  and Monumental Errors
description: PARIS  Nearly 20 years ago Francois Mitterrand was elected president of France with a platform that, at least subliminally, promised to make France the Cool capital of the world. There was an explosion of cheering, honking and partying in the streets of Paris, particularly at the Place de la Bastille, that symbol of regicide. People power was the message.

title: One Awful Night in Thanh Phong
description: Senator Bob Kerrey's hands trembled slightly as he began to read six pages of documents that had just been handed to him. It was late 1998; the papers were nearly 30 years old. On the face of it, they were routine "after action" combat reports of the sort filed by the thousands during the Vietnam War. But Kerrey knew the pages held a personal secret -- of an event so traumatic that he says it once prompted fleeting thoughts of suicide.

title: Watson Might Miss United States Open
description: ''Saying that my time has passed,'' Tom Watson said he would probably miss next month's United States Open, ending a 29-year stretch of appearances.

title: Cigna Warns on Profits, and H.M.O. Stocks Take a Tumble
description: The Cigna Corporation, one of the strongest managed care companies, said yesterday that profits would be lower than expected this year, blaming weaker earnings from pension and retirement accounts that it manages for large employers. Analysts, however, were particularly concerned by an unexpected increase in Cigna's medical costs.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Semiconductor Sales Decline
description: A report issued yesterday by a semiconductor trade group confirmed what first-quarter earnings announcements by chip makers had already suggested: March sales were dismal. The Semiconductor Industry Association said worldwide chip sales declined 4.5 percent year on year, to $14.4 billion from $15.1 billion, and 7 percent sequentially, from $15.5 billion in February. Compared with March 2000, , sales fell 10.6 percent in the Americas, 10.4 percent in Asia-Pacific and 0.7 percent in Europe, but rose 7 percent in Japan. George Scalise, president of the association, echoing comments by industry executives, said he believed that chip sales would stabilize in the third quarter and turn up in the fourth. The Philadelphia semiconductor index, which has already taken the slumping sales largely into account, rose $4.21, to $670.65. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Con Edison Says Use of Old Boiler Will Not Increase Air Pollution at Brooklyn Plant
description: Consolidated Edison said yesterday that there would be no increase in air pollution from restarting a dormant power generator in Brooklyn, because it planned to reduce its use of four other units at the same plant.

title: CHEMICAL COMPANY TO LAY OFF UP TO 1,260 PEOPLE
description: The Rohm & Haas Company said yesterday that it would lay off as many as 1,260 employees to cut costs and make the company, which produces specialty chemicals, more competitive. Rohm & Haas, which makes additives for paints and owns Morton Salt, said the job cuts would save at least $200 million by the end of 2002. Some of the job reductions will be tied to plant closings in California and Mississippi, said a spokeswoman, Laura Hadden. The company, based in Philadelphia, which also makes chemicals used in electronics, has been hurt by declining sales as the economy has slowed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, MARY
description: TOBIN-Mary on May 2, 2001 after a short illness. Survived by daughter Jamie, sisters Patricia & Alma, brother Richard, nieces & nephews. Visiting May 4, 9-10AM at Church of St. Francis of Assisi, 135 W. 31 St; service immediately following. She will be greatly missed.

title: DEAL IS REACHED ON U.S. SPENDING
description: A day after agreeing to cut taxes by $1.35 trillion over the next 11 years, the White House and Congressional negotiators settled today on a spending increase for next year greater than what President Bush had sought but less than what most Democrats said was needed to pay for domestic programs and the military.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Texan Charged In Police Scam
description: Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn district attorney, announced a 22-count indictment yesterday against a Texas man accused of conning thousands of dollars from Brooklyn store owners by posing as a police officer collecting donations for missing and exploited children. The authorities said that David Garber, 53, above, of El Paso, preyed on Latino store owners in Bushwick for at least the past five years. He would face up to four years in prison if convicted. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Sony's New Organizer Plays a Different Tune
description: The battle for the coolest hand-held organizer heated up this week with the release of Sony Electronics' latest version of its Cli. The Cli PEG-N710C, $499.99, performs all the standard functions and makes room for future features and additional memory by way of a Memory Stick slot in its top. But it also packs new capabilities: it can play music files in both MP3 and Sony's own ATRAC3 audio format; it can also store and play back short digital video clips with sound and show digital photographs.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Board Joins Gramercy Suit
description: The Board of Education said yesterday that it would join a lawsuit charging the trustees of Gramercy Park with racial discrimination. The board plans to file a brief supporting a suit by a group of minority plaintiffs, teachers and a neighborhood resident charging that the trustees twice threatened to have black and Hispanic children visiting the private park on a school trip arrested. The trustees have denied the allegations. A statement from Ninfa Segarra, president of the Board of Education, said, ''As a parent and board member, I was offended by the alleged behavior of the park gatekeepers toward our children.'' Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPLEN, MARTHA
description: SHAPLEN-Martha. Of Manhattan died March 9, 2001, in Petaluma, CA. Mother of Peter, grandmother of Leigh, Robert and Joseph. Funeral at St. Francis De Sales, Manhattan, 1 P.M. Friday, May 4.

title: Plotless Balanchine And 4 Temperaments
description: No one at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night could accuse ballet of being frivolous. The New York City Ballet opened its spring season with a program that insisted upon the art's high seriousness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, LUCILLE RUTH
description: EISENBERG-Lucille Ruth. On May 2, 2000. Beloved wife for 61 years of Harold. Loving mother of Bob and Ardyth Eisenberg and Edward and Barbara Eisenberg. Devoted grandmother of Jennifer, Ben, Emily and Sally Eisenberg and Jill Trowbridge and greatgrandmother of Crystal Moutoussamy and James and Holly Trowbridge. Funeral arrangements will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Hypertension Research Fund, 161 Port Washington Avenue, Room 648, New York, New York 10032.

title: Tours of the British Isles
description: Couples can save $150 on 28 Trafalgar Tours escorted land packages through the British Isles from June 15 to Aug. 31. The discount applies to any First Class or CostSaver vacation that begins and ends in London, Dublin or Shannon, when booked in conjunction with Continental Airlines. Reservations and deposits must be made by May 31. The itineraries range from 8 to 26 days. An 11-day Britain and Ireland Highlights tour, for example, with stops in London, Stratford, York, Glasgow, Dublin, Tramore and Bath, starts at $1,585 a person, based on double occupancy. A nine-day Scottish Whirl itinerary, with stops in London, Glasgow, Fort William, Isle of Skye and Edinburgh, starts at $1,255 a person, double. Rates include air fare, accommodations, all breakfasts, many dinners, motorcoach travel and some admissions. The discount is subject to availability. Information: (800) 648-1638 or www.trafalgartours.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: New Zealand: Air Takeover Challenged
description: The Ansett unit of Air New Zealand Ltd. said it might compete with Qantas Airways Ltd. to buy Impulse Airlines, one of two discount carriers that ignited a price war last year in Australia. Air New Zealand's chief executive, Gary Toomey, said the company was eager to regain market share and had more than 600 million Australian dollars ($311 million) for expansion.

title: Sports of The Times; In Search of a Bit More Funk
description: TAMIKA WHITMORE sat alone at one of several round tables in Madison Square Garden yesterday. This was media day for the Liberty, the W.N.B.A.'s defending Eastern Conference champion.

title: Carter Shoots Raptors Back Into the Series
description: The Toronto Raptors took the floor wearing grimaces and purple headbands, a team on the verge of playoff elimination that appeared to be searching for strength in frowns and apparel. But the Raptors did more than change their look tonight.

title: Fleeing Spam, Some Go by Way of Foo
description: ONE way, it seems, to avoid an e-mail box littered with those unwanted direct-marketing messages called spam is to lie and lie often. Or more specifically, to provide a fake e-mail address -- whether you are venting on alt.bitterness (marketers consistently ''harvest'' e-mail addresses from such Internet discussions) or filling in forms at Web sites that require registration.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on April 21 about ''Varian's War,'' a film on Showtime about the efforts of Varian Fry, an American, to save European artists and intellectuals from the Holocaust, misstated the religious affiliation of some notable figures he rescued. Marcel Duchamp, Max Ernst and Heinrich Mann were not Jews.

title: Metro Matters; Next Mayor Will Inherit Hard Times
description: MYSTIFYING. A crowd of at least a half-dozen is fighting it out to be the next mayor of New York, a job that, objectively speaking, nobody should want. It's abundantly clear that Rudolph W. Giuliani's reputation as dragon-slayer will torment his successor. No way out of that one. But beyond that, the next few years are shaping up as dauntingly rocky for the city's 108th mayor.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell after an industry report showed an unexpected increase in United States inventories. In New York, crude oil for June delivery fell $1.14, or 3.9 percent, to $27.80 a barrel.

title: Transcript of Joe Drape's Visit to the Horse Racing Forum
description: Joe Drape, who covers horse racing for The Times, visited the forum on Thursday, May 3, to discuss the Kentucky Derby and his new book, "The Race for the Triple Crown."

title: Research Guided Jury Selection in Bombing Trial
description: The jury that took barely two hours on Tuesday to convict a former Klansman in a 1963 church bombing was chosen with the help of a long and sophisticated process guided by a prosecution jury consultant with vast experience in similar civil rights cases.

description: JASEN-Michael. On May 2, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Anna. Loving father of Georgette Jasen and her husband Max Van Gilder. Cherished grandfather of Noah and Alexa. Services Friday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Several Accounts Find New Homes
description: Several advertisers are making account changes.

title: Addenda: Bcom3 Chairman to Step Down
description: Roy J. Bostock, chairman at the Bcom3 Group in Chicago since it was formed in February 2000, is stepping down, Bcom3 said yesterday. He will be succeeded by Roger Haupt, who continues as chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the decline of free offerings on Web sites misstated the cost of storing e-mail on Yahoo. The $20 charge is for only those users who store more than six megabytes of e-mail; for others, the service remains free. The article also misstated the charge that Salon.com is considering. David Talbot, Salon's chairman, said that for the entire site, his company might charge more than the $30 a year it now costs for the premium section alone. He did not say the charge would be $75 to $150 a year.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Financing For Muslims
description: HSBC Bank, based in Manhattan, plans to offer services for Muslim clients who observe Shariah, the legal code of Islam, according to Kathleen Whelehan, the bank's executive vice president for consumer finance. One prohibition of Shariah is the payment of interest, and HSBC will offer home financing, deposit accounts and debit and credit cards that exclude interest payments. For example, rather than structuring the financing of a home purchase as a loan, HSBC could buy the home. The client then, in installments, would pay the bank for the home and an agreed-upon profit. The bank is a unit of HSBC Holdings P.L.C. of Britain. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: Lemony Snicket Says, 'Don't Read My Books!'
description: Who is this mysterious and unlikely sounding Lemony Snicket, creator of the best-selling books called "A Series of Unfortunate Events," and what has kept him from showing up at his own scheduled author appearance? What does he look like and where, exactly, is he from? (His author photo, which changes from book to book, is always a blurry shot taken from the back, in which he is walking away from the camera, or staring out a window or down at a book.) And why are the wildly tongue-in-cheek, neo-gothic stories he spins about the miserable lives of the terrorized but resourceful Baudelaire orphans -- 14-year-old Violet, who is a whiz at inventing things; her bookwormish brother, Klaus; and baby Sunny -- always dedicated to the late but still longed-for Beatrice? (From "The Ersatz Elevator": "For Beatrice -- When we met, my life began. Soon afterward, yours ended.")

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAR, BEATRICE
description: KLAR-Beatrice. Born June 27, 1914. Passed away peacefully on May 2, 2001. Survived by Arnold, her loving husband for over 60 years, and by her loving children Regina, Neil and Eileen, Deborah & Elliott, and loving grandchildren Lisa and Jennifer Klein, Dan and John Klar and Harrison Marks. Bea was a teacher for many years and her life was filled with love for her family, a thirst for knowledge and reading, a need to travel and experience. She has been a shining example and is missed by all who have known her. Funeral service Thursday, May 3, 2001, at 12 Noon, Temple Shaaray Tefila of Northern Westchester, Baldwin Road, Bedford Corners, New York. Interment is in Sharon Gardens. Donations in Bea's memory may be sent to the Larchmont Chapter of Hadassah, C/O Arlene Kaplan, 27 Prior Manor Road, Larchmont, New York 10538.

title: All-Defensive Team Has No Knick Players
description: TORONTO, May 2  The Knicks are the best defensive team in the National Basketball Association, one of only two clubs to hold opponents to less than 42 percent shooting. Yet even as they are showcasing their defensive prowess against Toronto's Vince Carter, none of the Knicks came close to earning a spot on the league's all-defensive team.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Students Polled On Voting
description: Far more college students say voting in a presidential election is important than actually vote, according to a survey for the Leon and Sylvia Panetta Institute, which promotes student involvement in government. Eighty-four percent said voting was important, and 60 percent said they had voted last fall, far more than actually did, said Peter D. Hart, who conducted the poll. Students said political activity was unlikely to make much of a difference, but they claimed a high level of participation in voluntary and charitable work. Adam Clymer (NYT)

title: Prouv, Everywhere
description: Jean Prouv, the French industrial engineer, architect and designer who died in 1984, is, like Oscar Niemeyer, at the height of fashion today. Among the activities to honor the 100th anniversary of Mr. Prouv's birth this year is a retrospective at the Pavillon de l'Arsenal, 21 Boulevard Morland, near the Bastille. It opens May 11 and runs to the end of August; the focus is on his architectural work, like the 1951 prototype for a house at a Paris salon, top. Exhibitions in Nancy, Mr. Prouv's hometown, will open in July, and a show of his furniture will be on view starting July 7 at the gallery Jousse Entreprise. The 1954 Antony chair (above) was shown at a recent Prouv exhibition in Hyres. And Vitra has announced that it will make licensed reproductions of Mr. Prouv's furniture this fall, including the Standard, Antony and Cit chairs and a number of tables.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Low-Tech Lois Lane

title: Oscar Wilde Quipped Here
description: Oscar Wilde died a pauper in this hotel on the Left Bank, leaving an unpaid bill and a final quip: ''I suppose I shall have to die above my means.'' New owners and the ubiquitous French decorator Jacques Garcia have lavishly refurbished this 20-room, four-star hotel, L'Htel -- sometimes, redundantly, Htel L'Htel. Rooms include the Oscar Wilde (below) and an Art Deco-themed room with furniture by Jean-Gabriel Domergue that belonged to the legendary French star Mistinguett. Chances are that no one will take the hefty bronze room keys (above) home by mistake. From $230 (single) to $529 (deluxe double) a night; L'Htel, 13 rue des Beaux-Arts; 011-33.1.44.41.99.00; Internet, www.l-hotel.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAKAUER, BARBARA
description: KRAKAUER-Barbara. On April 30, 2001. Violinist and teacher at the Preparatory and Extension Divisions of Mannes College of Music, and also in Provence annually since 1977. Most recently teaching in the Music Studies Abroad Program which she organized with her husband in collaboration with pianist Jeaneane Dowis Lipman. In addition to her active teaching and coaching, she participated in numerous chamber music performances and sonata recitals, both here and abroad, and proudly gave a belated Town Hall debut recital in her 50's. She is survived by her husband, Dr. William Krakauer, her son clarinetist David Krakauer, her daughter and sonin-law Lisa and Steve Schultz of San Jose, CA, her mother, Jean Lieberman, her brother and sisterin-law, Dr. Theodore and Dorita Lieberman of NY, grandchildren Matthew and Alicia Krakauer and Dory Schultz, loving nieces, nephews and cousins and many grateful and reconnaissant students here and abroad. Visiting hours Thursday, 6:30 to 9 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, followed by a Memorial Service Friday 11:45AM.

title: Hamptons Take a Mashie to Miniature Golf
description: IF it's springtime in the Hamptons, a development battle must be brewing. Three years ago, it was Ira Rennert and his 57,000-square-foot villa. Two years ago, it was Itzhak and Toby Perlman's rejected plan for a music school on Ronald S. Lauder's land. Last year, it was Alec Baldwin and friends fighting a proposed golf course in the Springs section of Easthampton.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: A Veiled Message To Parliament
description: Two days after being censured by parliament, President Abdurrahman Wahid addressed the nation briefly on television and described the separation of government powers, an oblique rebuff to the legitimacy of Parliament's action. But he did not specifically address the censure. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Microsoft Is Set To Be Top Foe Of Free Code
description: Microsoft is preparing a broad campaign countering the movement to give away and share software code, arguing that it potentially undermines the intellectual property of countries and companies. At the same time, the company is acknowledging that it is feeling pressure from the freely shared alternatives to its commercial software.

title: Bush Administration to Revise Clinton's Forest Rules
description: WASHINGTON -- The Bush administration will revise a Clinton-era ban on road-building and most logging in a third of the country's national forests to allow decisions to be made locally on a forest-by-forest basis, officials said Thursday.

title: I.B.M. Enhances Liquid Crystal Display Process
description: Acting on a scientist's hunch, a team of researchers at I.B.M. have perfected a significant improvement in the process used to align liquid crystals that form displays in laptop computers and increasingly in desktop machines.

title: EBay Removes Auction Posting After Objections From Diallos
description: The auction for what was said to be a piece of the front door from the Bronx apartment building where Amadou Diallo was killed came to an end yesterday when eBay, the Internet auction company, removed the posting from its Web site.

title: Learning and Playing Online Has Some Fringe Benefits
description: The newest way to learn the game is on your computer. Last month the American Contract Bridge League introduced Learn to Play Bridge, which can be downloaded from its Web site, www.acbl.org. It is also available on a free CD-ROM by calling (901) 332-5586.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Paying For Elections Overhaul
description: Because Massachusetts voters took it upon themselves to pass a Clean Elections Law by referendum in 1998, legislators decided to let them pay for it. The law would provide money to political candidates who agree to abide by fund-raising and spending restrictions. But instead of financing it, the House voted to ask taxpayers to pay directly for the changes by voluntarily increasing their tax payments by $100. Gov. Jane M. Swift took legislators to task and called on the Senate to make appropriations. ''We must abide by what the voters spoke on,'' Ms. Swift said. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Board Sues Ex-Candidates
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board has filed lawsuits against four former candidates -- including a city councilwoman and a Giuliani administration official -- asserting that they have refused to settle longstanding debts with the agency.

title: Tara Plantation, the Downstairs Version
description: MIDWAY through a new novel, ''The Wind Done Gone,'' Alice Randall's retelling of ''Gone With the Wind,'' the narrator receives a visitor from her past. The narrator, Cynara Brown, is a former slave and, as the novel has it, the half sister of Scarlett O'Hara.

description: PARIS  If there is one of the Grands Travaux that has won universal, though not undiluted, praise, it is the so-called Grand Louvre, in which the Mitterrand government transferred the Finance Ministry out of the Richelieu wing and removed parking and tour buses from the general area.

title: California Raids a Business That Refuses to Withhold Taxes
description: The California tax authorities and local police yesterday raided the factory and home of a California businessman who does not withhold taxes from his workers' paychecks, one of a small but growing number of business owners who contend the tax laws are a hoax.

description: Agencies and companies are making acquisitions and alliances.

title: SALTON TO BUY BRITISH APPLIANCE MAKER FOR $75 MILLION
description: Salton, the maker of George Foreman grills and Ultrasonic toothbrushes, agreed yesterday to buy Pifco Holdings for about $75 million so it can sell more products in Britain and Europe. Pifco, which is based in Britain, makes personal-care and kitchen appliances and cookware under the Pifco, Russell Hobbs, Salton and Carmen brands. The company had $67 million in sales for the year ended April 30, Salton said. Salton, which is based in Mount Prospect, Ill., also makes Farberware and Toastmaster appliances.

title: Shell Profits Top Forecasts
description: LONDON, May 3  Enjoying the good times in oil refining and natural gas while they last, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group reported today that its first-quarter profits rose 23 percent, outstripping analysts' forecasts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, RICHARDSON, JR.
description: PRATT-Richardson, Jr. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation mourn the loss of our dear friend and Board Member, Richardson Pratt, Jr. With passion, commitment and good humor he served as a Trustee for more than eighteen years, ten of those years as the Foundation's Treasurer. Throughout his tenure, Jerry enthusiastically embraced the goals of the Foundations and used his fine intellect and interpersonal skills to advance its purposes. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Jerry's wife, Jan, and to the rest of his family. He was a lovely man and he will be sorely missed. Winthrop R. Munyan, President Margaret C. Ayers, Executive Director

description: City firefighters are overwhelmingly white and male because the Fire Department imposes barriers to recruiting and hiring women, minorities and the poor, according to an audit by the city's Equal Employment Practices Commission.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Air Strike Planned
description: Pilots at Luft hansa, Germany's dominant airline, announced plans to go on strike for 12 hours today and block flights every Friday for the next four weeks if they cannot reach an agreement for wage increases. It would be the first real strike in Germany since 1992, because German unions and corporations have a tradition of promoting labor peace. But the pilots, some of whom are paid more than $200,000 a year, argue that they made big wage concessions when Lufthansa nearly went bankrupt 10 years ago and now earn less than their counterparts in Europe. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

Rumsfeld.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, RUTH

title: Hollywood Contract Talks Are Inching Along
description: Negotiators for Hollywood's writers and the major movie studios and television networks continued to inch toward a settlement today in negotiations that have stretched two days beyond the expiration of the writers' previous three-year contract.

title: More Sexual Allegations Emerge Against Teacher in Bronx
description: At least five students have come forward to accuse a second-grade teacher in the Bronx of sexual assaults or other sexual advances in recent months, police officials said yesterday. The latest accusations emerged as school officials admitted that they never informed the police of similar allegations against the teacher three years ago.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Up At Bank
description: Germany's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank, said its first-quarter income rose 7 percent in the first quarter, to 1.03 billion euros ($920 million). It was a sharp rebound from the decline that took place at the end of last year and a modest improvement over spectacular earnings during the last days of the bull market one year ago. Despite the plunge in global stock markets, the bank continued to earn a big share of its profit from trading activities.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Kerik Rating Slips Among Blacks
description: While Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik has made improvement of community relations a goal of his administration, a recent poll suggests that his popularity among blacks has fallen. The poll found that 36 percent of blacks viewed Mr. Kerik negatively, compared with 26 percent in February. The percentage of blacks who say they approve of the job he is doing fell to 32 percent from 39 percent. The poll was conducted by Quinnipiac University between April 23 and April 30, around the time Mr. Kerik announced that he would not discipline the officers who shot Amadou Diallo. Over all, Mr. Kerik retains a 46 percent approval rating. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

description: By indicting the two former chairmen of the world's most powerful auction houses on Wednesday, prosecutors are poised to build a case against A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's who is also its largest shareholder. Mr. Taubman, along with Sir Anthony Tennant, the onetime chairman of Christie's, are charged with organizing a scheme to fix the fees charged to about 130,000 customers.

title: VIVENDI WILL CREATE VIDEO GAMES BASED ON TOLKIEN BOOKS
description: Vivendi Universal S.A., Europe's largest media company, received an eight-year exclusive license from Tolkien Enterprises to create video games based on J. R. R. Tolkien's books ''The Hobbit'' and ''The Lord of the Rings.'' Vivendi Universal Publishing's Sierra studio, which is based in Bellevue, Wash., will develop games for computers, consoles and hand-held systems based on the fantasy novels. Financial terms were not disclosed, said Mark Hood, Sierra's senior vice president for development. The books have sold nearly 100 million copies worldwide since ''The Hobbit'' was published in 1937 and have been translated into 26 languages.

description: The plan to build a World War II Memorial on the Mall was sent back to the drawing board today after a powerful government planning group voted to reconsider both the location and the design of the $100 million-plus project.

title: MARRIOTT INTERNATIONAL STOPS BIDDING FOR LE MERIDIEN
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it had pulled out of the bidding for the luxury hotel chain Le Meridien. Marriott, which is based in Bethesda, Md., and operates Marriott, Ritz-Carlton and other hotels, had hoped to purchase Le Meridien as part of a plan to double the number of its hotel rooms in Europe. Le Meridien, a unit of the Compass Group of Britain, has 124 hotels in 60 countries.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Cameras to Fight Crime
description: Mayor Bret D. Schundler unveiled a criminal monitoring system yesterday that uses 17 cameras trained on high-crime areas of the city. Mr. Schundler, left, said the cameras did not violate privacy rights because they were equipped to monitor storefronts but not, for example, second-floor windows of homes. Mr. Schundler, a Republican who is running for governor, said he hoped to install more than 100 cameras across the city. An opponent of the cameras, Glenn Cunningham, a former United States marshal who is running for mayor, said he would remove them if elected. But Councilwoman Melissa Holloway, who represents the largely black neighborhood where the cameras are concentrated, defended them as necessary to fight crime. ''Right now, what we need is a little Big Brother,'' she said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits yesterday about hobbyists who alter electronic gadgets misstated the capacity of hard drives installed on TiVo digital video recorders to add memory. It is 80 gigabytes, not megabytes.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Senate Battle Over Judgeships
description: Senate Democrats raised the stakes in a partisan battle over the shape of the nation's courts. The nine Democrats on the Judiciary Committee walked out of a session, foiling Republican plans to confirm the nominations of Larry Thompson to be the deputy attorney general and Theodore B. Olson to be solicitor general. The Democrats blocked the nominations to gain leverage in a dispute over the influence they will have in choosing federal judges. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Certification for Interior Designers
description: The Assembly Appropriations Committee passed a measure yesterday that would require interior designers to be certified by the state. ''Issuing a state certification to interior designers will ensure that their services are professionally and competently delivered,'' said one of the bill's sponsors, Assemblyman Anthony Impreveduto, a Democrat from Secaucus.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Arrest In Mortgage Fraud Case
description: The president of a nonprofit corporation in Newport Beach, Calif., is scheduled to be arrested on Long Island today on charges stemming from a home mortgage fraud case involving hundreds of dilapidated brownstones in Harlem and elsewhere in New York City, federal prosecutors said yesterday. Edward MacDonald of Las Vegas is the president of St. Stephen's Baptist Church, the owner of 50 properties in Harlem that were acquired under a federally insured mortgage program open only to nonprofit groups or people who intend to live in their homes. In documents filed last month in United States District Court in Central Islip, N.Y., an investigator for the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development said that although St. Stephen's ''purports to be an active church,'' no mail is delivered to the address it lists in Newport Beach. A spokesman for Mr. MacDonald, the 19th person arrested in the case, said he would plead not guilty to the charges. Mr. MacDonald is accused of participating in at least four transactions in 1998 involving properties in Harlem that were bought and quickly resold for a much higher price, a practice known as flipping. According to the court documents, St. Stephen's claimed that the down payments were coming from its own funds when the money actually came from real estate speculators and lawyers, who also paid Mr. MacDonald $5,000 for each property he bought. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bridgewater: Water Restrictions Lifted
description: Residents of a six-county area in central New Jersey were told yesterday that they no longer had to boil their drinking water, after officials of the Elizabethtown Water Company found no contamination in pipes after a Monday night water-main break that briefly left one million people with low water pressure or no water at all. With the completion of tests on Wednesday, the company said it was all right to drink the water after letting faucets and drinking fountains run for three to five minutes, discarding three batches of ice from reactivated ice makers and draining and refilling water heaters unused for 24 hours.

title: Judge Blocks Efforts by Strangers to Post Bail for Drug Suspect
description: First a juror, and then an investment banker and a civil rights advocate who are opposed to New York's harsh drug laws have tried to post bail for a man in jail awaiting retrial on charges that he sold $10 of heroin.

title: Taipei Family, American Angst
description: When it was shown last year at the New York Film Festival, Edward Yang's ''Yi Yi (A One and a Two)'' was praised for its profundity and easy, fluid rhythm. Now it can be said that another of its strengths is a high degree of watchability on video. Its intimacy works well on a small screen. And it is in no hurry. This is a movie, available on VHS and DVD next week from Winstar, that requires reflection, perhaps even an intermission or two.

description: The former business administrator for the Wyckoff school district pleaded guilty today to federal charges that he helped embezzle $1.7 million from the Bergen County district over a seven-year period.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Utility's Profits Fall
description: The largest utility in Britain utility, Scottish Power P.L.C., outlined a restructuring program that focused on expansion in the United States, as it reported fourth-quarter profit that declined 15 percent, to $892 million, compared with $1 billion a year ago. Profit was hurt by stricter regulation in Britain, the volatile energy market in the United States and a breakdown at the company's Hunter power station in Utah. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Lessons From Teacher, Strictly Extracurricular
description: Macaulay Culkin is 20 now, but his face still glows with a preternatural purity that has little to do with innocence. As the 15-year-old narrator and passive center of ''Madame Melville,'' the memory play by Richard Nelson that opened last night at the Promenade Theater, the onetime child superstar radiates self-consciousness and self-confidence in equally intense measures. It sometimes hurts to watch him, but it's impossible to look away.

description: To reduce the reliance on pesticides in the battle against West Nile virus, the city will use a more conservative, concentrated approach to spraying this summer, officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Spanish-Language Gay Paper
description: LGNY, a gay and lesbian newspaper in New York, announced yesterday that it would begin distributing 10,000 copies of a new Spanish-language edition, called LGNY Latino, once a month. In a statement, Troy Masters, the editor of LGNY, which is published every two weeks and has a circulation of 35,000, said Oriol Gutierrez will be appointed editor in chief and publisher of LGNY Latino. The first issue of the new Spanish-language edition is scheduled to be published later this month, the statement said. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: New York in Las Vegas
description: Ahotel room in New York for $70 a night is just about unheard of. But when it's a re-creation of New York along the Las Vegas Strip, anything is possible. From June 3 through Aug. 30, room rates at the New York, New York Hotel and Casino will start at $70 from Sunday through Thursday. Rates are based on availability. As part of the program, called "In a New York Minute," guests also receive a coupon book good for discounts at various hotel shows, shops and restaurants. The hotel features 2,023 rooms in 12 Manhattan-style skyscrapers. Information: (800) 693-6763 or www.nynyhotelcasino.com .

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: Energy Commission Criticized
description: Environmental groups are complaining about the composition of a commission created to study rising energy demand and available fuel sources in the state. The commission is made up of six elected officials and nine members, appointed this week by Gov. Jim Geringer, who all have ties to energy companies. The group includes no one from an environmental or consumer group. ''You're either at the table or you're not at the table,'' said Larry Mehlhaff of the Sierra Club's Wyoming office. title: Many-Colored Coat of Arts
description: TO THE degree that anything can be called usual at Makor, the eclectic cultural center on West 67th Street in Manhattan, the atmosphere in its basement cafe on a recent Sunday evening was uncharacteristically staid. Instead of the jazz, Latin, folk or Israeli pop musicians who pack nearly 250 people into the room, Adam Grabois, a young cellist, and John Nauman, a pianist, were playing works by Bach, Beethoven, Schumann, Glazunov, Glinka and Rachmaninoff for an audience of about 60. And instead of milling around, dancing, chatting up potential dates or placing food and drink orders, listeners were quietly focused on the stage, some unobtrusively picking at the food on their tables, but most concentrating as if they were in a concert hall rather than a club.

title: A Jewish Honor Touches a Nerve
description: To the Editor:

title: Exploring the Allure of the Prolific Lee Friedlander, as It Was and as It Is
description: Every time you turn around, it sometimes seems, the versatile and prolific Lee Friedlander is having a show -- two right now in Manhattan -- or a book of his photographs is coming out, or he is being given an award or is otherwise making news.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUERNSEY, OTIS
description: GUERNSEY-Otis. The Council of The Dramatists Guild of America mourns the loss of our colleague, Otis Guernsey. Mr. Guernsey was a lifetime member of the Guild, as well as the founder of ''The Dramatists Guild Quarterly,'' which he served as original editor for thirty years. Our deepest sympathies to his family. He will be missed. John Weidman, President The Dramatists Guild of America

title: Scarsdale Parents Call Test Boycott a Success
description: Rebellious mothers in Scarsdale declared a victory yesterday in their insurgency against state standardized tests, having carried out the first of several planned test boycotts with the precision and organization of a military exercise.

title: MACROMEDIA'S SHARE PRICE DROPS 23 PERCENT
description: Shares in Macromedia Inc. fell 23 percent yesterday after the maker of Web-site-design software posted quarterly results that disappointed investors. Its stock fell $5.98, to $20.60 a share, on the Nasdaq, where it was among the top five percentage losers. The shares have fallen 75 percent in the last year. Macromedia, which is based in San Francisco, said late Wednesday that it lost $22 million, or 42 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of its fiscal year. A year earlier, the company earned $6 million, or 10 cents a share. Revenue rose to $89.1 million from $86.4 million.

title: Public Interests; Hurry Up and Shield
description: If you want to estimate the Bush missile shield's chances for success, consider the Army beret crisis.

title: 'Suspicious' Fire Damages Bellmore Firehouse
description: A fast-moving fire tore through a firehouse here just before dawn today, causing about $1 million in damage. The authorities said they believed that it was intentionally set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, MILTON S.
description: PRINCE-Milton S. RADM NYNM. Died on May 1, 2001 in Brooklyn, N.Y. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice Prince. He was the loving father of his sons Thomas and Andrew and father-in-law of Deborah and Shelley and grandfather of Brett, Kenny, Adam and Samantha. He was truly devoted to the service of his country and was awarded the Navy's highest civilian award for distinguished public service. A graduate of Carnegie Tech and a Doctor of Laws from the St. Johns School of Law. He had his own real estate business and was active in a variety of civic organizations including numerous leadership roles in the U.S.O., U.S. Naval Academy Foundation, MOWW, Veteran's of Foreign Wars, Navy League, Municipal Club of Brooklyn, and Boy Scouts of America. He was a member of the NYS Bar and was admitted to practice law before the U.S. Supreme Court. He will be sorely missed by his family and numerous friends. Shiva will be held through Sunday afternoon.

title: Elite French College Tackles Affirmative Action
description: In this town, where blocks of public housing and laundry lines dominate the landscape, few high school students even dream of going to France's most prestigious colleges. In fact, no senior has ever passed the entrance exam for the Institut d'tudes Politiques just a few miles away in the Seventh Arrondissement of Paris.

title: Bush Condemns Suppression Of Religious Freedom in Sudan
description: President Bush tonight delivered his most strongly worded condemnation of countries that seek to suppress religious freedom, particularly singling out Sudan and declaring that ''my administration will continue to speak and act for as long as persecution and atrocities in Sudan last.''

title: A Convert To Fitness Transformed As a Hitter
description: Luis Gonzalez would drag his weary body to the breakfast table last season, and his wife, Christine, would not even need to ask him if he was sore. She would hear the creaking and cracking of different joints, she would see his familiar anguished expression and she would watch her husband move toward his first sip of coffee as if his legs were shackled.

title: Haggling Over Technicalities Delays Voting on Budget
description: The budget compromise worked out this week by Republican negotiators and the White House became snagged in technicalities today, and a final Congressional vote was postponed until next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENACH, HENRY

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Public Records Bill Amended
description: Amendments to a bill that would expand access to public records passed the State Senate yesterday in a 33-to-0 vote. The amended bill, if passed, will grant access to all documents not explicitly prohibited, and will grant computerized records the same status as paper documents. The amendments were agreed on after a yearlong standstill between the New Jersey Press Association and the state attorney general's office over access to files on criminal investigations.

title: An Ugly and Cowardly Hit, Even by Hockey's Code
description: TORONTO  Referees are reluctant to call penalties in Stanley Cup playoff games and National Hockey League executives are even more reluctant to suspend players. But Toronto's thuggish Tie Domi made it simple for everybody last night in the Air Canada Center with a vicious elbow to the head of Scott Niedermayer that sent the stylish Devils defenseman off the ice on a stretcher.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYLE, JANICE D.
description: BOYLE-Janice D. Of Gilford, NH and formerly of Garden City, LI on May 3, 2001 in Laconia, NH. The case is coming under scrutiny as investigators look into the work of an Oklahoma City police department forensic scientist, Joyce Gilchrist. A recent Federal Bureau of Investigation report harshly criticized Ms. Gilchrist for misidentifying evidence in a handful of noncapital cases. Jim Yardley (NYT)

description: On first glance, the exhibition of the early work of Marc Chagall at the Jewish Museum looks like a case of too little too soon. The museum's last show of early Chagall, twice as large, was only five years ago.

title: Sending the Innocence of a Lost World Through a Bath of Anguish and Cynicism
description: The changing of the world is expressed in more ways than scientific milestones or industrial statistics. The Boston Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was telling us in specific terms about the death of the pastoral life, the hegemony of all things urban and the victory of cynicism over any pretense to innocence.

title: Democrats Consider Rule For Ballots
description: Little more than a year ago, Democrats were gloating at the public relations beating the Republican Party was taking over its attempts to keep Senator John McCain off New York's presidential primary ballot.

title: Home Video: Taipei Family, American Angst
description: When it was shown last year at the New York Film Festival, Edward Yang's "Yi Yi (A One and a Two)" was praised for its profundity and easy, fluid rhythm. Now it can be said that another of its strengths is a high degree of watchability on video. Its intimacy works well on a small screen. And it is in no hurry. This is a movie, available on VHS and DVD next week from Winstar , that requires reflection, perhaps even an intermission or two.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Video Gambling Approved
description: After a raucous session, the State Senate approved a bill permitting video gambling machines at dog-racing tracks. Earlier in the day, opponents of the bill, noting that yesterday was the National Day of Prayer, introduced a bill that would allow a moment of reflection at school athletic events and began a lengthy debate. Several senators exchanged harsh words before the filibuster was broken. The gambling bill goes to the House for another vote. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Two Republican Candidates Are Swinging (and Stinging)
description: The reshuffled Republican primary for governor was off to a hectic start today, as Bob Franks detailed a major campaign proposal, Bret D. Schundler began running a radio commercial attacking him, and a new poll showed that Mr. Franks would be much more competitive in November against the Democratic candidate, James E. McGreevey.

description: As art worldlings go, there was no one quite like John Powers. title: Trafficking in Children
description: It is now clear that the mysterious ship that left Benin in late March was indeed carrying children sold into slavery -- not the 250 initially reported by a newspaper in Benin, but at least a few, and possibly as many as 40. The ship, the MV Etireno, was denied port in Cameroon and Gabon after an international outcry about the possible presence of the children. It finally returned to Benin last month with 40 unaccompanied children and young adults aboard. They are being cared for by charitable groups.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Malcolm X Marchers File Suit
description: Lawyers for the annual Malcolm X March filed a civil rights suit yesterday against the New York Police Department for denying marchers a permit. Organizers said there was no legitimate basis for denying a permit for the march, which they said had taken place without incident for 11 years. The suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, charged that the department violated the group's First Amendment right to free speech. In denying the permit last month, the police said the march conflicted with a street festival sponsored by the 125th Street Business Improvement District for which a permit had already been issued.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bill Would Ban Human Cloning
description: Health Minister Allan Rock introduced a draft bill to ban the cloning of human beings. The legislation would establish a semiprivate agency to oversee a range of reproductive issues and regulate the commercial use of genetic material, including human embryos. A parliamentary health committee will review the draft bill and hold public hearings over the next two years before presenting it to Parliament. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Defense Attacks Reliability Of a Witness in Terror Case
description: A defense lawyer in the embassy bombings trial charged yesterday that a crucial government witness who was a former aide to Osama bin Laden had lied repeatedly, to the American authorities to win protection for himself, and again when he took the witness stand.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Exports Fall
description: Philippine exports fell 0.5 percent in the first three months of this year to $8.5 billion, led by declines in electronics to the United States, the National Statistics Office said. Economists said the export slowdown was sure to hit the country's economic growth rate; the government has set a growth target of 3.8 percent this year. Exports of electronics, which account for more than half of Philippine exports over all, dropped 11.2 percent in March, contributing to an overall monthly export decline of 4 percent.

Genuity's first-quarter loss widened to $292.4 million, or 30 cents a fully diluted share, from $209.8 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected a loss of 33 cents. Quarterly sales rose 21 percent, to $299.5 million.

title: Mr. Freeh Retires
description: In eight years as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Louis Freeh suffered several embarrassments, not least the arrest in February of an F.B.I. agent who had allegedly been passing secrets to the Soviet Union and then Russia for 15 years. But Mr. Freeh can claim important successes. He strengthened the bureau's capacity to combat terrorism at home and abroad, greatly increased its budget and began the process of reforming its inequitable hiring and promotion practices. He also stood up to President Clinton and Attorney General Janet Reno on the issue of fund-raising abuses by the Democrats.

title: Introduction
description: Thanks to decades of mind-numbing marketing, most of us know mayonnaise primarily as a boring, commonplace bottled condiment and spread, like ketchup. But mayonnaise is a true sauce, a culinary treasure, and once you start making it yourself it is an invitation to set your imagination free -- especially when you're thinking about fish at the same time. That's what happened to us when we started creating this lesson: we just kept trying one variation after another. We began thinking simply of a mustardy basic mayo, and found that we couldn't stop. We created six more, with the mustardy one as the base, using three of those mayos in specific dishes but merely suggesting food pairings for the rest.

Under the bill, school districts would have to write antibullying policies and train teachers, students and others to help stop such harassment. The Christian group said the measure could be used to prevent students from speaking against homosexuality. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: E.D.S. Gets Service Contracts
description: Electronic Data Systems, the big Texas-based computer service company, said it had won $1 billion in contracts from four organizations around the world. The company signed a 10-year, $390 million contract from the British lender Abbey National; three contracts with BellSouth; a two-year contract with the Board of the Austrian Insurance Agencies; and a five-year deal with Afrox, a South African gas and health care concern. Last week, E.D.S. reported first-quarter earnings that met Wall Street's expectations, announced that it expected to do so for the rest of the year and said that it had its ninth consecutive quarter of record signings. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Laptop Batteries Recalled
description: Laptop computer batteries made by Dell Computer are being recalled because they may overcharge and catch fire. Dell, the biggest United States PC maker, announced the recall yesterday in cooperation with the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission. The commission said there had been one report of an overcharged battery that caught fire and caused minor property damage. Dell said that it was recalling about 284,000 batteries sold with Inspiron 5000 series notebook computers from Jan. 7, 2000, through March 21, 2001. The computers themselves are not being recalled. Dell said it would replace any recalled battery at no cost to the consumer.

title: Budget Farce in Washington
description: Congress appeared set yesterday to approve a misbegotten federal budget negotiated in secret between the White House and Republican leaders, with the support of a few Democrats. Then an unusual thing happened. The lawmakers realized that the numbers in the budget did not add up. To make room for the outsized tax cut, the budget had been stripped of vital funding for energy, housing, education, health and the environment. It also made no room for the military spending increases certain to be requested by President Bush later this year. Suddenly the budget's warped priorities became too hard to reconcile. Though the House was preparing to approve the budget, senators who had been ready to vote for it were having second thoughts.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Trade Tension
description: A group of American executives in Vietnam criticized the United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, for moves it said would delay Congressional ratification of a trade agreement with Hanoi signed last July. The American Chamber of Commerce in Vietnam said Mr. Zoellick had decided to submit the bilateral trade agreement to Congress together with several more controversial trade measures. The agreement, reached after four years of negotiations, would reduce tariffs on Vietnamese imports in return for Vietnam's gradually opening its economy to greater United States investment and exports. Vietnamese officials have expressed their own impatience, with Trade Minister Vu Khoan, above, warning that further delays could jeopardize the existing trade status of the United States. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

description: President Thabo Mbeki said in a televised interview that he had ''no reason to think'' that three senior African National Congress members seen as possible rivals were conspiring to oust him or threatening to harm him. Instead of being treated to exposition or significant dialogue, we are immersed in the details of ordinary life, the tiny habits and almost imperceptible courtesies that constitute the intimate and easy familiarity of long-married people.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New East River Ferries
description: New York Waterway plans to open two ferry routes on the East River next fall, using new bow-loading, high-speed ferries, the company's president, Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., announced yesterday. The routes are from Hunters Point, Queens, to Wall Street's Pier 11, and from East 90th Street in Manhattan to Pier 11. The new Hunters Point line replaces service between the Queens terminal and 34th Street in Manhattan that the company, based in Weehawken, N.J., discontinued in February because of low ridership. New York Waterway said the ferries can carry up to 97 passengers at 30 miles per hour, and will make the trip to Pier 11 in 15 minutes from East 90th Street, and in 12 minutes from Hunters Point. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: F.B.I. Denies an Effort to Hinder Alabama's Bombing Inquiry
description: The F.B.I. acknowledged today that it did not give secretly recorded audiotapes and other relevant evidence to Alabama officials in the early 1970's when the state reopened its investigation of the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church. The tapes played a decisive role in the conviction this week of Thomas E. Blanton Jr., a former Klansman who lived free for nearly 38 years after the bombing and for 24 years after state prosecutors concluded they did not have enough evidence to charge him.

The committee, which considers national security issues when foreign companies buy into the American market, was unable to reach a decision during its standard 45-day assessment period and had requested assistance from the White House last week. But in an unusual move, the committee reconsidered the deal; President Bush will not be required to weigh in on the matter. The Silicon Valley Group manufactures lithography systems and optical components used in spy satellites.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ex-Kremlin Aide Sought -- Again
description: Pavel Borodin, the former Kremlin official briefly held in the United States this spring on Swiss money-laundering charges, has been summoned to Switzerland again for questioning. Mr. Borodin flew to Switzerland last month to face charges but Swiss authorities freed him on bail, saying Russian prosecutors had not handed over crucial evidence. Mr. Borodin said on Wednesday that he would return for questioning; Swiss officials said they were skeptical. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Cross-Channel Policing
description: In an effort to thwart illegal immigrants sneaking into England through the Channel Tunnel, the French Parliament approved an accord with Britain that allows British police officers to patrol railway stations in France. The British officers will be stationed at the Gare du Nord in Paris and in Lille and Calais to prevent illegal immigrants from boarding the Eurostar train that links Paris and London. In return, France will be permitted to station police at Waterloo and St. Pancras stations in London and at Ashford in southeast England, where the Eurostar regularly stops. John Tagliabue (NYT)

He also expressed the hope that it would lead to renewed dialogue between the United States and North Korea.

title: Bush Says U.S. Wants to Help California Solve Energy Crisis
description: Saying ''we want to be part of any solutions'' to the energy crunch crippling California, President Bush ordered federal agencies there today to cut power use by curtailing air-conditioning and even e-mail use during state electricity shortages.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: New Trial for Cannibal
description: A state judge has ordered a new trial to determine whether Albert Fentress, a former Hudson Valley teacher who killed and cannibalized a Poughkeepsie teenager in 1979, should be released from a Suffolk County mental hospital. The ruling, which Justice Robert W. Doyle of State Supreme Court issued on April 16, came two years after a Suffolk jury decided that Mr. Fentress, 59, was mentally ill but was no longer a threat to society and should be released. That verdict was set aside, but the Appellate Division later ordered a new trial, a decision that the attorney general's office asked Justice Doyle to dismiss. In 1980, Mr. Fentress pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity to killing the teenager, Paul Masters, then cooking and eating parts of his body. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Art Can Take Heat in the Kitchen; Gritty Tales Leave Food Insiders Feeling Well Served
description: Only yesterday, it seems, New York's diners wanted nothing more from hot restaurants than glammy fantasy. Think: theatrical display kitchens. Gazillion-dollar dcor by Richard Lewis, David Rockwell or Adam Tihany. Sycophantic matres d'htel. Worshiped chefs. And food, glorious food.

description: In a move that reflected a growing frustration with America's attitude toward international organizations and treaties, the United States was voted off the United Nations Human Rights Commission today for the first time since the panel's founding under American leadership in 1947.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Waterloo Brasserie, sensing the limits of enthusiasm for Belgian food, closed its doors in February. In a quick refitting, the restaurant has reopened with the same owners, the same chef but a new name and menu. It's now Midway, and Bill Schutz, the executive chef and a partner, is sending American bistro dishes from the kitchen, supported by a list of mostly American wines.
