title: A Tragedy in Search Of an Ending
description: The execution of Timothy McVeigh on May 16 is supposed to bring an end to the national trauma of the Oklahoma City bombing. Attorney General John Ashcroft said that his decision to permit survivors and relatives of the victims of the bombing to witness the execution on television was intended to allow them to ''close this chapter in their lives.''

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Profit Is Up 23%
description: Enjoying the good times in oil refining and natural gas while they last, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group reported first-quarter profits today that increased 23 percent, outstripping analysts' forecasts.

title: PHELPS DODGE CUTS DIVIDEND AND CANCELS SALE PLANS
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the world's No. 2 copper producer, said yesterday that it would cut its quarterly dividend by 37.5 cents and canceled plans to sell its specialty chemicals and wire and cable businesses. The company, which is based in Phoenix, said it would cut its quarterly dividend to 12.5 cents a share from 50 cents, resulting in annual savings of $120 million for the company. The decision was based on a number of factors, including the slowing economy, Phelps Dodge said. It also said it had decided to drop plans to sell its Columbian Chemicals and PD Wire and Cable units because it would not be able to get the price it wants in the current economic environment.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Great Train Robber Eyes Return
description: After more than 35 years as a fugitive and celebrity in Rio de Janeiro, Ronnie Biggs, a member of the gang that stole 2.6 million in the ''Great Train Robbery'' in 1963, wants to return to Britain, even if it means he will face criminal charges there. Now 71 and in poor health, Mr. Biggs sent an e-mail message to Scotland Yard saying he is willing to surrender, and told a London newspaper that ''my last wish is to walk into a Margate pub as an Englishman and buy a pint of bitter.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Letting the River Run
description: The Bush administration has scolded the city of Davenport, Iowa, for its failure to build a permanent flood wall to protect itself from the swollen Mississippi River. But as the administration, through the Federal Emergency Management Agency, appears to advocate lining the river with levees and flood walls, it should look downstream to Louisiana, which has come to its own solution, for better or worse, about how to handle its end of the Mississippi.

description: Iran's president, Mohammad Khatami, ended months of speculation about whether he would seek a second term by registering today as a candidate for the June 8 election.

title: 2 Youths Drown at a Beach in Brooklyn
description: A 13-year-old girl and a 12-year-old boy drowned yesterday afternoon when a group of friends trying to escape the record-setting spring heat skipped school for a swim in the frigid waters at a Brooklyn shorefront park, where they were swept away by treacherous currents, the authorities said.

title: In Argentina, More Room To Breathe
description: At just about every public ceremony, the Argentine economy minister, Domingo F. Cavallo, reminds his audiences that his mother nicknamed him ''Lightning'' as a child.

title: Only the Guilty Are Guilty, Not Their Sons
description: Let me begin with a confession. I was wrong to believe that 50-odd years after the most cruel of human tragedies, caused by Hitler's Germany, some passions had begun to cool. For the victims, their children and their friends, the wounds remain understandably raw. They still have nightmares, and they are sensitive to certain words. They remember a time when the very word ''German'' evoked terror.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Benefits Blocked For Gay Partners
description: The House voted to stop Gov. Jesse Ventura from extending health insurance benefits to same-sex partners of state employees. The Senate passed a similar measure this week blocking discussion of the benefits during this year's labor negotiations. The measure was then changed to allow the benefits to be part of negotiations, but all contracts must be ratified by the Legislature. The health benefits would not apply to nonunion employees. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Flute Wins Easily in the Oaks
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 4  Flute, making only her fourth career start, took the lead at the top of the stretch and cruised home a 2 3/8- length winner today in the 127th running of the Kentucky Oaks.

title: New Jersey, Like Life but More Complex
description: For New Jerseyans, both loyal citizens and nostalgic expatriates like myself, the last few years have felt something like riding the old Cyclone roller coaster at Palisades Amusement Park. Long inured to cheap, what-exit-are-you-from gibes, we suddenly found ourselves, a short while back, in the sunlight of what seemed like a Jersey renaissance, set in motion by an artistic effusion about our state from its natives -- in works from Philip Roth's ''American Pastoral'' to David Chase's ''The Sopranos.'' The press began to sing the state's praises; all at once it was remembered that the place known for the New Jersey Turnpike, the Meadowlands and the Linden refineries had also nurtured the divine afflatus of artists like Walt Whitman, Allen Ginsberg and William Carlos Williams, not to mention Bruce Springsteen and Lauryn Hill.

title: Tokyo Journal; Ryotei: Vanishing Havens of the High and Mighty
description: The view from the street is as discreet as they come: a gate so plain it almost describes nondescript. To reach the true entrance one must cross a stone path past saucers containing the salt used in Shinto purification rites and open the slatted wooden doors.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS HUGE VERDICT AGAINST EXXON MOBIL
description: Accusing Exxon Mobil of fraud, an Alabama judge yesterday upheld a $3.5 billion jury verdict against the company for underpaying natural gas revenue to the state. The verdict, which was issued in December, was the largest in Alabama history, and the company's lawyers had tried to persuade the judge, Tracy McCooey, that it was excessive. But she ruled that it was justified, particularly because Exxon Mobil, which is based in Irving, Tex., had expressed no regret for its actions. The company plans to appeal to the state Supreme Court. David Firestone

title: Hackers Leave Pro-China Trail on U.S. Sites
description: WASHINGTON, May 4  After federal officials issued warnings that Chinese hackers were planning a wave of attacks against United States-based Web sites, more than 650 American sites were defaced this week, culminating in a two-hour attack this morning that partly paralyzed the official White House site.

title: Be Inclusive: Take a Nap For Charity
description: HERE'S the deal. Each of you puts up 20 bucks in the name of cancer research -- 10 will do, if you're feeling strapped -- and I will take a nap for a full hour this afternoon. It could even last an hour and a half, if you're worried about getting your money's worth. The important thing is that you will be sponsoring an activity dedicated to raising money to find a cure for a terrible disease.

title: Henry Benach, 83; Developer
description: Henry Benach, a retired chairman of the Starrett Corporation, the New York-based development and construction concern, died last Sunday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 83.

title: Revolt at the U.N.
description: Thanks in part to the inattention of the Bush administration, the United States lost its seat on the United Nations Human Rights Commission this week for the first time since the panel was established in 1947. But the administration's failure to detect and defeat the brewing rebellion among other nations was only one element of an embarrassing defeat. Even more important was the rising resentment abroad about America's often patronizing treatment of the U.N. and Washington's disdain for international compacts on issues ranging from the environment to the use of land mines.

title: North Korea Refuses to Stop Arms Exports, Delegation Says
description: North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, refused to renounce exports of missiles and missile technology, the European Union's top security official said today.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Polling Fuels Speculation On Helms
description: Senator Jesse Helms's campaign committee has started polling, prompting state Republican officials to speculate that he is leaning toward a re-election campaign in 2002. Mr. Helms, 79, was first elected in 1972, and many have questioned whether declining health would push him into retirement. On the Democratic side, the State Senate majority leader, Marc Basnight, has announced that he will not run. Erskine B. Bowles, a former White House chief of staff, and Elaine F. Marshall, the North Carolina secretary of state, are among those said to be considering a race. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Banking Profits Rise
description: Profit at the Westpac Banking Corporation for the six months ended March 31 rose 13 percent to 924 million Australian dollars ($480 million) on increased volume of mortgage, credit card and business lending. Expenses were flat, but bad debt nearly tripled to 176 million Australian dollars ($91.4 million) from the period last year, a sign that economic sluggishness in the second half will probably retard growth, the bank said, echoing a warning from a major rival, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, earlier this week. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Error in Type Gets Blame For Inflating Profit Figure
description: Computer Associates said yesterday that a typographical error had caused it to overstate its annual profit by about $130 million in a news release last month.

title: So It's Like a Concert Without Any Instruments
description: An opera without singing might seem like an affair without embraces, but such weighty absences characterized ''Decreation,'' by the Canadian poet and classics scholar Anne Carson, staged Monday at the Culture Project as a benefit for the adventurous literary magazine Fence. Linking the Greek myth of Hephaistos, Aphrodite and Ares to the story of the medieval heretic Marguerite Porete and the life of the philosopher Simone Weil, ''Decreation'' used opera's florid formality to render vivid an abstract text about spiritual fulfillment.

title: WRITERS IN ACCORD WITH THE STUDIOS
description: Negotiators for Hollywood's film and television writers reached a tentative agreement today on a three-year contract with the major studios and networks that will, if approved by the union's members, avert a strike. Only a few months ago, Hollywood thought that a strike was all but inevitable and that it would have the potential to cripple the entertainment industry.

title: U.S. Charges Traficant, Colorful Ohio Congressman, With Taking Bribes
description: Representative James A. Traficant Jr., a colorful and blustery Ohio Democrat who was stripped of his committee assignments earlier this year after he voted for a Republican for House speaker, was indicted by a federal grand jury in Cleveland today on 10 charges of bribery, racketeering, obstruction of justice and income tax evasion.

description: When someone in Karachi sneezes, someone in America catches a cold. And someone in Lima may have the cure. A look at global medicine. A special issue of The Times Magazine.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: No Foot-and-Mouth In Humans
description: British health authorities said tests on 21 people suspected of having foot-and-mouth disease were negative. The disease, which has swept through cloven-hoofed animals in Britain since mid-February, is very rare in humans and produces only mild symptoms. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Warning From Bank
description: Doldrums on Wall Street will reduce first-quarter profit at Socit Gnrale, the bank's chairman, Daniel Bouton, said at a shareholders' meeting. ''Certain areas of investment banking in the United States have practically come to a standstill, in particular public offerings,'' Mr. Bouton said. Still, he expects the quarter to improve on the fourth quarter of 2000. The warning, after a similar one from Crdit Lyonnais this week, prompted a 6 percent fall in Socit Gnrale's share price. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Yankees Pull Out Another At Friendly Camden Yards
description: The Yankees like Camden Yards the way children like ice cream, the way cats like lying in the sun. Hitters consider the stadium lights here to be the brightest in the American League, making for favorable conditions, and the Yankees feel so comfortable here. Early deficits turn into late-inning leads. Plus they win most of the time.

title: When Love Was In and Youthful Confidence High
description: They arrive in battalions, stretching luminously across an elevated platform at the back of the stage. Swathed in a misty lighting that seems to emanate from inside, as if such an effect might be generated by the percolating hormones, they look just a bit dangerous in their contained, combustible energy. And, boy, wouldn't you like to borrow a little of that glow for yourself?

title: NEW YORK STATE IS SLOW TO SPEND WELFARE WINDFALL

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Receivership Avoided
description: Hynix Semiconductor, formerly Hyundai Electronics, will not go into court receivership, according to both its creditor institutions and the government. Officials sought to end rumors arising from the refusal of creditors to extend fresh credit to the company. Creditors balked at extending repayment on $1.4 billion of nearly $5 billion in debts that Hynix still hopes to repay this year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: U.S. Student Says Russia Tried to Recruit Him
description: An American student imprisoned on marijuana charges in a southwest Russian city asserted in a handwritten note last month that Russian officials set up his arrest in January, then asked him to conduct unspecified work for them.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: State Agency Given Control Of Wetlands
description: Three months after the United States Supreme Court limited the protection of wetlands, the State Assembly voted unanimously to give the State Department of Natural Resources the power to limit development. Wisconsin's 4.2 million acres of isolated wetlands, those not connected to bodies of water, have been largely unregulated since the court ruled that under the Clean Water Act, the Army Corps of Engineers did not have jurisdiction over them. Wisconsin had relied on the corps to regulate its wetlands, and since the court decision, 37 wetlands have been designated as eligible for development. Gov. Scott McCallum, a Republican, has said he will sign the bill. Bill Dedman (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Pact With Coca Growers
description: The government and coca growers have reached an agreement ending three weeks of protests that blocked major highways and threatened the government's stability. The coca growers won concessions to improve working conditions and loan terms for small producers, peasant farmers and teachers. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Asian Employees at Lucent Are Troubled by Handling of Arrests
description: Asian employees of Lucent Technologies and leaders of groups that represent Asian scientists and engineers in the United States expressed concern yesterday over the arrests of three men accused of stealing Lucent trade secrets.

title: World Briefing | The World: Less Money For Contraceptives
description: The head of the United Nations Population Fund said that donations to international agencies for the distribution of contraceptives in poor countries had fallen to the lowest level in five years -- $875 million for this year -- just as AIDS experts are urging wider distribution of condoms as a way to slow the spread of the epidemic. Thoraya Obaid, who became executive director of the population fund last year, said the world must spend $1.8 billion on contraceptives annually to meet global needs by 2015. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Franco, the Newest Captain, Goes Through His Old Routine
description: Bobby Valentine had two duties last night for his team's new captain: take out the lineup card and get the last out of the game. John Franco, who now has a C stitched to his jersey, almost failed to perform them both.

title: Within Its Genre, A Takeoff on Tara Gropes for a Place
description: If you sit down and read ''The Wind Done Gone,'' Alice Randall's controversial ''Gone With the Wind'' takeoff, it's hard to understand how the novel could be considered a ''blatant and wholesale theft'' of ''Gone With the Wind,'' as lawyers for the trusts that own Margaret Mitchell's copyright have contended. Though clumsy, self-important and sometimes laughably silly, ''The Wind Done Gone'' ardently contests the romanticized view of the antebellum South set down in ''Gone With the Wind'' and proposes an Afrocentric version of history in its stead. It is both a commentary on an iconic work of fiction and a repudiation of that novel's worldview.

title: Knicks' Flaws Are Exposed in the End
description: On one defining possession, they all hoisted 3-pointers, desperation jump shots that never had a chance. Allan Houston, Glen Rice and Latrell Sprewell -- the three players most entrusted to score and advance the Knicks in the post-Patrick era -- could not find the range with their season in the balance.

title: Cuomo and McCall Make Pitches to Party
description: A gathering of state Democrats here provided a preview of next year's gubernatorial campaign, as H. Carl McCall and Andrew M. Cuomo both dipped into national politics to make cases for themselves and against Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: National Briefing | Washington: 2 New Nominations Announced
description: President Bush announced his intention to nominate 2 people to serve in his administration this week and formally nominated them and 61 others by sending their names to the Senate for confirmation hearings. Now 102 nominees are awaiting confirmation. The Senate confirmed 8 nominees this week, bringing the total to 40.

title: Pivotal Senators Find Flaws In Fine Print of Budget Plan
description: When Republican lawmakers return to the Capitol next week, they may find that the budget agreement they worked out with the White House this week is not the done deal they thought it was when they left for the weekend.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Merger
description: As expected, the Halifax Group, Britain's biggest mortgage lender, and the Bank of Scotland announced a $26 billion merger to create the fifth-largest of Britain's highly competitive Main Street banks, which include Barclays, Lloyds and HSBC. Existing Halifax shareholders will have 63 percent of the stock in the merged group, to be called HBOS P.L.C., and Halifax executives will fill the top two management positions. The deal is expected to hasten a further takeover of the Abbey National mortgage lender by Lloyds TSB bank. Halifax and Bank of Scotland said they expected cost savings of $420 million from the elimination of 2,000 jobs, 3 percent of the combined work force, over three years. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Sanctions To Hit Liberia Monday
description: New sanctions against Liberia, scheduled to take effect on Monday, were announced by the Security Council president, Ambassador James Cunningham of the United States. The measures include a ban on the import of rough diamonds from Liberia and steps to prevent travel by government officials, including President Charles Taylor. Liberia's diamond purchases from rebels in neighboring Sierra Leone have helped fuel the civil war there. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: For Devils, Winning Will Lead To Revenge
description: Devils Coach Larry Robinson had plenty to worry about today other than Tie Domi. His team won the Stanley Cup last year because his players paid close attention to their assignments. Robinson now sees his players scrambling, as if they were fighter pilots rushing from one dogfight to another.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Infant Mortality Among Blacks
description: Citing a disproportionately high infant mortality rate among blacks in the city, a group of local officials announced a plan yesterday for a $5 million outreach program that City Council officials said they would make a priority in the forthcoming budget negotiations with the Giuliani administration.

title: 223,000 JOBS LOST
description: The American job creation machine went into reverse in April as companies shed employees across much of the weak economy.

description: Most New Yorkers would have no reason to know about it, but in the last five months, the Democratic mayoral candidates have been shuttling around the city, taking questions at often tiny forums, as they tested -- presumably without much public attention -- the themes and appeals for their campaigns.

title: For DiFrancesco, Fighting Words In Deodorant Ad
description: It is not often that the chief executive of a big state demands an apology for a deodorant ad. But Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco appears to have caught Devils fever.

title: U.S. Attacks Rights Group For Ousting It as a Member
description: Bush administration officials said today that the vote removing the United States from the United Nations Human Rights Commission raised questions about the group's commitment to human rights. But the officials vowed that the United States would continue lobbying the body from the sidelines as an observer.

title: Florida's Ballot Reform
description: It took an election debacle of historic proportions to achieve the necessary changes. Even so, Gov. Jeb Bush and leaders of Florida's State Legislature deserve credit for achieving passage of a voting reform package that promises to vault Florida beyond its embarrassing ''hanging chad'' crisis of last November into a leadership role in the effort to modernize voting throughout the country.

title: Chief of America West Plans To Step Down at End of 2002
description: The chairman and chief executive of America West Holdings, who led it out of bankruptcy, will retire when his contract expires at the end of 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, RICHARDSON, JR.
description: PRATT-Richardson, Jr. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation mourn the loss of our dear friend and Board Member, Richardson Pratt, Jr. With passion, commitment and good humor he served as a Trustee for more than eighteen years, ten of those years as the Foundation's Treasurer. Throughout his tenure, Jerry enthusiastically embraced the goals of the Foundations and used his fine intellect and interpersonal skills to advance its purposes. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Jerry's wife, Jan, and to the rest of his family. He was a lovely man and he will be sorely missed. Winthrop R. Munyan, President Margaret C. Ayers, Executive Director

title: Bush, and Democrats, Plan Speeches in Spanish
description: In a tug-of-war for the support of Hispanic voters, President Bush will conduct a version of his weekly radio address in Spanish on Saturday, a Mexican national holiday, and Democratic leaders will respond in kind.

title: Religion Journal; Bahais Prepare to Dedicate a Most Unusual Garden
description: Ask people to envision a work of monumental religious architecture, and most will probably think of some great structure with a lot of history. A medieval cathedral in Europe, an Aztec pyramid, a Mogul-era mosque, maybe the Dalai Lama's palace -- any and all may come to mind.

title: In Racketeering Trial, Well-Dressed Strip Club Takes the Stage
description: For 14 years, the Gold Club has been the destination of choice for a restless segment of the city's huge convention business, clusters of boisterous men footloose in the city and eager to spend those precious evenings away from home in the company of nude dancers and expensive cigars. Shuttle buses to the club leave regularly from the city's best hotels.

description: In the pecking order of the professoriat, Houston A. Baker Jr. ranks somewhere near the top. An expert in African-American studies, he helped found the discipline 30 years ago and now has an endowed chair at Duke University.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Mint Strikes American Buffalo Coin
description: The Indian head nickel is back, in the form of a silver dollar. A ceremony in Denver introduced the American Buffalo commemorative coin, which is based on the nickels that were minted from 1913 to 1938. The new coin has a buffalo on one side and the profile of an American Indian on the other. Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell, Republican of Colorado, who is a Northern Cheyenne chief, sponsored a bill to issue the coin with Representative Frank D. Lucas, Republican of Oklahoma. The United States Mint will sell the coins beginning on June 7. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: A deputy police inspector who just weeks ago was promoted for successfully bringing down crime in his Brooklyn precinct was demoted yesterday amid a federal investigation into accusations he was involved in drug-related misconduct, officials said.

title: Profit Decreases at Insurer
description: BRANCHVILLE, N.J., May 4  The Selective Insurance Group Inc. reported today that its first-quarter profit fell as market conditions in the New Jersey auto insurance market remained unfavorable.

title: Sky Watch: A Martian Rival for Sirius
description: Mars was last mentioned here in September when it was an inconspicuous morning object, rising just before the Sun. Then, Mars was dim because it was more than 230 million miles from Earth. Now, however, its distance from Earth has shrunk considerably.

title: Richardson Pratt Jr., 78; Led Pratt Institute
description: Richardson Pratt Jr., a former president of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn and chairman of Charles Pratt & Company, which was established in 1891 to oversee the Pratt family interests, died Tuesday at his home in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. He was 78.

title: Abroad at Home; A Regime Of Thugs
description: The title of worst government on earth the most brutal, destructive, lawless -- can probably be claimed today by Robert Mugabe's regime in Zimbabwe. Mr. Mugabe has turned a prosperous country into a land of chaos and desperation.

title: Theodore Roosevelt III; Brokerage Partner, 86
description: Theodore Roosevelt III, a grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt and former partner in a Philadelphia brokerage firm, died on Wednesday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 86.

title: Micrel to Acquire Kendin Communications
description: Micrel Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer, agreed to buy Kendin Communications Inc. for about $215 million in stock in an effort to gain a business that designs chips for communications and computer networking equipment.

title: Britain Found to Violate Rights in Ulster Cases
description: The European Court of Human Rights ruled today that Britain violated the human rights of 10 members of the Irish Republican Army and two civilians shot to death by security forces in Northern Ireland in the 1980's and early '90's.

title: RAMBUS, COMPUTER CHIP DESIGNER, LOSES PATENT CASE
description: Rambus Inc., which designs high-speed computer chips, lost a patent infringement case against Infineon Technologies yesterday. Judge Robert Payne of United States District Court, who dismissed 54 claims on Tuesday, threw out three remaining claims yesterday. Stock in Rambus, which is based in Los Altos, Calif., fell $3.55, or 20 percent, to $14.60 a share on Nasdaq, where it led the list of percentage losers. Eight companies, controlling almost half the world's memory chip sales, have already bought licenses from Rambus and now may stop paying in light of the ruling. ''We are disappointed with the court's decision and plan to appeal,'' said Rambus's chief executive, Geoff Tate.

title: Jefferson Smurfit Investors Confront Board at Meeting
description: Gone, evidently, are the days when the annual meetings of Ireland's blue-chip companies were placid affairs attended by retirees who showed up as much for the free sandwiches as for the financial outlook.

title: 3rd Set of Genes Used In Fertility Treatment
description: Some babies born from a new method used to treat a rare form of infertility have genes from three different people in their cells, researchers are reporting. They found the extra genes in babies born to women who were injected with other women's cytoplasm, the material that surrounds the nucleus of eggs.

title: Move in Shooting Case
description: The United States Justice Department has offered to help the authorities here with their investigation into the Monday shooting death of an unarmed man by an Irvington police officer.

description: LEE ABRAHAMS-Nita. 1949-1989. With your eyes we saw the beauty & with your spirit we experienced the joy. Your loving Family

title: Old Fuels And Poor Policy
description: The Bush administration's energy policy, centered primarily on increasing the supply of oil, coal and nuclear power, is shortsighted and misaimed, focusing too much on the wrong fuels and too firmly on supply.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Investigators See Missionaries' Plane
description: American and Peruvian investigators inspected the fuselage of an American missionary plane downed last month by the Peruvian Air Force, killing an American woman and her baby. Antidrug flights have been suspended in Peru and Colombia pending the results of an investigation into why the plane was identified as a drug-carrying plane and shot down. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: A Ban on Punch Cards And a Lull in Division
description: The last time Florida lawmakers met to consider election law, they split bitterly on partisan lines. Democrats angrily demanded that ''every vote be counted'' in the presidential election and Republicans fiercely defended the laws, waving off concerns about undervotes and threatening to defy the courts by naming their own slate to the Electoral College.

title: Decision Delayed On Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry must wait until May 17 to find out if he will be imprisoned for violating his probation for the third time.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline climbed as supply disruptions in the Midwest increased concern that inventories will be low this summer. In New York, gasoline for June delivery rose 1.32 cents, to $1.0843 a gallon.

title: Houston Fades Out With Game on Line
description: Allan Houston faded from leading scorer to invisible All-Star last night, shrinking into the off-season with unsettling thoughts of his disappearance.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about museums dedicated to spying and the cold war misstated the location of a Titan missile complex that has been preserved by the Pima Air Museum. It is near Green Valley, Ariz., not Green River.

title: Maple Leafs' Domi Draws Suspension For Rest of Playoffs
description: When the Devils meet the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight at Continental Arena for Game 5, each team will be without a significant player for different reasons that are intertwined. The Maple Leafs will not have Tie Domi, their aggressive right wing, who was suspended yesterday by the National Hockey League for at least the remainder of the Stanley Cup tournament.

title: In Athens, Pope Seeks to Mend An Ancient Rift
description: John Paul II tried to mend the ancient rift with the Orthodox faith today by expressing ''deep regret'' for the misdeeds of the Roman Catholic Church as he made the first papal visit to Greece since the churches were one.

title: Otis L. Guernsey Jr., 82, Editor and Critic
description: Otis L. Guernsey Jr., whose love affair with theater led to 36 years of chronicling its achievements as editor of the annual ''Best Plays'' volumes, died on Wednesday at his home in Woodstock, Vt. He was 82.

title: Seeking Traction in Jamesian Fluidity
description: The golden bowl that supplies the title of Henry James's final novel -- and its new film version by Merchant-Ivory -- bears more weight than its gold-plated crystal might suggest. The bowl is found by two former lovers in an obscure Bloomsbury shop. The man, a poverty-stricken Italian prince, is about to be married to an American heiress. Yet there are intimations that the couple, while shopping for a gift for the bride, may be secretly planning to give one to each other. They spend hours in the shop, picking over the detritus of squandered Old World prosperity -- ornaments, lockets, buckles, worthless pearls, poorly set diamonds, objects worth less than old pawn tickets -- until finally, they are shown the bowl. It appears to be solid gold, but as the dealer gradually concedes, it is just gold-plated crystal. Moreover, the plating hides a flaw that might never be discovered.

title: Decision on Forest Rules Spurs Concern About Implementation
description: The White House's decision to put in place a Clinton administration rule to protect national forests but allow changes to be made locally kindled a tense and unsettled debate today over how the rule would be carried out.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Taliban Unleashes Offensive
description: A major Taliban offensive has sent the opposition into retreat in fighting near the city of Bamiyan, according to spokesmen for the opposition forces led by Ahmad Shah Massoud. In recent years, the Taliban has begun major pushes for territory soon after the spring thaw opens the roads of snowbound mountain passes. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Weekender Rates at SRS-Worldhotels
description: Weekend getaways are usually close to home, and SRS-Worldhotels, with more than 250 participating properties, probably has something not too far away with its Weekender rates. The rates, available throughout this year, represent savings as high as 50 percent. (Be sure to check individual hotels directly to comparison shop.) Depending on the hotel, rates could include tax and daily breakfast. Sample discounted weekend rates (available Friday through Sunday nights, based on availability and with some blackout dates): the Hotel Monteleone in New Orleans, $165; Burnsley All-Suite in Denver, $109; the Hampshire in New York, $109; the Celebration in Orlando, $169. In Europe, the Hotel Ametyst in Prague is $165; the Royal Santina, Rome, is $139; the Kensington in London, $146; and the Husa Princess in Madrid, $128. Participating hotels in the Asia-Pacific area include the Elizabeth in Singapore, $88; the Pan Pacific in Manila, $75; the Furama in Hong Kong, $201; and the Caravelle in Ho Chi Minh City, $78. Information: (800) 223-5652 or www.srs-worldhotels.com .

description: As governor of Wisconsin, Tommy G. Thompson complained mightily about a federal bureaucracy that was too controlling, too inflexible, too slow. As secretary of health and human services, he is now in the belly of the beast.

description: RUBINSTEIN-Max. The Officers and Board of The City of Hope Sadie Rubinstein Chapter extend heartfelt sympathy to the Rubinstein family. Max, you will be missed.

title: Sports of The Times; Tinker Here, Cajole There, And Presto
description: YOU tend to take Lenny Wilkens for granted. A player from 1960 to 1975 and a head coach since 1969, he has been in the National Basketball Association for so many lifetimes that he's become like the myth of the mighty Mississippi: always been there, goes on forever it seems, no beginning, no end.

title: Monarchos Strategy Was Geared for Derby
description: They stuck to their mantra when their colt, Monarchos, catapulted to a 4 1/2-length victory in the Florida Derby and was hailed as the best and brightest Kentucky Derby prospect there. They stuck to it after the Wood Memorial, when Monarchos finished second by nearly three lengths to Congaree and was dismissed as a promising prospect who peaked too early.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the settlement of lawsuits that accused William Warren, former president of Monster.com, and 18 other former employees of stealing information and trade secrets before joining WOWemployers, a competing company founded by Mr. Warren, misstated a provision. WOWemployers is not barred from soliciting Monster.com clients.

title: Learning From the Diallo Case
description: The 41 shots that New York City police officers fired at Amadou Diallo two years ago have become a graphic reminder of the disparate risks that black Americans face during encounters with the law. The four white officers who killed Mr. Diallo, who was unarmed, were acquitted of criminal charges in a closely watched trial last year. The United States Justice Department later decided that federal civil rights charges were unwarranted in the case. But Police Commissioner Bernard Kerik made the right call when he assigned the officers to desk duty, taking away their guns and shields.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   L.A.P.
description: L.A.P. February 4, 1944-May 5, 1991 ''Whatever we were to each other, that we are still.''

title: What, Us Worry?; Layoff: A Spring Break For Some In the Dot-Com Generation
description: Until he was laid off in February, Andrew H. Way oversaw customer service and some sales operations at an Internet company, an $85,000-a-year job that demanded 12-hour days. But lately, since moving to Seattle, he has centered his life around snowboarding in the nearby Cascade Mountains, where he plans to spend the summer hiking and fishing.

title: Levy Punishes Four Involved In '98 Inquiry
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday disciplined four current or former public school employees involved in a mishandled 1998 inquiry into allegations of sexual assault by a second-grade teacher at Public School 78 in the Bronx. He also ordered a review of all allegations of sexual abuse investigated by the Board of Education over the last three years.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Thursday about a man who pleaded guilty to the rape of a homeless woman omitted a comment from the Coalition for the Homeless, which operates the office where Queens prosecutors said the man had been a volunteer and met his victim. Patrick Markee, a spokesman for the coalition, said that while the defendant might once have been a client, he had never been a volunteer.

description: Face-Recognition Systems OfferNew Tools, but Mixed Results

title: World Business Briefing | Philippines: Philippines: Battle for Brewer
description: Conciliation was in the air after the chairman of San Miguel, Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., left, held off a government bid to oust him at the company's annual shareholders meeting. Mr. Cojuangco, a close friend of two ousted presidents, Joseph E. Estrada and Ferdinand E. Marcos, said he was eager to talk with the administation of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo about how to end a 15-year dispute over who controls 47 percent of San Miguel, the country's largest brewer. Ms. Arroyo has vowed to stamp out cronyism, and government pension funds had sought control of the disputed stake to win control of San Miguel. The funds vowed to continue fighting, but Ms. Arroyo said she had no plan to unseat Mr. Cojuangco. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Avon to Expand Retail Outlets
description: Avon Products Inc., which plans to begin selling cosmetics in 195 J.C. Penney and Sears, Roebuckcoei stores in August, expects to have 800 retail outlets next year.

title: Cuban Official Dismisses Chance Of Improved Relations With U.S.
description: A top official has dismissed any chance for improved relations with the United States. But the official, Ricardo Alarcn, insisted that any toughening of Bush administration policy on Cuba would prove as fruitless as past efforts.

title: Democrats Enter Legal Battle Over Rescheduling of Primary
description: Even as a state judge rejected Bret D. Schundler's effort to block Bob Franks from the Republican primary, help for Mr. Schundler arrived today from an unlikely ally: the New Jersey Democratic Committee.

(Sonia) Rapaport, Rose (Morris) Teicher, Anne (Sidney) Serotte; Grandfather of Michael I. Rapaport; Step-Grandfather of Sheryl L., Laura D. and Robert A. DiPirro. Mr. Rapaport was business manager of the Central Brooklyn Medical Group of H.I.P.

title: Grass Is Gone on Other Side of These Fences
description: Barbara Porter was the first to cross the line, and it was very much a premeditated act. She had reached her limit with the mowing, the mulching, the weeding, the watering, the fertilizing, the thatching, the whole range of green lawn pathologies. Finally, she took hoe to turf, hacking away -- and it felt good.

title: Zambia's President Abandons Re-election Bid
description: With his party in revolt over his bid for another five years in office, President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia said tonight that he would abandon his effort to change the Constitution's two-term limit and would step down when his second term ends later this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a visit by the President of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, to her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, misstated the given name of a leading opposition politician who was detained this week after an unsuccessful uprising by Mr. Estrada's supporters. He is Juan Ponce Enrile, not Jose.

title: Champs Share Laugh With Bush
description: Most of the Yankees had been to the White House at least once already, and some would have probably preferred to sleep in and bypass the trip. But after President Bush took them through the Oval Office, after he playfully teased the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, some players told Manager Joe Torre what a great time they had today.

title: State Suspends License of a Prominent Doctor at Methodist
description: The New York State Commissioner of Health has suspended the license of the president of the medical board of New York Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, calling the doctor, who has a large surgery practice there, a danger to patients.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose after the United States economy unexpectedly lost jobs last month, fueling speculation that growth is still flagging. In New York, the euro settled at 89.53 cents, up from 89 cents on Thursday.

title: Corrections

title: Meat Plants Fare Badly In Inspections
description: Special teams of inspectors found unsanitary conditions at 22 of the 44 meat-processing plants examined during a recent investigation of safety problems in New York City and northern New Jersey, federal officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Museums section on Wednesday about the American Museum of the Moving Image misstated its address. As noted in a listing with the article, it is at 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens; 34-12 36th Street is its former address.

title: Grocers Pull Ads After Articles on Cleanliness
description: At least two supermarket chains, Gristede's and Associated Supermarkets, have withdrawn their advertising indefinitely from The Daily News, following the newspaper's publication of articles about cleanliness or the lack of it at local stores.

title: The Whys and Wherefores Of Conventions on CD-ROM
description: Hundreds of books and booklets have been written about conventions, but the average player has difficulty absorbing the information. The authors seldom describe how to handle intervention, how to defend against the conventions or what you give up by adopting them.

title: Mets Appeal Beanball Fines
description: Reliever Turk Wendell was fined $1,250 by Major League Baseball, which said he intentionally threw behind the St. Louis Cardinals' Mike Matheny last Saturday. Wendell, who was ejected from the game, maintained that he did not throw at Matheny on purpose and said he would appeal the fine to Frank Robinson, baseball's vice president for on-field operations.

Mishkin and Susan Fine. Devoted grandfather of Sarah, Naomi, Allison, Benjamin & Pamela Mishkin. Longtime professor at Polytechnic University. The Shiva will be at his home, 136 Hicks St., Brooklyn, Saturday night, Sunday, Monday night and Tuesday night. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to either the American Technion Society or Polytechnic University.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Thursday about a law denying federal aid to students convicted of drug charges gave an erroneous surname in some copies for a Cincinnati man whose conviction cost him college aid. He is Russell Selkirk, not Selker.

title: Sports of The Times; Bob Baffert And Family Riding Tall
description: EVERYBODY wants to see the Bafferts these days. It is a heady time for a family that worked hard on the small quarter-horse tracks of the Southwest to get where they are today.

title: BLANK SLATE -- Greeting the Governor; Charter School Class Gets a First-Hand Social Studies Lesson
description: Just a typical day in sixth grade social studies. Only it's a double period, usually reserved for reading or math. And it's in the science classroom, which has more space. The American and New York State flags are flanking the chalkboard, the school banner hanging above them, klieg lights shining on them from the back.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Fight Over Treaty Looms
description: Ireland moved closer to a divisive national debate on foreign policy as the Senate approved the European Union's Treaty of Nice, which sets the terms for expanding membership to include Central and Eastern European countries. The treaty is likely to be approved in most European Union countries, but the Irish Constitution requires a referendum to ratify it and many groups oppose its provisions for a Europe-wide military force, saying it would compromise Ireland's traditional neutrality. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Knicks Exit, Heads Shaking
description: With 33 seconds remaining in the Knicks' season, Latrell Sprewell stood at midcourt, staring at his teammates. His arms were spread wide as he wore a dumbfounded look. He was wondering about a recent turnover, but his frustration applied to much of the game:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Broken Deal Hits Stock
description: The day after a French court blocked a friendly $7 billion takeover of Legrand, an electrical equipment maker, by a rival, Schneider Electric, investors punished both companies' ordinary shares: Legrand's fell 7 percent, Schneider's, 4 percent. But investors bid up Legrand preferred shares almost 8 percent, apparently betting that Schneider will sweeten its bid for the preferred. The court blocked the original deal in response to shareholder complaints that Schneider's bid, which valued the preferred shares at a 43 percent discount to the ordinary shares, was unfair. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Ulysses, Maybe. But Don't Call Me Ishmael.
description: To the Editor:

title: In Rockland Suburb, Deep Racial Change Melts Into the Everyday
description: In the 1960s, this unassuming bedroom community in Rockland County attracted secular Jews from Brooklyn and the Bronx. They liked the affordable starter homes, the suburban hush and the bearable commute. In the 1990s, Hillcrest attracted immigrants from Asia and the Caribbean, often by way of Brooklyn or the Bronx. They liked the affordable starter homes, the suburban hush and the bearable commute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIDLER, BEATRICE R.
description: FIDLER-Beatrice R. Died on Friday, May 4, 2001 as she approached her 100th birthday. Widow of Irving. Beloved mother of Roy and Jay. Adoring grandmother of Shelley, Meg, Josh, Lisa, and Matthew. Loving great-grandmother of Ali, Drew, Mica, Aaron, and Jake. Services Sunday, May 6, 10:00 AM at ''the Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Cuttings: An Early Bloomer That Hasn't Finished Its Show
description: THE hellebores have just about finished their long blooming season in my garden, but their show is by no means over. In a shade garden it is character, not color, that sustains the gardener through the leafy summer. The columbines will float on delicate stems above the ferns and foam flowers, the little yellow foxgloves will shine in the dappled light, and the Japanese anemones will come along in good time, but the hellebores are the anchors in my backyard, the off-center centerpieces of what people with sunny gardens have the privilege of calling their flower beds.

title: An Alabama Prosecutor Confronts the Burden of History
description: IT barely registered with 9-year-old Doug Jones in the fall of 1963 that a bomb had exploded in a black church down the road in Birmingham, killing four girls just a few years older than he was. Growing up white in the segregated suburb of Fairfield, he had other concerns.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Detroit Police Chief Won't Run For Mayor
description: The Detroit police chief, Benny N. Napoleon, announced that he would not run for mayor. Mr. Napoleon said his friendship with Gil Hill, the City Council president and a mayoral candidate, was more important than the race. He did not say whom he would endorse. Last week, Mr. Napoleon announced that he would resign in January when Mayor Dennis Archer ends his term. Mr. Archer appointed Mr. Napoleon as chief in 1998. In the last year, the Justice Department has investigated the Police Department's high numbers of police shootings and its practice of arresting homicide witnesses. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Surviving 'Survivor' With Ms. Nice Gal
description: Malnutrition, second-degree burns, a slaughtered boar, hair falling out in clumps -- all that and still the thrill was gone from the second season of ''Survivor.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISSEMANN, CHARLES HENRY
description: WISSEMANN-Charles Henry. Of Southold, New York. Previously of Richmond Hill and Queens Village. Father of Charles, Diane and Peter. Grandfather of 10, great grandfather of 13.

title: Tyson Is Suing for Shot at Titles
description: Mike Tyson is suing the World Boxing Council to prevent an immediate rematch between Hasim Rahman and Lennox Lewis in hopes that he can fight Rahman first for a chance to win two heavyweight titles.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Senator Will Stick With Democrats
description: Senator Zell Miller denied rumors printed in an Atlanta political newsletter that he was considering switching to the Republican Party from the Democratic. ''I have no plans at this time of changing parties,'' he said in a statement. Mr. Miller won the seat last year after promising to vote in a nonpartisan way and shying away from Al Gore's campaign, but he has infuriated many Democrats by following through on his pledge and supporting President Bush's tax cut plan. David Firestone (NYT)

title: General's Confessions Of Torture Stun France
description: PARIS  A retired French Army general's confession that he and others tortured and murdered victims as a matter of routine during the Algerian civil war is shaking the highest level of state in France, with President Jacques Chirac stating Friday that he was "horrified" by the revelations and disposed to punish the 83-year-old former officer.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Deaths Linked To Tainted Water
description: Health officials say contamination of the water system in North Battleford, Saskatchewan, may have caused the death of 3 people and the illness of 100. Residents have been advised to boil water for a second week since parasites seeped into the drinking water. A year ago, 7 people died and 2,300 became ill in Walkerton, Ontario, after bacteria entered the town's water supply. A commission is investigating Canada's drinking water supplies and the qualifications of officials who run local water systems. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Second Well Comes In
description: The consortium of international oil companies exploring the Kashagan field in the Caspian Sea said that it had struck oil in a second well, supporting estimates that Kashagan may be the largest find in 30 years. The new well yielded oil at 3,400 barrels a day and gas at 7.6 million cubic feet a day, according to ENI of Italy, the consortium member chosen to manage the field. Drilling work was interrupted last month by a minor oil spill. Birgit Brauer (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a visit by the President of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, to her jailed predecessor, Joseph Estrada, misstated the given name of a leading opposition politician who was detained this week after an unsuccessful uprising by Mr. Estrada's supporters. He is Juan Ponce Enrile, not Jose.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Stake Sale
description: Desperate to reduce $43 billion in debt, British Telecommunications said it would raise $500 million by selling its 33 percent stake in the Maxis Communications mobile phone operator of Malaysia to Usaha Tegas, the company's largest shareholder. The announcement followed British Telecom's $6.9 billion sale this week of stakes in major Japanese and Spanish wireless businesses to its rival Vodafone. Investors also expect British Telecom to embark on an emergency rights issue of new equity to raise about $7 billion as it seeks to cut debt by one-third. The discounted rights issue would be the biggest in Britain's corporate history, eclipsing a similar move this week by Vodafone, which raised $5 billion to finance its acquisitions in Japan and Spain. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: A Seat At The Table For Hadassah
description: After a three-year struggle to overcome Arab objections, Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization in America, has been accredited as a nongovernmental organization at the United Nations. The organization, which supports medical, educational and environmental projects in the Mideast, can now attend meetings and conferences not limited to official delegations. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Brill's Content to Trim Publishing Schedule
description: Reversing plans announced a month ago, Brill's Content, the magazine about the media, will not change its name to Inside Content. It will keep its name, Steven Brill, the magazine's founder, said yesterday, but it will no longer be published 10 times a year, emerging in the fall, after a summer hiatus, as a quarterly magazine.

title: Volunteer Tied to Arson At Firehouse In Bellmore
description: A teenage volunteer firefighter was charged with arson today in a fire Thursday inside the Bellmore firehouse that caused about $1 million in damage. The authorities said he was a suspect in four other arsons in and around the firehouse in the last 18 months, the period for which he has been a Bellmore firefighter.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Manila Quiets Down
description: The Philippine defense secretary, Angelo Reyes, said he would call troops off the streets of Manila in the next few days because the political situation was stabilizing. ''We're over the hump,'' Mr. Reyes said. The move came three days after President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo declared a ''state of rebellion'' when 40,000 protesters stormed the presidential palace in support of her ousted predecessor, Joseph Estrada. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Shay Romps in Big East Meet
description: The senior Ryan Shay breezed to victory in the 10,000-meter run today to bolster Notre Dame's bid to repeat as men's champion at the Big East track and field championships.

title: Redesigned Red Buses Tour Manhattan Streets
description: Gray Line New York has introduced a new style of sightseeing bus to New York City. The bright red buses do not look much different from the double-deckers that returned to the city in 1991 after a hiatus of about 30 years, but the new model is the first redesign since shortly after World War II of the Scottish-made buses that have long been familiar in London, Hong Kong and Singapore. The changes include wheelchair accessibility, better driver visibility through a larger windshield and reduced emissions from a more powerful engine.

title: Language Lessons
description: To the Editor: Not all language school experiences are as positive as those of Sarah and Glenn Collins (''A Classroom With Quiche at the Bell,'' April 8). In Montpellier, France, my wife and I took a month of lessons at a school recommended by locals. My intermediate-level class was above my ability, but the school offered nothing between that and my wife's ''dbutante'' class.

title: Bayern Munich Remembers Barcelona
description: ''There are no style points in ftbol,'' Real Madrid Coach Vicente del Bosque said, declining the opportunity to denigrate a dirty job very well done.

title: April 29-May 5; A Closer European Union
description: Most European leaders agree that the 15-member European Union will only grow more unwieldy if it expands to include nations in central Europe. But many blanched when Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schrder, proposed that Europe become more like a single country, with a powerful parliament and executive branch. The plan drew barbed criticism from France, which is fiercely protective of its national sovereignty, and it is likely to run into hostility from Euro-skeptics in Britain and perhaps Scandinavia. Edmund L. Andrews

title: A Midwifery Practice That's Not Just About Birth
description: Laura Cross and Kathy Herron's midwifery practice is called Full Circle Women's Health for a reason. Based in Croton-on-Hudson, this independent private practice provides care to women throughout their reproductive cycle, from puberty to menopause.

title: When Misery Doesn't Love Company
description: I CAN always count on having fun with my friend Laura. She appeals to the side of me that likes to walk on the wild side, doubled up with laughter. If we were still in grade school, we'd be separated by the teacher and probably forced to lay our heads on the desk until we could behave. Recently we had to quit our book club when our wisecracks during discussions of great literature met with a frosty reception.

description: Maybe it's the air in Flushing. No, on second thought, it can't be the air in Flushing. Maybe it's the rhythmic rumble of the No. 7 train that chugs by periodically beyond the right-field fence. No, cross that one off, too. The planes flying overhead? Be serious. They would pose more of a distraction than anything.

title: The Proles and Nobs Cavort in a Fresh 'Fair Lady'
description: ONE representative segment of the British people leaps about the stage in colorful caps and waistcoats, bonnets and shawls, using pots and kettles as cymbals and making a triumphant clatter with the dustbin lids that, strapped to their feet, double as tap shoes. Another glides on in elegantly exotic Edwardian blacks and does a high-stepping trot that escalates into a stately canter, like a set of overbred ponies sedately flaunting their dressage skills.

title: Political Briefing; California G.O.P. Wary of Initiative
description: Republicans are close to being an endangered species in California -- Democrats control the Legislature, most Congressional seats and all but one statewide elective job -- and a main reason is that in recent years Republicans have backed a number of ballot initiatives that struck many voters as discriminatory.

description: FOUR questions could be posed to the bipartisan commission that President Bush appointed last week to devise a plan for personal investment accounts in Social Security:

description: SILVERSTEIN-Beatrice. Beloved wife of Joseph. Mother of Mark and daughter-in-law Aline. Always in our thoughts.

title: INVESTING WITH/Andrew P. Pilara Jr.; RS Partners Fund
description: LIKE many Californians, Andrew P. Pilara Jr. received an office memorandum recently advising that elevator service would be curtailed, lighting reduced and other steps taken to minimize energy use. Even though blackouts have slowed traffic and shut down high-technology factories, the California energy crisis has a bright side for Mr. Pilara, who runs the $55 million RS Partners fund.

title: The World; Modern Asia's Anomaly: The Girls Who Don't Get Born
description: WOMEN are making strides in both India and China, which together are home to a third of humanity. They are living longer and are more likely to be able to read and write than ever before. In democratic India, more than a million women have been elected to village councils in the past decade.

title: Footlights; A Debut for New Jersey Filmmaker
description: For Michael Fiore, an emerging New Jersey filmmaker who cites Hitchcock and Robert Zemeckis as influences and who often roots his films in a dusky world of illusion and suspense, tonight makes for an enviable inaugural. At 11 p.m., ''Cadaverous,'' the award-winning film he made for his thesis at New York University, makes its national television debut on ''Exposure,'' a weekly Sci-Fi Channel showcase of what Mr. Fiore dubs ''the best of the best of current suspense, horror and sci-fi short films.''

title: POSTINGS: Relics of a Residential E. 55th Street; 2 Town Houses Landmarked
description: Midtown is about the last place anyone would look for single-family town houses. But they are there to be found, recalling the early 20th century when the mid-Manhattan side streets were ''filled with fashionable residences,'' in the words of Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, which designated two ''rare survivors'' on Tuesday.

title: Gathering Laurels
description: EVENING HOURS Correction: May 13, 2001, Sunday A picture caption in the Evening Hours column last Sunday about an awards luncheon for the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy misidentified an official of the group. She was Regina Peruggi, the new president of the conservancy, not Suzanne Cochran, who will become the president of the women's committee in October.

title: New Nonstop Flights: New York to Caymans
description: For the first time in nine years travelers can fly nonstop from New York to the Cayman Islands -- on Delta Air Lines or Continental Airlines. Delta offers daily service from Kennedy Airport, and Continental flies on Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday and Sunday from Newark International Airport.

title: Quality Time? You're Soaking In It
description: As the big day approaches, the beauty industry is pushing the ''pamper Mom'' angle with alacrity. Elizabeth Arden Red Door Salon and Spa, 691 Fifth Avenue (54th Street), is trotting out beauty products for mothers, chock full of comfort ingredients like mint, tangerine, cream and sugar; Donna Karan's Cashmere Mist product line has a Wrapped in Cashmere kit for Mom, containing body polishing cream, shampoo, body oil and other unguents. And the new Susan Ciminelli Spa at Bergdorf Goodman is offering mother-minded services, like a one-hour prenatal massage ($115) or mother-to-be reflexology ($105 for one hour). For $265, mothers and daughters can receive tandem manicures and pedicures, along with a box of three products from Ms. Ciminelli's beauty line. What better than an hour or so of sharing tips and bonding?

title: Investing Diary: Union Tries New Route in Eastman Kodak Vote
description: This time, Bill Bradley, the former senator and basketball star whose bid for the Democratic presidential nomination fell short last year, is almost certain to win an election. But millions of union members, a natural constituency, will not be supporting him.

title: A Second Act Far Healthier Than the First
description: THOMAS CUPP has thrown away many of his 49 years, taking what he terms the perfect childhood and parlaying it into a career as a drug abuser, con man, cocaine dealer and ballroom dance champion. That was before he ran into the law, his body's frailties and God.

title: Closing the Season at Fleetwood Stage, 'A Coupla White Chicks . . .'
description: WHY a secondhand play like ''A Coupla White Chicks Sitting Around Talking'' is closing the season at Fleetwood Stage, right here, right now, is hard to figure. Here is a thing of the past, being passed off as a cause for present concern and present laughter.

title: Why Mortgage Rates Aren't Even Better
description: DELIGHTED though they may be at the potential business, mortgage brokers are grinding their teeth, frustrated by a bulging loan-application pipeline that was jammed, at first, by refinance fence-sitters waiting for that optimal interest rate, followed around April 15 by tax write-off seekers urged on by their accountants, and in recent weeks by Fed rate-cut dreamers.

title: DataBank; Mostly Bad News Draws Mostly Cheers
description: Stocks ended the week on a high note as a weaker-than-expected employment report had investors guessing that the Federal Reserve would continue cutting interest rates to stave off a recession.

title: Foes of War Say Kerrey Was a Victim Too
description: IF there were condemnations coming, one might expect them to come from this crevice of the city, filled with yellowed memorabilia denouncing the Vietnam War and home to an equally yellow cat named Rusty, after the pacifist and civil rights leader Bayard Rustin.

title: A Campaign to Harbor The City's Little Outlaws
description: The e-mail started again at the end of April. ''Full City Council Vote Is Only 2 Weeks Away!'' screamed a message seeking volunteers and supplies for a letter-writing campaign. ''We have enough Xerox volunteers!'' read the next day's bulletin. ''What we really need now is stamps!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKEL, EDWARD
description: FINKEL-Edward. Son of Julius and Tamara Finkel, a pioneer in the development and manufacture of television antennas and electronic components, died Saturday morning at 4:45AM at the age of 81. Mr. Finkel, along with his father Julius and his six brothers, employed over one thousand people in building JFD Electronics into one of the world's largest manufacturers of indoor and outdoor antennas, including the famous ''rabbit ears'' antennas that came with virtually every TV set sold in the US in the 50's and 60's. Mr. Finkel is survived by his first wife, Johanna Gillman, an accomplished artist, his second wife, Elaine Land, owner of Ted Land Shoes of Palm Springs, his sons Todd and Glen, his daughter Randii and his seven grandchildren. Edward Finkel was loving, generous and supportive, especially to his family and many friends. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. (corner of Amsterdam Avenue) on Monday, May 7, 2001 at 11:15AM.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-6-01: On Language; Fulminations
description: The specialists are in open rebellion at the theft of their vocabularies. Egged on by sly agitation in this space to fulminate about raids by the general public on their fields' linguistic larders, the specialists have at last found an outlet for their ire at the twisting of their favorite terms.

Third son of Max and Ida Rose Landay, survived by wife Carolyn; children, Vincent, Mark, James and Roseanne; brother, Robert; and grandchildren, Siena and Gabriella. In lieu of flowers, make donations to: Interfaith Hunger Appeal, c/o Church World Services, 475 Riverside Dr, #

description: Both mayoral candidates who want to govern this downtrodden city, the poorest in New Jersey, say Tuesday's nonpartisan election is the most crucial in city history.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-6-01: Chart; Patchwork Genes
description: Some people look at the wonder of human diversity and see a gorgeous mosaic. Others see proof of God's handiwork. But more and more biotechnology companies see a business opportunity. In particular, they are interested in populations around the world that have a higher-than-average concentration of rare genetic diseases. The hope is that by studying these people's unusual chromosomal arrangements, scientists will be able to gain insight into the nature of the disease and develop a cure. But lest there be any dispute about the profits that might result, some companies have gone so far as to purchase the rights to these populations' genes. Herewith, a sampling of ethnic genetic variation, adapted from the coming book ''Your Genetic Destiny: Know Your Genes, Secure Your Health, Save Your Life,'' by Aubrey Milunsky, M.D., D.Sc. (Perseus Publishing, 2001).

title: A Glimpse Through the Walls of Privacy
description: FOR most New Yorkers, May 20, 1995 was probably just a sunny Saturday in the spring. For Barbara Bloom, a wryly provocative installation artist of international stature who was soon to open an exhibition at the Leo Castelli Gallery in SoHo, the afternoon seemed made for a favorite avocation -- window gardening. At least that is what she had in mind when she stepped onto the deeply recessed sill of a window of her TriBeCa loft, intent on training a few vines to climb around a trellis just outside.

title: Streetscapes/17 East 47th Street; The Mercantile Library Finds a New Literary Life
description: A DECADE ago a nonlibrarian, Harold Augenbraum, set out to revitalize the Mercantile Library, a paying-membership institution at 17 East 47th Street that had a distinguished history and empty pockets. Since then, Mr. Augenbraum said, he and the trustees have increased the membership and the endowment as well as the library's literary activities, renovated its ground floor and cleaned its elegant white marble facade.

title: Troubles for Campaign Reform
description: Campaign finance reform commands majority support in the House. Yet legislation that the Senate approved last month faces a troubling array of obstacles. On the Republican side, Speaker Dennis Hastert says he will not allow the bill to go to the House floor until late summer, an unnecessary delay. On the Democratic side, some lawmakers appear to be getting cold feet about a bill they have long supported. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSCHREIBER, SELVEN F.
description: FEINSCHREIBER-Selven F. Was a member and President of the first graduating class of Long Island University as well as President of the Alumni Association in later years. He received his JD from Brooklyn Law School in 1935 and became a member of the New York Bar in 1936. He had the distinction of working for Fannie Holtzman, Esquire, with whom he represented media figures including Robert Alda and a number of television shows. He was the first male attorney to work as an assistant to a female attorney. He was a member of Africa House where he met and worked with Eleanor Roosevelt. Starting in 1956, he was the Registered Agent for: King George Rukidi, the Omakama of Toro, Uganda; Ghana Ministry of Trade and Labor; Rukurato Drafting Committee, Kingdom of Toro; Uganda Ministry of Minerals and Water Resources; His Highness Prince Aserate Kassa, GovernorGeneral of Eritrea; and, Cuthbert J. Obwangor, Minister of Justice of Uganda. He wrote the original Ugandan Constitution in 1962, negotiated Uganda's independence from the United Kingdom, and advised President Milton Obote. Mr. Feinschreiber was friendly with and offered advice to President Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana; President Nnamdi Azikiwe of Nigeria; President Jomo Kenyatta of Kenya; the Kabaka of Buganda; the Omugabe of Ankole, Uganda; King Henry Muloki, Kyabazinga of Busoga; President Idi Amin, Uganda; and, King Mwami Mutara Rudahigwa of Rwanda. He represented the Sudan in a United Nations conference in Geneva regarding the International Law of the Sea. Mr. Feinschreiber was advisor to the Archbishop of Haiti in 1966 then advisor to NBC International Instructional Television and Chairman of the Board for Instructional TV Systems Corp, NYC. He was the Chairman of Americans by Choice, Inc. and is credited by Senator Larry Pressler as the originator of Ethnic American Day, proclaimed by President Reagan to be September 21, 1986. Mr. Feinschreiber was born in Vilna (Vilnus) Lithuania but lived most of his life in New York. His first wife, Maxine Borodkin, died in 1980. Two children were born of that marriage. Mr. Feinschreiber moved to Key Biscayne, Florida upon his retirement. He is survived by his wife Patricia Barnett Feinschreiber, his son Robert married to Margaret Kent, his daughter Margery Glickman married to Fred Glickman, his stepsons Charles and Thomas, five grandchildren and two great grandchildren.

description: left my home in Vit&#243ria, a city in southeastern Brazil, and took a 16-hour bus ride to S&#227o Paulo. I had to pawn my house and a plot of land in Vitoria to raise the $8,000 needed to pay the coyotes that smuggled me to the United States. But I didn't find a job when I got here. Instead, I ended up in this health center after being detained by an immigration officer. The doctors took an X-ray and found a spot in my lungs. They told me I had to stay in isolation, that I might have to stay here two months. All I could think was that I was going to die in this cold place, away from my kids. But I know I'm not sick. My brother had a lung removed due to resistant tuberculosis. I'm not coughing like my brother. I am not wasted away like him. They gave me a Bible in Portuguese, so I read all the time. I also watch TV a lot. There's not much else to do. The worst part is falling asleep. I keep on thinking about my debts, my disease, my kids. I don't know what I'm going to do."

Professor Rothenberg taught there while studying for his Ph.D. in art history at Columbia University, which he received in 1967. He served as chairman of the art department for many years. title: Jorge Robson de Souza, Port Isabel Service Processing Center near Los Fresnos, Tex., April 24, 2001
description: left my home in Vitoria, a city in southeastern Brazil, and took a 16-hour bus ride to Sao Paulo. I had to pawn my house and a plot of land in Vitoria to raise the $8,000 needed to pay the coyotes that smuggled me to the United States. But I didn't find a job when I got here. Instead, I ended up in this health center after being detained by an immigration officer. The doctors took an X-ray and found a spot in my lungs. They told me I had to stay in isolation, that I might have to stay here two months. All I could think was that I was going to die in this cold place, away from my kids. But I know I'm not sick. My brother had a lung removed due to resistant tuberculosis. I'm not coughing like my brother. I am not wasted away like him. They gave me a Bible in Portuguese, so I read all the time. I also watch TV a lot. There's not much else to do. The worst part is falling asleep. I keep on thinking about my debts, my disease, my kids. I don't know what I'm going to do."

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-6-01; Pox Populi
description: Since Feb. 19, Britain has been under the pall of foot-and-mouth disease, or aftosa fever, as it's called in other parts of the world. The clinical slides of afflicted animals are unpleasant enough. They show blistered tongues and gums, lesions on the coronary band, where hair meets hoof, a look of slackness and profuse salivation. But the news photographs are genuinely gruesome -- stiff, swollen cattle stacked on their backs in long rows for mass interment, sheep penned in great herds for killing, farmers looking away from the sight of it all in grief and disgust. If you believe Daniel Defoe, whose ''A Journal of the Plague Year'' is closely attested fiction, one of the worst horrors of the 1665 London plague was the shutting up of houses where infection was discovered. By official order, healthy occupants were imprisoned with the dying, a red cross marked on the door, a watchman posted outside. That's how the containment of foot-and-mouth disease works too.

title: Cuttings: An Early Bloomer That Hasn't Finished Its Show
description: THE hellebores have just about finished their long blooming season in my garden, but their show is by no means over. In a shade garden it is character, not color, that sustains the gardener through the leafy summer. The columbines will float on delicate stems above the ferns and foam flowers, the little yellow foxgloves will shine in the dappled light, and the Japanese anemones will come along in good time, but the hellebores are the anchors in my backyard, the off-center centerpieces of what people with sunny gardens have the privilege of calling their flower beds.

title: Like Daughter, Like Mother
description: When the Japanese company Sanrio introduced the Hello Kitty character in the mid-1970's, little girls swooned for the hair clips, notepads and other grammar-school-age accessories. Twenty-five years later, the cat is back, and with the resurgence comes products for both the mothers who grew up with Kitty and their daughters. At last winter's opening of Sanrio's first New York City store, in Times Square, the merchandise went beyond the requisite backpacks and sticker kits, and included items with adult kitsch appeal: grommet-studded sleeveless T-shirts and evening bags, both above, camouflage surfboards and even vacuum cleaners. With the actresses Laetitia Casta, Tyra Banks and Christina Aguilera having declared their love for Hello Kitty, the character's popularity has even reached adult men, who are pinning Kitty buttons on their denim jackets. At last Sunday's Kids for Kids event in Central Park, a number of mother-daughter pairs were in Hello Kitty garb. That same day, at the Reebok gym on the Upper West Side, three Hello Kitty gym bags were spotted. And this summer, both Patricia Field and Fred Segal will carry Hello Kitty T-shirts and tanks for women. Talk about nine lives.

To go it alone is to go for broke.

title: The Medicine Man's Table
description: On a typical day at Enos Thaba's clinic in Soshanguve township, north of Pretoria, up to a hundred patients come for treatment of everything from the flu to heart trouble. Thaba, 66, one of the best-known healers in the area, begins by ''throwing the dollars,'' casting small pieces of bones like dice. This ritual helps Thaba divine the nature of the patient's disease. If he decides, for instance, that the patient suffers from asthma, he waves a horsetail (bottom left) over his head to help him breathe. For most ailments, he prepares a muti, a Sotho word meaning ''medicine,'' usually in liquid or lotion form. Many of the ingredients come from the leaves and bark of local plants, ground with a mortar and pestle (top center, next to a good-luck mask) or cow horn (bottom right) and distilled in water or alcohol or mixed with fat or Vaseline. Then there's the aspirin. ''For headache, I take something like Pando-Co,'' Thaba says, referring to over-the-counter pills containing acetaminophen and codeine, ''then mix it with my muti.'' He claims his mutis make Western medicines, like aspirin and cough syrup, much stronger. ''We used to send people to the hospital or a private doctor, but they don't get better,'' Thaba says. ''I am the only one who can stop their disease.'' Matthew Steinglass
