title: Reality Bites
description: Cue the music: ''DUM dum dum dum, DUM dum dum dum.'' That scary ''Jaws'' theme feels especially appropriate with the arrival of two books recounting a series of fatal shark attacks that terrorized the Jersey Shore in the summer of 1916, events that in fact inspired ''Jaws.'' The books, ''Close to Shore,'' by Michael Capuzzo (Broadway Books, $24.95), and ''Twelve Days of Terror,'' by Richard G. Fernicola, M.D. (Lyons Press, $27.95), describe the furor that started when a man was mauled in the ocean off Beach Haven and ended when a great white shark was caught in Raritan Bay. Though Beach Haven officials, perhaps fearful of frightening off tourists, did not notify officials, sharks came to steal headlines from a World War and established themselves as a symbol of predatory terror. The Fernicola book is that of a scientific researcher, while Mr. Capuzzo's is more novelistic, even presenting the shark's point of view. Both lay out a background of grand seaside resorts and the relatively new fashion of beachgoing, with rumblings of war across the water that for a while held a much more immediate threat.

title: Too Cool for Words
description: You'd have to be a curmudgeon to resist the charms of Timothy McSweeney's Quarterly Concern, the magazine portion of the literary empire (it includes a Web site, a store and a book-publishing division) run by Dave Eggers, the author of ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius'' and a man rather suddenly appointed to be the voice of his barely 30-something generation. McSweeney's most recent issue, the sixth, comes with a CD of original music, much of it by the band They Might Be Giants, whose deadpan affect predates that of McSweeney's but is here identical to it. Each track accompanies an article, and you are admonished sternly to listen to the songs only while reading the pieces that correspond to them. A childish ditty that goes like this -- Timothy McSweeney, Timothy McSweeney / He takes a pen and paper and he writes things down'' -- makes more sense if you are looking at the anecdote that accompanies it. The anecdote recounts Eggers's recent discovery of the real-life tragedy underlying his journal's name, which was chosen, naturally, as a joke.

title: How to Sequence Your Own Genome
description: Last summer, Celera Genomics and the National Institutes of Health's Human Genome Project announced the completion of a "working draft" of the human genome. The final copy-edit will probably take another couple of years -- there are 3.2 billion biochemical letters of DNA in a person's book of life -- but later this month the American Museum of Natural History will unveil "The Genomic Revolution," an exhibition designed to "get the genetic vocabulary out to people," in the words of Rob DeSalle, a director of the museum's molecular lab and the exhibition's curator. title: April 29-May 5; A Slightly Smaller Tax Cut
description: He had to give a little, but President Bush won tentative agreement from Congress for the bulk of his tax cut. Mr. Bush wanted a cut of $1.6 trillion over the next decade. After negotiations with centrist Democrats, he agreed to $1.25 trillion, plus another $100 billion this year to give a kick to the faltering economy. The two parties are now negotiating over how to apportion the money. Mr. Bush also had to compromise on spending levels in next year's budget. But as last-minute haggling continued, he seemed likely to win a figure close to what he had sought. Richard W. Stevenson

title: Rockers Who Foretold the Future

The work of the mysterious 1970's German duo Neu! was a stubborn holdout, and later this month, after an eternity of negotiations and delays, its first three albums will finally be released in America. Ordinary listeners can assess the elusive virtues that have long been praised by admirers of Neu! like David Bowie, Brian Eno, Sonic Youth, Stereolab and Radiohead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOZAN, PHOEBE STARFIELD
description: GOZAN-Phoebe Starfield of Coconut Creek, FL. Formerly of Great Neck, NY. Devoted wife of late husband Henry A. Gozan, M.D.; loving mother of Judy Goldstein, Dr. Neil Gozan and Gale Antokal; grandmother of Henry and Samuel Gozan; dear sister of Esther Siegel and adored aunt of many neices and nephews, passed away on April 30, 2001 in Margate, FL after a brief illness. Passionate gardener, fierce tennis player and ardent supporter of Israel, she had high expectations, broad interests and deep commitments. Commanding in presence, asking questions and making suggestions, she left the mark of her fine mind and strong character throughout her long life-growing up in Brooklyn; as a young wife and mother in Cambria Heights; parent, friend and tireless member of the PTA, Hadassah, Brandeis Women's Committee and North Shore Child Guidance League in Great Neck, and, finally, active resident of Wynmoor. title: Demystifying Islam
description: FOR much of last year, the Chicago suburb of Palo Heights was caught up in a nasty clash of civilizations. It all started when the al-Salam Mosque Foundation, a Muslim group that had outgrown its mosque on the South side, agreed to buy the Reformed Church of Palo Heights. Although the property had been on sale for more than two years, city officials suddenly decided to buy the church themselves and turn it into a municipal recreation center. Eventually the mosque foundation withdrew its offer and filed a $6.2 million discrimmination lawsuit against the city.

title: Shell Condos Where Oysters Can Move In and Raise a Family
description: When Henry Hudson explored the waters around what is present-day New York and New Jersey, he found 35 square miles of oyster beds. They formed reefs six to eight feet high. The colonists consumed oysters voraciously, and by the War of 1812, the natural beds were exhausted and had to be reseeded with oysters from other areas. By 1900, overharvesting, plus pollution and disease, wiped out almost all the beds. Hoping to bring oysters back to Raritan Bay, the staff of the New York-New Jersey Baykeeper of the Hudson-Raritan Estuary will begin an effort in June to build new oyster reefs. Michael Stringer, a restoration associate with the Baykeeper's staff, recently discussed the project.

title: Think Bollywood, Australia and Paris in Song
description: A FEW weeks ago, Nicole Kidman was plagued by insomnia after a dose of NyQuil had turned on her. But instead of tossing restlessly in her bed with her head cold, she could have called the director Baz Luhrmann, who wasn't getting much sleep, either. His all-nighter, however, was work-related. In five days his latest film, a modernistic musical called ''Moulin Rouge,'' starring Ms. Kidman and Ewan McGregor, would have its unofficial debut in New York at a benefit screening, courtesy of Vogue magazine. And right up until he had to catch a plane to the East Coast, Mr. Luhrmann could be found here, in a post-production facility on the Twentieth Century Fox lot, feverishly trying to get his film in shape.

The final copy-edit will probably take another couple of years -- there are 3.2 billion biochemical letters of DNA in a person's book

title: For Angolans, U.N. Suggests Timid Return To the Farms
description: The periphery of this battle-seared city, marked by scores of grass-topped huts, grows ever wider, and that means more people for relief agencies to feed, year after year. Hundreds of children, recently arrived from the countryside, line up for late afternoon servings of cornmeal.

title: Footlights; Zimmerli Auctioning Art Works
description: The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University was created in 1966 to collect and exhibit artwork of interest to the general public and to scholars. Among its special collections are graphic artworks from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, a collection of nonconformist Soviet art and a historical Russian collection, as well as works influenced by Japanese styles from the late 19th and early 20th centuries. An exhibition of printmaking and a collection of children's books also are among the works collected by the museum.

title: In Suffolk, Just Saying No to Spraying
description: BORN with what doctors diagnosed as a terminal form of juvenile leukemia, William Benjamin was not yet a year old when a helicopter sprayed pesticide on his family's home in Huntington late in September of 1999.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: A Life Forever Changed In a Police Encounter

title: Where the Baubles Bloom
description: This year, traditionalists who still think that Mother's Day requires May flowers can find a few fresh alternatives to the conventional bouquet. Lee Angel, a jewelry designer, has produced a line of Swarovski crystal baubles with a witty gardening theme -- including fuchsia-and-amber pansy brooches ($165) and white cherry blossom earrings ($65, far right). Both at Saks Fifth Avenue, they are nestled in bright, preppy-stripe boxes filled with artificial turf. Expressly for Mother's Day, L'Artisan Parfumeur has created Little Elf Garden sachets, above left, cunning silk flowers attached to a tiny sachet, which come in small satin boxes that can be reused as ring caddies ($25 each). And for the month of May, Sephora is wrapping Mother's Day gifts topped with a pink silk peony, which doubles as a pin.

title: Linda Vester, Glenn Greenberg
description: Linda Vester, the daughter of Dorothy Vester and Dr. John Vester of Cincinnati, was married yesterday morning to Glenn Hank Greenberg, a son of Caral Lebworth of Manhattan and the late Hank Greenberg, the baseball player. Justice Ann Feldman of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated at the couple's apartment in Manhattan. Later in the day, Paul J. Fribourg, the mutual friend who introduced them to each other, led a celebration of their marriage at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: Message in a Bracelet
description: The Louis Vuitton Wish Bracelet, which the company bills as the ultimate Mother's Day card, was grabbed from stores before most people started shopping for Mom. The bracelet, which resembles a leather watchband with a beflowered silver buckle, is embossed with the company's ''LV'' logo, and comes with plastic strips on which a message or wish can be written and slipped into a slot on the band. While both Louis Vuitton Manhattan stores are sold out of the $160 bracelet (sales representatives at the stores say they will not restock for another two weeks), the shopping secret is that they are available at www.eLUXURY.com, in lilac or vanilla.

title: Thai With Spice or for the Faint-Hearted
description: SOPHISTICATED Asian restaurants are currently the rage on Long Island. Penang, a Malaysian hot spot in Syosset, is packing them in; Baang, a sleek Asian fusion destination in Woodbury, is a big hit; and Korean eating places rarely seen in Nassau or Suffolk just a year or two ago are becoming commonplace. Although most of the chatter is about the glamorous, cutting-edge newcomers, the same genre of food is also served at local Thai restaurants and at lower prices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGE, ELIZA SALLY
description: BURGE-Eliza Sally, age 97, of Manhattan, died April 30, 2001. Survived by nephew, Herbert Burg; two grandnieces, two grandnephews and two great-grandnieces, all of Canada.

title: This Time, Youthful lan Triumphs Over Experience
description: When age and experience are counterbalanced by youth and energy, it's not easy to predict the outcome. That is what adds excitement to this matchup. In the confrontation between the 26-year-old Bulgarian grandmaster Veselin Topalov and the 49-year-old former world champion Anatoly Karpov of Russia in Round 8 of the Amber Tournament in Monte Carlo, tentativeness took a back seat to lan. Topalov won their second game, too.

title: Soldiering On; Columbia Tennis Debate Affects Larger Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian-Americans Diving Gracefully Into Political Waters
description: Except for a few judges and school board members, no Asian-American has ever held elected office in New York City. None has ever filibustered against a bill or shouted down an opponent on the City Council floor.

title: An Executives' Guide To Crystal Gazing . . .
description: LAYOFFS and unemployment are rising, but so is the stock market. Consumer confidence and corporate profits are falling, but nine days ago the government announced that the economy grew at an annual rate of 2 percent in the first quarter. Shoppers cut back during the all-important holiday season a few months ago, but they opened their wallets again at the start of the year.

title: Imaginary People In Real Gardens
description: MOONING over the real estate classifieds is as close as most New Yorkers come to living in the fab hi flr 3000 SF 3BR in F/S wht glv bldg of their dreams. But writers of fiction can install their characters in the palace of their desires. And in this turf-driven city, novelists do it all the time.

title: LOCATION: VENICE, ITALY; To Sleep No More
description: In 1791, in a small town near Venice, a man named Giacomo was born. Members of his family tended to be physically impressive, powerful and broad-shouldered (and still are today), but one day in the fall of 1836, at the age of 45, Giacomo fell mysteriously ill. He began to suffer from dementia. Eventually he was confined to bed, lying awake in torment. Then he died.

title: Investing; For a Venture Fund, Home Is an Exchange
description: IT used to take at least $1 million in net worth to be admitted to the exclusive club of venture capital investors. But at the peak of the technology bubble last year, a wave of egalitarianism temporarily welcomed the mom-and-pop crowd. A handful of entrepreneurs and mutual fund companies proposed funds that would allow almost anyone to invest in fledgling, privately held technology companies.

title: Reckonings; The Farce Is With Us
description: It was, if you believe the official story, a case of farce majeure: House Republican leaders had to call off Thursday's planned vote on the budget resolution because two pages that were supposed to be in the document were accidentally omitted. Strangely, the two missing pages happened to contain language crucial to the compromise that had persuaded moderates to agree to the budget. Just as strangely, the budget resolution contained only a 4 percent increase in spending -- the amount George W. Bush originally wanted, not the 5 percent he had agreed to.

title: The Egoist, the Altruist
description: I SIGNED UP as a public-school volunteer eight years ago. After six hours of training, I was placed as a tutor in a magnet school on West 24th Street, the High School of Fashion Industries. It was a good school without metal detectors, but not so good that it didn't need some extra help.

title: Space-Time Cubism
description: EINSTEIN, PICASSO

title: Through the Muddle, Art, Again, Triumphs
description: LIEUT. MARTIN FEINGOLD is fighting for Claudia Lazlo's right to sing. No matter her Nazi membership card. To the army officer, art is at issue, not politics, and certainly not humaneness.

title: April 29-May 5; Tentative Writers' Pact
description: The show, it seems, will go on. After months of hand-wringing over the possibility that a writers' strike would effectively close down the nation's film and television industries, the Writers Guild of America agreed to a tentative three-year contract. The pact -- if approved, as expected -- would alter how residuals are computed and may help raise writers' status in an industry that often takes them for granted. And it may offer a template for a contract for actors, who otherwise may strike in July. Rick Lyman

title: LOCATION: HARBIN, CHINA; Chairman Mao's Cure for Cancer
description: At the height of China's tumultuous Cultural Revolution, when Mao closed universities and banished intellectuals to the countryside for a ''real'' education, Dr. Zhang Tingdong found himself dispatched from the city of Harbin to a remote agricultural commune in the far reaches of frigid Heilongjiang Province in the northeast of China. His mission was to seek out an uneducated doctor said to possess a miraculous curative elixir.

title: Jaclyn Rann, Ronald Cohen
description: Jaclyn Rann, a television executive, and Ronald Howard Cohen, an advertising executive, are to be married today at the Alger Mansion in Manhattan. Cantor Bette Cohen will officiate.

title: Article 2001050692472881157 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Sprewell Demands That the Knicks Get Bigger and Tougher
description: Latrell Sprewell and Jeff Van Gundy met for 25 minutes today, two downcast individuals whose worlds revolve around winning basketball games. If Sprewell was as forthcoming with his coach as he was with reporters, then Van Gundy will spend the summer pushing Knicks management to do everything it can to bring a strong, tough big man to New York.

title: East Hampton to Buy Development Rights
description: Ending a long debate pitting farm preservation against recreational needs, the East Hampton Town Board has narrowly approved the purchase of development rights to 42 acres of farmland on Long Lane.

title: Surrogate Shopper
description: Mother's helpers include baby sitters, dog walkers, housekeepers and personal trainers, so why not a personal shopper for the little one's wardrobe? Barbara Becker, a children's shopping consultant, does the legwork for busy moms, scouting stores for everything from hats and socks to python halters and camouflage pants. Ms. Becker, who for the last 12 years has been the manager of a Madison Avenue children's boutique, Small Change, covers key issues in preliminary interviews with mother -- height, weight, coloring -- as well as asking lifestyle questions. Do you go to church or temple every week? Does the child wear a uniform to school? Do you have a country house? From there, she will construct a wardrobe for that season, and will return anything that doesn't please Mom. Her fee is $1,000, plus 20 percent of the cost of the clothing -- and $750 for each additional child. While the price may seem high, Ms. Becker says that on the average, each of her clients spends more than $3,500 for a season's worth of children's duds.

title: In Israel, Panel Urges Settlement Freeze and an End to Terror
description: An international committee investigating the continuing violence in the region has issued an unexpectedly strong call for an Israeli freeze on settlements and a Palestinian crackdown on terrorism as a prelude to the resumption of peace talks.

title: April 29-May 5; Brave New TV, That Has Such Shows On It
description: More than 36 million people watched ''Survivor'' on CBS Thursday night, when one person on the show had a chance to win $1 million.

title: Lawyers Seeking to Expose Plea Deal in Bombings Case
description: Last fall, Ali A. Mohamed, a former sergeant in the United States Army, pleaded guilty to terrorism conspiracy charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan. At that time, he told the judge that Osama bin Laden had looked at a photograph of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, and ''pointed to where a truck could go as a suicide bomber.''

title: Truck Safari
description: To the Editor: Geronimo Madrid's report of the truck safari in Botswana and Namibia, ''Just the Basics on a Truck Safari'' (April 22), left me wondering about the attitude of the travelers. To blast loud music and send the animals retreating from the water to the tree line beyond the pond is intruding on the natural world in an arrogant manner.

title: BENEFITS
description: Aid for Fulbrights

title: New Challenge to the Bogot Leadership
description: Normally, Guillermo Jaramillo, governor of a poor and debt-ridden province, could expect to be ignored by Colombia's highly centralized government in far off Bogot.

title: SUGAR RULES DEFY FREE-TRADE LOGIC
description: For anyone who thinks of the United States as a free-trade nation, the 10-story brick sugar refinery on Highway 90A here on the outskirts of Houston is startling.

title: Virtuosos Reign at Guitar Festival
description: ON a visit to New York City from Berlin in 1997, Ayse Domeniconi stumbled upon a classical guitar performance by two C. W. Post faculty members at a church in Brooklyn. After the show, she introduced herself to the musicians, Harris Becker and Pasquale Bianculli, mentioning that she was the wife of the guitar composer Carlo Domeniconi.

title: WILDFIRES
description: The scorching weather early this spring has been a boom for beach lovers, but it has also created tinderbox conditions for open land like the Meadowlands and the Pine Barrens. Last weekend, more than 1,000 acres throughout the state were ablaze, and firefighters worked around the clock to protect the turnpike, the Meadowlands sports complex and other buildings. There was no damage or injuries, officials said. The spring always brings some brush fires, as a lack of foliage allows the sun to dry dead grasses and old forest beds. Maria Newman

title: A Miracle of the Buddha: A Temple Turns Rice Into Money
description: Three weeks ago, worshipers going to the Wat Buddhathai Thavornvanaram temple at 46th Avenue and 76th Street were met with what looked like sandbags blocking a main entryway.

title: WHITMAN 'PAT-DOWN' SUIT
description: The state attorney general's office decided last week to represent former Governor Christie Whitman in a civil rights lawsuit brought against her by Sherron Rolax, the young man photographed being patted down by her during a 1996 Camden drug sweep. The suit contends that Mr. Whitman violated Mr. Rolax's Fourth Amendment rights because a search had already found him without anything illegal. State employees who act in an official capacity can be represented by the state. Anne Ruderman

title: Taking Open Spaces Out of Developers' Hands
description: Who is Jim Morgo kidding when he suggests that efforts to protect drinking water are preventing the construction of affordable housing? The president of the Long Island Housing Partnership knows full well that Long Island developers simply aren't building much of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEBY, ROGER
description: APPLEBY-Roger. On May 2, 2001. Beloved husband of Leigh Westbrook; dear father of Shaun, Amy, and Jed; loving grandfather of Travis, Ethan, and Matthew. Roger studied music at University of Michigan and toured internationally with the Robert Shaw Chorale. An advertising executive in Manhattan for 25 years, he also established Appleby's restaurants in Westchester and The Pet Department Store in Manhattan. His book of essays, ''Out of Left Field'', is forthcoming. Your talent, energy, and love touched many. We will miss you always.

title: Hey, Let's Build a Shield Against Another Incoming Threat
description: CONTROVERSY is already raging around the Bush administration's bold new initiative to halt the flow of illegal substances into the United States for good. Details are secret and security tight, but the ''Drug Wars'' concept closely resembles its sibling, the newest incarnation of the ''Star Wars'' dream of an anti-missile defense system to protect the entire continental United States.

title: Moss Is a Long Shot to Be a Star
description: Some two weeks after the National Football League draft, one of the most talked about -- and debated -- picks among executives and coaches remains the Jets' Santana Moss.

description: PHILIPPE BOURGUIGNON says Club Med is ''about rejuvenation, not about evasion.''

title: Hands-On Dining
description: THERE was a time when loud, dark and smoky was my kind of place. The drinks were cool, the food was hot, the men were single and the music was nothing but the blues.

title: Despite Swift Spread of TB, Russians May Reject Big Loan
description: Hit with objections from drug makers, legislators and its own Health Ministry, the Russian government is debating whether to turn down a $150 million loan that some experts call crucial to containing a serious tuberculosis epidemic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, VIRGINIA A.
description: KING-Virginia A., On April 28th, 2001 at age 84. Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Susan DeVoge and Deborah Dunn, stepmother of Cynthia Betts, Sara Gervasio, John King, Mary Braley and William King. Devoted grandmother of 12. Elizabeth Knotts, loyal caretaker. Service in W. VA at a later date. Contributions may be made to Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., 5th Floor, NYC 10017. For information, contact 775-332-5105.

title: Footlights; The Garden of Drumthwacket
description: Pink and white dogwoods, purple crab apple blossoms and golden daffodils are abloom in the garden at Drumthwacket in Princeton, the governor's official residence. ''It does seem to be a very lush year,'' said Lisa Paine, executive director of the Drumthwacket Foundation. To take advantage of the seasonal beauty, special garden tours will be offered this month only, starting with an open house today, 11 to 2 p.m. It is one of the only Sundays during the year when the house is open to visitors. There will be floral arrangements by the Garden Club of New Jersey along with music by Purcell, Mozart and Handel played by Hopewell Valley Regional Schools students. The battleship New Jersey silver will also be on display. Other garden programs will be on Wednesday, May 16 and May 23. Margo Nash

description: MANDELBAUM-Gerard. On May 5, 2001, after a brief illness. Memorial services to be announced at a later date.

description: President Bush as the conservative ideologue had a pretty good week.

title: LOCATION: WILMINGTON, DEL.; The Breast Offense
description: By most measures, Kym Smythe is, at 38, an ordinary suburban mother. She lives with her husband, Doug, an accountant, in a new-model Colonial set inside a neatly gridded housing development just south of Wilmington, Del. In the driveway sits the family's minivan, equipped with three car seats and a stereo whose primary purpose these days is to pump out songs by the cartoon band the Rugrats -- Over and over and over,'' says Smythe, grimacing good-naturedly -- while her four kids sing, quartet-style, from the back seats.

description: SCHENKEL-Elizabeth Johnston of Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Garden City, NY, died May 2. She graduated Packer Collegiate Institute, Class of 1934 and became the first woman to graduate from New York Law School, Class of 1937. In 1992 she was honored by the law school and was awarded the Distinguished Alumna Award. She was the wife of James M. Schenkel, Vice President and Actuary for Home Life Insurance Company in New York. Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach.

description: An article on April 22 about the actress Uma Thurman misidentified her first film role. It was in ''Kiss Daddy Goodnight,'' not in ''Dangerous Liaisons.''

title: Footlights; Jazz Quintet Just Needs a Name
description: Gerry Niewood of Glen Ridge, a professional saxophonist, plays regularly for Radio City Music Hall and Chuck Mangione. His son Adam, 24, of West Orange, also a saxophonist, has just been accepted on full scholarship to the jazz studies program at Juilliard in Manhattan. And now the Niewoods are putting together their own quintet, although they have yet to settle on a name. The quintet's debut will be next weekend at Trumpets Jazz Club and Restaurant in Montclair. Jim McNeely, Rufus Reid and Bill Goodwin make up the rhythm section. They will play jazz standards by Porter, Gershwin and Berlin. Debra Galant

title: Sounding an Alarm For Diabetics
description: ONE of the more joyless tasks for a diabetic sufferer is the constant monitoring of blood sugar levels by drawing blood from a fingertip. Cygnus Inc., a company in Redwood City, Calif., that develops and makes diagnostic medical devices, recently won approval from the Food and Drug Administration for its Gluco-Watch Biographer, a device that monitors those sugar levels continuously and automatically through the skin and beeps if they drop or rise significantly. The monitor resembles a wristwatch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARVAN, HOPE J.
description: GARVAN-Hope J. On April 26, 2001, at age 86. Loving mother of Patricia Graham-Collier. Services and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to Best Friends Animal Sanctuary in Kanab, UT 84741.

title: Stock Investors Manage to Ignore 223,000 Lost Jobs
description: A GIANT tree fell in the forest on Friday, but to stock market investors, it didn't make a sound.

description: This time, Bill Bradley, the former senator and basketball star whose bid for the Democratic presidential nomination fell short last year, is almost certain to win an election. But millions of union members, a natural constituency, will not be supporting him.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE best way to watch EAST-WEST (1999) is to know nothing aobut it beforehand. Like Marie (Sandrine Bonnaire) and her husband, Aleksei (Oleg Menshikov), you'll want to break out the best wine and drink to their imminent arrival in the Soviet Union just after World War II. Like Marie and Aleksei, a Russian exile, you'll recoil in horror when their ship reaches port and they realize the Soviet invitation was a trick and they have just made the worst mistake of their lives. But then we have the advantage of knowing how Stalin turned out. Catherine Deneuve is regal as Gabrielle, the French actress who uses her influence to help. Regis Wargnier directed -- Saturday at 6:30 a.m. on Cinemax.

title: Maple Leafs Capitalize On Corson's Resurgence
description: The assist Shayne Corson was credited with on Tomas Kaberle's game-winning goal with 29.4 seconds left in the game tonight was not for falling on Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur as Kaberle was about to shoot the puck.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBACKS
description: THE HUMAN STAIN, by Philip Roth. (Vintage International, $14.) Coleman Silk is a classics professor at a Massachusetts college who is forced to resign because he used the word ''spooks,'' meaning ghosts, in a lecture and is branded a racist. He turns for understanding to Roth's literary doppelg* nger, Nathan Zuckerman, who discovers, among other things, that Silk is a light-skinned black man who reinvented himself as a Jew. In praising this novel, which was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, our reviewer, Lorrie Moore, said its ''hero-fool is arguably the most socially intriguing character to whom Roth has ever devoted himself.''

title: Business; Can Entrepreneurs and Environmentalists Mix?
description: MANY Americans consider economic interests and environmental protection about as compatible as, well, oil and water. Bob Epstein is out to change that perception.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-6-01: The Ethicist; File Sharing
description: While training as a psychoanalyst, my husband fails to protect his patient notes. I frequently find them next to the family computer or in any odd location around the house. I have complained that these notes should be kept away from my children and whoever might enter the house. He maintains that anyone who reads them has committed a boundary violation. With whom does the responsibility for confidentiality rest? Anonymous, Virginia

title: In Capital, Quilts With Floral Themes
description: Through June 3, the Textile Museum in Washington will display ''Fanciful Flowers: Botany and the American Quilt,'' featuring 25 19th-century American quilts with floral themes. The quilts, on loan from the International Quilt Study Center at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, all have botanical motifs and include flowers, gardens and color palettes that reflect the growing interest in gardening and botany at the time.

title: STATE REVOKES CHARTER
description: Administrators at Samuel DeWitt Proctor Charter School Academy, one of the state's original 13 charter schools, will appeal the state Department of Education's decision last week not to renew its charter for the next school year. The school, which has about 100 pupils in grades 7 through 11, opened in Ewing in 1997. The state cited low test scores and high student turnover. Four charter schools have had their charters withdrawn. Debra Nussbaum

As they chat amid candles and tasseled red lampshades, Patrick Shields, at the far end of the room, has a problem to solve.

title: April 29-May 5; Debating AIDS Strategies
description: A call by Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, for a global fund to provide up to $10 billion annually to fight AIDS has sparked a debate about strategies for poor countries. Many experts say that prevention and improving health services must rank high on the list of tasks; others, now led by Brazil, want to concentrate first on inexpensive drugs to prolong the lives of those infected. Barbara Crossette

title: Arbitration Gaining In Popularity
description: Re the April 8 letter by Pasquale J. Curcio, chairman of the Suffolk County Conservative Party [''Binding Arbitration Must Go in Suffolk'']: Mr. Curcio will be disappointed to learn that, rather than going anywhere, binding arbitration is becoming an increasingly popular method of resolving employment disputes. Arbitration has certain advantages over litigation: it is less costly, it is not pubic record and it does not get mired down as does the litigation process. Arbitration also has certain disadvantages: there is little discovery and no sympathetic jury and an arbitrator may be inclined to reach a compromise result. Although there are no appeals to the decision of an arbitrator, in some cases, an employee may later litigate the same claim.

With 8 to 10 people, you have a banquet table, the better to sample a wider range of dishes at every meal.

title: LOCATION: GUATEMALA; Building a Better Bloodsucker

There are other men in the aisle, homeowners who are wheeling their flatbed lumber carts among the forests of upright planks -- poplar, oak, pine. They are building huts for their children to play in or sheds for their tools. Their mumblings involve the important issues of length and width.

title: The Nation; Civil War: All for One and None for You
description: THROUGHOUT last year's presidential campaign, George W. Bush's recurring mantra was bipartisanship. Everywhere the Republican nominee went, he reminded voters of the cooperation he had forged between his Republican gubernatorial administration in Texas and the state's Democrats; and he promised it would be the same in a Bush White House. President Bush picked up the theme again for the flood of coverage marking his 100th day in office, telling one interviewer that he had already effected a ''change in attitude'' in Washington where, he said, it was no longer a zero-sum game between the parties.

title: An Optimal Number of Options
description: Legions of high-technology employees have lost fortunes as their companies' stocks have collapsed, making their stock options virtually worthless. Now there is evidence that issuing too many options was a cause of corporate failure and skidding stock prices.

title: Courtney Carlson, David Yarkin
description: Courtney Anne Carlson, the daughter of Margaret Carlson and Eugene Carlson, both of Washington, was married there yesterday to David Paul Yarkin, the son of Reesa and Larry Yarkin of Framingham, Mass. Judge Marjorie O. Rendell of the Federal Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit in Philadelphia officiated at the home of Katharine Graham, the former publisher of The Washington Post, a family friend.

title: LOCATION: WASHINGTON, D.C.; A Cure For Poverty
description: Wendy was born just below the poverty line, where she spent the next 30 years of her life. These were grim times for her. When she was 6, a disabled friend of her alcoholic grandmother began abusing her sexually. In seventh grade she began to withdraw. ''I felt there was no reason to go on,'' she says. ''I did my schoolwork and everything, but I was not happy in any way. I would just stay to myself. Everyone thought I couldn't talk for a while, because for a few years there I wouldn't say anything to anyone.'' Her first boyfriend, from her neighborhood in the slums around Washington, was physically and verbally brutal. After the birth of her first child, when she was 17, she managed to ''escape from him, I don't know how.'' Not long after, Wendy, a petite African-American woman with grave eyes and a wide mouth, was raped by a family friend. Soon after that, under pressure from her family, she married a man who was also abusive. She had three more children by him in the next two years. ''He was abusing the children too, even though he was the one who wanted them, cursing and yelling all the time, and the spankings, I couldn't take that, over any little thing, and I couldn't protect them from it.'' She also had to assume responsibility at this time for her sister's children, because the sister was addicted to crack cocaine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, RICHARDSON, JR.
description: PRATT-Richardson, Jr. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Robert Sterling Clark Foundation mourn the loss of our dear friend and Board Member, Richardson Pratt, Jr. With passion, commitment and good humor he served as a Trustee for more than eighteen years, ten of those years as the Foundation's Treasurer. Throughout his tenure, Jerry enthusiastically embraced the goals of the Foundations and used his fine intellect and interpersonal skills to advance its purposes. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Jerry's wife, Jan, and to the rest of his family. He was a lovely man and he will be sorely missed. Winthrop R. Munyan, President Margaret C. Ayers, Executive Director

title: The View From/Kent; From a Pile of Rocks To a Dream Museum
description: THE Statue of Liberty, the mantle in the Green Room of the White House and the first atomic bomb all have something in common, and it has to do with the minerals mined in Connecticut.

title: Cameras Are Being Turned On a Once-Shy Spy Agency
description: Central Intelligence Agency headquarters is a sleepy place most weekends, but one recent Saturday it was forced to call in dozens of reinforcements to stave off a 20-hour siege.

title: 8. CASE STUDY: LATAH; LOCATION: BORNEO, MALAYSIA; Regional Disturbances
description: The little house looks like most of the others in the Malaysian jungle hamlet of Kampung Sebiris. The louvered windows are trimmed with heavy curtains, the tiled floor is immaculate and cushioned chairs line the walls. Even though it is over 90 degrees, there is no fan; outside, humid forest spreads out beneath a mist-wrapped mountain. As in many rural Malay homes, in the front room there is an ornate display cabinet filled with knickknacks: teapots, wooden pineapples, gaudy silk flowers. The jungle comes right up to the glass slats, and the whistling of insects is deafening.

title: Setting Minimum Prices in a Co-op
description: Q -- I have lived in a co-op for many years. Our board recently enacted a new policy, and I am wondering whether it has overstepped its authority.

title: Near Paris, a Trove of Porcelain and Faience
description: ONLY a handful of museums around Paris remain almost unknown to tourists. Among them, the National Museum of Ceramics is perhaps the loveliest. Situated just 30 minutes by Mtro or taxi from the center of the city, at the Pont de Svres overlooking the Seine, it houses a trove of Svres porcelain as well as an extensive collection of French faience and ceramics from Europe, the Far East and the Middle East, some of which date back to the fourth century B.C.

title: The Last Hanging: There Was a Reason They Outlawed Public Executions
description: IN Terre Haute, Ind., every hotel room is booked. More than 1,400 members of the news media have requested credentials to cover the May 16 execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, who was convicted of murder in the 1995 bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. The T- shirt and button sellers will be there, too, cashing in on the crowds of protesters and curiosity seekers expected to pour into town.

title: Domi Saves Some Contrition for His Circumstances
description: Tie Domi said he was sorry. He said the word several times. Tears filled his eyes and he spoke in a choked voice before tonight's playoff game between the Devils and the Toronto Maple Leafs at Continental Arena. But it was difficult to tell exactly what he was most sorry about.

title: California Struggling Over Budget Amid Crisis
description: The dot-com boom produced such unexpected cascades of tax revenues in California over the last several years that the Legislature's early summer budget negotiations had come to look more like Christmas morning than partisan maneuvering.

title: Youth Movement Has Created New Energy in Playoffs
description: Before he arrived at Madison Square Garden for Game 5, Latrell Sprewell already had an uneasy feeling stewing inside, almost a premonition. The Dallas-Utah game had caught his attention the night before.

title: Where Dancers and Deer Can Play
description: DANCERS from the Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg cavorted on a recent weekend through a rehearsal of a raucous seduction scene from Boris Eifman's ''Don Juan and Molire,'' the new work that will open the company's weeklong New York engagement at City Center on Friday. But the setting of the rehearsal looked about as far from New York City as one could get.

title: In the Middle on Medicare

title: Rare Praise From India on U.S. Defense
description: For decades, India was a leader in the nonaligned movement of third world nations, often and loudly proclaiming its opposition to America's foreign policy. So it was striking this week when India effusively praised elements of President Bush's missile-defense plan and said nary a critical word.

Yaddo, the 100-year-old artists' colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., provides writers, painters and composers who take up residence the serenity necessary for them to create -- this and a maximized opportunity for romantic liaisons.

title: Language Lessons
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed your articles about language learning abroad. But I wonder whether people won't end up believing that they must go to language schools in order to speak correctly. Being caught up in the niceties of the French subjunctive can block any attempt at simple communication. The experiences of the authors in schools in France and especially Mexico seemed to imply such a potential problem.

One of them wakes to find his sleeping companion embracing him ''in the most loving and affectionate manner.'' Silently, lingeringly, he examines the bare, tattooed arm, ''no two parts of which were of one precise shade,'' lying across his body.

title: Footlights; Hoboken Festival
description: It's time for one of the area's most eclectic street festivals. The Hoboken Arts and Music Festival is returning today (rain date May 20) with more than 300 artists, artisans and photographers, a wide selection of food and a children's area featuring rides, games, animals and music. The music for grownups includes rock (Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes), folk (Richie Havens), ska (the Skanatras, who perform ska renditions of Sinatra songs), Broadway tunes (the Hoboken Charter School performing selections from ''Annie''), jazz (Don Carter Jazz Trio), Caribbean/reggae (Verdict) and more. There will be Shakepearean performances, circus comedy, swing dancing and a wide assortment of activities on Washington Street between First and Seventh Streets, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Robbie Woliver

title: QUICK BITE/Monroe Township; Country Cooking, With Some Fancy Twists
description: As you drive west on Prospect Plains Road in Monroe Township, if you don't see the left just before the railroad tracks, you'll miss Cranberry's Gourmet Shoppe. Fortunately for its co-owners, Tom Scaramuzzo and Sam Ippolito, as many as 250 people a day manage to make the turn. The shop's out-of-the-way setting would be ideal for a country store or a rural post office, both of which the place once was. As you enter, there is a counter case filled with home-baked goods. In the rear is another counter with a variety of salads and more. In the middle, surrounded by remnants of the past -- including, on the wall, the storefront window from the onetime ''General Store,'' plus a ''Joshua Carter & Sons'' sign, with the likeness of a pig -- are a half-dozen tables. More tables are one flight up and on a back patio. Mr. Scaramuzzo, who used to work in research and development at General Foods, describes the menu items as ''country-style'' and, above all, ''made from scratch.'' Among items, $4.25 and up, are smoked chicken breast with apples, grapes and walnuts on a bed of lettuce; a grilled veggie sandwich; and tortellini salad with spicy andouille sausage, sweet peppers and red onions tossed in a basil shallot. And then there is the dish on which Ames Hoyt, an environmental manager from Carter-Wallace Inc., 15 minutes away in Princeton, was recently feasting: caramelized onions and peas. Just right -- a little gourmet, and a lot country. Norm Oshrin

But the bank is notable in other ways: it is 40 percent owned by a group including Magic Johnson, the basketball star; the singer Janet Jackson; and the DreamWorks executive Jheryl Busby. title: LOCATION: BANGKOK; Nip, Tuck and Frequent-Flier Miles
description: In 1999, Thai Airways International, the government airline of Thailand, began offering travelers an unusual new package-tour option. Most tourists might still prefer the old add-ons: the river cruise, the round of golf, the Thai cooking course. But others, those who were part of a new market that government officials were calling ''medical tourists,'' could now combine their Asian holiday with a comprehensive physical, including abdominal ultrasound, chest and barium stomach X-rays and a complete laboratory analysis of blood, urine and stool samples. They could get a written report sent to their hotel within three days. And they could get it all done at Bumrungrad Hospital, a modern medical complex in Bangkok that had all sorts of inviting, foreigner-friendly amenities, starting with a Starbucks and a McDonald's in the lobby.

title: Ideas & Trends; What if the Buffalo Roam Into Foot-and-Mouth?
description: BRITAIN'S prime minister, Tony Blair, preparing for an election, declared last week that his government was bringing foot-and-mouth under control. But in Washington, officials are drawing up detailed plans of what they will do if -- some say when -- the foot-and-mouth virus arrives in this country. They know they have a luxury denied Europeans: time to make advance battle plans. But they also have to grapple with one major problem that Europe was spared -- wildlife.

title: Tony Blair's Big Idea
description: Tony Blair's re-election campaign opens a trans-Atlantic dialogue on the future of equal opportunity. While President Bush pushes for an enormous tax cut, Mr. Blair, the British prime minister, proposes giving the next generation a start toward economic security and independence.

title: Mutombo's Mere Presence Creates Detours
description: Dikembe Mutombo, that Human Detour who forces opponents' bodies and shots to go in unintended directions, began this season with his 7-foot-2-inch frame stretched out in a hospital bed. He had contracted malaria while on a trip back to his home in Congo and wound up in an Atlanta hospital. He missed the first five games of the season before he was declared fit to join the Atlanta Hawks in their National Basketball Association struggles, which is not a casual depiction.

Paid Notice: Deaths  SWIRSKY, PHILIP (RET. MAJOR RESERVES, US ARMY)
description: SWIRSKY-Philip (ret. Major reserves-US Army) died Friday, April 27, 2001 at the NJ Veterans Memorial Home, Menlo Park, NJ, from the effects of a stroke. Born in Lithuania during WWI, came to the US when he was 10 with his mother Sophie, to join his father Harry in Brooklyn, NY. Graduate from Boy's HS in Brooklyn, attended CCNY. A lieut. during WWII in the Quartermaster Corps, he was decorated for bravery during the North African Campaign, and later was stationed in Bari, Italy. He retired from the reserves after 20 years, but not before he was recalled to active duty during the 1961 Berlin crisis. In his civilian life, he had been a quality control engineer in the fashion industry. A lifetime member of the Retired Officers Assoc. and Reserve Officers Assoc. of the US, he was also active in B'nai Brith, A.D.L., and Temple Beth-El of E. Windsor, NJ. He and his beloved wife of 54 years, Jessie Leibowitz Swirsky at first lived in Bayonne, NJ, and for the past 25 years resided in Clearbrook in Monroe Township, NJ. He is also survived by loving son, Dr Daniel Swirsky (Nancy), Princeton Junction, NJ, sister, Irene S. Wolk Lipschitz, Delray Beach, Fl, brother, Sheldon Swirsky (Linda), Cedarhurst, NY and beloved granddaughter, Pamela Swirsky, Milltown, NJ. Interment was in Washington Cemetery, Monmouth Jct, NJ on April 30, 2001. Uncle Phil was a feisty, bright and caring individual. Loving nephew, Joel M. Wolk Loving niece, Naomi W. Gibbons

title: Crime
description: Michael Ledwidge, a telephone man who works in Manhattan, has written a really good novel about a telephone man who works in Manhattan. BAD CONNECTION (Pocket Books, $23.95) follows the misadventures of Sean Macklin from the fateful moment when this phone repairman accidentally taps into a conversation between the C.E.O. of a big chemical company and the rapacious investment banker who is steering his takeover of a small biotech firm. Armed with this insider dope, Sean sinks his life's savings into a quick stock purchase. Even after he makes his modest killing, Sean doesn't stop his eavesdropping; only this time he learns something about the chemical company's operations that could make him very rich or very dead. In a truly bad judgment call, Sean seeks advice from his brother, a bent cop who tries to handle the problem himself.

title: A Steakhouse With More Than Steaks
description: I'M still a bit confused. I know the Original Frank's Steaks in Wantagh and Smithtown changed their names recently to Burke & Shapiro to avoid confusion with Frank's Steaks in Jericho and the Frank's steakhouse in Manhattan (both unrelated). But if clarity and distinctiveness were the object, why choose a new name so similar to existing Long Island steakhouses, both of which start with B's: Burton & Doyle in Great Neck and Bryant & Cooper in Roslyn?

title: Tryon Leads Youth Invasion in Old Sport
description: As Ty Tryon headed to the first tee in the second round of the Honda Classic recently, the 16-year-old stopped to sign autographs. The demand was high after his first-round 67 and Tryon was willing, so he kept signing as he walked along a roped-off area. But when he finally finished, Tryon was disoriented. He began walking down the wrong path.

description: Rita Hunter, the British soprano famed especially for her performances as Brnnhilde and Norma, died last Sunday in Sydney, Australia. She was 67.

title: MapQuest Issues Atlas With Online Component
description: The traditional road atlas -- especially one for an area as large as North America -- presents mapmakers with quite a challenge: divining where its users want to go, where they're starting out from and what level of detail they want.

title: April 29-May 5; Bush Pursues Missile Shield
description: President Bush said he would move ahead with a missile defense system -- a primitive one that might be fielded by 2004, with additional ''layers'' to be added later that could protect against terrorists, accidental launches and rogue states. The system he described requires eventually abandoning the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty. The Russians seem willing to talk about that, for the right price. The Chinese are another matter. They said the United States ''is apparently attempting to seek absolute military supremacy and even greater global hegemony.'' David E. Sanger

title: Princeton Picks Professor As President
description: Shirley M. Tilghman, a molecular biologist who was among the architects of the national effort to map the human genome and an early advocate for women in a field still dominated by men, was named the 19th president of Princeton University today.

description: THE MOBILIZATION OF SHAME

title: Giving Summer to a Child
description: For one city teenager, the night sky was a revelation. ''If you look up in New York City, you see one star, and it is probably a plane,'' the 14-year-old mused during her first summer vacation outside the city. ''Out here, there are millions of stars.'' For children and adolescents who spend their summers playing on steamy urban streets, their view of the horizon limited by a wall of city apartments, the Fresh Air Fund offers a few weeks of discovery and relief. This year, the fund hopes to give 10,000 inner-city children a chance to walk on freshly cut grass, to swim in cool lakes and uncrowded pools, or simply to indulge in carefree play at camps and private homes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPIN, DOROTHY B.
description: CHAPIN-Dorothy B. Of New Canaan, CT. Beloved mother to Dorothy (Didi) Ermo and H. King Chapin. Sister to Sylvia Weaber of St. John's, USVI; six grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren also survive. She was predeceased by two grandchildren. Mrs. Chapin was the daughter of the late Frederick and Dorothy Doubleday Babcock, and was born and resided in Oyster Bay, LI, and Park Ave, NY, before moving to New Canaan, CT, 49 years ago. Mrs. Chapin was very active in the American Red Cross in New Canaan, and helped found the Multiple Sclerosis Foundation of Fairfield County and the Winter Club and Field Club in New Canaan. She was top Director of the Southern New England Tennis Championships and the New England Lawn and Tennis Association. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, May 10, at 11 AM, in the United Methodist Church of New Canaan. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the New Canaan Group Home/South Ave Cottage, 162 South Ave, New Canaan, CT 06840; or the American Red Cross, New Canaan Chapter, 51 Main St, New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: 'Tales' That Look More Up to Date As They Get Older
description: HERE they come again. Michael Tolliver, known as Mouse, is still looking for love -- as often as possible -- in the cowboy bars of San Francisco and in the relative anonymity of the baths. His neighbor Mary Ann Singleton, no longer just off the plane from Cleveland, can't decide whether Brian -- as sexually active in the straight world as Mouse is in gay circles -- is the man for her. Their landlady, the late-middle-aged transsexual Anna Madrigal, still smokes marijuana the way others drink wine and still supplies it to those she loves. Anna is a woman of her time: the 1970's.

title: Perfect Model: Gorgeous, No Complaints, Made of Pixels
description: DR. AKI ROSS, the young female protagonist of ''Final Fantasy,'' Columbia Pictures' new science-fiction epic, has the sinewy efficiency of Sigourney Weaver in ''Alien'' and the curves of Julia Roberts in ''Erin Brockovich.'' But when Aki arrives at the megaplex on July 11, audiences are as likely to be struck by the anxious furrows that flit across her brow and the scattering of moles on her neck. To be sure, Aki's flaws are minimal; they register just enough to render her human.

title: Taking Harlem Down to the Sea In Ships, Sailboats and Kayaks
description: Community boathouses have mushroomed along the Hudson, and kayaks, rowboats and small sailboats have now become familiar sights. But one part of the shoreline is unaffected, and it is the one place where the views start to display the beauty celebrated in paintings by the Hudson River School: Harlem.

title: The Fresh Air Fund; A Child's Portion of Summer Serenity
description: For most of the year, when 8-year-old Mel-Asia Pugh of Manhattan wants to play outside, she must wait for an older family member to join her for the two-block walk to a city park. But for the last three summers, during her three-week stays with a family in Long Valley, N.J., she has done something wholly exotic: opened the door, walked outside and dribbled her basketball, whenever she wished.

title: Federal Executions Have Been Rare but May Increase
description: For his last meal, Victor Feguer asked for an olive, just one olive, pit and all. He expressed hope that others would avoid his fate, said the priests who spent some of his last hours with him. Soon, chewing gum rapidly, he mounted a scaffold in the auto body shop of an Iowa prison. His thick glasses were removed, a hood was put over his head and he was hanged.

description: Goalkeeper Tim Howard of the MetroStars dropped to his knees and raised his hands toward the heavens when the referee blew the final whistle in the MetroStars' 3-2 triumph over D.C. United tonight before a crowd of 20,877 at Giants Stadium.

title: A Blinkered Energy Strategy
description: President Bush has said that his forthcoming energy package will be a balanced mix of recommendations aimed at increasing supply and, through improved energy efficiency, lowering demand. But it will be surprising if things actually turn out that way. The main architect of the energy plan is Vice President Dick Cheney, who made clear in a speech last weekend that the plan would focus heavily on increasing supplies of fossil fuels. With the certitude that he brings to most matters, Mr. Cheney contemptuously dismissed those who would look elsewhere to satisfy the country's energy needs. ''Conservation may be a sign of personal virtue,'' he said, ''but it is not a sufficient basis for a sound, comprehensive energy policy.''

title: How to Redraw Congressional Lines
description: New York State will lose 2 of its 31 Congressional seats as a result of the 2000 national census, forcing state legislators to redraw the maps of voting districts. The custom in Albany has been for the political parties to spread the pain between parties and regions, which in this case would mean eliminating one Democratic district and one Republican, one from upstate and one from downstate. But this old-style map making is not appropriate this time around. The census shows that over the last decade New York has lost population upstate and gained population downstate. The Legislature should heed that pattern and make certain that New York City and neighboring areas do not lose Congressional representation in some backroom barter.

description: ARFFA-Stanley H. Beloved and devoted husband, father, grandfather, brother, friend and active member of many Jewish and other organizations. Born August 6, 1923, in Kerhonksen, New York. After serving in both World War II and the Korean War, he moved to New Haven, Connecticut, where he was Vice-President of Interstate Container Corporation and then for 30 years, the Exeuctive Vice-President and part owner of Connecticut Container Corporation, a corrugated products manufacturer in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont. He served as President of Tower One, a residence for the elderly in New Haven affiliated with UJA-Federation; President of Sage Services, an interfaith organization assisting seniors with employment; President of Jewish Education in New Haven; VicePresident of the New Haven Jewish Federation and the Jewish Community Council; Co-Chair of the Committee of Development for Establishing the Jewish Studies Department of Yale University; for 15 years the delegate of New Haven to the Jewish Agency for Israel; and a member of the Boards of Directors of many organizations, including the New Haven Symphony, Ezra Academy, the United Israel Appeal and the New Haven Jewish Center. He is survived by his wife Shirley of Palm Beach Gardens, Florida; his children, Dr. Robert C. of Pittsburgh, Allan J. of New York and Bonnie Perman of London; seven grandchildren; and his sister Charlotte Burkholz of Palm Desert, California. Funeral services will be held at 11 AM, on May 9, at Temple Emanu-El of Palm Beach, 190 North County Road, Palm Beach, Florida, 33480, with observance thereafter at 114B Palms Point Circle, Ballen Isles, Palm Beach Gardens, Florida 33418. He then became a ''Gold Medalist'' intern at Clark Air Force Base in the Philippines for two years. In 1961 he did a second internship at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia, PA. Henry then accepted a residency at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City. He completed his general surgical residency in 1966. At that time he was recognized as an outstanding graduate and continued his training at the Children's Hospital of Buffalo. He achieved the status of a pediatric surgeon at that time. Dr. So returned to Manila where he became chief of pediatric surgery at the University of Santo Tomas. On June 1, 1970, he married Dr. Flora (Te) a pediatric surgeon who received her training in Philadelphia under the guidance of Dr. C. Koop. The family returned to New York in 1973. In 1974 Dr. So became a member of BSK Pediatric Surgical Associates. He was an honored member of this practice for 20 years. He was a member of many medical societies, but his proudest was The American Pediatric Surgical Association. Dr. So was on the staff of many hospitals and was chosen to be the chief of the division of pediatric surgery at Northshore University Hospital in Manhasset, LI. He was the first to perform a procedure for the cure of Hirschsprung's Disease in the newborn without the need for a colostomy. He reported this procedure in 1980 and is now performed by most pediatric surgeons worldwide. Besides his devotion to family, patients and collegues he will be remembered for his singing of the ''oldies'' in the operating room and of course his great love for his garden. I met Henry on a Monday morning in 1974, I took him on rounds. My mother-in-law, with whom I lived, met him as well, and she fell in love with him. Why not? He was a Chinse doctor who spoke Yiddish to her. On a handshake he started his career the next day and it was the best decision we ever made. A soft spoken, gentle soul, you could not help being touched by him and it lasted forever. In all our daily lives he represented the best and will be dearly missed. Services to be held on Tuesday, May 8, at 11 AM, at Our Lady of Hope, Westbury, NY. David L. Schwartz, M.D. Neil D. Kutin, M.D. Jerrold M. Becker, M.D. Keith Schneider, M.D. (deceased) Thomas K. Lee, M.D. Erwin Krasna, M.D. and all of the Office Staff of BSK

title: Breaking the Hickory Stick
description: Every school day, children in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi and 20 other states across the southwestern and southeastern United States stand a chance of being physically assaulted, often with a wooden paddle, at school and with the full sanction of the law. Not many are actually struck in the course of an ordinary day, and the number of children disciplined this way has dropped from 1.4 million in the 1979-80 school year to 365,000 in 1996-97. But it is primitive and unconscionable for educators anywhere to cling to the right to beat a child in the name of learning. The practice is contrary to this nation's respect for individual rights and its legal traditions against punishments that are arbitrary and not administered under strict rules and limits. Corporal punishment in schools has been outlawed by most democratic nations. Yet Congress is considering a Teacher Liability Protection Act, supported by President Bush, that is likely to increase the number of paddlings in states and school districts where corporal punishment is still legal.

title: Jorge Robson de Souza, Port Isabel Service Processing Center near Los Fresnos, Tex., April 24, 2001
description: left my home in Vitoria, a city in southeastern Brazil, and took a 16-hour bus ride to Sao Paulo. I had to pawn my house and a plot of land in Vitoria to raise the $8,000 needed to pay the coyotes that smuggled me to the United States. But I didn't find a job when I got here. Instead, I ended up in this health center after being detained by an immigration officer. The doctors took an X-ray and found a spot in my lungs. They told me I had to stay in isolation, that I might have to stay here two months. All I could think was that I was going to die in this cold place, away from my kids. But I know I'm not sick. My brother had a lung removed due to resistant tuberculosis. I'm not coughing like my brother. I am not wasted away like him. They gave me a Bible in Portuguese, so I read all the time. I also watch TV a lot. There's not much else to do. The worst part is falling asleep. I keep on thinking about my debts, my disease, my kids. I don't know what I'm going to do."

description: STADTMAUER-Paula. We extend our heartfelt sympathies and condolences to our dear Helene, and to David, Susan and Alan, Nana and Lenny and their entire families upon the passing of their most beloved Paula. Energetic and inspiring to the end, she lived her life with boundless love for her husband, children, grandchildren, family and friends. No detail was too small, or task too burdensome. Her successful and enduring accomplishments in establishing jobtraining programs for the unskilled and underprivileged afforded many hundreds of worthy individuals a new start on life. In this and many other ways, she set an extraordinary example of discrete but effective Chesed, and embodied the Rabbinic advise to ''Say little, but do much.'' May the memory of her devotion to her family and friends and the enduring consequences of her actions provide perpetual comfort to all who were touched by her, and especially to the center of her universe, her husband David, her mother Rose Goodman, her children Alan, Susan and Joel, Helene and Josh, and her grandchildren Dani, Cal, Jeremy, Gabrielle, Alex and Rebecca. title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Proxicom Gets A Second Ardent Suitor
description: Shares of Proxicom, an Internet consulting company that recently agreed to be acquired by the Compaq Computer Corporation, soared 31 percent yesterday after a competing bid came in at $112 million more. The second bidder was Dimension Data Holdings, a South African network services company known as Didata. It offered $7.50 a share, a 30 percent premium over Compaq's bid of $5.75, which Proxicom's board accepted in late April. The Dimension Data offer valued Proxicom at $448 million. Proxicom, based in Reston, Va., said its board would consider the new proposal and expected to choose a suitor this week. If Proxicom accepts the bid from Dimension Data, which is seeking to expand into the United States, Compaq will have three business days to match the price or settle for a $10 million termination fee for its troubles. Proxicom shares rose $1.78, to $7.44. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: MEDICAL COMPANY'S SHARES RISE AFTER F.D.A. STATEMENT
description: Shares in the Guidant Corporation rose 10 percent yesterday after the Food and Drug Administration said a statement it had made about the company was incorrect. Shares of Guidant, which is based in Indianapolis, rose $3.25, to $36.25. The shares fell 13 percent Friday after an F.D.A. spokeswoman said that Guidant's statements in a press release on the results of a clinical study of a new implantable heart defibrilator might have violated the law . Larry Spears, acting director of the F.D.A.'s office of compliance for devices, said the agency now thought its own statement ''went too far.'' Guidant said last week that its Contak CD device improved symptoms in heart-failure patients, whose weakening hearts cannot pump blood effectively. The device slowed the progression of heart failure, the company said. F.D.A. rules, however, prohibit companies from saying a product is safe or effective before the agency makes that determination.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Report Shows Nurses May Leave Profession
description: Nurses are dissatisfied with hospital conditions, and many plan to leave their jobs soon, a report in the journal Health Affairs has found. The study by the University of Pennsylvania surveyed 43,000 nurses in five countries, and found that they believe their pay is satisfactory and that doctors are generally good, but that patient care is rapidly deteriorating and stress is increasing, largely because of bad management and cost-cutting. In the United States, 20 percent of the nurses surveyed, and a third of those younger than 30, plan to leave the field in the next year. Philip J. Hilts (NYT)

Mr. Haigood, 37, is accused of stabbing Mr. Smith to death on Sunday in a fight that broke out when Mr. Haigood returned to the room where he lived with his wife, Shannon, and their two young children and found Mr. Smith, a friend, there. description: State laws that set lower alcohol limits for teenage drivers appear to reduce the number of young people who drink and drive, researchers have found.

McAlpin, Jr., Skillman, NJ; Stepdaughter Esther Mead Brownell of ME. Grandmother of John C. title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Crew's Names Added to Memorial
description: Twenty-one names were added to the Fishermen's Memorial in Seattle, above, including those of the 15-man crew of the Arctic Rose, the trawler that disappeared last month in the Bering Sea off Alaska. It was one of the highest totals ever added to the memorial in the annual ceremony commemorating those in the Seattle-based fleet lost at sea during the previous year. The ceremony was conducted partly in Spanish for mourners who came from Texas and Veracruz, Mexico, to honor several Mexican immigrants who worked aboard the Arctic Rose. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

description: PEARSON-George Bernard on Saturday, May 5, 2001 of Cabin John, MD. Beloved husband of Jean Royall Pearson. Father of April Michelle Pearson. Funeral service will be held at Pumprey's Bethesda-Chevy Chase Funeral Home, 7557 Wisconsin Ave., Bethesda, MD on Friday, May 11 at 11:00 AM. Interment Parklawn Memorial Park. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association, 839-E Quince Orchard Blvd., Gaithersburg, MD 20878

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Trade Group Deplores Potential Regulatory Costs
description: Privacy regulations being considered by Congress could add billions of dollars to the costs of doing business online, a technology industry trade group said. The group, Americans for Competitive Technology, which counts Microsoft among its chief sponsors, will publish a study from the American Enterprise Institute-Brookings Institution Joint Center for Regulatory Studies, and estimates the costs of modifying Web sites to comply with proposed privacy laws could range from $9 billion to $36 billion without necessarily providing provable benefits to consumers. John Schwartz (NYT)

description: After some 500 deaths in seven months, Imam Hajo today became the youngest known victim of the current Israeli-Palestinian violence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STADTMAUER, PAULA
description: STADTMAUER-Paula. We mourn the loss of our beloved wife, daughter, sister, mother and Bobbi. We stand amazed at the intensity of her talents and the breadth of her achievements. Her energy, devotion and great humor were the center of our lives and we grieve the loss of her magical touch. Her many family members and friends loved her deeply and their outpouring of affection and support is a great comfort to us now. As founder and director of Urban Employment Opportunities, she assisted so many in establishing secure and rewarding careers and thereby positively impacting upon thousands of others. Her life is best captured by Proverbs, ''Her children arise and praise her. Her husband lauds her. Many daughters have amassed achievement, but you surpassed them all.'' David Stadtmauer Rose Goodman Leonard and Helen Goodman Alan Stadtmauer Susan and Joel Rosh Helene and Josh Peyser Dani, Jeremy and Alex Rosh Cal, Gabriel and Rebecca Peyser

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Protests Over French Fries
description: In this Hindu nation where cows are sacred, McDonald's boasts that its burgers and other products are 100 percent nonbeef. But protesters in several cities are challenging that assertion, trying to close down the fast-food outlets for supposedly lacing fries with beef fat. The company denies the charge, but that has not stopped demonstrators from laying siege to the golden arches in Bombay, Pune and New Delhi. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Now, Easier Ways to Eliminate Varicose Veins
description: For years, Sal Salvaggio hid his legs. The ugly blue and red knots of veins that bulged out like clusters of grapes embarrassed him so much that he refused to wear shorts. Even more vexing was the weariness and pain he felt each evening, when he finally had a chance to rest his limbs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKMAN, LILLIAN
description: BERKMAN-Lillian. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, Lillian Berkman, and send condolences to her family.

title: Worker Pulled From East River After Falling From Bridge
description: A construction worker slipped off the Williamsburg Bridge and plunged 200 feet into the East River yesterday morning, prompting a daring rescue by two paramedics whom the Fire Department hailed as heroes for their quick thinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, REGINA
description: SCHREIBER-Regina, on May 6th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Leslie. Devoted mother of Buddy and Lucy, Larry and Alice. Dear sister of Edward and Amor. Loving grandmother of Lauri and Ronnie. Adored great-grandmother of Tal, Jonathan, Yasmin, Romy and Kelly. Services Wednesday, 11 AM, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Horse Is a Horse, Of Course, at NBC
description: NBC Sports promised nothing dramatically new or different about its first-time coverage of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday. True. The telecast, which culminated in Monarchos's upset victory, was not an improvement upon ABC's efforts in the past. Maybe NBC was playing it safe, waiting to take greater technical chances at the Preakness Stakes in two weeks and at the Belmont Stakes on June 9.

title: Spending on Prescription Drugs Increases by Almost 19 Percent
description: As an aging population coped with arthritis, diabetes and high cholesterol, spending on prescription drugs shot up 18.8 percent last year, to $131.9 billion, a new study shows.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Officer In Sex Case Resigns
description: A Nassau County police officer accused of forcing a woman to perform oral sex on him while he was on duty resigned from the force yesterday and, as part of a plea negotiation, was formally charged with the lesser crimes of receiving a bribe and official misconduct, the authorities said. The officer, Matthew Murphy, 36, a six-year veteran of the Nassau department, is expected to plead guilty in court today and to be sentenced to five years' probation, officials in the Nassau district attorney's office said. Mr. Murphy would have faced up to 25 years in prison if convicted of the original charge, first-degree sodomy. His lawyer, Paul Gianelli, did not return repeated phone calls seeking comment. Al Baker (NYT)

title: A Garden Party With a Bounty of Hors d'Oeuvres
description: George Balanchine's ''Divertimento No. 15'' has the charm of a springtime garden party. When the New York City Ballet performed this work to Mozart on Saturday night at the New York State Theater many of the guests were new.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Fox Urged For U.S. Attorney
description: Gov. John G. Rowland has formally recommended that President Bush name Brendan M. Fox Jr., Mr. Rowland's former legal counsel, as the next United States attorney in Connecticut. In a letter sent to Mr. Bush on Friday, Mr. Rowland described Mr. Fox, 36, the executive director of the Capital City Economic Development Authority, as ''the ultimate professional.'' Two weeks ago, the governor said he would supply a list of candidates to the Bush administration. But Mr. Fox was the only candidate on the governor's list, Dean Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, said yesterday. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Accounts
description: * Pioneer North America, Long Beach, Calif., expanded its relationship with BBDO West, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, by naming the BBDO West San Francisco office to handle a new corporate branding assignment, focusing on a line of digital products. Marketing spending was estimated at $20 million. BBDO West currently handles advertising for Pioneer's home and car divisions.

title: President Is Selected By Ad Industry Group
description: The National Advertising Review Council in New York, part of the self-regulatory mechanism of the advertising industry, said yesterday that it had filled the post of president, vacant for two years, by hiring James R. Guthrie, a longtime media and agency executive.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If you are H.I.V.-positive now, it doesn't mean you are dying. If you want to go to school, you should go to school. If you want to buy a car, you should buy a car.''

title: A Room-Service Treat at $25,000 (Piano Included)
description: BOBBY SHORT lowers his famous voice, his improbable, inimitable liquid sandpaper voice, as if the gleaming black Bechstein grand that dominates his living room might overhear. ''Let's sit and talk in the library,'' he suggests, his raspy, conspiratorial whisper calculated to charm. ''Sometimes I like to get away from the piano,'' Mr. Short says with a let's-play-hooky grin.

title: Creating a Modern Ark of Genetic Samples
description: Scientists at the American Museum of Natural History are building a 21st century version of Noah's Ark. Except this time, instead of two by two, the animals will go in little bits and pieces, deep frozen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, JANET CHASE
description: MEAD-Janet Chase, 4/21/1918-5/ 5/2001 83, died at Yale New Haven Hospital, May 5, 2001 from cancer. She lived with her husband of 59 years, Lawrence M. Mead, at Evergreen Woods, a life care facility, in North Branford, CT. The Meads moved there in 1994 from Huntington, L.I., NY where they were residents for 52 years. She was born in Montclair, NJ and graduated from Wellesley College as a biologist. She worked as a laboratory assistant for several New York City hospitals before marriage and as a Doctor's Assistant in later years. She served terms as Treasurer and then President of the Planned Parenthood chapter in Huntington, and later was a Board member of Huntington Visiting Nurse. She had four sons, Lawrence M. Mead III, of New York City, Kirtland C. Mead of Cambridge, MA, Jonathan T. Mead, deceased, and Branford M. Mead of Simsbury, CT, seven grandchildren and a brother, Thomas T. Chase, of Wilmington DE. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM, May 11, 2001 at the First Congregational Church in Branford, CT. Memorial gifts may be made to Planned Parenthood, 755 New York Ave., Huntington, NY 11743.
