title: China Rejects U.S. Proposal to Fly Spy Plane Off Island
description: BEIJING, May 8  China today officially rejected a plan by United States military officials to repair and fly out of the country a damaged American spy plane now stranded on China's Hainan Island.

title: New Warnings on Lead and Children
description: A new study raises questions about whether the current measure used to define lead poisoning is stringent enough.

title: Preschools Give Poor Children Lasting Benefits, Study Says
description: Poor children who attend intensive preschool classes are more likely to graduate from high school and less likely to be arrested than poor children who have not participated in such programs, according to a study that followed graduates of urban preschools for 15 years.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Nero's Home Damaged (But No Fire)
description: Nero may be best known for fiddling while Rome went up in flames but the remains of his palace are now threatened by another element -- water. The Domus Aurea, or House of Gold, built on Nero's orders after the fire of Rome in 64 A.D. and reopened to visitors two years ago after two decades of painstaking restoration, has been shut temporarily after heavy rains caused chunks of a ceiling to fall in. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Defibrillators, and Minutes, Count
description: Equipping police officers with portable defibrillators, which shock the hearts of some heart victims back into normal rhythm, could significantly increase survival rates, a new study finds.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRATT, RICHARDSON, JR.
description: PRATT-Richardson, Jr. A memorial service to commemorate the life of Richardson (Jerry) Pratt, Jr. will be held on Monday, May 21, 2001 at 11:30 AM at Old First Presbyterian Church, 125 Main St., Huntington, NY. For directions, call 631-427-2101. In lieu of flowers the Richardson Pratt, Jr. Scholarship Fund has been established at Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11205.

title: Hampton's Change of Pace Is Working Out All Right
description: Just above the foothills in Evergreen, Colo., situated in the Rocky Mountains about 40 minutes from Coors Field, Mike Hampton and his family have found paradise. The way Hampton described it today, his off-season move from New York to Colorado has fulfilled his greatest expectations.

title: U.S. Resumes Its Spy Flights Close to China
description: The United States resumed reconnaissance flights off the coast of China today for the first time since a collision on April 1 between a Navy surveillance plane and a Chinese fighter jet bruised relations between the two nations, defense officials said.

title: Ex-Heads of Auction HousesIndicted in Price-Fixing Case
WHITE HOUSE PICKS CHAIRMAN OF S.E.C.
description: The Bush administration has chosen Harvey L. Pitt, a prominent corporate lawyer, to be the next chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, officials said today. Mr. Pitt, a frequent critic of the agency, has represented many of the industries he will now regulate.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Emergency Housing Criticized
description: Dozens of families displaced by fires and other emergencies are housed in ''deplorably unsafe and unsanitary'' apartments financed by the city, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday. The conditions include roach infestation, clogged sinks, holes in ceilings, broken beds and ripped mattresses, he said. The worst conditions were found in apartments the city rents for emergency housing on Amboy Street in Brooklyn, but similar problems were identified at Manhattan apartments on West 143rd Street and West 129th Street, said Mr. Hevesi, a candidate for mayor. The administration said it had already proposed allocating money for repairs. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: Yankees Are Off and Running and Causing Havoc on the Bases
description: The Yankees are running the bases so much these days that their aggressive tendencies are invading their sleep. Scott Brosius had this dream last Friday night: He was leading off first base, against Danny Darwin -- a pitcher who retired three years ago -- and he noticed that Darwin had a big leg kick in his delivery. Plus all the lights in the stadium were dimmed, as if he were running in a cave.

title: Court Considers Ownership Of Seized 'Hitler' Paintings
description: In a climate-controlled basement downtown, at a location that the United States Army has insisted on keeping secret since the end of World War II, is a carefully executed, traditional watercolor of a quaint, empty courtyard. Measuring about 16 by 21 inches, it lies in a steel-gray cabinet along with three others by the same hand.

title: Officer Charged in Killing That Roiled Cincinnati
description: Two misdemeanor charges were filed today against a white police officer who shot an unarmed black man to death last month, a killing that sparked four days of protest and street violence in this racially tense city.

title: Building a Better Racehorse, From the Genome Up
description: Alice Chandler breeds racehorses the way her father did, the way generations of Kentucky hardboots have bred the sleek, swift-footed competitors in the sport of kings.

title: McKay's Punches Enrage Joseph
description: Twenty-five seconds were left in the game when Devils wing Randy McKay backed into Maple Leafs goalie Curtis Joseph in his crease.

title: Bush Chooses Hutchinson as New Counter-Drug Chief
description: WASHINGTON, May 8  Representative Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas, a Republican who was a House prosecutor in the impeachment trial of President Bill Clinton, has been chosen by President Bush to head the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: Patients Embrace New Generation of Imaging Machines
description: Until recently, Phil Whitton always asked to be heavily sedated before undergoing magnetic resonance imaging tests. Ms. Whitton, a nurse from Milwaukee who had a benign salivary gland tumor removed 15 years ago, still has a follow-up M.R.I. every six months. But the long, dark tunnel, the cramped quarters and the whirring racket of a standard imaging machine brought on a previously unnoticed claustrophobia so severe that she could not bear the procedure without being medicated.

title: Legislators Back Sharp Limits On Cell Calls by Nassau Drivers
description: Nassau County legislators caught up with their neighbors in Suffolk and Westchester Counties today by moving to curb the use of cell phones in cars. But the bill they approved is one notch stricter than the laws in those other suburban enclaves: it would even outlaw dialing while driving.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Verisign Offering New Corporate Service
description: In an effort to stand out in an increasingly competitive business, the Internet address registrar VeriSign said yesterday that it would offer businesses a new Web-based console to simplify and streamline the search, registration, renewal and management of multiple domain names. Through the new service, companies that subscribe to VeriSign's Online Brand Identity and Protection Services can view their company's portfolio of domain names, generate reports, view invoices and modify registrations. To earn revenue, Internet registrars like VeriSign and Register.com are vying for corporate clients that hold dozens of Internet names. Some Fortune 500 companies may have Web sites numbering ''in the hundreds,'' said Maigread Eichten, VeriSign's vice president for corporate domain name services. Prices for VeriSign's enhanced services start at $95,000 a year, she said. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Huge Brooklyn Lease Signed
description: The Atlantic Telecom Center in Brooklyn has signed the largest least at a so-called telecommunications hotel in the city with Williams Communications, a broadband network company based in Tulsa, Okla., center officials announced yesterday. The company is taking 169,000 square feet in the telecommunications center, which is scheduled to open later this year. The center, backed by the Carlyle Group and JP Morgan Partners, is being built on Vanderbilt Avenue on the border of Fort Greene and Clinton Hill in Brooklyn. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Clearing Pinochet's Minefields
description: The Senate has unanimously approved an international land-mine treaty that obliges the country to remove hundreds of mines planted along the Argentine, Bolivian and Peruvian borders during the 1973-90 Augusto Pinochet dictatorship. Congressional officials said the operation would cost Chile $300 million. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Strand of Ancient Yarn Suggests Early European Presence in Canada
description: A summer spent working at ''Greenland's Pompeii'' inspired one Canadian archaeologist to take a second look at Canadian collections of native artifacts gathered from Labrador and Baffin Island, a treeless Canadian Arctic region that Viking sagas call ''Helluland,'' or the land of the flat stones.

title: Florida Ruling Delays Payments To Smokers, Pending Appeals
description: The Philip Morris Companies and other tobacco companies will not have to pay damages to Florida smokers until appeals of a $145 billion jury award, the largest in history, are resolved, a state judge ruled today.

title: Contradicting the Liturgy With Anger and Disgust
description: This is a city of memorials. Leaders in time of conflict look out from Greek and Roman temples. Monuments soar up in abstract celebration. Walls record the names of the fallen. Marble and granite have a cleansing effect on the experience of war. Courage and sacrifice take on a disembodied air. There is no longer an event, only a statue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, HELENA DEKAY GILDER, M.D.
description: MILLER-Helena deKay Gilder, M.D. The last surviving granddaughter of Louis Comfort Tiffany, formerly of Upper Montclair, NJ and Tyringham, MA died at her home in Mitchellville, MD on April 6, 2001. She was 87. There will be a memorial service on June 22, 2001 at 2 p.m. in the Tyringham Union Church, Tyringham, MA

title: After Heart Surgery, an Added Concern
description: No one is sure why, but researchers say it appears that women who have heart surgery are at greater risk of having strokes and other neurological problems afterward than are men who have the same operation.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Effort To Soothe China
description: In a bid to improve relations with China, Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka acknowledged that the recent government approval of textbooks with a nationalist bent had offended Chinese sensibilities. ''My heart aches as the textbook issue had a negative impact on Japan-China relations,'' Ms. Tanaka said in a telephone conversation with her counterpart, Tang Jiaxuan, according to foreign ministry officials. She said Japan's new government shared the sentiments of Tomiichi Murayama, Japan's prime minister in 1995, who apologized to China for Japan's wartime atrocities.

title: Bush Declares Freer Trade A Moral Issue; Chides Critics
description: President Bush took on critics of his free trade agenda today, arguing that his administration's effort to break down tariffs was ''a moral imperative'' that would help clean up the environment and promote workers' rights.

title: New Auto Emissions Testing System Faces Elimination by Lawmakers
description: Less than a year after officials finally declared New Jersey's problem-plagued enhanced auto emissions testing system complete, state lawmakers are now citing new federal rules in calling for an end to the enhanced test for about half the state's cars.

title: Decrease in Chronic Illness Bodes Well for Medicare Costs
description: The chances that elderly Americans will be devastated by chronic disabilities like stroke and dementia have declined sharply, the National Academy of Sciences said yesterday. If the trend continues, researchers said, spending on Medicare could actually stop increasing.

title: High Demand For Energy Spurs Mergers
description: Two mergers announced yesterday in disparate parts of the energy industry may not seem to have much in common, but they point to an effort by some companies to capitalize on growing demand for gasoline and electricity and lagging supplies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFFMILLER, HENRY
description: SCHIFFMILLER-Henry. Young Israel of Oceanside expresses heartfelt condolences to our member Marty Schiffmiller and family on the loss of his beloved father, Henry. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Tzion and Yerushalayim. Joel Felderman, President Jay Yaacov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: Aage Sorensen, 59, Inequality Theorist at Harvard
description: Aage B. Sorensen, a Danish-born Harvard sociologist who played an important role in developing new sociological theories of inequality, died on April 18 in Boston He was 59.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLINTOCK, MALCOLM SCOTT
description: McCLINTOCK-Malcolm Scott of Northport, NY suddenly on May 6th, 2001 in his 70th year. Husband of Winifred Jolly. Father of Sara Louise McClintock and her husband John Dunne and Malcolm James McClintock and his wife Annie Herr. Devoted grandfather of Thomas Malcolm McClintock and James Donald McClintock. Family will receive friends Wednesday, May 9th, 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, Northport, LI, NY. Funeral service Thursday May 10, 4 PM at Congregational Church of Huntington, 30 Washington Drive, Centerport, NY with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers donations to International Campaign for Tibet, P.O. Box 97241, Washington, D.C. 20090, in his memory appreciated.

title: Yankees Bulk Up On Plankton
description: With the season in its sixth week, the Yankees have yet to lose to a team with a losing record. No other major league team can make that claim. Syllogistically, the Yankees could be viewed this way: good teams beat up on bad teams, the Yankees beat up on bad teams, therefore the Yankees are a good team.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Con Ed to Expand Plants
description: Con Edison said yesterday that it would invest $286 million to expand two of its power generating plants in New Jersey and Massachusetts that are operated by a subsidiary, Con Edison Development. The expansion, at natural gas turbine plants in Lakewood, N.J. and West Springfield, Mass., will add 600 megawatts -- enough power for 600,000 homes -- to the plants' existing combined output of 359 megawatts. The Lakewood project, which is scheduled to be completed by the end of 2002, will cost about $228 million and the Massachusetts plant, to be completed before the summer of 2002, will cost $58 million. Con Edison Development is the utility's power-generating arm that operates outside of New York. Under deregulation, Con Edison sold off most of its plants and now mainly distributes electricity and gas to its three million customers in New York City and Westchester. The electricity generated by the New Jersey and Massachusetts plants will be offered for sale in wholesale markets in New England and the Mid-Atlantic region, company officials said. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Airline Lends Shares
description: Swissair Group said it was lending its 10 percent stake in Austrian Airlines A.G., including voting rights, to Credit Suisse First Boston ahead of a planned sale of the holding. Swissair would not disclose the financial terms of the loan, but analysts said the airline was trying to raise money after the company posted a loss of 2.9 billion Swiss francs for 2000, the worst one-year loss in its 70-year history. The move comes less than two weeks after Swissair obtained a credit line of 1 billion Swiss francs ($578 million) from a group of banks to meet operating costs.

description: Two recent studies show both the risk and potential benefits of moderate alcohol consumption among older adults.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: RADIOSHACK CORP., Fort Worth, said Verizon Wireless will sell wireless telephones and service plans at almost 4,400 RadioShack stores as part of an alliance.

title: John Lee, 64, an Athlete at Yale Who Chose Industry Over Knicks
description: John J. Lee Jr., a basketball star for Yale who became a corporate executive and a leading fund-raiser for his alma mater, died Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 64.

title: Change at the Smithsonian
description: In deference to public and scientific outcry, Lawrence M. Small, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, has announced that he is withdrawing a plan to close the National Zoo's Conservation and Research Center in Front Royal, Va., which studies the behavior, reproductive biology and preservation of endangered and threatened species. This is the kind of flip-flop that no institutional head likes to make, and Mr. Small was right to make it. But more was at issue than what he called the ''false perception'' that the Smithsonian ''was backing away from its commitment to science.'' The protest against the closing of the Front Royal conservation center was a sensible effort to preserve an asset that would be sorely missed and difficult to replicate were it to be lost in a shortsighted effort to save money.

title: Charles L. Black Jr., 85, Constitutional Law Expert Who Wrote on Impeachment, Dies
description: Prof. Charles L. Black Jr., a leading authority on constitutional law who taught at Columbia and Yale Universities for 52 years and was a prominent voice in the national debates on presidential impeachments, desegregation, the death penalty and other issues, died at his home in Manhattan on Saturday. He was 85.

title: Falun Gong Protests Greet China's Leader in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG, May 8  President Jiang Zemin of China championed the freedom of Hong Kong today, as protesters from the Falun Gong spiritual movement rallied throughout the city, accusing Mr. Jiang of imprisoning and torturing their members on the Chinese mainland.

title: Vigilant in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Prayer for Tech Stocks
description: The Rev. Douglas W. Schroeder still believes in technology stocks. His father, the Rev. Paul R. Schroeder, has lost his faith.

title: Born to Run, Sure, but Thoroughbreds Face Physical Limits to Improvement
description: Human runners broke the four-minute mile in 1954 and have been getting faster and faster ever since.

title: The Democrats Talk It Over
description: Since they have 127 days in which to squabble, it is no surprise that the first televised debate among the four major Democratic mayoral candidates was a decorous affair. With multiple exhibitions of bonhomie, each attempted to describe what he would preserve and what he would not preserve of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's method of running New York City. With the primaries set for Sept. 11 and any runoff two weeks later if no candidate gets 40 percent of the vote, the candidates all seem to understand the next mayor's necessary priorities.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Toshiba Laptop to Use Upstart Chip
description: The Transmeta Corporation said yesterday that its low-power Crusoe microprocessor will power a new lightweight Toshiba notebook computer that goes on sale as the Libretto model in Japan on May 18. Toshiba, the world's biggest maker of laptop computers, said the low-power chip would contribute to a battery life of up to 14 hours. Transmeta, once a secretive upstart, has recently signed a number of big deals with hardware vendors, challenging Intel's market dominance. Still, its shares fell nearly 24 percent, to $11.17 yesterday, after the company's initial public offering lockup period expired, freeing a majority of its shares from trading restrictions. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Jorge Robson de Souza, Port Isabel Service Processing Center near Los Fresnos, Tex., April 24, 2001
description: left my home in Vitoria, a city in southeastern Brazil, and took a 16-hour bus ride to Sao Paulo. I had to pawn my house and a plot of land in Vitoria to raise the $8,000 needed to pay the coyotes that smuggled me to the United States. But I didn't find a job when I got here. Instead, I ended up in this health center after being detained by an immigration officer. The doctors took an X-ray and found a spot in my lungs. They told me I had to stay in isolation, that I might have to stay here two months. All I could think was that I was going to die in this cold place, away from my kids. But I know I'm not sick. My brother had a lung removed due to resistant tuberculosis. I'm not coughing like my brother. I am not wasted away like him. They gave me a Bible in Portuguese, so I read all the time. I also watch TV a lot. There's not much else to do. The worst part is falling asleep. I keep on thinking about my debts, my disease, my kids. I don't know what I'm going to do."

title: Metro Business Briefing | Newark Improvement Award
description: The Newark Downtown District yesterday awarded its first reimbursement check to a property owner under its Facade Improvement Program, which it began last year. The check for $18,000 was presented to David Anstatt, a partner in Halsey Associates, a Newark real estate company that is restoring the original brick and wood facades of a row of five town houses at 25-33 Halsey Street. The check is worth about half the total award, which matches the amount the owners are spending to restore the three-story buildings, which have a total of seven commercial units intended to house restaurants and shops, said Dennis Frost, the district's grant project manager. title: Morris Graves, Mystical Painter of Nature, Is Dead at 90
description: Morris Graves, an artist whose paintings of wounded birds and supernaturally radiant flowers combined the spirit of American Transcendentalism with Asian philosophy, and whose reclusive efforts to avoid what he called ''the machine-age noise of America'' were the stuff of legend, died on Saturday at his home in Loleta, Calif. He was 90.

title: Texas Senate Passes Hate Crimes Bill That Bush's Allies Killed
description: Joining the Texas House, the State Senate today approved a hate crimes bill, two years after Senate allies of Gov. George W. Bush suppressed similar legislation opposed by conservatives because it specifically included protections for gays.

title: Race by the Numbers
description: In recent weeks, reporting and commentary that misinterpret early census results have been persistently misinforming the nation about its ethnic and racial composition. The misinformation is dangerous, since it fuels fears of decline and displacement among some whites, anxieties that are not only divisive but groundless. The Center for Immigration Studies, for example, a think tank in Washington, recently warned that by the middle of the century non-Hispanic whites will cease to be a majority and that ''each group in the new minority-majority country has longstanding grievances against whites.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Inflation Slows
description: Producer price inflation slowed in the 12-member euro zone in March, the European statistical office Eurostat said. Prices rose 0.1 percent on the previous month compared with 0.2 percent in February, and were 4.1 percent higher than a year earlier. In the European Union as a whole, producer price inflation was unchanged from February at an annual rate of 3.6 percent. Nondurable consumer goods registered the biggest monthly rise, of 0.5 percent, in both the euro zone and the European Union. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Output Is Up
description: The pace of Brazilian industrial output quickened in March as manufacturers stepped up production to meet growing demand for big-ticket items like automobiles. Output rose 7.7 percent from the period a year earlier, more than the revised 1.4 percent rise in February, the government said. A Bloomberg News survey of nine economists forecast an 8.2 percent growth rate. A falling jobless rate is increasing consumer purchases on credit, prompting companies like General Motors and the steel maker Gerdau S.A. to crank up output and push forward an 18-month-old economic expansion.

His business, the Currency Group, was based in Branford, Conn., but it drew investors from around the world with promises of high returns on the trading of Brazilian bonds. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

National Briefing | Washington: Scalia's Son Named to Bush Administration Post
description: The Bush administration has chosen a son of Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court to be solicitor of labor, the top legal position in the Department of Labor. The son, Eugene Scalia, is a labor and employment law specialist in the Washington office of a Los Angeles-based law firm, Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher. The court's rules are not completely clear, but the appointment of Mr. Scalia, 37, to the policy-making position may require his father to recuse himself from some cases in which the labor department is involved. Because the Solicitor General's office, a unit of the Justice Department, represents the federal government in all Supreme Court cases, Mr. Scalia will not actually argue before the court. But the name of the solicitor of labor typically appears on any briefs in cases involving the labor department.

The tests are a sign the government is paying special attention to Airbus, and that ''major events between China and the U.S. would affect the balance that the Chinese government holds in deciding whose aircraft it is going to buy,'' the report stated. description: GARLEN-David on Sunday May 6, 2001 of Summit, NJ. Beloved husband of 52 years to Hyla (nee Brodkin). Devoted father of Nancy Leone, Elizabeth Arrison, and Daniel Garlen. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Memorial services will be conducted from Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road Union, NJ on Tuesday May 8, 2001 at 3:30 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Cornell University Library.

title: Mayor's Wife Wants His Friend Kept From Mansion
description: Lawyers for Donna Hanover, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's estranged wife, have asked a judge to bar Judith Nathan, the mayor's companion, from Gracie Mansion.

title: Residents Backing Strikers At Big Apartment Complex
description: For more than two months now, the handymen and janitors at Fairfield Towers, a sprawling high-rise apartment and condominium complex in East New York, Brooklyn, have camped out along Van Siclen Avenue on strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WESTERMAN, EDWARD
description: WESTERMAN-Edward. A beloved, gentle man whose beautiful smile revealed his warmth and kindness. Sleep in peace, dear friend and ''Uncle Ed.'' Betty Davis, Alyce and Scott Davis, Vicki and Jeffrey Gradinger

title: Education: School District Buys 23,000 Laptops
description: Aschool district's order for new books is rarely met with the buzz this year's purchase is generating among teachers and students in Richmond, Va. But these are no ordinary books.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Manufacturing Setback
description: German manufacturing orders fell 4.4 percent in March, a bigger decline than most economists had expected and new evidence of the impact that slumping demand in the United States is having on Germany's economy, the biggest in Europe. Foreign orders were 7 percent lower in March than in February, the third consecutive monthly decline. Economists at Deutsche Bank said the data suggested that economic growth in Germany would be weaker in the months ahead. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: A Book Spreads the Word: Prayer for Prosperity Works
description: Buried in what many religion scholars agree is the least read and most boring section of the Bible, among the interminable genealogies where one ancient ''begat'' another, are 73 words about a mysterious character named Jabez.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Ex-Publisher Is Sentenced
description: The former publisher of The Cheboygan Daily Tribune was ordered to perform 80 hours of community service for violating Michigan's campaign-finance law by giving special advertising rates to one mayoral candidate last year. The former publisher, Roy S. Trahan II, pleaded guilty last month, acknowledging that he charged one candidate, Thomas J. VerWys, a discount flat rate of $1 each for four campaign advertisements, but charged the incumbent mayor, Bill Chlopan, the regular rate of $5.20 a column inch. Mr. Chlopan won re-election in Cheboygan, a city in northern Lower Michigan. Mr. Trahan resigned his job last year and is now publisher of two Indiana newspapers. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Bombing Trial Defense Disavows bin Laden Calls for Violence
description: Lawyers for two defendants in the embassy bombings trial sharply distanced their clients yesterday from the views of the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden, saying they had never agreed with his calls for killing Americans around the world.

title: Chinese Tread Warily in Secrets-Theft Case
description: Datang Telecom Technology, the Chinese company said to be the intended beneficiary of corporate espionage at Lucent Technologies, said today that it was ''shocked'' by reports of theft of Lucent's trade secrets. But Datang stopped short of denying that it had planned to sell the stolen technology through a company it controls.

title: Confession in Brooklyn Stabbing Is Ruled Admissable as Evidence
description: A Brooklyn judge yesterday allowed into evidence the confession of a man who said that he killed Amy Watkins, a 26-year-old graduate student, as she walked home from the subway one night in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Prospect Heights.

title: Addenda: 2 Units Are Expanding at Havas Advertising
description: Arnold Worldwide in Boston acquired Simmons Durham in St. Louis, an agency with 32 employees and billings estimated at $71 million from clients like the Jack Daniel's whiskey brand sold by the Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide unit of the Brown-Forman Corporation. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Albany Moves to Expand Use Of Private Diesel Generators
description: New York State has taken a crucial step toward making it easier for businesses to rely on their own diesel generators for power this summer, while promising to set rules for reducing the air pollution from those generators.

title: Experts See Flaws in U.S. Mad Cow Safeguards
description: Despite stringent measures to protect people and cattle from mad cow disease, experts in and out of government say more can be done.

title: Honor, Hate and the German Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RIVES, WENDY A., M.D.
description: RIVES-Wendy A., M.D. Memorial service, Friday, May 18, 2001, 5:30 P.M. All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue at East 80th Street. Reception to follow.

title: Corrections
description: The Connections column in Arts & Ideas on Saturday, about Henry James's novel ''The Golden Bowl'' and the recent Merchant-Ivory film adaptation of it, misidentified the publisher of ''Henry James and Modern Moral Life'' by the philosopher Robert Pippin. It is Cambridge University Press, not Oxford.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISTER, WENDY
description: MEISTER-Wendy. We extend heartfelt condolences to Robert, Todd, and Keith Meister, as well as Gail Mason and Richard Alexander on the untimely, sad passing of their beloved wife, mother and sister. A ''Woman of Valor'', Wendy was a role model to her family and friends. Her life was a blessing, full of compassion, goodness and selflessness. To all who had the privilege of knowing this beautiful woman, she personified the highest standards of grace, dignity and courage. The tradition of Tzedakah and Chesed faithfully fulfilled by Wendy, is a legacy of a woman who imbued her family with profound values. As a Diamond Founder of the Medical Center, together with her husband, Robert, and as an honorary member of the National Women's Division Board, Wendy made a vital difference to the health-care needs of thousands of people in Jerusalem and Israel. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr. Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, Pres. Sidney Adler, Treas. Lee Weinbach, Pres. Nat'l Women's Div. Michael S. Strauss, Chrmn. NY Bd.

title: California Blackouts
description: Hit with a hot spell at a time when several power plants were down for maintenance, California yesterday began its first rolling blackouts since March. Power-grid operators ordered utilities to cut electricity to tens of thousands of customers at the start of the evening rush hour.

title: China's 'Go West' Drive Seeks to Funnel Aid to Poor Region
description: BEIJING  When he took control of the nation in the late 1970s, Deng Xiaoping made a dramatic break with China's decades-long commitment to the socialist principles of egalitarianism by declaring that "some people and some regions in China should be allowed to get rich before others."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Payton Injures Hamstring and May Go on D.L.
description: The Mets have shown signs of life over the last week, signs that their offense is coming together and sustaining rallies. Jay Payton, who has batted .409 over his last 16 games, is a big reason. Now Payton is likely to go on the disabled list after straining his right hamstring in the Mets' 10-9 victory over the Colorado Rockies tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORMAN, HARVEY
description: CORMAN-Harvey. A gifted physician who lives on in the patients he healed. Bunny Grossinger

title: Central Park Mob Victim Identifies Officer She Says Didn't Help
description: A woman who was sexually assaulted in Central Park after last year's National Puerto Rican Day Parade took the stand yesterday at a Police Department disciplinary trial to identify the officer who she said ignored her pleas for help after she was molested by rampaging men.

title: MILITARY COMMUNICATIONS COMPANY BUYS MAKER OF FUSES
description: L-3 Communications Holdings, which makes military communications systems and flight-data recorders, said yesterday that it had bought the closely held KDI Precision Products for about $67.5 million. KDI makes fuses that are designed to prevent the inadvertent firing or detonation of weapons like artillery shells, guided missiles and grenades during handling. KDI, based in Cincinnati, is expected to have sales of about $70 million in 2001, said L-3, which is based in New York.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Lockheed's Ad Account Goes to a New Agency
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it had named Keiler & Company in Farmington, Conn., to take on its account, which had been handled by the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Another Setback for U.S.
description: The United States has lost its seat on a second United Nations panel, the International Narcotics Control Board, said the State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher. He called the loss ''very regrettable.'' The 13-member board, based in Vienna, monitors compliance with international agreements to control drugs. A diplomat, Herbert S. Okun, has been the American representative since 1997. Last week the United States lost its seat on the Human Rights Commission. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: O'Neal Looms Even Larger to Kings
description: Scot Pollard, the 6-foot-11 Sacramento Kings reserve center, perhaps put it best on the day after he and his 7-1 teammate Vlade Divac were consistently overpowered by the Los Angeles Lakers' Shaquille O'Neal.

title: A Vexed Mission of Reconciliation
description: Pope John Paul II has been on the road again in recent days, renewing his heartfelt effort to heal historic rifts between the Roman Catholic Church and other religions. This cause, which last year took John Paul to Israel, has become a central mission of his papacy, and will form one of his most important legacies to his church and the world.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Pirro Conviction Upheld
description: A federal appeals court has upheld the conviction of Anthony G. Pirro, the brother-in-law of the Westchester district attorney. Mr. Pirro, an accountant, and his older brother, Albert J. Pirro Jr., the husband of Jeanine F. Pirro, were convicted in June of improperly deducting $1.2 million of Albert Pirro's personal expenses as business expenses. Anthony Pirro appealed, arguing that the trial judge had coerced a holdout juror and that a prosecutor had unfairly compared him to Richard Nixon. But in a decision made public yesterday, a three-judge appellate panel said the arguments lacked merit. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Montagnards, a group of ethnic minorities formerly allied with the United States and now protesting their treatment by the Vietnamese government, misstated the name of a Buddhist leader who recently met with a United Nations official to discuss religious persecution in Vietnam. He was Dr. Thich An Hue of the Vietnamese American Unified Buddhist Congress, not Trich An Hue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTGOMERY, WRIGHT
description: MONTGOMERY-Wright a resident of Fairfield, Ct. for 50 yearsdied at the age of 74 May 5, 2001. He was a graduate of Colgate University and served in the Navy during WW II in the Pacific. His business career was devoted to the marine insurance industry, starting with the firm of Leighton K. Montgomery Inc., later with J.F. Frelinghuysen Inc. and concluding with Marsh and McLennan in New York City. His four children and six grandchildren survive him.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Telephone Investments
description: Singapore Telecommunications and E. M. Warburg Pincus will each invest as much as $200 million in Bharti Group, the holding company for a leading phone company in India. The investments are part of a $460 million package that includes $35 million from AIF Funds Management, $20 million from the World Bank's International Finance Corporation, and $5 million from New York Life Insurance. Bharti will use the money to expand its fixed-line and cellular phone networks around the subcontinent. SingTel and Bharti have also said they plan to bid for a 25 percent stake in India's state-controlled international long-distance monopoly. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABBINER, JOAN
description: RABBINER-Joan. With profound sadness we note the passing of Joan Rabbiner, the most wonderful wife, mother and mother-inlaw. She will be extraordinarily missed by her husband, Marvin, and her children, Susan, Nancy, David, Kenneth and Andrea, who loved her so very much, and by her friends who were lucky to know her. Simply, the best. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 402 Park St, Hackensack NJ Tuesday 12:30PM.

title: London Journal; The Carnival Is Over for Devil-May-Care Ronnie
description: After 35 years as a fugitive who nurtured a raffish, playboy image, Ronald Biggs, one of Britain's ''Great Train Robbers,'' returned home today from Brazil -- sick, silver-haired and barely able to respond to a judge who sent him back to prison to serve out the 28 years of his term.

title: Small Loans Go Far in Indonesia
description: MEKARSARI, Indonesia  When the inhabitants of this village in West Java cross the narrow river that separates them from the markets and factories a short distance beyond, they know it may be a day or more before they can return home. Boats will not make the crossing at night for fear of bandit attacks while strong currents or seasonal rains can make the river impossible to negotiate even during the day.

title: Rules Keeper Is Dismissed By Senate, Official Says
description: Republican leaders decided last week to dismiss the Senate's parliamentarian, Robert B. Dove, because of their frustration over his recent rulings on tax and budget matters, a top leadership staff assistant said today.

title: Q & A
description: Liver Spots

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: Scores Die In Rebel Attack
description: In one of their boldest and deadliest strikes in recent memory, rebels of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola attacked a food warehouse in Caxito about 35 miles from the capital, Luanda. Reports of the death toll ranged from 69 to 100, but with thousands of people fleeing the town the exact number was unclear. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Diagnosis, With Blood And Timing
description: The day of the week or even the time of day a doctor examines a patient can play a significant role in making a correct diagnosis. This became clear to me when I treated a college student who came to my clinic late one Wednesday afternoon complaining of extreme fatigue.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Court Upholds Extended Privacy Rules
description: High-tech companies wanting to collect consumer information without regulatory restraint have lost a round in federal court. Judge Ellen Segal Shuzelle of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia denied a challenge to the Federal Trade Commission's regulations interpreting of the consumer privacy protection measures in the Gramm-Leach-Bliley financial services modernization bill. In a decision handed down last week but publicized by the regulatory agency yesterday, Judge Shuzelle sided with the government, which had been challenged by a coalition of credit reporting agencies and other companies that collect personal data on consumers. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Statewide Blackouts Ordered As Heat Strains California Grid
description: An early hot spell and a high number of power plants out of service for maintenance forced the first rolling power blackouts since March in California late today. Operators of the state's power grid suddenly ordered utilities to cut power to tens of thousands of customers at the evening rush hour, officials said.

description: PLATT-John Arthur, 48. British author, broadcaster, Rock on Film curator, and expert on 60's psychedelic poster art. Died at home in NYC, May 7, 2001. Survived by his wife Marylou Capes, his sister Mary Simpson, both his parents, and all his loving friends. Goodbye party/wake/nonsectarian shiva on Friday and Saturday at the home of friends. For info, 212-431-4373. No flowers. Bring food, memories, snappy patter, profound kindness.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Senate Parliamentarian Named
description: Republican leaders announced the appointment of a new Senate parliamentarian, Alan S. Frumin, who had been the associate parliamentarian. He succeeds Robert S. Dove, who was dismissed last week because of frustration over his rulings on tax and budget matters, a Republican staff assistant said. The parliamentarian advises the Senate on interpretation of its rules and procedures.

title: Several Executives Leave Red Sky
description: Several executives have left Red Sky, an interactive agency with offices in eight cities, including New York and San Francisco.

title: Fear of Fromage? A Survival Guide
description: FOR those new to the world of cheese, the moment when that cart comes rolling toward your table can be an uneasy one. A good cheese steward should guide you through it, but a few simple rules can help you navigate on your own.

title: Europe Plans Full Inquiry On G.E.-Honeywell Deal
description: Resisting pressure to cut it short, the European Commission will carry to completion its investigation of the General Electric Company's planned acquisition of Honeywell International, the commission confirmed today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Classically, the eyewitness is the king of the trial process. It was very hard for the courts to say scientific inquiry could call into question a person who has direct evidence to give.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Supercomputer Maker Reverses Loss
description: The supercomputer maker Cray Inc. of Seattle reported yesterday that its net income rose during the first quarter, beating analysts' consensus estimates by a penny a share. For the quarter ended March 31, Cray reported net income of $2.8 million, or 7 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $8 million, the equivalent of 27 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Philippine Eruption Snuffed Out Tribe's Way of Life : Pinatubo:10 Years Later
description: PATALBATO, Philippines  The sky darkened and the ground shook. It sounded like a "stampede of 100,000 animals," said a Filipino who witnessed it.

title: No Man Is an Island, Or Owns One Forever
description: Human expression doesn't get much chillier than in the gusts of icy contempt wafted by a British aristocrat in high dudgeon. When Lord Glenconner, the subject of Joseph Bullman's creepily fascinating documentary film, ''The Man Who Bought Mustique,'' turns his scorn on the residents of the tiny Caribbean island he once owned and then lost, you can feel your blood begin to freeze. And when he arrogantly tries to commandeer the movie being made about him, demanding reshoots to achieve a fake spontaneity and to cultivate a smoother screen image, you begin to understand why certain British monarchs were banished to the Tower of London.

title: Full Warning
description: MTV has taken extra steps to make people think twice before imitating the brazen stunts performed by the stars of its weekly ''Jackass'' show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, MORRIS
description: GRAVES-Morris. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

title: To Refresh a Palate, or a Sultan's Kiss
description: THIS is how you eat paan in India: You and your sweetheart go to a favorite restaurant and feed each other delicious food till you are so full you can barely stand. You saunter down the promenade, lulled by the moonlit waves, tropical breeze and twinkling stars. You happen upon a paan wallah, or betel vendor, ringing his bell as he pushes his truck.

title: Tharp Cancels Plan for Brooklyn Studio
description: In a setback for a budding arts enclave in Brooklyn, the choreographer Twyla Tharp has abruptly backed out of a plan to open her first permanent dance studio in a Civil War-era church a few blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: New Kind of Test at Amherst, on the Day the Urns Went Dry
description: On any given day, the coffee house in the Amherst College campus center offers a dozen brews, plus espresso. But today the pots were covered with white shrouds, and the dispensers in the dining hall were empty.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Cuts 1,000 Jobs
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation, which makes chips for cellular phones and personal computers, said it would eliminate 1,100 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, to reduce costs as orders slump. Sales in the fourth quarter ending May 27 will be $390 million to $400 million, the company said, down 16 percent to 18 percent from the previous quarter.

title: Flaws in Voucher Findings
description: WITH education high on the national agenda, some scholars have been tempted to publish sensational but premature conclusions. These can exploit policy makers' inability to distinguish simplistic analyses from those that stand up to closer examination.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cisco Has First-Ever Loss As It Writes Off Inventory

title: Metro Business Briefing | YankeeNets Make Land Offer
description: The company hoping to develop a basketball and hockey arena in Newark said yesterday it will pay $3 million for nine houses on the proposed site, if a deal is reached with the state to build the arena. The developer, YankeeNets, which owns the New York Yankees, the New Jersey Nets, and the New Jersey Devils, said it would pay $330,000 each for the nine houses, which are on Lafayette, Columbia and Hamilton Streets. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: U.S. Weighing Future of Strategic Arms Pacts
description: President Bush's decision to build missile defenses and eventually break with a central treaty of the cold war was the first outward sign of a far-reaching debate over whether the United States should simply abandon the business of negotiating strategic arms treaties.

title: Harvard Sit-In Over Pay Ends With Deal to Re-examine Policies
description: Bathed in cheers and blinking in the unaccustomed sunlight, 26 student protesters emerged today from a Harvard University administration building where they had staged a three-week sit-in to demand a ''living wage'' for the university's lowest-paid workers.

title: The End of a Family Business
description: JAY NEWTON has four children: three sons and a 15,000-square-foot restaurant in Phoenix. He opened the sprawling Beef Eaters steakhouse 40 years ago and has given his heart to the place ever since.

title: Sales Grow at Volkswagen, But Rest of Year Is a Concern
description: Judging by the results announced today, Volkswagen A.G., Europe's biggest automaker, managed to avoid the worst of the slowdowns in the United States and Germany in the first quarter. But the company cautioned that the rest of the year would be difficult, and analysts said they remained perplexed by the company's accounting practices.

title: U.S. Approves Univision Deal
description: Federal antitrust enforcement officials approved the acquisition of the broadcast group of USA Networks by Univision Communications for $1.1 billion, the companies said today.

title: South Korea Scraps Military Exercise With Japan
description: South Korea canceled a military exercise with Japan today and issued its strongest demand so far that Japan correct what it called distortions in schoolbook accounts of that country's role on the Korean Peninsula before and during World War II.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday comparing the time it takes to cross Manhattan on foot and by bus misstated the pedestrian's route. At Central Park West, the author turned south for one block, to 81st Street (not three blocks, to 79th Street), to look west for the bus.

title: A Site That Was an Accident Waiting to Happen. It Did.
description: For weeks, residents of South Eighth Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, worried that something bad was going to happen at the old meatpacking plant that was being converted into housing. Work went on late at night, they said. During the day, building beams toppled onto the street where children played.

title: Children Stay Free in Jamaica
description: Why deal with the guilt of leaving the kids at home? The Wyndham Rose Hall Resort in Montego Bay, Jamaica, will allow children 12 or younger to stay and dine for free when sharing a room with two adults (roll-away beds are extra) under its Kids On Us plan. Children must dine with the adults and meals must be ordered from the children's menu (by the kids, not the adults). This plan is available May 1 to Sept. 30. And for parents who need at least a little time away from their children, the Kids' Klub plan provides a 50 percent discount on an adjoining room for children 18 or younger. Room rates start at $140 a night, and are good through Dec. 22. A 22 percent room tax is extra, and there are a few blacked-out days in July and November. The 488-room resort offers a large array of water sports and an extensive pool complex with a float river and a 30-foot-high water slide. Information: (800) 996-3426 or www.wyndham.com .

title: Reckonings; The Unrefined Truth
description: Gasoline prices are rising again, and the administration is rushing to turn this into another argument for its drill-and-burn energy strategy. But a look at the causes of the current gasoline shortage actually suggests a quite different moral: namely, that conservation ought to be a major element in our energy strategy, and that lack of conservation is a large part of what we've been doing wrong.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Hearing a Wild and Crazy Guy From 11th-Century China
description: States of drunkenness are probably more fun when expressed in art than when experienced in real life. For one thing, there are no hangovers.

title: Bush Presses Yugoslav Leader to Hand Over Milosevic
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 - President Bush told Yugoslavia's president, Vojislav Kostunica, today that American financial assistance to Belgrade would depend on the fledgling democracy's cooperation with the war crimes tribunal at The Hague.

title: California Utility Accuses El Paso of Inflating Gas Prices
description: One of California's struggling utility companies accused the El Paso Corporation yesterday of artificially inflating the price of natural gas in the state by $3.7 billion over the last year by using its partial control of a major pipeline to curtail the flow of gas.

title: The Farm Boy Sharon Recalls Struggle as a Way of Life
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon explained today why he would not agree to freeze construction in existing Jewish settlements in the West Bank and Gaza. He told the Foreign Press Association that sometimes settler women get pregnant -- ''it happens'' -- and that their houses become too small.

title: Public Lives: An Alabama Prosecutor Confronts the Burden of History
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. - It barely registered with 9- year-old Doug Jones in the fall of 1963 that a bomb had exploded in a black church down the road in Birmingham, killing four girls just a few years older than he was. Growing up white in the segregated suburb of Fairfield, he had other concerns.

title: Cecil Price, 63, Deputy Guilty In Killing of 3 Rights Workers
description: Cecil R. Price, who as a deputy sheriff arrested three civil rights workers in Mississippi in 1964 and was eventually found guilty of delivering them into the hands of their killers, died on Sunday in Jackson, Miss. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABBINER, JOAN
description: RABBINER-Joan. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Marvin and the entire family. Stanley Plonchak, President

title: Twins' Milton And Guzman Tame Yankees
description: The Yankees, the Twins, the fans and the security personnel at Yankee Stadium were unsure of what to expect last night. Would spectators in the outfield seats try to retaliate for the abuse left fielder Chuck Knoblauch underwent in Minnesota last week?

title: China Says It Won't Let U.S. Spy Plane Fly Home
description: Days after American officials voiced hope that the damaged surveillance plane stranded on Hainan island could be repaired and flown out of China, China rejected that plan, saying today that it would not let the plane fly home.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: HALE HOUSE INQUIRY WIDENS The state attorney general's office said yesterday it would investigate allegations that donations to Hale House, the Harlem children's shelter, were used to shore up a failing off-Broadway musical produced by the husband of the charity's president. The Daily News reported yesterday that Dr. Lorraine E. Hale and her husband, Jesse DeVore, funneled $500,000 to Mr. DeVore's show, "Faith Journey," which was based on the life of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Both Dr. Hale and Mr. DeVore, the charity's public relations director, agreed earlier this week to resign from Hale House, and a new interim board of directors was named. It is expected to name Edna Wells Handy, a former general counsel for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, as the charity's interim executive director.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES, MAKER OF TEXTILES, WILL SHUT 2 FACTORIES
description: Fab Industries Inc., whose textiles are used to make sleepwear, sportswear and intimate apparel, will close two factories and eliminate about 150 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, to cut costs. The company will close the Travis Knits plant in Cherryville, N.C., and the Adirondack Knitting factory in Amsterdam, N.Y., by the end of the year. The knitting, dyeing and finishing done at the two plants will be moved to the company's Mohican Mills plant in Lincolnton, N.C., the chief financial officer, David Miller, said. Fab Industries, based in New York, said the weak economy and competition from imports had reduced demand for its products.

title: Northrop Grumman Joins Bidding for Shipbuilder
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation made an unsolicited bid yesterday to buy Newport News Shipbuilding Inc., an effort intended to undercut a deal struck last month between Newport News and the General Dynamics Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRUMBERG, IRA H.
description: FRUMBERG-Ira H., 79. Of Long Beach on May 7, 2001. Devoted husband of Gloria, loving father to Lawrence & Charles. Proud grandfather to Joshua, Brian, David, William, Emily, Alexandra, Kathryn & Jane. Uncle to Amy Beth Bates & brother-in-law to Evelyn. Veteran U.S. Army World War II Pacific Theater. Services at Riverside Chapel, Great Neck. Burial Calverton National Cemetery.

Cherished grandfather of Christin Shanahan Brecher and Mark Shanahan and great-grandfather of Thomas Henry Brecher. Dear brother of Peter Re. Friends may call Thursday, 6-8 PM, at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel), 1076 Madison Avenue, corner of 81st Street. Funeral Mass on Thursday, 9:15 AM, at St. Thomas More R.C. Church. Interment St. Mary's Cemetery, Nantucket.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Jets Fly Again
description: Regulators said Ansett Australia could resume flying all but two of its 767 jets, which were grounded last month because of safety problems and lax maintenance. The other two 767's had already been scheduled for overhauls, a spokesman said. Ansett is owned by Air New Zealand and its rival, Qantas. Those airlines have both warned of falling profits because of high fuel costs, currency weakness and slowing demand. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: The Essence Of Beauty? Ooh La Loren
description: LET'S begin with a story about Sophia Loren, if only because mentioning Sophia Loren in the first sentence improves a column's chances of being read.

title: Olympic Champion Thrives With Twins
description: Twenty-four Twins were talking and laughing as they prepared to stretch before yesterday's game with the Yankees, but Doug Mientkiewicz stood apart from them, inched closer to the batting cage and watched the three-time defending World Series champions hit. Mientkiewicz was riveted. Mientkiewicz had previously said that he appreciates the subtleties of baseball now that he has had success, and this was a chance for him to soak up some casual yet worthwhile moments.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Resignation Sought at Roche
description: Roche Holding A.G., 20 percent of whose shares were bought by its rival Novartis, said that it had asked its chief financial officer to resign less than five months after taking the job. The Geneva-based pharmaceutical company said it had asked the executive, Anton Affentranger to leave, but gave no reason. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 2 about the public-radio broadcast of excerpts from audiotapes of 23 Georgia executions referred incorrectly to the recordings' origin. They were obtained by Mike Mears, a Georgia criminal defense lawyer, who subpoenaed them in a lawsuit. He did not discover them; excerpts from some had been played by other radio stations in the mid-1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNA, RABBI ISAAC
description: SUNA-Rabbi Isaac. The Yeshiva University family mourns the loss of a highly respected member of the faculty of its affiliated Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy/YUHS for Boys. For more than 40 years, he taught and inspired his students, guided their intellectual and spiritual growth, and nurtured their understanding that they represent the future of their people and faith. He served as a role model of integrity, modesty, and quiet dignity. His accomplishments as a teacher and his personal commitment to the traditions of Israel will be preserved through the thousands of students who were blessed to have him as their mentor. Sincerest condolences to his wife, Odette; children, Rochelle, Hillel, and David; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Dr. Michael Hecht, Dean YUHSB Julius Berman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees Dr. Felix L. Glaubach, Chairman YUHS Steering Committee

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, HELEN
description: BENSON-Helen. 83 years old. Survived by Alberta Bellisario and Stan Benson, and five grandchildren.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Caught in the sights of a takeover bid, Gehl turns to fight back.
description: IS the billionaire corporate raider Harold C. Simmons bluffing?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, RODERIC S.
description: O'CONNOR-Roderic S. Of Denver, CO, formerly of Douglaston, NY. Died peacefully on April 13, 2001 surrounded by family. Devoted husband of the late Jane O'Connor. Beloved father of Christine O'Connor and her husband Dave Mitzner of Denver, CO, Barbara Gossel and her husband Jim of Corte Madera, CA., and Josephine O'Shaughnessy and her husband John of Berkeley, CA. Beloved grandfather of Ben and Tess Mitzner, Mary, Jane and Alison Gossel and Lynn, Claire and Eileen O'Shaughnessy. Born Brooklyn, NY 1913, served six years in 101st U.S. Cavalry. Worked for Sperry Rand Corp. in NYC until retirement in the late 70's. Travel, golf and French studies were some of his many retirement interests. Rod will be greatly missed and remembered by friends & family for his unique warmth, generosity and love of life. There will be a Mass in Remembrance on Friday, June 1st, 2001 at St. Anastasia's Church in Douglaston, NY (45-14 245th St off Northern Blvd). Contributions can be made to Catholic Charities, 2525 W. Alameda Ave. Denver, CO 80219 or Hospice of Metro Denver, 425 South Cherry Street, Denver, CO. 80246.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, EDWARD R.
description: MOORE-Edward R. Of Beth Page, on May 6, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Adelaide. Loving father of Kathleen Bogle of Valley Stream and Bob Moore of Albany, New York. Cherished grandfather of James and Robert Bogle. Predeceased by brothers, James and John. Mr. Moore, originally from Lawrence, lived most of his life in Beth Page where he was active in his community as Little League coach, Boy Scout committeeman, and member of the VFW and Knights of Columbus. Recently he volunteered with Meals on Wheels. At 18, Mr. Moore joined the U.S. Army First Division and was decorated with the Bronze Star and Purple Heart. He saw action in World War II in Africa, Sicily and invaded Normandy on Utah Beach. As father, friend and companion, he will be missed. Funeral mass, at 9:45 A.M., on Wednesday, at St. Martin of Tours RC Church, Beth Page. Interment is to follow at Calverton National Cemetery, Calverton, New York.

title: Bargaining Is Under Way In Spying Case Of F.B.I. Man
description: Federal prosecutors and lawyers for Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent charged with spying for Russia, have opened plea bargain negotiations, government officials said today.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Soprano's Adventures On the Road

title: BRITISH TELECOM'S SHARES FALL 6% ON FEARS OF DILUTION
description: Shares in British Telecommunications fell by 6 percent yesterday as investors worried that the debt-laden former state monopoly will announce plans for an emergency issue of new equity that would dilute the value of existing stock. British Telecom made no comment. The company has promised to cut its $43 billion debt by a third and has already disposed of important stakes in Japan and Spain. The company is set to announce full-year results on May 17, but that announcement may be brought forward. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Argentines Sell Short-Term Debt at a High Cost
description: In a crucial financial test, the Argentine government succeeded today in selling $350 million of benchmark three-month Treasury bills only two weeks after it was forced to suspend a bond auction because of climbing interest rates and increased fear among investors that default might at some point be inevitable.

title: Business Travel; Don't look now, corporate travelers, but hitchhiking might become a viable option.
description: LAST summer, at the National Business Travel Association convention in Los Angeles, Mark Walton, a travel-policy consultant, began a speech with selections from a parody corporate travel department memo that a client had sent to him.

title: Phone Companies? Don't Get Me Started
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill's Assets Unit Is Cutting Work Force
description: Merrill Lynch & Company's asset-management unit is reducing its work force by 20 percent this year, slicing costs as revenue declines.

title: NBC Promotes Its News Chief To President
description: In a decision that may result in moves by NBC to expand its media holdings, the network named Andrew Lack, the president of NBC News, to the newly created position of president and chief operating officer yesterday. The promotion makes Mr. Lack the No. 2 executive in the company under Bob Wright and his likely successor.

title: HOUSE THREATENS TO HOLD U.N. DUES IN LOSS OF A SEAT
description: Administration and congressional officials expressed anger today at the United Nations for the loss of a United States seat on the Human Rights Commission, and influential Republicans and Democrats in the House threatened to hold $244 million in dues to the organization if Washington's seat is not restored next year.

title: Blacks Found on Short End of Heart Attack Procedure
description: Black heart attack patients are far less likely than whites to undergo the common and potentially life-saving procedure known as cardiac catheterization, regardless of the race of their doctors, researchers at Yale University said yesterday.

title: Despite Strong Year at Safety, Green Agrees to Jets' Pay Cut
description: Victor Green's pride and wallet may have been dented, but he is still a Jet.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Bill to License Tattoo Parlors
description: A Republican bill to have all Nassau County tattoo parlors licensed by the county's Health Department has quickly gained bipartisan support. The bill, proposed yesterday by Legislator Vincent Muscarella, would also require anyone under 18 to receive notarized parental consent before being tattooed, branded or having body parts pierced, except for the ear. Concerns about diseases being transmitted through unclean needles led to the legislation. If passed, the law would take effect on Jan. 1, and violators would face fines of up to $1,000. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Blacks and Hispanics in House Balk on Campaign Finance Bill
description: A group of black and Hispanic Democrats in the House is threatening to oppose the overhaul of the campaign finance law, arguing that it could hurt efforts to mobilize minority voters and that their constituents want fundamental changes in the electoral system, not in fund-raising.

title: Cisco Takes $3 Billion Charge and Posts Its First Loss
description: Seeking to wipe the slate clean after enduring a sharp plunge in its business, Cisco Systems said today that it took more than $3 billion in charges against its earnings, leading it to report an overall quarterly loss for the first time in its 11-year history.

title: N.Y.U. Names Its Law Dean As President Of the School
description: As expected, New York University named John E. Sexton, the genial, driven dean of its increasingly prestigious law school, as its next president yesterday. He has already begun to talk about how he can push the university, like the law school, to a higher level.

title: Arthur Walker, 64, Scientist and Mentor, Dies
description: Dr. Arthur Walker, who shot innovative telescopes into space to give scientists a view of the Sun that they had never seen before and who spent a lifetime helping women and minority students find careers in science, died on April 29 at his home on the campus of Stanford University. He was 64 and a professor of physics and applied physics there.

title: Lillian Berkman, 79, Eclectic Arts Patron
description: Lillian R. Berkman, a pioneering businesswoman, a collector of Renaissance art and an arts patron involved with many of New York's cultural institutions, died on May 1 at her home in Manhattan. She was 79.

title: Falun Gong Stages Protests as Jiang Visits Hong Kong
description: President Jiang Zemin of China hailed the freedom in Hong Kong today, as protesters from the Falun Gong spiritual movement rallied throughout the city, accusing Mr. Jiang of imprisoning and torturing their members on the Chinese mainland.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Settlement In Desegregation Case
description: A federal judge in Mississippi made clear that he was not satisfied with a settlement reached by the state, the Department of Justice and black plaintiffs in a 26-year-old college desegregation case. The judge, Neal B. Biggers Jr., set a Sept. 4 hearing to consider the settlement but expressed a ''serious reservation'' about ordering the Legislature to pay $500 million over 17 years to improve the state's three historically black colleges to try to attract white students. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES. Cocoa rose on increased demand from chocolate makers during a seasonal lull in production from Ivory Coast. In New York, cocoa for July delivery rose $55, or 5.6 percent, to $1,044 a metric ton.

title: Behind the Drawl, a Real New York Know-It-All
description: HERE is a guy who really New York.

title: FCB Worldwide Is Planning Layoffs
description: The three offices of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, are laying off employees. And at one office, the fire department is investigating a fire that occurred along with the layoffs.

title: Father Finds Girl, 11, Fatally Injured in Hall
description: A father opened the door to his apartment in the Bronx yesterday and found his 11-year-old daughter lying in the hallway, bleeding and apparently unconscious, the police said. The girl was pronounced dead on arrival at Montefiore Medical Center, and investigators said they believed that she had been sexually abused and were treating the case as a homicide.

title: The Boss: Imprints of the Holocaust
description: My grandfather told me I would be a businessman some day. When I was a child, he once sent me to buy him a pack of cigarettes, but the store did not have his brand. I knew if I bought a different brand, he would be annoyed and if I came back empty-handed, he would also be annoyed. I had to develop some judgment.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: $18 Million Settlement In Shooting
description: The City of Chicago has agreed to pay $18 million to settle a lawsuit brought by the family of a woman shot to death by police officers after a car chase two years ago. The woman, LaTanya Haggerty, left, a 26-year-old computer analyst, was a passenger in a car that the police chased for 31 blocks after the driver drove away from a traffic stop. The officer who fired the fatal shot, Serena Daniels, mistook a cellular telephone Ms. Haggerty was holding for a gun. Ms. Daniels and two other officers were dismissed last year. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURTH, FRANK
description: FURTH-Frank. The Trustees and Staff of the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust mourn the passing of our dear friend, Frank Furth, a member of the Museum's Board of Overseers and a longtime volunteer. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Furth family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chairman Alfred Gottschalk, President

title: CALENDAR
description: Italian Tastes at the U.N.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Journalist's Body Identified
description: F.B.I. experts say the headless body found in November near Kiev is that of a missing journalist, Georgy Gongadze, according to the deputy prosecutor general. The experts were unable to establish the cause of death. The disappearance of Mr. Gongadze set off a political crisis when secret recordings were released indicating that President Leonid D. Kuchma asked his security chief to ''get rid'' of the journalist. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Close Election Forces Runoff For Mayor Of Jersey City
description: Jersey City's mayoral election yesterday appeared to produce a runoff between a former and current City Council president in the race to succeed Mayor Bret D. Schundler, a Republican who is forgoing a bid for a third four-year term in order to run for governor.

title: Tapping a Thirst for Latin Cinema; Films Win Festival Raves but Struggle to Reach Their Markets
description: In Fabin Bielinsky's film ''Nueve Reinas'' (''Nine Queens''), a swindler takes his reluctant apprentice out on the street to show him they are hardly alone in their pursuits. Looking around, they easily spot people being robbed, or about to be, by a purse snatcher, a car thief, a shoplifter.

title: Goodbye to Lawns
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan Gives Gonzalez New Deal
description: Manhattan College gave its men's coach, Bobby Gonzalez, a two-year contract extension through the 2004-5 season, the university said yesterday.

title: An Old Mystery On 'The X-Files'
description: With one week to go before Fox announces its fall schedule, it is still unclear whether the network will show another season of ''The X-Files,'' its hit Sunday night science-fiction show. A decision has not been made, Fox executives have said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARWOOD, DOROTHY
description: HARWOOD-Dorothy. On April 29. Loving wife of the late Cantor Lawrence Harwood. Adored mother of Joyce Ratner. Your Spirit and Humor lives on.

title: CARTER-WALLACE SELLS ITSELF AS TWO BUSINESSES
description: Carter-Wallace Inc. agreed to sell itself for $1.12 billion, splitting consumer brands including Trojan condoms and Arrid deodorant from its health business after failing to attract a better offer for the entire company. A venture of the consumer goods maker Church & Dwight Company and the private equity group Kelso & Company will buy Carter-Wallace's consumer division for $739 million in cash. MedPointe Capital Partners L.L.C., formed last year to build a specialty health care business, will buy the drug and tests unit for $408 million. Shareholders will receive about $20.30 a share, 10 percent less than the company's closing price Monday. Shares of Carter-Wallace, based in New York, dropped $2.57, or 11 percent, to $19.99.

title: Overwhelm Mom With a Dozen Roses
description: A rose may always be a rose, but here is a fresh take on a brioche. Judith Norell, an owner of the Silver Moon Bakery, 2740 Broadway (105th Street), is selling an eight-inch-wide, pound-and-a-quarter brioche decorated with a fresh white rose for Mother's Day. Actually, the idea is not hers alone. Ms. Norell was inspired by Manet's ''Nature Morte  la Brioche,'' left. A gift card with a print of the painting is included with every brioche.

title: Vodafone Picks Wieden & Kennedy
description: The Vodafone Group in Newbury, England, said yesterday that it had named the Amsterdam office of Wieden & Kennedy as its lead agency, responsible for creating global campaigns as the company moves to a single mobile telephone brand. Billings have not been determined.

title: People
description: * Margaret Wagner, director for marketing services at Euro RSCG Worldwide, New York, part of Havas Advertising, was named to the new post of director for integrated client services.

title: Court Lets Experts Challenge Witnesses' Accuracy in Trials
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that experts' testimony on the reliability of eyewitnesses could be admitted at a trial, a decision that legal scholars said could have a major impact on criminal prosecutions in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCALZULLI, NORMA
description: SCALZULLI-Norma. Beloved wife of Giovanni, cherished mother of Gina and Fritz, Alex and Jane, adored honey to Jacob, Dakota, and Michael. A woman of many talents, who was cherished, respected, loved, and will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Funeral services Wednesday, May 9, 2001 at 11:45 A.M. ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: The Uncountable Toll
description: As many as 2.5 million people may have died since 1998 as a result of civil war in Congo, deaths beyond those that would have taken place from natural causes in peacetime, the International Rescue Committee said in New York. Les Roberts, an epidemiologist who directs health policy for the private organization and conducted the survey, said that in Moba and Kalemi, in eastern Congo, 75 percent of children born during the war are dead or will die before their second birthdays. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Pizza's Turkish Twin
description: OUTDOOR-EATING season has arrived, and the city's sidewalks and plazas are filled with lunchers sampling an international smorgasbord of street foods. To the usual sandwiches, salads and kebabs, I would like to add these excellent Turkish dishes, courtesy of Sultan II, a new takeout shop near the Flatiron building that is a sibling of the Sultan on the Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUPKIN, ROSE
description: LUPKIN-Rose. On May 4, 2001. Beloved sister of the late Sonia Kaye. Services were private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the International Center of New York, 50 West 23rd St., 7th Floor, New York, NY 10010-5205.
