A New Show at the Apollo Raises Hopes in Harlem
description: Since the 1930's the Apollo Theater in Harlem has been known for its variety shows, with acts like the tap-dancing Nicholas Brothers, the comedian Redd Foxx and the jazz singer Ruth Brown, and the weekly amateur nights, which started the careers of Sarah Vaughan and Ella Fitzgerald.

title: Dispute and Blackouts
description: Southern California Edison accused the El Paso Corporation of inflating the price of natural gas by $3.7 billion in the last year by restricting the flow in a pipeline it partly controls. And a second straight day of blackouts affected nearly 300,000 California customers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Power Plant Power Reduction
description: A faulty water pump at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant was repaired yesterday, and the plant was to resume full power 24 hours after a computer problem forced Consolidated Edison to cut power to 60 percent. Michael Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman, said there were no leaks and no danger to the public. The incident was the second in the last three months involving the plant's two water pumps, which channel nonradioactive water under pressure to the plant's steam generators. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEISTER, WENDY
description: MEISTER-Wendy. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a dear friend, a highly respected member of the Jewish community, and beloved wife of Robert A. Meister, Board member of our Sy Syms School of Business. They are Fellows of the Syms School, Yeshiva College, and our affiliated YU Museum, as well as Founders of our Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Mrs. Meister was a member of the New York Chapter of AECOM's National Women's Division. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, Robert; sons, Todd and Keith; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Bernard L. Madoff, Chairman SSSB Board of Directors Robert A. Belfer, Chairperson AECOM Board of Overseers

title: No. 2 Official Of the I.M.F. To Step Down By Year's End
description: Stanley Fischer, who engineered record bailouts for several of the largest developing countries as the day-to-day manager of the International Monetary Fund, announced that he would leave his post by the year's end.

title: A Creamy Custard Has a Mellowing Effect on Pork
description: ONE reward of having a small restaurant is the chance to get to know the customers. I can see every diner from the kitchen and they can see me. For their first visit or two, I feed them and they leave. But usually by the third, we're talking.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: 15 Indicted in Crackdown on Bloods Gang
description: Federal authorities unsealed a racketeering indictment yesterday against the founder and other suspected leaders of the Bloods street gang, whom they accused of using violence and intimidation to further a range of criminal activities in New York City.

title: Springtime for Show Biz
description: The Tony nominations were announced on Monday, and it was no surprise that ''The Producers'' -- a musical about producing musicals -- broke a 30-year record for the most nominations, with 15, beating Stephen Sondheim's ''Company,'' which ran for nearly 700 performances a generation ago. But in the Broadway trifecta, that is only one of the accomplishments ''The Producers'' has rung up. It has also broken records for box-office sales and ticket prices. In short, it instantly produced that beloved Broadway phenomenon: the unobtainable seat. In this case, the most exclusive ticket in town admits you to a three-hour binge not of high opera but of low comedy, an irony almost as satisfying as the wildfire success of a musical about the wildfire success of producers who are trying desperately to fail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERSON, LEO
description: MERSON-Leo. On May 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Paula. Loving father of Michael, Mark & Melissa. Dear brother of Hy. Adoring grandfather of Jonathan, Erica, Dana & Zachary. Service Thursday 1:00 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Cheney Is Backing Plan to Expand Cleaner Sources of Energy
description: The Bush administration will encourage the widespread use of agricultural, animal and human waste to produce energy as part of an effort to expand environmentally friendly energy supplies along with fossil fuels, administration officials said today.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Ex-Police Officer Pleads Guilty
description: Matthew Murphy, a former Nassau County police officer, pleaded guilty yesterday to a felony charge of receiving a bribe and, for the first time, gave his version of events. Last August, Mr. Murphy, 36, was accused of stopping a driver who later told the police that he had forced her to undress and perform oral sex on him. Mr. Murphy said that the woman described herself as an exotic dancer and that ''an understanding was reached'' for sex, but that ''no force or coercion was ever used.'' Under the guilty plea, Mr. Murphy faces probation rather than imprisonment. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Heinz to Offer New Snack
description: The H. J. Heinz Frozen Food Company, an affiliate of the H. J. Heinz Company, said today that it would introduce bite-size pizza and potato snacks called Hot Bites as part of a plan to attract more pre-teen and teenage customers. Five varieties of Hot Bites, an extension of Heinz's Bagel Bites, will start selling in supermarkets this month, Heinz Frozen Food said. Heinz, which is the largest ketchup maker, will advertise Hot Bites with a television commercial starring Tony Hawk, a skateboarder.

title: Article 2001050993666576900 -- No Title
description: Face-Recognition Systems OfferNew Tools, but Mixed Results

title: Mets' Starters Find It's Not Pretty at Coors Field
description: If the experience of Dicky Gonzalez and Kevin Appier mean anything to him, Glendon Rusch may want to run and hide. Rusch will be the third Mets starter to make his mile-high debut this week when he pitches the finale of a four-game series at Coors Field on Thursday. The first two introductions have not gone very well.

title: A Korean Sidewalk Cafe Fits In on the Upper East Side
description: SECOND AVENUE in the 80's is like one big open-air restaurant in the warm spring weather. The glass storefronts swing open, extending dining rooms onto sidewalks, where tables from one place to the next form blocklong parties. Emo's, a handsome new restaurant a couple of months old, has blended seamlessly into this seasonal expression of high spirits. Nothing remarkable there, except that Emo's is Korean.

title: In New York, It's Cheese-Cart Gridlock
description: WALK into Artisanal, Terrance Brennan's new restaurant, and the first thing that hits you is the smell.

title: Comcast Shows Profit as Customer Base Surges
description: The Comcast Corporation, the third-largest cable television operator, said yesterday that it had a first-quarter profit as it doubled Internet and digital-television customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPEL, MORTON J.
description: APPEL-Morton J. Loving husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Janet and Lewis, dear brother-inlaw of Ann and Martin Rabinowitz & Gloria Appel, died peacefully at home having graciously finished his last set. The funeral is May 10 at noon, Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY.

title: Accounts
description: * Canon U.K., Reigate, England, to EPB London, part of Panoramic Communications, to handle a new integrated communications assignment. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: Weak Ads and Failed Movie Depress News Corp.'s Profits
description: Weathering a weak advertising market and a Hollywood flop, the News Corporation of Australia, the media conglomerate, announced today that its earnings fell sharply in the most recent quarter.

title: Cook, St. John's Guard, To Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: Omar Cook, the freshman point guard at St. John's who was one of college basketball's leading playmakers last season, is entering the N.B.A. draft, college athletic officials said yesterday.

title: Suit on Security Tags
description: Checkpoint Systems Inc., which makes antitheft devices like the tags attached by stores to clothing, filed a patent-infringement lawsuit against the Sensormatic Electronics Corporation and two of Sensormatic's suppliers. The complaint was filed in Federal District Court in Philadelphia and centers on a disposable radio-frequency tag made by All-Tag Security S.A. in Belgium and All-Tag Security Americas Inc. in Florida. The tags are sold by Sensormatic, Checkpoint Systems said. Lee Pernice, a Sensormatic spokeswoman, said the company had not seen the suit and could not comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, LYNNE S., ESQ.
description: COOPER-Lynne S., Esq. Beloved daughter of the late Joseph and Judith Cooper. Dear sister of Rhea Greenspan. Services on Thursday 1PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. The family will be receiving at the Mark Hotel, 77 St, NYC, 7:00 PM, Thursday & Friday.

title: New Surveys in Gubernatorial Race Are Called Politically and Statistically Questionable
description: A brand-new polling organization appeared on the New Jersey political scene with a splash last week and again today, publishing two surveys that portray former Representative Bob Franks as having a commanding advantage in the governor's race over Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Advance Reported
description: Europe's largest biotech company, Serono S.A., said its multiple sclerosis treatment Rebif fared better than Biogen's rival drug Avonex in a new study. In the six-month comparative trial, Rebif patients had a 90 percent greater chance of avoiding a relapse than patients on Avonex. Serono, of Geneva, wants to gain Food and Drug Administration approval of Rebif, which controls about a third of the market outside the United States, to break Biogen's hold on the $1 billion American market for multiple sclerosis therapies. Biogen said the study was flawed. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: After 6 Years, First-Quarter Productivity Fell in U.S.
description: The productivity of American workers, which rose sharply as new technologies took hold and served as the great source of prosperity in the late 1990's, fell in the first quarter for the first time in six years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, SHIRLEY
description: SNYDER-Shirley. On May 7, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Loving mother of Ted and his wife Beth. Grandmother of Aaron.

title: 20 Different Olives, and 32 Feet of Fish
description: Fairway in Manhattan is famous for harried scenes of bargain-hunting hordes pawing through produce before proceeding to chaotic checkout lines. But for Long Island customers, there's a kinder, gentler Fairway, a giant on Manetto Hill Road in Plainview, about a mile south of the Long Island Expressway (Exit 45). The store is the size of both Manhattan Fairways combined. It has 18 checkout lanes; a 32-foot-long counter for prepared and fresh seafood (above); a station for Asian stir-fries, Caesar salads and pizza; a cafe for snacking; a bakery with a wood-burning oven; more than 20 kinds of olives; and perhaps the best cheese department on Long Island. On the first day, 6,500 bagels were sold.

title: Olive Oil That's Hard to Keep the Cap On
description: In Sicily, olive oils are full bodied, pungent and peppery, with a citrusy note reminiscent of lemons. Don Luigi Sicilian extra virgin olive oil is a perfect expression of this character. Produced near the Mediterranean coast in Agrigento, the oil is unfiltered, with a golden green hue that clouds with brown sediment when the bottle is tipped. Don't worry: it's the sediment that gives the oil its intense flavor. In a salad, the olive taste is so pronounced you'll almost look for pits. The oil also adds brightness to soups or sauces. Or try it as a dip for thick-crusted country bread.

title: Williams's Father In Hospital
description: Bernie Williams said yesterday that his father, Bernabe Sr., went back into a hospital in Puerto Rico last week because of continuing problems caused by pulmonary fibrosis. Williams's father, 73, was initially put on a respirator in the intensive care unit, but Williams said he was then taken off the respirator and moved to a room.

title: The Decision to Play Is Niedermayer's
description: Scott Niedermayer skated back and forth across the Continental Arena ice for 40 minutes. He made stops and starts, skated sprints and took his customary shots from the point.

title: THE BOSS; Imprints of the Holocaust
description: My grandfather told me I would be a businessman some day. When I was a child, he once sent me to buy him a pack of cigarettes, but the store did not have his brand. I knew if I bought a different brand, he would be annoyed and if I came back empty-handed, he would also be annoyed. I had to develop some judgment.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Less Bar Exam Success
description: Only 44 percent of those taking the February bar exam passed, down from 44.9 percent the year earlier, the State Board of Law Examiners has reported. The drop continues a decline in the pass rate that began several years ago, said Nancy Oppe Carpenter, the executive secretary of the board. The rate is always lower in February than in July, in part because many are taking the test for the second time and are more likely to fail. The board planned to post the names of those who passed at http://www.nybarexam.org tomorrow at noon. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRATT, RICHARDSON, JR.
description: PRATT-Richardson, Jr. A memorial service to commemorate the life of Richardson (Jerry) Pratt, Jr. will be held on Monday, May 21, 2001 at 11:30 AM at Old First Presbyterian Church, 125 Main St., Huntington, NY. For directions, call 631-427-2101. In lieu of flowers the Richardson Pratt, Jr. Scholarship Fund has been established at Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11205.

title: A Hard Choice in Peru
description: The American media has followed recent events in Peru with a mixture of fascination and horror. A year ago, Peru drew international attention when President Alberto Fujimori and his cronies maneuvered to steal their way to a third term. Then, while much of the international community prepared to recognize the election as a fait accompli, a leaked videotape revealed the extraordinary web of corruption spun by spy chief Vladimiro Montesinos, prompting Mr. Fujimori's resignation and the holding of new elections on April 8. The results of that election also stunned observers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOTOROLA INC., Arlington Heights, Ill., the No. 2 cell phone maker, signed 5 contracts with China Mobile Communications valued at $146 million to increase the network of the country's largest mobile-phone operator.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the attempt by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's estranged wife to bar the mayor's companion, Judith Nathan, from Gracie Mansion misidentified Ms. Nathan's employer. In March, Ms. Nathan became a managing director of Changing Our World Inc., a philanthropic services company with headquarters in New York. She is no longer a district sales manager for Bristol-Myers Squibb.

title: Chief to Regularly Sell Amazon Shares
description: Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chief executive of the online retailer Amazon.com Inc., has adopted a plan committing him to selling company stock at fixed intervals, a move that might shield him from future questions about insider trading.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Cuban Sound and Soul

title: Lots of Ifs, So Tyson Postpones June Bout
description: With the bidding war enveloping Hasim Rahman intensifying, representatives for Mike Tyson said yesterday that they were officially postponing Tyson's scheduled bout with David Izon on June 2. Tyson is instead awaiting a decision from Rahman, the new World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, who has yet to choose between Tyson and Lennox Lewis for his first title defense.

title: Technology Briefing | Health: Progress on Blood Substitute
description: Biopure, which makes human blood substitutes from purified cow's blood, said yesterday that more than 60 percent of orthopedic surgery patients who received its Hemopure solution in a clinical trial required no human blood throughout the entire six weeks of the study. Biopure, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., said it expected to seek government clearance later this year to market Hemopure. Its shares jumped $2.76, to $30.41. Barnaby J. Feder (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMEONE, MARGARET (MAGGIE)
description: SIMEONE-Margaret (Maggie). Age 87. On May 8, 2001. Daughter of the late George and Ellen McCravy. Sister of the late Frank, John & James McCravy. Beloved wife of Harry M. Simeone. Adored mother of Harry M. Simeone, Jr. and his wife Darlene, and Molly Stevenson. Loving grandmother of Gary Edward Simeone, Corrine Ellen Simeone, Katie Stevenson and Laura Ann Stevenson. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 10AM at Saint Vincent Ferrer Church. Burial at Roslyn Cemetery. Friends may call on Wednesday evening, 7-9PM and Thursday, 2-4 and 79PM at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Furman University, Greenville, S.C.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Musicians Sue MP3.Com
description: The recording artists Tom Waits, left, Randy Newman and the rock band Heart filed a lawsuit against MP3.com, seeking $40 million for copyright infringement. In the suit, filed on Monday in Federal District Court in Los Angeles, the musicians contend that MP3.com wrongly copied hundreds of songs onto its Web site, including tracks from Mr. Waits's ''Mule Variations,'' Mr. Newman's ''I Love L.A.'' and numerous songs written by Heart's Ann and Nancy Wilson. They asked the court to award damages based on $150,000 per infringement. An MP3.com spokesman said the company would have no immediate comment.

title: Plan to Sink Subway Cars Gains Support
description: Despite being rejected in New York, New Jersey and Maryland, a plan to sink about 400 New York City subway cars in the Atlantic Ocean gained support in Delaware, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said.

title: White Knows Game 7 Is Time to Keep Cool
description: Scott Stevens sidled up to Colin White on the Devils' flight home early today and gently told him that he understood. Stevens once had sharp edges on his temper, too, and he has had the benefit of nearly 20 seasons in the National Hockey League to sand down those edges, at least a little.

title: U.N. Chief Asks for New Funds to Fight AIDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, May 9  With anger rising in Congress over the United States' loss of seats on two United Nations panels, Secretary General Kofi Annan went to Washington today to ask the Bush Administration for more money to fight AIDS in Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTENS, JOSEPHINE ''JO'' (NEE BOKROS)

Loving mother of Barbara Gladding and her husband Sanford, David & his wife Maureen. Loving grandmother of Sanford & his wife Kristi, Jennifer, and John and his wife Annie. Dear great grandmother of Julia and Mitchell. Also survived by his sister Rita Eckhardt and her husband Mel. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Thursday 3-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Friday at 10 AM, St. Peter of Alcantara R.C. Church, Port Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the visit of Pope John Paul II to Syria referred imprecisely to the destruction in the Golan Heights city of Quneitra, where he has since delivered a prayer for peace. The city was captured by Israel during the 1967 Arab- Israeli war. It is the Syrians who contend that the Israelis used dynamite and bulldozers to level the town before they left in 1974. Israel says the damage was a byproduct of fighting in the wars of 1967 and 1973.

title: Grupo Mexicano Chief and Others Accused of Insider Trading
description: Three members of Mexico's prominent Ballesteros family, one of whom died in a car crash a year ago, have been accused by federal prosecutors in New York of reaping more than $3.5 million in illegal profits in 1999 by trading on inside information about the acquisition of an American chemical company by a giant French conglomerate.

title: A New Conductor Shifts an Orchestra's Mood to Allegro
description: When the maestro Christof Perick swept his baton down to start the opening percussive crescendo of Strauss's ''Also Sprach Zarathustra'' at a concert here in October, the principal timpanist, Carol Stumpf, knew immediately that she was being taken into a new league.

title: Rumsfeld Plan Skirts a Call For Stationing Arms in Space
description: Unveiling a new plan to strengthen the military's space programs, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld stopped short today of advocating putting weapons in outer space, an idea that has come under sharp criticism from Congressional Democrats.

title: G.O.P. Pushes Budget Through House
description: WASHINGTON, May 9 - Again displaying a solid wall of support for President Bush, House Republicans voted nearly unanimously today to pass a budget resolution that was favored by the president and opposed by nearly all the Democrats.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Welfare Policy Criticized
description: City Council officials accused the Giuliani administration yesterday of trying to punish or intimidate poor women with children who have remained on the welfare rolls for at least five years. The charges came as Jason A. Turner, the city's commissioner of human resources, agreed to return to testify before the Council, only one day after storming out of a meeting to protest his treatment. Mr. Turner reiterated the city's wish to require welfare recipients who will hit a five-year federal benefit limit in December to file an application before being switched into a state program, Safety Net, meant to prevent poverty. Council members said the welfare clients should instead be automatically transferred to Safety Net. ''You seem to feel the need to punish people who are on public assistance,'' Councilman Bill Perkins said. Eric Lipton (NYT)

description: THIS was not some sick joke on ''A Prairie Home Companion,'' some weird reversal of form between demonstrative New Yorkers and phlegmatic folks from the upper Midwest.

title: And Strange Gods Landed In the Kingdom of Gold
description: You've got to admire a historian who climbs 14,000-foot mountains for the cause. And slogs through knee-deep mud. And pitches a tent in freezing rain. And eats things that are pets in many households.

title: Torre Elaborates on Abuse
description: Growing up in Brooklyn, Joe Torre was terrified of his abusive father, a policeman, the Yankees manager told CBS's ''60 Minutes II'' last night. ''He used to abuse my mom,'' Torre said during an interview about his managing career, ''and I tried to stay out of the house when he was home during waking hours.''

title: Valletta Journal; Malta Greets the Pope Like a Beloved Spa Client
description: John Paul II arrived in Malta today to find himself facing a vast platform crammed with jostling journalists, all craning for an intimate shot. The bent, fragile pope pointed at the photographers, then folded his fingers in a hand gesture more common to Roman taxi drivers than popes. It means, roughly, ''What the heck do you want from me?''

title: Yugoslav Leader Backs Law on Cooperation With Hague Tribunal
description: President Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia reaffirmed here today that he wanted his country's laws amended to allow the government to cooperate with the Balkan war crimes tribunal in The Hague, but he stopped short of saying whether the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, would be turned over to the court.

title: Top Bush Aide Urges Japan to Form In-Depth Ties With U.S.
description: A senior American official who in the past has advocated a full-fledged army for Japan urged Tokyo today to develop a partnership with Washington that more closely resembles the alliance between Britain and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATIVIDADE, NURIMAR
description: NATIVIDADE-Nurimar. To ''Nury,'' beautiful woman who left us too soon. She was only 48 years old. Planning to go back to the love of her life, she died of cancer on April 30, 2001, at 3 AM. My memories, my love, my heart. Truly your friend, sister and caretaker. Goodbye, angel. Your sister, Patty

description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: More Postal-Rate Rises
description: The Postal Service said rates for most mailing categories would go up in July. The cost of sending a one-ounce, first-class letter will remain 34 cents, but each additional ounce will cost 23 cents, up from 21 cents. The price of sending a postcard will rise a penny, to 21 cents; Express Mail rates will increase by about 20 cents. Officials said the latest increases would generate about $975 million; the service faces possible losses this year of more than $2 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about efforts to persuade Germans to clear out coins accumulated in jars and piggy banks, to ease the transition to euro coins and bills in January, translated an advertising slogan for the new currency incorrectly. It is ''The euro. Our money,'' not ''The euro, your money.''

title: A Glittery Circus With Many Rings
description: LOOK at that man,'' whispered the Young Thing at my table. ''He looks like he just came out of a rotisserie.''

title: Judges Refuse to Reverse Election Law Change
description: A panel of judges today dismissed an appeal by New Jersey Democrats seeking to nullify a law that allowed Bob Franks to enter the governor's race. They held off ruling on a petition by Bret D. Schundler, a Republican candidate for governor, to keep Mr. Franks's name off the Republican primary ballot.

description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, MICHAEL ROBERT

A published poet and contributor to the largest ''Poem of Peace''. Services Wednesday 1:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Beijing Aide Tries to Explain Its Stance on U.S. Spy Plane
description: HONG KONG, May 9  A senior Chinese official sought today to explain China's decision not to allow the United States to fly home its damaged spy plane, which is stranded on Hainan island, saying it would arouse "strong indignation and opposition in the Chinese population."

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shiseido Posts Loss
description: Japan's biggest cosmetics manufacturer, the Shiseido Company, said it lost 45 billion yen ($370 million) for the year ended March 31. The company said slow sales and a write-off for unfunded pension liabilities led to the loss, its first in 55 years.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Nashville Mayor To Run For Governor
description: Phil Bredesen, the Nashville mayor credited with bringing professional football to Tennessee, said he would run for governor in 2002. Mr. Bredesen, 57, left, was the Democratic nominee for governor in 1994 but lost to Don Sundquist, a Republican now completing his second term. Mr. Bredesen is expected to face Representative Bob Clement of Nashville in a Democratic primary; the Republican frontrunner is expected to be Representative Van Hilleary. In addition to the Tennessee Titans of the N.F.L., Mr. Bredesen is credited with bringing a number of major employers to the city. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Liberties; Donna, Prima Donna
description: After I saw ''Town and Country,'' the strenuously libidinous comedy with Warren Beatty, Goldie Hawn and Diane Keaton, I was walking out behind three teenage girls.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: More Trains Urged For New Haven
description: A new study by the Connecticut Department of Transportation supports a bid by Metro-North to add 10 locomotives and 60 train cars to the New Haven line because of a 27 percent jump in ridership in the last three years. The recommendation would cost Connecticut $89 million. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Mayor Is Taking School Board on Voucher Tour
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is taking Board of Education members to Milwaukee on Monday to tour schools that accept publicly financed tuition vouchers, an indication that the hostile climate toward vouchers within the board may be shifting.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Online Network Acquires Rival
description: UGO Networks, an entertainment site for teenagers and young adults, announced yesterday that it is acquiring rival Bla-Bla Entertainment Network, a group of independent online sites. UGO, which recently closed a $23 million round of financing, said it has begun a plan to acquire several of its competitors. ''The acquisition of Bla-Bla represents UGO's first major move towards consolidation,'' said J. Moses, UGO's chief executive. The merger will give UGO the largest share of the teenager and young-adult market, according to Media Metrix, the Internet research firm. As part of the transaction, former Bla-Bla investors, including Silicon Alley Venture Partners, Liberty View Equity Partners, and Hudson Partners will invest an undisclosed amount, under $1 million, in UGO, officials said. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: ST. JAMES RETIRES
description: Lyn St. James, 54, who began racing sports cars in 1976 and became the second woman to compete at the Indianapolis 500, announced her retirement on Sunday before the start of practice for this year's Indy 500.

title: Surging Prices Of Natural Gas Aid BP's Profit
description: BP P.L.C., the world's third-largest oil company, said today that high natural gas prices in the United States along with BP's American acquisitions pushed its first-quarter profit to $4.12 billion, up about 52 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: Mercury in Fish: What's Too Much?
description: IN January, for the first time, the Food and Drug Administration issued a health alert warning pregnant women to avoid four species of fish -- swordfish, king mackerel, shark and tilefish -- because of mercury contamination. At the same time, the agency urged them to continue eating up to 12 ounces of other fish a week.

title: Chicken With a Nip
description: CHICKEN thighs have a huge advantage over lean breasts. The skin browns nicely and the meat stays juicy even when thoroughly cooked, which makes them ideal for grilling or broiling.

Memorial service to be held at St. John's Church in Larchmont, on Friday, May 11, at 11 AM, with reception at the Larchmont Yacht Club to follow. Family will receive visitors on Saturday and Sunday, from 1-5 PM, May 12 and 13, at Mrs. Lee's home in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to either of the following: Cancer Research Foundation, c/o Dr. Janice Dutcher, 640 W. 239th St, Riverdale, NY 10463; or, the Cancer Support Team, 933 Mamaroneck Ave, Suite 102, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

title: Addenda: Vodafone Picks Wieden & Kennedy
description: The Vodafone Group in Newbury, England, said yesterday that it had named the Amsterdam office of Wieden & Kennedy as its lead agency, responsible for creating global campaigns as the company moves to a single mobile telephone brand. Billings have not been determined.

title: A Nice Red to Go With That Fillet? No? Then How About a Piercing Green?
description: Wake Woody Allen from ''Sleeper'' and deposit him at Pod in Philadelphia, and he'd be right at home. One feature of this futuristic new restaurant, owned by Stephen Starr, is three dining alcoves, or pods, where the touch of a button changes the color of the lights. Diners -- and their potatoes -- can be bathed in shocking pink, electric blue, bright orange or brilliant green, among nine choices. The pan-Asian restaurant, which also has lounge stools that light up when occupied, was designed by David Rockwell, presumably just after he was abducted by aliens. Pod is at 3636 Sansom Street, in the Inn at Penn, near the university; (215) 387-1803.

title: More agencies are finding pay tied to the results of a campaign rather than the campaign itself.
description: THE shift by major advertisers from compensating their agencies based on the traditional billings method to compensating them based on results has accelerated since 1997, according to a study conducted by the Association of National Advertisers in New York.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Pc Maker Seeking a Buyer
description: EMachines, once one of the fastest-growing makers of personal computers, said yesterday that it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to look for a company to buy it. EMachines, backed by two big South Korean manufacturers of computer hardware, had specialized in producing low-priced computers sold in retail stores. It now claims to rank third in home computers sold at retail and has sold more than 3.7 million machines since 1998. EMachines had hoped to profit by selling its customers Internet services and putting advertising on its computers. Saul Hansell (NYT)

Although the gap between supply and demand has tightened, capacity has risen since 1994, not fallen.

description: More than 60 environmental and fishermen's groups will ask the Food and Drug Administration today for a moratorium on the approval of any genetically modified fish, arguing that the environmental and health risks have not been adequately studied.

description: The veteran Maple Leafs forward Steve Thomas was a member of the Islanders team that stunned the Pittsburgh Penguins in Game 7 of their second-round series in 1993, and he can only hope that history is about to repeat itself.

title: Escobar, the Future of the Mets, Is Offered a Chance Right Now
description: Outfielder Alex Escobar is the prize of the Mets' farm system, and the team has shown great restraint with him this season. Escobar joined the Mets at Coors Field today, but only because the circumstances were perfect. He will only be with the team for a short time.

title: The Pollen Count Is Miserably High, As if (Ah-choo!) You Didn't Know

The puffy, reddened lids, almost swollen shut, are proof that even a medicine cabinet filled with prescription allergy drugs won't reverse the effects of the recent high pollen counts.

title: In Study of Nation's Worst Traffic, New York Must Yield
description: The drivers of the South and the West, squirming ever longer in their upholstered commutes to work, can take perverse pleasure in a validation of their suffering. Just as they had always suspected, they had it worse -- much worse -- than the eight million residents of New York City.

title: Just the Thing for the Chococoffeeholic
description: I have never liked flavored coffees, with their chemically enhanced effluvia of nuts, fruits or spices. But I was intrigued when I heard about Chocatal, a new coffee from Jeremiah's Pick, a San Francisco company. Mixed with the roasted coffee beans are roasted cacao nibs, the small kernels that chocolate-makers pulverize to produce cocoa and chocolate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, GWENDOLYN

Born May 21, 1915 near Adelaide, Australia, the daughter of Augusta Wilhelmina Nossenheim of Saal, Germany and Arthur Saunders of Aberdeen, Scotland, Gwendolyn & her widowed mother arrived in Brooklyn in early 1918. A graduate of Brooklyn College, she worked as a legal secretary at the law firms of Webster Sheffield Fleischmann Hitchcock and Chrystie, Bangser Klein Rocca and Blum and Rogers and Wells. She is fondly remembered by her many friends and former associates. Visitation will be on Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Herbst-Trzaska Waldeck Chapels, 7614 - 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. Attended valet parking. Funeral services will be on Friday 11:30 AM at Redeemer-St. John's Lutheran Church, 939-83 St., Brooklyn, NY. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: CARGILL WILL RAISE THE PRICE OF ITS SALT PRODUCTS

Cargill's salt unit did not give the size of the increase, which will take effect June 11, and apply to its brand of table salt, Diamond Crystal, and its industrial salts, which are used for icing roads, conditioning water and other purposes.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit Up At Pioneer
description: The home electronics manufacturer Pioneer Corporation reported a 40 percent increase in group profit, to 18.3 billion yen ($150 million), for the year that ended in March, helped by cost-cutting and strong sales of plasma display panels. Sales increased 5.1 percent, to a record 647 billion yen. The company expects its profit this year to climb 15 percent, to 21 billion yen, and revenue to grow 11 percent, to 720 billion yen. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hale House Inquiry Widens
description: The state attorney general's office said yesterday it would investigate allegations that donations to Hale House, the Harlem children's shelter, were used to shore up a failing off-Broadway musical produced by the husband of the charity's president. The Daily News reported yesterday that Dr. Lorraine E. Hale and her husband, Jesse DeVore, funneled $500,000 to Mr. DeVore's show, ''Faith Journey,'' which was based on the life of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. Both Dr. Hale and Mr. DeVore, the charity's public relations director, agreed earlier this week to resign from Hale House, and a new interim board of directors was named. It is expected to name Edna Wells Handy, a former general counsel for the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, as the charity's interim executive director. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Blair, at School in London, Announces June 7 Election
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that Britons would vote on June 7 in an election that surveys say will almost certainly give him a coveted second term. In a scripted breach with tradition, he chose a showcase girls' school in urban London rather than the steps of 10 Downing Street today to confirm the date.

title: Giuliani Calls for 3 Percent Increase in Rent
description: As the New York City Rent Guidelines Board prepared for a vote tonight to set rents for 2.3 million tenants, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed what he called moderate increases, of 3 percent and 5 percent. And in an effort to get his way, the mayor is making three last-minute appointments to the board.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Ban On Confederate T-Shirts Is Opposed
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a federal lawsuit challenging a school district's recent ban on T-shirts bearing the Confederate battle flag. The suit was filed on behalf of nine students in middle school and high school in Seminole County who had worn shirts that depicted cars and hunting but included the flag in the background. The A.C.L.U. has opposed the use of the Confederate emblem on the Georgia flag, but said it regarded the case as a free-speech issue. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: South Korea Cancels Joint Military Exercise in Dispute Over Textbooks : Seoul Demands Tokyo Rewrite History
description: SEOUL  South Korea canceled an air-naval military rescue exercise with Japan on Tuesday while demanding "correction of distortions" in Japanese textbooks of Tokyo's role as an imperial power in Korea before World War II.

title: Jorge Robson de Souza, Port Isabel Service Processing Center near Los Fresnos, Tex., April 24, 2001
description: left my home in Vitoria, a city in southeastern Brazil, and took a 16-hour bus ride to Sao Paulo. I had to pawn my house and a plot of land in Vitoria to raise the $8,000 needed to pay the coyotes that smuggled me to the United States. But I didn't find a job when I got here. Instead, I ended up in this health center after being detained by an immigration officer. The doctors took an X-ray and found a spot in my lungs. They told me I had to stay in isolation, that I might have to stay here two months. All I could think was that I was going to die in this cold place, away from my kids. But I know I'm not sick. My brother had a lung removed due to resistant tuberculosis. I'm not coughing like my brother. I am not wasted away like him. They gave me a Bible in Portuguese, so I read all the time. I also watch TV a lot. There's not much else to do. The worst part is falling asleep. I keep on thinking about my debts, my disease, my kids. I don't know what I'm going to do."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the visit of Pope John Paul II to Syria referred imprecisely to the destruction in the Golan Heights city of Quneitra, where he has since delivered a prayer for peace. The city was captured by Israel during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war. It is the Syrians who contend that the Israelis used dynamite and bulldozers to level the town before they left in 1974. Israel says the damage was a byproduct of fighting in the wars of 1967 and 1973.

title: Despite Denial, Torricelli Aided In Donor's Deal
description: Soon after Senator Robert G. Torricelli began his relationship with David Chang, the wealthy political contributor who says he gave the senator unreported gifts and cash, Mr. Torricelli intervened in an international business deal to help Mr. Chang recover a debt of more than $70 million.

title: Funky, Runny, Ripe: Waiter, Bring It On
description: PROGRESS never comes without a price. America, the country responsible for American cheese (not to mention foam-rubber cheese hats) no longer snickers at ''Sonoma Valley goat cheese,'' a guaranteed laugh-getter on the ''Tonight'' show for years. It fears not when a funky Muenster lurches toward the table. From blank-slate status, cheese consciousness in the United States has grown by leaps and bounds in recent years, and with it, a swelling population of cheese snobs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Airline Stake
description: The Russian oil magnate Roman Abramovich, who was elected governor of a Far Eastern region last year, is reported to have accumulated a 29 percent stake in Russia's main international airline, Aeroflot. According to the Russian business daily Vedomosti, companies linked to Mr. Abramovich bought shares of Aeroflot on the market as well as from investors, including the self-exiled tycoon Boris Berezovsky. A spokesman for Mr. Abramovich had no comment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, ESTELLE ARONSON
description: SCHULMAN-Estelle Aronson. Of Tamarac, Florida, formerly of Eastchester, New York. Wife of Milton Schulman and the late Jules Aronson. Beloved mother of Gail Spielholtz, Laura Aronson and the late Karen Aronson Weber. Loving sister of Jesse Josephs, Lucille Singerman, Milton Josephs, and Linda Katz. Grandmother of Valerie Schur, Elizabeth Fischer, Audrey Altschul, David Schur and Jonathan Spielholtz. Great grandmother of Benjamin and Chloe Altschul. A graveside service will be held 11AM Friday, May 11, Sharon Gardens, Valhalla NY. Shiva will be held Friday immediately following the service & Sunday at noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: The Day California Shook the World
description: ON May 24, 1976, six weeks before America's bicentennial celebration, there occurred in Paris a tasting that American winemakers and cultural historians have come to characterize as the defining moment in the evolution of fine wine in this country.

title: Sotheby's 20th-Century Art Auction Fetches $54 Million
description: Despite the rocky economy, when the prices are right and the material is top notch, the art market rallies with stunning vigor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MECKLER, HERMAN
description: MECKLER-Herman. 1913-2000. Forever loved. Forever mourned. Remembered by your family.

title: Where Are the Heroes of Summers Past?
description: It is the baseball equivalent of the French Foreign Legion, with the twist that those here are hoping to be remembered, rather than forgotten.

title: PLAYBOY OPENS WEB SITE FOR OVERSEAS BETTING ON SPORTS
description: Playboy Enterprises started an online betting site, where gamblers outside the United States can wager on items ranging from who will win the Super Bowl to the magazine's Playmate of the Year title. The site comes three months after Playboy entered into an agreement with the British bookmaker Ladbrokes eGaming and SportsLine.com to add more sports content to its Web site, Playboy.com. The site, PlayboySportsBook.com, will offer wagering on football, basketball, baseball, boxing, tennis and golf in the United States, on international sports, as well as on events related to Playboy magazine. The site, to be based in Gibraltar, will have safeguards to prevent taking bets from the United States or other countries where sports betting is illegal.

title: Civilian Complaints About Police Rise
description: Allegations of police misconduct to the Civilian Complaint Review Board rose in first four months of this year, a jump that comes after several years of declines, according to data obtained from the board yesterday.

title: The Bumpy Road to Damascus
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: Ginsburg Discusses Cancer
description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the Supreme Court told a women's medical group that after her successful treatment for colon cancer, ''each thing I do comes with a heightened appreciation that I am able to do it.'' Justice Ginsburg, 68, learned she had cancer shortly before the court's 1999-2000 term. She underwent surgery, chemotherapy and radiation treatment without missing a day on the bench. At a dinner sponsored by the Society for Women's Health Research on Monday night, she urged listeners to schedule colonoscopies. Linda Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Gains Found for the Poor in Rigorous Preschool
description: Poor children who attend intensive preschool classes are more likely to graduate from high school and less likely to be arrested than poor children who have not participated in such programs, according to a study that followed graduates of urban preschools for 15 years.

title: Nuns Offer Clues to Alzheimer's and Aging
description: MANKATO, Minn., May 2  A spiraling road slopes gently up to Good Counsel Hill, where the convent of the School Sisters of Notre Dame perches peacefully. Within its thick red brick walls are bright paintings of nuns and children. Organ hymns waft from a circular chapel, and nuns attend Mass and murmur rosaries under a white vaulted dome.

title: Running for Mayor, in Perpetuity; Herman Badillo Is Hoping That the Timing Is Right
description: As Herman Badillo sees it, his perpetual campaign for mayor of New York City was given a huge push one Sunday early last month when Gov. George E. Pataki praised him with the same words he used to describe a far more flush Republican mayoral contender, Michael R. Bloomberg. Just like Mr. Bloomberg, the governor said on WABC-TV, Mr. Badillo was ''an incredible success'' who would be a fine candidate.

title: Technology Shares Gain But Dow and S.& P. Decline
description: The Nasdaq composite index rose yesterday as investors hoped for a positive earnings report from Cisco Systems, the networking equipment giant, after markets closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, FRANK
description: BRILL-Frank. Of Sarasota, FL and New York died May 7, 2001. Survived by beloved & cherished wife Sylvia (Berland); Devoted father of Alice (John) and Robert (Chris); Loving grandfather of Elizabeth, Sam and Melanie; Caring stepfather of Ilene, Fred, Warren and Joan. Predeceased by former wife, Lillian and brother, Martin.

title: Phone Companies? Don't Get Me Started
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: A Cabinet Resignation
description: A scandal has forced the minister of integration, Fernando Bezerra, to resign. Mr. Bezerra stepped down after news reports that the country's main business confederation had been paying the rent of his residence, and accusations that a company he once owned received improper benefits from a government economic development agency. Mr. Bezerra denied any wrongdoing, saying ''I decided that I could not remain as minister without the political support of my party.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Stays Afloat
description: Creditors of Hynix Semiconductor are hoping to keep the company afloat by issuing bonds and rolling over debts totaling 5.1 trillion won ($3.9 billion). The Korea Exchange Bank, a government-controlled institution that is the lead creditor, said Hynix creditors had pledged support if the Seoul Guarantee Insurance Company would underwrite bonds totaling 600 billion won ($462 million). The government's Financial Supervisory Service indicated that Seoul Guarantee could do so if the bonds were classified as rollovers. Seoul Guarantee cannot underwrite new bonds with public funds. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: DOW CHEMICAL ENHANCES ITS BID FOR A BRITISH COMPETITOR
description: The Dow Chemical Company raised its bid for a rival British chemical maker, Ascot P.L.C., 2 percent, to 311 million ($443 million) because Ascot will get more than expected for a subsidiary. Dow will now pay 407.14 pence a share in cash, said J. P. Morgan, the investment banker for the chemical company. The offer was 400 pence when Dow announced the deal on March 29. The difference represents a larger-than-expected gain from the sale of Ashtenne Holdings P.L.C., a property business. Ashtenne, which had 32 million ($45.7 million) in 2000 sales, will be sold to a management group for 44 million, about 17 percent more than expected, J. P. Morgan said.

title: A Secret Kept Under a Terra Cotta Lid
description: IT is midday in Morocco. The aroma of sizzling lamb mingled with cumin and sweet cinnamon drifts from rows of little terra cotta pots called tagines, which sit atop charcoal burners outside a cafe. And of course, you stop for lunch. The tagine is placed before you, the lid is lifted, and suddenly a village in the Atlas Mountains becomes an enchantment.

title: Adam's the Apple of Her Eye, And Hers, and Hers and Hers
description: In a climate of rampant confession, where every talk show oracle encourages brutal, unbridled honesty, the premise behind Gerard Strembridge's teasing romantic comedy ''About Adam'' seems refreshing, even mildly subversive. The implausible chronicle of a rake who adopts the saintly guise of an empathetic Mr. Right to work his wiles, it promotes the sensible notion that a little discretion and secrecy are necessary to maintain domestic peace.

title: A Company's Nazi Past
description: To the Editor:

title: After Going the Distance, Devils Advance
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. -- Loaded with heart and talent, the New Jersey Devils didn't need Scott Niedermayer to come back against the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Lawyers Cite Statements Of Defendants In Terror Case
description: A lawyer for a Saudi man charged in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, acknowledged yesterday that prosecutors had presented a strong case to the jury. But he contended that his client, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, should be acquitted because a confession he made was coerced.

title: Protean South African Blend
description: THE wines of South Africa have largely been ignored in the American market. Burdened by the fading stigma of apartheid, and without the romantic imagery of, say, French and Italian wines, South Africa has had difficulty gaining traction here.

title: Bush to Nominate 11 to Judgeships Today
description: President Bush is set to announce his first judicial choices on Wednesday, formally entering the high-stakes debate about the ideological shape of the federal courts and their influence over some of the nation's most intensely felt social issues.

title: Telecommuting's Big Experiment
description: There is something quixotic about the quest of Representative Frank R. Wolf to encourage federal workers to stay out of the office more often.

title: Oklahoma Governor Weighs Independent Inquiry on Lab
description: With defense lawyers maintaining that state and local officials have a conflict of interest and so should remove themselves from the investigation of the police chemist Joyce Gilchrist, Gov. Frank Keating said today that he would consider appointing an independent prosecutor, although he denied any conflict.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Laser Project Said To Hold Hidden Costs
description: A mammoth laser in Northern California whose rising costs nearly led Congress to kill it last year has at least another $1 billion in hidden costs still to be accounted for, according to a new study. The conclusions were disputed by Susan Houghton, a spokeswoman for Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, which runs the project, the National Ignition Facility. She noted that the study was commissioned by Tri-Valley Cares, a group long opposed to the project. Proponents of the laser say it can test aspects of nuclear weapons without exploding them, though others dispute this. James Glanz (NYT)

title: New Jersey's Redistricting
description: In the first major redistricting case following the 2000 census, a panel of three federal judges upheld New Jersey's newly redrawn legislative districts. The judges rejected Republican Party claims that by shifting some black and Hispanic voters out of three predominantly minority districts in and around Newark and spreading them to other, mostly white districts, the plan diluted minority voting strength in violation of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Woods Is Expected to Play in Westchester
description: Tiger Woods, who is expected to play in this year's Buick Classic, may officially commit himself to the tournament as early as Monday.

title: Berlusconi's Balancing Act With Italy's Rightists
description: If Silvio Berlusconi, the media tycoon, prevails over his opponent, former Mayor Francesco Rutelli of Rome, and becomes prime minister of Italy in the election on Sunday, it will be at least in part because of an uncanny skill at bringing disparate partners under one political umbrella.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Disclosure Sought On Presidential-Library Donors
description: A House subcommittee approved a measure that requires presidential libraries to disclose the names and occupations of donors who give more than $5,000 as well as the amounts contributed. Representative John J. Duncan, Republican of Tennessee, introduced a version of the bill more than a year ago, but it languished until Congress began investigating whether any contributions to Bill Clinton's presidential library were linked to pardons he granted. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Belmont Opens With Nassau County
description: Belmont Park begins its 55-day spring and summer meeting today with the $150,000 Nassau County Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at seven-eighths of a mile.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: State Budget Cuts Ordered
description: South Carolina's Budget and Control Board ordered a spending cut of 1 percent for most state services, including public schools, for the fiscal year that ends June 30. State economists blamed a stagnant first quarter, high tax refunds, and open-ended legislative commitments to property tax cuts and college scholarships. State law requires the board, whose chairman is Gov. Jim Hodges, to make cuts when revenue lags. The $48 million in cuts came as lawmakers debated how to cut $500 million from the budget for the year that begins July 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SY, STEVEN
description: SY-Steven. Friends and colleagues at The Brooklyn Hospital Center mourn the untimely death of the son of Drs. Wilfrido & Milan Sy, and brother of Melanie Sy, on Sunday, May 6, 2001. We are all saddened and express our deepest sympathy to the Sy family. Visiting hours will be held Wednesday, May 9th, from 3 to 5 PM and 6 to 8 PM at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave (81st St), New York. Funeral mass will be held on Thursday, May 10, at 10 AM at the Saint Agnes RC Church, 143 E. 43 St (Lexington), New York. Condolences may be sent to the family at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel or contributions may be forwarded to the Saint Agnes Homeless Center/ Soup Kitchen in Steven's memory. Seth S. Faison Chairman, Board of Trustees Frederick D. Alley President & CEO

description: HAHN-Ross Bertram, 80. On May 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Terri Schiffman Hahn, devoted father of Devorah (Dody) Hahn, cherished brother of Doris Treuhaft. Will be missed by generations of friends and family, especially nieces and nephews for whom ''great-uncle'' had a double meaning. Service today at 1 PM at Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam at 91st. Contributions to The Sherman Library, P.O. Box 40, Sherman CT, 06784

title: Study Says Gays Can Shift Sexual Orientation
description: A psychiatrist at Columbia University who contends that the mental health profession has ''totally bought the idea that once you are gay you cannot be changed'' will report today that some ''highly motivated'' gays can become heterosexual.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPPLE, ALFRED S.
description: KOPPLE-Alfred S. May 9, 1999. We close our eyes and see your face, your smile so filled with love. You are always with us.

description: Dorothee Metlitzki, a retired professor of English at Yale and a prominent scholar of medieval Arabic, Middle English and Herman Melville, died on April 14 in Hamden, Conn. She was 86.

description: LENAHAN-Thomas E. Jr. Of Ridgewood, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY on Monday, May 7, 2001. Husband of Eleanor Lenahan. Devoted father of Patricia Jarrell, Thomas Richard Lenahan, William R. Lenahan, Mary Lenahan, Joan DeMaio, Jean Qualliu, Maureen Mosley, Christine Lenahan and Kathleen Heslin. Dear brother of Capt. Robert P. Lenahan and John Lenahan. Also survived by eighteen grandchildren. Funeral from Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kinderkamack Road, Westwood, New Jersey, Thursday at 9:00 AM. Funeral Liturgy at Church of St. Pius X, Old Tappan, NJ at 10:00 AM. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family will receive their friends Wednesday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the zydeco accordionist Boozoo Chavis on Monday and in some copies on Sunday misstated the date of the heart attack that preceded his death on Saturday at age 70. It was on April 28, not April 24.

title: Panel Reaches Deal on Budget Framework
description: Republicans in the Senate and a handful of moderate Democrats reached a final deal tonight on how much money to allocate to tax cuts and spending, and Republicans and Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee intensified their talks over how to apportion the tax reductions.

description: THE OTHER SIDE OF EDEN

description: To the Editor:

title: Wild and Crazy Guys: Too Wild and Crazy?
description: As head coach, Larry Robinson has modified his behavior behind the bench. When he was a Devils assistant, Robinson sang along with ''My Sharona'' and other songs played before face-offs. Sometimes he is still tempted to bob his head like those lounge lizards from ''Saturday Night Live'' when the Continental Arena video board shows an ''S.N.L.'' clip of them driving through Times Square and dancing at night clubs.

title: Worrisome Signals on Drugs
description: The Bush administration has been sending disappointing signals to those who had hoped the new team might fashion a better balance between military interdiction of drug producers abroad and treatment for drug addicts at home. President Bush's reported plan to nominate John Walters as chief of the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy suggests a clear preference for military and law enforcement strategies, the traditional emphasis, as opposed to more effective treatment strategies. Even before the formal announcement, his expected nomination has stirred sharp commentary from critics and supporters. The Senate should subject him to a rigorous examination of his priorities before confirming his appointment.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HEALTH

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: At-Home Access Dips
description: The overall number of United States homes with Internet access declined during the first quarter for the first time in the 21 years it has been tracked, largely as a result of the failure of the free Internet service provider as a viable business model, according to a survey conducted by Telecommunications Reports International, a consulting concern. The survey found that the number of online household subscribers dropped just over a quarter percentage point during the period, to just under 68.5 million, as the number of subscribers to free Internet services dropped more than 19 percent.

title: Food Stuff: Just the Thing for the Chococoffeeholic
description: Ihave never liked flavored coffees, with their chemically enhanced effluvia of nuts, fruits or spices. But I was intrigued when I heard about Chocatal, a new coffee from Jeremiah's Pick, a San Francisco company. Mixed with the roasted coffee beans are roasted cacao nibs, the small kernels that chocolate-makers pulverize to produce cocoa and chocolate.

title: Sharpton Gives Ferrer a List Of Conditions
description: Throwing a wrench into Fernando Ferrer's attempt to assemble a coalition of black and Hispanic voters behind his mayoral candidacy, the Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that he would support Mr. Ferrer only if he publicly pledged to endorse black candidates running for Bronx borough president and city comptroller.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Victory For Opposition
description: The leader of the country's main opposition party won a hearing before the Supreme Court on the constitutionality of the colonial-era law under which the government has charged him with inciting violence against the state. The charges stem from a speech last year in which Morgan Tsvangirai warned President Robert Mugabe that if he did not leave office peacefully, ''we will remove you violently.'' Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Higher Stakes in Eviction Battles
description: Even in the storied annals of New York City Housing Court, where landlords have tried to evict tenants for everything from barking dogs to unauthorized washing machines, the case against Dana Escoffier was novel.

title: Fired Workers Fire Back, Then Fall Hard
description: If only their case could be laid out in a court of law, Ira and Suzanne Stitz believe, the judge would surely conclude they were illegally fired and would order their former employer to make them whole.

title: Bomb's Effects Linger Along a Road
description: Patrick Livingston remembers selling Timothy J. McVeigh a gun. Roberta Erickson remembers signing Terry L. Nichols up for cable TV. And Jim Jones remembers seeing a Ryder truck parked outside his office.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Layoffs at Internet Service
description: The Spanish company TerraLycos, a large provider of Internet service, narrowed its first-quarter loss, but said it would lay off 15 percent of its 3,352 employees. TerraLycos said its loss before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization was 76 million euros ($68 million), compared with 102 million euros in the fourth quarter. The company said revenue fell 6 percent, to 178 million euros.

title: More Truth in Titles
description: Looking for more game show magic from the BBC after the showing of ''Weakest Link,'' NBC announced yesterday that it had picked up a show from England in which the contestants are the ruthless ones rather than the host.

title: Legally Blind Art Teacher Opens Students' Minds
description: The art teacher, Elizabeth Castellano, moved carefully from one table to another, appraising one sixth grader's handling of perspective, assisting another in rendering a charcoal line more sharply, gently suggesting to a third how to capture the bend of the model's elbow with a purposeful smudge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRESSEL, HERMAN A. (LEFTY)
description: KRESSEL-Herman A. (Lefty). 85. Died on May 5, 2001 in Buffalo, N.Y., his home after many years in Hewlett, N.Y. and St. Petersburg, FL. Mr. Kressel was born in NYC, 1915 and had a BS degree from Brooklyn College and a Master's Degree from NYU. He was a Master Plumber who became a vocational high school teacher in NYC and later, entered school administration and became original Director of the NYC Manpower Development and Training Program. He is predeceased by his wife Louise Alexander Kressel and is survived by his daughters Alexandra K. Sussman, Esquire, Patricia Duffner, MD, and her husband John, two grandchildren Michael and Jeremy Sussman, and his sister Frances Smith. He will be missed.

title: 'Survivor' Survives
description: Say what you will about how CBS's second ''Survivor'' series stacked up against the first -- less tension, far more pleasantries, far fewer clashes -- it is still primed to be the most-watched prime-time series of the television season.

title: War and Remembrance
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ferrer Refuses Endorsement Linked to Race
description: Fernando Ferrer last night rejected a demand from the Rev. Al Sharpton that he pledge to endorse black candidates for two specific city offices as a condition for winning Mr. Sharpton's backing for his mayoral bid. Mr. Ferrer said that while he eagerly wanted Mr. Sharpton's support, he would not make endorsements based on race.

title: Missiles and Treaties in the Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Video Gambling Bills Killed
description: Video gambling legislation appears dead after three bills -- one to limit the location and payoffs of the machines, one to tax them and one to ban them -- were removed from consideration in the State House five days before the session's end. A measure approved by the Senate last week would have closed adult video arcades, concentrated video gambling at the state's dog tracks and limited payouts to $5 in coupons. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Recalling a Profitable Lead As the Cavendish Begins
description: The biggest bridge tournament of the year in financial terms is the Cavendish, which began yesterday in Las Vegas. A year ago the auction pool in the preliminary Teams totaled $312,000, and the Pairs totaled $1,140,000. This year those totals may well be exceeded. There are 100 players from 12 countries, and 25 have won world titles.

title: America Lashes Back
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Net, There Is Nothing Like a Dam
description: THE giant Western dams of the 20th century are a civics class and epic novel in one. They are both public and private, each needing the other -- colossi that made the desert bloom, at a cost measured in sweat and sometimes lives. A dam is not always concrete, but it is never abstract.

title: Addenda: Acquisitions by 2 Agencies
description: Two agencies are making acquisitions for undisclosed terms.

title: Nintendo Grows Up and Goes for the Gross-Out
description: CONKER the squirrel, the title character in a new Nintendo game, is having a terrible day or, as he puts it, a bad fur day. It all began with a few too many drinks at the local saloon. After throwing up outside the bar, Conker heads through the darkness until he comes to a sign that points in two directions, Naughty and Nice. "Emmm," Conker slurs, teetering down the Naughty path, "this way, I suppose."

title: Fitting Out a Triplex Cloister
description: ON a dazzling spring afternoon, Andres Serrano sat in the dark, still living room of his East Village apartment waiting for his visitor's eyes to adjust to the light. A wrought-iron chandelier hung ineffectually from the 16-foot-high vaulted ceiling, its dimmer switch on the fritz, he explained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERSON, LEO
description: MERSON-Leo. On May 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Paula. Loving father of Michael, Mark & Melissa. Dear brother of Hy. Adoring grandfather of Jonathan, Erica, Dana & Zachary. Service Thurs day 1:00 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Edwin Finckel, 83, Composer, Jazz Pianist and Music Educator
description: Edwin Finckel, a composer, jazz pianist, conductor and musical educator, died on Monday in Madison, N.J. He was 83 and lived in Madison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, DORIS A.
description: COOK-Doris A. On May 8, 2001. Retired Senior Associate Director of Nursing at Beth Israel Medi cal Center. Lifelong companion Karen Kirschner. Devoted sister of Ralph (Freeda) Cook. Dear aunt and great aunt. Friends may call at A ndrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Friday 7-9PM. Ser vices 10AM Saturday at the funeral home. Entombment to follow at Trinit y Cemetery, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions to the American Heart Association or American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Article 2001051092023501607 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: U.S. Shells Hit School
description: The German police said that two aluminum projectiles fired by an American Army Bradley fighting vehicle on the training ground of the Grafenwhr military base crashed into the roof of a nearby elementary school in the Bavarian village of Kirchenthumbach on Tuesday afternoon. Children were playing in the schoolyard at the time, but no one was injured and the projectiles did not explode. The army temporarily suspended the exercise after learning of the incident. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Israel Strikes Targets in Gaza City
description: JERUSALEM, May 10  Two Romanian guest workers were killed by a bomb today as they were repairing the fence along the Israeli-Gazan border.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cost Of Digital Technology
description: British Sky Broadcasting's satellite TV group said it would reorganize its interactive TV services, which allow viewers to shop, bet, send e-mail messages or even choose camera angles in sports coverage from their armchairs, to absorb Open, a shopping and games affiliate. British Sky Broadcasting said it completed the $560 million purchase, announced last year, bringing its stake to 80 percent. The cost of introducing digital technology emerged anew when British Sky Broadcasting also reported its eighth successive quarterly loss, which widened to $152 million, five times that of a year earlier. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Date Set For Europe Vote
description: The government set June 7 for a referendum on the Treaty of Nice, which paves the way for Central and Eastern European countries to join the European Union. All 15 union members must ratify the treaty for it to take effect, and Ireland is the only one required by its Constitution to put such a measure before the public. Critics say the treaty sets the stage for the development of a pan-European federal government and compromises Ireland's traditional neutrality; the government began a publicity campaign to encourage approval. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Harlem Man Killed By Bus
description: A man playing with his grandson was killed by a Greyhound bus yesterday when he chased a ball into the street, the police said. The man, Mark White, 42, was hit on Seventh Avenue near 121st Street, not far from his home, by a southbound bus carrying 15 passengers, the police said. There were no other serious injuries. No one has been charged in the incident, said Sgt. James Foley, a police spokesman, but an investigation is continuing. Susan Saulny (NYT)

description: MIKE PETERS, an avid collector of artifacts from World War II, was once an enthusiastic user of online auctions. Every day, he logged on to Yahoo Auctions or eBay and trolled for uniforms, helmets, medals, flags, bayonets and books. Sometimes he would come across items that had belonged to Nazi soldiers, and he would snap them up, proud to fill a gap in his collection.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Suffolk Tax Increase
description: The Suffolk County Legislature has approved by a vote of 12 to 5, with one abstention, a temporary increase in the sales tax to 8.5 percent from 8.25 percent. The increase, approved on Tuesday, is intended to avoid property tax increases next year. The county budget deficit is expected to total at least $96 million and the sales tax increase is expected to raise about $50 million annually. Suffolk's sales tax, effective June 1, will match neighboring Nassau County's rate. John Rather (NYT)

The real appeal is the freedom to express oneself. Much of Frank Gehry's early work was in Venice. Asked how he got away with such challenging designs, he said, ''In Venice everything becomes part of the context in five minutes.''

description: Turn, girl. Here comes the first in what will probably be a long, leggy stretch of New York buildings inspired by the world of fashion. The Astor Place Hotel, to be built on the south side of Astor Place between Lafayette Street and Fourth Avenue, will resemble a gigantic pair of slacks with asymmetrical legs cut from shimmering, confetti-patterned fabric.

description: Northwest Airlines mechanics approved a new contract today that gave them the best pay in the industry and eliminated the threat of a strike this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Airline Merger Surprise
description: The HNA Group, owner of Hainan Airlines, said that it would take over Shanxi Airlines, a regional carrier in northern China, pre-empting a widely expected merger of Shanxi with another Chinese carrier, Shandong Airlines. The American financier George Soros controls 15 percent of HNA, which took over Changan Airlines last year and Beijing-based Xinhua Airlines in March. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

This week, NEC unveiled not only a new laptop, the Versa TXi, but also a new term (new for NEC, at least): ultraportable. Other PC makers have used the term, but NEC says the Versa TXi is part of a new class of ultraportable laptops that includes a modular bay.

description: A leading maker of drugs that fight AIDS, the Agouron Pharmaceuticals division of Pfizer, and its agency, CCA Advertising in New York, are changing a consumer campaign they recently introduced for the drug Viracept. They are adding cautionary words that such drugs are not a cure for AIDS nor do they prevent the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

description: BERLIN, May 10  Unconvinced by President Bush's proposals for a missile defense shield, Germany posed today what one American envoy called "very, very serious questions" over the project.

title: Straight Up Or on the Reef?
description: Finding a sea creature floating in your drink doesn't mean a grilled shrimp has dived into your tumbler. Each of six Coral Reef glasses has a photo-image decal of marine life -- urchins, sea fans, corals -- on the bottom. Filled with water (or if Mom prefers, vodka) the glasses magnify the image, which appears to float to the surface. AMY GOLDWASSER

description: In any given season, the New Victory Theater, which is dedicated to children, presents entertainment that arches across a spectrum of appeal in terms of age.
