description: Gay and lesbian book publishing appears to be in a somewhat quiescent period, and it's difficult to know if that's because of a generational change or because the struggle for assimilation has in many ways largely succeeded.

title: Prosecutor's Summation in African Embassy Bombings Case Highlights Victims' Misery
description: In the end, a prosecutor told a federal jury in Manhattan yesterday, it came down to a body lying in the rubble for two days in the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya. The victim, Roselyn Wanjiku Mwangi, had struggled to survive, talking intermittently to a fellow victim, who was dragged out alive before her. But the rescuers did not get to Ms. Mwangi in time.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Web Site Manager Cuts Jobs
description: Exodus Communications said yesterday that it would eliminate 675 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, after reductions in spending by customers led to wider losses in the latest quarter. The company, a large manager of corporate Web sites based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it now expected a loss of $110 million to $115 million, or 19 to 20 cents a share, in the second quarter. It recently cut its 2001 sales forecast by a third, to about $1.6 billion. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, MARY FISCHER
description: BELL-Mary Fischer. Mary Fischer Bell's long and f ull life ended peacefully on May 8, 2001. Born Mary Agatha Fischer in Newark, NJ on June 25, 1912, she grew up in the Bronx, attended St. A thanasius School, and graduated from Ursuline Academy. Mary earned a B.A. in History from the College of New Rochelle in 1934. She was ma rried to the late Ralph Herbert Bell from July 16, 1943, until his de ath on June 4, 1995. Mary had a brief but memorable career as a fift h grade teacher at Epiphany School in the early 1960's, but her true life's work outside of the home was volunteer service to others. Mary was devoted to her alma mater. On June 7, 1969, she was a warded the Ursula Laurus Citation by the College of New Rochell e ''honoring alumnae who have provided outstanding leadership and have demonstrated selfless and generous devotion in furthering high ideals and rich traditions of Ursuline education.'' On June 2, 1979, Mary received the highest award given by the College of New Rochelle, the Angela Merici Medal. She is responsible, along with her late hu sband, for a scholarship fund at the College, and for the Ralph H. Bell Reading Room in the new College library. She served as the Class o f 1934, fund agent for over twenty years and was a longtime member of the Board of Directors of the Alumnae Association. Mary was an active leader in Epiphany Parish for over fifty years. When, in 1964, the church building was destroyed by fire, she helped raise funds to b uild the present church. She was a Trustee of the Parish for fou r years. Mary was a founding Board member and the first chairperson of the Board of FISH (Friends in Service to the Housebound) at Epiphany Parish. She gave tirelessly to this effort for many years an d helped bring comfort, sustenance and companionship to countle ss housebound people. The March of Dimes, American Association o f University Women and the Ladies of Charity were among the other causes to which she gave of herself. Among other recognitions of her devoted service, Mary received the New York Archdiocesan Silve r Cross and Thanks Badge, the highest honor bestowed by the Girl Scouts of America. Mary was aunt to thirtynine nieces and nephews, and followed their lives and the lives of their children closely. Mary' s interest in others extended to families of her children's spouses, and friends of her family members. Numerous photographs of child ren adorned a large bulletin board next to her telephone. Birthdays, Easter, Christmas, St. Patrick's Day, wedding anniversaries, Mo ther's Day and Father's Day all saw scores of delivery vehicles acro ss the country deliver beautiful floral arrangements sent by Mary. While in her seventies, Mary lost her ''Book of Life'' in which she had collected names, addresses, birthdays, and anniversary dates. Sh e tirelessly reconstructed her book, concerned that she might miss an occasion to pass along her love and greetings. Other instances of her generosity, both to groups and individuals are too numerous to r ecount. Mary Fischer Bell was preceded in death by her husband, Ralph H. Bell, her parents, William Fischer and Katherine Towey Fischer, he r brother William Fischer, Jr. and her sister Patricia Fischer Weber. She is survived by her three daughters, Elizabeth Bell LeVaca, Katherine M. Bell, Roberta Bell Williamson, her sons - in - law, J oseph LeVaca, Thomas Blackburn and Bruce Williamson, Jr., and he r four grandchildren, Christopher Eric Fuhrman and his wife Jean Fl ores Fuhrman, Jennifer Anne Fuhrman, Erin Mary Williamson, and Sarah Elizabeth Williamson. Mary is also survived by her brother, Jo hn Fischer and his wife Eleanor Fischer, and her sisters, Kathryn Mos eley Davis and her husband Lou Davis, Helen Fischer, Joan Fischer Popylisen and her husband Daniel Popylisen, and Claire Fischer Adilet ta and her husband Joseph Adiletta, and by her nieces, nephews, g randnieces and nephews and friends. The family will receive visitors at Gannon's Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, NY, NY on May 10 from 2:00PM to 5:00PM and 7:00PM to 9:00PM. Mary's life will be celebrated in a funeral Mass at Epiphany Church on May 11, at 10:00AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in her name to the Ralph and Mary Bell Scholarship Fund, t he College of New Rochelle, New Rochelle, New York 10805.

title: A Place to Rest Her Head
description: Chance cannot be underestimated. In 1996, Imbisat Usman, below right, a professor of literature in Lahore, Pakistan, wanted a new career so she could stay home with her newborn daughter. She met a rickshaw driver who had lost a job embroidering badges for college blazers. She hired him, and 24 others, to make her designs of embroidered silk pillows and throws for her company in Lahore, Rano's Heirlooms. The staff hand-embroiders pillows 14 inches square to 24 by 15 inches ($115 to $225) and 30-by-36-inch wall hangings ($750). By appointment with Amber Sami at (212) 924-5312. ELAINE LOUIE

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: Lieutenant Governor Stays In The Race
description: Virginia's lieutenant governor, John H. Hager, left, says he will not give up his race for the Republican nomination for governor. Many party leaders believe Attorney General Mark L. Earley is too far ahead. In the fall contest, party leaders contend, Mr. Earley would have a better shot at beating the Democratic nominee, Mark R. Warner, a businessman who four years ago almost upset Senator John W. Warner. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: House Rejects Darwin Resolution
description: The State House refused to pass a resolution calling Charles Darwin and his theories racist. Supporters said Darwin's theories advocated the notion of superior and inferior races. But opponents said the resolution was an indirect way to support creationism, and the governor's office said the inevitable ridicule would be bad for business. The House approved a resolution condemning racism and the idea of superior races, with no mention of Darwin or evolution. David Firestone (NYT)

title: G.E. PROJECTS BIGGER SAVINGS FROM HONEYWELL
description: Profit at General Electric this year will be at the upper end of its projections, and the company probably will save more from the planned purchase of Honeywell International Inc. than forecast, G.E.'s president, Jeffrey R. Immelt, said yesterday. Mr. Immelt said G.E. would have profit ''solidly above'' $1.45 a share. The company initially forecast a range of $1.40 to $1.50. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call project a profit of $1.47 a share. Mr. Immelt spoke in Florida at a conference sponsored by a group of equity analysts called the Electrical Products Group. He also gave details about the business combinations of the Honeywell acquisition, which will merge products and services in aerospace, industrial controls, chemicals and power systems. That transaction has been tentatively approved by the Justice Department and is being reviewed by European regulators.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Photographer Wins Settlement
description: A photographer who has been arrested repeatedly for taking pictures of groups of nude people in public places will receive a settlement from the city, his lawyer, Ronald L. Kuby, said yesterday. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan awarded the photographer, Spencer Tunick, above, $33,368.75 for his legal fees. After a court battle last June in which the city appealed unsuccessfully to the United States Supreme Court, Mr. Tunick won the right to photograph nudes in public. Since then he has completed several sessions without interference, Mr. Kuby said. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

Ms. Swift, 36, is almost eight months pregnant with twins, and was confined to hospital bed rest on Tuesday because she was experiencing contractions every six or seven minutes, her doctor said. She is expected to give birth within days. Ms. Swift will be the first governor to give birth while in office. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Home Movies Starring the Cute Beatle
description: If you didn't know who the interviewer was sitting opposite Paul McCartney in the two-hour documentary ''Wingspan,'' tomorrow night on ABC, you might write her off as a typical entertainment-media sycophant.

title: Boy Accused of Killing Teacher Is Cross-Examined
description: A 14-year-old boy charged with shooting his teacher to death stayed calm under pointed cross-examination from a prosecutor today. But when given the murder weapon on the witness stand, he admitted that he could not show how it had gone off accidentally, as he had contended.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Northrop Grumman is short of details but long on defenses of its bid for Newport News.
description: EXECUTIVES from the Northrop Grumman Corporation began explaining and defending the company's hostile $2.1 billion bid for Newport News Shipbuilding yesterday. But as of the close of business, the company had yet to make details of the offer available to the company it intends to wrest away from the General Dynamics Corporation, which agreed last month to buy Newport News for the same price in cash.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Charles L. Black Jr., an authority on the law and history of impeachment, misidentified the final arbiter in the battle for White House tape recordings that President Richard M. Nixon had refused to surrender to Watergate prosecutors. It was the Supreme Court, not merely a judge, who ruled against the president's claim of executive privilege.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRATT, RICHARDSON, JR.
description: PRATT-Richardson, Jr. A memorial service to commemorate the life of Richardson (Jerry) Pratt, J r. will be held on Monday, May 21, 2001 at 11:30 AM at Old First Presbyterian Church, 125 Main St., Huntington, NY. For directions , call 631-427-2101. In lieu of flowers the Richardson Pratt, Jr. Scholarsh ip Fund has been established at Pratt Institute, 200 Willoughby A ve., Brooklyn, NY 11205.

title: Yanks' Morales Clears Waivers
description: Andy Morales, a third baseman from Cuba who signed a four-year, $4.4 million contract with the Yankees on March 11, has cleared waivers and was sent outright back to Class AA Norwich yesterday.

title: Dumbo Stands for Offbeat Furniture Heaven
description: THE slice of Brooklyn waterfront known as Dumbo (''down under the Manhattan Bridge overpass'') sits between the Manhattan and Brooklyn bridges, with 19th-century red-brick warehouses and streets paved with Belgian blocks. Today, the buildings are home to artists, furniture designers, upholsterers and metalworkers. ''The neighborhood is a real powerhouse of creativity,'' said Pedro Kornbluth, who publishes Dumbo Direct, a neighborhood guide (www.dumbodirect

title: Council Legalizes Ferrets, but Veto Is Expected From Giuliani
description: Ferrets, rejoice.

title: A Masterful Clemens Nibbles at a No-Hitter
description: Roger Clemens's evening of dominance appeared over when Manager Joe Torre approached the mound in the eighth inning last night at Yankee Stadium. Clemens's 114th pitch had just been slapped to center by the Minnesota Twins' Cristian Guzman after a seven-pitch at-bat.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Con Artist Database
description: New York State has begun building a central database of ''itinerant scam artists'' who travel from one city or town to another to swindle residents through fraudulent home-repair or sales schemes, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said yesterday. He said the statewide data repository would permit local police forces and prosecutors to increase their efforts against the con artists by sharing information gleaned about them from their victims -- many of whom are elderly and live alone -- in various parts of the state. Some victims find that not only have they been defrauded in the repair or sales transactions, but the swindlers have also stolen valuables from their homes. These traveling ''work crews'' and ''sales people'' especially proliferate in spring, said a spokeswoman for Mr. Spitzer, Christine Pritchard. She said the database was designed for law-enforcement agencies and would not be available to the public.

title: Mexico's Leader Is Finding the Democratic Road Bumpy
description: Five months into his term as the first opposition president of Mexico in 71 years, Vicente Fox is learning that presidencies made by democracy can also be battered by them.

title: Missing Game 7 Because of Headache
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 9  Recurring headaches forced Scott Niedermayer to sit out the Devils' 5-1 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in Game 7 of their series tonight. Niedermayer's head began aching Tuesday evening, hours after he skated in practice. Today, after participating in the Devils' morning skate, Niedermayer had another headache.

title: ATLANTA COMPANY TO DEVELOP APARTMENTS IN NEW YORK
description: Post Properties Inc., a real estate investment trust, is planning to develop three apartment buildings in New York City, including one high- rise just north of Times Square, company officials said. The company, based in Atlanta, and its partners are working on a 330-unit luxury tower at 51st Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, a 140-unit project at 23rd Street and First Avenue, and a 185-unit tower at 89th Street and First Avenue, David Stockert, the president of Post, said during a conference call yesterday with analysts and investors. Analysts at Merrill Lynch estimated development costs at about $225 million. Post plans to start looking for financing soon and begin construction later this year, Mr. Stockert said.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Storrs: Students Protest for Janitors
description: Students at the University of Connecticut held a protest yesterday to urge the school to raise the wages of its janitors. The students protested inside the main administration building while others camped overnight out front. Philip Austin, president of the university, praised the students for showing concern for others. The demonstration came a day after 30 Harvard students ended a three-week sit-in in which they demanded that all of Harvard's janitors and food workers be paid a ''living wage.'' Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Seething in Traffic, in Search of an Exit
description: To the Editor:

title: Economists Say Recession Is Unlikely
description: Business economists still say they believe that the United States will probably avoid recession this year, a quarterly survey released today found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, GWENDOLYN
description: SAUNDERS - Gwendolyn. Born May 21, 1915 near Adelaide, Australia, the daug hter of Augusta Wilhelmina Nossenheim of Saal, Germany and Arthur Saunders of Aberdeen, Scotland, Gwendolyn & her widowed mother ar rived in Brooklyn in early 1918. A graduate of Brooklyn College, she worked as a legal secretary at the law firms of Webster Sheffield Fleischmann Hitchcock and Chrystie, Bangser Klein Rocca and Blu m and Rogers and Wells. She is fondly remembered by her many friends and former associates. Visitation will be on Thursday, 2-5 an d 7-9 PM at the Herbst-Trzaska Waldeck Chapels, 7614 - 4th Avenue , Brooklyn, NY. Attended valet parking. Funeral services will be o n Friday 11:30 AM at Redeemer-St. John's Lutheran Church, 939-83 St., Brooklyn, NY. Interment Greenwood Cemetery.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We like living here. It's a beautiful place. The only thing we don't like, you can't make any money to survive. My son is getting straight A's. He's not going to be around here.''

title: Annan in Washington to Seek AIDS Funds
description: Against a background of rising anger in Congress over the loss of American seats on two United Nations panels, Secretary General Kofi Annan went to Washington today to ask the Bush administration for more money to fight AIDS in Africa.

title: Nintendo Grows Up and Goes for the Gross-Out
description: CONKER the squirrel, the title character in a new Nintendo game, is having a terrible day or, as he puts it, a bad fur day. It all began with a few too many drinks at the local saloon. After throwing up outside the bar, Conker heads through the darkness until he comes to a sign that points in two directions, Naughty and Nice. ''Emmm,'' Conker slurs, teetering down the Naughty path, ''this way, I suppose.''

title: Parrying CNN, CNBC Plans To Augment 'Business Center'
description: The cable business-news war between CNN and CNBC is about to intensify.

title: Board Allows Rent Increases Of 3 and 5%
description: The New York City Rent Guidelines Board voted last night for increases of 3 percent for one-year lease renewals and 5 percent for two-year renewals for the 2.3 million residents of rent-stabilized apartments, matching what Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had sought. The board at first voted for bigger increases before abruptly reversing itself.

title: The Next Mayor's Education Agenda
description: Polls show that New York City voters rank education at the top of their issues list this year. It should therefore come as no surprise that so do the candidates who hope to succeed Rudolph Giuliani as mayor. The city has 1.1 million public-school students, many with parents who vote. But plenty of people who do not have children in the public schools are no less concerned about the sad state of those schools. This broad interest in better schools offers the mayoral candidates an unusual opportunity to wrestle with a problem that looks as intractable today as the city's crime rate appeared to be a few years ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CPI AEROSTRUCTURES INC., Edgewood, N.Y., a maker of aircraft parts and electronics, won a 10-year contract valued at more than $60.8 million from the Air Force as it replaces engines on more than 500 jets.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: General Warns President
description: The army chief of staff, Gen. Endriartono Sutarto, who has criticized President Abdurrahman Wahid in the past, warned him not to dissolve Parliament as a way of evading possible impeachment proceedings. Mr. Wahid told reporters he had no intention of doing so, despite widespread rumors. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Livery Driver Killed
description: A woman driving a livery cab in the Bronx was shot and killed early yesterday morning, becoming the city's first female livery driver to be killed on the job. The police said the driver, Anlidva Brown, 32, a mother of two who lived with her children in Soundview, was shot north of Co-op City at the intersection of Steenwick and Hollers Avenues, minutes after being dispatched at 12:46 a.m. by her employer, the Monaco Cab Company. The driver had pressed the danger signal, which sets off a blinking yellow light at the front and back of the car to alert the police, said Fernando Mateo, president of the New York State Federation of Taxi Drivers, which represents mainly livery drivers. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: An Uncanny Tale: Hampton Shuts Out the Mets
description: When the Mets traded for Mike Hampton two winters ago, they were asked to do something extraordinary, to overwhelm him with a contract offer. The Mets waited.

title: Court Theatrics Abound At a Murder Sentencing
description: It was supposed to be a sentencing hearing, but it turned into a circus.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: ICQ Reaches 100 Million Members
description: ICQ, the popular instant-messaging service owned by AOL Time Warner, said it had reached 100 million registered users worldwide. Since its acquisition by AOL in 1998, ICQ's user base has grown tenfold; two-thirds of its users live outside the United States. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Suits Accuse Drug Makers of Keeping Generics Off Market
description: In the latest challenge to the efforts of drug companies to block the sale of many generic drugs, a coalition of 17 consumer groups filed several lawsuits yesterday against Barr Laboratories and AstraZeneca, charging that the companies illegally kept a generic version of an important breast cancer drug off the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAEMMERLI, ALFRED (FRED)
description: HAEMMERLI-Alfred (Fred) . Beloved husband of Alice and father of Justine, son of Ursula, brothe r of Peter Michael, Monique and Christine. A devoted member of the United Nations community who worked tirelessly & selflessly for the goo d of others. Faithful, funny and kind, he epitomized grace, dignity and courage to the end. Memorial services Friday, May 11th, 11 AM, Marble C ollegiate Church, 29 St and 5th Ave, & May 17th, 12:30PM at the Church Center of the United Nations. We love you, Fredy.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Red Cross Pilot Killed
description: One pilot of a small plane was killed over southern Sudan when the plane, clearly marked with the symbol of the International Committee of the Red Cross, was fired on. The victim was a 26-year-old Dane, Ole Friis Eriksen; the co-pilot, who was not injured, landed the plane safely in Kenya. It was unclear whether the twin-engine plane was shot at by rebels fighting the government or the government itself, which has bombed Red Cross planes on the ground three times in the last year. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Agencies Named For Accounts
description: Agencies have been named to handle accounts.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Warrant Out For Former Governor
description: An arrest warrant has been issued for Laloo Prasad Yadav, the former chief minister of the state of Bihar. The colorful political maverick said he would surrender by May 22 to face charges in the huge embezzlement case that has dogged him since 1996. In 1997, he stepped down from Bihar's top post and installed his wife, Rabri Devi, as chief minister. The arrest warrant does not permit bail. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: A Telltale Clue
description: To the Editor:

title: Ad Revenue Drops At Magazines
description: In another sign of the effect of the weakening economy on advertising and the media, the Publishers Information Bureau in New York reported yesterday that ad revenue in magazines declined in April compared with figures in the month a year earlier.

title: A Lifeline, With Conditions
description: Locked in a costly lawsuit with a big pharmaceutical company, Igen International was within a few months of running out of cash earlier this year. And with biotechnology stocks falling, there seemed little chance of raising money by selling more shares to the public.

title: Bit by Bit, Tiny Morland, Kan., Fades Away
description: As a lawyer in this little town, Jerry Helberg does just about everything. He settles estates, writes contracts and wills, prepares tax returns and handles the rare small crime. Mr. Helberg is Morland's only lawyer. At 63, he is also probably its last, for this town is getting smaller by the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, GEORGE
description: ADAMS-George, 83 years o ld. Of Ridge, NY. Served in World War II WOJG. Survived by wife Vita, daughters Sue and Lorraine and sons James and Thomas. Funeral mass St. Anthony's, Ridge, New York, Friday, May 11.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Carmaker Turns A Profit
description: The bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company said it had earned an operating profit of 6.7 billion won ($5.1 million) in April, its first monthly profit since June 1998. Cost savings from laying off 7,000 workers, one-third of its work force, over the last year and from a matching cut in production were mainly responsible, the company said, adding that it hoped the improved results would help it complete a deal to be acquired by General Motors. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: In America; Mr. Ferrer's Dilemma
description: So here's what must be racing through Fernando Ferrer's mind: ''With friends like Al Sharpton . . .''

title: An Irresponsible Budget Plan
description: After several days of backroom negotiations, the House approved a federal budget plan yesterday that is a model of fiscal evasion and irresponsibility. The tax cut of $1.35 trillion, to be spread out over 11 years, is lower than the original proposal by President Bush but still so large that it wipes out resources for vital domestic spending programs. Mr. Bush and the Republican leadership assert that there is plenty of money for domestic needs, but their claims are belied by the embarrassing fact that this budget does not even provide the money on the spending side that Mr. Bush sought for education and health research. If Congress wants to come up with funds for these areas, it will have to find the money by cutting even more elsewhere.

title: Pataki Auto Insurance Plan Seeks Ways to Reduce Rates
description: The Pataki administration proposed wide-ranging changes in New York's auto insurance rules today, aiming to reduce costs just as the state is poised to earn the unwanted distinction of having the nation's highest rates.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Israeli Boys Killed

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: $100 Million To Fight Malaria
description: An anonymous donor has pledged $100 million to Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore to help develop antimalarial drugs and vaccines. The gift, the largest in the university's history for a single purpose, is to be spent over 10 years, mainly to hire researchers to combine traditional approaches with newer fields like genomics. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Westchester Executive Urges Law Banning Racial Profiling
description: Vowing to keep Westchester from experiencing a problem that has troubled New Jersey, Andrew J. Spano, the county executive, proposed legislation today that would require more strict monitoring of traffic stops by the county police to prevent racial profiling.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Drug Maker Profits
description: Strong demand for its drugs in the United States, in part to replenish depleted inventories, helped lift first-quarter net profit at the French-German drug giant Aventis by 64 percent, to 306 million euros ($270 million), on a 12 percent revenue increase, to 4.1 billion euros. Shares in Aventis rose almost 4 percent on the news. Pierre Langlois, the chief financial officer, attributed growth in the United States, where drug sales rose almost 37 percent, in part to ''lower inventory levels in wholesale distribution channels at the end of 2000.'' John Tagliabue (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, DR. JOSEPH
description: JACOBS-Dr. Joseph. American Friends of The Hebrew Uni versity is deeply saddened by the passing of our dear Board of Dir ectors Member and Guardian, Dr. Joseph Jacobs. A prominent dentist and tireless campaigner to improve Israel's dental care facilities , Joe was instrumental in the development of The Hebrew University-Hadassah School of Dental Medicine and the D. Walter Cohen Middle East Center for Dental Education. He also served as a Governor of The Hebrew University, Vice President of the AFHU Western Region and Chairman of the AFHU Dental Division. For his wa rm friendship and firm commitment toward The Hebrew Universit y of Jerusalem, he was named an Honorary Fellow. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Benita, their children Renae Jacob s and David Anson and Ehren and Gaye Jacobs, their grandchildre n, and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew Un iversity Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice Pre sident

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: One More Winter Run

title: NTT DoCoMo Reports Strong Earnings
description: Riding a sustained boom for mobile communication services, NTT DoCoMo, Japan's biggest cellular phone operator, reported strong earnings today that exceeded many analysts' projections.

title: People
description: * Brad Bennett, new-business director at Mullen/LHC, Winston-Salem, N.C., the Winston-Salem office of Mullen, was named to the new post of senior vice president and marketing director, overseeing new-business development and marketing for the Mullen offices in Winston-Salem; Wenham, Mass.; and Detroit. Mullen is part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, JOHN J.
description: LEE-John J. Loving husband of Gayle K. Lee, and father of Jocelyn, Lauren, John and Roger. Adoring grandfathe r to Aidan, Jack, Austin, Simon and Isabelle. Loving brother to Robe rt Lee. Memorial service to be held at St. John's Church in Larch mont, on Friday, May 11, at 11 AM, with reception at the Larchmont Yacht Club to follow. Family will receive visitors on Saturday and Sun day, from 1-5 PM, May 12 and 13, at Mrs. Lee's home in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to either of the following: Cancer Research Foundation, c/o Dr. Janice Dutcher, 640 W. 239th St, Riverdale, NY 10463; or, the Cancer Support Team, 933 Mama roneck Ave, Suite 102, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

title: M.I.T. Official Is Chosen to Be the President of Tufts
description: Lawrence S. Bacow, chancellor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an architect of its research partnership with the University of Cambridge in England, was appointed president of Tufts University yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCANLON, JOHN P.
description: SCANLON-John P. Concern Worldwide, the international reli ef organization, expresses its deepest regret at the death of our dear friend, humanitarian and patron. Our sincerest sympathy to his wife Jul ienne, family and friends. Our profound gratitude to John for his selfles s work helping to establish Concern in the U.S. His tireless efforts, rall ying support for ''Seeds of Hope'', our annual fundraising event, saved thousands of lives. The many who have survived famine and suffer ing remain living memorials to a great man. Concern Worldwide, New York

title: Families of Chechnya's Disappeared Seek Answers
description: The families of those who have disappeared and are disappearing -- in Chechnya can be seen keeping vigil outside Russia's military prisons and police stations, showing photos to those who enter.

title: Bridging Time and an Ocean, A Couple's Influence Spreads
description: The designers Robin and Lucienne Day are as unsung in America as they are celebrated in Britain, most recently with an exhibition at the Barbican Gallery in London. The show's curator, Lesley Jackson, has written a new book, ''Robin and Lucienne Day: Pioneers of Modern Design'' (Princeton Architectural Press; $50), that could change that. Married in 1942, the Days, left, have been called England's version of the Eameses. Their own belief in the power of good design produced 60 influential years of simple, sophisticated furniture, fabrics, ceramics and interiors, including Mr. Day's polypropylene armchair of 1967 and Ms. Day's Fall, a fine-leaf-patterned fabric of 1952 (both below). Several of their designs, old and new, are available in London at twentytwentyone (www.twentytwentyone.com) and Habitat (www .habitat.co.uk). WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: Missiles and Treaties in the Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Takeover Speculator to Pay $450,000 to Settle With S.E.C.
description: Guy P. Wyser-Pratte, a well-known speculator in takeover stocks, agreed yesterday that he and the two companies he runs would pay $450,000 to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle charges that his companies did not have adequate safeguards to prevent insider trading.

title: Blacks Found on Short End Of Heart Attack Procedure
description: Black heart attack patients are far less likely than whites to undergo the common and potentially life-saving procedure known as cardiac catheterization, regardless of the race of their doctors, researchers at Yale University said yesterday.

title: All Couplets, All the Way, In a Molire Manqu
description: With only a few exceptions, the French theater after Molire did not produce many candidates for the pantheon of playwrights until the absurdists came along. Jean-Franois Regnard was not one of the exceptions, and a somewhat static revival of his last play, ''A Will of His Own,'' by the Pearl Theater Company shows why.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Budget Airline
description: Despite increases in sales, passengers and Internet bookings, EasyJet, a British airline for budget travelers to European destinations, said its first-half net loss widened to $14.6 million, five times that of a year earlier, because of higher fuel prices and the cost of new aircraft. EasyJet, the Continent's second-largest low-cost airline, said its losses included exceptional charges of $4.7 million. Sales rose 43 percent, to $203 million, and its passenger load rose 31 percent, to 3.2 million. Sales on the company's Web site accounted for 85.6 percent of the total, compared with 59.6 percent a year earlier. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Western Governors Turn Focus to Need for More Power Lines
description: Saying the nation had failed to build enough transmission lines to satisfy soaring energy demands, the Western Governors' Association took steps today to figure out -- quickly -- how to build new power lines across the region.

title: Passaic Firefighter Dies in Mistaken Rescue
description: A firefighter responding to reports that a mother and two children were trapped in a burning building in Passaic, N.J., died yesterday when a roof collapsed on him, officials said.

title: Digital Storage: Computer Age Gets a Valhalla
description: TWELVE years ago, Keith Uncapher, a computer scientist at the RAND Corporation, was shocked to discover that the Johnniac, a behemoth of a computer he had helped develop in the 1950's, had been left out to rust in a parking lot behind the Museum of Science and Industry in Los Angeles.

title: This Time, It's Iverson's Turn to Light the Fire
description: Allen Iverson rocked to a rhythm only he could feel tonight: stopping and popping, fading away to find twine, slashing with brash assurance and finishing with soft finger-rolls. Iverson, the smallest player on the court at 6 feet tall, created an electrical storm every time he touched the ball.

title: The Hard Part to Come, Murdoch Beats Forecasts
description: Weathering a weak advertising market and a Hollywood flop, the News Corporation, the Australian-based media conglomerate, announced yesterday that its earnings fell sharply in the most recent quarter.

title: Officer Suspected of Cover-Up in Killing
description: A federal grand jury in Manhattan is investigating whether a city police detective tampered with evidence to help cover up his cousin's role in a 1998 mob killing on the Brooklyn waterfront, officials said.

title: Labor Abuses In El Salvador Are Detailed In Document
description: A long-suppressed report by the Salvadoran government, made public yesterday by an American labor rights group, spelled out serious problems in the country's apparel factories, including unhealthy air and water, large amounts of forced overtime and the frequent dismissal of workers who supported labor unions.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Gang Members Linked To 1969 Killing
description: Two former members of a white street gang in York were accused of criminal homicide in the shooting death of a black woman 32 years ago, prosecutors announced as they continued their inquiry into two unsolved 1969 shooting deaths. Rick Lynn Knouse, 48, and Gregory Harry Neff, 53, identified as former members of the Girarders gang, were accused of firing at a car carrying the woman, Lillie Belle Allen. Two members of another white gang, Robert Messersmith, 52, and Arthur Messersmith, 47, were charged two weeks ago in the homicide, with seven more indictments pending in the death of Ms. Allen and the fatal shooting of a white police officer, Henry Schaad. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: A Mournful Balladeer Squares Off With Her Muse
description: Erstwhile flower children and other fans of Laura Nyro, the ardent balladeer of the 1960's and 70's, will find much to cheer in ''Eli's Comin','' the stage celebration of her work that opened this week at the Vineyard Theater. Its strengths include four vivid singers led by the ever appealing Judy Kuhn, a tight five-man band that moves easily around Nyro's eclectic idiom and assured arrangements by Diedre Murray.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Andrew Lack as president and chief operating officer of NBC misidentified the longest-serving president in broadcast television. He was Frank Stanton, who headed CBS for 25 years, from 1946 to 1971; Bob Wright, Mr. Lack's predecessor, served for 15 years.

title: U. of Virginia Hit by Scandal Over Cheating
description: As they have for 160 years, students at the University of Virginia took their final exams unsupervised today, despite a cheating scandal that has shaken the campus.

title: Marie Jahoda, 94; Studied Work and Women
description: Marie Jahoda, one of the world's foremost social psychologists and an emeritus professor at the University of Sussex, died on April 28 at her home in Keymer, in southeast England. Dr. Jahoda, who taught at New York University in the 1950's, was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSCHENBAUM, PETER
description: KIRSCHENBAUM-Peter, 65. Of New City, NY, di ed on May 3, 2001. Devoted husband, father and grandfather.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLEHER, AGNES P.
description: KELLEHER-Agnes P. Of Bro nxville, NY, on May 9, 2001. Beloved sister of Miriam Kelleher and Fr. William A. Kelleher. Ms. Kelleher was a retiree of Union Carbide C orporation NYC. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral H ome, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday, May 11, 10AM. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Privacy and the C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: City Clothing Bank Manager Charged in Fraud
description: A top official at the city Clothing Bank, which distributes apparel to the needy and homeless, was arrested yesterday for taking cash payoffs from an undercover investigator who said he wanted to divert $9,000 worth of donated clothes and merchandise to bogus charities, officials said.

title: For All Their Woes, the Yankees Are in the Hunt
description: Derek Jeter's right shoulder glistened after another round of treatment for pain that will not cease. Jorge Posada lugged enough ice atop his right shoulder to make snow cones for everyone in the clubhouse. Bernie Williams stared at the lineup card for about 30 seconds to digest the fact that he was not batting cleanup. Orlando Hernndez told Manager Joe Torre that he felt uncomfortable because he had not won yet.

title: Ferrer Refuses Endorsement Linked to Race
description: Fernando Ferrer last night rejected a demand from the Rev. Al Sharpton that he pledge to endorse black candidates for two specific city offices as a condition for winning Mr. Sharpton's backing for his mayoral bid. Mr. Ferrer said that while he eagerly wanted Mr. Sharpton's support, he would not make endorsements based on race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, JESSIE I.
description: KURZ-Jessie I. A beloved aunt to countless nieces and nephews, devoted wife of the late Aaron Kurz, and a friend to all with whom she came in contact, Jessie I. Kurz passed away on May 8, 2001, at the age of 97. Mrs. Kurz, affectionately known by everyone as just ''Aunt Jessie,'' was a pioneer in psychoanalysis a nd a contributor to many worthy causes. Those of us who knew her will always treasure her warmth, sensitivity, practicality and unde rstanding. The celebration of her life and teachings will resonate so undly through generations of family and friends as we all describe to our children what we learned from this truly remarkable, inspr ing person. Contributions may be made in her name to the Alzh eimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association Inc. NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10017.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Illegal Tide From Africa
description: The police have detained more than 200 illegal immigrants in the past two days, mostly sub-Saharan Africans who set sail from Morocco and took advantage of improved weather in the treacherous Strait of Gibraltar. At dawn yesterday, 77 illegal immigrants, including a 4-month-old baby and a pregnant woman, were intercepted. On Tuesday, the police caught 165 people trying to land in several small boats, one of which overturned close to shore. At least one Moroccan man was drowned. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: In Throes of Passion, A Sniper Is Born
description: THE green clock haunts me still. Night after night I lie awake and replay the chain of tragic events that led me to love a green Art Deco kitchen clock -- and to lose it -- when the clock went on sale on eBay a couple of weeks ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the killing of a 4-month old Palestinian girl misstated her given name. She was Iman Hajo, not Imam.

title: Senate Passes Budget to Set Foundation for Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, May 10 -- A budget plan close to what President Bush proposed won final Congressional approval today, clearing the way for the first big tax cut in 20 years.

title: Momma's Little Kitchen Helper

And like a toy, it has a whimsical name, the Can Can can opener. '' 'Can can,' in the Italian language, means something like confusion, like a jam session, where different persons play different instruments,'' he said. Like Alabama, Mississippi has been pressured by court orders to ease crowding in state prisons. But in Jackson the inmates released were awaiting trial. Mr. McMillin said the suspects needed to be moved through the court system more quickly or they would have to be housed in tents or released from jail. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | News On Old News Building
description: The sale of the landmark Art Deco skyscraper on 42nd Street that once housed The Daily News is drawing to a close. According to real estate executives, the owners of the 37-story, 1.1-million-square-foot building at 220 East 42nd Street recently winnowed the list of bidders to three, including Aby Rosen and SL Green, a real estate investment trust based in Manhattan. The skyscraper was something of a success story for its owners, Steven C. Witkoff and Dreyfus Realty Advisors. Mr. Witkoff bought the tower in 1996 for $101 million, after The Daily News moved out. He quickly signed a lease with Omnicom for most of the vacant space in the building, enabling him to get a $140 million mortgage for the property. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Rahman Postpones Decision
description: Hasim Rahman, the World Boxing Council and International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion, has delayed his decision on whom to fight in his first title defense and may not make up his mind for several days or more. The convicts are among 148 sex offenders who were civilly committed after serving prison sentences. Some closed-circuit television cameras will not be installed until next week, said a corrections spokeswoman, Deirdre Fedkenheuer. But she said roaming guards and electrified fences would ensure security in the meantime. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

description: Charles Dutoit was on the podium at Avery Fisher Hall last Thursday evening to lead the New York Philharmonic in his specialties -- evocative, pictorial works by Debussy and Ravel -- as well as a performance of Beethoven's Second Piano Concerto with Martha Argerich as the soloist. Also on the program was the latest installment of what the Philharmonic is calling an Arnold Schoenberg celebration, in honor of the 50th anniversary of the composer's death.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Guilty On Fraud Charge
description: Rambus Inc., which develops memory-chip technology, was found guilty by a federal civil court jury of fraud for using information from an industry standards group to obtain patents. Rambus filed suit in September against Infineon Technologies, a German chip maker, charging patent infringement and seeking royalties for using its technology; Infineon countersued. The jury awarded Infineon $3.5 million in damages. But a United States District Court judge in Richmond, Va., reduced the jury award to $350,000, the maximum permitted in the state, and threw out Rambus's patent claims. Geoff Tate, chief executive of Rambus, said it would appeal the decision.

title: Elias Goes to the Front of the Line
description: Patrik Elias bristled at the widespread notion that his center, Jason Arnott, is the catalyst of the Devils' A line.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Video Gambling Bills Killed
description: Video gambling legislation appears dead after three bills -- one to limit the location and payoffs of the machines, one to tax them and one to ban them -- were removed from consideration in the State House five days before the session's end. A measure approved by the Senate last week would have closed adult video arcades, concentrated video gambling at the state's dog tracks and limited payouts to $5 in coupons. Dana Byerele (NYT)

title: Torre Feels Reassured on Hernndez's Health
description: Yankee Manager Joe Torre spoke briefly with the struggling Orlando Hernandez yesterday without the aid of an interpreter and, through the language barrier, was confident that Hernandez's elbow was not bothering him. Torre said his mind was more at ease than on Tuesday night, when he watched Hernandez allow two runs in six shaky innings of a 2-0 loss to the Twins. Hernandez fell to 0-4 and has a 4.97 earned run average.

title: European Central Bank Surprises Markets With Rate Cut
description: LEIPZIG, Germany, May 10  Having insisted for months that Europe had no need to join the rest of the world in easing up on monetary policy, the European Central Bank baffled investors today by reversing course and reducing interest rates without any advance warning.

title: Agreement on a Tougher Drunken-Driving Standard
description: For the first time, the leaders of both the Assembly and the State Senate have endorsed lowering the level of alcohol in the bloodstream required for one to be charged with drunken driving.

title: Morton Klein, 75, Industrial Engineering Professor
description: Morton Klein, a professor of industrial engineering at Columbia University who did pioneering work in the field of operations research, a discipline that applies mathematics to complex management problems, died on April 26 after collapsing in his office on campus. He was 75 and lived in Haworth, N.J.

The series was written and presented by Michael Wood, based on his book of the same name; produced by Rebecca Dobbs; and directed by David Wallace. The executive producers were Leo Eaton for PBS and Laurence Rees for the BBC; the editors were Gerry Branigan and Chris Lysaght; Peter Harvey was responsible for the photography and Howard Davidson for the music. title: Metro Business Briefing | Less Capital Ventured
description: Venture capital invested in companies in the New York City region dipped to its lowest level in six fiscal quarters, according to the MoneyTree report released yesterday by PricewaterhouseCoopers. In the first quarter of 2001, $875 million in venture capital was invested in the region, compared with $2.5 billion in venture capital invested in the first quarter of 2000. The drop represents a 65 percent decline. The last quarter the numbers were that low was in the third quarter of 1999, when $760 million was invested in companies in the region. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Dutch Bank Says Profit Is Down 12%
description: Feeling the squeeze from a steep decline in commissions generated from selling and trading stocks, ABN Amro said today that its profit slumped 12 percent in the first quarter, and warned that it might not meet forecasts for the remainder of the year.

title: World Briefing | The World: Survey Counts More Than 400 N-Plants
description: A survey by the International Atomic Energy Agency found that there are now 438 nuclear power stations operating around the world, producing 16 percent of global energy needs. Another 31 reactors are being constructed. France and Lithuania are most dependent on nuclear power, with reactors supplying about three-quarters of their needs. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Foot-and-Mouth Vaccination Ordered
description: The government announced that it will require the vaccination of all cattle in the country's southernmost state, Rio Grande do Sul, after foot-and-mouth disease was found there in a herd less than two miles from the border with Uruguay, where an outbreak was discovered last month. Brazil has the world's largest commercial cattle herd, 167 million head, and has sent troops to the southern border to prevent infected cattle from being smuggled into the country. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: The Declining Support For Executions
description: Rising public opposition to the death penalty has been one of the few liberal social trends in recent years. But there is some reason to wonder whether the public's overwhelming enthusiasm for executing Timothy McVeigh will stall or possibly reverse this development. Every nationwide poll taken has found the vast majority of Americans favoring the execution, scheduled for May 16. This comes at a time when the same nationwide surveys are finding diminishing support for capital punishment since the early 1990's. The Pew Center's polls show backing for the death penalty slipping to 66 percent this year from a high of 80 percent in 1994. But our most recent survey also finds 75 percent favoring Timothy McVeigh's execution.

title: Economic Scene; Lest we forget: each generation has its own 'new economy.'
description: EVER since high-technology stocks began to plummet last spring, the press has become increasingly disillusioned with the ''new economy.'' But this was always a loosely defined concept. As The Economist wrote in 1999, the stunning economic boom of the late 1990's needed a ''very big idea'' to explain it. The press, Wall Street and a handful of influential authors rushed to fill the void.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: EquaL Opportunity Throne?
description: Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, said he would support changes in the law governing imperial succession to allow a woman to ascend to the throne and become empress. His statement was echoed by Japan's leading opposition party, suggesting easy passage of legislation to change the so-called Imperial Household Law, which dates to 1947 and permits only emperors. But the political comeback of Silvio Berlusconi, the media tycoon and target of numerous criminal investigations, is a sign of just how deep that cynicism now runs. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Banks To Beef Up Capital
description: The central bank governor, Dai Xianglong, said China would bring all four of its major state-owned banks up to international minimum capital standards by the end of 2001. He did not say how the recapitalization would be accomplished. Of the four -- the Bank of China, the Agricultural Bank of China, the China Construction Bank and the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China -- only the Bank of China listed in its most recent annual report a capital adequacy ratio greater than 8 percent, the minimum set by the Bank for International Settlements. description: Strongly defending the way in which the Chrysler Corporation became a German-run subsidiary, DaimlerChrysler A.G. filed a motion today to dismiss a lawsuit by Kirk Kerkorian, the corporate raider who tried to buy Chrysler nearly six years ago.

title: Excesses of Hoboken's Success Helped Defeat Mayor
description: For some voters, it may have been Mayor Anthony Russo's strong-handed style. Others may have had concerns about his health, after his bouts with a brain tumor and lung cancer. And nearly everyone seemed to have an opinion about the mayor's aborted plan last month to keep out-of-towners from driving through the city on their way elsewhere.

title: Spearheading a Marketing Makeover at Avon
description: TRADITION has it that the Avon Lady rings your doorbell with a smiling face, comes to visit on your turf and terms. But that's not quite the way it works with the head Avon Lady, Andrea Jung. Here we are on her turf, the hushed 27th floor of the Avenue of the Americas skyscraper that serves as global headquarters of Avon Products Inc., the 115-year-old cosmetics heirloom she's hustled ever deeper into makeover mode since her installation 18 months ago as chief executive.

title: At 20, Fisher Appreciates Her 2nd Indianapolis Bid
description: Last year, Sarah Fisher was too busy trying to qualify for her first Indianapolis 500 to fully appreciate the milestones she had to tiptoe across to get there. Too busy to enjoy what it was like to be only 19 and starting in one of auto racing's most prestigious events. Too caught up in the news media swirl that engulfed the third and youngest woman to race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway to savor the track's history and tradition.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Trinidad Leaves Careers in His Wake
description: Felix Trinidad's career has been like one of his fights -- little guile, little glitz -- simply an unrelenting march forward. He has been an undefeated champion for eight years now, a tank churning through the weight classes: welterweights, super-welterweights, junior middleweights, and next up, the middleweights.

title: Divorce Under One Roof
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Seeks Candidate Law
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sent legislation to the City Council yesterday that appeared directed at City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Democratic candidate for mayor. The bill would bar candidates from accepting political contributions from investment managers who handle the city's pension funds. In 1998, Mr. Hevesi approved the investment of $130 million in city pension fund money in a private equity fund with a sparse track record. The fund was controlled by a top Hevesi political donor, the Fisher real estate family. Mr. Giuliani said, ''The reality is, the concern over it emerged because of the situation with Alan Hevesi.'' Mr. Hevesi said he supported the bill. Elisabeth Bumiller (NYT)

title: A Patch for Family Bonds Put Asunder
description: WHEN you are 10 years old and face the immense task of deciding what to wear for your school photos, nothing is as important as Mom's advice. So Ashton Kaleita did what any little girl would do: She pulled outfits out of her bedroom closet and modeled them for her mother, then fixed her hair to show the style she was considering.

title: PRICE OF GASOLINE MAY POSE PROBLEM FOR WHITE HOUSE
description: Republicans in the White House and around the country are increasingly nervous that surging gas prices and rolling blackouts will pose a colossal political problem for President Bush because they are matters that he has limited control over but that touch people in their daily lives.

title: Yellow Taxis Battle to Keep Livery Cabs Off Their Turf
description: A former New York City police detective stood on the corner of 67th Street and Central Park West the other morning trying to hail a taxi. What made this unusual was that he was not going anywhere.

title: Article 2001051092591151001 -- No Title
description: Looking Back at My First PC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODTKE, RICHARD
description: BODTKE-Richard, 80. Died New Yor k City, May 3rd, 2001. Husband of Shirley, father of Christina Carlson, father-in-law of Raymond Carlson, grandfather of Julie, Suzanna, and Laura, brother of Ruth & Grace. Emeritus Professor of English, Adelphi University, author, poet. We mourn his loss. Memorial service at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, New York City, Friday, May 25, promp tly at 1:30PM. Contributions may be sent to Development Office, W aldorf School, Garden City, NY.

title: Article 2001051093516805455 -- No Title
Court Says H.M.O.'s Must Give More Data
description: Aetna Inc., Humana Inc., the Cigna Corporation and other health insurers have to turn over more documents to the doctors suing them, a judge has ruled. The physicians say the companies engaged in racketeering and broke contracts by not paying claims on time.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Longer PC Sales Downturn Foreseen
description: Michael S. Dell, head of the Dell Computer Corporation, said the company did not expect the PC business to rebound until the second quarter of next year. Companies will probably start increasing their PC purchases again in the second quarter of 2002 as new software from Microsoft and lower chip prices from Intel help spur demand, Mr. Dell said at a meeting in Hong Kong.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Cable Bill Refunds
description: Cable television regulators in New Jersey have ordered the Comcast Corporation to refund $1.3 million to 230,000 customers in seven of the state's counties, and to freeze until next Jan. 31 the charges in those locations for basic service and installation. The refunds, in the form of a credit against future charges, will average $5.64 a customer, the state's Board of Public Utilities said Tuesday, adding that the order stems from a settlement of 36 contested rate cases dating as far as 1994. The counties are Atlantic, Cape May, Cumberland, Gloucester, Salem, Camden and Hunterdon.

title: Bayern Munich Advances to Final
description: Bayern Munich beat the defending champion Real Madrid of Spain, 2-1, yesterday in Germany in a European Champions League semifinal, second-leg match to reach the final of the world's premier club competition for the seventh time.

title: SBC IS SELLING ITS CELLULAR PHONE STAKE IN TAIWAN
description: SBC Communications Inc., the second-largest local phone company in the United States, will sell its 44 percent stake in TransAsia Telecommunications Ltd., ending a four-year investment in Taiwan's cellular phone industry. SBC is selling its stake as part of a $410 million transaction that will cede control of TransAsia to the Taiwan Cellular Corporation, the largest cellular company in Taiwan. The purchase of Trans-Asia, based in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's second-largest city, may herald further consolidation in the local wireless industry.

title: Downtown Style Uptown, And Art All Around
description: What makes the new Chambers Hotel on 56th Street feel like a downtown hotel? What makes its duplex (top right, $2,000 a night), feel like a SoHo loft? ''There's not that perfect 'everything matching' look, which gives it more of a loft, home feel,'' said David Rockwell, the president of the Rockwell Group, which designed the 15-story, 77-room hotel (a new building, built from the ground up, a first for the firm) and Town restaurant downstairs. Entrance is by an imposing 12 1/2-foot-tall front door, right, carved out of American walnut in a weave pattern. Eclecticism rules in the 12th-floor duplex, which comes with a 400-square-foot terrace. The rug is Tibetan, the cherry oval table is English and the off-white sofa was designed by the Rockwell Group. To intensify the SoHo ambience, there are the ''exposed concrete ceilings, steel and glass, and art installations,'' said Ira Drukier, an owner of the Chambers, the Mercer and other hotels in New York City. Twelve artists created wall drawings, paintings and sculptures for the corridors on each of the 12 residential floors, including the exuberant design on the eighth floor by John Newsom, a Manhattan artist who painted a hummingbird soaring above fruit. ''I wanted to bring the American landscape indoors,'' he said. Guests will probably just ask for the floor with the Hawaiian-shirt-print walls. Rooms start at $425. The Chambers Hotel is at 15 West 56th Street; (212) 974-5656. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Competition Is Feverish As 3 Cities Woo Boeing
description: Some cities will do just about anything to lure the Boeing Company.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Sales Down At Telephone Concern
description: Telefnica Moviles, the wireless arm of the Spanish telecommunications group Telefnica, said it earned 154.7 million euros ($136.7 million) in the first quarter, up 13.7 percent from last year. Although subscriber numbers have risen 41.6 percent, to 22.8 million, Moviles revenues were lower than expected, largely because of economic problems in Latin America, where it has eight million clients. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Smart Wheelchairs Will Ease Many Paths
description: ON a cold February afternoon this year, a wheelchair equipped with sensors and a computer rolled across the busy concourse of a railway station in Ulm, Germany, dodging passengers and piles of baggage. A group of engineers watched intently from one end of the concourse as a man stepped in front of the wheelchair. It stopped and turned right, stopped again and turned left as the man danced around, repeatedly blocking its path. Finally, a metallic voice from the wheelchair asked in polite German, ''Could you please give way?''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Hamburger Recalled
description: A Wisconsin meat processing company recalled 254,000 pounds of frozen hamburger patties on Tuesday, saying the meat might be contaminated with E. coli bacteria. On Friday, the company, Emmpak Foods Inc. of Milwaukee, recalled 471,000 pounds of ground chuck beef that could be contaminated with E. coli. The patties were sold in 12 states, including New York, Wisconsin and Florida. They were shipped in 10-pound boxes as ''100% Pure Beef Hamburger Patties'' and marked with a date code starting with ''2940.'' The number ''924-A'' was printed inside the U.S.D.A. inspection seal. Elizabeth Becker (NYT)

title: Essay; Battle of the Blue Slips
description: In the slang of the Senate, a ''blue slip'' is like a private club's ''blackball.'' When a senator opposes a president's nominee for a judgeship from that senator's home state, he or she deliberately fails to return the blue slip of approval to the chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile yesterday, about Kenneth T. Jackson, editor of the Encyclopedia of New York City, misspelled the name of a photographer who is among the book's first entries. She was Berenice Abbott, not Bernice Abbot.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Games To Be Adapted For Gamecube
description: The video game maker Electronic Arts said it would develop 10 games for the forthcoming Nintendo GameCube, giving a lift to Nintendo's competitive position in the increasingly crowded game console market. The titles that will be adapted for the GameCube platform include the 2002 edition of its best-selling Madden NFL 2001 as well as snowboarding and basketball. Nintendo officials said the new sports titles would help it compete for teenagers and older customers. The GameCube will be available in Japan in September and in the United States two months later. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: City Ballet's Meteor Lights Up the Mirror
description: In a rehearsal studio eight stories above Lincoln Center the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon was, as usual, thinking on his feet.

title: A Virtual Palm Keyboard That Is Easier on the Eyes
description: Tapping in text using the tiny virtual keyboard of a Palm can be a struggle for those with failing eyesight. A revision by Seiko Instruments of its SmartPad device offers a large-type alternative.

title: Devils Advance, Then Exhale
description: How good are the Devils? As good as last season, when they won the Stanley Cup? As good as late this season, when they clinched the Eastern Conference regular-season title with a 19-2 finish? As good as they were for most of the game tonight?

title: House Votes to Withhold Payment of Some U.N. Dues
description: WASHINGTON, May 10  The House voted today to withhold $244 million in dues to the United Nations next year unless member countries restore the United States to the seat from which it was ousted on the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

title: Dan Hanley, 85, U.S. Olympic Doctor, Dies
description: Dr. Dan Hanley, the chief physician of the United States Olympic team from 1964 through 1972 and a pioneer who helped develop Olympic drug-testing programs, died Sunday at a hospital in Portland, Me. He was 85.

title: Back to the Future
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORMAN, D. ELIZABETH
description: HORMAN-D. Elizabeth. At age 96. Gifted artist. Passed away peacefully on May 10, 2001. Graduated from Barnard and studied at NYC Art Students League. Beloved wife of the late Edmund Horman. Loving mother of the late Charles Horman who was killed in Chile in 1973 during Pinochet's violent coup as told in the movie Missing. Dear sister of Daniel Lazar, Lawrence Lazar and the late Ruth Lazar. Cherished mother-in-law of Joyce Horman. Elizabeth's many friends will miss her greatly. Memorial service at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th St., Wednesday, May 16th, 3PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Center for Constitutional Rights for the Charles Horman Truth Fund, 666 Broadway, New York, New York 10012.

title: Don't Count Out Joppy, Durn Advises
description: Roberto Durn knows a little about William Joppy's punches. He took a few in 1998. He took enough, in fact, to get knocked out in the third round of a World Boxing Association middleweight title bout in Las Vegas.

title: Judge Blocks Rules For Forest Protection
description: A federal judge in Idaho blocked a Clinton administration plan to restrict road building and logging in about a third of the nation's forests, saying that if the rules went into effect as scheduled tomorrow they could cause ''irreparable long-term harm'' to local communities.

title: In Galleries This Week
description: Glenn Ligon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SYBIL
description: SILVERMAN-Sybil. Beloved sister of the late Muriel Schwartz and George Silverman, aunt and great aunt, died May 9, 2001. Born on September 25, 1918, Baltimore, MD-moved to NYC as a child. Worked for Standard & Poor's for over 30 years. Served proudly as a sergeant in the U.S. Women's Army Corps (WAC) during World War II and the Korean War. She will be greatly missed by her nephew, Robert and niece, Laura, their spouses Sara and Edward, and her great nieces and nephews Elana, Aliza, Seth, Jessica, Gabriel and Daniel. Service today, 9 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Henry Schuman, 69, Oboist, Conductor and Festival Director
description: Henry Schuman, a prominent oboist, conductor and teacher who founded and directed Our Bach Concerts, a popular series of midnight performances at Carnegie Hall and Lincoln Center in the 1970's, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOTHERS, MARTHA D.
description: STOTHERS-Martha D. On May 7, 2001, after a struggle against lung cancer. Beloved wife of Hedley. Devoted mother of Ruth, Hedley III and Sarah. Dear sister of Dr. Hope Dillon of Warwick, RI and Paul Dillon of Juneau, AK. Cherished daughter of Ruth Langford Dillon of Durham, NC. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers donation may be made to the John C. Dillon Scholarship Fund, Fordham Law School, 140 West 62nd Street, New York, New York 10023.

title: Jorge Robson de Souza, Port Isabel Service Processing Center near Los Fresnos, Tex., April 24, 2001
description: left my home in Vitoria, a city in southeastern Brazil, and took a 16-hour bus ride to Sao Paulo. I had to pawn my house and a plot of land in Vitoria to raise the $8,000 needed to pay the coyotes that smuggled me to the United States. But I didn't find a job when I got here. Instead, I ended up in this health center after being detained by an immigration officer. The doctors took an X-ray and found a spot in my lungs. They told me I had to stay in isolation, that I might have to stay here two months. All I could think was that I was going to die in this cold place, away from my kids. But I know I'm not sick. My brother had a lung removed due to resistant tuberculosis. I'm not coughing like my brother. I am not wasted away like him. They gave me a Bible in Portuguese, so I read all the time. I also watch TV a lot. There's not much else to do. The worst part is falling asleep. I keep on thinking about my debts, my disease, my kids. I don't know what I'm going to do."

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Herman Badillo, who is considering seeking the Republican nomination for mayor of New York, referred imprecisely to his national origin. When he left Puerto Rico as a young boy, he was already in America; Puerto Rico is a United States commonwealth.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Thomson Posts Profit
description: The Thomson Corporation, a publisher of legal, financial and educational information, posted a first-quarter profit of $167 million, mostly as a result of the sale of various units, including a stake in The Globe and Mail newspaper of Toronto, and other investments. The company's profit, which amounted to 27 cents a share, was in contrast to a loss of $22 million, or 4 cents a share, recorded a year earlier.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Pressure On Media Magnate
description: Prosecutors handed over to American officials documents to support their case that the media executive Vladimir Gusinsky, who has been traveling in the United States, should be extradited to Russia to face charges of embezzlement and money laundering. Mr. Gusinsky lost control of his independent television network and other media holdings after a Kremlin-inspired takeover by the state-controlled gas giant, Gazprom. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about House passage of a budget resolution misidentified one of the six Democrats who supported it. He was Robert E. Cramer of Alabama. (Earl F. Hilliard of Alabama voted against it.) The article also misstated the breakdown of Republican votes. Three Republicans voted no and 214 yes; three did not vote.

title: Boston Journal; Could You Please Hold for a Minute? The Governor Is About to Give Birth
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, who is about to make American history by giving birth while in office, to twins no less, appears to be going through a rare late-pregnancy complication, Massachusetts politics.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Green Offers Schools Plan
description: Mark Green, the city's public advocate and one of four major Democratic mayoral candidates, reiterated his plan yesterday for improving city schools, saying that he would reduce class size, abolish the Board of Education and offer bonuses to teachers who work in troubled schools. He did not provide details for increases in teachers' salaries and other plans. ''I think it's really foolish for a candidate to give a number,'' Mr. Green said in a speech at City College. Abby Goodnough (NYT)

title: House Moving to Ease California Power Crisis
description: With members of Congress stepping up the partisan fight over California's energy crisis, the House moved today toward passage of a bill that Republican sponsors said would increase the supply of electricity in California but would not impose the energy price caps sought by Democrats.

title: A Convoy of Snakes Crawling Across the Desert
description: ''The King Is Alive,'' a new film by the Danish director Kristian Levring, a Dogma 95 signer, takes off from a sturdy and irresistible premise: a group of people stranded in the middle of nowhere struggle for survival against the elements and in the process reveal some basic truths of human nature. This idea has been explored by countless first-time playwrights, to say nothing of Alfred Hitchcock in ''Lifeboat'' and the creators of ''Gilligan's Island'' and ''Survivor.''

title: Everyone Wants to Fix Rent Regulations. No One Knows How.
description: Tenant groups seldom agree with landlord groups, but after the latest contortions on the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, the two sides have found common ground.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Ruling On Police Board
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani won his six-year legal battle with the City Council over its effort to create an independent board to investigate police misconduct when the state's highest court declined yesterday to hear an appeal. The Court of Appeals tacitly upheld a lower-court ruling in February that the Council's legislation improperly curtailed the mayor's powers. Since 1995, Mr. Giuliani has thwarted Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone's efforts to create an independent review board with a series of legal challenges. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: From a Few Small Gems, the Delight of the Unexpected
description: A sweet, magical little picture hangs among hundreds of museum-worthy paintings on view in the eighth annual International Fine Art Fair.

title: U.S. Says Gravano Plotted to Murder His Son's Girlfriend
description: Salvatore Gravano, the Gambino family turncoat, is having a difficult month.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Did The Doctor Kill More Than 400?
description: The inquiry into the killings of patients by a Manchester physician, Harold Shipman, will examine at least 466 deaths and seek information on 152 others, Dame Judith Smith, the High Court justice heading the panel, said. Dr. Shipman, 54, was convicted in January 2000 of all 15 murders he was charged with and a Health Department report this January said the number of victims could be as high as 345. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: DEL WEBB AND AMERICAN NEVADA WIN LAND IN AUCTION
description: The Del Webb Corporation, which develops retirement communities, and the American Nevada Corporation won 1,900 government-owned acres in a Las Vegas land auction with a $47.2 million bid. The land will be used to build homes. The property was owned by the federal government, which had to sell it under a 1998 law, Del Webb said. The partnership must work with the city of North Las Vegas to create guidelines for developing the land, Del Webb said. About 500 acres will be set aside for public use and 100 will be used for building a new highway, leaving 1,300 acres for development.

title: ABN AMRO TO BUY LENDING UNIT OF MELLON FINANCIAL
description: ABN Amro Holding N.V., the Dutch bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the asset-based lending unit of the Mellon Financial Corporation to add loan officers in new cities. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. LaSalle Bank, a Chicago-based subsidiary of ABN Amro, will absorb the Mellon unit, gaining officers based in Philadelphia; Atlanta; Charlotte, N.C.; Los Angeles; and San Francisco. Mellon, which is based in Pittsburgh, agreed to sell two equipment-leasing and finance businesses to the GE Capital Corporation last week. Mellon said in January that it might sell the three businesses after reviewing whether they were profitable enough.

title: Misguided Opponents of Reform
description: With campaign finance reform facing a tough challenge in the House in coming weeks, the last thing supporters of reform need is dissent and defection within their own ranks. But that is what is happening, as several members of the Black and Hispanic Caucuses raise objections to campaign legislation that many supported in the past. Their new concerns about the McCain-Feingold ''soft money'' ban reflect a misguided belief that it would harm their interests and impede efforts to register blacks and Hispanics and get them to the polls. In fact, campaign finance reform would advance the interests of minorities.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Riverdeep Sales Surge
description: The Riverdeep Group, an educational software developer based in Dublin and Cambridge, Mass., reported a nearly sixfold yearly increase in revenue for the third quarter, which ended March 31, to $14.8 million. The company, which makes Internet- and CD-based learning products for students from kindergarten through high school, had a net loss of $4.4 million in the quarter, compared with $6.4 million in the 2000 period. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Clock on Houston's Future Will Tick
description: For the past year, Allan Houston and the Knicks' brass have spoken of their desire to stay together, each saying it is committed to the other for the long haul. But it will be at least two months before Houston's future is assured.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, MICHAEL
description: WEISSBERG-Michael. At 21 you left too soon. Words cannot express our pain and sorrow. May you rest in peace. Joe Sr., Joe Jr., John P., and Mylene Liggett

title: Yearlong Tunnel Repairs to Disrupt Trains Through Hoboken
description: One of the two aged railroad tunnels leading to New Jersey Transit's train station here will be shut down next month for 15 months of major renovations, forcing thousands of passengers to adjust their weekday commute.

title: Scientists Try to Find Answer for Dead Foals
description: As scientists and veterinarians in Kentucky worked to pinpoint why hundreds of pregnant mares have lost their foals in the past two weeks, members of the state's horse breeding industry battled rumors yesterday that it is on the verge of disaster and vowed not to panic.
