description: To the Editor:

title: NBC News Appointment
description: As expected, NBC named Neal Shapiro, the longtime executive producer of its magazine show ''Dateline NBC,'' the new president of NBC News.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, RUTH (NEE LANGHOLTZ)
description: FISCHER-Ruth (nee Langholtz). On May 10, 2001. Loving wife of Sol. Beloved mother of Barry and daughter-in-law Beth. Cherished and devoted aunt and great aunt. Funeral services on Friday, 12 noon from the Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: After Being Fired in New York, a Playoff Reunion
description: Ernie Grunfeld cannot remember the exact time, but on the morning of March 8, 1996, he stepped off an Amtrak train in Philadelphia, got a ride to the downtown Ritz-Cartlon and knocked on the door of Don Nelson's hotel room.

title: PUSHING THE LIMITS -- A special report.; Someday Soon, Athletic Edge May Be From Altered Genes
description: For three decades, the International Olympic Committee has been engaged in a game of chemical cat-and-mouse. Athletes use drugs to enhance their performances, scientists devise tests to identify those drugs, then the athletes move on to more sophisticated doping techniques.

title: Battle Wounds And War Stories
description: Michael Bay's ''Pearl Harbor,'' being released at theaters on May 25, has home video sprinting for the ack-ack guns. (Or in the case of National Geographic's ''Pearl Harbor: Legacy of Attack,'' to be released on videocassette on May 29, racing for the underwater gear to poke around wreckage on the bottom.)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Bank Meets Forecast
description: The Bank of Ireland Group, Ireland's second-largest bank, reported annual results in line with analysts' expectations, with pretax profits increasing 18 percent, to 1.1 billion euros, for the year that ended March 31. That figure excludes exceptional costs like a 39 million euro payment to the Irish government in penalties and back taxes on bogus nonresident accounts, and 68 million euros worth of staff severance packages that were part of a domestic restructuring that will eliminate 60 percent of the branches in Ireland. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Pataki Courts Immigrants, but His Ally Is Seen as Their Foe
description: Four weeks ago, Gov. George E. Pataki was in Puerto Rico, surrounded by Hispanic politicians from New York, sprinkling his remarks with Spanish, denouncing the Navy's bombing tests on the island of Vieques.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Panera To Open Long Island Cafes
description: The Panera Bread Company has agreed to open 20 bakery cafes on Long Island with an owner of restaurant franchises. Panera Bread said in a news release that it will open the cafes with Edward W. Doherty, of the closely held Doherty Enterprises. The first cafe will open in March 2002. Doherty, based in Allendale, N.J., operates Applebee's, Chevys and Wendy's restaurants.

title: The Mystique Of Japan's Fishing Coats
description: Fashionistas take note: Madison Avenue may be pushing the equestrian look for next fall, but fisherman's style could be the next big thing. Both designers and antique-textile enthusiasts will surely be impressed by the antique quilted coats in deep blue with white stitching in ''Japanese Fishermen's Coats From Awaji Island,'' a traveling exhibition of 22 examples at the museum of the University of California at Santa Barbara (through May 20).

title: Cyber Law Journal: Does a Parody Site Go Too Far?
description: One day about seven years ago, Michael T. Doughney was driving his car when he saw a bumper sticker that read: "People Eating Tasty Animals."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BINGHAM, ELIZABETH M.
description: BINGHAM-Elizabeth M. Died on May 9, 2001. A graduate of Bryn Mawr College. M.A. from Teachers College, Columbia University. Elementary school teacher in private schools for several years and in Great Neck Public Schools for 23 years. Survived by 3 nieces: Scott DeCamp of France, Cameron D. Whitman of Washington D.C. and Allen DeCamp of Wheaton, Illinois, and grandniece Ellis Whitman of New York City. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Organ Restoration Fund, Great Neck Community Church.

title: Panel Postpones Vote on Solicitor General
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee put off a vote today on the nomination of Theodore B. Olson to be solicitor general in order to examine accusations that he was more active in anti-Clinton activities than he had acknowledged.

title: A Full Studio Museum Show Starts With 28 Young Artists and a Shoehorn
description: Spring in New York usually brings a museum survey of new art. Such shows don't have to be ''great''; they seldom are. But if they're good, they deliver a hint of newness and promise that the commercial art world, month by month, can only sporadically muster. Sometimes a Whitney Biennial fills the bill; last year it was ''Greater New York.'' This spring ''Freestyle,'' at the Studio Museum in Harlem, is the showcase to see.

title: Parody or Plagiarism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer in Africa Once More Turns Deadly
description: The official toll issued by Ghana to day at least 123 deaths and 93 injuries -- turned a stampede at a soccer match on Wednesday into the worst sporting disaster in Africa's history and pushed to nearly 180 the number of spectators killed across the continent in the last month.

title: U.S. Resident Jailed in China Needs Medical Care, Lawyers Say
description: A United States-based Chinese businessman who has been held for more than two months in a Chinese military prison is extremely ill and could die if he does not receive prompt medical treatment, said lawyers who were allowed to visit him for the first time on Thursday.

title: DELTA AIR LINES MAY SEEK OTHER USES FOR COMAIR PLANES
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. threatened to shift or sell aircraft from its Comair commuter carrier if the unit's 1,400 striking pilots reject a settlement offer that they started voting on yesterday. If the six-week strike continues, the airline will act to protect its interests and customers, Delta's president, Fred Reid, said at a news conference in Cincinnati, where Comair is based. A rejection of the contract will ''regrettably force Comair management to minimize the economic impact,'' Mr. Reid said. ''We would look for other markets to deploy these aircraft'' or consider selling them.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Stylish and splashy, Ouest looks like a bistro having a torrid love affair with a 1950's lounge. A string of semicircular booths in blood-red leather line the corridor leading to the main dining room, where they are repeated on a larger scale in wraparound booths big enough for six diners. These little islands of intimacy, almost totally enclosed, contrast starkly with the bright open kitchen, a beehive of activity that makes the act of dining seem like a pleasant form of leisure, which it's supposed to be.

title: Student's Father Tells Jury of Identifying Her Body
description: Lawrence Watkins has cried at news conferences. He has cried to reporters on the telephone. He has cried in the privacy of his own home.

title: House Republicans Urge Bush to Ease Health Care Rules
description: Influential House Republicans told President Bush today that he should make major changes in new rules that protect the privacy of medical records. Otherwise, they said, Congress would need to make the changes because some of the rules were unworkable.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: European Court Cites Abuses
description: The European Court of Human Rights has found Turkey guilty of widespread human rights abuses arising from its 1974 invasion and 27-year occupation of northern Cyprus. The court said Turkey had violated 14 articles of the European Human Rights Convention, including the right to life, the right to liberty and security and the right to freedom of thought. The case was brought by the Cyprus government. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Import Prices Ease Again
description: The prices of imported goods declined in April, the seventh consecutive month without an increase and a sign of tame inflationary pressure, the Labor Department reported today.

title: House Votes to Bar U.N. Dues Payment
description: Expressing disgust because the United States was removed from the United Nations human rights commission, the House voted to withhold $244 million in dues next year unless the seat is restored.

title: Commencement; For 5,000 N.Y.U. Graduates, A Farewell to Mother School
description: Mary Wilson's mother could neither read nor write; still, she fervently wanted Mary and her other children to go to college. But as a young woman who worked as a member of the Supremes, the popular Motown group that sang with Diana Ross, Ms. Wilson had no time.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST Gov. Gary Locke and some of his fellow Democrats are trying to resurrect a measure intended to stop bullying in public schools that was derailed in the legislature recently after the Washington chapter of the Christian Coalition denounced the bill as a gay rights measure in disguise. Mr. Locke said of the opposition's argument, "That's so stupid." He stepped up his call for lawmakers to pass the bill, which would require school districts to write antibullying policies and train teachers, students and others to help stop such harassment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Montagnards, former allies of the United States who are protesting their treatment by the Vietnamese government, misspelled the name of the Communist Party newspaper that responded to their charges. It is Nhan Dan, not Nan Dhan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, BARBARA
description: BERKLEY-Barbara. Arthur I. Frankel, President Brian J. Strum, Secretary

title: The Big City; On This Isle, Maternal Is No Instinct
description: ON the Upper West Side, a private school has banned Mother's Day activities on the ground that making cards for Mom leaves some children ''uncomfortable.'' On the Upper East Side, the First Mother is preparing for Mother's Day by asking a judge to keep Dad's girlfriend out of their home.

description: EVERY year at this time, the National Hockey League shoots itself in the boot, obliquely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZMAN, IRVING M.
description: KATZMAN-Irving M. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, deeply mourn the passing of Irving M. Katzman, the father of our esteemed partner, Stuart Katzman. The warmth, affection, compassion, love and understanding, so prominently displayed by Stuart, his brother, sister, and their families, is the foundation created by their father and will be his legacy to them forever. To Ruth, his wife of 53 years, his children, Stuart, Judy, Cindy, Fred and Randi, his grandchildren, Jenna, Zachary, Joseph and Gregg, his brother, Jerome, his sister, Diane Kahn, our heartfelt condolences.

title: In Merrie Olde England, Waving His Banner All Over the Place
description: If you're part of Gen Y or younger, the concept of using the martial rock 'n' roll of the 1970's for source music in ''A Knight's Tale'' is a funny idea.

title: Foreign Affairs; Empty Deeds, Ugly Words
description: The Middle East these days is hardly a neighborhood where one would expect much religious tolerance, but when President Bashar al-Assad of Syria spewed out his venomous anti-Jewish declaration last week, he stunned even the most cynical observers. With Pope John Paul II at his side, during the pontiff's tour of Syria to promote religious understanding, Mr. Assad suggested that Christians and Muslims join in confronting Israel and the Jews, ''who try to kill the principles of all religions with the same mentality with which they betrayed Jesus Christ and in the same way they tried to kill the prophet Muhammad.'' A few weeks earlier, Mr. Assad opined that Israel was ''a racist society, even more racist than the Nazis.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern art on Wednesday night misidentified the buyer of Picasso's ''Figure,'' a 1927 Surrealist portrait. It was the dealer Beda Jedlicka of the Art Focus gallery in Zurich, not Alfred Bader, a Milwaukee collector.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, MARY FISCHER
description: BELL-Mary Fischer. Mary Fischer Bell's long and full life ended peacefully on May 8, 2001. Born Mary Agatha Fischer in Newark, NJ on June 25, 1912, she grew up in the Bronx, attended St. Athanasius School, and graduated from Ursuline Academy. Mary earned a B.A. in History from the College of New Rochelle in 1934. She was married to the late Ralph Herbert Bell from July 16, 1943, until his death on June 4, 1995. She is survived by her three daughters, Elizabeth Bell LeVaca, Katherine M. Bell, Roberta Bell Williamson, her sons-in-law, Joseph LeVaca, Thomas Blackburn and Bruce Williamson, Jr., and her four grandchildren, Christopher Eric Fuhrman and his wife Jean Flores Fuhrman, Jennifer Anne Fuhrman, Erin Mary Williamson, and Sarah Elizabeth Williamson. Mary's life will be celebrated in a funeral Mass at Epiphany Church on May 11, at 10:00AM. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that a donation be made in her name to the Ralph and Mary Bell Scholarship Fund, the College of New Rochelle, New Rochelle, New York 10805.

title: L. Dean Brown, 80, Diplomat Who Ran Airlift From Saigon
description: L. Dean Brown, a World War II combat veteran who became a career diplomat and carried out tough assignments in the Middle East and elsewhere including organizing the airlift of Americans and friendly Vietnamese from Saigon, died on May 2 at a hospital in Washington. He was 80.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Rights Advocates Arrested
description: Two Ethiopian human rights advocates have been arrested on charges of inciting student riots last month in which 41 people were reported killed. The two men, Mesfin Woldemariam and Berhanu Nega, prominent professors at Addis Ababa University, have been denied bail. The students were protesting a lack of academic and political rights. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: A Lecture on Punk May Not Be What You Thunk
description: ''Eek!'' goes the narrator. The squeals erupt like hiccups, involuntary and alarmed, as this learned young woman talks about things like ideological constructs in ''Lipstick Traces,'' the smart, spirited examination of punk rock and its antecedents that opened last night.

title: Suit to Block Plant In Camden Allowed
description: Approving a novel approach for civil rights suits after a United States Supreme Court decision last month, a federal judge in New Jersey ruled yesterday that a suit filed by residents of a black and Hispanic neighborhood in Camden to block the opening of a cement additive plant could proceed.

title: Dylan Keeps A-Changin'
description: Bob Dylan is the Devil's Triangle of rock 'n' roll. Fly into his atmosphere, and you're bound to get fatally lost. First there's the sheer density of his output. More than 40 official releases on Columbia Records float like uprooted trees amid a deluge of live bootlegs, work tapes, planned collaborations and jam sessions, swollen even larger by others' interpretations of his repertory. Dylan's presence is bottomless. Pete Townshend once said of trying to assess it, ''That's like asking how I was influenced by being born.''

title: Terror Strikes Small Town Twice
description: More than a decade before Harold Frederick Shipman came to town, Hyde was the central location for another series of grisly murders.

title: Spreading the Bronx Gospel; Teacher Takes Chorus Students to Her Eager Finland Home
description: Sixty fifth and sixth graders fidget and chatter as they wait for Johanna Grussner, their Finnish-born chorus teacher, to begin rehearsal.

title: A Motivator of Women in a League of His Own
description: HALF of the lights are not even turned on in the new headquarters of the Women's United Soccer Association in Midtown Manhattan. Most of the staff has yet to arrive. But there is Tony DiCicco, in his office at 7:30 a.m., crouched over a computer. It is hard to imagine anyone looking more focused, more in control, more tanned.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Digital Island Gets Microsoft Assignment
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Digital Island in San Francisco, by naming the company to deliver all of the online advertisements on its MSN network including MSN eShop, Search, Hotmail, Messenger Service and MSNBC.com Web sites. Digital Island, which provides e-commerce infrastructure services, had already been working for Microsoft, providing services like live and on-demand streaming media. Shares of Digital Island rose $1.69, or 84.5 percent, to $3.69. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: CONGRESS ADOPTS BUDGET PROPOSAL WITH BIG TAX CUT
description: A budget plan close to what President Bush proposed won final Congressional approval today, clearing the way for the first big tax cut in 20 years.

description: Retailers' sales rose more than forecast in April, led by low-price chains like Wal-Mart Stores, as warm weather prompted consumers to buy gardening supplies and spring dresses.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Collision Sensors for Big Trucks
description: LARGE trucks are involved in only 9 percent of fatal crashes, but 40 percent of fatal rear-end crashes, according to federal statistics. Highway safety experts say that technology could sharply reduce the number of rear-end fatalities.

title: Another Pounding Quickens Mets' Downward Spiral
description: The Mets do not just lose games these days. With increasing frequency, they are humiliated. There is a blah attitude, Bobby Valentine said. Bad spirits, Edgardo Alfonzo said. It is only May, but the season might be slipping away.

title: Judge Clears Obstacles To Pay Slaves Of the Nazis
description: A federal judge dismissed lawsuits yesterday that had blocked payments from a $5 billion German fund set up last summer to pay reparations to a million or more people forced into slave labor during the Nazi regime.

title: Swift Approval For a New Kind Of Cancer Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved a new kind of anti-cancer drug yesterday after a swift, two-and-a-half-month review of clinical data.

description: The charged atmosphere of the neighborhood just blocks north of Times Square was ratcheted up even more last night, to a frenzied state described by some of the hundreds of people on the streets -- tourists and office workers, residents and thrill seekers -- as ''absolute pandemonium'' and ''chaos.''

description: SYDNEY  It was midafternoon and the waves kept rolling in from the Pacific Ocean. Mark Butler, an experienced board surfer, had been in the water for more than an hour and had just caught a wave almost to the shore of the deserted beach.

description: Whereas the office of the governor of the Commonwealth of Virginia issues scores of proclamations every year that commemorate everything from Smithfield hams to the Blue Ridge Mountains, it seemed entirely natural, as aides to Gov. title: Stocks End the Day Lower on Rate Cut Fears
description: Stock prices fell today as investors became concerned that new signs of economic strength might lead the Federal Reserve to move less aggressively in cutting interest rates.

title: Yesterday's Tomorrows: Past Visions of the Future
description: The future is not what it used to be -- not, at least, if judged by an entertaining exhibition at the New-York Historical Society called ''Out of Time: Designs for the 20th-Century Future.''

title: Yankees Score Some Runs, but Give a Big One Away
description: Mariano Rivera admitted he wanted a strikeout and that desire may have caused him to throw his fastball just a bit harder. Joe Oliver, a veteran catcher playing for the first time in six games, knows he should have caught the ball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MARILYN I., MSW, CSW, R.
description: ROSS-Marilyn I., MSW, CSW-R. Born July 7, 1949-died peacefully on May 10, 2001. Beloved wife of Edward Poteet. Loving mother of Jeremy and Caitlin. Daughter of Jean Ross and the Late John Ross, Sister of Michael Ross and Joanne Schenendorf. Funeral Service Friday 2:30PM, May 11th at the Dix Hills Chapel of IJ Morris, Inc. Marilyn was a graduate of Cornell University, College of Human Ecology; Hofstra University, Graduate School of Education; and Rutgers University, Graduate School of Social Work. She was a psychotherapist in private practice in Commack, NY and a partner in the Commack Consultation Center. Ms. Ross was a longtime lover of modern dance, sports, nature, music and most of all family and friends.

title: Nuns Offer Clues to Alzheimer's and Aging
description: MANKATO, Minn., May 2  A spiraling road slopes gently up to Good Counsel Hill, where the convent of the School Sisters of Notre Dame perches peacefully. Within its thick red brick walls are bright paintings of nuns and children. Organ hymns waft from a circular chapel, and nuns attend Mass and murmur rosaries under a white vaulted dome.

title: Lester Atwell, 92, Writer Influenced by War
description: Lester Atwell, a novelist and short-story writer, died on April 30 at his home in Cary, N.C. He was 92.

title: To the Thinnest Of Applause, Europeans Cut Interest Rates
description: Having insisted for months that Europe had no need to join the rest of the world in easing monetary policy, the European Central Bank unexpectedly shifted ground today and reduced its benchmark interest rate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Herman Badillo, who is considering seeking the Republican nomination for mayor of New York, referred imprecisely to his national origin. When he left Puerto Rico as a young boy, he was already in America; Puerto Rico is a United States commonwealth.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar/Today: Hearing On High Natural Gas Prices
description: The New York State Assembly plans a public hearing on the increase in natural gas prices. Auditorium, Buffalo and Erie County Public Library, 1 Lafayette Square, Buffalo, 9:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. Information: (518) 455-4363.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Troops Beat Journalists
description: Seventeen journalists covering a funeral in Kashmir were beaten by Indian paramilitary troops who broke their photographic equipment and hunted them down as they tried to take refuge in nearby homes. The funeral was for three civilians killed by an explosion near a Border Security Force camp north of Srinagar. Indian officials apologized for the attack on the journalists and promised an inquiry. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: A Battle for the Courts
description: President's Bush's initial batch of nominations for the nation's Circuit Courts of Appeal has turned out to be more eclectic and conciliatory than most people expected. It contains fewer hard-right legal activists than expected and also includes a number of mainstream conservatives who will be acceptable to Senate Democrats. Even so, Mr. Bush is unlikely to get his wish for ''civility'' in the confirmation process, if by that he means a free pass to carry out his plan to fill the 100 federal court vacancies with judges who will reshape the federal judiciary into a conservative force.

title: Fees on Currency Exchanges Investigated in Europe
description: More than 100 banks and money-changing businesses in seven countries are considering whether to cut sharply the fees they charge to exchange some European currencies, after the European Commission offered them what amounts to amnesty from an investigation into market-rigging.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Automaker's Profit Is Up
description: Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G. said first-quarter profit more than quadrupled, helped by the disposal of its unprofitable Rover Cars unit and demand in the United States and Germany. The shares rose to a record. Net income rose to 409 million euros ($362 million), or 70 euro cents a share, from 87 million euros, or 18 cents a share. The Munich-based company, which sold Rover last May, increased operating profit at its BMW brand car unit by 44.7 percent, outpacing that of its rival, Mercedes-Benz, which rose 13 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, JULIUS
description: SHAPIRO-Julius. On May 10, age 78. Loving husband of the late Helen. Adoring father of Jeffrey, Cindy and Morty Kozak & the late Stewart. Beloved brother of Goldie Baron. Devoted grandfather of Jaclyn, Harli and Lauren. Your feisty, loving, charming and humorous personality will remain in our hearts forever. Services are today, 12:30 at ''Sinai Chapels'', 16205 Horrace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Jury Gets Terror Case
description: A federal jury in Manhattan began deliberations yesterday in the trial of four men who, federal prosecutors said, conspired in the 1998 bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, killing 224 people. The jury asked to review 19 pieces of evidence, including maps, grand jury testimony and a declaration by Osama bin Laden, who is said to have led the conspiracy. If convicted, two of the defendants, Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali, above, 24, and Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, 27, could face the death penalty. Wadih El-Hage, 40, and Mohammed Saddiq Odeh, 27, could face life sentences.

title: MORTON'S TO CONSIDER BUYOUT BID FROM FLORIDA COMPANY
description: Morton's Restaurant Group will consider a buyout offer made by a Florida company with backing from the financier Carl C. Icahn, according to the chairman of the investment group. The BFMA Holding Corporation said yesterday that it was ready to begin talks to acquire Morton's, which is based in New Hyde Park, N.Y., and owns Morton's of Chicago steakhouses and Bertolini's Authentic Trattorias. BFMA already owns 9.3 percent of Morton's and has bid $28.25 a share to acquire the rest. BFMA is based in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: U.S. ADMITS FAILURE TO SHARE EVIDENCE IN MCVEIGH'S TRIAL
description: The F.B.I. has discovered thousands of pages of interview reports and other materials about the Oklahoma City bombing that the government failed to turn over to a lawyer for Timothy J. McVeigh, Justice Department officials said today.

title: A Conservation Countdown
description: To understand what California is up against in its search for enough electricity to get through the summer, look no further than Michael Chroman, owner of Brooklyn Hardware in East Los Angeles.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From smelly air conditioners to buying versus leasing, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: National Briefing | West: California: TV Character Remembered
description: In a clear indication that the legislature is not completely preoccupied with the energy crisis, the Assembly observed a moment of silence in memory of a character from NBC's ''The West Wing.'' The Assembly leader, Kevin Shelley, a San Francisco Democrat, adjourned the session in memory of the fictional Mrs. Landingham, the president's secretary on the program. The character, played by Kathryn Joosten, died in a car accident in Wednesday night's episode. (Ms. Joosten is alive and well.) Mr. Shelley told the Assembly that Mrs. Landingham was a ''great American'' whose contributions to the nation ''were too numerous to count.'' Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: An Exile's Self-Portrait Sells for $22.5 Million
description: A haunting self-portrait by the German artist Max Beckmann, painted in 1938 while he was in exile in Amsterdam after the Nazis branded him a degenerate artist, was sold in Manhattan at Sotheby's auction of Impressionist and modern art for $22.5 million, a record for the artist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, JOHN J.
description: LEE-John J. Loving husband of Gayle K. Lee, and father of Jocelyn, Lauren, John and Roger. Adoring grandfather to Aidan, Jack, Austin, Simon and Isabelle. Loving brother to Robert Lee. Memorial service to be held at St. John's Church in Larchmont, on Friday, May 11, at 11 AM, with reception at the Larchmont Yacht Club to follow. Family will receive visitors on Saturday and Sunday, from 1-5 PM, May 12 and 13, at Mrs. Lee's home in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to either of the following: Cancer Research Foundation, c/o Dr. Janice Dutcher, 640 W. 239th St, Riverdale, NY 10463; or, the Cancer Support Team, 933 Mamaroneck Ave, Suite 102, Mamaroneck, NY 10543.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Conviction In Influential Abuse Case
description: In a case that led Suffolk County to change its arrest policy in abuse situations, a man was convicted Wednesday of attempted murder and first-degree assault in the stabbing of his friend. The defendant, John Gardella, 44, stabbed Naghmeh Taebi repeatedly with a penknife on Feb. 12, 2000. The day before, Ms. Taebi told the police that she was afraid for her life but did not want Mr. Gardella arrested. The attack prompted the Suffolk police to require arrests in misdemeanor cases, even if the victim objects. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Myanmar's Incorrigible Leaders
description: A few months ago it looked as if the military junta in Myanmar might ease its repressive rule slightly. The regime was talking with the country's courageous pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and there even seemed to be a possibility that she would be liberated from the prolonged house arrest the government has enforced. But those hopes have all but vanished. If the Bush administration means to speak out against human rights abuses abroad and pressure governments to treat their citizens humanely, Myanmar would be a fine place to start.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANA, CHARLES
description: DANA-Charles. The family of Charles A. Dana, Jr., of New Canaan, CT, announces with deep sorrow the loss of their husband, father, grandfather and greatgrandfather Wednesday night. We know that his generosity, his intrinsic goodness, and his warmth will be missed. But, we are much blessed for having had him as part of our lives for 86 years. He left behind his wife, Norma; three children, Marion, Charles, and Sandra; a stepson, Bruce Kendall; seven grandchildren, two stepgrandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Services will be held on Monday, May 14 11:30 AM at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue (between 71 & 72). Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the NYU Medical Center or to the Museum of the City of New York.

title: OPENWAVE TO ACQUIRE AVOGADRO FOR $99.6 MILLION
description: Openwave Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire another telecommunications software developer, Avogadro, for about $99.6 million in stock. Avogadro, a closely held company based in Seattle, is developing an instant messaging product and its communications technology should enhance Openwave's line of software, which allows users of portable electronic devices to send e-mail messages and use computer programs, Openwave said. Openwave, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., will take a one-time charge of about $2 million for the acquisition.

title: Democrat Vows To Defy Party With a Primary In Key Contest
description: Thomas R. Suozzi, rejected by the Democratic Party as their candidate for Nassau County executive at a raucous convention Wednesday night, vowed today to stay in the race and gather the signatures needed to force a September primary against Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Gold Mine To Close
description: Gold Fields Ltd., the world's third-biggest gold producer, plans a gradual shutdown of a 55-year-old South African mine that employs 3,600 workers after falling gold prices caused profit to decline 14 percent in the third quarter. The decision ends more than a year of debate about the mine, the St. Helena, which represents 6.5 percent of the company's work force.

description: Michael Bay's "Pearl Harbor," being released at theaters on May 25, has home video sprinting for the ack-ack guns. title: Neighbor Is Arrested in Rape and Murder of 11-Year-Old Bronx Girl
description: An 11-year-old Bronx girl's knock on a neighbor's door in search of a playmate appears to have inadvertently led her into the hands of her killer, the police said last night as they announced the arrest of a 43-year-old maintenance man in the rape and murder of the girl, Tamiqua Gutierrez.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chernomyrdin Heading To Ukraine
description: President Vladimir V. Putin named former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as ambassador to Ukraine, significantly raising the level of relations at a time of political turmoil in the former Soviet republic, which Mr. Putin called a ''fundamental partner.'' Ukraine's president, Leonid D. Kuchma, has lost domestic and international support over accusations of corruption, election rigging and government involvement in the disappearance of a journalist. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Lee Etheredge IV Sermin Kardestuncer
description: Pierogi

title: Public Lives: An Alabama Prosecutor Confronts the Burden of History
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. - It barely registered with 9- year-old Doug Jones in the fall of 1963 that a bomb had exploded in a black church down the road in Birmingham, killing four girls just a few years older than he was. Growing up white in the segregated suburb of Fairfield, he had other concerns.

title: Prices Climb 4.6% For Home Resales
description: Existing-home prices rose 4.6 percent in the first quarter, as demand outstripped supply in many metropolitan areas, according to a National Association of Realtors report.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.com Offers Music From Unknowns
description: Offering small-time musicians a way to distribute their music, MP3.com, an Internet music site, said it would sell recordings to Internet users without necessarily creating physical copies of the albums. Instead, users of the service, called netCD, could purchase the music online, then keep the songs stored on MP3.com's computer servers. They could then get access to the songs via the Internet, download them to portable devices or record them onto homemade compact discs. MP3.com said individual albums would cost $3.99 to $30. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASSEY, JAMES R.
description: MASSEY-James R. Born on September 28, 1953. Died May 5, 2001. Devoted, loving and cherished son, brother, nephew, friend and neighbor. He is survived by his mother Elsie, sisters Evelyn, Margaret and Dale. Brother Jerry. Employee of SMS Health Services Corp. A memorial service will be held June 15 at the St. Thomas Church, 5th Avenue (at 53rd). Contributions in his name may be made to American Cancer Society of Cabrini Hospice.

title: Substantial Cutbacks For 2 Big Agencies
description: Two large agencies -- the United States division of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide in New York and Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex. -- are making significant cutbacks and staff reductions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Sunday with an article about efforts to overturn a New York City ban on keeping ferrets as pets was published in error. The animal shown was a wild black-footed ferret, an endangered species; such ferrets are not kept as pets.

title: Bush Names a Drug Czar And Addresses Criticism
description: President Bush today nominated as his drug czar John P. Walters, who has long argued for jail time over voluntary treatment for drug offenders, calling him the man to battle illegal drugs that rob people ''of innocence and ambition and hope.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, JESSIE I.
description: KURZ-Jessie I. A beloved aunt to countless nieces and nephews, devoted wife of the late Aaron Kurz, and a friend to all with whom she came in contact, Jessie I. Kurz passed away on May 8, 2001, at the age of 97. Mrs. Kurz, affectionately known by everyone as just ''Aunt Jessie,'' was a pioneer in psychoanalysis and a contributor to many worthy causes. Those of us who knew her will always treasure her warmth, sensitivity, practicality and understanding. The celebration of her life and teachings will resonate soundly through generations of family and friends as we all describe to our children what we learned from this truly remarkable, inspring person. Contributions may be made in her name to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association Inc. NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10017.

title: A Diverse City Exists Equal but Separate
description: Stephanie Davis sat serenely on the bleachers watching her son, David, romping on the grass in his Reds uniform, getting ready to play the dreaded Twins. On the field a gaggle of boys -- whites, blacks, Asians, a few Hispanics -- tossed balls back and forth, united by the universal inability of 6-year-olds to catch most things thrown their way.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Poll Shows Support For Voting Changes
description: A study has found that 74 percent of Republicans and 85 percent of Democrats rate changes in the election system as ''important'' or ''very important.'' The survey, by the University of Southern California-Caltech Center for the Study of Law and Politics, found that 87 percent of respondents favored a uniform national voting machine, and 75 percent favored uniform voting hours. Eighty percent of respondents favored restricting the reporting of results before the polls close. The survey of 1,500 people was conducted in late March. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: HUD Scraps Cuomo Remedy for Harlem Housing Scandal
description: Federal housing officials said yesterday that they had scrapped a costly plan that was engineered by Andrew M. Cuomo, the secretary of housing and urban development in the Clinton administration, as a remedy for a vast federal home mortgage scandal.

title: Hedge Fund Managers Said to Talk to Grand Jury
description: The managers of a New York hedge fund have been testifying before a federal grand jury in Manhattan about how Wall Street investment banks controlled the market for new stocks in the late 1990's, people close to the matter said.

title: Multiple Manipulations in Space, Line and Color
description: Fortunately, Ralston Crawford (1906-1978) never got over his youthful exposure to the sea and its surroundings. It was an exposure that brought this still underrated American painter not only spiritual satisfaction but also a permanent subject for his art.

title: Marilyn, Shirley and a 5-Year-Old's Lessons in Fame
description: ''Her sweet face, a perfect moon face, and her eager blue eyes . . . made you think of a more subdued Shirley Temple,'' Joyce Carol Oates writes of her fictional Norma Jeane Baker as a little girl in ''Blonde.'' The connection between the child who grew up to be Marilyn Monroe and the one who played ''Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm'' is not obvious, but Ms. Oates's dynamic novel is filled with such startling connections. With leaps of imagination and excursions into the heroine's thoughts, her enthralling ''Blonde'' allows us to see the worn-out Monroe story from the inside out, as if it were new.

title: Pachuca Journal; Up From Bedlam: New Model for the Mentally Ill
description: Although it still hulks like a fortress over the desert landscape, the colonial hacienda that became one of Mexico's most notorious psychiatric hospitals has been closed, and the wards once filled with naked patients have been abandoned.

title: Productivity: An Exaggerated Boom May Soon Be a Bust
description: PRODUCTIVITY is not what it was cracked up to be. And therein lies one of the great fallacies of the recent boom and bubble.

title: Flood of New Corporate Debt Pushes Down Treasury Prices
description: Treasury prices posted their biggest losses in two weeks yesterday as investors sold government debt to buy more than $20 billion of bonds issued by companies including Viacom, WorldCom and the CIT Group.

title: 3 Killed and 2 Are Wounded Above Busy Midtown Block
description: Gunmen shot five people in the head, killing three, in a railroad flat above the Carnegie Delicatessen in Midtown last evening as tourists and office workers crowded the streets below. The police said the execution-style killings resulted from a dispute over drugs.

title: Insurance Giants Are Near Merger Of $23 Billion
description: After more than a month of intense negotiations, American International Group is close to a deal to acquire American General, one of the nation's largest insurers, for $23 billion in stock, executives close to the transaction said yesterday. An announcement could come as early as today, they said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Campaign Kickoff For Tories
description: The Conservative party launched its campaign for next month's election with an $11.5 billion tax-cut pledge that included a reduction in the gasoline levy, which was at the center of anti-government protests last fall that gave the Tories the only poll lead they have had since Labor came to power in 1997. William Hague, the party leader, said he would make necessary savings from trimming bureaucracy and uncovering fraud. Labor is 20 points ahead in the polls. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Syrup Production Down
description: For the second consecutive year, Connecticut will produce about half its usual amount of maple syrup because of the cold winter and the warm spring, which shortens the sugaring season, a Department of Agriculture official said. The state's several hundred syrup producers expect to bottle about 7,000 gallons, down from the usual 14,000 gallons, said Ronald Olsen, a marketing representative for the Agriculture Department. Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: Theodore Van Dam, a philatelic writer and historian of the handling of mail in wartime, died in Los Angeles on May 1. He was 84.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Antibullying Measure Supported
description: Gov. Gary Locke and some of his fellow Democrats are trying to resurrect a measure intended to stop bullying in public schools that was derailed in the legislature recently after the Washington chapter of the Christian Coalition denounced the bill as a gay rights measure in disguise. Mr. Locke said of the opposition's argument, ''That's so stupid.'' He stepped up his call for lawmakers to pass the bill, which would require school districts to write antibullying policies and train teachers, students and others to help stop such harassment. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Junk Science, Junk Evidence
description: For much of the 20th century, prosecutors served up the forensic scientist as a source of certainty amid fleeting glimpses, shaky memories and disputed confessions. Or so it seemed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Charged In Livery Killing
description: Two Bronx men were charged yesterday in the death early Wednesday morning of Anlidva Brown, a livery driver who was shot in her cab near Co-op City. The police said they had arrested Fermin Pena, 30, a livery driver who was a former boyfriend of Ms. Brown's, and Erlen Jose Abreu Guzman, 22, whom Mr. Pena is accused of having hired to kill her. Investigators said Ms. Brown, 32, a mother of two, had been lured to a remote street corner by Mr. Pena, who had called to say his cab had broken down. The police said Ms. Brown, the city's first female livery driver to be killed on the job, was then shot by Mr. Guzman. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Theft Ring Alleged
description: Luxury cars worth millions of dollars -- including dozens of Corvettes, BMW's and similar sports cars -- were stolen by an international car theft ring that shipped the cars from New York to Russia, the office of Mary Jo White, the United States attorney, announced yesterday. Ten men were accused in a federal indictment. The ring, prosecutors said, used false documents to get replacement car keys from dealerships and duped roadside assistance services to cooperate in replacing keys. They also worked to overcome Lo-Jack tracking devices, prosecutors said. Lawyers for the accused could not be immediately reached for comment.

title: A Grim Week of Tit-for-Tat Mideast Violence
description: Two Romanian contract workers in Israel were killed by a roadside bomb today as they were repairing the fence along the Gaza border. Israel retaliated by firing surface-to-surface missiles at security and political offices in the heart of Gaza City, wounding more than a dozen Palestinians.

description: Roberto Ramirez, the chairman of the Bronx Democratic Committee and a senior adviser to Fernando Ferrer, has a simple explanation for why he is certain that Mr. Ferrer will be the next mayor of New York, and it is as old as the city itself: the power of ethnic politics.

description: When Scott Verplank was a teenager growing up in Dallas, he worked at the Byron Nelson Classic, carrying the portable scoreboards that follow along with each group of players.

description: Looming behind the cinder block house where 4-month-old Iman Hijo was killed by Israeli tank fire on Monday is an Israeli Army bunker in the dunes fringing this refugee camp.

description: In what may signal a heightened significance for a case testing the constitutionality of a 1998 digital copyright law, a panel of appeals court judges has asked both sides of a case to answer a list of 11 questions on whether computer code can qualify as free speech.

description: Mud and Mirth, For Art's Sake

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: 2 Charged With Economic Espionage
description: Federal prosecutors have filed charges under the 1996 Economic Espionage Act against two Japanese researchers, accusing them of stealing genetic material from an Alzheimer's research project at a clinic in Cleveland. The two, Hiroaki Serizawa, 39, a researcher at the University of Kansas School of Medicine in Kansas City, Kan., and Takashi Okamoto, a former employee of the Cleveland Clinic Foundation, are accused of taking DNA and cell reagents from the clinic in 1999. The indictment accuses Mr. Okamoto of bringing the material to his new employer, the Institute of Physical and Chemical Research in Japan, which has denied ever receiving it. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Sports of The Times; Billy C. On Iverson: 'Phenomenal'
description: BILLY CUNNINGHAM made it home for the fourth quarter Wednesday night, in time to watch Allen Iverson erase him from the record book. ''To tell you the truth, I was more impressed with the 19 straight points he scored in the fourth than with the 54 over all,'' Cunningham said yesterday. ''Because they needed every one of them.''

title: LABOR GROUP CRITICIZES LEAGUE
description: A labor rights group from the United States said yesterday that replica jerseys of National Basketball Association teams were made at factories in El Salvador that use extensive, systemic sweatshop practices.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Move To Rental Model
description: Microsoft said it would let large business customers rent computer programs for three years, a plan that could protect sales during slowdowns in the personal computer market. Microsoft customers now buy software licenses outright and can use them forever. The new program, which will be offered starting Oct. 1, would require users to buy a new license after the subscription term expires.

title: DOW CHEMICAL SAYS IT WILL INCREASE DIVIDEND 15.5%
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would increase its dividend 15.5 percent. A quarterly dividend of 33.5 cents, up from 29 cents, will be paid July 30 to shareholders of record as of June 29. Last month, Dow Chemical, based in Midland, Mich., reported a first-quarter loss of $685 million, or 76 cents a share, as higher energy costs and a slowing economy hurt chemical companies' profits. Excluding a $1.4 billion pretax charge related to its February acquisition of the Union Carbide Corporation, Dow would have earned 8 cents a share.

title: Energy and Originality Take Varied Jazzy Forms
description: The karma was more than good as the Fred Benjamin Dance Company packed Symphony Space on Sunday night. Produced by Dr. Glory Van Scott, the program of four pieces by Mr. Benjamin drew a young audience. Many were jazz dancers, including students and alumni of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center, where Mr. Benjamin heads the jazz dance department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LILLIAN
description: HOFFMAN-Lillian, 95. Of Hollywood, FL. formerly of N.Y. passed away May 8, 2001. Loving mother of Sheldon Hoffman and Elaine (Richard) Blumencranz. Dear sister of Sybil Goldin and Dinah Rosenberg. Cherished grandmother of 7 and the late Eric Hoffman. Adored great grandmother of 14.

title: Ghanaian Cabbies in Atlanta Sue Over a Jackpot
description: Back home in Ghana, this all would have been settled quietly by the village elders, say the Ghanaian cab drivers who while away their days in the bullpen at Atlanta's Hartsfield International Airport. But this is America, and the Ghanaians have learned a thing or two since immigrating here. So when a dispute arose last weekend over a winning lottery ticket -- a $49.4 million winning ticket -- some of the Ghanaians did the American thing. They sued.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Whale Hunt Begins
description: Three Japanese ships left for the Northwest Pacific to begin a two-month hunt for minke, Bryde's and sperm whales, part of what the fisheries ministry said was a two-year investigation to see if they are suffering from pollution. Foreign governments and conservation groups sharply criticize Japan's whaling activities as a front for commercial whaling; much of the meat ends up in restaurants. The United States has threatened to block Japanese imports under an American law authorizing penalties against any nation that violates a marine conservation treaty. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: The Swamp's Intimidating Charms
description: There's a moment in every swamp movie when you know things are not going to go well. Usually it's just before somebody enters a particularly dense tangle of vegetation. You see a poisonous snake hanging from a limb or an alligator slipping into the water or, if the movie is really tacky, the dripping head of a monster rising from the fecund depths of the hellish muck.

title: KeySpan and LIPA Planning Power Plant in Melville
description: Warning that California-like blackouts will occur on Long Island if new power plants are not built, the KeySpan Energy Corporation and the Long Island Power Authority announced plans today for a $300 million natural-gas-fired plant on a dusty industrial tract here near the border between Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

description: Expressing disgust because the United States had been removed as a member of the United Nations Human Rights Commission, the House struck back today by voting to withhold $244 million in dues next year unless the United States is restored to the panel.

title: Bush Urges Congress to Act on Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, May 11  President Bush said today that the surest and swiftest way to help Americans cope with rising gas and oil prices was to enact a sweeping tax cut, which he said would give them more money to pay for the increases.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hotel Occupancy Shows Decline
description: Hotel occupancy rates in New York City fell in the first quarter of this year from last year's record highs, and further declines are expected as the national economy continues to slow, according to figures made public yesterday. But at a luncheon to celebrate National Tourism Week, Cristyne F. Lategano-Nicholas, president of NYC & Company, the city's conventions and visitors bureau, said the bureau had already taken a cooling economy into account. She said the bureau saw no reason to change last December's projection of modest growth of 2 to 3 percent, to a record 39.4 million, in the number of travelers to the city this year compared with 2000. The occupancy figures, compiled by PKF Consulting, show a 73 percent occupancy rate in the first quarter of this year, down from 79.1 percent in the first quarter of 2000. An 81 percent occupancy rate was projected for all of 2001, compared with 84.6 percent last year and 81.2 percent in 1999. A spokeswoman for the bureau, Nell Barrett, noted that more than 3,000 rooms have been added in the city in the last year. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Jersey Station Purchase
description: Greater Media Inc., operator of two radio stations in central New Jersey, has agreed to buy four radio stations from New Jersey Broadcasting Partners. Three of the stations, WDHA-FM, WMTR-AM and WWTR-AM are in Morris County. WRAT-FM is in Monmouth County. Financial terms were not disclosed. The closely held Greater Media operates WMGQ-FM and WCTC-AM.

description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said yesterday that it was creating a sales unit for Mexico, the only North American market where it does not build or sell cars and trucks.

The sale of wireless transmission towers bolstered earnings by 88 million Australian dollars ($45.8 million).

description: The United States men's team will face Japan, France and Nigeria when the ninth FIFA Under-17 world championship kicks off in Trinidad and Tobago in September. The United States will play its three group games at Dwight Yorke Stadium just outside of Scarborough, Tobago. The top two finishers in each of the fours group will advance to the quarterfinals.

description: The Republican speaker of the Assembly easily brushed aside an effort today by the Democratic minority to begin impeachment proceedings against Peter G. Verniero for his testimony about racial profiling two years ago.

description: After intense lobbying by opponents of paddling in schools, the Senate on Wednesday changed the wording of legislation protecting teachers from lawsuits to say explicitly that it was not intended to affect policies regarding corporal punishment.

description: On the last Sunday afternoon in April, James Levine, the Met Orchestra and Chorus and a dream quartet of vocal soloists gave a stunning performance of Verdi's Requiem at Carnegie Hall. Exactly one week later, Mr. Levine and the orchestra were back at Carnegie on Sunday along with another thrilling roster of vocalists to perform an even more gigantic work of an entirely different style: Schoenberg's ''Gurrelieder.'' A selection from its 6,000 objects, which include this late 19th-century Okuyi mask from Gabon, moved into newly installed permanent galleries just a few years ago, and this month those galleries reopened after a makeover intended to put the objects in a lively visual context, helping to explain their uses and meanings.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Compaq Mulls Proxicom Bid
description: Compaq Computer will consider raising its takeover bid for Proxicom, an Internet consulting firm, after receiving formal notice yesterday of a higher competing bid. On Monday, shares in Proxicom rose 31 percent after Dimension Data Holdings, a South African network services company known as Didata, offered $7.50 a share, a 30 percent premium over Compaq's bid of $5.75. The Dimension Data offer valued Proxicom at $448 million. Proxicom had recommended that shareholders accept the Compaq offer, but said in a release yesterday that it saw Dimension Data's offer as superior to Compaq's.

description: British Telecommunications eked out some breathing room from impatient investors today by outlining a widely anticipated corporate overhaul that will enable it to raise $8.4 billion and spin off its wireless division.

title: Hawaiian Getaway
description: Agetaway to Hawaii from the West Coast can start as low as $814 a person. Runaway Tours and Sheraton are offering five-night packages in Waikiki that include round-trip air fare on United from Los Angeles or San Francisco, accommodations, rental of a Jeep Wrangler or convertible from Dollar and a $125 food credit. The price of $814, based on double occupancy, is for accommodations at the Sheraton Princess Kaiulani. It's $970 a person, double, for the Sheraton Waikiki, $1,020 at the Sheraton Moana Surfrider and $1,198 at the Royal Hawaiian. Prices are valid through Dec. 15 and are subject to availability and seasonal surcharges. Taxes and other fees are extra. Book through a travel agent.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON GETS APPROVAL FOR ALZA PURCHASE
description: Johnson & Johnson received early antitrust clearance for its planned $14 billion stock purchase of the Alza Corporation, the companies said yesterday. The 30-day antitrust waiting period was scheduled to expire next Monday, and the Federal Trade Commission said in a letter that it had no objections to the merger, said Jeffrey Leebaw, a spokesman for Johnson & Johnson. The transaction is expected to be completed by early in the third quarter, the companies said in March. Johnson & Johnson, which is based in New Brunswick, N.J., agreed to pay 0.49 share for each share of Alza, which is based in California. Johnson & Johnson will gain the attention-deficit medicine Concerta which the companies now market together, and the purchase will add about $700 million to Johnson & Johnson's $12 billion in yearly sales of prescription drugs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCALA, HELEN T. (GRIFFIN)
description: SCALA-Helen T. (Griffin). Of Harrison, New York and New Marlboro, MA, died on May 8th, 2001 at St. Agnes Hospital. She was seventy-four years old. Her loving husband Anthony of fifty-one years of marriage survives her. She was the devoted mother of five sons. Helen Scala was born May 17, 1926 in New York City to the late Cornelius and Beatrice Glavey Griffin. She graduated from Cathedral High School in 1942. On April 29, 1950 she married Anthony J. Scala at St. Anthony's Church in New York City. She lived in Harrison for the past 40 years. Before that she was a resident of Crestwood from 1950 to 1961. She was a parishioner of St. Gregory's Church in Harrison and a Lady of the Holy Sepulchre. In addition to her husband, Anthony, her sons and their wives, Anthony Jr. & Mary Ellen of Port Chester, James and Deborah of Harrison, Peter and Joyce of New Marlboro, MA, and Christopher and Kerry of Harrison survive her. She also leaves behind ten grandchildren, Anthony, Jennifer, Christopher W., Stephanie, Laura, Victoria, Suzanne, Kimberly, Christopher Jr. and Margaret. She was the sister of Cornelius Griffin of Scarsdale, Teresa Talbot of Watertown, Geraldine McNulty of Newtown, & the aunt to many nieces and nephews. Her son William in 1979, and her two sisters Mary McAuliffe & Ann Walsh predeceased her. Calling hours are 2-4 & 7-9PM Wednesday and Thursday at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road in Rye, NY. The funeral is Friday, May 11th at 11 AM at St. Gregory's Church in Harrison. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: TRAVIS STREET INCREASES BID FOR ICO TO $70.3 MILLION
description: The investor group Travis Street Partners said yesterday that it had raised its hostile bid for the Houston oil services company ICO Inc. to about $70.3 million to top an offer from the company's management. Travis, a Houston-based partnership, had bid about $60 million in April and was outbid earlier this week by the management group, which is led by ICO's chairman, Al Packholder. The management group bid about $68 million, or $3 a share. The Travis group, which already owns about 5 percent of ICO's 22.7 million outstanding shares, bid $3.10 a share for the rest of ICO's stock.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Haiti: A Quest For Democracy
description: A mission led by Luigi Einaudi, assistant secretary general of the Organization of American States, arrived in Port-au-Prince to investigate the fragile state of democracy after last year's disputed elections. The members will meet with President Jean-Bertrand Aristide and other politicians. At the Summit of the Americas in Quebec last month, Prime Minister Jean Chrtien of Canada asked for a fact-finding mission to report on Haiti and develop plans to fortify its democratic institutions. Many experts believe that Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's chances of winning the presidency would have been hurt if his party made a poor showing in the legislative elections. Mr. Jospin proposed the new calendar; his likely opponent, President Jacques Chirac, objected. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Profit Falls
description: France's biggest bank, BNP Paribas, reported that a slump in investment banking caused first-quarter net profit to drop 7.4 percent, to 1.25 billion euros ($1.1 billion), from 1.35 billion euros a year earlier. The investment banking decline was partly offset by a 15 percent rise in operating income from retail banking, so that shares in BNP Paribas rose on the news more than 4 percent. The chief executive, Michel Pebereau, said the outlook for the remainder of the year ''appears particularly difficult to predict.'' Socit Gnrale and Crdit Lyonnais, domestic rivals, said last week that first-quarter profit would drop significantly because of declining stock markets and the slowdown in the United States. The state's population of 4.3 million is expected to increase by 1 million over the next 10 years. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loss At Shipbuilder
description: Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest builder of merchant ships, paid the price in the first quarter of this year for diverting funds into money-losing companies in the Hyundai group. The shipbuilder, generally one of Korea's most profitable enterprises, reported an unconsolidated loss of $63 billion in the first quarter of this year, largely as a result of losses suffered by Hyundai Petrochemical, of which it is the major shareholder. A court in Seoul, meanwhile, ordered the liquidation of Dong Ah Construction, once Korea's second-largest builder. Dong Ah, which failed to pay debts of $3 billion in November, will still be able to complete its ditch project in Libya. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Welfare Agency Recalls Advice
description: Oregon officials recalled a tip sheet for state welfare recipients that recommended rooting through trash hauling bins as a good way to save money. The recommendations were produced by a private company that had been hired by the state to train welfare recipients. ''We shot ourselves in the foot on this,'' said Bob Mink, director of the state Department of Human Services. The tips included shopping at thrift stores, clipping coupons and this idea: ''Check the dump and residential/business Dumpsters.'' Several welfare recipients described the Dumpster tip as demeaning. title: Soul-Searching and Beauty From Holocaust Composers
description: The members of the Hawthorne String Quartet all play in the Boston Symphony Orchestra, but quartet playing for them is more like a mission than an extracurricular hobby. Their repertory tends toward the unusual rather than the standard, and they have made a specialty of finding and reviving works by Jewish composers who were killed in the Holocaust, or who died while trying to escape it. A particular focus is on the musicians of Terezin (or Theresienstadt), the concentration camp in Czechoslovakia that the Nazis turned into a model camp, with an arts program, for propaganda purposes.

title: DIMENSION DATA TO ADD PROXICOM FOR $448 MILLION
description: Dimension Data Holdings agreed yesterday to acquire Proxicom Inc. for $448 million, ending a brief bidding war with the Compaq Computer Corporation. The agreement came after Compaq said it declined to raise its bid for Proxicom, an Internet consulting firm. Dimension Data Holdings, a South African network services company known as Didata, bid $7.50 a share for Proxicom on Monday, topping Compaq's bid of $5.75, which was made last month and valued Proxicom at $344 million. Compaq will receive a $10 million termination fee.

title: The F.B.I.'s Lost Files
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has had its share of lapses and scandals over the years, but its mishandling of 3,000 pages of investigative documents in the biggest domestic terrorism case ever tried in this country is a particularly shocking failure. An angry and embarrassed attorney general, John Ashcroft, acted correctly in postponing Mr. McVeigh's execution until June 11 to allow his attorneys a chance to examine these documents, which were supposed to have been turned over before his trial. The lawyers need at least that much time to determine if the documents -- and the F.B.I.'s action in itself -- provide grounds for an appeal of their client's 1997 conviction. He was sentenced to death for the Oklahoma City bombing that killed 168 people and has since confessed to the crime in a recently published book.

title: Cuttings: Putting Azaleas' Vivid Colors in Their Place
description: AZALEAS really need to be in a woods, that's all there is to it. When you see them massed up a wooded hill, as I did last week, at the National Arboretum in Washington, you can almost like them.

title: Clues to a Meteor That Aided Dinosaurs
description: Dinosaurs were unlucky 65 million years ago when a meteor struck off the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico; they died out in the environmental cataclysm that followed. But dinosaurs were beneficiaries of an earlier mass extinction 200 million years ago that killed off a competing group of animals and enabled dinosaurs to flourish for the next 135 million years.

title: CLOROX TO GET 50% STAKE IN BRAZILIAN CONCERN
description: The Clorox Company agreed to pay $175 million for a 50 percent stake in a unit of Bombril S.A. of Brazil, resurrecting a transaction that it says will help build its presence in Latin America. Clorox will acquire half of Detergentes Bombril, a unit of Bombril, the Brazilian company said. The two companies agreed to talk again after Clorox pulled out of the transaction on April 6, Bombril said. In January, Clorox, based in Oakland, Calif., said it agreed to pay $200 million to acquire 50 percent of Detergentes, a new company. Bombril, which makes steel wool, detergents and other household products, was supposed to transfer assets including trademarks, three production plants and about 1,900 employees to the venture.

description: President Bush said today that the surest and swiftest way to help Americans cope with rising gas and oil prices was to enact a sweeping tax cut, which he said would give them more money to pay for the increases.

description: You are Fox Sports and you have a message: your World Series demographics last year were better than NBC's for the Summer Olympics.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: President Digs In
description: President Abdurrahman Wahid dug in against his critics, brushing aside proposals that he share power with Vice President Megawati Sukarnoputri and asserting that he would offer no response to a parliamentary censure that could lead to impeachment proceedings. Parliamentary officials said they would go ahead with a meeting on May 31 to decide whether to convene an impeachment assembly. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: KRAFT FOODS NARROWS PRICE RANGE OF ITS STOCK SALES
description: Kraft Foods Inc., the Philip Morris Companies unit that makes Oreo cookies and Oscar Mayer lunch meats, narrowed the price range for its initial stock sale to $27 to $30 a share, or as much as $8.4 billion. The new range was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Earlier, the company had set a range of $26 to $31 a share for the 280 million common shares. That would have raised as much as $8.68 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Telecom Spinoff
description: Shareholders of Eircom, the former Irish state phone company, approved the sale of its mobile arm, Eircell, to the Vodafone Group, for shares valued at 3.45 billion euros ($3 billion). The deal was valued at 4.5 billion euros when it was made in December, but Vodafone's shares have fallen since then, reducing its value. With the sale of its mobile arm completed, Eircom will turn next to its fixed-line assets and has asked three suitors to submit formal bids by the end of the month. Brian Lavery (NYT)

The only player they traded for who made the opening day roster and is still on the team is reliever Donne Wall. To get him, they gave up outfielder Bubba Trammell.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Foreign Investments Approved
description: India will allow 100 percent foreign investment in several industrial sectors like pharmaceuticals, hotels and tourism, airports and rapid transit systems. A ministerial panel eased the curbs at a meeting on Wednesday. The parliamentary affairs minister, Pramod Mahajan, said foreign investors would no longer be required to sell a 26 percent stake to an Indian partner or the public. India also raised foreign investment limits from 20 to 49 percent in banking, and from 49 to 74 percent in Internet service providers, paging and bandwidth. The country also opened its military sector to private investors, an area that previously was classified off-limits even to domestic investors. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: More Tax-Cut Follies
description: In the latest chapter of Washington's budget wars, a bipartisan group of senators on the Finance Committee yesterday put forward a tax cut designed to look more fair and digestible than the one advocated by President Bush. Their proposal for $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over 11 years does contain some elements more favorable to lower-income groups than earlier versions. But over all it amounts to another gross abdication of fiscal responsibility. The new tax-cut ideas actually underscore the lack of realism with which Congress has approached budget and tax matters this year.

In Christopher Wheeldon's equally new but comic ''Variations Srieuses,'' the set simulates a backstage area and a stage on which dancers perform at a diagonal. They face a make-believe audience on a backdrop.

title: Yao Can't Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: Yao Ming, the 7-foot-6 center for the Shanghai Sharks, will not be allowed to join the N.B.A. next season, team officials said today.

title: Two Leaders Of Tax Panel Agree on a Bill
description: The Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee and the committee's top Democrat presented a detailed tax proposal today that would save most income-tax payers several hundred dollars this year and eventually give those of highest income a cut of tens of thousands of dollars.

title: Big Store, Seen as Interloper, Wins Over a Neighborhood
description: The floors were clean and shiny. The seafood counter was stocked with Alaskan snow crabs. A wide-screen television overhead offered cooking tips. Even Gertrud Wittingham, who had been dead set against the Pathmark supermarket, was singing its praises at the tomato sauce display.

title: Bush Says U.S. Will Give $200 Million to World AIDS Fund
description: President Bush said today that the United States would contribute $200 million to a global fund to attack AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis, but critics and some members of Congress said the initial donation was paltry.

title: In Oklahoma City, Delay Brings Even More Anguish
description: The contempt for Timothy J. McVeigh is so deep in this city that many people will not speak his name. He is ''the perpetrator'' or ''that man.'' To say his name aloud, many people here believe, is to waste a breath on a man who killed their loved ones and has spent the last six years laughing in their faces.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Students Chase College President
description: Hundreds of Northeastern University students chased the institution's president and blocked traffic through the Boston campus on Thursday after he announced plans to tear down the building that houses the black student center and replace it with a structure housing the institute and other programs. The president, Richard M. Freeland, finally left in a car. Several students, who say the John D. O'Bryant African-American Institute should remain freestanding, have been occupying the building since April 12. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Homo Sapiens in Museums?; Look Under 'Insignificant Interlopers'
description: In one of his more fantastical moments, the novelist Jorge Luis Borges imagined an ancient Chinese encyclopedia that presented a method for ordering all the world's animals. Any creature, instead of belonging to groups like ''insects'' or ''amphibians,'' could be classified in one of these categories: 1) belonging to the emperor, 2) embalmed, 3) tame, 4) suckling pigs, 5) sirens, 6) fabulous, 7) stray dogs, 8) included in the present classification, 9) frenzied, 10) innumerable, 11) drawn with a very fine camel-hair brush, 12) et cetera, 13) having just broken the water pitcher and 14) that from a long way off look like flies. These categories, of course, disrupt the very idea of taxonomy. But the list, which is cited by the French philosopher Michel Foucault in his book ''The Order of Things,'' forces us to question how we create categories in the first place.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: World's Worst Refugee Crisis
description: The United Nations official conducting a worldwide survey of displaced people said that families fleeing drought in Afghanistan now constitute ''the fastest growing displacement crisis anywhere.'' The official, Dennis McNamara, said that 2,000 people a day are arriving in the western Afghan city of Herat alone. Others are fleeing to other parts of the country and the Pakistani border. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

Usually loyal and louder than any crowd in the N.B.A., fans of the Kings shuffled quietly out of Arco Arena, as if they did not want to stick around for the unbearable end.

They stood around and talked in groups. The only thing missing was big clouds of cigar smoke.

title: Italy's Moment of Decision
description: The fact that Italy is about to elect its 59th government since World War II is regarded with almost complete indifference in the United States. Since the end of the cold war and the dissolution of the Italian Communist Party, Italy has virtually disappeared from the radar screen of American foreign policy. But the potential consequences of tomorrow's election are far more important than many realize.

title: Terror Case To End Secrets Of Plea Deals By Informers
description: A federal judge in the embassy bombings trial ordered the government yesterday to turn over to the defense records of any secret deals that it has made with certain informants who have agreed to cooperate in the investigation of Osama bin Laden. The order covers people who were members of what the government calls Mr. bin Laden's terrorist conspiracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROGSTAD, JOHN

He was born in Hovin, Norway, on January 10, 1906, and emigrated to Seattle in 1917. He graduated from Renton High School in Seattle in 1925 and from the University of Washington in 1930. From 1931 to 1971 he worked at Barnes & Noble, where he was vice president for 25 years, directed the wholesale department and helped develop the College Outline Series. In 1975 he and his wife Ruth (who died in 1998) moved from Long Island to Florida. He is survived by two sons, Donald J. Krogstad, M.D., of New Orleans, LA, and Robert T. Krogstad of Rochester, NY, and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Mark's Presbyterian Church on State Road 52 in Hudson, FL, at 2PM on Monday, May 14. description: Charles A. Dana Jr., a philanthropist of diverse interests, died on Wednesday at Bellevue Hospital Center in New York City. He was 86.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Prudential Withdraws Bid
description: Britain's second- biggest insurer, Prudential P.L.C., formally withdrew its all-stock bid for the American General Corporation after the American International Group agreed to buy American General for $23 billion. Investors on both sides of the Atlantic had been unhappy with the initial $26.5 billion offer and Prudential's stock slumped by 15 percent, lowering its bid price. Prudential, which has said it will look elsewhere in the United States, secured an agreed $600 million breakup fee from the deal, but some analysts said Prudential might now be a takeover target itself. Alan Cowell (NYT)

The union has been campaigning against poor working conditions in delis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, BARBARA GLASGALL
description: BERKLEY-Barbara Glasgall. On May 10, at home. Bobbie inspired family and friends with her warmth, wit, charity and love. She was a vibrant and passionate woman who frequently devoted her efforts to political and educational campaigns. She loved sports and enjoyed competing and developing her skills. Bobbie was a student in Hanya Holm's first dance class in the United States, and was an early modern dance enthusiast thanks to her avant-garde mother. She danced and performed under the direction of Margaret Dobler at the University of Wisconsin. Bobbie was a fine student and graduated from UW in 1941. May 4th was her 61st wedding anniversary, an anniversary that marked so many years of a rare marriage. From that day in September 1938, when Bobbie and Bob met at the AEPhi Sorority tea, at the University of Wisconsin, it was a continuing love affair. They eloped to Dubuque, Iowa on May 4, 1940. As a new mother during World War II, Bobbie suffered the worry of separation from her husband. Shaped by her happy childhood in the Jewish community in Paterson, NJ, she maintained a lifelong bond to that place and those people. In Hillsdale, NJ, where Bobbie and her family resided for 45 years, she was active in many community activities including drama, fund-raising for many causes, and ardent support for the Bergen YJCC and Temple Emanuel. She regarded the growth and popularity of both these institutions as miraculous. Bobbie and Bob sponsored the immigration of the Raiskin family from Russia. She considered this to be a highlight of her life, & was immensely proud of this addition to her family. Bobbie leaves her husband, Bob, a daughter, Alison and a son, Roger, as well as a sister, Judith Weiner and her sister-in-law, Jane Kantor. She also leaves her three grandchildren, Kate, Daniel, and Sarah, and a host of loving nieces and nephews. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ; burial at Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimers Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., NYC would be appreciated.
