title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Marriage Age Raised To 16
description: The House of Representatives unanimously approved a bill that would raise the marriage age to 16 from 14. Under the bill, teenagers younger than 16 could not get married, and those under 18 would need their parents' consent to marry. The issue has been in the news recently after leaders of a church in Georgia -- where the marriage age is 16 -- began taking teenagers to Alabama to get married. David Firestone (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: The Eternal Arm Of The Law
description: ''Perpetual arrest warrants'' have been issued by a court for former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, according to the state-run Associated Press of Pakistan. Ms. Bhutto, who is living in self-exile in London, has been charged with misusing her position to acquire illegal wealth. Judge Rustam Ali earlier issued six warrants demanding that she answer the charges. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: TV Tycoon and Career Politician Wrap Up Campaign to Lead Italy

title: Wal-Mart to End Practice of Sharing Sales Data

title: Guns and Children
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: 8 Nominations Announced
description: President Bush announced his intention to nominate eight people to serve in his administration and formally nominated five others by sending their names to the Senate, bringing to 97 the number awaiting confirmation. The Senate confirmed 11 nominees, bringing the total to 51. The president drew from the House of Representatives for one nominee, choosing Asa Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, to serve as his administrator in the Drug Enforcement Administration. President Bush also announced his intention to nominate as his drug czar John P. Walters, who was deputy director of the office under Mr. Bush's father.

title: Indiana Execution Site Is Facing More Strain
description: Jill Gilmour's customers at Jodi and Jane's gift shop could talk of nothing else today, not the antique plates or knicknacks, not the sentimental jewelry that is all 20 percent off for Mother's Day. The only subject of conversation was the postponement of the death of Timothy J. McVeigh.

title: Fugitive Shot and Killed by the Authorities in a Bustling Midtown Hotel Lobby
description: A fugitive wanted nationwide on charges of murder, robbery and sexual abuse was shot and killed by law enforcement agents yesterday morning in the lobby of a crowded Midtown hotel.

title: Despite European Unity Efforts, to Most Workers There's No Country Like Home
description: Three years ago, when Catalina Martnez was finishing her doctorate in economics at the University of Barcelona, she could not find work in Spain. So, with a British professor's help, she got a job in London. The next year she moved to Brussels. The year after that she arrived in Paris.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALCATEL S.A., San Francisco, the Genesys Telecommunications Laboratories Inc. unit of Alcatel has agreed to purchase International Business Machines Corp.'s CallPath assets. Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed.

title: An Unlikely Mexican Foreign Minister
description: Jorge Castaeda, Mexico's new foreign minister, finds himself upbraided by Cuba and warmly received by the United States these days, a once unthinkable position for a onetime Communist supporter and critic of American foreign policy. But then it is equally improbable that Mr. Castaeda would become one of the main architects of a constructive new partnership between Mexico and the United States. Yet he has done just that, and the two nations are the better for it.

title: World Briefing | The World: Threat Seen From 'Aliens'
description: As global trade expands, the problem of so-called alien species of insects and plants is spreading and inflicting economic damage running into billions of dollars, the Swiss-based World Conservation Union said. Exporting countries need to take steps against giving free rides to such invaders, which are causing the extinction of some native species, the group said. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Albany Power Agency to Weigh In Next Week on Penalties for Price Gouging
description: The agency that manages the state's power grid plans to decide next week whether to impose financial penalties on power plant owners for price gouging.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Fracture In President's Coalition
description: A left-wing party that has been an important part of the government coalition has broken with President Hugo Chvez, accusing him of seeking to concentrate all power in his own hands. The Movement Toward Socialism took the step as Mr. Chvez announced in a speech on Thursday night that he was considering declaring a state of emergency that would allow him to rule by decree. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Lemieux Gets the Devils' Attention, but Not Exclusively
description: In the past 10 seasons, the Devils and the Pittsburgh Penguins have won the Stanley Cup 40 percent of the time. The Penguins won it in 1991 and 1992; the Devils in 1995 and 2000. But this year's quest is special. When these teams meet in the Eastern Conference finals, beginning on Saturday night in the Meadowlands, they will present one of the most compelling sports plot lines in recent years.

description: Alex Escobar called home to Venezuela on Thursday and spoke to his father, Claudio, who had read all about his son's first few games in the local newspapers.

description: Three years after the American Center in Paris suspended its activities and put its celebrated Frank Gehry building up for sale, a new and different showcase for the cultural interchange between the United States and France is opening in Paris this summer.

description: Attorney General John Ashcroft today postponed Wednesday's planned execution of Timothy J. McVeigh until June 11, saying the F.B.I.'s failure to turn over to defense lawyers more than 3,000 pages of interview reports challenged the integrity of the nation's system of justice.

title: Weekend Rates in L.A.
description: Is there anything to do in "downtown" Los Angeles? Here's a way to find out: the Omni Los Angeles Hotel, in the heart of the city's downtown business and financial districts, sells a Weekend City Lights package through Dec. 31 for $119 a night (good Friday through Sunday) with free parking. The hotel is near the Staples Center, Little Tokyo, the outdoor summer jazz concerts at Watercourt Plaza and Olvera Street. Taxes and tips are extra; subject to availability. Information: (213) 617-3300 or www.omnihotels.com .

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Aid Groups Pressured
description: In their campaign of intimidation against companies and organizations that have laid off or fired workers, militants from President Robert Mugabe's party have pressured at least two orphanages in the capital, Harare, demanding money for dismissed employees, according to local news reports. Major aid agencies like CARE International have been approached as well. The party's supporters hope to reclaim some of the poor city dwellers who backed the new opposition party last year. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Ssangyong Has Profit
description: The Ssangyong Motor Company, a motor vehicle manufacturer that specializes in sports utility vehicles, made an operating profit of $20.7 million in the first quarter of this year from sales of 31,646 vehicles, up 7.8 percent from the first quarter of last year. The company, once part of the Ssangyong Group, was taken over by Daewoo Motor in the depths of Korea's economic crisis in December 1997 and then placed in the hands of creditors when the entire Daewoo Group collapsed in mid-1999. The creditors, looking for a buyer independently from efforts to sell Daewoo Motor to General Motors, have so far found no one willing to place a bid. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Saturday about ''Decreation,'' an opera by Anne Carson at the Culture Project in the East Village, omitted the identity of Ms. Carson's musical collaborator. He is Jean-Pierre Leduc. The review also misstated the surname of the actor who played Hephaistos in Part 1 of the work. He is Larry Pine, not Price.

title: Making a Fuss Over Faith
description: ''I don't want you to be out there like a Methodist church,'' said Clarence Fountain, leader of the Blind Boys of Alabama, on Tuesday at the Bottom Line. ''I'm a Baptist, and I like to hear some fuss.'' The audience responded in the only proper way, hollering and stomping up a storm.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Boy Pleads Guilty To Bomb Plot
description: A 15-year-old boy in Savannah, who was accused of plotting to bomb a middle school, pleaded guilty to juvenile charges of conspiracy, bomb possession and making terroristic threats. The 15-year-old boy and a 14-year-old boy who pleaded guilty to similar charges face a maximum sentence of five years in juvenile detention when they are sentenced on Monday. The authorities raided the homes of 11 students on April 11 after classmates reported a plot to bomb West Chatham Middle School in Pooler, near Savannah. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: AT&T Gives Details on Pending Breakup
description: AT&T provided new details yesterday of its plan to split into four companies, showing that its money-losing AT&T Broadband business, the smallest of the four operations in terms of revenue, will be saddled with the largest debt load.

title: Strike Is Planned by Drivers Of Shuttle Service to Airports
description: Union drivers at Connecticut Limousine, the largest privately owned transportation service between Connecticut and metropolitan New York's three major airports, were poised to go out on strike starting Saturday, union officials said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: No Surrender In Textbook Clash
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said Japan would not revise a recently approved history textbook that has drawn strong protests from China and North and South Korea. Critics say the middle-school book, written by right-wing academics, glosses over Japan's wartime aggression. On Thursday, South Korean lawmakers went to court in Tokyo to try to halt publication of the book, scheduled to be circulated next year. Calvin Sims (NYT)

title: INSTINET GROUP ADVANCES ITS PROTRADER GROUP BID
description: The Instinet Group, seeking to enhance its services for individual investors, reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the ProTrader Group for about $150 million. ProTrader, based in Austin, Tex., provides electronic brokerage services that give customers direct access to stock trading. The company's chief customers are private individuals, according to Jim Herbold, ProTrader's chief information officer. Similarly, Instinet, based in New York, operates an electronic marketplace that permits clients to enter their own orders to buy and sell stocks traded on the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange. The company, a unit of the Reuters Group, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise almost $400 million through an initial public offering.

title: STARMEDIA, AN INTERNET COMPANY, SET TO CUT 200 JOBS
description: StarMedia Network Inc., an Internet company that aims at Latin American customers, said that it would eliminate about 200 jobs, or 25 percent of its work force, and had a narrower first-quarter loss. The company will take a $4 million to $6 million charge in the second quarter to cover the job cuts and other restructuring costs, a spokeswoman, Brooke Harlow, said late Thursday. StarMedia, based in New York, has about 800 full-time employees, she said. The company, whose shares have fallen 89 percent in the last year, said its loss narrowed to $31.2 million, or 46 cents a share.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: A Slap At Taiwan
description: Vincent Siew, a former prime minister of Taiwan from the long-ruling Nationalist Party, which lost the presidency last year, held talks in Beijing with China's top foreign policy official, Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen. China has shunned Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, refusing to meet him unless he accepts the ''one China'' principle, and has met with opposition leaders like Mr. Siew in an effort to isolate and pressure him. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Field Trip to Sicily Helps Youngstown Face Latest Indictment

Traficant Jr., and his flamboyant denunciations of the federal government as organized-crime investigators closed in on him.

title: 2 Candidates For Mayor Lead Debate
description: Of the four Democratic candidates for mayor, Peter F. Vallone and Alan G. Hevesi are the most alike. They both come from Queens. They are both relatively moderate in their views. They both market their credentials in similar ways. And they are both battling for support from many of the same voters and the same political leaders.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Clinton Speaks to Investors
description: Former President Bill Clinton headed back to New York after a stopover in Shanghai where he spoke to prospective China investors at a conference sponsored by Crdit Lyonnais Securities. Mr. Clinton met President Jiang Zemin of China earlier at a conference in Hong Kong. At both conferences he spoke about the need for China to enter the World Trade Organization as soon as possible. Talks in Geneva on China's entry to the organization have been stalled since an American spy plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet in April. The delay threatens to push China's entry into the global body into next year. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: How The New Yorker Took Wing In Its Larval Years With Ross
description: Harold Ross knew that you can't choose your family or your birthplace, but you can always choose where to live. When he founded The New Yorker in 1925, he captured the Jazz Age ambiance of popping Champagne corks, Broadway lights and ultradry wit that still exerts a mythic pull on outsiders who flock to New York and decide to call it home. Oddly enough, the magazine that came to represent the city's sophistication was created by a miner's son and high school dropout from Colorado.

Senate Democrats still resent the long procedural delays that Republicans imposed on President Clinton's nominees, and threaten to follow suit if the Bush appointments prove too conservative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTDIENER, RUTH JENTZER
description: GOTTDIENER - Ruth Jentzer. Camp Ranger's Aunt Ruth's long and full life ended peacefully on May 10, 2001. Born July 21, 1903, Ruth spent her life helping make the life of others more meaningful. Mother to Stephen and Phyllis, loving grandmother to Gary, Scott, Sheryl and Karen, adoring great grandmother to Adam, Jared, Dana and Emma. A civic leader in Brooklyn, NY, served as President of various PTA's and the UPA as well as past President of the Brooklyn Chapter of NCJW. In her early years as a dancer, trained under Martha Graham and taught Modern Dance from her studio in Brooklyn. Upon her move to Florida she quickly became an involved citizen assuming the Presidency of the Okeechobee Chapter of NCJW soon after her arrival in Florida. She continued her involvement in civic affairs until her death. A vigorous person who swam every day. For over sixty years she was involved in childrens camping, a past Board Member of the American Camping Association and for 40 years Head Counselor/Director of Camp Rangers Girls Camp. She gave enormous time and effort to insure the well being and molding of youth with whom she came in contact. Adored by her contemporaries, she was always involved in local community affairs. Aunt Ruth as she was affectionately called touched the lives of thousands and will indeed be missed. Services at The Riverside, 180 West 76 St, NY, on Tuesday, May 15 at 11:45 a.m.

title: Business; As Power Prices Surge, Montana, Too, Asks Why
description: THE last large-scale metal mine is silent in this city perched in the Rocky Mountains. The 170-ton, house-sized ore-hauling trucks, which once rumbled with loads 24 hours a day, have not fired up their engines since last summer. Nor have the conveyors, the crushers, the concentrators and the grinders. And most of the 320 workers who carved out a living extracting copper, molybdenum and silver from the 600-foot deep Continental Pit have scattered to other states and other jobs.

title: Cinderella, on Her Toes
description: The fairy tale ''Cinderella'' has long found forms of expression beyond the pages of children's storybooks. The American Repertory Ballet brings its newly choreographed version to the State Theater in New Brunswick next weekend. American Repertory's rendering, by its artistic director Graham Lustig, blends new and old elements, using Prokofiev's score but expanding the children's roles to take advantage of the troupe's affiliation with the Princeton Ballet School. This Cinderella has cricket and dragonfly escorts, as well as Time dwarfs who pop out menacingly as the clock strikes midnight. There are plot tinkerings too: the Fairy Godmother first appears as a street person to whom Cinderella is generous. Leslie Kandell

Nationwide, roads are congested an average of six hours each workday. The report cited a dramatic jump in daily vehicle miles traveled, which went from 183,000 in 1982 in the nnorthern region to 257,000 in 1999 and, in South Jersey, from 51,000 to 76,000. title: 10 Drive-Ins Worth A Detour
description: THE drive-in movie has been part of the American summer since 1933, when Richard Hollingshead built the first drive-in theater in Camden, N.J. A canny invention that recognized that while Americans love to get into the car and go somewhere, they resist actually experiencing the outside world, the drive-in caught on quickly. By the start of World War II, there were 100 scattered across the country; the post-war period's entertainment-hungry young families further fueled their growth, and by around 1960, there were 5,000 drive-ins. Today only some 500 survive, but a small resurgence seems under way: more than 40 have reopened or have been built from scratch in the last five years. If the summer awakens the urge to watch a first-run movie without leaving the car -- or spending a lot -- here are 10 of the best drive-in operations we know, listed in alphabetical order by location.

That compared with 38 percent in 1999 and 35.5 percent in 1998, according to the American Management Association, which conducted the survey in January and released the results last week.

title: Yes to More Energy, But Not With Shoreham
description: To suggest that the Shoreham nuclear plant could have solved our energy problems [letter, May 6] is absolutely crazy. If Shoreham would have started, who knows what health and safety problems would have resulted? Long Islanders fought it because they did not want to live in the shadow of the nuclear menace and we knew that radiation causes cancer and reactors are complex machines that are not foolproof. The goal of those who opposed Shoreham was to ensure that we had safe, clean energy for our Island and this goal has yet to be realized.

title: May 6-12; Kentucky's Foals Dying
description: The bad news started leaking out a few days after the running of the Kentucky Derby. Hundreds of pregnant mares on horse farms throughout central Kentucky have been losing their foals due to a mysterious illness that scientists say might be a result of a fungus growing in the state's famous bluegrass. From April 28 to May 11, 386 stillborn or spontaneously aborted foals were brought to the University of Kentucky for examination. The horse breeding industry stands to lose tens of millions of dollars, perhaps hundreds of millions. Kentucky normally produces about 10,000 thoroughbred foals each year, accounting for one-third of the thoroughbreds born in the country. Edward Wong

title: Smithsonian Benefactors
description: To the Editor:

It's said that parents spend the first 2 years of their children's life wanting them to stand up and talk and the next 18 years wanting them to sit down and be quiet. Brett Banfe, 19, of Haddonfield has complied with the second part. His kung fu instructor had told him he talked too much and listened too little and gave him the idea of taking a vow of silence. Good idea, Brett thought, and since September he has not talked, using e-mail and facial expressions to communicate, and he plans to stay quiet for a year. He's a freshman at William Paterson University in Wayne, where he doesn't raise his hand in class. He wants to use the publicity he has gotten for his project to encourage an hour of silence for other students on May 23 starting at 10 a.m. Students might use the time to write an essay or to think about what listening means to them, he says. Discussion will follow.

So he took his amazing band, which included Charlie (Bird) Parker, John Birks (Dizzy) Gillespie and Art Blakey, to a Negro establishment, the Riviera Club, where they played with fiery beauty before a large, enthusiastic black audience -- and hurled a lightning bolt of inspiration at an 18-year-old trumpeter named Miles Davis.

title: Tunnel Vision
description: Colson Whitehead warily approached the cold, abandoned tunnel and ventured inside. ''Water was dripping everywhere,'' he recalls. ''It was really dank and muddy.'' As his eyes adjusted to the darkness, he tried to block out the graffiti covering the tunnel's slick walls and summon a sense of grandeur. After all, he was standing inside the very mountain that, according to Appalachian legend, had been blasted through with the help of John Henry, the fabled ''steel-driving man.'' The black laborer's brawny exploits in building the C&O Railroad had inspired a famous folk ballad -- as well as the novel Whitehead was struggling to write. He wanted to feel transported.

title: On Writers and Writing; Fearful Symmetry
description: WILLA CATHER wrote that the title of her 1915 novel, ''The Song of the Lark,'' was inspired by ''a rather second-rate'' painting in the Chicago Art Institute that shows a peasant girl alone in a field listening to a bird. What's the connection to the tale of the young girl from Moonstone, Colo., who became a great Wagnerian soprano? No prettified comparison of skylark to soprano, Cather sniffed: ''The title was meant to suggest a young girl's awakening to something beautiful.'' Cather used one art to help represent another. To see the William Blake exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art -- the books he wrote in his own hand and illustrated with his own engraving -- is to see the primal relation between word and image renewed. It's a relation we find mostly in children's books and comics now, or in those deluxe limited and costly editions with illustrations commissioned from a famous artist by the publisher.

title: Footnotes; What's Modern Now
description: Just because you've bought a 1950's modern house doesn't mean you have to fill it with postwar classics. Although they're now regarded as giants of 20th-century design, Eames, Nelson, Bertoia and company were upstarts once. At this year's International Furniture Fair in Milan, there was some genuine innovation, employing new materials and technologies amid all the upholstered wannabes and colored-plastic fashion victims. For example: 1. The B.L.O. light took fairgoers' breaths away. Designed for Flos by Marcel Wanders, who seems destined to become design's poet laureate, it turns on or off with a single puff, via an electronic sensor. 2. The Bikini lounge chair, by Franco Bizzozzero for Bonacina Pierantonio, uses translucent plastic to give an old standby -- tube-wrapped outdoor furniture -- a glamorous makeover. 3. Carlotta de Bevilacqua's adjustable, polycarbonate Sui light for Artemide has an 18-L.E.D. light source instead of bulbs. 4. The Table That Eats Chairs, still in prototype form only for Cassina, is Ron Arad's latest mad-genius moment. What appear to be drawers under the plastic-topped table unfold into -- presto! -- molded-plastic chairs. 5. At Driade, Philippe Starck's Jelly Slice glass-topped table winningly combines whimsy and common sense; it becomes a bench when a polyurethane gel cushion is added. 6. Looking like an otherworldly gumdrop, Denis Santachiara's polyurethane-foam, Lycra-covered Marocchino pouf -- for Campeggi, a company known for its witty convertible furniture -- conceals a 24-watt light bulb. 7. Mario Bellini's Vol au Vent chair for B&B Italia is covered in a polyamide and stainless-steel fabric. 8. The Brazilian brothers Fernando and Humberto Campana's penchant for humble materials inspired their Papel cardboard sofa for Edra. 9. Carved wood is hardly revolutionary, but it sure looks modern in William Sawaya's Modovar chair for Sawaya & Moroni. 10. Mark McKenna and Jason Klimoski showed their lighted umbrella, Blame Sid, at Ingo Maurer. Tiny, rechargeable lithium batteries power the fluorescent tube. 11. Among Cappellini's many ahead-of-the-curve offerings was Fabio Novembre's Org Prototipo, a table with a glass top and 171 rope legs. (Don't worry: six of them are reinforced with metal.) 12. Illuminating Cappellini's exhibition was the Flying Light, a Starck design for Flos; it hovers gracefully in a helium-filled mylar balloon. Text by Pilar Viladas

title: How Do You Make a Movie Sing?
description: Julie Andrews is about to sing. No, not the actual Julie Andrews, whose vocal cords were crippled in a 1997 throat operation. I mean the iconic Julie Andrews: the one twirling in a dirndl, with the Alps looming and the Nazis lurking. That's the Julie you see right off the bat, on the giant mural at the end of a long allee of palms and parking spaces, as you enter the 20th Century Fox lot, in Los Angeles. Unreasonably happy and achingly youthful, she looks for all the world as if she were about to launch into the title song from -- well, you know. Everyone knows; it's surely one of the best-known movies ever made. Still, it comes as something of a surprise that Fox hasn't painted Julie over with, say, Leonardo DiCaprio, that they would devote such prime space to a nearly ancient musical. Or for that matter, to a musical at all; Fox hasn't made a good one in decades. But musicals are about nothing if not militant optimism, and so Julie is frozen there, waiting to ''sing once more'' -- and many of us are waiting to listen.

But this year they seem so global. Even World War II will be seen from at least four vantage points (Hawaii, Greece, France and Czechoslovakia). title: Theories of Connectivity

These products have very short lives, typically less than two years for a cell phone, and they contain many toxic materials, including mercury, cadmium, lead and brominated flame retardants. There is talk of throwaway versions of phones and electronic devices. What are we planning to do with all the waste generated when we discard these products?

title: Letting Go of McVeigh
description: 'I wanted to stick my thumbs into Timothy McVeigh's windpipe and crush his larynx,'' says Patrick Reeder, sitting at a table in a McDonald's in Oklahoma City on a gray Saturday afternoon. Fifteen feet away, children are throwing French fries and swimming in a sea of plastic balls, oblivious to our conversation. ''You die very slowly that way,'' Reeder continues. ''You basically suffocate.'' He is a strong, wiry 40-year-old man who spent 14 years in the Marine Corps and now teaches football at a local high school. You get the feeling he knows what he's talking about. ''But before he was gone,'' Reeder adds, his eyes burning, ''I wanted to take out a knife and begin slicing off parts of his anatomy, starting with his most private parts first.''

title: A Garden to a Modern Martyr Keeps a Memory Green
description: For Josephine Kubiaczyk, spring means packing a worn plastic bag with seedlings and gardening tools and walking three blocks from her home on Eckford Street to the intersection of Bedford and Nassau Avenues. There, she spends most of her day tending a quarter-acre of tulips, daffodils and lilacs in a small garden surrounding a statue. The statue memorializes the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, a slain Polish hero associated with the Solidarity movement.

title: Swaggering Sexuality Before the Mandated Blush
description: THEY were often called Lil or Lily, a moniker less redolent of a flower in its first white freshness than of the siren scent of a worldly wise broad -- especially when accompanied by a warning prefix. There was Marlene Dietrich's feather-bedecked adventuress in ''Shanghai Express.'' (''It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily.'') Or the heroine of Mae West's notorious play ''Diamond Lil.'' (When Paramount bought the property, it nervously changed the title to ''She Done Him Wrong'' and called the character Lady Lou, in the misplaced hope of refining her image.) There was also Lil Andrews, Jean Harlow's irrepressible gold-digging secretary, in ''Red-Headed Woman.'' And Barbara Stanwyck's Lily Powers in ''Baby Face,'' sleeping her way up the corporate ladder. And Lily, alias Mlle. Vautier (Miriam Hopkins), the slyly amoral thief of ''Trouble in Paradise.''

title: The Last Straw
description: As a longtime Red Sox fan and Yankees ''hater,'' I can remember enjoying a bitter ballgame between the two rivals on a warm September afternoon in 1998. Blaring from my hoarse vocal cords came that derisive chant ''DAR-ryl, DAR-ryl.'' I hope it's not too late, but I would like to express my deepest apology to Strawberry. Great job, Michael Sokolove.

title: Dateline: Paris
description: String of Pearls

title: A Ramble Around the Battery
description: LOWER Manhattan is tranquil at dawn on a Friday in April as I head down Pearl Street, binoculars in hand, toward Battery Park. Though the present waterfront is still a few blocks away, in Colonial times I'd have been mucking here in the oyster beds at Manhattan's original shoreline.

title: Dali Museum
description: To the Editor: It is with two grateful yet furious hands that I applaud Francine Prose's article ''A Museum in Florida for a Spanish Original,'' (April 22) on the Dali Museum in St. Petersburg.

title: Presto! Disappearing Roofs Appear on Low-Priced Cars
description: FOR years, designers have been trying to provide the greatest possible interior space in their cars. More and more, they are opening automobiles to the whole outdoors, at least when the weather is good.

title: Cheney Ever More Powerful As Crucial Link to Congress
description: A dozen House Republicans from California were seething when they met with Vice President Dick Cheney last week to discuss the state's power crisis.

title: ON THE WATER WITH: THE FISHERMEN; A 40-Year Love Affair With the Bass
description: I KNEW the minute I ambled over to their boat that whatever they did, they were the genuine article. If they were plumbers, the sinks and toilets and showers they installed never leaked. If they were accountants, their figures added up; mechanics, their engines purred.

title: Nancy Turner, Gideon Bernstein
description: Nancy Carolyn Turner, a daughter of Sarah Thomas Turner of Reston, Va., and Henry Brown Turner IV of Paradise Valley, Ariz., was married yesterday evening to Gideon Hodes Bernstein, the son of Antonia and David Bernstein of Bronxville, N.Y. Rabbi Lev Baesh officiated at the Sebasco Harbor Resort near Bath, Me.

title: Style; Inside The Box
description: Matt Kahn has been a modernist since modernism was new. But he knows that when it comes to designing a room, it's all in the mix -- Eames, Nelson and Bertoia are great, but don't forget the antique piano and the African masks. That's why Kahn, who has taught design at Stanford University since 1949, was hired in the late 1950's (along with his wife, Lyda, who died in 1990) to decorate model houses for Joseph Eichler, the legendary West Coast developer who brought modern design to affordable housing in the 1950's and 60's and who made Eichler Homes the architecturally enlightened counterpart to Levitt & Sons. And that is also why Kahn's own house, a 1959 Eichler in Stanford, Calif., still looks right after more than 40 years.

title: How Not to Blend In
description: Coco Chanel claimed that fashion starts on the streets. If that's true, it has taken 50 years for camouflage-patterned clothing to reach from the post-World War II surplus stores to the rarefied Dior salon in Paris: top far right, a Dior spring gown. Decades before Paris discovered the military print, hippies, punks and bike messengers adopted the pattern as a sign of rebellion. Today's deluge of camouflage clothing stretches from $15 T-shirts to $30,000 couture gowns.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-13-01; The Myth of Fingerprints
description: Future historians of science and law may well date the beginning of the end of fingerprinting to the opening night of the third season of ''The Sopranos.'' Coked to the gills, Christopher Moltisanti, Tony Soprano's nephew, brings Livia Soprano's wake to an absurd anticlimax as he muses on the claim that no two fingerprints are exactly alike. For scientists to know this, Christopher reasons, they would have to get everyone in the world together in one room to check. And not just everyone in the world, but everyone who ever lived. Since this would be impossible -- even using computers -- he concludes, ''They got nothin.'''

title: Margaret Schafer, Joseph Gallin
description: Margaret MacGillivray Schafer and Joseph William Gallin were married yesterday by the Rev. Daniel H. Schoonmaker at St. Hubert's Episcopal Church in Kirtland Hills, Ohio.

title: May 6-12; The Millionaire Has Landed
description: American space capsules always splash down and the shuttle flies in from the cosmos like an airliner, but the California millionaire Dennis A. Tito, returning from his historic jaunt to the International Space Station plopped down from his visit to the International Space Station on the hard steppe of Kazakhstan. It's a landing mode Russia prefers since the country stretches over 11 time zones and is an easy target to hit. Mr. Tito, the world's first paying space tourist, called the jolt back to Earth a ''soft landing'' from ''paradise,'' but, gravity-deprived, he could barely stand up during his first minutes back. His trip was opposed by NASA and defiantly approved by the Russian space agency, which desperately needed the $20 million air fare Mr. Tito reportedly paid. Patrick E. Tyler

title: From the Tinderbox Of a Friendship, Comedy With Spark
description: KNOWN, according to the encyclopedia, for the manufacturing of farm equipment and the growing of mint, South Bend, Ind., is not the first location that would suggest itself to someone story-boarding the birth of a hot Hollywood partnership. Nevertheless, it was down its clean streets that Jon Favreau and Vince Vaughn, creators of ''Swingers,'' the fringe-of-the-movie-business comedy that catapulted its writer, Mr. Favreau, into a series of development deals, Mr. Vaughn into a leading role in Steven Spielberg's ''Lost World,'' and ''you're so money'' into an indie-cult catch phrase, discovered each other in the fall of 1992.

title: Coffee and Charm, Not From Seattle
description: THE bottomless cup of coffee. The waitresses who sing out your first name when your order is ready. The dimly lighted, music-free room with the worn wooden floors and the small wooden tables and chairs. All are among the enduring, funky charms of the Hungarian Pastry Shop, which is celebrating an important anniversary next month.

title: Bronxville Journal; Mother's Day? Florists Love and Love It Not
description: There is a type of man who will walk into a flower shop and say he's in trouble. He's done something wrong or forgotten someone, and he needs a special flower to make it right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, MORTIMER
description: RESNICK-Mortimer. On May 11, 2001. Loving husband of the late Natalie Sisskin Resnick. Cherished friend of Arlyne Ettinger. Devoted father of Ann and Mel, Robert and Valeria, Carol and Howard. Adoring grandfather of Adam, Michelle, Jodi, Alexis, Brett, Jessica and Michael. He lived for his family and friends and will be missed by all.

title: Letters From the Past
description: One may not consider the link between 16th-century typography and current book design, but there it is, on bookstore shelves: Garamond No. 3. The typeface, designed in 1919 by two Americans after a centuries-old style, has been sprouting on books with buzz by mediagenic young authors. It is recognizable from McSweeney's, Dave Eggers's literary journal. It also appeared on his book, ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius'' (Simon & Schuster, 2000). Last fall, Random House adopted it for Lucinda Rosenfeld's ''What She Saw''; then came Rick Moody's story collection, ''Demonology,'' and Sarah Stonich's novel, ''These Granite Islands.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Yorktown, N.Y.
description: One of Westchester's most northern townships, it values its sense of country, and it draws young families seeking a child-centered place. By Elsa Brenner

description: Here are dry, white summer refreshers at Best Cellars, 1291 Lexington Avenue (87th Street), where most wines cost under $15.

description: When the real estate giant Coldwell Banker wanted to make buying and selling a house easier, it decided to adopt a mainstay of the hotel industry.

title: The Last Straw
description: Let's keep the sad saga of Darryl Strawberry in perspective. The Oklahoma City bombing was an American tragedy. The Columbine massacre was an American tragedy. The story of a wealthy and talented man who became a self-indulgent, drug-addicted shell of himself after being given second, third and fourth chances is not an American tragedy. It is the story of an American loser.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, PETER F.
description: THOMPSON-Peter F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Peter F. Thompson, associated with The Times from 1973 to 1978.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULVERMACHER, LOUIS CECIL
description: PULVERMACHER-Louis Cecil, of 53 Ore Hill Road, Lakeveille, CT suddenly May 7, 2001. Was a retired trial attorney. Millbrook School Board 1995-1998. Was Lakeville resident 10 yrs. Member of Millbrook Rod & Gun Club. Served aboard USS Charles Sperry, USN during Korean conflict. Born NYC son of the late Joseph & Lucille Pulvermacher. Educated Horace Mann School, Franklin & Marshall College, U. of Penn Law School. Married May 17, 1974 to Jo Kuchai who survives. Also Louis and Andrew of CT., Robin of CA., and Stanley of NY. Funeral 11 A.M., Thursday, May 10, 2001 at Union Fields Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Mother's Day Muddle
description: Afraid of betraying her real mother, Caitlin (Lindsay Felton, above right) refuses to help Griffen when he enters Dori (Cynthia Belliveau, left) in a Mother of the Year contest on ''Caitlin's Way,'' tonight at 8 on Nickelodeon.

title: At Annual Meetings Around the World, the Shots Aren't Heard; The Meeting Is Bite-Sized, Too
description: The peanut butter-filled cheese crackers and other vending-machine snacks of Lance Inc. are unpretentious and utilitarian. So it is no surprise that the company's annual meeting last month was a spartan, quick affair in an employee cafeteria at a cracker-and-chip plant adjoining the headquarters in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Habitats/East 49th Street Between Third and Lexington Avenues; Temporary and Furnished
description: AS an executive for Burson-Marsteller, the big public relations agency, Chet Burchett has always traveled a lot. Quite often, he has stayed at one of the W hotels, hip places with tiny potted lawns in the bedrooms and stylish customers in the lobby.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for MARTIN REYNOLDS; A Computer Price War Leaves Buyers Smiling
description: PERSONAL-COMPUTER shoppers may not realize it, but they are benefiting from a price war among suppliers desperate for their business. Price cuts on PC's may seem like business as usual. After all, the PC industry routinely pares prices as components improve. But the new bargains also reflect a brawl unlike any the industry has seen. Martin Reynolds, an analyst at Gartner Dataquest in San Jose, Calif., spoke last Thursday about the causes and effects. BARNABY J. FEDER

title: Contributors' Role
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Films; 'Apocalypse' Then, and Now
description: BY 1976, Francis Ford Coppola had made the two parts of ''The Godfather'' and ''The Conversation.'' He had won the Oscar for best picture twice and for best director once and, in 1974, he had had two films -- ''The Godfather Part II'' and ''The Conversation'' -- nominated for best picture. It was easy to think that he had made it in every way: whether he did something large, grand and public, or something small, private and artistic, he was a champion. He was very rich, still young, and he had become a kind of god in the San Francisco area. In an age crowded with film students, his protg George Lucas had already made ''American Graffiti'' and was off to England to shoot a thing called ''Star Wars.''

title: Leonard's 61 Puts Him A Stroke Off the Lead
description: Until today, Justin Leonard had never played his best golf at the Byron Nelson Classic, even though he lives only a half-hour drive from the tournament site. Perhaps Leonard was trying too hard to impress his family, his friends and his fans, who have rooted for him over the years but who have often left disappointed.

title: At Annual Meetings Around the World, the Shots Aren't Heard; Haute Cuisine But Little Drama
description: French shareholder meetings, traditionally listless rubber-stamp affairs, have occasionally grown livelier in recent years as activist shareholders, often spurred by American financiers, have taken to challenging management on questions of strategy, executive appointments and corporate governance.

title: May 6-12; Misdemeanor Charges For Cincinnati Officer
description: It was difficult to tell whether Cincinnati's racial tensions were eased or heightened by a grand jury's decision to file misdemeanor charges against a white policeman for shooting an unarmed black man whose death prompted protest and violence last month. Blacks who accuse the city police of racial profiling said felony charges were in order. Defenders of the policeman, Officer Stephen Roach, said the misdemeanor charges amounted to a split-the-baby attempt to pacify the city. He allegedly offered investigators contradictory versions of the shooting during a foot chase, drawing charges of negligent homicide and obstructing official business. Francis X. Clines

title: From Digital To Disney, Ballet Bows To Youth
description: THE dance equivalent of the search for the holy grail is finding a work with the appeal of ''The Nutcracker,'' ''The Wizard of Oz,'' ''Riverdance'' and ''The Lion King'' rolled into one. ''Every arts organization is wanting to bring families to the theater,'' said Kevin McKenzie, artistic director of American Ballet Theater. ''You don't wake up at age 25 and say let's go to the ballet.''

title: Make It More of the Same but, You Know, Different
description: DAN TAYLOR sat at his computer monitor, running the scene backward and forward, backward and forward. ''This is one of our new creatures for this movie,'' he said, as a 65-foot-tall spinosaurus turned, leapt forward and gobbled up a screaming actor. ''So this one, obviously, we built from scratch for this movie. Notice the movement of the muscles under the skin.''

title: Mexican Ports Open a Coast
description: TWO big new ports for cruise ships are opening this year on the Yucatn peninsula in Mexico, and while they promise to bring thousands of tourists to popular destinations, one of them also opens up one of the last unspoiled reaches of the Caribbean to development.

title: Pro and Con of Permitting Teenage Pros in N.B.A.: THE COACH; Value of Education Must Be Considered
description: I've always been a large person and at the age of 13 I was big enough to drive a car. I had the desire and the ability, but was not allowed to drive. I might have been able to captain a ship, perform surgery, pilot a plane or start a family, but society didn't want me to do any of those things either. We establish minimum ages for drinking, voting, smoking, marrying, renting a car, going to the movies and working. We do this not based on the individual but because of the larger needs of society.

title: The Nation: A Conspiracy So Vast; How Crimes Become Obsessions
description: THE disclosure that the Federal Bureau of Investigation withheld documents from Timothy McVeigh's lawyers seems certain to ignite a controversy that will burn for years, perhaps decades.

title: Sara Bethell, Gene Clark

description: BRUNO-Thomas A. Of Los Angeles passed away on April 8, 2001 at the age of 49 after a brief illness-16 years. He is survived by his parents, his beloved sister Anne, and cherished nephews Christopher and Kevin. He also leaves behind his best friend and life partner, Kevin Ritter. Memorial arrangements are pending. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to either the Elizabeth Taylor AIDS Foundation (POB 55995, Sherman Oaks, California 91413), or Actors & Others for Animals (11523 Burbank Boulevard, North Hollywood, California 91601).

title: GOING OUT
description: An guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Lollipops to Lipstick
description: Ashley Rose Orr stars in ''Child Star: The Shirley Temple Story,'' tonight at 7 on ABC. Based on the autobiography of Shirley Temple Black, the film follows the dimpled darling as she sings and dances her way through Hollywood and the Depression into a surprisingly well-adjusted adolescence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZ, JESSIE I.
description: KURZ-Jessie I. A beloved aunt to countless nieces and nephews, devoted wife of the late Aaron Kurz, and a friend to all with whom she came in contact, Jessie I. Kurz passed away on May 8, 2001, at the age of 97. Mrs. Kurz, affectionately known by everyone as just ''Aunt Jessie,'' was a pioneer in psychoanalysis and a contributor to many worthy causes. Those of us who knew her will always treasure her warmth, sensitivity, practicality and understanding. The celebration of her life and teachings will resonate soundly through generations of family and friends as we all describe to our children what we learned from this truly remarkable, inspring person. Contributions may be made in her name to the Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders Association Inc. NYC Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave, 5th Floor, NY, NY 10017.

title: Corrections
description: The Vows column last Sunday, about the marriage of Kathy Geier and Rick Perlstein, misstated the given names of the bridegroom's parents. His mother is Sandi Perlstein, not Celia, and his father is Jerold Perlstein, not Gerald.

title: Study Suggests Overuse of Chemotherapy Near Life's End
description: Many cancer patients receive chemotherapy at the end of life, even if their kind of cancer is known to be unresponsive to the drugs, according to a study reported here today.

description: To the Editor:

title: MAYORAL RACES
description: The race to replace Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City, who is running for governor, will go to a runoff on June 5, between Glenn Cunningham and Tom DeGise. Mr. Cunningham, a former federal marshal for New Jersey who has the backing of the Hudson County Democratic organization, and Mr. DeGise, the city council president and recipient of Mr. Schundler's endorsement, were the top two vote getters among five candidates, none of whom won a majority. Jersey City was among 43 municipalities that held nonpartisan elections on Tuesday. Notable races included Camden's, where Acting Mayor Gwendolyn A. Faison was elected following the removal of Milton Milan on a corruption charge, and in Hoboken, where City Councilman David Roberts defeated Anthony Russo, the two-term incumbent. In Hackensack, Mayor John Zisa was re-elected, and will continue to serve alongside his brother, Charles Zisa, the police chief. Steve Strunsky

title: Marcus Camby Has Nobody to Play With
description: Perhaps Charlie Ward is small-minded enough to believe the tripe he spews. That shouldn't mean that the Knicks ought to endorse his statements by keeping him on the team. Get rid of this bigot -- he's not worth keeping, no matter how well he plays.

title: May 6-12; Boeing Picks Chicago
description: Boeing is headed to Chicago. After calling Seattle its home for 85 years, the world's largest maker of commercial aircraft said it was relocating its corporate headquarters to Chicago. Boeing picked the Windy City over Dallas and Denver. The company got millions of dollars in tax breaks and other incentives from Chicago and the state of Illinois to move about 500 employees to a downtown office tower. Boeing, whose move is part of a plan to become a diversified defense, satellite and aircraft manufacturer, said it has no plans to move its gigantic aircraft operation, which employs more than 70,000 people in the Seattle area. David Barboza

title: The Nation; Is the Business of America Business?
description: WHO governs the United States? A recent Washington Post/ ABC News poll revealed that an overwhelming majority of Americans, almost two-thirds, believe that President Bush ''cares more about protecting the interests of large business corporations'' than ''protecting the interests of ordinary working people.'' The Bush administration has made a friendly business climate its top priority, relaxing regulations and seeking to slash taxes, as the budget proposal passed by Congress last week demonstrates. The administration is expected to continue this approach with its energy policy, which will be unveiled this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, ESTELLE
description: SOLOMON-Estelle. On May 11, 2001, age 88. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Solomon M.D. Loving mother of Gail Solomon M.D. and Harvey Hecht M.D. Adoring grandmother of Daniel, Jonathan and Elizabeth. Graduate of NYU. Dedicated to family, Jewish causes and helping others, particularly in working closely with her husband in his daily medical practice. She was an energetic, intelligent and insightful person. Service Sunday 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory to Temple Israel Center of White Plains and Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY.

title: At Annual Meetings Around the World, the Shots Aren't Heard
description: Shareholders who turned up for the annual meeting of Freeport- McMoRan Copper & Gold this month in Wilmington, Del., never had a chance to hear James R. Moffett, the chief executive, discuss the company's performance or a proposal, from a fellow stockholder, to change the way board members are elected. Mr. Moffett didn't bother to show up. Neither did any other director.

title: OPINION; A Last Visit to My Suburban Roots
description: FOOTSTEPS echo in an empty house. I mean a house that's been stripped clean to the windows and walls, an oldish three-story house with low ceilings and wide-plank wooden floors. The real estate agent's ad called it an ''elegant English Country Tudor'' and highlighted the brick fireplace in the living room. ''Walking distance to the Long Island Rail Road,'' the ad said, and ''Children attend the Great Neck South Middle and High Schools.''

title: Footlights
description: Pupil Replaces Teacher in Quartet

title: Research in an Unreal Reality
description: IT'S not often you see a woman whose hair matches her T-shirt especially when her T-shirt is red-and-black striped. But here comes Franka Potente, marching across the patio of a venerable Hollywood hotel in romper-stomper boots and a miniskirt, with elbow-length, red-and-black striped hair and a matching stretch top.

title: High School Students' Works Make Talent Scouts of Viewers
description: AN exhibition of high school art isn't looked at just like any other show. Viewers become talent scouts, hoping to see indications of promise. They hope to find seeds, some of which might fully blossom one day. Such a show is almost always refreshing, not least because it takes viewers back to their own high school days, when they might have had their first encounter with art materials and the possibilities they afford.

title: Blues Clues
description: Nobody wants to get the blues, but lots of people want to listen to them. The newest edition of ''The Da Capo Jazz and Blues Lover's Guide to the United States,'' by Christiane Bird, available this month, helps find where jazz and the blues are played and where they came from. It looks at the music scene in various cities, with listings of clubs, concert halls, festivals, musicians' homes, record stores and local radio stations that play the music. The 448-page paperback, $17.50, is available from Da Capo Press, (800) 242-7737 or www.dacapopress.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBURG, WALTER
description: MARBURG-Walter. Of Fort Lee, N.J. Beloved husband of Gerda. Loving father of Annette Berg, Mark and Susan Berg. Devoted grandfather of Jeffrey and Robert Berg. He was the Founder and President of The New Synagogue of Fort Lee. His loss will be felt by his extended family and friends from around the world. Services Monday, 12 Noon, ''GuttermanMusicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. Contributions to The New Synagogue of Fort Lee would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, LYNNE S., ESQ.
description: COOPER-Lynne S., Esq. Beloved daughter of the late Joseph and Judith Cooper. Dear sister of Rhea Greenspan. Services on Monday 1PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street & Amsterdam Avenue. Interment in Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. The family will be receiving at the Mark Hotel, 77th Street, NYC, Monday and Tuesday at 7 PM.

title: Landscape Art in Spotlight
description: Landscape art will be the theme of Artworks, an afternoon of art, music, theater, poetry and hands-on art workshops next Saturday organized by the Gallery of South Orange and the South Orange Department of Recreation and Cultural Affairs in the downtown business district, Spiotta Park and Meadowland Park, 12 to 4 p.m. The event is being held in conjunction with Earthline/Landscape, an exhibition of landscape art on display at the gallery and around town. Visitors can see painters, digital artists and other artists at work in the park. There will be free water color, collage and mixed media workshops for adults and children, African dance performances, lute music, a comedy about the future of trees and a poetry garden where visitors can hang their verse. Margo Nash

title: Not Ideal Feminism
description: To the Editor:

title: Six Children, But Who's Counting?
description: LORI and William Siegel have their hands full with four children, including twin 3-year-old boys, and a newly purchased house they are gutting and remodeling. Scheduling a bit of time when the entire family can be together is difficult.

title: Writers Are Halted Mid-Sentence as a Y Cancels Classes
description: Every week for the past three years, Susie Stulz, an Internet marketer, has walked into the West Side Y.M.C.A. on 63rd Street in search of a new career. Ms. Stulz ignores the usual attractions -- the pool and fitness machines -- and instead heads to a small classroom to talk fiction with other aspiring authors enrolled in the Writer's Voice program.

title: Made in New York: Variety of Musical Instruments
description: AMATEURS and professionals are making beautiful music on instruments handcrafted in Westchester and Putnam Counties. The area is home to makers of violins, violas and cellos; electric guitars, basses and mandolins; English horns and oboes; and two -- yes, two -- kinds of bagpipes.

title: CHERRY HILL DESEGREGATION
description: An educational research center has recommended that Cherry Hill realign its elementary school districts in order to comply with the state's order to comply with a state order to make its schools comply with racial guidelines. The recommendation came from the Equity Assistance Center, which is associated with New York University. Robert Strauss

title: Westchester Expects Less In Sales Tax Than Forecast

title: Her Art Imitates Her Life. You Got That?
description: ''Why not? Why not? Why should my poems not imitate my life?'' Louise Glck writes passionately, almost maniacally, in THE SEVEN AGES (Ecco/ HarperCollins, $23), her ninth book of poems. In life, she continues, the ''lesson is not the apotheosis but the pattern.'' If ''The Seven Ages'' is any kind of proof, she's right. It's a book in which repetition functions as incantation, forming a hazy magic that's alternately frightening and beautiful. Whether Glck is talking about her relationship with her sister, a love affair or her own grappling with the passage of time, her insistence on getting at what lies beyond the physical world through seemingly ordinary details produces raw emotion covered with a deceptively simple sheen. Although these poems are autobiographical, there's not what we've come to think of as a confessional moment among them. ''We felt safe, / meaning we saw the world as dangerous,'' she writes of herself and her sister. ''We would prevail or conquer, meaning / we saw homage as love.'' Then, plunging to the center of the odd unconscious understanding that accompanies so much of childhood, she recalls: ''It was obvious to us two people couldn't / prevail at the same time. My sister / took my hand, reaching across the flowered cushions. / Neither of us could see, yet, / the cost of any of this. / But she was frightened, she trusted me.'' It's a moment of real heartbreak, the missteps of the future weighing down the memory of this small, hopeless survival tactic, and Glck handles it with the same delicacy that makes every poem in ''The Seven Ages'' a weighty, incandescent marvel. Melanie Rehak

title: A Persian Pioneer In a Western Art
description: SHAH or desert chieftain, tourist or native, the place to have your photograph taken in Tehran at the end of the 19th century was the studio of Antoin Sevruguin. His business imprint was decorated in Farsi, French and Russian, and it bore the sign of the Persian imperial order, the Shah's stamp of approval. And should the customers have any doubt about the studio's expertise, the imprint also displayed images of photography's three distinctly un-Oriental originators: William Henry Fox Talbot, Nicphore Nipce and Louis-Jacques Mande Daguerre. The sign captures the polyglot character and the diverse clientele of Persia's first master photographer, who deserves a place among the pioneers he so revered.

title: For This Arch, the Triumph Was to Hide the Bridge
description: The Romans erected triumphal arches to commemorate emperors and military conquests. New Yorkers built one to upstage a modern eyesore.

title: From Co-Stars Turned Co-Directors, A Marriage Tale
description: ALAN CUMMING and Jennifer Jason Leigh met backstage in 1998 at the Broadway revival of ''Cabaret.'' Mr. Cumming had won virtually every award the theater world gives for his blazing performance as the musical's provocative, androgynous M.C. And Ms. Leigh, celebrated for her bold and intense performances in such films as ''Last Exit to Brooklyn,'' ''Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle'' and ''Georgia,'' was soon to join him onstage for her Broadway debut, replacing Natasha Richardson in the starring role of Sally Bowles. Doing the show together for seven months, they formed a friendship that led to their making ''The Anniversary Party,'' a digital video film, which they wrote, produced, directed and starred in. It opens on June 8.

title: THE SOPHISTICATED TRAVELER; Rajasthan
description: These days I don't often take a motorized rickshaw through streets thronged with beggars, monkeys, wandering cows and laughing children; I don't usually get to watch the sun sink over a lake palace from a private balcony, wearing a garland of marigolds, while a falcon hovers on the thermals a few yards from my face and the town below emits the throbbing of a Hindu festival. Yet this and much else seemed quite normal when I traveled through Rajasthan with my wife, Veronica, in February, and it struck me that this is one of the more discreet charms of India: that while almost every experience is, to a Westerner, awe inspiring, gruesome or bizarre, something in the manner of the people contrives to make it normal. India is one of the last surviving culture collisions the world can offer, yet, thanks to the wit and ingenuity of the people, it comes with built-in shock absorbers.

title: Kosher Steakhouse With Exotic Turns
description: YOU don't have to be Jewish to love Hamid, a new Persian-style glatt kosher steakhouse. Because glatt kosher restaurants are limited by strict dietary rules, exceptional ones are rare. Yet, Hamid, at 210 Mineola Avenue in Roslyn (516-625-6664), just off exit 37 of the Long Island Expressway, is noteworthy. Its bright yellow walls, skylights, subdued art work, cathedral ceiling, flickering Ali Baba-like multicolored hanging wall lanterns, peppy Turkish, Persian and Israeli music and effervescent young hostess from Izmir, Turkey, make people of all races, religions and nationalities feel welcome.

title: QUICK BITE/Princeton; Where the Catfish Are Always Jumping
description: At Downtown Deluxe, timing is everything. So are catfish. The 20-seat restaurant often swells with the residents of the John Witherspoon neighborhood, professors and ever-hungry undergraduates. Catfish, shipped from Mississippi, is cooked four ways: garden, baked, Cajun and Southern fried. The restaurant, a rare outpost of Southern cooking in New Jersey, has been a fixture on Leigh Street since 1988. Dinners (catfish $10.50, whiting $9.75, chicken $8.75, spare ribs $9.75) include two vegetables and a generous hunk of cornbread. The kitchen is a one-man, four-frying-pan show. The owner, George Cumberbatch, puts in 14-hour workdays, cooking up everything from a fish and grits breakfast ($6.50) to sweet potato pie ($2.50). Specials have included curry chicken ($8.75), Jamaican beef patties ($2) and cheese fries ($1.95). With help from his mother, sister and 18-year-old nephew, Mr. Cumberbatch also does some catering for Princeton University and for local church functions. He has lived on Leigh Street since moving from Barbados in 1973 and the restaurant is like an extension of his home. As for timing: closing time is a lost cause. The restaurant ''technically closes at 10,'' Mr. Cumberbatch says, but the screen door continues to creak open well past that hour. ''If need be, I'll go open up,'' he admits. Just come by for a sandwich to go, and that's need enough. Anne Ruderman

I pray and close my eyes, and the songs are going in my head, and I'm worshiping him. It's not rock. It's quiet worship music or fast celebration songs. I listen to them all the time. title: Tokyo
description: Tokyo, destroyed twice in the last 80 years, first by earthquake and then firebombed to rubble in World War II, has been on a hellbent path toward reconstruction and economic growth ever since. The resultant megalopolis sprawls for 40 miles in every direction -- factories, hotels, office buildings, cemeteries, restaurants, schools, shrines, hospitals -- arranged as if dumped out in a high wind. It is a place where people, 12 million of them -- 20 million if you count outlying communities -- travel like vast schools of fish, moving along with great purpose, jamming themselves into things.

title: Safety in Turkey
description: To the Editor: While on a visit to Istanbul early in April, I was the victim of a theft perpetrated by two confidence artists. I was approached near Taksem Square by two men who said they were Lebanese students. They had apparently overheard me seeking directions to a museum. They followed me into the museum and volunteered to translate some Arabic script on tombstones in a small graveyard. After leaving the museum, I volunteered to buy them ice cream nearby.

title: Playing the Market, Internationally
description: ONE day, early in my most recent French vacation, I resolved to conquer my fear of shopping in a foreign language -- and my desire to stay inside our garden walls, where everyone spoke my mother tongue. (My fear of French -- both the language and the people -- came from a stint in elementary school with the stern, unsmiling Mlle. LeBlonde.) So I headed for the mercantile hubbub at the foot of our street. We had traded our family house in California for one near Paris, in Joinville-le-Pont, and after several days of gathering our wits, it was time to get serious about stocking the refrigerator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKLEY, BARBARA GLASGALL
description: BERKLEY-Barbara Glasgall. On May 10, at home. Bobbie inspired family and friends with her warmth, wit, charity and love. She was a vibrant and passionate woman who frequently devoted her efforts to political and educational campaigns. She loved sports and enjoyed competing and developing her skills. Bobbie was a student in Hanya Holm's first dance class in the United States, and was an early modern dance enthusiast thanks to her avant-garde mother. She danced and performed under the direction of Margaret Dobler at the University of Wisconsin. Bobbie was a fine student and graduated from UW in 1941. May 4th was her 61st wedding anniversary, an anniversary that marked so many years of a rare marriage. From that day in September 1938, when Bobbie and Bob met at the AEPhi Sorority tea, at the University of Wisconsin, it was a continuing love affair. They eloped to Dubuque, Iowa on May 4, 1940. As a new mother during World War II, Bobbie suffered the worry of separation from her husband. Shaped by her happy childhood in the Jewish community in Paterson, NJ, she maintained a lifelong bond to that place and those people. In Hillsdale, NJ, where Bobbie and her family resided for 45 years, she was active in many community activities including drama, fund-raising for many causes, and ardent support for the Bergen YJCC and Temple Emanuel. She regarded the growth and popularity of both these institutions as miraculous. Bobbie and Bob sponsored the immigration of the Raiskin family from Russia. She considered this to be a highlight of her life, & was immensely proud of this addition to her family. Bobbie leaves her husband, Bob, a daughter, Alison and a son, Roger, as well as a sister, Judith Weiner and her sister-in-law, Jane Kantor. She also leaves her three grandchildren, Kate, Daniel, and Sarah, and a host of loving nieces and nephews. Services 11:30 AM, Sunday at Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ; burial at Temple B'nai Abraham Memorial Park, Union, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Alzheimers Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., NYC would be appreciated.

title: A Spellbinding Scottish Isle
description: Several years ago I heard about the Isle of Mull from a friend of mine whose cousin owned a castle there. It sounded like a wonderful place to visit, but when I consulted my atlas and found out where it was -- off the western coast of Scotland in the Inner Hebrides -- it seemed too far to go. Like most truly out-of-the-way places, the Isle of Mull is protected by the traveler's inability to imagine getting there. But once you do, your imagination is the first thing that Mull restores.

title: The Last Straw

title: Ideas & Trends: Taking Care; It's Not Just for Mothers Anymore
description: IN the 1960's, when women began pouring into the work force, the changes in family life were profound. By 1990, with 70 percent of the nation's children living in households where every parent was in the labor force, millions of families were groping for child care that could accommodate overtime or night shifts -- or work schedules that could bend for teacher conferences, sick children, school holidays, or ailing grandparents.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Jennifer Belle; On Familiar Turf
description: TWO friends were scouting for an apartment on Wednesday night, and also indulging in some diet-breaking noshing to cushion the trauma of it all. Jennifer Belle, a novelist and recreational crier (''I've cried five times today,'' she said), was helping her best friend, Brendan O'Meara, find a pied--terre in Manhattan. Ms. Belle had been a real estate agent at the Corcoran Group in Manhattan, an experience that turns up in her comic novel ''High Maintenance,'' published last week. She left Corcoran when Madonna bought the film rights to her first novel, ''Going Down,'' which details the colorful exploits of a college student who becomes a prostitute.

title: May 6-12; Soccer Stampede in Ghana
description: Africa's fourth soccer tragedy in a month became its deadliest, as 123 fans were killed in a soccer stampede in Accra, Ghana, during a match between two of the country's top teams. It raised to about 180 the total number of spectators killed across the continent, since 43 fans died trying to get into a packed stadium in South Africa last month. The incident also highlighted the poor security in most of Africa's stadiums. Few have security personnel managing crowds and rely instead on police officers who tend to overreact in riots by indiscriminately firing tear gas. Norimitsu Onishi

Kofi Annan, the secretary general of the United Nations, envisions a budget of $7 billion to $10 billion annually; Mr. Bush offered up $200 million. His critics said it was insufficient, but the White House said it is meant as a start, to encourage other countries to get the fund under way. David E. Sanger

title: Europe's View of the Death Penalty
description: The legal drama and publicity surrounding Timothy McVeigh point up a fact of cultural geography. America and Europe are land masses separated by both the Atlantic Ocean and enthusiasm for the death penalty. Americans who travel in Europe, whether as tourists or ambassadors, marvel at the frequency with which they are called on to defend the American legal system's reliance on capital punishment. At least among European elites, the death penalty has become an even stronger metaphor for America since the nation is led by a man who presided over 40 executions in 2000 alone and the government was preparing, until Friday, to carry out on May 16 its first federal execution in 38 years.

title: BRIEFING: CAMPFIRE BAN

The ban, a response to the 10 to 15 daily forest fires in southern parts of the state, prohibits all campfires on the ground, allowing only those elevated at least a foot. According to the chief of the forest fire service, David Harrison, the service is likely to ban all kinds of campfires if the state does not get significant rain this weekend.

While the demise of the Soviet system left only one superpower standing, it also freed scores of other nations from the gridlock of East-West confrontation, and they began to build new or stronger alliances outside Washington's reach.

Ms. Campagne has long blond hair and a piquant, heart-shaped face, and with a flick of Ms. Cosio's brush, expression flooded her pale features.

title: The Risks of a New Space Race
description: Watching Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld set a new agenda for the Pentagon is like viewing an accomplished chess player at work -- his opening moves only hint at complex and audacious strategies to come. That seemed especially so last week as Mr. Rumsfeld ordered a reorganization of the Pentagon's numerous and entangled space operations. The bureaucratic reforms are sensible and long overdue. But they also lay the groundwork for possible new American military initiatives in space that could invite a celestial arms race and transform the heavens into a future battlefield.

description: HORMAN-D. Elizabeth. At age 96. Gifted artist. Passed away peacefully on May 10, 2001. Graduated from Barnard and studied at NYC Art Students League. Beloved wife of the late Edmund Horman. Loving mother of the late Charles Horman who was killed in Chile in 1973 during Pinochet's violent coup as told in the movie Missing. Dear sister of Daniel Lazar, Lawrence Lazar and the late Ruth Lazar. Cherished mother-in-law of Joyce Horman. Elizabeth's many friends will miss her greatly. Memorial service at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue at 80th St., Wednesday, May 16th, 3PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Center for Constitutional Rights for the Charles Horman Truth Fund, POB 2331, NY, NY 10021.

title: Broad Shoulders, Gentle Shoreline

Daley Center all seem to face you, conspiring to hide Lake Michigan behind them.

title: Playing Tourist at Home in Brooklyn
description: ONE afternoon last summer I was sauntering home with a bag of vegetables when I saw something on my Brooklyn street corner that stopped me in my tracks: a red double-decker sightseeing bus and a throng of sunburned, backpack-toting tourists, chattering excitedly in some Scandinavian language.

title: Spring in Philadelphia Country
description: IN mid-April, when only the crocuses and snowdrops were out in New York and you had to look hard for the occasional brave daffodil, I jumped in the car and headed to the notch in the southeastern border of Pennsylvania, where I grew up and where spring had a head start. Along with 210,000 others, I had seen the season in previews indoors in March at the fabulously splashy Philadelphia Flower Show, where 10 acres of displays ran the gamut from elegant to wacky. Now I wanted to see spring's grand entrance, late as it was, and I had three gardens in mind.

The city has flown the flags of Spain, Mexico, the United States, the Confederacy and the United States once more. It's a rich and mingled history, as befits a city that is older than Philadelphia or Boston or New York. And one that is -- in its explosive growth -- newer than they are.

title: They Talk War, but They Shoot Movies
description: ONCE upon a time on the set of a children's movie in Paris, an American producer recounted to a reporter her love for the story on which it was based, a charming one she had been struggling to commit to film for decades. And there she was, dutifully planting kisses on the cheeks of her French colleagues. Taking Bordeaux with lunch in the canteen. Going native in cashmere, silk and pearls. ''It's hard,'' she confessed, with a stories-I-could-tell look in her eyes. ''Movies are like war.''

title: May 6-12; A Papal Pilgrimage
description: Pope John Paul II has long sought to heal ties to other world religions, in 1986 becoming the first pope ever to enter a synagogue. The latest trip for this frail, weary pope, a six-day pilgrimage following a route once taken by St. Paul, was marred by his failure to denounce the anti-Semitic remarks of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria. But it was also marked by two more historic milestones: he became the first pope to visit Greece since the Orthodox and Roman Catholic churches split in 1054, and the first to enter a mosque. Hubert B. Herring

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-13-01: Testimony; Waiting to Get Paid
description: After the Agios Minas delivered its load of South American tree stumps to port in Brunswick, Ga., in late February, the ship dropped anchor 10 miles off the coast and awaited instructions from its owners in Greece. Alas, the company had gone bankrupt. For 48 days, the captain and his crew of seven refused to leave the ship out of fear of forfeiting their wages. When food and water began to run short, a local support group for sailors, the International Seamen's House, helped out. The crew left the Agios Minas last month when a New York shipyard expressed interest in taking over the ship and paying the men. But that deal fell through. The ship will be auctioned later this week; any proceeds from the sale will first be used to pay the sailors and the captain, who remains on board. Alexandra Starr

title: Secretive Agents Of Real Estate; A Dearth of Shared Listings Makes Home-Hunting Hard

This concern may come from a belief that the artistic object is imbued with some residue of its creator's psychic energy, much as sacred artifacts or Zen ink drawings are said to pack a spiritual charge.

title: Miles Davis: The Chameleon of Cool; A Jazz Genius In the Guise Of a Hustler
description: EVIL genius.'' ''Prince of Darkness.'' ''Endearing with his music, offending with his personality.'' For nearly half a century, critics have come up with all sorts of phrases to describe the darkness and light that is Miles Davis. Miles commanded attention from every generation since the early days of the cold war, fostering undying devotion and disgust along the way. Even in death he remains one of the most revered and reviled artists on the planet. As we near his 75th birthday on May 25, Miles is everywhere, the subject of books, new musical interpretations and a flood of boxed sets and previously unreleased recordings.

What is he doing, this specter of the extreme right, haunting the hall of Bertolt Brecht? Elfriede Jelinek, the outspoken Austrian playwright of conscience, has created his dramatic persona, and Claus Peymann, the theater's new artistic director, has put him there.

title: Trieste

Perhaps it's just the setting -- the glossy, dark wood paneling, the golden walls, the marble-topped tables, the paintings of masked revelers, the uniquely Triestian mix of Vienna and Venice -- but it's easy to imagine that the elegant coffee drinker has been at that same table with his newspaper for the century or so since the cafe was founded.

title: Scrap Heap to Some, Piles of Money to Others
description: If travelers on the turnpike through Newark look down at one point, they see what appear to be giant metallic ant hills. In fact, the mounds are made up of steel gas meters, beer kegs, 20,000-pound beams from the Williamsburg Bridge, a lunch truck, wire coils of every imaginable type, buses, cars and hand-sized pieces of a 747, stacked in an imperfect pyramid 15 feet high. This is the 20-acre scrap yard of Metal Management Northeast Inc., a metal recycler on Foot of Hawkins Street that has also handled much of the metal from the Newark housing projects that have come down in recent years. All the metals are sorted, melted or crushed, then sold and reused. Alan D. Ratner, the president, and Tom Schaad, manager of the demolition division, recently described their business.

title: Zimbabwe's Spreading Misery

President Mugabe's paramilitary troops have brutalized and killed opponents; assaulted lawyers, human rights activists and democratic reformers; and invaded factories and universities as well as farms. Washington, London and Pretoria must act together to end this lawlessness before it undermines the entire region.

The police said a van struck Rabbi Kagan's car. The driver of the van, Glenroy Hunter, was treated for minor injuries and given a summons for speeding, the police said. Rabbi Kagan, 59, was an editor and translator of his spiritual leader's work, said Rabbi Moshe J. Kotlarsky, director of the International Conference of Lubavitch Emissaries.
