title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, DR. WELDON B.
description: GIBSON-Dr. Weldon B. Passed away on May 6 in his home on the Stanford University campus. A founding executive of SRI International, a non-profit research institute formerly known as ''Stanford Research Institute'', Dr. Gibson was 84 years old and is survived in loving memory by his wife Helen, son David, and grandson Ruben. Dr. Gibson was a key person at SRI for 54 of the Institute's 55 years. Throughout his remarkable career, Dr. Gibson was a leader who brought SRI to worldwide prominence. He organized more than 80 major international conferences for executives. In recognition of his contributions and achievements, SRI International founded the Weldon B. Gibson Achievement Award in his honor. This award-among the Institute's most prestigious awards, recognizes outstanding contributions that have had a noteworthy impact on the standard of living and on the peace and prosperity of society. Dr. Gibson was an active supporter to both Washington State University and Stanford University which both gave him so much as a struggling student. Memorial service will be held on July 10 at 2PM at Stanford University Memorial Church.

description: If films like ''Freddy Got Fingered'' and ''Crocodile Dundee in L.A.'' made you suspect the movie industry had been sandbagging it lately, you might be on to something. Early spring is typically when the box office hits a seasonal lull.

title: A BROAD ALLIANCE TRIES TO HEAD OFF CUTS IN MEDICARE
description: Elected officials, hospital administrators, doctors and union leaders across the country are seeking to reverse a new Medicare policy that they say will slash billions of dollars from the health care industry and force cutbacks in critical hospital services.

title: Sixth Man Performs Like Leading Man
description: Aaron McKie was honored as the best N.B.A. player off the bench this season, but today he relished his new role as a starter in the Philadelphia 76ers' lineup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MIMI
description: ROSS-Mimi. Age 67, of Shelter Island, NY. On May 12, 2001, after a brief illness. Beloved wife of Gerald. Loving mother of Glen, Andrew and Robert, and mother-inlaw of Kirsten and Mary. Adored grandmother of Anthony, Sarah, Shelley, Jake and Carolyn. Mimi lived a full and active life, both trying to help out others less fortunate and becoming involved in the community, as well as enjoying life herself. School teacher NYC public school system. Past President South Shore Section of National Council of Jewish Women. Founder, and for numerous years, coordinator of, and head instructor in, the Rockville Centre Junior Tennis League. Ran the Free Tennis Clinic at the Martin Luther King Center in Rockville Centre. Four time women's golf champion Gardiner's Bay Country Club and Gold Life Master bridge player. Mimi frequently took actions to enable those whom she thought had received bad breaks in life to get a fresh start. In addition to being a natural and accomplished all around athlete, Mimi loved the ballet and the opera, and especially loved entertaining and cooking for her many dear friends. Her high spirt, compassion, energy and love will be dearly missed. Services at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY, on Monday, May 14 at 1 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the updated television listing in Section 1 yesterday for the ''Money Talks'' program on Channel 7, about family travel, misstated the title of Wendy Perrin at Cond Nast Traveler. She is the consumer news editor; the editor in chief is Thomas J. Wallace.

title: MediaTalk; In Los Angeles, the Hubcap as Billboard
description: Worried that the dog isn't seeing enough ads lately? Shin-level sponsorship may soon be just a hailed cab away.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGELMAN, GUS
description: ENGELMAN-Gus. Former reporter for WABC Radio and the NY Journal American, adjunct professor at NYU, former president of the New York Press Club. The family of Gus Engelman deeply mourns his passing on May 7. His intelligence, wit, enthusiasm for life and love of knowledge will be greatly missed. He is survived by his wife Linda, mother Eva Engelman, brother Harold Engelman, nephew Mark Engleman, nieces Alice Engleman and Roni Bongiovianni, three grandnieces and two grandnephews. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, May 20, 2 PM, at Morrison Funeral Home, 86 Bartholdi Ave., Butler, NJ. For further information call 973-838-2290.

title: Penguins Resolve To Storm Devils' Net
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins will be pleased if the next game gets ugly. At least they want their shots on goal in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals against the Devils to look that way, even if it means shooting from awkward angles and creating traffic jams in front of the net to generate rebounds or just some hope.

title: Power Has A Lead But Settles For a Tie
description: The prayers of May Fair, the mother of the New York Power's Ronnie Fair and Philadelphia's Lorrie Fair, were answered on this Mother's Day. She asked for a tie, with both teams scoring, and her wish came true as the Power and the Charge played to a 2-2 tie tonight at Mitchel Athletic Complex.

description: This spotless city of 148,000 people an hour's drive south of Los Angeles is the largest planned community in the country, with a web of freeways feeding autos into neat patterns of eight-lane boulevards that, on normal days, are almost a balletic composition in traffic management.

description: The Olympics aren't only about harmony among nations, transcendent sportsmanship, urban image-building and all that happy-face multinational blah blah blah. In New York City, the really cool idea is to leave a legacy.

description: A new class of cancer drugs is showing promise in treating patients who have not responded to chemotherapy, researchers at a major cancer conference said this weekend.

title: R. K. Narayan, India's Prolific Storyteller, Dies at 94
description: R.K. Narayan, the literary chronicler of small-town life in South India and one of the first Indians writing in English to achieve international acclaim, died yesterday in Madras, India. He was 94.

title: Technical Debate On Insurance Data
description: In processing medical payments, the longstanding promise of computer networks has been their ability to convey insurance claims and other billing records, without need of the paperwork and documents that can be delayed in the mail or waylaid in some bureaucrat's file drawer.

title: Wary Spending By Companies Cools Economy
description: People hang on Alan Greenspan's every word, but these days they should listen to business executives like Earnest W. Deavenport and David E. Berges even more. The decisions they make are turning out to have more power to lift the economy, or keep it weak, than Mr. Greenspan's control over interest rates. And for now, corporate executives are pulling back.

title: It's Not the Economy, Stupid, in Japan
description: When Jun ichiro Koizumi became prime minister, much of Japan braced itself for the kind of sweeping economic change hinted at by a politician whose motto has been ''structural reform with no sacred cows.''

title: Sports of The Times; Trinidad Again Proves Just How Bad He Can Be
description: FELIX TRINIDAD is a bad man. Not bad in the conventional sense of wicked or wrong, but bad in the slang sense of superb -- defined in his case by being strong, fast and efficient, with power in each hand.

title: A Long Road to M.L.S. For MetroStars' Villegas
description: Susana Villegas used her savings to send her only son alone from Ecuador to live with friends in New Jersey to pursue the American dream 12 years ago. The dream of 13-year-old Petter Villegas, however, was to play soccer. Since there was no professional league when he came to the United States, Villegas wanted to return home soon after he arrived.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITTEMORE, FREDRICK O.
description: WHITTEMORE - Fredrick O. March 21, 2001, in Florida. Husband of the late Marjorie Vassar. Survived by Linda Christina of Florida, and Robert Vassar of NYC. Former owner of Dorset Inn in Vermont. Avid golfer, Middlebury College '28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARRIER, LISA
description: CARRIER-Lisa. Age 38 of New York City, NY, on May 11, 2001. Lisa's warmth, wit and beauty enchanted all who knew her. Her valiant struggle against pancreatic cancer taught us the true meaning of bravery and dignity. In her final months she earned her cerfitication to captain large for-hire sailboats and maintained her strength through a vigorous body fitness program. Lisa leaves three loving sisters, Christine, Dawn and Robin, who selflessly devoted their time to comfort her during her 18 month fight. She also leaves her brother Kip who forever has lossed a younger sister and business partner. Her nieces and nephews, Wesley, Brett and Kristen, Christopher and Lili, Jonathan and Bryan, all loose a great friend. She will also be missed by her cats, Kitty, Baxter and Theo and their Nanny Tacy. In repose at John Kritil Funeral Home, 1297 1st Ave, NY, NY Tuesday 4-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLUTZKY, OLEG (ALEC)
description: SLUTZKY-Oleg (Alec). Age 84, of Township of Washington, NJ on Friday, May 11, 2001. Husband of Olga Slutzky (nee Washnik). Father of Valentina Mescolotto, Gregory, Dennis and Timothy Slutzky. Brother of Larry and Walter Slutzky. Grandfather of seven. Son of Dimitry, a well known professor and conductor. Served in action, US Pacific Fleet, World War II. Before retiring, he was a principal in Hoyt Equipment Co. and was an active contributor to Russian Orthodox churches and charities. Oleg was an original founder in 1940 of the Capella Russian Male Chorus and sang as a beautiful second tenor. He was a member of St. John the Baptist Russian Orthodox Church, Spring Valley, NY. The family will receive their friends at Becker Funeral Home, 219 Kindermack Road, Westwood, NJ on Monday, 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Funeral service will be held at Christ the Savior Church, 365 Paramus Road, Paramus, NJ on Tuesday at 9:00 AM. Interment, St. Vladimir's Russian Orthodox Christian Cemetery, Jackson, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested for the American Heart Association, 2550 US Highway 1, North Brunswick, NJ 08902-4301.

title: MediaTalk; News Executives Playing the China Card
description: Pity Walter Isaacson, the editorial director of Time Inc. He arrived here last Tuesday after a long flight from New York -- granted, by corporate jet -- and quickly found himself in a ticklish situation.

title: Treasury to Sell Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Italians Swamp Polls
description: Silvio Berlusconi, the conservative media baron who promised to do for Italy what he has done for his business, appeared to be heading toward the chance to form Italy's next government, according to partial returns and voter surveys. His coalition led in each of the houses of Parliament, but the final results hung in the balance, as a high turnout and a shortage of polling stations forced many centers to stay open past 2 a.m. A1

title: The Sound of Protest
description: Bob Dylan turns 60 this month. It's been almost 40 years since Joan Baez took him on stage with her at the Newport Folk Festival, where he appalled just about everyone with his stridently unpretty singing voice and his raucous, edgy lyrics. He was then, at least in theory, a folk singer. But Bob Dylan wasn't interested in wistful melancholy or febrile lament. He sang about poverty and desperation; he sang about love's limitations in a voice hoarse with feeling.

title: Fulham's Owner, Al-Fayed, Kept His Promise
description: In 1997, the new owner of London's Fulham promised club supporters a future in England's Premier League within five years.

title: An Education 'Warrior' With a Soft Spot for His Boss
description: HE is a Democratic school reformer pressing the cause for a Republican president. He commands a coveted corner office in the Old Executive Office Building, next door to the White House. But Sandy Kress has planted nothing there -- not a painting or souvenir or even a framed family picture -- that would signal a desire to stay on as President Bush's senior education adviser.

title: O'Neal Gives Kings' Fans False Hope
description: Shaquille O'Neal trudged to the bench after he picked up his sixth foul with more than three minutes left in the game today, a development that brought more hope than the resigned fans at Arco Arena had known for a while.

title: Compressed Data; Reprising a Classic End, HAL Computer Perishes
description: Even in the staid world of supercomputing, life sometimes imitates art. Like its literary namesake, HAL Computer failed to survive 2001.

title: Bush Hopes to Win Backing Of Unions for Energy Plan
description: A meeting today between President Bush and labor leaders to discuss energy policy is shaping up as a crucial administration overture to the nation's labor unions, long among Mr. Bush's fiercest opponents.

title: Dick Cheney, Energy Czar
description: Soaring gasoline prices have landed President Bush in the middle of a political storm, and to some extent he has only himself to blame. Mr. Bush did not cause gas prices to rise, any more than President Bill Clinton did when prices jumped above $2 a gallon last summer. As with Mr. Clinton, there is little he can do in the short term to bring prices down. However, he set himself up, but good, for the lashing he is getting from the Democrats.

title: Far From Dead, Subsidies Fuel Big Farms
description: By any measure, Lanny Bezner is a successful family farmer. His eldest son, John, rides herd over his cattle, spread out on pastureland from here to nearby New Mexico. A younger son, Brian, looks after the farm's heavily irrigated cornfields, with help from the husband of Mr. Bezner's daughter, Virginia. As a Texas patriarch, Mr. Bezner rigorously sticks to the principle that economy of scale is the only way to survive in modern farming. The bigger the farm, the better likelihood of turning a profit, he says.

title: Perry Como, Relaxed and Elegant Troubadour of Recordings and TV, Is Dead at 88
description: Perry Como, a small-town barber from Pennsylvania whose rich voice and easy manner made him one of the nation's most popular singers and entertainers in the decades after World War II, died in his sleep at his home in Jupiter, Fla., on Saturday. He was six days short of his 89th birthday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, ELI
description: ROSEN-Eli. Beloved husband of the late Dorothy. Devoted father of Dr. Marvin Rosen, Gerald Rosen and Karen Collins. Cherished grandfather of Barbara Shoham, Steven, Alan, Jonathan and Geoffrey Rosen, Marion and Rebecca Collins. Great-grandfather of Ari and Maytal Shoham. Services Monday, 12 Noon at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Dispirited by More Than a Mere Defeat
description: The cell phone on the floor in Bernie Williams's locker kept buzzing yesterday. Someone was trying to call Williams a few minutes after the Yankees' 10-5 loss to the Orioles. The noisy ring continued a few feet from Mariano Rivera as he talked about Derek Jeter's flubbing a potential double-play grounder that would have ended a rally and about how he wound up allowing five earned runs in the 11th inning.

title: Compressed Data; After Instant Messaging Comes Instant Kibitzing
description: If you're not a teenager or a Net-chatty office worker, you may be only dimly aware of the extraordinary popularity of instant messaging -- a system in which words typed on a computer appear almost simultaneously on the screens of one or more other people.

title: Artemas Holmes Crimmins; Construction Executive, 92
description: Artemas Holmes Crimmins, former chairman and president of Thomas Crimmins Contracting, once a prominent builder in the New York City area, died on April 21 at a hospital in Boulder, Colo. He was 92 and had homes in Longmont, Colo., and Boca Grande, Fla.

title: In America; Trouble For Ferrer
description: Al Sharpton was enjoying himself. He had publicly humiliated mayoral candidate Fernando Ferrer. Whipped him good. And while Mr. Sharpton himself had been bruised in the encounter, he also had the consolation of luxuriating in the media attention that he loves so much.

title: Dropping Managerial Reins In a Now Contentious Arena
description: When James J. Schiro took over management of the New York office of the accounting firm Price Waterhouse in the late 1980's, colleagues gave him a tip about how to prepare for the job of managing within a partnership.

title: In Egypt, Law of Man Creates A Caste of Shunned Children
description: In Egypt, as in most of the Arab world, children born to women who marry foreigners often endure a painful awakening that they are not quite like other citizens. In every country except for Tunisia, in fact, they are not considered citizens at all.

title: Troubled Washington Group Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
description: Washington Group International, one of the nation's largest construction companies, filed for bankruptcy protection today and settled in for a long fight with the Raytheon Company, which it has accused of misrepresenting the financial condition of a unit that Washington bought last year.

title: East Village Woman Known for Service Ethic Is Fatally Stabbed in Apartment
description: For as long as anyone could remember, Pauline Sejenko was a fixture in the East Village, with her fondness for unusual hats, her brood of cats and her deeply held Roman Catholic faith. She was someone who served meals to the elderly, even as she became elderly herself.

title: Shoulder Injury Hampers Jagr's Search for Offense
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., May 14  Jaromir Jagr said tonight that his right shoulder hurts and that he will not take painkillers for his injury, which is a startling concession from a player in the middle of the Stanley Cup playoffs. Jagr might as well put a neon arrow on his shoulder so the Devils could bludgeon it with more hard hits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAY, ANDREW MACKENZIE, C.B.E.
description: HAY-Andrew Mackenzie, C.B.E. Beloved husband of Catherine, brother of Dr. David. Died at home on May 2nd in Portland, OR. Honorary British Consul; President of British American Chamber of Commerce, 1966-68; President, American Importers and Exporters Association, 1977-79. Memorial service today, Trinity Episcopal Cathedral, Portland.

description: NAPHTALIE-Paula. On May 14, 2001. Former New York Public School teacher until her retirement in 1977. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside'' 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Democrats Criticize Bush Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 15  House Democratic leaders, portraying President Bush's soon-to-be-released energy policy as an environmentally disastrous giveaway to his friends in the energy industry, today released their own energy blueprint that called for the government to force down electricity prices and to step up conservation efforts.

title: An Audio Spotlight Creates a Personal Wall of Sound
description: A person hears a voice in her ear, turns around and sees nobody there. No one else has heard it. Or she hears footsteps in a room, the product of an invisible presence. Is her mind playing tricks on her?

description: BERKLEY-Barbara. The Joyce Theater mourns the passing of Bobbi Berkley, a devoted patron of dance. Deepest condolences to her husband, Bob, and her children. The Board and Staff of the Joyce Theater

title: Senate Leader Sits on Campaign Finance Bill
description: In a slap at supporters of a campaign financing overhaul that the Senate passed last month, the Senate Republican leader said today that the measure would not be sent to the House until the House had acted on its own bill.

title: At Phillips, a Strong if Not Stellar Sale
description: Phillips, the fledgling third-place auction house, tried its hand at contemporary art last night. And in contrast with last week, when it failed to sell a large number of expensive Impressionist and modern artworks, the bidding was enthusiastic for paintings, drawings and sculptures made since World War II as buyers from both sides of the Atlantic crowded into the 57th Street salesroom.

description: Eager to start a school voucher program in New York City before he leaves office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani flew the seven members of the Board of Education here today for an immersion course in how such a system would work.

title: Tale of the Tories: The Leader Under Fire
description: Everyone loves a winner, but in the campaign for Britain's election on June 7, it is the man everyone expects to lose, the Conservative, William Hague, who is attracting most of the attention.

description: In a bipartisan attempt to revive a voting overhaul, four senators plan to join forces to offer a single bill on Tuesday to give the states billions of dollars to buy new voting machines.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Company To Set Up Headquarters
description: A Japanese optoelectronics company will invest $500,000 to establish its American headquarters in Colonie, N.Y., creating 100 new jobs over five years, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. The Optrans Corporation of Kawasaki, Japan, makes optoelectronic components. The company picked Colonie because it is near university research laboratories in Albany, said Maura Gallucci, a spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation. The company may apply for up to $120,000 in state grants. The headquarters is to open in July.

title: Gauges Are Mixed as Investors Await Fed Move on Rates
description: The Nasdaq composite index fell for a fourth consecutive session yesterday, as some investors worried that shares would drop today if the Federal Reserve did not reduce interest rates by the half-point they expected.

description: SINCE they finished finals at the end of April, Ben Royal and three fellow University of Michigan students have been driving around the Northeast in a green 1992 Toyota Corolla, trying to make a movement.

title: Urdu Made Simple, and Other Advice
description: RICK STEVES, the travel guru and author of ''Europe Through the Back Door,'' has made an industry out of teaching Americans who speak only English to bluff their way from Finland to Spain. Emboldened by his advice, I traveled solo with a backpack and a phrasebook through Italy and the Czech Republic. Then, having faked my way through those European countries without speaking the native tongue, I was ready for a tougher challenge -- China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, THOMAS JOHN
description: HAYES-Thomas John. On May 12, 2001 of Lawrenceville, GA. formerly of Ozone Park, NY. Beloved husband of the late Bette (nee Kerensky). Dear father of Jim and Ginny. Father-in-law of Tom Ring. Loving grandfather of Christopher and Lauren. Brother of Sr. Margaret Assissium, RSM. Reposing Leahy McDonald Funeral Home, Atlantic Avenue @ 111th Street, Wednesday 2-4:30 & 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Thursday 9:45 AM Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary, Ozone Park, NY. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: A Fresh Look at the Straying Ways of the Female Chimp
description: Consider it a serious case of chimp change.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Nominee For United States Attorney
description: An assistant United States attorney from New York City has been nominated to be the new United States attorney for the Chicago area. Patrick J. Fitzgerald, who prosecuted cases including the World Trade Center bombing, was nominated by Senator Peter Fitzgerald, a Republican from Illinois who is not related to the prosecutor. The nomination must be approved by President Bush and confirmed by the Senate. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: From Pearls to Pillbox Hats, A Show Evokes Awe and Sadness; Crowds Wait 90 Minutes for 'Jacqueline Kennedy' at the Met
description: By noon on Friday, the line for the exhibition ''Jacqueline Kennedy: The White House Years'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was snaking through the Robert Wood Johnson Drawings and Prints Gallery, past the Altman porcelain collection in the Great Hall Balcony, and back into the Asian art galleries, where David Canu had to figure out a way to wrap a double line of visitors around two large Buddhas.

title: Jets Re-Sign Lyle For New Defense
description: The Jets bolstered their defensive line yesterday, re-signing Rick Lyle, who has been with the Jets since 1997. Lyle played defensive end in the 3-4 scheme, but with the switch to the 4-3 this season, Lyle could play either end or tackle.

title: King in Charge From Zaire to Beijing
description: How sporting of the Chinese government to overlook the human rights record of the world's foremost boxing promoter when it comes to professional fighters.

title: Sports of The Times; Doomed By Failures Of His Teams
description: TEN years. Dave Checketts lasted a decade in the corporate jungle known as Madison Square Garden, and maybe that's the achievement he can brag about most as he exits a building prematurely emptied of basketball and hockey postseason fans.

title: Miscellany
description: CyberSight, Portland, Ore., an interactive marketing agency majority-owned by the MDC Corporation, was renamed Nine Dots.

title: Beijing Remains Front-Runner for 2008 Summer Games
description: Beijing appeared to remain the front-runner while Paris and Toronto received encouraging evaluations today in a report issued by the International Olympic Committee that assessed the cities bidding on the 2008 Summer Games.

title: Douglas Adams, 49, Author Of 'Hitchhiker's Guide' Spoofs
description: Douglas Adams, the whimsical British novelist who wrote ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy,'' the best-selling science fiction humor series that introduced readers to a universe of preening, two-headed aliens, manic-depressive robots and space travelers who never parted with their bath towels, died on Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 49.

title: In California, Ruling on Drug Spurs Bitterness and Resolve
description: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14  For supporters of medical marijuana, today's unanimous United States Supreme Court ruling upholding a federal law banning the distribution of marijuana for any reason was a major blow, especially coming at a time when national polls show a growing acceptance of the drug for the sick and dying.

title: For Fall, NBC Plans a Double Dose of 'Weakest Link'
description: NBC announced a fall television schedule yesterday with six new programs and additional reliance on ''Weakest Link,'' a game show that network executives once vowed not to use more than once a week.

title: Making Enemies in Space
description: As the Bush administration tries in the coming months to convince a wary world that it has nothing to fear from American plans to develop a national missile shield, the first priority should be to ensure that Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld does not bring any more damage to the cause. At the very moment President Bush's emissaries were fanning out across the globe to explain his goal of defending America from missiles launched by so-called rogue states, Mr. Rumsfeld chose to announce a major reorganization of the Pentagon's space programs, including assigning responsibility to the Air Force ''to organize, train, and equip for prompt and sustained offensive and defensive space operations.''

title: Drossin Decides to Run in New York
description: Deena Drossin is a national champion on the track (10 kilometers), on the road (15 kilometers) and in cross-country (8 kilometers), but she has never run a marathon. That will soon change.

title: HEVESI CITES IMPACT OF OPEN
description: The two weeks of play in the United States Open last year grossed more money for the states of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut than did the Yankees and the Mets combined, according to a study sponsored by the United States Tennis Association.

title: Japan's Princess Is Pregnant
description: TOKYO, 15 May  The Imperial Household Agency officially confirmed today that Crown Princess Masako is pregnant.

title: North Korea May Get Help Under Plan By Europeans
description: The European Union announced today that it would open diplomatic relations with North Korea to help Pyongyang solve its food and health crisis.

title: Who Needs Training? Nondancers Make a Case
description: The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company has not formally performed in New York City since 1996. But Mr. Jones and his company have been working here for the past four years in a residency at Davis Hall that drew in Harlem residents for a variety of dance programs. Out of that came Mr. Jones's new piece, ''The Table Project,'' which was performed on Saturday night at Davis. It is a winner.

title: With a Provider Lost, Businesses Seek an Internet Link
description: Jan Kalanda, the managing partner of a group of Manhattan hotels, grimaces when he remembers how a company reserved eight rooms at one of them, the Casablanca, sold on the spacious suites, Moroccan decor and Internet access. When the company learned that the Casablanca's Internet access was gone, it canceled and picked another hotel.

title: Two Agencies Reviewing Accounts
description: Two advertisers are making decisions on accounts.

title: Devils' Holik Has a Mission. His Name Is Lemieux.
description: As he entered the Devils' dressing room today after practice, Bobby Holik saw the reporters gathered with their television cameras, their microphones and their notebooks. He glanced over his shoulder, noticed Martin Brodeur and decided to split the journalistic herd.

title: Gossip and Jokes Before the Canasta Begins
description: What can you say about a musical comedy that extols the virtues and indulges the foibles of Jewish motherhood while celebrating the joys and heartaches of lifelong friendship?

title: The Calendar Says May, The Record Says, 'Uh-Oh'
description: A visitors locker room clears out quickly on the last day of a road trip, players hurriedly changing into sports coats and slacks, clubhouse workers loading equipment, airport-bound buses idling outside the gates. With the Mets this season, there has been an added component: the somber analysis of what has gone wrong. Each of their three road trips have ended with a discouraging game. The flights home cannot be upbeat.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: I.B.M. Offering New Internet Software
description: I.B.M. is selling a new line of Internet software that permits businesses to link their buying and selling processes with other businesses. I.B.M. said its so-called middleware programs, which include Lotus, Tivoli, DB2 and WebSphere, will be the industry's first to be based on open standards. For example, an automaker's e-business application will be able to seek certain products and prices automatically from its suppliers, even if those suppliers use software from I.B.M. competitors like Sun and Microsoft. Shares of I.B.M. gained 75 cents, to close at $112.56. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Critics Praise N.Y.U. Plan
description: The New York University School of Law, ending a dispute that began last summer, has detailed its plans for Judson House and a row house where Edgar Allan Poe once lived. Preservationist groups had feared that the school would demolish the buildings and replace them with a tower. The groups recently reviewed and expressed satisfaction with architectural plans that call for a shorter 145-foot tower with facades rebuilt from the original Poe and Judson buildings. Jim O'Grady (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper dropped after a report showed that United States industrial production declined, intensifying concern that demand will fall. In New York, copper for July delivery fell 0.85 cent, to 75.5 cents a pound.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about efforts to head off reductions in Medicare spending misspelled the surname of the Republican senator from Texas who introduced a bill that would reverse them. She is Kay Bailey Hutchison, not Hutchinson.

title: New President Tested by Vote in Philippines
description: After rival ''people power'' demonstrations changed the face of Philippine politics in the last four months, Filipinos finally had a chance to vote today in an election widely viewed as a referendum on the legitimacy of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

title: Review of Revised Internet Names Contract
description: Representatives of the Commerce Department met yesterday with VeriSign Inc. and the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers to review an agreement that would change the contract that governs VeriSign's control over the Internet address system.

title: Moderate Basques Promise To Focus on Peace Talks
description: Moderate Basque nationalists, who won a bitterly fought regional election on Sunday, have begun working to form a new government with the aim of ending the violent separatism of the radical E.T.A., party officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two Brooklyn men who were ordered released from prison after being cleared in a 1987 murder misstated the given name of a private investigator who worked for the defense. He is Michael S. Race, not Mark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARMAN, JANE (NEE SHANKMAN)
description: KARMAN-Jane (Nee Shankman). Wife of the late Sam. Our Aunt Jane passed away peacefully on May 12, 2001 at her home in Plantation Florida. We will remember her indomitable spirit and courage as she confronted life's challenges with enviable vitality, humor and balance. Our condolences to her children, Malcolm and Shira and granddaughter Michaela. Al, Mickey, Steven and Richard Shankman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, GHITA
description: FRIED-Ghita. Beloved matriarch of her family, died Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91. She is survived by a daughter, Marilyn Frank, Teaneck, NJ; a son, Jeffrey Krugman, Roslyn Heights, NY, and seven grandchildren. Devoted wife to first Barnett and later Morris, both deceased. Services 1 PM, Tuesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.), NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, PEARL
description: GOLD-Pearl. The Board of Directors, Administration and Staff at Just One Life, Inc. (USA and Israel), record with profound sorrow the passing of Pearl Gold, beloved mother of its founder and President, Joel Gold. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family: children Joel and Miriam Gold and Sy and Marilyn Baker, grandchildren and great grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack Forgash, Chairman, USA Hillel Weinberger, Chairman, USA Steve Adelsberg, Vice Pres., USA Rabbi Martin Katz, Exec. VP, USA Rabbi Solomon Sharfman, Honorary Chairman, Israel Rabbi Macy Gordon Honorary President, Israel Steven Esses, Chairman, Israel Dr. David Ribner, Chairman, Israel Madelaine Gitelman, Exec VP, Isrl

title: VITAL SIGNS: REGIMENS; Beating Chemo Fatigue, at the Gym
description: Moderate exercise can help women undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer to fend off the fatigue the treatment causes, but only if they stick to it regularly, according to a new study from the Oregon Health and Sciences University in Portland.

title: AGENCY.COM TO CUT 350 JOBS AS LOSSES WIDEN
description: Agency.com Inc., an Internet-consulting company, said it would cut 350 jobs, reducing its work force by 25 percent, after reporting that its first-quarter loss had widened. The loss was $10.3 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to a loss of $4.2 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Agency.Com said its founders, Chan Suh and Kyle Shannon, would sell their shares to Seneca Investments L.L.C., a holding company formed by the Omnicom Group and Pegasus Partners II. The cash sale will raise Seneca's stake in Agency.Com from 45.3 percent to 65.7 percent.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Lawsuits Against F.B.I.
description: Two Boston lawyers say they will seek hundreds of millions of dollars in damages from the Federal Bureau of Investigation for two families whose lives they say were ruined by its relationship with two gangsters, James Bulger and Stephen Flemmi. The two were F.B.I. informants, and court proceedings and investigations have shown that F.B.I. agents protected them even though they knew they were committing serious crimes. One of the families owned a liquor store that they say Mr. Bulger and Mr. Flemmi forced them to sell at a low price; the others are related to a Tulsa, Okla., man whose killing the two are accused of ordering. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Experts Say McVeigh Lawyers Now Face a Range of Options
description: Defense lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh are most likely focusing on four options, legal experts say, including seeking a new delay in the execution that could leave the country's biggest domestic terrorism case open for months or even years.

title: Checketts Is Out as President of the Garden
description: Dave Checketts will no longer run Madison Square Garden after reaching a mutual agreement with Cablevision, a Garden official who would not speak unless given anonymity said last night. A news conference is expected today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer's Revenue Falls
description: Europe's biggest insurance group, AXA of France, reported that first-quarter revenue dropped 3.3 percent, to 20.6 billion euros ($18 billion), mainly as a result of its sale of the investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in November to the Credit Suisse Group. AXA also reported a drop in premiums in its two largest markets, France and the United States, attributing it to flagging stock prices that deter investments by clients. Financial service companies in Europe have been reporting lower profits this year as slumping stock markets reduce their fees. But AXA's chief executive, Henri de Castries, gave a mildly upbeat assessment for the full year, noting that AXA was ''becoming more optimistic regarding this year's revenue growth,'' because of higher rates in property and casualty markets, but also ''due to the recent stabilization of equity markets.'' John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Progress on Election Reform
description: The chances for meaningful election reform, which stalled after an initial round of fervent pledges to repair deficiencies that surfaced in last November's presidential balloting, have suddenly improved as the result of an unlikely compromise on Capitol Hill. Senators Charles Schumer of New York and Robert Torricelli of New Jersey, both Democrats, will join Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and Sam Brownback of Kansas, both Republicans, in announcing today that they will co-sponsor an election reform bill aimed at providing $2.5 billion in federal funds over five years to states willing to meet certain standards in upgrading the way they hold federal elections.

title: National Briefing | Science and Health: Counterfeit Cancer Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration is warning cancer patients and pharmacists to beware of counterfeit packages of the prescription drug Neupogen, which is used to prevent infections in people receiving some types of chemotherapy. Packages with labels and vials closely imitating those of the real Neupogen have turned up in Florida and Ohio, said the F.D.A., which is investigating. Denise Grady (NYT)

title: Some Traditions Point to Bone Disease
description: Astudy of teenagers in an ultra-Orthodox Jewish community found that many boys had strikingly low bone mineral densities, a condition that could leave them vulnerable to osteoporosis later in life.

title: TELLME NETWORKS BUYS MAGICPHONE TO EXPAND TO EUROPE
description: TellMe Networks Inc., a company backed by the AT&T Corporation that helps people get Web content over the telephone, bought MagicPhone for an undisclosed price to expand to Europe. Both companies are closely held. MagicPhone, based in Brussels, automates phone systems for European businesses so customers can have access to stock quotes, bank information and other data through phone calls. TellMe, whose investors also include Amerindo Investment Advisors, has shifted focus in the last year to provide more services to corporate call centers as advertising spending has slowed, its chief executive, Mike McCue, said. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., operates a service that offers free information like movie times and traffic conditions, relying on ads for revenue.

title: Exploring Okinawans' Recipes for Longer Lives
description: ''The Okinawa Way: How The World's Longest-Lived People Achieve Everlasting Health,'' by Dr. Bradley J. Willcox, Dr. D. Craig Willcox, and Dr. Makoto Suzuki, Clarkson Potter/Publishers, $24.95.

title: China Assails Missile Defense as Danger to World Security
description: BEIJING, May 15  While President Bush's emissary was here making the case for building a national missile defense, the Chinese government today publicly condemned the American proposal, calling it a fruitless step that would endanger global security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, JANET
description: MORGAN-Janet. The entire Long Island College Hospital family mourns the passing of Janet Morgan, on Saturday May 12, 2001, and extend condolences to her beloved daughter, Nancy. Mrs. Morgan, a member of The Long Island College Hospital Guild, was the wife of the late E. King Morgan, M.D., Chair of The Department of Neurology and a valued member of LICH's Medical staff. Mrs. Morgan, along with her daughter, Nancy, was a benefactor of the Hospital and endowed The E. King Morgan M.D. Health Sciences Library. She will be missed by everyone who knew her at The Hospital and in Brooklyn Heights community. John Wren, Chairman, Board of Regents, LICH Allan Gibofsky, M.D., J.D., President and CEO, LICH George Wahlert, Director, E. King Morgan, M.D. Health Sciences Library, LICH

description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra Looks to Link Jazz and Tango
description: Jazz at Lincoln Center has always had an educational edge to its concerts, but now Wynton Marsalis and the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra are teaching more obscure lessons.

title: U.S. Diplomat in Beijing to Calm Fears on Antimissile Project
description: An American diplomat is meeting skeptical Chinese officials today in an effort to convince them that President Bush's plans to build a missile defense will not undermine China's power and security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, RALPH M. M.D.
description: SUSSMAN-Ralph M. M.D. Former Chairman of the Department of Cardiology at Doctor's Hospital. He served the Manhattan community as a caring physician for 60 years. Beloved husband of Gertrude and the late Frances Goldberg. Devoted father of Elizabeth Anne Socolow and the late Victoria Sussman and step-children, Elizabeth Stevens and Henry Gottlieb. Loving grandfather of seven grandchildren. Services Tuesday 12 noon at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Ave at 16th St., NY, NY 10003.

title: Supreme Court Roundup: Punitive Damages Must Get a Searching Review on Appeal, Justices Rule
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  In a substantial victory for opponents of punitive damages, the Supreme Court ruled today that appellate courts must give searching scrutiny to whether a jury's award of punitive damages was excessive.

title: Testimony Begins in Hearing on California Natural Gas Pricing
description: In evaluating whether the El Paso Corporation artificially drove up natural gas prices in California -- and thus the cost of power -- a key factor will be determining whether pipeline constraints created a Southern California gas market that is separate from the rest of the state, an administrative law judge said today.

title: Corrections
description: A Public Lives profile on Saturday about Shirley M. Tilghman, the new president of Princeton, misstated the precedent for a Princeton president without a Princeton degree. She is the first since Francis L. Patton, who served from 1888 to 1902; she is not the first ever.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From stuffed pepper recipes to wines for a vegetarian barbecue, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: JUSTICES SET BACK USE OF MARIJUANA TO TREAT SICKNESS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that federal law does not allow a ''medical necessity'' exception to the prohibition on the distribution of marijuana. The 8-to-0 decision dealt a setback, but not a definitive blow, to a movement that has passed medical marijuana ballot initiatives in eight states.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Trade-Secrets Trial Begins
description: Jury selection began yesterday in Santa Clara County, Calif., in a long-awaited criminal case against the Avant Corporation, a maker of software. In 1997, Cadence Design Systems accused four Avant executives, Eric Cho, Mike Tsai, Stephen Wuu and Y. Z. Liao, of stealing source code while they worked for Cadence and illegally taking it with them when they left to form Avant. Both Cadence and Avant develop software that lets engineers lay out and design integrated circuits. The trial is being closely watched in Silicon Valley for the precedent it could set in intellectual property protection. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Nearby Firehouse Was of Little Use, Residents Say
description: It is only a few steps across 29th Street to Engine Company No. 4. And according to firefighters' records, it took them only four minutes to respond Sunday morning when fire broke out in a set of row houses here.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Is Cutting Prices Again
description: Palm Inc., the largest maker of the hand-held computers called personal digital assistants, said it was cutting

title: Let the Circle Be Unbroken
description: Never unduly distressed when today's creative chefs play as fast and loose with culinary terminology as they do with traditional ingredients, I have cared more about how a dish tastes than what it is called as long as the name does not lead me astray by arousing wrong expectations.

title: Caps on Outlets, but No Locks for Guns
description: Asurvey of parents who own guns found that they were far more likely to place caps over electrical outlets than to lock up their firearms.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: GIFT TO UNIVERSITY The founder of E*Trade , Christos M. Cotsakos, announced a $10 million gift to his alma mater, William Paterson University in Wayne, N.J., which will preface its College of Business with his name, the company and the university announced yesterday. The university is receiving an additional $500,000 in the name of Mr. Cotsakos's wife, Tami Cotsakos, to endow the Cotsakos Family Scholarship Fund in Music. The donation lets William Paterson apply for matching funds under New Jersey's Higher Education Incentive Funding Act. Upon application, the state provides 10 percent of the gift amount each year for 10 years. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPAR, HERBERT M.
description: SPAR-Herbert M. We celebrate your birthday today with beautiful memories and love everlasting. Dad and family

title: Devils' Defense Receives Good News
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., May 14  Scott Niedermayer said today that he was optimistic about returning to the Devils' lineup for Game 2 of the Eastern Conference finals against the Pittsburgh Penguins on Tuesday night in the Meadowlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GHITELMAN, FLORENCE
description: GHITELMAN-Florence. In her 97th year. Devoted wife of her late husband Jacob, mother of Simon, Gilbert and her late son Lawrence. A not so tough lady who knew how to make a tender chicken. She will be sorely missed by all who were touched by her kind and generous spirit. Services Wednesday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, L.I.

title: A Brief Exchange Proves Too Good to Be True
description: A FEW years back, while traveling through French-speaking Switzerland, I decided to speak only French, despite having a paltry command of the language. I had grand plans to immerse myself into fluency, but being at the stage where I was, at ease asking questions and flummoxed if anyone answered, it didn't take long before I was feeling walloped.

title: Production At Factories Decreases For 7th Month
description: Industrial production fell in April for a seventh consecutive month, the longest string of declines since 1982.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, DOROTHY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Dorothy. Of Jackson Heights, Queens, a longtime member of the Jewish Center of Jackson Heights, died peacefully after a battle with cancer. Loving wife of Louis J. Rubenstein, cherished sister of Lou Barnett, adored second mother to Fred & Martin, beloved grandmother to Steven, Amy, Susanne, Jonathan, Estelle, Debbie, Prahbin, Maggie and Tim, extraordinary great grandmother of Jake, Stephanie, Perri, Alexander, Nora, Brendan and Lena. Memorial Service 2 PM, Monday, May 21st at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens

title: CASES; House Call Opens Door Into the Past
description: When I made house calls, it was for the Amish. They did not have cars, and I filled a need beyond simple convenience each time I saw them. My awe of their appearance had faded in the months I had been in practice, and I appreciated them as regular people with a different lifestyle.

title: A Timid Gun Bill
description: President Bush's plan to hire scores of attorneys at the federal, state and local levels and redirect the duties of others to strengthen the prosecution of gun crimes is a move that few people on either side of the nation's gun control debate would disagree with. The new Project Safe Neighborhoods program that Mr. Bush announced yesterday seeks to replicate on a national scale a successful Virginia program of stepped-up enforcement against people who commit gun crimes. The original program began four years ago in Richmond, and has since spread to other jurisdictions, including Mr. Bush's home state of Texas.

title: High Bail Is Ordered In Trade-Secret Case
description: A federal magistrate ordered that bail be set at $900,000 each today for the three men accused of conspiring to steal trade secrets from Lucent Technologies.

title: Foreign Affairs; Who's Crazy Here?
description: The Bush team's explanation for why we have to build a national missile defense shield gets more interesting by the week.

title: Letters: A Dolphin Shows Its Smarts
description: To the Editor:

title: Changing Times Challenge World Hunger Organization
description: The organization that brought the world the green revolution is now struggling to survive the gene revolution.

title: Same as He Ever Was, but More Appreciated
description: When David Byrne became famous in the late 1970's, he played weird; the first hit by his band, Talking Heads, was called ''Psycho Killer.'' Then as Mr. Byrne's perspective grew he realized that one man's weirdness is another man's magic, and he used that observation to domesticate what others thought exotic, especially his passion: the music and rituals of the African diaspora.

title: VITAL SIGNS: PATTERNS; Some Traditions Point to Bone Disease
description: A study of teenagers in an ultra-Orthodox Jewish community found that many boys had strikingly low bone mineral densities, a condition that could leave them vulnerable to osteoporosis later in life.

description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: The Big City; A System For Lawyers, Not Children
description: IN other places, the end of a marriage is something that people prefer not to discuss in public. In New York, it is an occasion to hire a spokesman.

title: Computer Sciences Has Quarterly Loss
description: The Computer Sciences Corporation, a leading computer-services company, reported a loss for its most recent quarter and said profit in the current period will fall short of analysts' forecasts.

title: Sheldon Oliensis; Former Bar Association Head, 79
description: Sheldon Oliensis, who was president of the City Bar Association from 1988 to 1990 and headed other New York law organizations, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOS, FRIEDA
description: ROOS-Frieda. Passed away peacefully at age 96 on May 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Gene & Norbert Stern. Devoted grandmother of Jeffrey & Peter. Loving sister of Alice Dewald. Survived by nieces and nephews. Services Tuesday, May 15 at 12 noon from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: N.B.A. Assists Literacy
description: In one of the most comprehensive educational projects ever undertaken by a professional sports league, the National Basketball Association will consolidate its community outreach efforts into a national reading campaign geared toward providing young people with better reading materials and technology.

title: WEST BANK DEATHS HEIGHTEN ANXIETY
description: The Palestinian officers operating the roadblock outside Beituniya did not have much to do after the Israelis closed the road here last fall. But they maintained their inactive post as an expression of where Israeli rule supposedly ended and Palestinian rule began, Palestinian officials said.

title: F.A.A. Plans To Enforce Work Rules
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today said it would tell the airlines to stop requiring pilots to fly without regard to delays that stretch their work days to more than 16 hours. The agency warned that beginning in six months it would ''rigorously enforce'' rules that have been on the books since 1985.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH: Dan Shapiro; A Doctor's Story of Hope, Humor and Deadly Cancer
description: In May 1987, Dan Shapiro, then a 20-year-old junior at Vassar College, discovered he had Hodgkin's disease. After seven months of treatment with four chemotherapy drugs and radiation, he seemed healthy again.

title: Those Congested Roads
description: To the Editor:

title: Mummies Found in Peru May Shed Light on Pre-Inca People
description: Explorers of caves in the Andes of Peru have found well-preserved mummies arranged in fetal positions and wrapped in baskets and textiles. They are reported to be remains of people of the pre-Inca Chachapoya culture, a little-studied society.

title: Graduate Students Push For Union Membership
description: Jason Esters, who is finishing a doctorate in English at Temple University here, always considered himself a scholar. But lately he feels more like a laborer, and one with rather oppressive working conditions.

title: Corrections
description: The cable television ratings for April 30 through May 6 listed in the Most Wanted chart in Business Day yesterday misidentified the network that carried the Winston Cup stock car race. It was the FX network, not Fox.

title: Lead Damage Lingers After Lead Is Gone
description: The medicine that is the primary treatment for lead exposure can reduce the lead level of children's blood, but it does not appear to protect their learning abilities from harm, a study last week in The New England Journal of Medicine reports.

title: Felons Gain Voting Rights In Connecticut
description: Next year, Connecticut will join 21 other states when, for the first time in its history, it will allow convicted felons who are on probation to vote.

title: BOOZ-ALLEN & HAMILTON TO LAY OFF 95 CONSULTANTS
description: Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a consulting firm with about 10,800 employees worldwide, said yesterday that it was laying off about 95 of its consultants. A company spokesman attributed the cuts to cutbacks in client spending. The firm is also pushing back to next year the starting dates for college students it is hiring from this spring's graduating classes, the spokesman said. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

title: A Sewer Plant Smells Sweeter By Any Other Name, Bill Says
description: The State Senate passed a bill today that would allow sewage plants to shed their less-than-glamorous names for the more appealing euphemism ''water reclamation facility.''

title: Mideast Settlements: What's at Stake?
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Elbows Wall St. for Share of China Offering
description: For American investment banks in China, politics has often been a handmaiden to business, enabling the more savvy firms to elbow aside their rivals with comparable credentials for deals.

title: Aides Vote to End Nursing-Home Strike if Hartford Provides More Budget Aid
description: The roughly 6,000 nursing-home workers on strike in Connecticut since May 1 voted this evening to return to work, possibly by Tuesday, on the condition that the top two Democrats in Connecticut's legislature promise to find more money for them in next year's budget, a top union official said.

title: Lessons From an F.B.I. Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Honda Output
description: Honda Motor said it would spend 3.8 billion yen to increase production at its Accord plant in southern China. Honda, the Japanese automaker, said demand for the car was stronger than expected. It sold 32,000 Accords last year. The company said it planned to increase output to 50,000 cars this year and that the increased investment would push the plant's capacity even higher by late 2002. Meanwhile, General Motors' main joint venture in China sold just over 23,000 Buick sedans in 2000. Honda is one of the main competitors of General Motors in China. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: New Challenge to Domain Name Registry
description: New.net, a domain-name registry skirting the guidelines created by the Internet standards group known as Icann, says it has a partnership with its fifth major Internet service provider, Prodigy. New.net, a start-up company based in Pasadena, Calif., said Prodigy's customers could now create and visit World Wide Web sites with top-level domain names like .shop, .sports and .free, which are not sanctioned by the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers. To reach those sites, Internet users must either download software from New.net's Web site or enter the Internet through one of the company's partner service providers. David Hernand, New.net's chief executive, said his company created a co-branded registry with Prodigy and will share the profits. Excite@Home, Earthlink, Juno and NetZero have already reached similar agreements with New.net. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: A Category, Not a Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Prosecutor May Move Up
description: Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the lead prosecutor in the embassy bombings trial in Manhattan, has been recommended by Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald of Illinois to be the next United States attorney in Chicago. The men are not related. Patrick Fitzgerald, 40, a 1985 graduate of Harvard Law School, is a senior prosecutor in the United States attorney's office in Manhattan. A 13-year-veteran, Mr. Fitzgerald needs to be nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing in Arts & Leisure on Sunday for a concert tonight by the New York Pops was published in error. The concert took place at Carnegie Hall a year ago.

title: Joseph Greenberg, 85, Singular Linguist, Dies
description: Dr. Joseph H. Greenberg, an eminent linguist and classifier of the world's languages, died on May 7 in Stanford, Calif. He was 85.

title: Medicare Panel Head Is Replaced as Holdings Are Questioned
description: Gail R. Wilensky, one of the Republican Party's top health care experts, is losing her job as chairwoman of an influential commission that advises Congress on Medicare, in part because of concerns about her substantial investments in health care companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNNE, FRANCIS J.
description: DUNNE-Francis J., 73, Wilton, CT. Died Friday, Norwalk, CT. Born New York City, October 16, 1927, son of the late Timothy and Bridget Cunnion Dunne. Worked in paper industry over fifty years. World War II Veteran, of United States Army. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus of Wilton, CT and Croton-on-Hudson, NY. Survived by wife Jean Baillet Dunne, children, Tim Dunne, Wilton, CT; Nancy Dunne, Telluride, CO; Marilyn Dunne Siegel, Ginger Dunne and Cathy Thomas all of Hailey, ID, six grandchildren and many nieces and nephews. Predeceased by brother John Dunne. For information Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Avenue, Norwalk, CT., 203-866-0747.

title: SunTrust Makes Bid for Wachovia, Criticizing First Union's Offer
description: SunTrust Banks began an uphill battle yesterday to take over the Wachovia Corporation by offering $14.7 billion in stock and criticizing a rival suitor.

title: A '20th-Century Boy' Leads a Museum Into the Past
description: IF Andrew Carnegie's ghost wanders through the baronial mansion he built a century ago on the Upper East Side he will find his paintings, Persian carpets and crystal replaced by an eclectic collection of items including a 1937 Electrolux vacuum cleaner, sheets of mass-produced wallpaper and an aluminum alloy Audi car frame.

title: Williams's Father Dies of a Heart Attack
description: Bernie Williams bolted from Yankee Stadium after Sunday's 10-5 loss to the Orioles to visit his seriously ailing father in Puerto Rico, but Williams did not make it home in time. Shortly before Williams arrived, his 73-year-old father, Bernabe Williams Sr., died of a heart attack.

title: Verdi's Centennial as Celebrated by the Three Stooges
description: Comedy is so alien to a Verdi repertory devoted almost exclusively to mayhem and misery that ''Falstaff'' arrived as his great surprise. It was not the only one. By the 1890's a long career had subsided into retirement. No one, the composer least of all, could have expected this product of his 80th year.

title: Citing the Drain of Violence, Bush Backs Increased Prosecution of Gun-Related Crimes
description: President Bush lamented the toll of gun-related violence today and vowed to crack down on it, saying that he would devote more federal money to the prosecution of crimes involving firearms.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data and Dell Form Alliance
description: Electronic Data Services and Dell Computer said yesterday that they had agreed to market Dell computers and Electronic Data consulting services jointly in the United States. The two companies said they would offer ''one-stop shopping'' for computer systems and technology services, and expected to generate more than $500 million in sales over the next five years. Electronic Data stock fell 68 cents, to $61.35, while Dell shares fell 29 cents, to $24.19. E.D.S. also announced an alliance with Xdrive Technologies, a privately held developer of Internet storage technologies, to offer users a variety of desktop and mobile devices to store and retrieve data files over the Internet. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, SUZANNE
description: FISHER-Suzanne. On may 12, 2001. Loving wife of Richard. Beloved daughter of Carol Ehlers. Cherished sister of Elizabeth and brothers Robert, Thomas, and David. Donations in her memory can be made to either the Animal Medical Center of NY or the ASPCA. Services private.

title: Close Look Shows the Senate Tax Bill Isn't All That It Seems
description: Under the tax bill the Senate Finance Committee will take up on Tuesday, the federal estate tax would be repealed in 2011. Yet most people with estates large enough to owe taxes before the repeal date would owe more in taxes after the repeal.

title: In Energy Plan, Property Rights May Be an Issue
description: Western Republicans and property-rights groups, after years of fighting environmentalists over restrictions on land use, are gearing up to oppose the Bush administration on an issue at the heart of regional fears about overreaching federal power.

title: Mideast Settlements: What's at Stake?
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Investor
description: An investor in the United States has promised to buy $200 million worth of global depository receipts issued by Hynix Semiconductor, formerly Hyundai Electronics, according to Kim Kyung Lim, president of the Korea Exchange Bank. Mr. Kim said the investor had promised Salomon Smith Barney, as lead manager in the sale of Hynix global depository receipts valued at $1 billion, to make the purchase. In addition, Mr. Kim said, foreign companies are negotiating to buy the 19.1 percent stake in Hynix that is held by other Hyundai Group companies and by Chung Mong Hun, son of the late Hyundai founder Chung Ju Yung. As a result, the price of shares in the company, burdened by more than $4 billion in debt, rose 15 percent, the Korea Stock Exchange's daily limit. Don Kirk (NYT)

G.E. Engine Services will maintain the Southwest fleet through 2012. GE Aircraft Engines is based in Evendale, Ohio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZMAN, HENRY MANNERS
description: KATZMAN - Henry Manners. (1912-2001) Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather died on May 11, 2001. A musician, composer, landscape artist, and longtime Broadcast Music, Inc employee, he lived in NYC until he became a San Franciscan in 1970. As a pianist he played with George Gershwin, accompanied Irene Bordony, Fred Allen and Jan Peerce, volunteered with the Vererans Bedside Network, and was a longtime member of the Radio Pioneers. As a composer he wrote standards ''We Could Make Such Beautiful Music Together,'' ''Delilah,'' ''Keep an Eye on Your Heart'' and the ''Thumper Song'' and ''Twitterpated'' for the original Bambi animated film. He played beautiful music for his family, friends and audiences for 70 years, most recently at his wife Berdie's 90th birthday party. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Berdie, children Michael and Karyl Katzman, David and Sharyn Katzman, and Louise Katzman and Ned Kurabi; grandchildren Andrea Katzman and Steve Jacobson, Kynan Katzman, Eric and Julee Katzman, Kael Katzman, Chloe Kurabi and Oliver Kurabi; great-grandchildren Ariela Katzman-Jacobson, Henry Katzman and Theodore Katzman. In lieu of flowers, the family requests a donation to your favorite charity. A memorial service was held on Monday, May 14, at the Neptune Society San Francisco Columbarium, 1 Loraine Ct., San Francisco, CA 94118; 415-771-0717.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Health Care's Costs
description: New Jersey companies paid the highest premiums in the nation for individual employee health insurance plans, and New York companies paid the most for family plans, according to a Rutgers University study of 1998 data from 40 states for which figures were available. Connecticut businesses paid the second-highest premiums in both categories, according to the study, which will be discussed at a symposium today at the Princeton Marriott. New Jersey companies paid an average of $2,541 per year for individual policies, and $6,332 per year for family plans, the third-highest average. New York companies paid an average of $2,372 for individual plans, the 12th-highest average, but $6,453 for family plans. Connecticut businesses paid an average of $2,485 for individual plans and $6,380 for family plans. The national averages were $2,174 and $5,590. Kimberly Fox, a policy analyst at the Rutgers Center for State Health Policy who led the study, said probable reasons for the high premiums included higher costs generally in the Northeast and longer hospital stays.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Mobile Phone Venture
description: NTL Inc. of New York, Britain's biggest cable operator, said it would begin providing mobile phone service in the second half of the year with Orange, the British wireless division of France Tlcom. France Tlcom has a 25 percent stake in NTL and bought Orange, Britain's No. 3 wireless operator, one year ago. With three million customers, NTL has an extensive cable network through which Orange could route calls. Orange has about 28 percent of the British cellular phone market. No details were given of the deal, which extends France Tlcom's position in Britain and broadens NTL's offering of cable television, fixed-line telephone and Internet services. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Flatiron Partners Moving
description: Flat iron Partners, the investment firm that helped make Silicon Alley the hub of New York's dot-com boom, is giving up its offices to save on rent. The five-year-old venture capitalist operation is moving in with its main backer, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, one and a half miles north on Avenue of the Americas. The firm will save ''millions of dollars a year'' by giving up space with views of the historic three-sided Flatiron Building at Fifth Avenue and Broadway, said Jerry Colonna, its managing partner. Flatiron, which invested almost $500 million in 57 technology start-ups, has written off investments in failed companies like Kozmo.com, Urban Box Office and Scout Electromedia. Flatiron did realize gains from investments in VerticalOne, Gamesville.com and Yoyodyne.

title: Be Prepared: Nine Gizmos You Might Wish You'd Brought

For example, a pair of tiny magnifying glasses can help you read the small print on a map, and a mini-radio can deliver hours of pleasure during a stroll. The vote was 19 to 8 in favor of unionizing, with the company contesting one yes vote. The new bargaining unit also includes advertising production employees but excludes circulation, telemarketing, classified advertising and display advertising workers. title: After a Death, Doctors Can Offer Families Healing Help
description: A colleague recounting the circumstances of his father's recent death ultimately thanked the family doctor who had failed to diagnose the man's cancer.

title: Ocean Whitecaps May Help a Warming Planet Keep Its Cool
description: Oceans may be blue, but a new climate study suggests that Irving Berlin noted an important detail when when he wrote of "the ocean, white with foam" in his anthem "God Bless America."

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose on expectations the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.29 yen, up from 122.43 on Friday. The euro traded at 87.42 cents, down from 87.66.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Governor Revises Budget Plan
description: A softer economy and sharply lower revenues from the capital gains tax led Gov. Gray Davis to issue a revised budget plan that cuts almost $3.2 billion in new programs and proposed spending increases from the version he presented in January. The $101 billion proposal assumes that the close to $7 billion that the state has spent buying electricity will be repaid through a bond issue by August, and Mr. Davis sought to shelter his favored programs in education and public safety. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

description: EICHEL-Joy. Beloved wife of Morton. Loving mother of Roger and Sondra, Hillary and Peter. Proud grandmother of Scott, Jeremy, Marc & Melissa. Her warm, funny and embracing personality will live with us forever. Donations to The West Long Branch Library, West Long Branch, N.J. 07764.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Punitive Damages Must Get a Searching Review on Appeal, Justices Rule
description: In a substantial victory for opponents of punitive damages, the Supreme Court ruled today that appellate courts must give searching scrutiny to whether a jury's award of punitive damages was excessive.

title: Beating Chemo Fatigue, at the Gym
description: Moderate exercise can help women undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer to fend off the fatigue the treatment causes, but only if they stick to it regularly, according to a new study from the Oregon Health and Sciences University in Portland.

title: Health Agency Seeks to Close 27 Clinics
description: Facing huge deficits, New York City hospital officials have sought the state's permission to shut down more than two dozen school-based and neighborhood health clinics where poor children get basic medical care, from immunizations to treatment for asthma.

The Kreitman family supported an unprecedented number of academic programs and facilities to the benefit of faculty and students, including the creation of the Kreitman School of Advanced Graduate Studies. We extend sympathies to the Kreitman family. Robert H. Arnow, Chairman Emeritus of the Board of Governors American Associates: Zvi Alon, President Seth Moskowitz, Exec VP

title: Audit Shift Set on Fees to Put Goods in Stores
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board has decided to overhaul the bookkeeping practices of the nation's consumer products companies, potentially shedding light on the secretive and controversial payments manufacturers make to get their wares onto store shelves.

title: Fighting a Too Costly War; A Foe of Drugs Also Battles Harsh Laws of the 1970's
description: Jeffrion L. Aubry was playing basketball for the College of Santa Fe when the call came from home. A boyhood friend, a jokester who shot hoops with him at the park down the street, had died. The young man was around Mr. Aubry's age, in his early 20's, but already an addict. He had injected himself with what turned out to be rat poison.

title: Welcome to America, and to Stock Fraud
description: When it comes to separating immigrants from their money, few techniques have gone untested.

description: The 4-year-old son of a woman living with Jeremiah Parker, a backup defensive end for the Giants, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, N.J.

title: Wanted: A Few Good Women Looking to Go Somewhere
description: HARDLY a minute goes by when 45-year-old Teresa DeLillo is not obsessed with menopause. She is consumed by it sitting behind her carrel at a ritzy law firm, where she works full time as a legal secretary. She thinks about it constantly while waiting on tables two nights a week at a bistro on the Oakland waterfront. And it takes over completely around 2 in the morning most nights as she composes HOT FLASH!!, a monthly newsletter on pink paper that provides the latest intelligence on her fledgling women's travel company, Menopausal Tours.

title: Heavyweight Class Takes a Trip to China
description: According to Don King, east is east and west is west, and the two will finally meet at ringside. King, the boxing promoter, said yesterday that John Ruiz and Evander Holyfield will fight a rematch in Beijing in August for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title, and that the winner of that bout will most likely fight Hasim Rahman to unify the division.

title: Justices Set Back Use of Marijuana to Treat Sickness
description: WASHINGTON, May 14  The Supreme Court ruled today that federal law does not allow a "medical necessity" exception to the prohibition on the distribution of marijuana. The 8-to-0 decision dealt a setback, but not a definitive blow, to a movement that has passed medical marijuana ballot initiatives in eight states.

description: ZUCKER-Esther. On May 14, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Joseph Zucker and his wife Rosanne and the late Audrey Krinsky. Dear mother-inlaw of Paul Krinsky. Cherished grandmother of David, Ross, Harry and Amanda. Great grandmother of Peter, Daniel, Nathan, Tyler, Samantha & Alyssa. Sister of Mervin Altman and his wife Muriel. title: National Briefing | Washington: Inquiry Sought In Nomination
description: The dispute over the nomination of Theodore B. Olson to be solicitor general deepened as the ranking Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, formally asked for an investigation into Mr. Olson's links to anti-Clinton activities. At issue are unequivocal statements Mr. Olson made to the committee that he had no connection with a project at the American Spectator magazine to dig up damaging material about Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton. David Brock, a former writer for the magazine, said Mr. Olson's role on its board was ''to cover up, not to clean up,'' the effort against the Clintons, known as the Arkansas Project. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Wake For Slain Girl
description: About 500 relatives, friends and neighbors, including Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik, attended a wake last night for Tamiqua Gutierrez, an 11-year-old girl who the police say was raped and killed by a neighbor on May 8. As an elevated train rumbled by, youngsters wearing white T-shirts with a picture of Tamiqua on the front and the letters R.I.P. on the back stood solemn-faced beside their parents waiting to enter the Romano Funeral Home on White Plains Road. The funeral is set for tomorrow at Immaculate Conception Church.

description: In percent

title: In Rush Hour Of the Brides, The Word Is Sexy
description: One afternoon last week, Deanna Cunneen, a pert young woman whose figure suggested she had never gotten too close to ordering a cheese course, arrived on the eighth floor of Barneys uptown to try on a dress. The trajectory of events that took her there started out something like this: ''I have a friend who runs the derivatives desk at Merrill Lynch,'' Ms. Cunneen recalled. ''She had this guy who worked for her, and she told him, 'There's this great girl I want you to meet, and for every trade you give me I'll give you a digit of her phone number.' Of course it included the 212, and by the time he made it halfway through my number I already had a boyfriend.''

title: Chemotherapy Before Surgery Aids Bladder Cancer Sufferers
description: Chemotherapy given before surgery improved survival by 2.6 years for patients with advanced bladder cancer, researchers reported here today.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union: Hostage Crisis Fizzles
description: Two armed men in black ski masks were apparently surprised in midburglary by a restaurant manager yesterday, the police said, touching off what at first seemed like a potential hostage crisis. The men handcuffed the manager to a file cabinet and escaped through a vent, the police said. Unaware that the robbers were gone, scores of officers armed with rifles fanned out on nearby roofs, stopped morning rush-hour traffic on nearby Route 22 for more than an hour, and evacuated neighborhood stores before realizing that the robbers had already fled with an undisclosed amount of money. Ronald Smothers (NYT)
