description: ''He combines megalomania with self-irony. It's his way of being excessive in all things.''

title: Powell to Allow Taiwan's President to Stop Briefly in U.S.
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that he would grant President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan permission to stop briefly in the United States on his way to and from Latin America. But General Powell stressed that the visit would be an unofficial one that marks no change in United States policy of recognizing only one China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIENSIS, SHELDON
description: OLIENSIS-Sheldon. On May 14, 2001 at age 79. Husband of Lyn. Father of John Oliensis and Lucretia Moroni, Jane Oliensis, Ellen Oliensis and John Shoptaw. Grandfather of Melina and Chiara Bernardi, Rebecca Shoptaw and Adrian Oliensis. Brother of Doris Woldow and Dr. Asher Woldow. Also survived by many nephews, nieces, grand nephews and grand nieces. The funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held later. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Sheldon Oliensis Scholarship Fund at the Harvard Law School or to a charity of your choice.

title: Orpheus: In the Fast Lane Without a Driver
description: Orpheus, the conductorless orchestra, won its fourth Grammy this year, so it's well past the talking dog stage, at which one admires not that it is done well but that it is done at all.

title: Shuggie Otis: Back in the Groove
description: Shuggie Otis's album "Inspiration Information," released in 1974 and just reissued by Luaka Bop, slid into hip record stores a few weeks ago like an eight ball into a corner pocket. The collectors and sample fiends who knew about it already got the remastering they were waiting for, and those who didn't found the perfect 2001 record: interior, funky, well written but idiosyncratically produced, a musician's album somewhere in the middle of the aesthetic terrain of Sly and the Family Stone, D'Angelo and Tortoise.

title: Chicago Jazz Ensemble: Rehabilitating the Sound of Stan Kenton
description: You couldn't ask for a better intellectual workout than trying to rehabilitate the reputation of Stan Kenton in the New York City jazz scene. His big-band music from the 1940's, 50's and 60's, loud, intricately structured, occasionally kitschy and massively popular, now seems like a spacecraft that landed for a while and then returned to its home planet.

title: Toward a Smoother Flight
description: IT'S your vacation, and every millisecond is precious. How much of it do you want to spend in transit?

title: Hearing Bush Energy Plan, Union Leaders Offer Praise
description: Union leaders praised parts of President Bush's energy plan yesterday after attending a White House meeting where Vice President Dick Cheney and other administration officials outlined the plan and predicted that it would create hundreds of thousands of jobs.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Latin America Losses Grow
description: AT&T Latin America's losses widened in the first quarter, to $73 million, or 63 cents a share, from $39.4 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago, as the costs of expanding the company's fiber optic network across the region climbed. The company, based in Coral Gables, Fla., said the costs of operating its network increased to $25.8 million, from $12.4 million, while marketing costs climbed to $32.8 million, from $20.9 million. AT&T Latin America, which is controlled by AT&T, is competing with companies like 360networks, Telefnica and Worldcom that are seeking to lure business customers by making communications networks in the region as sophisticated as those in the United States and Europe. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: PRICELINE FOUNDER TO SELL $9.9 MILLION WORTH OF SHARES
description: Priceline.com Inc.'s founder, Jay Walker, is planning to sell nearly $9.9 million of the company's stock, according to a form Mr. Walker filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Walker intends to sell nearly 1.9 million shares, or less than 1 percent of the company's 200.6 million shares outstanding, said the filing, which listed Goldman, Sachs & Company as the broker. According to a recent proxy statement, Mr. Walker owned 43.4 million shares, or 17.8 percent, of Priceline, as of March 31. Priceline.com allows its users to set their own prices on the Internet for purchases from participating retailers, like airlines.

description: Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc., a leading maker of software for television-program guides, reported a first-quarter loss on write-offs for its $14.9 billion acquisition of TV Guide.

description: A new Mayo Clinic study has found that a single dose of a steroid medication can significantly reduce the pain from a sore throat.

title: Japan's Travails
description: After a decade-long slump, Japan faces nothing but painful choices in trying to revive its economy. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, who took office last month, is already encountering resistance to his reform proposals, which range from deregulation and privatization to writing off hundreds of billions of dollars in bad bank loans. But instead of promoting his economic agenda he is pressing to rewrite Japan's postwar Constitution, particularly its provision forever renouncing war as an option for Japan.

title: SunTrust to Acquire An Investment Bank From Citigroup Unit
description: Hours after making a $14.7 billion hostile bid for the Wachovia Corporation, SunTrust Banks said late yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the investment banking unit of the Robinson-Humphrey Company from Salomon Smith Barney. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

description: The Senate today gave final passage to a new version of the State Constitution that erases sexist language referring only to men, ensuring a statewide November referendum on the proposed changes.

title: Cabaret Skits From Jews Held Captive By the Nazis
description: Anyone presuming to construct a show out of the cabaret songs and skits that Jewish artists performed for one another while in a Nazi prison camp is in very treacherous waters. The potential for the venture to become an exercise in extremely bad taste or callous exploitation is considerable. Top your press release with the line ''Imagine Mel Brooks, Nathan Lane and Barbra Streisand in a concentration camp,'' and you're halfway there.

title: Man in the News; Italy's Billionaire Victor; Silvio Berlusconi
description: In the final days of Italy's election campaign, the media tycoon Silvio Berlusconi made a promise that summed up his brash style: with a flourish, he signed a five-point ''contract'' with Italians that commits him to leave office if he fails to deliver on at least four.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard Moves In With Officemax
description: OfficeMax said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to make Hewlett-Packard computers the only PC's sold in the chain's 1,000 stores nationwide. The deal replaces a similar one OfficeMax had with Gateway. Company officials said Gateway broke off the relationship earlier this year, and also cut back its own network of showrooms. In January, OfficeMax said it would close 50 stores and cut 1,200 jobs; two months later, the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $85 million, or 76 cents a share, down from $23 million, or 20 cents a share. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 3 Arrests In Burning Of Homeless Man
description: A 16-year-old boy and two younger accomplices were arrested yesterday and charged with setting fire to a homeless man Sunday morning in the lobby of a building in Chelsea, police and fire officials said. They said the boys set fire to the man's clothing after an argument. The man, identified as Walter Eakman, 47, was listed in critical condition at New York Weill Cornell Center with burns over most of his body. The charges were attempted murder, assault and arson. Kevin Flynn (NYT)

title: Front Row: Fashion Show Is Wrought by Young Designers
description: How do careers happen? Is it parental nagging, the sensitive and percipient guidance counselor in 10th grade, a class with Harold Bloom or, more typically, some fluke? For Quang Wayne Van, the seminal event was weekly exposure to "Style With Elsa Klensch." When Mr. Van was a boy in Alhambra, Calif., he spent Saturday mornings in typical boy fashion, watching cartoons. That is, he did when his sisters would let him. Most weekends, however, they would barge in and switch the channel to Ms. Klensch's long-running fashion show on CNN.

Services Tuesday, May 15, 10AM, Plaza Funeral Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue.

He faces Jeannette Gadson, the former deputy borough president, and State Senator Marty Markowitz in the Democratic primary. He is supported by Representatives Nydia M. Velazquez and Edolphus Towns, but the Brooklyn party organization and Borough President Howard Golden have endorsed Ms. Gadson. Jonathan Hicks (NYT)

title: The Weather Channel's new campaign aims for viewers who aren't climate 'fanatics.'

The satiric campaign, devised for the Weather Channel by the TBWA/Chiat/Day unit of TBWA, was a critical success, too. It won industry accolades almost as soon as it began running a few years ago.

The company has 28,000 employees worldwide, an Avaya spokeswoman, Lydia Whitefield, said. title: National Briefing | West: California: 12 Tons of Cocaine are Seized
description: The United States attorney in San Diego announced that the Coast Guard had made the largest seizure of cocaine ever made at sea, about 12 tons of the drug from a ship registered in Belize with a crew of Russians and Ukrainians. A federal prosecutor, Gonzalo Curiel, said the crew of the 52-foot fishing vessel was arrested after the discovery of the cocaine. The Coast Guard made the seizure about 500 miles south of Acapulco on May 3, then brought the boat and its 10-member crew to San Diego.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPENCE, HARTZELL
description: SPENCE-Hartzell. The writer and a founder of YANK the Army Weekly in World War II, died on May 9 at age 93, having made his home in Essex, CT since 1950. Best known for a novelized biography of his father titled One Foot in Heaven, Spence was the author of 15 published books and during his career wrote some 200 articles for such magazines as Saturday Evening Post, Look and Reader's Digest. Spence, born in Clarion, Iowa, Feb. 15, 1908 was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from the University of Iowa in 1930. He served the United Press Assoc. as Iowa bureau manager and then in New York as manager of the Special Service Bureau. In 1941, with the publication of One Foot in Heaven, a best seller, book club selection and motion picture, Spence became a freelance writer. In World War II he was assigned to the Army Special Services Div. to help develop the army weekly known as YANK. Ralph Stein's book The Pin-Up credits Spence with the first use of the term pin-up to describe pretty girl photos to adorn barracks walls. Spence's prospectus for YANK said that every issue should have a full-page ''pin-up'', and the term went into general usage. Later Spence was transferred to the Army Air Corps as special assistant to Gen. Lauris Norstad. For his service Spence received the Legion of Merit in 1945. Renewing his freelance career, Spence's books included two historical novels from the Spanish conquest of South America, Vain Shadow and Bride of the Conqueror, both book club selections, and Get Thee Behind Me, about his own Methodist parsonage upbringing. He wrote The Big Top with Fred Bradna, the renowned circus ringmaster and dramatized One Foot in Heaven for network radio. His three year series of Look Magazine articles studied the 16 largest American religious groups. These articles won 23 national awards and the series was published as a book under the title The Story of America's Religions. In 1964 Spence went to the Philippines and wrote a biography of Ferdinand E. Marcos, updated in 1969 under the title Marcos of The Philippines. More info at www.livingtributes.com

title: Land and the Intifada
description: With great precision, an international fact finding committee has identified the principal hindrance to calming the crisis and resuming the Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. In its report, completed at the end of April, the committee, headed by former United States Senator George Mitchell, declared: ''A cessation of Palestinian-Israeli violence will be particularly hard to sustain unless the government of Israel freezes all settlement construction activity.'' The implications of this statement are clear. The intifada, if it is to end, must first be seen for what it is: Palestinian resistance to Israeli military occupation, exemplified by Israel's continuing confiscation of Palestinian territory and destruction of Palestinian property in order to build and expand illegal settlements.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Conflict-Of-Interest Case
description: A state superior court judge temporarily blocked Friday's scheduled execution of Robert Bacon, convicted of a fatal 1987 stabbing, because of a possible conflict of interest involving Gov. Michael F. Easley, left, the former attorney general. The judge said it appeared unfair that Mr. Easley could decide on clemency for Mr. Bacon because in his previous job, Mr. Easley's office argued against Mr. Bacon's appeals. The issue, which could affect more than 100 other death-row cases in which Mr. Easley participated, was appealed to the State Supreme Court, which ruled that the governor could conduct a clemency hearing but held off a decision on the execution itself. A similar stay issued in March on another case was later overturned by the court. David Firestone (NYT)

description: A telescope in eastern Australia has seen what appear to be the faint imprint of waves, much like sound waves, that may have rippled through the gases of the young universe. Scientists have long theorized such waves were the seeds for all structures glittering in the heavens today.

The cutbacks are a response to intense competition in the domestic market, which is crowded by six carriers, and slowing customer growth. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: One More Reason to Eat Your Greens
description: IN the last three years, scientists have uncovered one reason after another that folic acid is important in the diet. First it was linked to the prevention of birth defects, then to a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease. And now, a study of nuns has offered intriguing hints that a folic acid deficiency might be linked to Alzheimer's disease.

title: Roy Jones Willing To Fight Trinidad
description: This is how much attention Roy Jones Jr. is paying to Felix Trinidad these days: He did not watch the fight last Saturday night when Trinidad cut down William Joppy like a thresher in a wheat field. Jones has not even looked at a tape of the bout.

title: McVeigh's Lawyer Known as a Stickler for Detail
description: DENVER, May 12  From the time he was appointed by a federal judge to represent Timothy J. McVeigh, Nathan D. Chambers had little more than a straight legal path to follow. His task was to manage Mr. McVeigh's appeals after his conviction and death sentence for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing six years ago.

title: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Apple To Open 25 Retail Stores
description: Apple Computer Inc., maker of the iMac personal computer, will open 25 retail stores this year to attract new customers by establishing more outlets for promoting its computers and software. The company will open stores in shopping areas that cater to affluent consumers in cities like New York, Chicago and San Jose, Calif., the chief executive, Steve Jobs, said. The first shops will open Saturday in McLean, Va., and Glendale, Calif.

title: Lucent, Motorola and 8 More to Supply China Cellular Growth
description: Lucent Technologies, Motorola, Nortel Networks and Ericsson are among 10 big Western suppliers that have won nearly $1.5 billion in phone equipment contracts from one of China's largest cellular providers, the companies disclosed today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Loss At Software Concern
description: The Irish security software developer Baltimore Technologies said it would cut 250 of its 1,400 jobs to reduce costs by nearly $50 million after posting a first-quarter loss of $24.4 million. The company said sales were up 150 percent from the quarter a year ago, but down 17 percent from the fourth quarter of 2000, and analysts said that without the job cuts, the company would run out of cash next year. The job losses will principally affect offices in England, where the company is continuing to consolidate operations. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BEL FUSE INC., Jersey City, a maker of fuses and computer-networking components, has bought the E-Power Co., Hangzhou, China, a closely held Chinese research company that develops power-conversion devices. Terms of the cash purchase were not disclosed.

title: Could There Be a Theme Here? Yes, It's Olives
description: When Oliviers & Company, the French chain of olive oil shops, sells crackers, you can be sure they will be olive-based, as are two new Italian imports. Flaky oil-rich Tuscan biscuits embedded with bits of black olive are almost business-letter size and are sold in pairs. Golden oval Ligurian biscuits -- smaller, crisper and firmer -- are lightly dusted with coarse salt; they come five to a package. Both varieties are $7 for 5.36 ounces and are sensational with a light schmear of Oliviers tapenades (five kinds, each $12 for 2.9 ounces). Available at the Oliviers shops in Grand Central Terminal and at 198 Columbus Avenue (69th Street).

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Deal Valued At $180 Million
description: Motient, which sells the Blackberry digital assistant and wireless e-mail and data services, agreed yesterday to acquire Rare Medium, an Internet services and investment company that is controlled by Apollo Management. The deal is valued at about $180 million. In essence, the deal replaces previous financial backing of Motient by Rare Medium with new arrangements intended to generate enough free cash for Motient to sustain operations into next year. Barnaby Feder (NYT)

title: Senators Criticize the F.B.I. Over McVeigh Documents
description: Lawmakers in both parties assailed the F.B.I. today for investigative breakdowns, slipshod evidence handling and information control problems that they said had culminated in the bureau's failure to turn over thousands of pages of interview reports in the Oklahoma City bombing case.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Accord Seen For Harlem Clinic
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation and the owners of a Harlem clinic have reached a tentative agreement that would keep the clinic open but shrink it, the Manhattan borough president, C. Virginia Fields, said yesterday. The corporation had planned to reduce the size of the Renaissance Diagnostic and Treatment Center, also known as the Sydenham clinic, from 50,000 square feet to 7,000 because of a rent increase. But under the agreement, the clinic would get 29,000 square feet for 10 years. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

Since moving to our community in 1989, following an inspired career as an educator in Long Island, Dr. Warrell distinguished himself as a dynamic leader and a most dedicated volunteer. He will be sorely missed. Our thoughts and prayers go to his wife, Lois and his family. William F. Streck, MD, President & CEO Thomas Q. Morris, MD, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing Buys Switches
description: Global Crossing Ltd., owner of a worldwide telephone and data network, signed a multimillion-dollar contract yesterday to buy new all-optical switches from Lucent Technologies Inc. for use in the United States and Europe. Lucent was not more specific about the contract's value. The LambdaRouter switches, which can send billions of e-mail messages each second, will distribute data across Global Crossing's trans-Atlantic fiber optic network.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 25 about James Parton, a founder of American Heritage magazine, misstated the number of times he was married, and omitted some survivors. Mr. Parton was married five times, not two. Besides his widow, Ruth, and his first wife, Jane Bourne, who died in 1962, he was married to Caroline M. Houser, Jane T. Carlson and Mar Jennings. Those marriages ended in divorce. He was survived by seven grandchildren, not five. His son Dana died in 1991.

description: As a young player breaking in with the Toronto Blue Jays, Robert Perez was sometimes used as a designated hitter because of questions about his defensive ability. Now, at 31, he will play the most challenging outfield position for the Yankees.

title: EGL, A GLOBAL FREIGHT COMPANY, TO LAY OFF 950 WORKERS
description: EGL Inc., an international freight company whose customers have been hurt by a slow economy, is cutting its United States work force about 15 percent to help trim $30 million in annual costs after an unexpected first-quarter loss. EGL, based in Houston, dismissed more than 450 employees through May 5 and plans to cut 400 more full-time workers, mostly in the United States, the company said. EGL employs more than 5,000 people in the United States and 9,000 worldwide and is trimming jobs through layoffs and attrition, a spokeswoman, Heather Fedele, said. EGL said its first-quarter loss was $9.1 million, or 19 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $8.5 million, or 18 cents, a year earlier. EGL expects to save $20 million a year from the job cuts and $10 million from other cost-cutting moves, which include consolidating offices.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Higher Pay-Phone Rates
description: The use of cell phones, toll-free numbers and credit cards has led one of the nation's biggest telephone companies, Qwest Communications, to raise the cost of a pay call to 50 cents from 35 cents. Officials of the company, based in Denver, said the change would take place in the next few months as computers adjust 96,000 pay phones in 14 states. The company said emergency calls to 911 would remain free. Qwest's predecessor, U S West, raised the rate from 25 cents to 35 cents over a 12-year period through 1998. Michael Janofsky(NYT)

The giant auction, which featured everything from first-rate Abstract Expressionist paintings to Pop art to pieces by trendy stars of the 1980's and 1990's, brought solid prices. title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Jury Asks For Replay
description: The jury deliberating murder charges against 14-year-old Nathaniel Brazill in the slaying of a teacher asked for the rereading of testimony from several prosecution witnesses. Nathaniel faces a first-degree murder charge in the shooting of his Lake Worth Middle School English teacher, Barry Grunow, 35, a year ago. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Casino Plan Blocked
description: A proposal by three Indian tribes for an off-reservation casino has been blocked by Gov. Scott McCallum. In February, the Lac Courte Oreilles, Red Cliff and Sokaogon bands of the Lake Superior Chippewa won federal approval to put 56 acres in Hudson, Wis., into federal trust for a casino. But in a letter to the Interior Department, Mr. McCallum, who must approve the plan, said the casino would not be in the best interest of the tribe or state residents. The tribes have sued to overturn his decision. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: A Stir-Fry That Isn't
description: I HAVE long enjoyed stir-fried tofu creations like ma-po tofu, a classic dish from Sichuan. But I found making them difficult. Tofu is as delicate as cream cheese and no easier to saut. Unless you pour half an inch or so of oil in the skillet or wok, the tofu sticks and falls apart.

title: The Fish That Swam Uptown
description: SABLEFISH is the Cinderella of the seafood world. But unlike Cinderella, who was transformed in a day, it took sablefish three-quarters of a century to move from the teeming Lower East Side, where it sold for 70 cents a pound and was usually carried home wrapped in butcher paper, to today's grand temples of gastronomy. On its circuitous journey uptown, sablefish, the stuff of Jewish delis, has assumed a fashionable new name and been cloaked in elegant new garments. It has become the darling of the culinistas.

title: Israel Praises Key Peace Plan but Rejects Settlement Freeze
description: JERUSALEM, May 16  Foreign Minister Shimon Peres today praised the report of a committee led by former Senator George Mitchell for its evenhanded analysis of eight months of violence between Israelis and Palestinians, noting that Israel endorses the report as a basis for resuming peace talks even though it rejects a key recommendation for a complete freeze on new Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip and West Bank.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pacts Made On New Domains
description: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, the group that oversees the Internet's address system announced yesterday that it had completed agreements with the two companies that will operate the new .biz and .info databases of names. The two new extensions, known as top-level domains, will be the first introduced to the address system since it became operational in the mid-1980's. The .biz extension -- operated by NeuLevel in Sterling, Va. -- will be restricted to business or commercial interests, while .info -- operated by a consortium of 18 domain registrars -- will be open to any interest. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: BASF CLEARS OUT Less than a year after it began leasing the site, BASF , the worldwide agricultural and industrial products giant, announced it will close its sprawling research facility in West Windsor, N.J., and will begin eliminating the 500 jobs there this fall. BASF leases the 640-acre property, with 700,000 feet of laboratory and other space, at Route 1 and Quakerbridge Road from American Home Products . The lease, which includes a purchase option, runs out in February 2003, but BASF has not decided what to do with the property, said Bill Pagano, a BASF spokesman in Mount Olive, N.J. About 300 researchers will keep working in West Windsor until late 2003, when their functions will move to labs in Ludwigshafen/Limburgerhof, Germany and to Research Triangle Park, N.C., Mr. Pagano said. About 200 support workers will be laid off starting in October. BASF employs 103,000 workers worldwide and had sales totaling $34 billion in 2000, with profits of $1.2 billion, Mr. Pagano said.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST Computer hackers gained access to a public portion of the Legislature's Web site over the weekend, marking the page with Chinese characters. Officials were still trying to trace the source of the attack. Last month, hackers gained access to a United States Department of Labor Web site and posted pictures of Wang Wei, the Chinese pilot killed in a collision with a United States surveillance plane.

title: ROBERT MONDAVI ABANDONS PLAN TO MAKE WINES IN FRANCE
description: Robert Mondavi, the big wine company from Oakville, Calif., is discontinuing an ambitious $8 million project to create France's first foreign-owned vin de terroir, the designation for a wine with special characteristics of a French region, said David Pearson, Mondavi's director in France. Mondavi's plan to plant vineyards outside Aniane, a village near the Mediterranean city of Montpellier, and create top-of-the-line wines for sale in the United States, had divided the local population because it aroused suspicions of a large foreign corporation's entering the area and would have required cutting down a forest where residents had hunted wild boar for centuries. description: WEISSMAN-Dr. Kenneth. My love, please find me again. I see your smile everywhere, sweet lips imprinted on my eyes. I have been betrayed! Today would have been our 2nd wedding anniversary. There are no words to confess the true contours of the pain that accompany my day. Baudelaire's line comes to mind: ''I have felt the wind of the wing of madness.'' and, my love, I dreamt you wanted to feel the wind on your naked skin again. title: Metro Business Briefing | Retailer's Bankruptcy Order
description: Purchasers waiting for delivery from the bankrupt retail chain American Appliance must receive their merchandise or money back, a federal bankruptcy judge ordered Monday. American Appliance abruptly closed its 24 stores in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month, then said it would not reopen. Judge Judith H. Wizmur of Federal Bankruptcy Court in Camden, N.J., ordered that, ''Arrangements will be made to notice each consumer who has paid in full or who has made a deposit for merchandise with instructions about how to process their claims and receive either their merchandise or a refund.'' Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Easier Union Elections Urged
description: Speaking to the New York State AFL-CIO yesterday, Gov. George E. Pataki endorsed the concept of changing state law to allow unions to be recognized without an election if they persuade more than half of the workers at a company to sign union cards. The governor stopped short of endorsing a bill before the Legislature that would legitimize such elections, but said he was willing to negotiate some version of it. The proposed bills would affect only employees covered by the Public Employment Relations Board. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Another Cut by the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday reaffirmed its strong commitment to averting a potential recession. The central bank, led by Alan Greenspan, cut the federal funds rate by a half-point for the fifth time this year. The rate, a key benchmark for short-term borrowing costs in the economy, is now 4 percent. Significantly, the Fed indicated in its statement announcing the move that it stands ready to cut rates even further because economic weakness remains a larger threat on the horizon than does inflation. It is worried about the decline in capital investment and corporate profits, weakening conditions overseas and the possible effect of stock market losses on people's behavior.

description: AMERICAN winemakers still hold tastings in which they pit their wines against the best of France or Italy. If these upstarts outscore the foreigners, it's a glorious victory. But winning isn't necessary.

title: THE PERILS OF PLENTY: A special report; Chad's Wait for Its Oil Riches May Be Long
description: A dozen men waited under the one giant tree that stood luckily for them, given the brutal midday sun -- just across from the front gate of ExxonMobil's office here. They were waiting for lunch time, and one of the new Toyota Land Cruisers carrying an expatriate boss, who might, at long last, stop at the gate and offer them work.

title: Jobs, and a City's Revival, Suffer in a Factory's Blaze
description: The Latex Foam Products plant here churned out tens of thousands of pillows, foam mattresses and cosmetic sponge pads every year, a world leader in the pillow industry and a source of pride -- and jobs -- for this struggling blue-collar city.

title: Democracy Weekend
description: To the Editor:

title: In Senate Battle, Specter of Clinton Wars
description: Republicans and Democrats in the Senate are heading toward a confrontation over the nomination of Theodore B. Olson to be solicitor general, a fight that is for many the latest chapter in the partisan wars of the last few years involving Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Brown Lungs, Lost Fingers; Now, a Lost Mill
description: When it was running wide open, when its workers fed truckloads of 500-pound bales of cotton into its gigantic machines, the mill almost seemed to come alive. It roared, the scarred wooden floors trembled and popped, and tiny scraps of cotton swirled like gnats in the vast, windowless rooms.

title: Japanese Are Told Officially That the Princess Is Expecting
description: The Imperial Household Agency officially confirmed today that Crown Princess Masako is pregnant.

title: City Revoked Arts Grant Illegally, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge in San Antonio ruled today that elected officials in that city acted unconstitutionally in 1997 when they cut off public financing of a controversial arts group that among other things had sponsored a gay and lesbian film festival.

title: Broad Rally on Wall Street Pushes Dow Above 11,000
description: Aday after the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year, stocks of all stripes posted strong gains today and bond prices rose as investors belatedly roared their approval.

title: The Mayor's Divorce Case
description: New Yorkers do not demand much in the way of gentility from their politicians, and even before Mayor Rudolph Giuliani got there, City Hall and Gracie Mansion were not temper-free zones. It is also true that the estrangement between Mr. Giuliani and his wife, Donna Hanover, has been public knowledge at least since Ms. Hanover demurred when asked in 1997 if she had voted for her husband. But even by the bellicose standards of local politics and the Giuliani household, the attack by the mayor's lawyer on Ms. Hanover in scathing language just before Mother's Day weekend was bizarre.

title: THE CHEF
description: IN some ways, my favorite part of my restaurant is the bar. It is a tiny showcase: there are just four stools (and no room for your knees). There, I have a small menu of snacks and cocktails. And though many of the snacks require no cooking at all, they contain flavors I adore and are served just as I would serve them at home when friends come over.

title: Business Travel; Airlines await the return of business passengers, creating bargain opportunities in leisure fares.
description: SOARING air fares usually get most of the blame for the cutbacks in business travel that hammered the airline industry's balance sheets in the first quarter of this year. But there are some early indications that the ascent in air fares has leveled off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, LAWRENCE A.
description: WIENER-Lawrence A. Of New York City and beyond, February 17, 1916 to May 14, 2001. Artist, tennis player, bicyclist, baritone, real estate entrepreneur, philanthopist, master negotiator, and above all, family man. Beloved husband of Ann, brother of Helen, father of Larry, Consuelo, Elizabeth, Bobbin, stepfather of Tim, Jenifer, Chad, Gregg, Monique. Grandfather of Aran, Rachel, Matthew, Daniel, Tamara, Esma, and Max. Celebration of his life to be held this summer. We will miss him.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Results From Applied Materials
description: Hurt by a 30 percent decline in sales from the previous quarter, Applied Materials, the world's largest manufacturer of chip-making equipment, reported quarterly earnings that missed Wall Street's expectations by a penny yesterday. For its second quarter, which ended on April 29, the company reported net income, excluding one-time charges, of $269 million, or 32 cents a share; that was a 41 percent decline from the period a year earlier. Applied Materials, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it expected to break even or earn a few pennies a share this quarter on revenues of $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion, compared with $1.91 billion last quarter. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Study Says Height Makes S.U.V.'s Dangerous in Collisions
description: The height that sport utility vehicles ride off the ground, more than their stiffness or the height of their bumpers, is causing them to inflict unusually heavy damage on cars that they hit in crashes, an insurance industry group said today.

title: New Jersey Prescription Plan Expanded for Elderly and Disabled
description: New Jersey expanded its groundbreaking prescription-drug assistance program, previously limited to low-income residents, to include about 100,000 middle-income disabled and elderly people under a bill signed into law today by Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco.

title: No. 1 Syracuse Next for Upstart Hofstra
description: Life continues to be uphill for the Hofstra men's lacrosse team.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Motient's Capital Move
description: The Motient Corporation, a wireless network company based in Reston, Va., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire Rare Medium Group, a troubled Silicon Alley company that operated as an incubator, consulting and venture capital firm, in a deal estimated to be worth $125 million to $130 million. The deal comes only a month after Rare Medium supplied Motient with a $50 million short-term loan, which was secured by Motient's promise to provide stock in a company it has a controlling interest in, XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. Motient is using some of the cash from the Rare Medium loan to buy the company. The combined company, which will employ about 1,000 people, will maintain offices in New York City and be based in Reston. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Reed to Rescue as a Skid Ends
description: The Mets were not about to count on the comfort of their home field to cure their woes. So, the team's brain trust gathered in Long Island yesterday for what was billed as a regularly scheduled meeting. Then, the team called its first players-only meeting of the season.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrests In Man's Abuse
description: Two men were arrested yesterday on charges that they imprisoned and sexually abused a 26-year-old mentally impaired man for a month in their room at the Times Square Hotel on West 43rd Street. Investigators said the two men, Rusty Heiner, 24, and Michael Sarik, 58, were charged with unlawful imprisonment, sodomy and grand larceny (for cashing the man's Social Security checks, the police say). Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Phillips and Valentine Talk Turkey With Wilpon
description: General Manager Steve Phillips and Manager Bobby Valentine gathered yesterday in the Long Island offices of the Mets co-owner Fred Wilpon for turkey sandwiches and what Phillips and Valentine characterized as a regular meeting on the state of the team. After a 1-6 road trip that ended with six straight losses, the state of the team was not good.

title: Verizon Will Seek a Rate Increase for Local New York Calls
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it would seek approval to raise local phone rates in New York State for the first time in a decade.

title: KEYCORP TO LAY OFF 900 IN 2001, MEETING PERSONNEL GOAL
description: KeyCorp, the banking company, said yesterday that it would cut 900 jobs this year to complete a round of 4,000 dismissals begun in November 1999. KeyCorp is laying off workers as part of an overhaul aimed at improving profit and paring expenses by $360 million. KeyCorp, based in Cleveland, said it had cut 3,100 of those jobs as of March 31 and planned to make the rest of the cuts by year-end, according to a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: In a Slowing Economy, They Are Not Worrying About the Ax
description: Call them the untouchables. As the economy slows and people are laid off, some workers are not sharing the pain. These workers are in professions that are so short-staffed that they are more likely to complain about being overworked than about losing their jobs.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit At Hyundai
description: Hyundai Engineering and Construction announced a first-quarter profit of $35.2 million, four times the year-earlier figure. The troubled company said, however, that most of the profit was in the form of shares that the founder, Chung Ju Yung, left to the company after his death in March. The company in turn transferred the shares, valued at about $60 million, to Korea Exchange Bank and Korea Development Bank as incentive for creditors to agree on a debt-for-equity swap of approximately $2.5 billion. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILIAN, JOSEPH
description: KILIAN-Joseph. May 10, 2001. The Art and Antique Dealers League of America sadly announces the passing of its former secretary (1984-1999). His dedicated service was indispensable in the building and maintenance of the association and its fine reputation. As a member of the League, he was known for his expertise in the field of antique English silver. Our condolences go to his sister, Jerry Appenzeller & his brother, Richard Kilian. He would have been 78 next month. George Subkoff, President James Frankel, Secretary

title: Recipe: Salad of Potatoes, Smoked Sable and Egg Mimosa
description: Adapted from Michael Otsuka

title: Finance Panel Moves Tax Plan Toward a Senate Vote
description: Legislation that would lower the taxes of all Americans who owe income taxes cleared the Senate Finance Committee tonight, moving it one more step toward enactment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARMAN, JANE (NEE SHANKMAN)
description: KARMAN-Jane (Nee Shankman). Wife of the late Sam. Our Aunt Jane passed away peacefully on May 12, 2001 at her home in Plantation Florida. We will remember her indomitable spirit and courage as she confronted life's challenges with enviable vitality, humor and balance. Our condolences to her children, Malcolm and Shira and granddaughter Michaela. Al, Mickey, Steven and Richard Shankman

title: Olbermann and Fox Sports Part Company After 2 Years
description: The eclectic, peripatetic Keith Olbermann is leaving another high-profile job, this time at the Fox Sports empire after a two-year run.

title: News Drops Nondisparagement Clause in Layoffs
description: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the publisher of The Daily News, has dropped a requirement that recently laid-off employees agree not to ''disparage, discredit, defame or belittle'' the newspaper in return for severance benefits, company officials said yesterday.

title: Devils Are Hard on Themselves for Letting Up in the 2nd Period
description: A goal was taken away from Patrik Elias tonight. It would have been a big goal, and Elias noticed that the official who blew the whistle just before he scored was standing on the other side of the net.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHR, BLOSSOM
description: FUHR-Blossom. Passed peacefully on May 14, 2001. Loving sister of Anita Kleinman, Roberta Schneider and Abe Fuhr. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Home of the Aged Blind in Yonkers, NY.

title: Helms and Lieberman Seek to Aid Dissidents in Cuba
description: Seeking to shift the United States' policy toward Cuba, two influential senators, backed by the largest Cuban exile lobby, will introduce legislation on Wednesday to send $100 million in aid to government critics and independent workers in Cuba during the next four years, Congressional officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIBACK, HOWARD
description: RIBACK-Howard. May 11, 2001. Loving husband to Beatrice. Devoted father to Jeffrey and Danna, Rena and Richard Geffen. Beloved grandfather of Jaclyn, Jesse and Gillian. Brother of Jean Edelman and Bunny Yegelwel.

title: A Small Strategy for Troubled Giants
description: Neighborhood high schools, the large, factory-size buildings attended by most people who grew up on the streets of New York City, may be in their twilight years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, MELVILLE J.
description: LEE-Melville J. Of New City, New York. Died Monday, May 14, 2001 at Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 85. He is survived by his wife, Charlotte, daughters Marcia and Judy, sons Michael and Jeffrey and eight grandchildren. For further information please call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

description: Fed Cuts Interest Rates For Fifth Time This Year

description: Following is the full text of an overview of the National Energy Policy proposed by President Bush:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Paintings Stolen
description: The owner of the Joan Peck Fine Paintings gallery on Madison Avenue found the front door pried open yesterday, and up to 15 paintings stolen, the police said last night. The thief or thieves managed to get past an electronically operated security gate and made off with the artworks, which mostly depicted dogs and horses, worth more than $100,000, the police said. Ms. Peck specializes in dog paintings, a recent minor fashion in New York art-buying circles. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Filmmakers Tremble, and Gladiators Fall Apart
description: INSTEAD of the typical hostess-houseguest exchange of threshold banalities, Pauline Kael, all 4 feet 9 fragile inches of her, cuts to the chase and offers an observation. ''You're tall, and I've lost four inches to osteoporosis, so now I'm really a shrimp,'' she announces, squinting up through oversize glasses that, she reveals later when she removes them for a photo in her airy study, make her look distressingly like Peter Sellers (''talented but crazy'').

title: THE BOSS; Speaking Up About Dyslexia
description: When my parents went to medical school, I went back and forth to my grandparents and was spoiled by everybody.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Easier Visas For Tourists
description: The government plans to ease its notoriously circuitous process of granting entry visas to visitors by selling three-day visas at Moscow and St. Petersburg airports and at posts along the Finnish border, officials said. The tourist visas will cost $25; one official said they may restrict travel to limited areas. Existing rules require visitors to apply for visas at local embassies and consulates and often wait weeks for approval. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | BASF Clears Out
description: Less than a year after it began leasing the site, BASF, the worldwide agricultural and industrial products giant, announced it will close its sprawling research facility in West Windsor, N.J., and will begin eliminating the 500 jobs there this fall. BASF leases the 640-acre property, with 700,000 feet of laboratory and other space, at Route 1 and Quakerbridge Road from American Home Products. The lease, which includes a purchase option, runs out in February 2003, but BASF has not decided what to do with the property, said Bill Pagano, a BASF spokesman in Mount Olive, N.J. About 300 researchers will keep working in West Windsor until late 2003, when their functions will move to labs in Ludwigshafen/Limburgerhof, Germany and to Research Triangle Park, N.C., Mr. Pagano said. About 200 support workers will be laid off starting in October. BASF employs 103,000 workers worldwide and had sales totaling $34 billion in 2000, with profits of $1.2 billion, Mr. Pagano said. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Parthus To Acquire Chicory
description: The Dublin-based Parthus Technologies, which designs chips to run wireless Internet devices, will pay $41.4 million in cash and shares to acquire Chicory Systems, a privately held company in Austin, Tex. Chicory's main product, now branded as MachStream, accelerates low-power data processing, and will be integrated with Parthus chip designs for wireless applications and streaming of digital video and audio content. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: When Love Is Brand-New But the Lovers Aren't
description: Selaelo Maredi's ''Beautiful Things'' may be the most adult love story on stage just now, but it is young people who respond most viscerally during performances at the Abrons Art Center of the Henry Street Settlement. Throughout, their half-suppressed sighs and whispers sound like a dialogue between audience and stage, and their cheers at the end make a fine tribute.

title: Governors I. Must Be Sold, A Justice Dept. Memo Says
description: The federal government must sell Governors Island, a former military base in New York Harbor, even though part of it was designated a protected national monument by President Bill Clinton in January, according to a legal memorandum prepared by the United States Department of Justice.

title: 76ers' Fans Called It: Iverson Is Most Valuable Player
description: For weeks, Philadelphia 76ers fans have serenaded Allen Iverson with chants of ''M.V.P., M.V.P.'' during his phenomenal season.

title: Wal-Mart and Home Depot Report Increases in Earnings
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Home Depot Inc. said yesterday that their first-quarter earnings rose as they kept a lid on costs and lured shoppers with low prices to weather the slowing economy. The J. C. Penney Company swung to a profit after posting a loss in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Court Backs Most E.P.A. Action On Polluters in Central States
description: An appeals court here today mostly upheld a crackdown by the Environmental Protection Agency on pollution from 392 Midwestern and Southern factories and power plants, based on petitions by Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITKIN, MERRILL
description: GITKIN-Merrill. The members, Board of Governors and Officers of the Preakness Hills Country Club mourn the loss of a good friend, fellow member of long standing and past President, and extend their deepest sympathies to his wife, Nancy, and the family. Morton Klein, President

title: Did the Gold Medalist Get Extra Help?
description: To the Editor:

title: Candace Phillippi and Judah Trabulsi, Stand UP! Florida Convention, St. Petersburg, Fla., March 3, 2001
description: Phillippi (left): "I've known Judah since I was little. I call him my big brother, and I'm his little sister. We stuck to each other the whole weekend. We were at a big gathering where Christians come together every year. There's concerts, speakers and worship. That was during worship when musicians from Teen Mania Ministry sings songs. I pray and close my eyes, and the songs are going in my head, and I'm worshiping him. It's not rock. It's quiet worship music or fast celebration songs. I listen to them all the time. I downloaded them off of Napster.

title: Lott Rebuked For Delaying Campaign Bill
description: Senator John McCain pushed through the Senate a rebuke of the Republican leader today for acting to ''thwart the will of the majority'' by failing to send to the House the overhaul of the campaign finance law that was handily approved by the Senate last month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column yesterday about counterfeit packages of Neupogen, a drug for cancer patients, omitted a Web address and phone number providing information on how to identify the counterfeits. An updated report appears today on Page A24.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Prank Calls Investigated
description: A prank caller has victimized scores of Long Island women by threatening the rape of a relative unless they answer sexually provocative questions, the Nassau County police said yesterday. More than 70 women have reported receiving such calls, said Officer Robert Jones, over an undisclosed time period. A recent victim managed to record a call, and the authorities held a news conference yesterday to draw public attention to the tape. The caller tells women that his accomplices have a female relative in a van, and that they will rape her unless the victim answers the questions, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEISLER, IRVING. (A.K.A. ''HICKEY'')
description: HEISLER-Irving. (A.K.A. ''Hickey''). Died May 14, 2001 at the age of 87. Beloved husband of Vivienne (deceased). He is survived by his loving son and daughter, Jeff and Toni (Jerry), his adored granddaughter Rebecca, and his dear friend Arlene. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the New York Public Library, or The Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: CITING DOWNTURN, FED LOWERS RATES 5TH TIME THIS YEAR
description: The Federal Reserve continued its campaign to reinvigorate the weakened economy today, cutting its benchmark interest rate half a percentage point for the fifth time this year.

title: Beyond Vindaloo: A New York Tour of India
description: FROM the outside, Mirchi is simply a glimmer of life on a stale stretch of Seventh Avenue South, where cars begin their prolonged crawl toward the Holland Tunnel. But a glance at the menu immediately brightens the outlook.

title: Tranquil Dining in a Cloister (What, No Monkfish?)
description: Cafe St. Bart's, on the outdoor terrace of St. Bartholomew's Church, at 50th Street and Park Avenue, now has a secluded dining area in the church's Alfred Miller Hoyt Cloister. The flower-bedecked courtyard, insulated from Park Avenue traffic and named for a church warden and vestryman, has a fountain and Romanesque-style arches. Its handful of tables can be booked for lunch, dinner and private parties. The cafe, which is run by Leslie Nilsson, also has a new chef, Paul Ripley. His menu is American, stylish and informal, with dishes like a thick pork chop with corn pudding, smoked chicken hash and a crab cake sandwich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLOR, FRANCES WALSH
description: LAWLOR-Frances Walsh. Wife of DFC winner John L. Lawlor. Attended Prospect Hill School and Pine Manor College. Assistant Advertising Manager Saks 1945-'47, staff member Mystic Seaport Museum since 1980. Beloved mother of Elizabeth Davis, Nancy Pennington, Mary Lawlor, Sarah Pearce. Will be buried beside her husband at Arlington National cemetery. In Lieu of flowers, donations to Mystic & Noank Library, Groton, CT., or Waveny Care Center, New Canaan, Ct.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the playwright and actor Jason Miller yesterday referred incompletely to his marriage to Linda Gleason, with whom he had three children. The couple were later divorced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAU, PAUL D.
description: CAU-Paul D., 69. Died May 14, 2001. Beloved husband of Borja. Devoted father of Christopher, Gregory, Dominique and JeanClaude & grandfather of Nicolette & Tyler. Loving brother of Roger, Marionette, Denise, Janine and Simone. The family will receive Friends at Morisco Funeral Home, 30-10 Astoria Boulevard, Astoria, Queens on Wednesday (today) 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Mass of the resurrection at Mount Carmel Church, Astoria, Queens, on Thursday, May 17, at 10:15 AM.

title: Huge Mulch Pile Burns Near Site Of Long Island's 1995 Wildfires
description: A stubborn fire tore through a bone-dry mulch and compost field in Yaphank, N.Y., yesterday, sending a vast arc of windblown smoke high into the sky and reminding Long Islanders of the explosive wildfires that ravaged the Pine Barrens nearly six years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, ALICE MARY CABLE
description: HAYES-Alice Mary Cable. Died May 10, 2001. Survived by husband, Samuel P., children, Susan & Jonathan, and six grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, BEA (TRAGER)
description: FRIEDLANDER-Bea (Trager). A longtime devoted member of The Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, New York. Bea's spirit was indomitable and contagious. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother. She will be missed by all of us. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Laurence A. Feldman, President

title: Levy Says Giuliani's Budget Puts Mayor's Favorite Programs at Risk
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that several education programs recently championed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani were among the initiatives likely to be cut if the City Council does not alter the mayor's budget proposal.

title: As Fighting Goes On, Palestinians Mark a Bitter Milestone
description: Beneath billboards for Coca-Cola and American Legend cigarettes in the main square here, tens of thousands of Palestinians froze in silence today as a three-minute siren marked the 53rd anniversary of what Palestinians call ''the catastrophe'' of their displacement when Israel was founded.

description: William E. Kennard, a former chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, joined the board of The New York Times Company yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OISLANDER, WILLIAM B. DR.
description: OISLANDER-William B. Dr. 87, passed away Monday, May 14, 2001 in Lake Worth, FL. He was a highly respected and dearly loved General Surgeon who practiced in Lindenhurst, NY and NYC for over 50 years. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Lillian, devoted daughters, Meredith Oislander, Marjorie Krause, and cherished grandchildren Lindsay and Allison. Graveside service will be held Wednesday May 16 at 2:30pm at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Direction Of Game Changes Quickly
description: Few would question Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur's credentials. Two Stanley Cups in the last six years quell such nonsense.
