title: Anne Anastasi, the 'Test Guru' of Psychology, Is Dead at 92
description: Dr. Anne Anastasi, whose influence is felt by every student who takes a psychology course and by anyone who fills in the answers on a standardized test intended to measure achievement, intelligence, aptitude, personality or creativity, died on May 4 at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CLARE, ROBERT L., JR.
description: CLARE-Robert L., Jr. A Memorial Service will be held at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave. at 84 St, NY, NY., Wednesday, May 16, 2001 at 2:30 PM.

title: Delays Possible for Over-the-Counter Allergy Drugs
description: Allergy sufferers who hope that Claritin will soon be available over the counter may well be waiting for many months, if not years.

title: Senator's Defection May Doom Milk Bill
description: James M. Jeffords, the longtime Republican senator from Vermont, recently discovered how risky it is to defy the White House.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Review Of Price-Gouging Plan
description: The managers of the state's power grid signaled their opposition yesterday to a plan to impose millions of dollars in fines on power plant owners for price gouging. The State Consumer Protection Board, responding to price manipulation last summer, had proposed that plant owners be fined double any overcharges. The board of the Independent System Operator, which runs the grid, asked its committees to modify the plan. Power producers vehemently opposed the proposal. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Some Papers on Downed Spy Plane Were Not Destroyed
description: The crew of the Navy surveillance plane forced to land in China last month was unable to destroy or dump all of its classified manuals and other documents, and Bush administration officials now assume that the Chinese military gained useful information about the workings of American reconnaissance flights, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide, White Plains, to Avrett Free & Ginsberg, New York, part of the Bozell Group unit of True North Communications, to handle its St. Regis hotel brand, which had been at Weiss Stagliano Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $6 million.

title: Chasing Hard After Luck
description: Success doesn't always come to those who deserve it. And that's because it takes not just talent but also timing. The illusion that aspiring pop stars often have is that they can control the timing, perhaps by recording the perfect pop song just at the moment when their sound is in style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNEY, ROBERT
description: BENNEY-Robert. The Officers and members of The Society of Illustrators deeply mourn the passing of beloved member Bob Benney. He will be missed by all who knew him.

title: Oh, Jackie!
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Biscotti Look Like Milquetoasts
description: LOVERS of soft, chewy cookies, read no further. For I have found what may be the hardest, nuttiest, most aggressively spiced cookies on earth.

title: Indifference to California
description: The unveiling of President Bush's energy strategy tomorrow will be accompanied by the usual White House hoopla and followed by a presidential tour aimed at selling Mr. Bush's proposals to the country and to Congress. The proposals will consist of long-term solutions to a range of energy problems, some of them real and some exaggerated. Meanwhile, however, Mr. Bush continues to give short shrift to a genuine crisis that needs immediate attention -- the energy mess in California, which is likely to become even more burdensome to individuals and more dangerous to California's financial integrity as the summer months approach.

title: The Isles of Greece in Microminiature
description: AT 380 square feet, kitchen included, and with seating for 10, barely, Snack is one of Manhattan's smallest restaurants. Even so, Elias Varkoutas, who opened Snack in SoHo in 1999, thought there was room enough to take on a partner. So he has joined forces with Adam Greene, a former general manager of Aquavit and Union Pacific. Together, they have expanded Snack's menu and hours, transforming a luncheonette serving vegetarian Greek appetizers into a restaurant with full Greek meals.

title: A New Line of Old-Time Ice Creams
description: Old-fashioned is a term that crops up a lot when Allysa Torey, above, the owner of Magnolia Bakery, 401 Bleecker Street (11th Street), talks about her new ice creams. Her chocolate chip has little semi-sweet chips; butter brickle has bits of crunch embedded in silken vanilla; the four others include peanut-butter swirl with a nice salty edge, and vanilla cookies and cream. They are made by Welsh Farms in West Caldwell, N.J. Scoops ($2.50) are sold from a cart outside. Starting Friday, pints ($3.99) will be sold at Grace's Marketplace and Gourmet Garage, Citarella and Balducci's stores.

title: China Unconvinced as Missile Talks End
description: Even as President Bush's emissary was here making the case for a missile defense system, the Chinese government publicly condemned the proposal on Tuesday, calling it a fruitless step that would endanger global security.

title: Live Trade Bait for Webber? Camby Says, I Don't Think So
description: Marcus Camby doesn't see himself as trade bait in a possible attempt by the Knicks to acquire Chris Webber, the Sacramento Kings' forward who can become a free agent this off-season. In fact, Camby, the Knicks' center, sees himself and Webber as partners on a new and improved Knick front line.

title: MetroStars To Focus On Spencer
description: John Spencer, the Scottish international player, will be the main challenge for the MetroStars tonight when they play the Colorado Rapids at Giants Stadium. The 30-year-old Spencer has scored or assisted on six of Colorado's seven goals this season.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Victory For President's Foe
description: Prosecutors broke the law early this year when they jailed a leading critic of the nation's embattled president, Leonid D. Kuchma, before a trial on public corruption charges, Ukraine's supreme court ruled. Yuliya Tymoshenko, head of the Fatherland Party, spent six weeks in a holding cell before being released on March 27. She faces trial on charges of bribery, smuggling and forgery linked to an earlier job as head of a natural-gas trading company. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Yankees Squander Chances to Win in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 15 - Roger Clemens came to the Yankees already in pursuit of his 300th victory, knowing that the presence of a strong closer like Mariano Rivera would increase his chances. But a little more offensive support would help, too.

title: Sports of The Times; Here's What The Dolans Should Do
description: SORRY, but I don't have much time for this right now. I'm so afraid my hero Tony Soprano is going to take a bullet in Sunday's season finale that I don't have much empathy left for peripheral issues like Dave Checketts and who's going to run Madison Square Garden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBEL, MONROE
description: SOBEL-Monroe. Of Florida and Long Beach, NY. Beloved husband of Beatrice, dear father of Irene Ross and the late Lee Sobel, grandfather of Adam and Joanna Ross. Loved and missed by all.

title: They're Putting Money Where Your Mouth Is
description: TWO words on a menu are guaranteed to strike fear into the heart of any card-carrying New Yorker: Cash only.

title: U.S. Panel Backs Broader Steps To Reduce Risk of Heart Attacks
description: Impressed by mounting evidence that deaths from heart disease could be significantly reduced with aggressive treatments, a national panel recommended yesterday that millions more Americans take powerful cholesterol-lowering drugs or immediately alter their diets.

title: Hong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu
description: HONG KONG, May 16  In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in 1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4,700 chickens after public health officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu.

title: Judge Closes Down Tax-Advice Company
description: A marketing company that persuaded 50,000 people that they could drastically lower their income tax bills if they bought the company's system was shut down yesterday by a Kansas judge, who ruled that the plan was an illegal pyramid scheme of a ''fundamentally deceptive nature.''

title: Decision on Nazi Reparations Is Appealed
description: Lawyers for German industry joined with lawyers for Nazi-era slave laborers yesterday to appeal a decision by a federal judge that they say will block payment of reparations to victims of the Nazi regime.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Ruling May Erode Longshoremen's Grip on Ports
description: In a major blow to the longshoremen's union and its grip on the docks of New York Harbor, a stevedoring company will be allowed to use members of its laborers' union to unload some ships at Port Newark.

title: Reliving a Life In Film as He Recuts His Gem
description: ''It was the bad-boy movie of its time,'' recalled Francis Ford Coppola as the Mediterranean sunshine burned off the last lingering clouds of the morning. He was talking about ''Apocalypse Now,'' and although his beard is mostly gray, Mr. Coppola at 62 discussed his film, which had its premiere here on Friday in an expanded version as ''Apocalypse Now Redux,'' with an unguarded enthusiasm that can only be described as boyish.

title: In the Catskills, Water Hazards; A 36-Hole, 500-Acre Resort Plan Draws Opposition
description: There were snickers and snide comments five years ago when Dean L. Gitter built Catskill Corners, a gaudy gift-shop mall featuring the world's largest kaleidoscope and a silo painted with psychedelic designs. Even Mr. Gitter, an actor-turned-developer who wears a cowboy hat and ponytail, seemed happy to poke fun at his hucksterish image, promoting himself as ''the P.T. Barnum of the Catskills.''

title: Parody, Not Plagiarism
description: To the Editor:

title: Hope, Helplessness and Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; A Tunnel Too Far, Or Is It?
description: BIG problems demand big solutions, so commuters should be grateful that Alexander Saunders has come along with a proposal for what can only be described as an Erie Canal for cars.

title: Checketts Leaves Knicks Murkier
description: With Latrell Sprewell demanding change, Allan Houston opting out of his contract and the hope of landing Chris Webber alive throughout the Knicks' organization, this off-season was already destined to be one of the team's most complicated in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREVOR, EVELYN L. BRUEN
description: TREVOR-Evelyn L. Bruen. May 14, 2001 at Palm Beach. Greatgreat granddaughter of John Jay, first Chief Justice of the United States. Survived by her husband of 62 years, John B. Trevor, Jr. three children, nine grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren.

title: Yahoo Goes Beyond Initial Plan Against Adult Sites
description: A month after Yahoo, the Internet service, eliminated a section that offered pornographic videos from its shopping area, the company has begun making it harder for users to find sexually explicit chat rooms and clubs. The action has sparked anger and fear among users, prompting thousands of them to sign a petition demanding that the company continue to maintain the popular online forums.

title: Boston Medical Center Turns to Lawyers for a Cure
description: A doctor gets very tired of this kind of thing: sending a child with asthma home to an apartment full of roaches and mold; telling the parents of an anemic toddler to buy more and healthier food when they clearly do not have a cent; seeing babies who live in unheated apartments come in again and again with lung ailments.

title: A Gag That Isn't So Funny
description: THE Giuliani family saga, which has all the charm of a blowtorch, brings to mind a Mel Brooks scene. Not from the white-hot show of the moment, ''The Producers.'' This is from his 1974 film, ''Blazing Saddles.''

title: Not Just for Brightening Up the Old Yurt Anymore
description: For centuries, the folk art of this mountainous realm reflected the nomadic wanderings of its people, and even the most beautiful and precious goods had to be useful and portable.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the pressure on NBC to expand its holdings misidentified the company that produces ''Law and Order.'' It is Studios USA, a division of USA Networks Inc., which is owned in part by Vivendi Universal. The producer is not Vivendi's Universal Studios.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a trip to Milwaukee by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the seven members of the Board of Education to study schools that receive tuition vouchers misstated the viewpoint of Greg Brooks, the Brooklyn member of the board. While Mr. Brooks has expressed skepticism about vouchers, he has not said that he would vote against such a program. He has not stated how he might vote.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Legislative Web Site  Sabotaged
description: Computer hackers gained access to a public portion of the Legislature's Web site over the weekend, marking the page with Chinese characters. Officials were still trying to trace the source of the attack. Last month, hackers gained access to a United States Department of Labor Web site and posted pictures of Wang Wei, the Chinese pilot killed in a collision with a United States surveillance plane. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENSTEIN, BENJAMIN S.
description: LOEWENSTEIN-Benjamin S. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of our dear friend Benjamin Loewenstein. Ben was a devoted member of our National Board of Governors for more than 40 years and a beloved member of two AJC chapters. In Philadelphia, he served as Chairman of the Board, and as a successful attorney since 1937, he worked diligently to open the doors of local law firms and banks to Jewish professionals. In Palm Beach County, he served on numerous committees to improve the Jewish condition and the human condition and, along with his wife Eleanor, was recently honored with the chapter's Founders Award. Ben was a man of great compassion, warmth and human kindness. We will miss his gentle nature and his wise counsel. We send our sincere condolences to Eleanor, his children, stepchildren and grandchildren. Harold Tanner, President David A. Harris, Exec. Dir. Shulamith Bahat, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGORAD, ALAN D.
description: BOGORAD-Alan D. Age 85, of Swampscott, MA, on May 13. Beloved father of Susan Bogorad, Carol and J. Frederick Bush. Grandfather of Dorothy B. and Christopher Thompson, Frederick and Christopher Bush. Great grandfather of Charles Thompson.

title: Italy's New Premier Begins Formalities of His New Post
description: ROME, May 16  After two days of secluded talks with advisers, Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's newly elected prime minister, paid a call on the president today, the first formality on his way to taking office.

title: A Small Space With a Lot to Share
description: WHEN 71 Clinton Fresh Food took the dining world by storm in the fall of 1999, it raised the bar for modest little restaurants all over downtown. It was the ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' of restaurants, a surprise low-budget hit that everyone wants to replicate. No longer is it enough to send out decent food at a decent price. Now, every little bote with 10 tables hopes to have its own cult.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELIZER, RABBI NATHAN
description: ZELIZER-Rabbi Nathan. We record with profound sadness the passing of our beloved colleague. In 1931, he became rabbi of Tifereth Israel Congregation in Columbus until he became rabbi emeritus in 1973. In 1980, he founded Beth Ami in Boca Raton and was also named its emeritus. He was instrumental in the establishment of the Melton Foundation for Jewish Education. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Jeanette and children, Deborah Kaplan, and our colleague and past president, Rabbi Gerald Zelizer, and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. V.P. The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Text of Fed's Statement
description: Following is the text of a statement by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, decided to lower interest rates:

title: California, With Attitude
description: FOR years, my attitude toward California sauvignon blanc was, ''Why bother?'' After all, it's hard to beat Sancerre and Pouilly-Fum for sauvignon blanc in its purest form: crisp, piquant and herbal. New Zealand has put its brand on a bolder style of great intensity. And let's not forget the weighty, complex Bordeaux whites, which generally are blends of sauvignon blanc and smillon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOFF, IDA F. EDD.
description: DAVIDOFF-Ida F. EdD. Passed away May 11, 2001. Marital and Family Therapist and Lecturer on healthy aging. Memorial service 4pm, June 8 at her home. Donations in lieu of flowers to the Banyan Tree Fund c/o The Fairfield County Foundation, 523 Danbury Road, Wilton, Ct. 06897.

title: RealNetworks to Put Its Software On Sony's PlayStation2 Console
description: Adding another piece to its goal of connecting video games and the Internet, Sony Computer Entertainment plans to announce on Wednesday a partnership to place streaming music and video player software from RealNetworks in the PlayStation2 game console.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Report Urges Bus Expansion
description: Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, said yesterday that a yearlong study of the county's transportation system ''tells us that we need to get people out of cars and onto the bus.'' Suffolk County Transit's new and expanded bus service, going into effect on May 29, should attract more riders to the system, Mr. Gaffney said. The new study also recommends more bus shelters and more highways. Al Baker (NYT)

title: So Happily Ever After, Beauty and the Beasts
description: The filmmaking team behind ''Shrek'' takes the bare bones of William Stieg's children's book about an ogre who thinks filthiness is next to godliness and glories in bad manners and ickiness and uses that as a taking-off point for a new animated film that rejoices in its own brand of perversity.

title: The Boss: Speaking Up About Dyslexia
description: When my parents went to medical school, I went back and forth to my grandparents and was spoiled by everybody.

title: Plea Bargain Talks Stall in Spying Case
description: A lawyer for Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent accused of spying for Russia, said talks about a plea bargain had broken off because government prosecutors had refused to offer a deal that would spare Mr. Hanssen's life.

title: An I.O.C. Report Gives Three Cities High Marks
description: Beijing appeared to remain the front-runner while Paris and Toronto received encouraging evaluations yesterday in a report issued by the International Olympic Committee that assessed the cities trying to play host to the 2008 Summer Games.

title: Job and Tax Data Show the Slowdown Reaching New York
description: The New York metropolitan economy, so strong for so long, is finally beginning to show signs of strain from the national slowdown.

title: INSIDE
description: Tax Cut Clears Senate Panel

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Crackdown On Tobacco
description: The European Parliament gave final approval to a new tobacco code that will put graphic photos depicting the harmful effects of smoking on cigarette packs. The directive also calls for a reduction of tar and nicotine in cigarettes and bans terms like ''light'' and ''mild'' on cigarette brands on the ground that they mislead smokers. The directive will begin to come into effect in about 18 months, when the 15 European Union members enact it in national laws. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Weaving Dreams, or Webs?; Michael Dorf of Knitmedia, the Entrepreneur of the Musically Avant
description: On a bright, cold afternoon in mid-January, Michael Dorf, owner of the Knitting Factory clubs in New York and Hollywood, strode into Odeon, a restaurant on West Broadway. His cell phone was attached to his ear, as always. To a harmless greeting -- ''How are you?'' -- Mr. Dorf, small, 38 and cyberhippie-ish, responded without his normal impish gleam. ''That's a loaded question,'' he sighed.

title: Audit of Union Details a Smorgasbord of Abuses
description: A new audit of District Council 37, New York City's giant municipal employees' union, adds embarrassing new details about systematic corruption and lavish perks at the union, including its spending $345,000 for a reception at a union convention.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Chief At Energis
description: Energis, Britain's largest Internet traffic carrier, said its chief executive, Mike Grabiner, would retire as of Aug. 1, and would be replaced by David Wickham, left, currently the chief operation officer. The shuffling comes as the company reported a loss of 98 million ($139 million), 6.1 pence a share, for the year to March 31, compared with a loss of 41.2 million, or 2.8 pence a share, a year earlier. Sales grew to 832.4 million, from 491 million a year ago, driven by acquisitions. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Mail Bonding
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Hewlett-Packard Revenues Fall but Top Revised Forecasts
description: Hewlett-Packard reported second-quarter earnings today that beat Wall Street's twice-lowered expectations by 3 cents a share, and the company restated its belief that revenue, which has fallen sharply in the last year, appeared to have hit bottom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, ESTELLE BROADMAN
description: HELLER-Estelle Broadman. Beloved wife of the late Sol Heller, mother of Anthony and Daniel, grandmother of Ry, Lauren and Jill, on May 11, 2001 in Ashland, Oregon. We will miss her.

title: Yankees Stew Over Missed Opportunities
description: OAKLAND, Calif., May 16  Gory details of the Yankees' loss in 12 innings Tuesday blared over the television in the visitors' clubhouse after the game, an ESPN announcer reporting the failures of the offense before noting that no batter had a worse day than Paul O'Neill  no hits in six at-bats.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Failed Heart Transplants Linked To Cold Virus
description: Heart transplants in children may sometimes fail because of infection with a common cold virus, researchers reported in The New England Journal of Medicine. They found the five-year survival rate was 62 percent among children who had an adenovirus infection of the new heart; it was 96 percent among those without the infection. Adenovirus causes colds, pinkeye and myocarditis, an inflammation of heart tissues. Researchers suggested that a vaccine against the virus might help prevent transplant failures. Philip J. Hilts (NYT)

title: Bush Is Likely to Meet Putin During June Visit to Europe
description: American officials said today that President Bush would probably meet Russia's president, Vladimir N. Putin, during a trip to Europe in June. The session will present their first opportunity to discuss several points of friction between Washington and Moscow, including the administration's missile defense plans, the future of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and Mr. Bush's oft-stated reluctance to provide additional financial aid to Russia.

title: Didi, 71, Elegant Midfielder Of Brazil's Soccer Champions
description: Didi, one of the world's most creative soccer players who, as the team captain, led Brazil to World Cup championships in 1958 and 1962, died on Saturday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUT, RABBI IRWIN
description: HAUT-Rabbi Irwin. Young Israel of Flatbush mourns the passing of our beloved member and supporter, Rabbi Irwin Haut. Kenneth Auman, Rabbi Mark Goldstein, President

title: Getting the F.B.I. in Harness
description: At first glance, the growing litany of grievous mistakes made by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in recent years seems to lack a common thread. The problems have ranged from an excessive, undisciplined use of force at Ruby Ridge and Waco to complacency about internal security in the case of the F.B.I. agent accused of spying for Moscow. The latest transgression, the missing evidence about the Oklahoma City bombing, suggests acute disorganization. But running through these and other lapses is a chronic failure of management. President Bush needs to find a new director who can get control of the F.B.I. and ensure that it exercises its considerable law enforcement powers fairly and effectively.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Filters Reprieve For Libraries
description: Public libraries will have until next summer to install Internet filtering technology that is required by federal law, under terms of an agreement reached in federal court in Philadelphia. The American Civil Liberties Union and the American Library Association challenged part of the Children's Internet Protection Act, passed last year, requiring libraries and schools to install software that would block access to ''child pornography'' and other online material considered obscene or harmful to minors. As part of the legislation, libraries and schools would lose federal grants for Internet connections unless they agree to install the filters. The groups contend that the law, which called for compliance by July 2001, is heavy-handed and interferes with local control of public libraries, a spokeswoman for the library association said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, JUDY
description: SPRUNG-Judy. Memorial service on May 21 at 8 PM at the Gramercy Park Hotel, 2 Lexington Ave.

title: Two Found Shot to Death on Banks of the Hudson
description: The bodies of two men who had been shot in the head were found yesterday on the banks of the Hudson River in Upper Manhattan.

title: Boy Who Killed Teacher Is Found Guilty of Murder
description: A jury convicted a 14-year-old boy of second-degree murder today for fatally shooting his favorite teacher. But the jury decided not to find the boy, Nathaniel Brazill, guilty of the most severe charge he faced, first-degree murder, thus sparing him a mandatory sentence of life in prison without parole.

title: Sports of The Times; Ignore Stern; Teenagers Should Play
description: A CAR can be a lethal weapon, a soldier in combat can suffer grave consequences, getting married and raising children can be a serious matter, and voting for politicians can change the nation. Even laboring on a garbage truck plays a significant role in sanitizing a community. These are all things that young men 18 and 19 years old can do in America. What they shouldn't be allowed to do is play basketball for a living, according to David Stern, the newly minted education commissioner of the National Basketball Association.

title: Cramped Singapore Military Relies on Space Elsewhere
description: SINGAPORE  Whenever Tan Kah Han, a lieutenant colonel in the Singapore Air Force, takes off to the north for training in his F-16C jet fighter, he faces an immediate problem: Climbing at 540 kilometers per hour, he has barely 45 seconds to avoid crossing the border with Malaysia, less than three kilometers away.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINNEGAN, JR., LAWRENCE J.
description: FINNEGAN, Jr.-Lawrence J. To my dearest Larry. Two years have passed and you are missed by many. Your name is spoken with a smile as we remember the laughter you gave us. Not a day passes that I do not think about you. I miss you terribly. You are forever in my heart and a part of my soul. You are unforgettable and I will love you always. With love and devotion. Jackie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOMMER, ESTHER
description: SOMMER-Esther. My beloved mother has joined my father Smitty and my sister Bonnie at rest, leaving me Elissa, her second daughter, alone in my grief. Mother is survived by the love of her life, her grandson Michael Samuel, named in blessed memory of my father and Zadie. Her sisters and brothers Minnie, Marilyn, Betty, and Ruth, Abe, David, and Mort also survive her. She was a founding member of United Leukemia Fund and an active member of Hadassah. My mother, my partner, my best friend will be missed more than words can express. Donations to Hadassah or a cancer research organization in her memory will be appreciated. The service will be held at Sherman's, 1283 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, 12 noon, Thursday, May 17th. Elissa Sommer

title: Honors
description: * The commercial and film director Tony Kaye was named the first recipient of the lifetime achievement award to be presented by Clio Awards, owned by VNU. He will be honored May 24 at the 42nd annual Clio Festival in Miami Beach.

title: Unadorned Sniping
description: To the Editor:

title: Proposals, With Catches,in Nursing Strike
description: Hoping to resolve a two-week strike at Connecticut's nursing homes, Gov. John G. Rowland asked unionized workers today to immediately adopt a 60-day no-strike provision and urged both parties to return to the bargaining table.

title: Jets Discover Their Coach's Joyful Energy
description: The Jets learned more this week about their new coach, Herman Edwards, and more about his energy and his joy. For Edwards, this Jets minicamp offers another chance to stroke and to nudge and to chastise and to commend -- to coach the communication-first way, his way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGMAN, ARTHUR
description: BREGMAN-Arthur. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Adored father of Lisa. Loving brother of Phyllis Olin & Myron Bregman. Dear brotherin-law of Vivian Bregman, Janet Mayer and the late Alvin Olin. Devoted uncle. Service today 12 Noon at Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Revisiting Familiar Territory With a Sense of Discovery
description: The pianist Claude Frank made his official recital debut at Times Hall in New York in 1947. But he has always considered his real New York debut, the concert that brought him widespread attention and inaugurated his important career, to be a 1951 recital at Town Hall.

title: CALENDAR
description: Gehry on Gehry

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GOLF DIGEST COS., New York, has agreed to buy the Golf for Women magazine from the Meredith Corp., Des Moines.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Front Row column of the Fashion page on Tuesday about the wardrobe worn by the actress Charlotte Gainsbourg at the Cannes Film Festival misspelled the surname of her mother, who had a dress that was once remade for Ms. Gainsbourg. She is Jane Birkin, not Birken.

title: IN ENERGY PLAN, BUSH URGES NEW DRILLING, CONSERVATION AND NUCLEAR POWER REVIEW
description: President Bush's long-awaited energy plan proposes loosening regulations on oil and gas exploration, conservation-minded efforts like a review of gas mileage standards and a $4 billion tax credit for a new generation of highly fuel efficient cars, and urges a reconsideration of a quarter-century ban on the reprocessing of nuclear fuel.

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Indicted in Spy Case
description: A federal grand jury indicted the former F.B.I. agent Robert P. Hanssen today on charges that he had spied for Moscow for more than 15 years, revealing the identities of Russian agents working for the United States and other secrets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIENSIS, SHELDON
description: OLIENSIS-Sheldon. On May 14, 2001 at age 79. Husband of Lyn. Father of John Oliensis and Lucretia Moroni, Jane Oliensis, Ellen Oliensis and John Shoptaw. Grandfather of Melina and Chiara Bernardi, Rebecca Shoptaw and Adrian Oliensis. Brother of Doris Woldow and Dr. Asher Woldow. Also survived by many nephews, nieces, grand nephews and grand nieces. The funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held later. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Sheldon Oliensis Scholarship Fund at the Harvard Law School or to a charity of your choice.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Hyperion Cuts Staff 15%
description: Hyperion Solutions, a publisher of business analysis software, said it would lay off as many as 15 percent of its nearly 2,700 employees to reduce expenses. The announcement came less than a month after the company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., reported a $1.3 million third-quarter loss on sales of $130.2 million. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Jobless Rate Falls
description: Three weeks before a general election, Britain's jobless rate was reported to have fallen to a 26-year low of 3.2 percent in April from 3.3 percent in March. And the slowing growth of wages and inflation suggested that the Bank of England might follow the United States Federal Reserve in a further reduction of interest rates. The data was more good news for Prime Minister Tony Blair, already well ahead in opinion surveys. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: When the Art's Public, Is the Site Fair Game?
description: TEN years ago, David Brooks, a computer programmer in Toronto, came across a passing reference to the Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh in one of Frank Herbert's ''Dune'' novels. In the book, which takes place in the future, one of the few artifacts of civilization to survive global destruction is the van Gogh painting ''Thatched Cottages at Cordeville.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE FALLS. Gasoline fell as rising inventories spurred expectations that supplies will be adequate this summer. In New York, gasoline for June delivery fell 1.6 cents, or 1.6 percent, to 98.76 cents a gallon.

title: Fuel Cells: Not So Expensive
description: To the Editor:

title: A Search Engine Goes Beyond Google
description: THERE seems to be little argument among Web-search gurus that Google is one of the best search engines out there -- if not at the top of the heap. It has won awards from more than a dozen magazines and is now used by Yahoo and Netscape to augment their category-based Web site directories.

title: National Briefing | Education: Teacher Salaries Are Said To Lag Behind Inflation
description: The average teacher salary rose 3.2 percent from 1998-99 to 1999-2000, to $41,820, less than the 3.4 percent rate of inflation, a survey by the American Federation of Teachers shows. Connecticut, New York and New Jersey had the highest average salaries, all more than $50,000; the least-paid teachers, in South Dakota, Oklahoma and North Dakota, earned about $29,000. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Mayor's Divorce Lawyers Seek New Order of Silence
description: Lawyers for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have asked a judge to impose another order of silence over his divorce case, saying in legal papers submitted this week that such an order would prevent Donna Hanover, the mayor's estranged wife, from gratifying her ''private spite.''

title: A Giver of Parties That a Set Jetted In For
description: WHEN Mary Wells Lawrence was 12 and growing up in the small town of Poland, Ohio, she had a recurring dream about an imposing white house perched on a cliff above the sea. ''Believe me, I knew nothing of big houses or oceans when I was 12,'' she said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Death-Sentence Bill Advances
description: The State Senate passed a bill that would allow death sentences for gang-related murders. The bill, which the House is expected to pass, could add more people to the state's death row. It was not clear if Gov. George Ryan, who imposed a moratorium on the death penalty last year after several people awaiting execution were exonerated, would sign the bill. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: New Portable Hard Drive Is Part Warehouse, Part Floppy
description: A nifty new external hard drive is trying to become the diskette of its generation. The makers of the Pockey drive, which can hold up to 20 gigabytes of data, say that it is the smallest, lightest and most portable hard drive available. The drive both transfers data and receives power via a U.S.B. connection. Almost every computer nowadays has a U.S.B. port, but the drive's slow transfer rate may annoy heavy users. The makers say that the drive moves data at up to 1.5 megabytes per second, so backing up 20 gigabytes of data could easily take more than four hours. Still, fans of miniaturization will find carrying around the equivalent of 1.25 million double-spaced, typewritten pages in a shirt pocket to be endlessly appealing.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: INSIDE
description: Former F.B.I. Agent Indicted

title: Ukraine Calls Newsman's Killing Nonpolitical; Skeptics Abound
description: Wielding adjectives like ''stupid'' and ''plodding,'' critics of President Leonid Kuchma heaped ridicule today on a government claim that a leading opposition journalist was killed not for political reasons but randomly, by two hooligans who were themselves killed later.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''You can literally wake up in the morning, log on and start losing all your money.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, DR. WANDA S.
description: WALSH-Dr. Wanda S. On May 16, age 74 after a short illness. She is survived by her husband of 48 years, Dr. Robert J. Walsh, whom she met in their first year at NYU Medical School. They graduated together in the class of 1950. She was an attending Pediatrician at NYU-Bellevue for 50 years and also at St. Vincent's Hospital for some time. She is survived by her children, Grail O'Neill, Noel Daniels, Robert T. Walsh, Susan McCarthy, MD, Patricia Siebecker, and ten grandchildren. She is also survived by her mother, Maria Scala, age 102, her brother Elio Scala and sister Clelia Paolino. Visiting hours Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at McMahon Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Sorrows Church, White Plains 9:30 AM, Saturday. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Article 2001051791211073752 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Injury to Jaha, Not a Fastball, Bothers Howe
description: Oakland Manager Art Howe came running out of the dugout after Roger Clemens threw a fastball high over the head of John Jaha on Tuesday night. But his alarm had nothing to do with a possible brushback pitch. Howe was concerned because Jaha had strained a leg muscle jackknifing his body and had fallen to the ground in pain.

title: For Trees, Some Respect; For Bikes, a Berth
description: An urban fence may yet make good neighbors of tree huggers and bicycle riders. A competition held by Trees New York, an educational group, and Cooper Union elicited 80 designs for a combination tree guard and bike rack. The winner, top, by Manuel Saez, a graduate design student at the University of Bridgeport, looks like a half-buried steel figure eight. Any number of them can be used to surround trees of different diameters or to form a fence. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: XBOX To Go On Sale Nov. 8
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it would start selling its Xbox video game system in the United States on Nov. 8 for $299. Although the company has committed $500 million to promote Xbox, the starting date gives Microsoft just a few weeks to build interest before the holiday shopping season begins. Robbie Bach, chief Xbox officer at Microsoft, said the company would have 600,000 to 800,000 consoles and 15 to 20 games available for sale. Sony, expected to be one of Xbox's major competitors, experienced embarrassing production shortages when it introduced its PlayStation 2 last fall. The competing video game consoles will be offered at identical suggested retail prices. A third game console, GameCube by Nintendo, is expected to reach North American stores on Nov. 5. title: Metro Business Briefing | Birthing An Overdue Hospital
description: After a long series of delays, officials at Jersey City Medical Center say they will finally begin building a replacement hospital this summer, now that the federal government has agreed to underwrite a $172 million mortgage. Liberty HealthCare System, which owns the medical center, plans to build a 326-bed hospital on vacant ground just east of the existing Art Deco medical complex built in the 1930's. Jonathan M. Metsch, Liberty's president, said approval of the mortgage guarantee by the Federal Housing Administration made the project feasible by ensuring that Liberty can issue investment-grade construction bonds. He said Representative Robert Menendez was instrumental in securing the guarantee. Liberty had hoped to begin building the hospital, which has been in planning since 1983, in the mid-1990's, but its finances went ''into a tailspin,'' Dr. Metsch said, after a cut in Medicaid reimbursements. He said the medical center regained its financial health with a $3 million surplus in 1999, the year it applied for the mortgage. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, JEROME
description: BRODY-Jerome. Successful businessman, restaurateur, thoroughbred horse breeder & owner, political activist and devoted husband and father, died yesterday in Miami, Florida at the age of 78. Mr. Brody is perhaps best known for his successful restaurants, Gallagher's Steak House and the Grand Central Oyster Bar. However, he was equally successful as a breeder of thoroughbred race horses and champion Angus cattle. He was also very active in politics, supporting and working for John F. Kennedy, Edward I. Koch, and Mario M. Cuomo, among others. Mr. Brody developed Restaurant Associates from a loose string of coffee houses into a powerful and profitable business. He conceived and initiated the movement to create high quality destination restaurants in New York City, beginning with the development of the Four Seasons. With architect Philip Johnson, Brody also transformed the Rainbow Room, atop the then RCA Building, from a failing eatery into a world-class restaurant and night spot. One of Mr. Brody's greatest insights was the intersection between the public and private sectors. He turned Restaurant Associates around by recognizing the need for quality food service at public locations. He worked with the Port Authority and the New York Thruway Authority to meet their needs and requirments, providing a quality service to the traveling pubic and also making a profit. The Grand Central Oyster Bar became a success because Brody understood the limitations and opportunity of a premier but decaying public space. His revitalization of the restaurant helped improve the environment and safety of the station. His support of the renovation of the station enabled it to go forward and the restaurant provides an anchor to ensure the public expenditures will continue to be viewed as well spent. With his wife, the former Marlene HeiderGray, Jerome Brody built Gallagher Stud in Ghent, N.Y. into the leading thoroughbred breeding farm in the state. International Champion Allez Milord won graded stakes in Europe and the United States and was ultimately sold for stud duty in Japan. Among the many successful horses raced by Jerome and Marlene Brody, include Adorable Micol, Adcat and Adorydar. In public position in the thoroughbred racing industry, Brody strongly advocated for improved health and safety procedures for the horses, including technologically advanced emergency medical vans on the race track and state-of-the-art medical clinics on the race track, to treat injured horses. The son of a successful New York businessman, Jerome Brody was educated at Dartmouth College. He interrupted his studies to become a B-24 Air Corps pilot during WWII. Before his death, Mr. Brody arranged to sell both the Oyster Bar and Gallagher's restaurants to his employees at the two restaurants. He also arranged for equity interests for his senior managers at Gallagher's Stud in Ghent, N.Y. Brody also protected the future of the upstate farm throught the mechanism of a land trust. His wife Marlene, also his best friend, his sister Ellie, his children Kathy and Scott, and his grandchildren, Jill, Jason, Marisa, Leigh, David and Rick survive Mr. Brody. Friday, May 18th, viewing from 6-9PM at FrankE. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street, N.Y., N.Y. (212-288-3500), Saturday, May 19th, 12 Noon service at Frank E. Campbell, Sunday, May 20th viewing from 6-9PM at Wenk Funeral Home, Chatham, N.Y. (518392-2909), Monday, May 21st interment service at Gallagher's Stud, Leggett Road, Ghent, N.Y. 12075 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in memory of Jerome Brodymay be made to the Dartmouth Medical Center, Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis Research, Hanover, N.H. will be greatly appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Power For Putin
description: Russia's Parliament expanded President Vladimir V. Putin's powers again, giving him legal authority to declare a national state of emergency during certain crises. The new law, which now needs only Mr. Putin's signature, permits a 30-day emergency declaration and some limits on civil rights during coups, threats to Russian lives or public order, terrorist acts and riots. A declaration requires the approval of Parliament's upper house within 72 hours. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Where There's Smoke, There's Duty (Until It Rains)
description: For 18 days now, Steven Alcorn has been patrolling 765 acres of smoldering, blackened woodland here in a bright red Dodge truck crammed with hoses, axes, shovels and a 250-gallon water tank and pump.

title: Intel Is Set to Announce A Chip of Many Functions
description: The Intel Corporation plans to announce on Thursday that its engineers have made a chip that combines the central functions of the next generation of wireless devices onto one piece of silicon, an advancement that Intel says will lead to smaller and faster consumer products.

title: Fed Considered Acting Earlier in April to Cut Interest Rates
description: WASHINGTON, May 17  The Federal Reserve chose not to cut interest rates between scheduled meetings at one point last month because of concerns that it would unsettle the financial markets, but it decided a week later to cut rates anyway as evidence mounted that the economy was continuing to weaken, according to minutes of the central bank's deliberations released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, DANIEL
description: MEYERS-Daniel. We mourn the passing of our inspiration, Daniel Meyers, 89, on May 16, 2001. Mr. Meyers suffered from Parkinson's Disease. He is survived by his wife, Florence, his children, Gail Meyers, Lynn Broide & Jonathan. He is also survived by his grandchildren Nina Martin and Binyomin Broide, his brother Hillel and sisters Miriam Kahn, Ruth Belilos and Esther Cohen, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. We will miss him a lot. Services will be held in Israel. The Family and Employees of A. Meyers & Sons Corp.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Boldface Names column yesterday about the dinner at which UJA-Federation of New York honored the chief executive of the Bertelsmann media company misspelled his surname in some copies. He is Thomas Middelhoff, not Middlehoff.

title: Globe-Trotting Reality Show Is Among 8 CBS Newcomers
description: CBS, coming off a successful season, will seek to magnify its gains by adding eight new series next fall, more than any other major network. Beyond adding five new drama series and two new comedies, CBS will once again rely on reality shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, HARRY
description: SIMON-Harry. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Harry Simon, husband of Phyllis Simon and father of Susan. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow.

title: South Korea Is Guaranteeing Debt of Distressed Companies
description: The South Korean government approved new financing to guarantee corporate bonds today in the latest effort to rescue Hynix Semiconductor and other troubled companies.

title: 400 Protest Racial Profiling, But Few Top Officials Hear
description: Carrying banners and an agenda for lawmakers, about 400 people gathered at the State House steps today to call for an end to racial profiling and police brutality against blacks and other minorities.

title: Stocks End Higher on Earnings and Economic Reports
description: Stocks advanced modestly today in the wake of Wednesday's powerful rally, as investors drew some encouragement from Hewlett-Packard's better-than-expected earnings and from reassuring economic data.

description: WITH their wedding party scattered across 3,000 miles, Gladys We and Tony Nathan did much of their wedding planning by e-mail.

description: Any day now, nine heavily laden trucks will pull out of a speck on the map called Rock Tavern, N.Y., and set out on the 10-hour journey to Washington.

title: New Jersey Concerns In Strategic Alliance
description: CommonHealth in Parsippany, N.J., part of the WPP Group, formed a strategic alliance with PDI in Upper Saddle River, N.J., a sales and marketing company that offers its services to United States health care companies. The partnership will begin with work for the Ceftin antibiotic brand of GlaxoSmithKline.

title: Anti-Abortion Group Endorses Schundler for Governor
description: New Jersey Right to Life, the state's largest anti-abortion group, endorsed Bret D. Schundler for governor today, throwing the weight of its 150,000 member households behind the Jersey City mayor's Republican primary campaign against Bob Franks.

description: One Tough Weed

title: Player Pianos Turn Parlors Into Virtual Concert Halls
description: Yamaha has been making sophisticated digital versions of the player piano for 13 years. Now its Disklavier system adds vocals to its piano stylings. When specially encoded CD's are inserted into the Disklavier Mark III series grand pianos, listeners can, among other things, experience Christopher Cross in a live performance of ''Ride Like the Wind'' with the piano playing along.

title: New York City's Endorsement Season
description: After a leisurely start, the New York City mayor's race has picked up speed. This is due mainly to the candidates' either winning or flubbing endorsements they wanted -- or pretended to want until they didn't get them. In reality, the importance of endorsements is hard to measure, and even political professionals differ about their importance. The general consensus, though, is that Mark Green, the city's public advocate and the leader in early polls, scored a tactical coup in gaining the endorsement yesterday of former Mayor David Dinkins. Since Mr. Green was part of the Dinkins administration, the announcement was not a total surprise. But it does damage the effort of Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, to put together the coalition of black and Latino voters that he envisioned as his ticket to a runoff. There is little dispute that an endorsement from Mr. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor, would have been helpful.

title: Essay; The Senate Plumbers
description: The American Spectator is a feisty little right-wing magazine that drove the Clinton White House crazy.

title: Where Adoption Is Suddenly an Open Book
description: WHEN Robert Crabtree saw an envelope from the Oregon health department in his mailbox one day last July, the black hole he had carried around for most of his life started to close. Inside was his birth certificate and the name of his mother, which he was seeing for the first time. ''As soon as I read her name and age and place of birth, I was O.K.,'' he said. ''If I didn't find out one other darn thing I would have been O.K.''

title: OFFER FOR KENDALL-JACKSON WINE ESTATES IS WITHDRAWN
description: BRL Hardy, an Australian winemaker, says it has withdrawn its offer to buy Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates of Santa Rosa, calif., because Kendall-Jackson sought too high a price. ''We thought we put up a fair bid,'' the chief executive of Hardy, Stephen B. Millar, said in an interview. Hardy is still looking for opportunities in the United States, Mr. Millar said. Kendall-Jackson, which is privately held, ended three months of talks. Analysts estimated that Kendall-Jackson Wine Estates could be sold for $1.2 billion to $1.5 billion.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Tajikistan: Help On The Way
description: International donors pledged $430 million to help rebuild the country, which is struggling to reduce poverty. Nearly 85 percent of the population of six million people live in extreme poverty on less than $1 a month. The decision to increase aid was made by a consortium of six countries and eight international organizations at a meeting in Tokyo sponsored by the World Bank. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROOT, NANDA
description: ROOT-Nanda. May 15, 2001. Beloved wife of John B. Root. Devoted mother of Melina Root-Stevens. Loving sister of Dimitri Bourouni and Anastasia Tangalakis. She was a lyricist, writer and translator, as well as a dedicated volunteer at the Lighthouse. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Friday, May 18, 2001, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Service Saturday, May 19, 10 AM at Holy Trinity Cathedral, 337 East 74 Street, NYC. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Lighthouse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTON, SIDGERT
description: ORNSTON-Sidgert. Of New York City, age 73, on May 16, 2001. We have lost a very special person, gifted in so many ways. Devoted and generous father and grandfather. Passionate businessman, athlete, collector and magician. Always wise and realistic, ''Sidge'' was also a man of great wit and warmth, and his enthusiasm for life made life better for many who loved and respected him. He attended Cornell University and graduated Cooper Union. CEO of Independent Metal Strap Co. Beloved husband of Joyce and Mimi, both of whom predeceased him. Deeply loved by daughters Patricia, Marjorie and Deedee and sonin-law Chris; adoring grandfather of Lucy and Jamie and stepgrandchildren Sarah and Sammy. Dear brother and friend to Larry and Marlene, niece Elizabeth and nephew Lincoln. Friend & mentor to Paul Maslar. Sidge will always be a guiding spirit & a comforting presence in our memories and hearts. Services Sunday, May 20, 2001 at 2 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Those wishing to, may make donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, SUZANNE
description: FISHER-Suzanne. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the death of Suzanne Fisher, beloved wife of Richard, and a cherished friend of our community, who embraced her family's commitment to Jewish philanthropic causes. The Fisher family has long been admired for their extraordinary generosity and leadership, which have helped sustain UJA-Federation's diverse network of health and human service agencies. We extend our deepest sympathies to Suzanne's husband, Richard; her mother, Carol Ehlers; her sister, Elizabeth; her brothers, Robert, Thomas, and David; and the entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: House Acts On Racial Profiling
description: The House approved a bill requiring police departments to collect racial statistics on people stopped for traffic violations to determine if racial profiling is taking place. The bill, approved 94 to 3 and sent to the Senate, would require the departments to report the figures every year for review by the Legislature. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Tape Shows Suspect Telling 'Mobsters' He Killed Officer
description: Charlie's Barbershop in Flushing, Queens, had smoked-glass windows and a door that was always locked. Unannounced visitors were turned away. But when Henry Vega showed up with a friend in January 1999, he was quickly welcomed into the inner circle of what he had been told was a social club for gangsters that was run by the mob.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Charges In Beating Of Palestinian
description: Seven Israeli policemen have been charged with the beating in custody of a Palestinian who was arrested on suspicion of taking part in the mob killing of two Israeli Army reservists in Ramallah in October. In another case, four Israelis were arrested on suspicion of severely beating a Palestinian laborer after a suicide bombing last month in Netanya. The police had come under mounting criticism for failing to find the attackers. Joel Greenberg (NYT)

description: Before the onslaught began, 20,939 fans stood and roared for the smallest player on the court. From Commissioner David Stern's pregame presentation of the National Basketball Association's most valuable player award to the merciful sound of the final buzzer, Game 5 was all about Allen Iverson.

title: Italy's New Leader Begins To Assemble His Cabinet
description: After two days of secluded talks with advisers, Silvio Berlusconi, Italy's newly elected prime minister, paid a call on the president today, the first formality on his way to taking office.

title: A Reshuffling At an Online Bookseller
description: The online bookseller Barnesandnoble.com reshuffled its executive ranks yesterday, giving its chief financial officer responsibility for marketing and merchandising but leaving the 16-month-old prefix ''acting'' in the title of its acting chief executive, Stephen Riggio.

description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from May 17.

title: Condo Rentals
description: Condominiums provide some of the comforts of home while on vacation. Leisure Link International offers rentals at resort condos nationwide, including Fairfield Bay, on 14,000 acres in the Ozark Mountains of Arkansas. The resort has two 18-hole golf courses, fishing guides, tennis and horseback riding. One-week rental of a one-bedroom, one-bath condo starts at $579; rates are valid through Oct. 31. Information: (888) 801-8808 or www.eleisurelink.com .

title: Tokyo Journal; Baseball's in a Sad State: Stars Shine (in the U.S.)

description: Q. Often when I'm not playing any music or programs that use audio, I can hear music coming from my desktop speakers. What's going on?

title: Extracting Diamonds in the Cavendish Pairs
description: Pronunciation has never been a major problem in international bridge. But two Polish stars are having so many successes that we should all master their names: Michal Kwiecien, pronounced like the American Michael and KVETCH-ehn, and Jacek Pszczola, pronounced YAW-chehk push-COE-luh. Pszczola's nickname is Pepsi-Cola, and he uses that in his e-mail address.

title: More Nuclear Power Means More Risk
description: Despite all the talk about nuclear power as the environmentally clean response to electricity shortages and global warming, many Americans are understandably wary. The Bush administration's energy task force announces its report today, and President Bush would do well to note the public's concerns about the combination of human fallibility and mechanical failure that can set off catastrophic accidents at nuclear plants and about the link between nuclear waste and nuclear weapons.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE AGREES TO BUY DUTCH CLOTHING COMPANY
description: Liz Claiborne, which pioneered fashionable, affordable business suits for working women, has agreed to buy the closely held Dutch apparel company Mexx Group for about $266 million in cash and assumed debt to increase sales in Europe. Liz Claiborne will get about 600 Mexx-owned stores and 6,000 independent outlets in Canada, Europe, the Middle East and the Pacific Rim. Mexx contracts out its manufacturing and owns no plants. The purchase will increase Liz Claiborne's clothing sales outside the United States by 10 percent, said the company's chief financial officer, Mike Scarpa. The company expects the deal to increase its 2001 profit 4 to 6 cents a share. The amount of long-term debt that was assumed was not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Murky Election Results
description: As counting continued three days after parliamentary and local elections, no clear winner was emerging between allies of former President Joseph Estrada and of his replacement, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. Mrs. Arroyo seemed to be falling short of a convincing victory that would bolster the legitimacy of her ouster of Mr. Estrada in January. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: New Chicken Virus
description: Hong Kong ordered the slaughter of 6,608 chickens after health officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu. Unlike the case with the previous strain, which killed six people, there is no evidence that this strain affects human beings, the officials said. But the disease has killed 797 chickens in three poultry markets. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Little Relief For Overcrowded Prisons
description: The Legislature approved a $1.2 billion general-fund budget that leaves the state far short of its goals in hiring new corrections officers or building new prisons. Prison crowding has reached a crisis, but the budget did not provide for new prisons or hiring more than about 50 new guards. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Where the Horsy Set Drank, and Clipped
description: IT was just the kind of night Harvey Ladew would have loved. The wisteria was blooming. The drinks were flowing. One half-expected to see Mr. Ladew and his friend Billy Baldwin, martinis in hand, dive into the oval pool.

title: FOUNDER OF CALLAWAY GOLF IS RETIRING FROM 2 POSTS
description: The Callaway Golf Company, the maker of Big Bertha golf clubs, has named Ronald Drapeau its chief executive and president, succeeding the founder, Ely Callaway, who is retiring for medical reasons. Mr. Drapeau, 54, joined the company in 1996 and was senior executive vice president for manufacturing. Mr. Callaway, 81, will remain the chairman, said the company, which is based in Carlsbad, Calif. The changes are effective immediately.

title: A Finnish Cheer For the Bronx; Students Find Stardom on Trip
description: Ashley Alvarez jumped onstage in the dollhouse-size gymnasium at Palsbole Skola, as familiar rap music filled the air. Knees and elbows pumping, she led the Finnish 11- and 12-year-olds in an exultant chorus of ''Put your hands in the air, wave 'em like you just don't care,'' while her American friends chanted, ''Must be the money.''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Teaneck: Suspected Bomb Actually Pennies
description: A driver, peeved over a parking ticket, paid the fine with 4,400 pennies in an apparent silent protest that led to a short-lived bomb scare in the Teaneck Municipal Court. The driver's cardboard box of pennies was taped, heavy and had no return address. The court clerk, Lucia Rodriguez, called the police Tuesday morning, the building was evacuated and the county bomb squad X-rayed the package. Lt. Robert Wilson of the Teaneck police said the driver, whose name was not released, did not break any laws but did overpay his fine by $18. The driver's refund will be in the form of a check. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

description: In percent

title: Remaking the Wireless Web Into a Feast for the Eyes
description: Consumers used to a rich online experience offered via high-speed connections are not rushing to surf the Web on cellular phone networks. Sprint and Sierra Wireless are trying to change their minds with a service that uses a Sierra Aircard 510 wireless modem to connect to the Web over Sprint's PCS digital network using a laptop computer. Surfing the Web would look no different from the way it would over a regular connection but without cords or a telephone.

title: A Wright House for Sale And a Threat of Demolition
description: RECIPE for a suburb stirred, not shaken: Take one Frank Lloyd Wright house. Add an owner eager to sell it and a buyer who may want to demolish it. Place in a town with no history of preservation and add an outside advocacy group with a strong preservation agenda. Pour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUHLFELD, FRANK BEARSS
description: MUHLFELD-Frank Bearss. Beloved husband of the late Betty Lou, died peacefully at home in Amagansett, NY surrounded by his family on May 15, 2001 at age 80. He leaves behind five children, Elizabeth Ingram of Manchester, MA, George Muhlfeld of Englewood, NJ, Katherine Bell of Northeast Harbor, ME, Lucy Kazickas of Amagansette, NY, Louise Patterson of San Francisco, CA and fourteen grandchildren all who loved him dearly. We send him on his way rejoicing with hallelujahs and a 21 gun salute. A memorial service will be held later.

title: Easy on the Ears, Easier Still to Lose
description: Portable digital audio players are pouring into the marketplace, so distinguishing between these chip-based music players is becoming harder and harder. But Samsung may have found a way to make its new Mini Yepp instantly recognizable. Not only is it tiny -- the thumb-size device is billed as the ''world's smallest 32-megabyte digital audio player'' -- it may also have the smallest price tag of any new audio player. Its suggested retail price is $99.99.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Sells Billing Unit
description: Intuit Inc., the leading maker of personal finance software, said yesterday that it had sold its online bill payment and presentment business to Princeton eCom of Princeton, N.J. Princeton eCom acquired Intuit's Quicken Bill Manager through the purchase of technologies from Intuit as well as all outstanding shares of the Venture Finance Software Corporation, an Intuit subsidiary. Intuit will continue to offer the Web-based Quicken Bill Manager, but the service will now be processed by Princeton eCom, which will share revenue from the service with Intuit. Intuit, based in Mountain View, Calif., will also receive royalty payments if Princeton eCom licenses the Web-based bill payment technology to other companies. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Telefnica Profit Grows
description: Telefnica reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit, with strong growth in Brazilian operations offsetting weaker performance elsewhere in Latin America. Domestic earnings rose, despite increased competition in the Spanish fixed-line phone market. The company earned 431.8 million euros ($379.8 million) in the quarter, while revenue rose 18 percent, to 7.6 billion euros ($6.7 billion). Telefnica, however, warned of slower domestic growth this year, and its shares fell 2.41 percent, to 18.2 euros ($15.98), in trading in Madrid. Emma Daly (NYT)

title: Garden Keeping Focus On Cable TV Network
description: Dave Checketts's ouster at Madison Square Garden does more than leave the Knicks and the Rangers in flux. The MSG Network, which accounted for 28 percent of the Garden's $785 million in revenue in 1999, is facing difficult times that must be addressed by James L. Dolan, the president of Cablevision, the Garden's parent company, as he replaces Checketts for the near term.

title: Elbowing Aside The Auction
description: Even among the clutch of often eccentric, often brilliant people who jumble up book publishing, there's something about the old-fashioned literary auction that can still be electric in its excitement. It's the romance of the shootout in the corral, and if the names of the writers are big enough and the pile of money high enough, then the auction even becomes what is called news.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Search for a Hofstra Sophomore Becomes a College Murder Case
description: For the last three weeks, Max B. Kolb's family scoured his favorite haunts, taped up posters and gave radio interviews, pleading for help in finding Mr. Kolb, a Hofstra University sophomore who had suddenly vanished, his dorm-room door papered with notes from friends: ''Max, where are you? You weren't in class'' and ''Max, give me a call.''

title: Fraud Protection for Winegrowers on Long Island
description: Granting a request by Long Island winegrowers, the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has designated all of Suffolk and Nassau Counties as a single grape-growing region.

title: Proposal Is Latest U.S. Reaction to Energy Concerns That Wax and Wane
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  Gov. Bob Wise of West Virginia was in a bullish mood when he met with his state's leading coal-industry officials last week. Once again, he said, an administration has declared an energy crisis and concluded that coal, the domestic workhorse of fossil fuels, is a major part of the solution. "We're back," he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DODGE, RUTH QUACKENBUSH
description: DODGE-Ruth Quackenbush. Memorial services for Ruth Quackenbush Dodge, 90, of Bowling Green, OH. will be at 11 AM, Saturday, May 19, 2001 at Carronor Hunt and Polo Club in Perrysburg, OH conducted by the Reverend J. Paul Board of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Maumee. Mrs. Dodge was formerly a resident of NYC. Surviving are her son David D. Dodge, five grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Mrs. Dodge was preceded in death by her husband, Henry M. Dodge and her daughter, Louise Q. Stoddard. The family suggests memorials to either the Volunteer Action Center in Toledo, OH, St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Maumee, OH, or Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT.

title: Bursting Tech Bubble Dampens Zeal for Online Projects
description: PARIS  As the financial markets convalesce from dot-com fever, many private banks are reviewing their online initiatives.

title: Soft, Mellow Colors That Are Built Into the Wall
description: Venetian plaster, which gives a surface the look of an aged European wall, is durable, lustrous and never needs repainting. This technique, in which pigment is mixed with the plaster (left half of the picture), can also be used with waterproof cement for countertops, floors and shower stalls (right half). Jeff Pappas, a Brooklyn artist, works with both materials and can advise on colors and textures. (A contractor recently had him touch up Venetian plaster in Jerry Seinfeld's Manhattan duplex.) He charges $10 to $20 a square foot for plaster walls, and though the cement is more costly, he says it ends up being less expensive than granite or marble; he also creates custom-colored cast-cement coffee table tops: (718) 643-3662, or www.jeffpappas.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIMOFF, ICK THORNTON, DR., D.D.S.
description: HIMOFF-Ick Thornton, Dr., D.D.S. 94, on May 15, 2001. Cherished husband of 57 years of Helen and their devoted children, Eve-Ellen and James Starkman, Aviva and Gregory Himoff. Beloved grandfather of Amy and Wendy Starkman, Arielle and Dana Himoff. Loving brother of the late Mildred Lewis, Dudley and Robert, and adored uncle and grand uncle to many nieces and nephews. A graduate of Pennsylvania State University and the University of Pennsylvania Dental School, he practiced dentistry in White Plains for 50 years. A W.W. II veteran leaves behind a legacy of wonderful memories for his family and friends. Embraced forever by all who were privileged to share in the life of a man for all seasons. Services will be held on Thursday, May 17 at 10:30 AM at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY 10606. Calling hours at 50 Winslow Road will be Thursday 7-9 PM, Friday 15 PM, Saturday 8-10 PM, and Sunday in NYC at 114 East 72nd Street from 2-6 PM. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Congregation Kol Ami.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Boy Killed By Bus
description: A 4-year-old Queens boy playing with his older sister chased a ball into the street and was struck and killed by an M.T.A. bus yesterday afternoon, the police said. The boy, whose identity was not immediately released, was playing near the corner of Beach 20th Street and New Haven Avenue in Far Rockaway when he was hit. A police spokeswoman said an investigation was continuing but that no charges were expected. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Regents Rescind Affirmative Action Ban
description: In a largely symbolic move, the Regents of the University of California rescinded their 1995 policies prohibiting consideration of race and sex in admissions and hiring decisions. The move will have little impact because California voters in 1996 passed an initiative barring affirmative action at public institutions. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

description: Nine real estate partnerships associated with a prominent New Jersey developer have donated a total of $60,000 to the mayoral campaigns of Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and Public Advocate Mark Green, contributions that collectively appear to violate New York City's campaign finance rules.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ex-Webvan Chief Rewarded
description: George T. Shaheen, who resigned as the chief executive of the Webvan Group after 18 months, will receive $375,000 each year for the rest of his life from the beleaguered company, an online grocer. Bud Grebey, a Webvan spokesman, said Mr. Shaheen's compensation had been negotiated and disclosed in late 1999, and that ''we as a company are going to honor our commitment to that contract.'' Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANA, CHARLES A. JR.
description: DANA-Charles A. Jr. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of our dear friend, devoted benefactor and steadfast supporter, Charles A. Dana, Jr. Charles Dana joined the NYU Medical Center Board of Trustees in 1960 and was appointed Life Trustee of Mount Sinai NYU Health in 1991. With a distinguished record of philanthropy both locally and nationally, he has been active on the Boards of the Charles A. Dana Foundation, the United Cerebral Palsy Research and Education Foundation, and the Museum of the City of New York, among others. His efforts have been matched by those of his wife, Norma Dana, who is active as a Board member and volunteer for numerous humanitarian organizations. We extend our deepest sympathy to Mr. Dana's family and loved ones. Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees

title: Devils Don't Compare Numbers, Only Results
description: A day after allowing three goals on four shots during the second period of a 4-2 loss to the Pittsburgh Penguins, Devils goaltender Martin Brodeur was asked to compare his postseason performances this year and last year, when he led New Jersey to its second Stanley Cup in five years.
