title: Piazza Remembers That It's Just a Game
description: Mike Piazza apologized three times in 10 minutes for being too philosophical. But the Mets have been so dreary and disappointing that he has been forced to be more introspective. Piazza has spent endless hours trying to determine what has gone wrong, what he could have done differently and how he can help make the Mets vibrant again.

title: At Web Police Auction, the Lost Can Be Found
description: IT'S a shame that life doesn't have a Control-F command to track down things that are lost  not just misplaced, but truly lost.

title: The Romance of the Early PC
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMAHON, MARIE (NEE STRINGER
description: McMAHON-Marie (nee Stringer. Of Bayonne, NJ, on May 13, 2001. Beloved wife of William, devoted mother of Eileen Marie and William Jr. Born in Jersey City, she worked for Merrill Lynch before marrying her husband, a sales and marketing executive. At the time of her death, Mrs. McMahon was the Treasurer of her daughter's agency, Eileen McMahon & Co., representing internationally renowned artists, including Ronald Searle, Gerald Scarfe, Andre Francois, Clare Mackie and the estate of Edward Gorey. Her constant pride in and support of her family is a true comfort to us during this last hard passage. Funeral arrangements were private, with burial in Dublin, Ireland.

title: Consumer Prices Up; Home Building Rises
description: Consumer prices rose less than expected last month, and home construction in April rose for the first time in three months, government reports showed today.

title: Cable and Wireless Feels Pressure of Too Much Cash
description: While most other telecommunications companies are saddled with too much debt, Cable and Wireless is facing a different problem.

title: An Array of Composers Casting Backward Glances
description: The New York Chamber Symphony brought its 24th season to a close with a program conducted by Keith Lockhart, who is best known as Arthur Fiedler's successor as conductor of the Boston Pops but is also the music director of the Utah Symphony. For his program on Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, Mr. Lockhart looked at works that seemed to look over their own shoulders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, SARAH REGINA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sarah Regina, 101. Peacefully passed away May 15, 2001 in her sleep. Born in New York City in 1899, she celebrated living in three centuries with her family and many friends. After almost nine decades as a staunch New Yorker, Sarah moved to Palm Desert, CA, where she lived for twelve years before moving yet again, at 100 years of age, to Westwood, CA. Sarah survived her loving husband of 67 years, Max, as well as her sons Monroe and Edward. Once an educator, and never at a loss for words, she reached all with a loving & guiding hand. Passionate about food and decor, Sarah was possessed of a remarkable sense of humor. She is survived by her son, Dr. Lewis Weintraub of Brentwood, CA; her brother, Jerome Pickman of New York City; three grandchildren; five great grandchildren; and many nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to the Anti Defamation League (ADL). Memorial service to be held today at Mount Sinai Memorial Park, Los Angeles, CA. The absolute matriarch of the family, we will remember and love Sarah always. She is greatly missed.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: And Now, Doctor Bob

title: For E-Mail On the Go, Or the Sly
description: DON'T let anyone tell you that two-way wireless messaging is a new technology -- using smoke signals, American Indians once sent instant messages to colleagues miles away. Of course, smoke signals had their drawbacks: reception was spotty in rainy weather, Microsoft Word attachments almost never came through, and the blankets got all sooty.

title: After Olympians Leave, A Struggle to Fill Seats
description: Marion Jones, Cathy Freeman and Michael Johnson would hardly recognize the scene of their Olympic triumphs here last September.

title: Layoffs at Agencies; Economy Is Cited
description: In more signs of the slowing economy, two agencies laid off employees on Tuesday.

title: Pentagon Review Puts Emphasis On Long-Range Arms in Pacific
description: A confidential Pentagon strategy review has cast the Pacific as the most important region for military planners and calls for the development of new long-range arms to counter China's military power.

title: Comas Gets a Boost, and So Do MetroStars
description: The boost of confidence Alex Comas needed to break out of his scoring funk came 11 minutes into tonight's game in the form of a penalty kick. Comas, the Colombian striker, converted the kick, giving the MetroStars a 1-0 triumph over the Colorado Rapids tonight before a crowd of 10,081 at Giants Stadium.

title: S.E.C. Move Hurts Stock of Pre-Paid Legal
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. said today that accounting changes demanded by the Securities and Exchange Commission would wipe out more than half its reported earnings for the last two years, setting off a 26 percent decline in its stock price.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, JEANNE (GOLDING)
description: SIEGEL-Jeanne (Golding), on May 15, 2001 in Cincinnati. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Sanford Golding and Rosalie Shaffer. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Mitchell Report on Mideast Violence May Thaw the Ice; Israel Backs Most Points as Step Toward Talks
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said today that Israel had endorsed a report of a committee led by former Senator George J. Mitchell as a possible basis for stopping violence and resuming peace talks.

title: Eleanor Sayre, 85, Curator and Goya Expert
description: Eleanor Axson Sayre, an authority on the prints of Francisco Goya and one of the first female curators at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, died Saturday. She was 85 and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: He-Mails, She-Mails: Where Sender Meets Gender
description: WITH their wedding party scattered across 3,000 miles, Gladys We and Tony Nathan did much of their wedding planning by e-mail.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Another Delay For U.N. Attacker
description: An Iraqi gunman who attacked a United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization office in Baghdad last year, killing two people, has had his sentencing postponed for the seventh time. This time, the judge said that the gunman, Fuad Hussein Haidar, was ill. Previous postponements were granted on the grounds that Mr. Haidar needed more lawyers. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Extra Innings Spell Trouble For Yankees
description: The offensive explosion is bound to come one of these days, the Yankees believe. Their lineup will come together again, hitters will get hot, the quality of their at-bats will improve, the runs will come in bunches and some of the early problems -- the heavy reliance on their primary relievers, the smallest margin for their numerous defensive errors -- will be resolved.

title: Mideast Battles, From '48 to Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota's Net Surges 16% Despite Slowing Economies
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its earnings rose 16 percent in the year ended March 31, as strong sales and aggressive cost-cutting helped the company overcome the impact of slowing economies in its main markets.

title: Mitchell Report on Mideast Violence May Thaw the Ice; U.S. Gingerly Discusses Taking More Active Role
description: Faced with increasing pressure to help reduce the violence in the Middle East, the Bush administration is trying to find ways to become involved in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, while steering clear of what it views as the failures of the Clinton presidency.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Vacation section on Tuesday about family car trips misspelled the surname of a professor at the University of Iowa who teaches a course on the American vacation. She is Susan Birrell, not Burrill.

title: A Dark View of the Street; Spotlight Shines on Skeptic Who Sees a Long Slowdown
description: Bearishness has its benefits these days. Just ask Stephen S. Roach, Morgan Stanley's chief economist and currently Wall Street's leading merchant of doom.

title: Article 2001051792814227307 -- No Title
description: Education: Government Internet Subsidy Stretched to Its Limits

title: With Polls Ebbing, Fox Reviews First 6 Months
description: With his popularity sliding in opinion polls, President Vicente Fox delivered a hastily arranged State of the Nation address today to outline what he considers the most significant achievements of his six-month-old administration.

title: New Drug Plan Shifts Focus in Latin America
description: After criticism that American anti-narcotics policy in South America relies too heavily on military aid to Colombia, the Bush administration proposed a more regional approach today that would emphasize economic development and cultivation of legal crops.

title: Article 2001051792366945706 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PULVERMACHER, LOUIS C.
description: PULVERMACHER-Louis C. Of Longboat Key, Fl. and Lakeville, CT. died May 7, 2001. Adored husband of Jo; loving son of the late Lucille and Joseph Pulvermacher, father of Lewis, Andrew, Robin and the late David. Graduate of Horace Mann School, Franklin and Marshall College, and University of Pennsylvania Law School. Chairman of the Board of the Federal Bar Council and member of the Millbrook Central School Board. A very special human being, who cared deeply about people and loved the law. Contributions to the Second Amendment Foundation would be much appreciated. Services were held.

title: Congress to Preview Digital Music Service
description: Music fans are expected to get their first glimpse of a major, and legal, online music subscription service today, as Congress convenes its third set of hearings in less than a year on the future of digital music.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECTER, RUTH
description: DECTER-Ruth. Age 91, of Maplewood, New Jersey. Mother of Julian (Ethel) Decter, and Ronnie (Barry) Gardiner, and beloved grandmother of Ben, Catherine, Beth and Jill; great-grandmother of Addie, Leo and Lucas. Adored wife of the late Benjamin Decter.

title: Energy Task Force: The Results Are In
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranians Winnow Election List: Women and Liberals Are Out
description: The Council of Guardians, which screens candidates for Iranian elections, announced today that it was rejecting all but 10 of the more than 800 who sought to run in the June 8 presidential race. Among those rejected were all of more than two dozen women and candidates known for their liberal views.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: U.S. Builds Base For Israelis
description: Israeli and American officials have broken ground for a $266 million Israeli military base that is being built by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and paid for by the United States under an agreement signed in 1998. The new base, in the southern Negev region, is replacing an Israeli Army training site in the West Bank. Martin Indyk, the American ambassador to Israel, called the project a symbol ''of America's continuing commitment to Israel's security.'' William A. Orme Jr. (NYT)

title: Mayor Says He Expects to Be Charged in 1969 Killing
description: Within hours of celebrating his victory in the Democratic primary in York, Pa., Mayor Charles Robertson, crestfallen and near tears, announced yesterday that he would surrender today on homicide charges dating to 1969 racial riots when he was a young white police officer who shouted ''white power'' at a rally of angry whites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOFF, IDA, ED. D.
description: DAVIDOFF-Ida, Ed. D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University notes with deep sorrow the passing of our distinguished former faculty member in psychiatry. She was also the widow of Dr. Leo Davidoff, the founding chairman of our surgery department. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the trainer of the race horse Griffinite misidentified the horse's mother in some editions. She was Copious, not Saratoga Dame. The article also misidentified horse racing's 2-year-old champion of 1995. He was Maria's Mon, not Unbridled's Song.

title: Monarchos Draws a Favored Post for His Quest
description: Before the Kentucky Derby, the trainer John Ward was certain that by the end of the first Saturday in May his colt, Monarchos, would be wearing the blanket of roses. Now, confidence has given way to serenity as Ward and Monarchos pursue a covering of black-eyed Susans and the second leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENHOUSE, AMY
description: GREENHOUSE-Amy. Sister of Andrew and of Frank Juliano; daughter of the late Stanley and Shirley (Shatz). Donations may be sent to the Jacob Perlow Hospice of Beth Israel Health Care System, 1st Ave at 16th Street, NY 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLACHBARTH, VIRGINIA BUSH SLOOK
description: FLACHBARTH - Virginia Bush Slook. Died May 15, 2001 in Parkersburg, West Va. of congested heart failure. Burial will be in Philadelphia. She was a direct descendant of Richard Peters, Secretary of War under the Articles of Confederation and a member of the Continental Congress. Richard Peters was appointed U.S. District Judge for Pennsylvania by his good friend George Washington. Virginia Flachbarth is survived by her husband Charles Thomas Flachbarth, her son Charles Thomas Pawling Flachbarth of Alexandria, Virginia, and various nephews and nieces.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Policeman Accused Of Fraud
description: A New York City police officer has been charged with defrauding fellow officers by copying their Social Security numbers from an in-house list of promotions and then applying for credit cards in their names. The scheme was uncovered, prosecutors say, when some officers received letters asking to confirm information for credit cards that they had not ordered. The accused officer, Thomas Perry, faces up to 10 years in prison if convicted.

title: The Philanthropy Mart
description: As multimillionaires and philanthropists, Alexander and Ilana Brodt are accustomed to people trying to get at their money. So when they agreed to join German friends recently for a seminar on charitable giving sponsored by Deutsche Bank AG's private banking unit at a swanky hotel in Palm Beach, Florida, they went expecting to hear a sales pitch.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about The Daily News's elimination of a clause in severance agreements that forbade laid-off employees to disparage the newspaper referred incorrectly to layoff agreements at Brill's Content magazine. They did not include such clauses.

title: Simon Raven, Satiric Novelist, Dies at 73
description: Simon Raven, whose 36 novels provided a highly personalized, exceedingly hedonistic vision of the English upper classes, died Saturday at a London hospital. He was 73.

title: A McVeigh Meeting on a Day Once Set as His Last
description: On the spring day Timothy J. McVeigh was scheduled to die for committing the worst terrorist attack on American soil, he spent the morning with his lawyers instead. They said afterward that Mr. McVeigh was in good spirits and considering his options.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO RISES. The dollar fell against the euro on speculation that the United States economy will continue to slow. In New York, the euro settled at 88.44 cents, up from 87.86 cents on Tuesday.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Pipelines In The Plans
description: Yankee Gas Services Company is planning a $23 million, 70-mile natural gas project that will extend pipelines through the business districts of Suffield, Middlebury, Woodbury, Prospect, Darien and other communities in Connecticut. A spokeswoman for the company, which is based in Meriden, Conn., said that the state's Department of Public Utility Control had asked for the expansion as part of an agreement when the company merged with Northeast Utilities last year. Beryl Lyons, a department spokeswoman, said no environmental review would be required unless an affected town objected to the work, but the state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said local construction permits would apply as they do to any building or renovation project. The project is scheduled to begin this year and to be completed in the next four years. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cow Disease Impact
description: Britain's worst outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease claimed a new victim when the country's largest retailer of outdoor goods warned that first-half sales would be severely hurt by the closing of campsites and walking trails as part of measures to eradicate the disease. Shares in the retailer, Blacks Leisure Group, fell almost 10 percent. The company also said a fall in year-end sales cut net profit in the year ending Feb. 28 by 30 percent, to $10 million, excluding a one-time gain of $11.4 million from selling a stake in a sportswear retailer. More than 2.7 million animals have been slaughtered in 1,600 cases of foot-and-mouth disease since Feb. 19. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Convicted at 14
description: Does it make sense to send a 14-year-old to prison for life?

title: Around the World With Saber in Hand
description: His heart was always in baseball. But when he was 14, Ivan Lee reluctantly put down his baseball bat for a saber.

title: Two Midcentury Signatures In Textiles and Wood
description: Angelo Testa and Franziska Hosken are not household names on an Eamesian scale. But both of these midcentury modernists had popular design studios, especially in the 1940's and 50's. Ms. Hosken made knockdown furniture from bentwood and laminates. Mr. Testa was known for his whimsical, sometimes architectural textiles. Seventy-five of their pieces -- furniture, fabric and jewelry -- are on display at the Lin/Weinberg Gallery in SoHo through June 17. Mr. Testa's celebrated Little Man fabric (1942), above, 46 by 58 inches, is $9,000, framed. His Little Elephant (1945), top, 34 by 33 inches, is $1,500, also framed. A plywood Hosken stool is $875. The show, presented with Gary Snyder Fine Art, is at 84 Wooster Street (Spring Street). ELAINE LOUIE

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: CAVEAT SMOKER, JURY FINDS A jury in New Brunswick, N.J., found yesterday that two tobacco companies held no liability for the lung cancer death of a Princeton lawyer, dismissing a claim that she had not been properly warned of smoking's risks. The verdict in the case, brought by the lawyer's husband against Philip Morris Inc. and R.J. Reynolds Tobacco, extended the industry's winning streak in cases brought by individuals. The plaintiff, Myron A. Mehlman, contended that the cancer that killed his wife, Constance, was caused by the Marlboro and Camel cigarettes she smoked. Mrs. Mehlman died at 62. Her husband claimed that the companies failed to warn her about health risks, and that the cigarettes were defectively designed. The six- member jury rejected both claims. The cigarette makers contended that Mrs. Mehlman, who was a social worker and publisher before receiving her law degree in 1992, was well aware of the risks of smoking. The companies also maintained that her husband, a toxicologist, argued with her about her smoking.

title: Article 2001051791647709311 -- No Title
Portland Journal; A Spirit of Nonviolence Creates a Stir in Oregon
description: When the Dalai Lama visited Salt Lake City and Minneapolis last week, he was well received. But in Portland this week he caused a downright sensation.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Science Times on Tuesday about a book on the health habits of people in Okinawa gave an outdated title, which was also shown on an illustration of the jacket. The title, changed by the publisher after galley proofs were distributed for review, is ''The Okinawa Program: How the World's Longest-Lived People Achieve Everlasting Health -- And How You Can Too,'' by Dr. Bradley J. Willcox, Dr. D. Craig Willcox and Dr. Makoto Suzuki (Clarkson Potter, 2001), not ''The Okinawa Way.''

title: Mideast Battles, From '48 to Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDING, AMY
description: GOLDING-Amy. 77 years. Passed away suddenly at home. Beloved cousin of Elise Josephson, David Abrahams and Elihu Abrahams. Neighbors and friends mourn her loss. Services Sunday 11:30AM at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2nd Ave. (at 10th St), NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLIANSKY, JOSEPH
description: MASLIANSKY-Joseph. 82 years old. Beloved husband of Tsippora, devoted father of Nechama, Ronnie Moshe (Susan) and Avi (Michele), adored grandfather of Reuven, Tzivia, Aaron, Chana, Ari, Adena, Daniel & Efi; dear brother of Frieda Fleischer. World War II veteran of U.S. Army. Active Zionist. Executive Director of Council of Organizations, UJA-Federation and of various synagogues. Shiva at 2805 Avenue J, Brooklyn, until Monday morning, May 21.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Rate Lowered
description: New Zealand's central bank cut a major overnight lending rate to 5.75 percent from 6 percent, the third rate cut in nine weeks. In easing monetary policy, a New Zealand Reserve Bank governor, Don Brash, left, noted the slowing economies of major trading partners, including Australia, Japan and the United States. The central bank expects low inflation, Mr. Brash said. ''However, other outcomes that are less benign -- in either direction -- can be easily envisaged, which would require more vigorous monetary policy responses,'' Mr. Brash said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Critic's Notebook; Shoving Through the Crowd To Taste Lyrical Nostalgia
description: ''An English journalist once wrote that the name Godard contains the name of God,'' remarked Henri Behar, the moderator of Tuesday afternoon's news conference. ''And so, ladies and gentlemen, I give you God.'' The deity in question, Jean-Luc Godard, whose new movie, ''loge de l'Amour,'' is in competition for the Palme d'Or at the 54th annual Cannes International Film Festival, wore a rumpled tan sport coat and gamely entertained inquiries from the assembled journalists. ''What do you have against Steven Spielberg?'' ''What do you think of the Internet?'' ''Is there life after cinema?''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Lufthansa Impasse
description: Talks between Deutsche Lufthansa and its pilots' union broke down again as the airline prepared for another 24-hour strike today that would ground almost all of its flights in Germany. Lufthansa's pilots have carried out one-day strikes in each of the last three weeks, forcing the cancellations of hundreds of flights each time. The pilots are asking for wage increases of 30 to 35 percent, saying they were never compensated for pay cuts they accepted when Lufthansa was near bankruptcy in the early 1990's. Lufthansa has offered what it describes as a 26 percent increase, but 16 of those percentage points are conditional on the airline's finances. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: The Pimlico 11
description: Here are the horses entered for the 126th running of the Preakness. The horses are listed in the predicted order of finish by Joe Drape, who handicapped the field and wrote the comments. The odds are the morning line set by Clem Florio, the linemaker at Pimlico Race Course.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bombing Jury Still Out
description: In the fourth full day of deliberation, the jury in the trial of four men charged in a conspiracy to bomb two American Embassies in Africa in 1998 sent five notes to the judge yesterday asking for more exhibits and seeking clarification of his instructions on how to vote on one count, but reached no verdict. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Backpack Boom Box Hurts Your Ears, Not Your Shoulders
description: Until now, if you have wanted to make a musical statement on city sidewalks or the beach, you have had to balance a boom box on your shoulder with a tiring, one-armed grip.

title: In America; 'Sorry' Isn't Enough
description: They got the wrong guys. Again.

title: Bird Lover Takes Urban Watchers Under Her Wing
description: BEYOND pigeons.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street's New Interest In Bulgaria
description: Wall Street developed a sudden interest in Bulgaria this week, as investors scrambled to get the facts about AremisSoft, an obscure software company with a supposedly rich contract to overhaul Bulgaria's health information network.

title: Of No Use but Delight
description: FOLLIES of the architectural type, not the Sondheim variety, have a long history. The term derives from the French word folie, meaning foolishness or madness, and it implies a foolish, often madly expensive, garden structure with no function other than to mark a view in a landscape, give scale to a garden or simply amuse its wealthy or eccentric owner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNER, RICHARD
description: BLAUNER-Richard. Passed away in Winter Park, Florida, on Monday, May 14th, 2001. Loving husband of Pat, devoted father to Laurie Blauner & Barbara Blauner Celli, brother of Helene Blauner Gans and Michael Blauner.

title: Yale's Hail to the Chief Is Surrounded by Secrecy and Protest
description: On Sunday night, according to the White House schedule, President Bush will travel to New Haven for an unspecified event the next day. On Monday morning, Yale University, the president's alma mater, will hold its 300th commencement ceremony. And while neither administration will confirm anything, it is hardly a secret that Mr. Bush will receive an honorary degree and speak to the graduating class.

title: Mideast Battles, From '48 to Today
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: National Labor Relations Chairman Named
description: President Bush appointed Peter J. Hurtgen, a Republican lawyer, as chairman of the National Labor Relations Board. Mr. Hurtgen has served on the board since 1997. John C. Truesdale, a Democrat, had been chairman; he will remain on the board. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Death Penalty's Essence
description: To the Editor:

title: Payout in 2001 In Diet Cases To Be $7 Billion
description: The American Home Products Corporation will make $7.1 billion in settlement payments related to diet drug lawsuits in 2001, the company's chief financial officer, Kenneth J. Martin, said yesterday.

title: Ethnic Antagonisms Sharpen in Macedonia as a Deadline Nears
description: Foreign diplomats scrambled today to avert a major clash between the forces of Macedonia's new unity government and ethnic Albanian rebels.

title: Boiler Explodes, Burning Worker, at Rockland County Power Plant
description: A boiler at a Rockland County power plant exploded yesterday, injuring a worker and causing a tense few hours in surrounding neighborhoods as officials tested residue from the blast for possible asbestos contamination.

title: Los Angeles Mayor Backs Ex-Speaker as Successor
description: Lending an establishment imprimatur to a candidacy once seen as a longshot, Mayor Richard J. Riordan, the multimillionaire Republican businessman who has led Los Angeles for eight years, today endorsed the former State Assembly speaker Antonio Villaraigosa, a liberal Democrat with strong labor backing, as his choice for mayor of this city, the nation's second-largest.

title: It's Time Once Again For Design-on-Hudson
description: For those who didn't make it to Milan in April for the Salone, America's largest showcase of new design opens on Saturday in New York: the International Contemporary Furniture Fair, a trade exhibition, will be on view at the Javits Convention Center through Tuesday, when it opens to the public (10 p.m. to 4 p.m.).

title: World Briefing | The World: Progress Against Leprosy
description: The World Health Organization said it had met its target of cutting leprosy by 90 percent around the world in the last decade. The organization, part of the United Nations system, said that 11 million people had been cured over 15 years through a combination of drugs that treat the disease and prevent its transmission. But leprosy has not been controlled in six countries: Brazil, India, Madagascar, Mozambique, Myanmar and Nepal. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Central Asia: Growing Aids Problem Feared
description: The spread of the virus that causes AIDS could reach epidemic proportions in the five nations of Central Asia -- Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan -- according to delegates at a conference in Kazakhstan. Some 1,700 people infected with the virus have registered in Kazakhstan and the number of unregistered infected people there is believed to be far higher. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Bush Proposes Energy Plan Tapping Oil and Gas Reserves
description: ST. PAUL, Minn., May 17  President Bush laid out his long-awaited energy plan today, proposing looser regulations on oil and gas exploration, conservation-minded efforts like a review of gas mileage standards and a $4 billion tax credit for a new generation of highly fuel efficient cars. And he urged a reconsideration of a quarter-century ban on the reprocessing of nuclear fuel.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Rate On Bonds Declines
description: China began selling $1 billion worth of 10-year bonds that will pay investors a lower rate of interest than expected. China also plans to offer $441 million of the bonds denominated in euros. The lower rate is just 1.35 percentage points higher than the rate of comparable United States Treasury bonds rather than the 1.5 percentage point premium expected. It reflects international money managers' confidence in China's economy, which is expected to grow at least 7 percent this year, and comfort with the country's ability to repay the loan. China has $166 billion in foreign reserves, the second-largest reserves in the world.

title: Warning Lines of Laser Light May Improve Airport Safety
description: MOST frequent fliers are all too familiar with the stop-and-go traffic of airport taxiways and the frustration that can set in while the plane waits in line to take off. But while the wait can be tedious for passengers, it is a time when the pilot has to be alert and pay careful attention to the various pavement markings and lights that lead to the runway.

title: That Festival Returns, Still The Talk Of the Town
description: The New Yorker Festival, a literary event in its second season, will run tomorrow through Sunday with more than 50 readings, interviews, panel discussions, performances and brunches.

title: EASTMAN TO SPIN OFF SPECIALTY CHEMICALS BUSINESS
description: The Eastman Chemical Company will spin off its specialty chemicals business later this year as part of its plan to split into two companies. Eastman, based in Kingsport, Tenn., announced in February that it would split itself into two companies, one making specialty chemicals and another making commodity plastics and fibers. The company could have spun off either business, but it found that it could reap more tax benefits by spinning off the specialty chemicals business, a spokeswoman, Martha Lawson, said. Eastman decided to split the company to separate its fast-growing chemicals unit, from the cycles of its commodities businesses. The new company will be called the Eastman Company. It will own 70 percent of the property and equipment of Eastman Chemical. The surviving company, yet to be named, will make plastics for soda bottles and fibers for cigarette filters.

title: Finding Art in All the Unexpected Places
description: Almost a century has passed since Marcel Duchamp shook up the art world by proposing that art could be many things, including a urinal and a bottle rack. By now, though, the question ''What is art?'' seems quaint, a relic of the predemocratic past, when critical debate on such matters seemed important -- or at least entertaining.

title: Energy Task Force: The Results Are In
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress Moves to Final Round on the Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, May 16  With Republican leaders determined to have the tax bill on President Bush's desk by Memorial Day, the House and Senate prepared today for a final round of negotiations and voting next week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Election Task Force
description: Mayor Giuliani made all three appointments yesterday to a task force to evaluate the needs of the city's Board of Elections. He named Manfred Ohrenstein, former State Senate minority leader; Edward Costikyan, a former county Democratic leader; and City Councilman Martin J. Golden. Mr. Golden said that the task force would begin meeting next week to examine financing, staffing, logistics and equipment for the elections this fall. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Crackdown on Threats in School Fails a Test
description: Just weeks after the school shootings in March in Santee, Calif., the county prosecutor here met with local school superintendents and emphasized the need for zero tolerance. There is no gray area, he told them. Any student who makes a threat, even in jest, must be disciplined.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: 3 Catholic Priests Killed
description: Militants in the northeastern state of Manipur killed three Catholic priests, the police said. The Catholic Bishops Conference of India said that the priests had received a demand for money and had paid a little over $600 but that the extortionists had wanted more. The police said they suspected the killings were related to this demand for money. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: More Than a Palmtop, Not Quite a PC

Domenici, a Republican. Participants in the trial, which is expected to start by the end of the year, will test a pay-per-play format that will allow them to play against each other over the Internet. Cable operators like Telewest are looking for new content that will help them increase revenue. Britain's largest cable operator, NTL Inc. of New York, said recently that it was in talks with AOL Time Warner about forming a marketing alliance that would allow it to funnel some of America Online's content to its customers. description: One imagines the sappy, tacky turns the idea might take these days. In 1929, two male musicians witness the St. Valentine's Day gangland massacre in Chicago. To escape the mob they dress as women and join an all-female band headed for Florida. On the train they are smitten by the band's voluptuous singer, who is on the lookout for a rich husband. In Florida the effort to maintain drag identities, control male impulses and avoid the gangsters (who show up by coincidence to attend a mob meeting) leads to logistical and emotional complications.

title: WATCHING MOVIES WITH: Michael Bay; A Connoisseur Of Illusions
description: MICHAEL BAY was just days away from putting the conclusive touches on his latest movie, the $135 million historical epic ''Pearl Harbor,'' and he had been working pretty much around the clock for a week, his head full of last-minute details about music, sound cues and the color mix.

title: National Briefing | Education: Survey Supports Teachers
description: Americans see focusing on teacher quality as a better way to improve the nation's schools than most other strategies, including high standards, standardized testing and vouchers for private school tuition, a poll has found. In the poll, by Recruiting New Teachers, a Belmont, Mass., job clearinghouse for educators, 9 out of 10 people said putting a well-qualified teacher in every classroom was ''very important.'' About 40 percent believe teachers are inadequately paid, and 88 percent favor raising salaries, up 10 points from a similar poll in 1998. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, GEORGE A.
description: FOX-George A. Died May 17 after a courageous struggle to recover from cancer surgery. We remember his vibrance, his love of life, his incredible generosity and his wonderful sense of humor. His diverse efforts and numerous commitments contributed to a more just world. A man of great integrity, he was our true mensch. He leaves a family and wide circle of friends and colleagues who will carry on, inspired by his spirit: loving wife Cecily, children Alice, Laurie, Andy and Roger, grandchildren Ana, Jesse and Maia, sonin-law Daniele, daughter-in-law Linda and brother Richard. Sweet good man, we let you go with love.

title: Andrew Mackenzie Hay, 73, Trade Expert
description: Andrew Mackenzie Hay, an importer and expert on international trade who was once married to the socialite Sharman Douglas, died in his sleep on May 2 at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 73 and had lived in Portland since 1982.

title: 25 Years Later, Rumsfeld's Dream Is Alive Again
description: A quarter of a century ago, a new secretary of defense, Donald H. Rumsfeld, faced a towering challenge: convincing a skeptical Congress that the post-Vietnam military needed a major infusion of money to meet the still-fearsome Soviet threat. Mr. Rumsfeld prevailed, winning the largest increase in military spending in a decade.

title: Notes on Fed Rate Reductions Show Debate on Economy
description: The Federal Reserve chose not to cut interest rates between scheduled meetings at one point last month because of concern that it would unsettle the financial markets, but a week later it decided to cut rates anyway as evidence mounted that the economy was continuing to weaken, according to minutes of the deliberations released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONALD, JAMES T.
description: McDONALD-James T., 98, retired attorney of Garden City, NY on Tuesday, May 15, 2001. Husband of Dorothy (Morgan), father of Monsignor James M., Anne E., Hugh Morgan, Robert A. & the late Stephen E., grandfather of Annie and David, father-in-law of Margaret. Visiting at Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th St., Garden City 79PM Thursday, and 2-4 & 7-9 PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church, Garden City, Saturday 10 AM. title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal by Britain and the United States to lift the 11-year ban on international trade with Iraq misstated the reason for the departure of international inspectors there in 1998. It occurred  that December, before the United States and Britain began bombing raids on Iraq  because the United Nations feared that they might be harmed or taken hostage. They were not expelled.

title: Ciena, Fiber Optic Company, Reports a Loss
description: The Ciena Corporation, the second-biggest United States maker of fiber optic networking gear, had a fiscal second-quarter loss of $50.7 million on acquisition costs and said third-quarter profit before some expenses might miss analysts' forecasts.

title: The Big City; Scalping Law May Be Ready For Execution
description: IF you want a ticket to ''The Producers'' this weekend, don't bother looking anywhere near Broadway. Unless Mel Brooks owes you a large favor or you get lucky on eBay, your best hope is to head for ticket brokers in New Jersey or Connecticut and be ready to spend at least $500.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Vulcan Buying Fantasy Games Concern
description: Vulcan Ventures, the technology-heavy investment firm of the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen, said it would acquire Small World Media, a provider of fantasy sports games, to add to its line of fantasy sports products. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Small World, based in New York, provides such games as fantasy football, baseball, basketball and hockey on its Web site. Small World, which provides most of its games free, has 2.6 million registered users, its chief executive, Mark Jacobstein, said in a statement. The closely held Vulcan Ventures will operate Small World as part of its Sporting News unit.

description: By custom and law, Swiss companies are permitted to keep executive pay secret, and nearly all do so. It is no wonder. The few Swiss companies that have voluntarily adopted the more investor-friendly openness required of companies in the United States are finding themselves squirming in a harsh spotlight.

description: MetLife Inc., the big United States insurer, said today that it was acquiring a Brazilian insurer, Seguradora America do Sul S.A., for an undisclosed amount, doubling its market share in Brazil, which has Latin America's largest economy.

description: The index of leading economic indicators rose in April for the first time in three months, an industry survey showed today, suggesting that the economy may rebound later this year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Telecom Profit
description: Swisscom, the country's biggest telecommunications company, exceeded market expectations by posting a 5.7 percent rise, to $697 million, in first-quarter operating income. The increase was attributed to higher traffic volume, efficiencies and its gain of $2.3 billion from the sale of 25 percent of the company's mobile phone operations to Vodafone Group of Britain. The company, majority owned by the Swiss government, doubled its net profit to $2.6 billion from $1.2 billion a year ago. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONE, PEGGY L.
description: CONE-Peggy L. The music world mourns the loss of New York jazz icon, Peggy Cone. Bandleader, swing dancer, singer, and composer, Peggy passed away at her home in New York City on February 5th, due to liver cancer. She is survived by her beloved sister, Carol Cone, and her brotherin-law, Harry Silverman of Weston, MA, and her two cats, Willow and Miso. Peggy was heralded as an innovator of the New Swing movement and combined her flair for fashion with the melodies written during the ''Big Band Era.'' She delighted audiences with her strong voice, over the top style, and elegant vintage clothing and accessories from her vast collection. With her group, Peggy Cone and The Central Park Stompers, they recorded 4 cd's, including one that is soon to be released entitled, ''Looking for Yesterday.'' In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in memory of Peggy Cone to Against All Odds (a liver cancer research foundation), PO Box 6046, Nashua, New Hampshire 03063, Attention: Jerry Caplan.

description: A parliamentary committee issued a scathing report today on France's handling of the mad cow crisis during the last 10 years, accusing successive agricultural ministers of blocking precautionary steps because they were trying to appease a powerful agriculture sector.

title: Posada a Keeper, Thank You
description: The Texas Rangers are willing to listen to offers for the All-Star catcher Ivan Rodriguez, and rumors are already flying about potential deals involving the Yankees -- Jorge Posada and Andy Pettitte for Rodriguez, Posada and Roger Clemens for Rodriguez.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Pager Maker Wins Key Patent
description: Research in Motion, maker of the BlackBerry e-mail pager, said yesterday that it had been issued a patent protecting a way to redirect e-mail from a computer or server to a hand-held device using a single e-mail address. The company also said it had filed a complaint on Wednesday against a competitor, Glenayre Electronics Inc., accusing it of infringing on this patent as well as its trademark. Glenayre has used Research in Motion's trademark ''Always On, Always Connected'' tagline to promote its line of pagers. The Research in Motion patent, which it applied for on May 29, 1998, and received a month ago, could force competitors to license its technology. Introduced at the start of 1999, Blackberry pagers are popular among corporate users. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: York, Pa., Mayor Is Arrested in 1969 Racial Killing
description: Declaring ''I am not a racist,'' Mayor Charles Robertson of York, Pa., surrendered to the authorities yesterday and was led away in handcuffs, charged with murder in the killing of a black motorist in race riots there 32 years ago, when he was a police officer.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about attacks on white-owned businesses in Zimbabwe, and the economic and political turmoil there, misstated the extent of the opposition's gain in parliamentary elections last June. Although the opposition indeed holds just over one-third of the seats, it won just under half -- 57 out of 120 contested. An additional 30 members were appointed by President Robert Mugabe and belong to his ruling party or support it.

description: The operative word in Baz Luhrmann's ''Moulin Rouge,'' the story of a doomed love between a writer (Ewan McGregor) and a dancer (Nicole Kidman), is rouge. In this movie there are more volatile or seductive shades of red than even Toulouse-Lautrec might have dreamed of.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball Tale: Successful In Seattle
description: THEY are baseball's hottest and most heartening team, America's anti-A-Rods, the superstar-stripped engine that could. Be careful, however, in characterizing the Seattle Mariners, who deserve a national round of applause but are no Main Street shop rising up against the mall.

title: Co-Founder of Hale House Is Dismissed With a Stinging Rebuke
description: The new interim Hale House board dismissed Dr. Lorraine E. Hale as the charity's president yesterday, saying she had failed to fulfill her recent promise to resign from the organization she founded with her mother in 1969.

title: Candace Phillippi and Judah Trabulsi, Stand UP! Florida Convention, St. Petersburg, Fla., March 3, 2001
description: Phillippi (left): "I've known Judah since I was little. I call him my big brother, and I'm his little sister. We stuck to each other the whole weekend. We were at a big gathering where Christians come together every year. There's concerts, speakers and worship. That was during worship when musicians from Teen Mania Ministry sings songs. I pray and close my eyes, and the songs are going in my head, and I'm worshiping him. It's not rock. It's quiet worship music or fast celebration songs. I listen to them all the time. I downloaded them off of Napster.

title: Notre Dame Is Upset
description: Kevin Bice homered in the top of the seventh to lift Virginia Tech past Notre Dame, the regular-season champion, by 4-3 yesterday in the Big East tourney in Bridgewater, N.J. Seton Hall beat Rutgers, 4-2, in the other game. The double-elimination event runs through tomorrow.

title: Safety Debate On Baby Seats For Bathtubs
description: At least 78 babies have died in infant bath seats since 1983, a statistic that has prompted the government to consider banning the product. But some experts now suggest that the Consumer Product Safety Commission has miscalculated the danger of bath seats, and is poised to regulate or outlaw the seats, which may lower, not raise, the risk of drowning for children.

title: Payoffs Rife and Approved, French Ex-Oil Chief Asserts
description: PARIS, May 19  A former head of France's state-owned oil company, now on trial for corruption, has told two newspapers that paying millions of dollars a year in "secret commissions" was a routine part of his job and had the approval of Elysee Palace.

title: Plan Proposes Voluntary Efforts
description: The Bush energy policy describes conservation as one of the ''important elements of a sound energy policy,'' and notes that in the last three decades, the American economy has grown nearly five times faster than energy use.

description: From window tinting to a shaking car, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Judge Would Allow Victim Photos in Terror Trial
description: A jury will be able to see gory photographs of victims of the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa if a death penalty hearing becomes necessary, a judge ruled yesterday over the objections of defense lawyers.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Rediscovering Color In a Fellini Fantasy
description: Made in 1965, around the time the term psychedelia was coined to describe a luminous Day-Glo vision of the world, Federico Fellini's phantasmagoric ''Juliet of the Spirits'' was the Italian master's first color film. Arriving when serious European filmmakers were discovering color, this gorgeous, sometimes garish immersion in a rainbow palette invites you to contemplate the symbolic vibration of every hue in its teeming, overcrowded canvas. Now, for the first time in years, that palette can be fully savored in a restored 35-millimeter print of ''Juliet'' that opens today at Film Forum.

title: Mom and Son Make a Killing in Real Estate
description: Mary Tyler Moore is pushing the envelope again. Yes, she surprised fans 21 years ago, when she lost the perky turn-the-world-on smile and transformed herself into the cold-as-ice suburban wife and mother in the film ''Ordinary People.'' But that woman's sins were emotional. Now Ms. Moore is playing a cold-blooded killer, an apparently heartless con artist who, strolling out of a restaurant, steals a fur coat as casually as some people might grab a matchbook.

title: Peruvian Runoff Quandary: Both Candidates Lose Favor
description: LIMA, Peru, May 18  Maria Arredondo, a sprightly street vendor of fried bananas and sweets, said she once thrilled at the sight of Alejandro Toledo campaigning for president dressed as a native Indian and embracing the Andean customs of her childhood.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Holbrook: Woman Accused Of Abusing Child
description: A baby sitter was arrested after she was caught on a hidden video camera hitting and sexually abusing a 2-year-old boy, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. Investigators said the boy's grandmother became suspicious of the sitter, Wendy Hatras, 29, of Holbrook, and installed the camera in a clock in the child's room. ''The videotape is pretty horrific once you view it,'' said Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick. Ms. Hatras was arrested on Wednesday and charged with first-degree sexual abuse, endangering the welfare of a child and second-degree reckless endangerment. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

description: Some rolled up in wheelchairs and hobbled on canes. Others swaggered in Stetsons and sauntered in dresses designed by the local fashion kingpin, Manuel. They were the country-music giants of the last seven decades -- Harlan Howard, Earl Scruggs, Brenda Lee, George Jones, Trisha Yearwood and dozens more.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Marconi
description: Britain's largest phone equipment maker, Marconi P.L.C., said it had lost money in its most recent fiscal year, as sales of network equipment slowed. The company said business was unlikely to improve in the first six months of the current year, given that customers like British Telecommunications, which is loaded with debt, had cut back orders. Marconi said it had lost 271 million ($388 million), or 9.8 pence a share, for the year ended March 31, compared with a profit of 522 million, or 19.1 pence a share, last year.

title: Valentine Moves Up Shinjo in Order
description: One of the things that has struck the Mets' decision makers about the team's recent slide has been the hitters' lack of aggressiveness. An exception has been Tsuyoshi Shinjo, who was an aggressive hitter in Japan and has continued that approach with the Mets. Manager Bobby Valentine wanted to see more of that last night, so he batted Shinjo third for the first time this year.

title: Two Styles of Queenly Beauty
description: When casting Donizetti's opera ''Maria Stuarda,'' it's ideal to find two sopranos of different vocal styles and temperaments to portray the two British queens whose rivalry dominates the story: the title character (Mary Stuart, Queen of Scots), and Elisabetta (Queen Elizabeth I). The conductor Eve Queler accomplished this and then some with the performance she conducted on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall with the Opera Orchestra of New York. Ruth Ann Swenson sang Maria and Lauren Flanigan sang Elisabetta. Both are great sopranos, but in totally different ways. The performance was a testimony to the stylistic and interpretive variety that is possible in bel canto opera.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Ban Ends On Political Parties
description: President Joseph Kabila announced that political parties would be allowed to organize and take part in future peace talks among the government, opposition and rebel groups. After seizing power four years ago, his father, Laurent D. Kabila, banned political parties and then imposed restrictions so onerous that no parties were able to operate. title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Turn To The Right
description: Gordon Campbell led the British Columbia Liberal Party to a landslide victory in provincial elections, ending a decade-long rule by Canada's most left-leaning government. The departing New Democratic Party, accused of incompetence and corruption, went from 39 seats to just 3 in the 79-seat provincial Parliament while the Liberals took 76. Mr. Campbell, the former mayor of Vancouver, has promised to cut taxes and hold a referendum on several Indian treaties that were signed over the last few years. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRILLON, YVES M.

title: The "Key to the City" Package: New York
description: The Avalon Hotel, with 20 rooms and 80 suites on 32nd Street just off Madison Avenue in Manhattan, has a Key to the City package that can save some time waiting in ticket lines. It includes tickets (real ones -- not vouchers that have to be exchanged at a ticket window) to six attractions: the Empire State Building and World Trade Center observatories, the Museum of Modern Art, the Guggenheim, the American Museum of Natural History and the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum. Although there's some duplication there (certainly with two skyscraper lookouts), the package also includes Continental breakfast and access to a Bally's fitness club. Guests should also factor in how much time they will have to use all the tickets, since the price of $450 provides two nights accommodations (an extra night is $199). Rates do not include tax and are subject to availability. Information: (888) 442-8256 or www.theavalonny.com .

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Library Services Companies To Unite
description: The Sirsi Corporation, a private company that makes software for libraries, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Data Research Associates, a library software and services company, for $11 a share, or about $51.5 million. Sirsi said it would make a tender offer for 4.5 million outstanding shares of Data Research Associates common stock. The offer represented an 86 percent premium to the share price on Wednesday, when they closed at $5.91 on the Nasdaq. The Data Research shares leaped $4.34, or 73 percent, to $10.25. Under the agreement, Data Research will become a unit of Sirsi. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Fuel Economy for New Cars Is at Lowest Level Since '80
description: The overall fuel economy of new cars and trucks sold in America, after improving slightly a year ago, has dropped back to the lowest levels since 1980, a new government report indicates.

title: Is He or Isn't He? It's a Haunting Question
description: In teaming Jennifer Lopez and Jim Caviezel as lovers with a supernatural bond, ''Angel Eyes'' has come up with a weird new variation on Hollywood notions of romantic role models: the super-tough gal and the quivering, walking-wounded guy. Watching these two share some awkward smooches that are supposed to transport them over the moon is a little like imagining Jane Russell and Montgomery Clift in a steamy clinch. (Back in the 1940's and 50's, casting directors apparently had more sense than they do today, since such a clinch never took place.) Despite much soulful staring into each other's eyes, their lip locks have no sizzle.

title: Public Interests; Education On Ice
description: In Texas, where, our current president has assured us, no child is left behind, a significant number do seem to have been left holding the bag.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''No matter how much we conserve, we're still going to need more energy.''

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Delay For Pinochet
description: Retired Gen. Augusto Pinochet won a third judicial delay in having his fingerprints and mug shots taken while he awaits a possible future trial for human rights violations that occurred during his rule over the country. Citing the former dictator's ailing health, a court of appeals suspended a judge's order that he be registered officially with the police, a process his supporters consider unnecessary. Human rights lawyers say it is important that General Pinochet be treated like any suspect. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: UAL to Provide Private Jets For Businesses
description: The board of the UAL Corporation approved plans today for a new business-jet unit that would serve corporate customers and complement its main carrier, United Airlines.

title: Mourning a Lost Dog, Lost Childhood Hopes
description: In his deeply affecting film ''Ponette,'' the French director Jacques Doillon dived headlong into the mind of a little girl whose mother had died and extracted a vision of early childhood so astonishing in its verisimilitude that it was enough to stir up your own primal impressions of a mostly forgotten age. And in his fine new film, ''Petits Frres,'' Mr. Doillon displays a similar empathy with youthful consciousness, but here his children are on the cusp of adolescence.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Aids Cases Rise
description: The number of AIDS cases in Washington has increased for the first time since 1993, state epidemiologists reported, with the increases especially pronounced among women and members of minorities. There were 385 cases reported in the state last year, compared with 364 in 1999. State officials said the new numbers indicated that prevention awareness was slipping. In the early stages of the AIDS epidemic in the state, women made up about 5 percent of all cases; they are now 14 percent. And African-Americans, once about 8 percent of the caseload, now represent 16 percent. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Citigroup Agrees to Buy Big Mexican Bank Company

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose on concern that President Bush's energy plan will not do enough to prevent supply disruptions. In New York, gasoline for June delivery rose 3.36 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $1.0212 a gallon.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Actions Follow Words
description: The authorities have arrested at least 10 people on charges of invading local businesses and extorting money from company owners. The arrests came after John Nkomo, the minister for home affairs, called for a halt to the invasions. Over the last month, government-backed militants have descended on the factories and offices of about 30 companies, mostly in the capital, plunging the country deeper into political and economic turmoil. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL IN $1 BILLION PURCHASE
description: Tyco International said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the electronic-security assets of Cambridge Protection Industries for $1 billion. The Cambridge businesses, which include the SecurityLink brand, have about $500 million in annual revenue, 5,000 employees and one million customers, a Tyco spokeswoman said. Tyco already owns ADT, a leading maker of burglar alarms. Tyco's burglar- and fire-alarm businesses accounted for about a fifth of its $28.9 billion in sales in the 2000 fiscal year. SecurityLink sells electronic systems and video surveillance for homes and businesses to detect intruders, fire and carbon monoxide and to monitor temperature and power use. Cambridge is a unit of GTCR Golder Rauner, a private equity firm.

title: Gehry's Vision Of Renovating Democracy
description: OH, what can you do with a man like Jacques Barzun, author of ''From Dawn to Decadence,'' the best-selling jeremiad on the culture of our times? ''What can you do?'' John Cheever famously wrung his hands over the evil eyes among us. ''How can you dissuade his eye in a crowd from seeking out the cheek with acne, the infirm hand? How can you teach him to respond to the inestimable greatness of the race, the harsh surface beauty of life?''

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Financier Denied Bail
description: A federal judge yesterday denied bail for the disgraced financier Robert E. Brennan, despite the nearly $6 million raised by friends and family for his bond. Mr. Brennan has been held in the Monmouth County Jail since he was convicted on April 16 of money laundering and bankruptcy fraud. Supporters had pledged cash, property, even their retirement packages to free Mr. Brennan. The prosecution, however, called Mr. Brennan a ''serious flight risk'' and noted that he was convicted of concealing assets in offshore accounts.

title: Corrections
description: The credit yesterday for a picture of the mayor of York, Pa., who announced that he would be charged with a 1969 murder, misspelled the photographer's given name. He is Bil Bowden, not Bill.

title: BUSH, PUSHING ENERGY PLAN, OFFERS SCORES OF PROPOSALS TO FIND NEW POWER SOURCES
description: President Bush began an intensive effort today to sell his plan for developing new sources of energy to Congress and the American people, arguing that the country had a future of ''energy abundance'' if it could break free of the traditional antagonism between energy producers and environmental advocates.

title: In Races for Triple Crown, Close Look at Fast Times
description: John Passero doesn't own or train a horse running in the 126th Preakness Stakes, and he is far too big and old to be a jockey. On Saturday, however, when the gates pop open on the second leg of horse racing's Triple Crown, he will be perhaps the most influential person at Pimlico Race Course.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Expensive Inauguration
description: After spending nearly $1 million on a two-day inaugural celebration that including an event where the actor Tony Randall was M.C., Gov. Bob Holden is being criticized because his inaugural committee is more than $417,000 in debt. The celebration, one of the most expensive of the 17 held for new governors this year, was called extravagant by a Republican state representative, Jason Crowell. A spokesman for Mr. Holden, a Democrat, said the governor planned to raise money to pay off the debts after the Legislature adjourns today. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: EQ has dropped the E, kept the Q and added ''bar.'' The alphabetic reshuffle is meant to signal a new, sporty personality and a more casual menu for what used to be a miniature temple of fine cuisine. In the end, EQ was simply too ambitious and too expensive for the West Village. So Dennis Foy, the chef, and Estelle Quinones, an owner of the restaurant, decided to revise the format and turn over the kitchen to the sous chef, Enrico Wahl.

title: Callaway Tees Up Another Commercial to Sell Controversial Club
description: The word came to Callaway Golf in late March: the major networks would not run a commercial for its new ERC Titanium II driver on their golf telecasts. The spot was not scandalous, just impertinent.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Murder Charges Reduced
description: A Bronx man who killed a reputed thief and was initially charged with second-degree murder had his charges reduced to second-degree manslaughter this week after a grand jury reviewed his case. The man, Victor Vicenty, a school bus driver, was accused of recklessly causing the death of Kevin Bethea when he shot him early on May 7, the Bronx district attorney's office said yesterday. The grand jury also charged Mr. Vicenty, who is being held without bail, with possession of a weapon.

title: Citigroup to Buy Mexican Bank In a Deal Valued at $12.5 Billion
description: In the biggest Latin American acquisition by a United States company, Citigroup announced yesterday that it would buy Mexico's second-largest bank for $12.5 billion in cash and stock.

description: It did not make sense, Tess Kingham thought as she took her seat in the House of Commons four years ago. Although she could buy bottles of whisky in the Parliament building, she could not buy fax paper.

description: The prosecution of Oliver Jovanovic is in its fifth year now, and public attention has faded in the case of the Columbia University graduate student accused of preying on a nave undergraduate he met on the Internet.

title: Giuliani Breaks Silence, Citing 'Adult' and 'Mature' Relationship
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his relationship with his friend Judith Nathan was ''adult'' and ''mature'' and that he hoped it would last forever.

title: Corrections

Small, to close its zoological research center despite a White House-approved increase in the institution's budget misstated the amount of the proposed increase. It is $40 million, not $50 million.

title: Dismissed for Chat Room, C.I.A. Workers Speak Out
description: Four C.I.A. employees, fired for their involvement with a private and unauthorized chat network on the agency's computer system, said in interviews this week that the agency had treated them far too harshly for what they considered a harmless social activity.

title: SAKS NAMES PRESIDENT FOR ITS PARISIAN STORES DIVISION
description: Saks Inc., the owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and other department stores, has named Rob Gruen president and chief executive of its Parisian stores division. Mr. Gruen, 51, will oversee 40 department stores in the Southeast and Midwest that operate under the Parisian name. He replaces Travis Saucer, who resigned last week, a company spokeswoman said. Most recently, Mr. Gruen has been executive vice president of Warner Brothers' consumer-products division.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New Mall Site Discussed
description: The Mills Corporation is talking with New Jersey officials about building its $330 million shopping mall project within the Meadowlands sports complex rather than on nearby marshland, company officials said yesterday. Mills's plan to dredge and fill wetland for what would be the state's largest shopping mall ran into opposition from environmental groups. In March, the acting governor, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said he opposed the project and asked the company, which is based in Arlington, Va., to move it to the alternative site next to Giants Stadium, where the Continental Airlines Arena stands. Mills's first choice remains a 90.5-acre site nearby in Carlstadt. The company is trying to get permission from the Army Corps of Engineers to fill in 206 acres of wetlands for the mall.

title: Devils Take Penguins (and Their Fans) Out of the Action
description: Hockey's common wisdom holds that the road team should ''take the home crowd out of the game'' by playing a methodical and conservative style that squelches emotion in the arena. Give the Devils full credit for doing so last night in their 3-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins in the Igloo.

description: MARLIN-George. So absent, so present, rest in peace. The Marlin Famil

title: Former Polish Ruler Wins New Delay In Trial Over 1970 Slayings
description: WARSAW, May 18  Poland's former military ruler, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, won another reprieve today from answering charges that he gave orders to shoot workers protesting price increases in 1970.

title: 34 Smuggled Icons Are Returned to the Russian Church
description: The United States Customs Service yesterday returned to the Russian Orthodox Church a cache of 34 valuable icons that had been smuggled out of Russia and were seized by customs agents just as they were about to be sold by a Utah bookseller in 1993.

title: Israelis Tell of Army Mistake In Killings of 5 Palestinians
description: An internal Israeli Army investigation has determined that the killing of five Palestinian security men earlier this week was a deadly mistake, Yossi Sarid, the Israeli opposition leader, said today.

title: Trachsel Takes a Pounding, and Then Gets Ripped
description: Steve Trachsel reclined in his padded folding chair in the clubhouse, jaw fixed, hands on his head, staring into his locker. It was the same pose so many Mets struck in the moments after they lost the World Series last fall. This was a game in May, but for Trachsel the loss could be devastating. He may lose his place in the Mets' rotation.

title: The Changing American Family
description: Few sociological metaphors have ever been as successful as that of the nuclear family, which entered the language in 1949 at the beginning of what turned out to be the baby boom -- another highly successful figure of speech. The phrase ''nuclear family,'' meaning a married man and woman living with their offspring, was introduced by the anthropologist George Murdock, who openly acknowledged the implicit metaphor. ''Among the majority of the peoples on earth,'' he wrote, ''nuclear families are combined, like atoms in a molecule, into larger aggregates.'' But he also noted that in our own society, the nuclear family was ''the type of family recognized to the exclusion of all others.''

title: Energy Executives Like Proposals; Outside Experts See Less Need for Action
description: Energy industry officials and analysts generally embraced the White House energy report issued yesterday. But they pointed out major aspects of the plan that could spark protracted battles with environmentalists and state governments.

title: Fox to Stagger New Shows And Bring Back 'Island'
description: Announcing a fall schedule that seems aimed at positioning the network for a competitive surge next January, Fox unveiled three new comedies and two new dramas yesterday while keeping three nights of programming intact.

title: In Two Different Rulings, Strawberry Avoids Prison
description: Tears welled in Darryl Strawberry's eyes today after a judge ruled that yet another probation violation by Strawberry would not result in a prison term. Judge Florence Foster of Hillsborough Circuit Court said she was sending Strawberry to a strict, privately run drug treatment program rather than agree to the state's request that he serve 18 months in a prison treatment program.

title: AOL Reorganization to Cost $965 Million
description: AOL Time Warner estimates that the cost of reorganizing its merged businesses will be about $965 million, with more than half from job cuts, a Securities and Exchange Commission filing says.

description: Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam Inc. unit of the WPP Group, made several changes in executive management yesterday.

title: Metro Business Briefing | No Tax Breaks For AOL Building
description: The AOL Time Warner Center, a $1.7 billion mixed-use project under construction at Columbus Circle, will not qualify for tax breaks, the City Finance Department determined yesterday. The developers of the overall project, Stephen M. Ross, Kenneth A. Himmel and William L. Mack, said at the outset that they would not seek abatements. But AOL Time Warner, whose headquarters and studios will occupy about one-third of the 2.8-million-square-foot structure, was exploring the possibility. In a letter informing the company that the project would not qualify, the director of property tax exemptions, Warren Hyman, cited an earlier agreement between the city and the owners ''prohibiting any otherwise eligible applicant from seeking or taking advantage of any as-of-right real estate tax exemption, abatement or incentive program.''

title: Residential Real Estate; Old Hospital Is Centerpiece Of a Luxurious Compound
description: For more than 25 years, a French Renaissance-style chateau on Central Park West between 105th and 106th Streets has sat vacant, falling ever further into decay as one developer after another abandoned efforts to restore it.

title: Good News for Yanks: They Play in A.L. East
description: The Yankees view all failure through the prism of their success, a benefit of winning championships. Oh, sure, they fully acknowledge how poorly they are playing, four straight losses, three in a row here to the Oakland Athletics, a sweep at the hands of a struggling team. The Yankees admitted that they were fortunate, that if they were members of the American League Central or West, they would be buried deep in the standing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMAN, JOSEPH
description: ROMAN-Joseph. Suddenly on May 15, 2001 at age 67. Son of the late Dyonizy and Bronislawa Roman, brother of the late Daniel J. Roman. Survived by his sister Theresa R. Lynch and husband James, two nieces, and a nephew. A noted Interior Designer, Mr. Roman was a longtime resident of New York City and East Hampton. He attended the New York School of Interior Design and for many years was a member of the American Society of Interior Designers. Mr. Roman was also a Board Member of the Pebble Hill Plantation Museum in Thomasville, Georgia. Funeral Mass at Church of the Holy Family, 315 East 47th St., 6PM Friday, May 18th. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the New York School of Interior Design.

description: If the fall season were to arrive next week and a viewer were to tune in to UPN on Tuesday at 8 p.m., he might think he was actually watching WB.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Gun-Training Classes Vetoed
description: Gov. Parris N. Glendening vetoed legislation that would have made the state the first to require gun-safety education for all public school students. Under the bills, students in grades 7 through 12 would have gone to shooting ranges to handle rifles, shotguns, handguns and ammunition in programs that included ones run by the National Rifle Association. Critics, including teachers, contended that the measure would glorify gun violence and lead to school shootings.

title: And Now It's Ex-Nazis For a Little Soap Opera
description: Nazi remembrances have in recent weeks given us theater ranging from the grim realities of crimes against humanity in ''Judgment at Nuremberg'' to the inspired madcap lunacy of ''The Producers.'' It was only a matter of time before the soap opera came along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFER, RAE
description: SCHAFFER-Rae, 94. Widow of Leo. Beloved mother of Jerry and Dan. Loving mother-in-law of Susan, Sally & the late Judy. Adoring grandmother of Noah. Dearest sister of Pearl Wald. Best friend of Helen Shapiro. Step-grandmother of Judi, Steve & Lou Ann, Michael and Hanna, and step-great grandmother of eight. Services Sunday, 11:30 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory can be made to your favorite charity.

description: Every Sunday night I've been taking the television critic's version of a busman's holiday: at 8:30, whether I have to or not, I watch ''Malcolm in the Middle'' on Fox, followed by -- what else? -- ''The Sopranos'' at 9 on HBO.

title: Link Between Human Genes and Bacteria Is Hotly Debated by Rival Scientific Camps
description: In a fresh skirmish in the genome wars, a finding presented as a major discovery by the consortium of academic centers that decoded the human genome has come under attack from the camp of the consortium's rival, Celera Genomics.

title: Miscellany
description: Digital Edge, New York and San Francisco, part of Media Edge, plans to open four additional offices, in Amsterdam; Bogot, Colombia; Santiago, Chile; and Singapore. In the last six months, the agency opened seven offices in Australia and Europe. Media Edge is a unit of Young & Rubicam, owned by the WPP Group.

title: Bush Travels to Pennsylvania to Promote His Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, May 18  President Bush journeyed to central Pennsylvania today to sell his energy plan, declaring again that there need be no conflict between environmental protection and energy production and prodding the federal bureaucracy to put his ideas into action.

title: Fitzgerald Is Out As Columbus Coach
description: The Columbus Crew, which has won only one game this season, fired Coach Tom Fitzgerald and replaced him on an interim basis with the goalkeepers coach, Greg Andrulis. The dismissal ended the longest current coaching tenure in Major League Soccer.

description: The Venator Group's profit nearly tripled in its most recent quarter as the company, an athletic-footwear retailer, reduced costs and sold more basketball shoes and more of its own brands, like Foot Locker T-shirts.

title: A New Focus on Supply
description: Under federal law, anyone wanting to drill oil wells, lay pipelines or build power plants has for decades been required to prepare an environmental impact statement clearing the project on environmental grounds.

title: An In-Your-Face Style That Thrives on Chaos
description: Something in William Klein's photographs is always lunging at you: a hand, a face, a gun, a protest, an ad. Even the flattest object -- a door, a mirror, a window -- is an occasion for intrusion. A 1955 Klein photograph shows a door decorated with an advertisement for Philip Morris's King Size Cigarettes. A bellboy in the ad shoves a pack of cigarettes in your face. On the same door is a piece of torn paper. It is taped flat to the surface, but its message reaches out with its combination of bad grammar and great poetry. It reads: ''Closed on kind of fire.''

title: Heritage Museum Receives $6 Million
description: The Museum of Jewish Heritage in Lower Manhattan has received a $6 million gift from the Edmond J. Safra Philanthropic Foundation to go toward a new auditorium, part of its $60 million expansion project. The gift was announced yesterday by the museum's chairman, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney.

title: Poetry as Armor Against Highs and Lows of Life
description: DISTURB not the woman called Alice in the late afternoon who walks, lost in concentration, in Bryant Park, with the odd slips of paper clutched between her fingers. Ask not for directions. Distract her not with idle gossip. Stay clear of her trancelike step as she circles round the bushes and the trees. Take no care of her soft murmurings. She is memorizing poems. She is gripped by the ''sad mechanic exercise,'' as Alfred Lord Tennyson wrote, the ''dull narcotics, numbing pain.'' She is making other words her own. And she has been doing it since she was a child.
