title: Murray Murdoch, 96, Player For Rangers and Yale Coach
description: Murray Murdoch, the last survivor of the original New York Rangers of 1926-27 and later the Yale hockey coach for 27 years, died yesterday at Georgetown Memorial Hospital in South Carolina. He was 96.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Climbed Sharply in March
description: After a steep drop in February, the United States trade deficit expanded widely in March, producing a record first-quarter gap, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Not So Fast, Judge Says
description: The chief investigating judge in the killing of the journalist Georgy Gongadze knocked down a claim by the interior minister that the killers had been found, saying it is ''still too soon to say that the murder of the journalist has been solved.'' Interior Minister Yuri Smirnov said this week that the crime was a random killing by two gangsters who later died themselves. Critics derided that account as a clumsy attempt to divert attention from President Leonid D. Kuchma, who has been implicated in the case; he denies any role in the killing. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 10 about Dr. Marie Jahoda, a social psychologist, omitted two survivors. They are a sister, Rosi Kuerti of Cleveland, and a brother, Fritz Jahoda of Concord, Mass.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Nursing-Home Workers
description: Five more nursing homes said they would allow union workers who had walked out on May 1 to return to work, raising the total number of homes bringing back their unionized work force to 15, union officials said yesterday. Meanwhile, 100 union supporters were arrested for blocking a driveway at the Capitol. Earlier this week, members of the New England Health Care Employees, District 1199, voted to return to work at 39 homes they had left two weeks earlier, but none of the homes welcomed the workers immediately.

title: A Vintage Brodeur Allows the Devils To Take Command
description: Martin Brodeur had the best view in the Igloo.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Legal Win For Drug Plan
description: The state's groundbreaking plan to pressure prescription drug makers into lowering prices won a critical victory in a federal appeals court. The Court of Appeals for the First Circuit denied the companies' request for an injunction to block the plan. The companies' lawsuit against the state will continue, but in the meanwhile, Maine can begin to begin a plan that turns the poor, elderly and uninsured into a giant pool that negotiates to cut prices. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

description: Shaun Alexander dawdled through college, driving a new car every year and winning friends by giving parties where the liquor flowed freely. Max Kolb, by contrast, was a dean's list student, diligent and strait-laced, a good listener who sent e-mail to his mother daily.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France/Belgium: Oil Profit
description: Riding the wave of higher crude oil prices, the French-Belgian oil group TotalFina Elf increased first-quarter profit 33 percent, to 2.2 billion euros ($1.9 billion), excluding exceptional items, the chairman, Thierry Demarest, told the annual shareholders meeting. He said profitability was also aided by strong refining margins, which averaged $15 a metric ton in Europe. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNON, VINCENT N.
description: GANNON-Vincent N., 77, of Dataw Island, S.C. (formerly of Huntington, NY), died May 15, 2001. Vince was a retired Senior Vice President of Hill & Knowlton, Inc. Survivors include his wife, May; daughter, Pamela, and brother, Thomas. Memorials may be made to the American Lung Association, NYC.

title: City Shows Job Growth in Face of Slowdown
description: New York's economy is clearly slowing, but is far stronger than the nation's, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ex-Kremlin Aide Questioned
description: The former Kremlin property manager, Pavel Borodin, appeared before a magistrate investigating whether he was involved in laundering $25 million from two Swiss construction companies. He remained silent under questioning where he faced, for the first time, a lawyer and two bankers accused of helping him launder the money, believed to be bribes for awarding multimillion-dollar contracts to renovate Kremlin buiildings. Mr. Borodin has denied any wrongdoing. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Cold War
description: Russian Su-24 warplanes rained 550- and 1,100-pound bombs on an old enemy: a thick 50-mile sheet of ice blocking the flow of the Lena River in Siberia and causing massive floods in towns along its banks. The Lena freezes every year but the last winter, one of the coldest in memory, has delayed the thaw in the north where the river empties into the Arctic Ocean, causing meltwater to back up. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIFER, BLANCHE
description: FEIFER-Blanche. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of its longtime member. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Shelley M. Limmer, President Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Maybelline turns to an actress from 'Providence' to attract more women who are over age 27.
description: THE appearance of those first fine lines on the face is a milestone most women could do without. For Maybelline, however, it is a golden opportunity to introduce a new age-minimizing makeup and establish a connection with a slightly older audience.

description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: FELSHER-Hal C. Of Southbury, CT, and formerly of Jericho, New York, on May 16, 2001. Husband of Beatrice Fink Felsher; father of Dr. Jonathan C. Felsher and Celia A. Felsher; father-in-law of John Cecil; brother of Dorothy Jacobs; grandfather of Matthew Felsher, Teddy Cecil, Marisa Felsher and Rachel Cecil. Memorial Service to be scheduled at a later date. For information contact the MinshallShropshire Funeral Home, Middletown Township, Media, PA.

title: Don't Call Them Mechanics, but Call Them Scarce
description: HOW many service technicans does it take to replace 426 million headlamps? To screw in more than a billion sparkplugs? To run computerized diagnostic checks on the evaporative emissions control systems of several million recent-model dual-cam V-6 engines?

title: NASA Begins Bid to Improve Its Launchings
description: Seeking ways to launch payloads into space more cheaply and reliably, NASA awarded contracts worth up to $767 million today to 22 companies and universities for improved rocket technology.

title: Dejected Jagr Fails To End A Drought
description: Jaromir Jagr says he is trying. He is trying to do the little things so that maybe those huge, game-winning things that used to come easily will return. Perhaps, he said, he is trying too hard.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Perfect Storm?
description: President Bush is not responsible for America's energy crisis, its current economic slowdown or even for all the tension between the U.S. and China and the U.S. and certain allies. What he is responsible for, though, is managing these situations. And that is what's worrying.

title: Backers of Caspian Pipeline Say Project Will Move Ahead
description: The companies involved in a much-debated pipeline to carry oil from the Caspian Sea to Turkey's Mediterranean coast have announced that they have found the initial cost estimate to be viable and will begin the next phase.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Power Plants Move Ahead
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that the state could continue construction of nine mini-power plants in New York City and a 10th in Brentwood, in Suffolk County, while the court considered whether the plants could be completed. The plants are to have gas-turbine generators to avert possible power shortages. Opponents contend that the state skirted environmental laws to avoid a public review of the proposed plants and that it improperly placed them in poor neighborhoods. Trial courts in Brooklyn and Queens have issued conflicting rulings on the issues. On Wednesday, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn declined to stop construction pending its ultimate ruling on the challenges, and it set June 29 for arguments on them. An 11th site, in Staten Island, is not before the appellate court because the trial court in that case has not yet issued its final ruling, said Lisa Garcia, a lawyer with the New York Public Interest Research Group, one of the groups seeking to block the plants. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Warns Of Poor Outlook
description: The hand-held computer maker Palm Inc. said yesterday that the slowing economy had forced it to abandon its proposed acquisition of Extended Systems. Palm also cut its earnings projections for its fiscal fourth quarter. Palm had announced on March 6 that it would pay $22 a share in stock for Extended Systems, which makes software used by businesses to manage mobile devices. But yesterday the two companies said they had agreed to scuttle the deal without a termination fee. Describing its earnings outlook as clouded in part by delays in shipment of a new product family, Palm said sales for the current quarter were likely to be $140 million to $160 million, scaling back previous estimates of $300 million to $315 million; the company said it expected its operating loss for the quarter to be $170 million to $190 million, roughly double what it had previously reported. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Green Light For Mormons
description: Mormons in New England can have not only their temple, but their steeple, too. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints ran into repeated court challenges from neighbors opposed to their wish to build a temple in Belmont, Mass. But first the courts upheld the church's right to build the temple, saying it was guaranteed by a law protecting religious institutions from local zoning rules. And now the state's Supreme Judicial Court has upheld the church's right to build a steeple that will reach the height of 139 feet and be topped by a golden angel. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAGGETT, LEONA (NEE RAYBEN)
description: HAGGETT-Leona (nee Rayben). In her 90th year. Wife of the late Arthur S. Haggett. Beloved mother of Simone and Alan Hartman, and Lois and Burton Spring. Loving grandmother of Andrew Spring, and Rochelle and Adam Flint. Cherished sister of Yvette Rosenberg. She will always be in our hearts. Graveside service Friday 1 PM. Call Riverside Chapel NYC for details. Contrbutions in her memory may be made to Fight For Sight or Hadassah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EHRENS, FRIEDA BELL
description: EHRENS-Frieda Bell. Age 92, in Brick, NJ on May 16, 2001. Born Frieda Alva Pollock on April 25, 1909 in New York City, she was the only child of Russian Jewish immigrants. She graduated from the Julliard School of Music, and won the gold medal in the piano competition from The New York Music Week Association. She was a soloist with The New York Philharmonic and appeared at Carnegie Hall. She was married to Dr. Harry Price Bell, Professor of Economics at Dartmouth College in Hanover, NH until his death in 1957. Dr. Bell was one of the first Jewish professors at an Ivy League school. She lived in Hanover for 26 years before returning to New York. From 1966 she was married to Henry Ehrens, the founder and former President of Sealed Unit Parts Corp. of Allenwood, NJ. Mr. and Mrs. Ehrens lived in Bayside, NY before moving to Brick, NJ in 1982. Mrs. Ehrens taught hundreds of piano students privately in her home over the years in Manhattan, Hanover, Bayside and Brick, and continued to give concerts locally. She is survived by her husband, Henry, her two daughters, Stephanie and Valerie, her two grandchildren, Michael and Jennifer and one great grandchild, Francesca. Services will be held at 2:00pm on Sunday, May 20, 2001 at Herbertsville Colonial Funeral Home, 1045 Sally Ike Rd, Brick, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBAUM, SID
description: LINDENBAUM-Sid. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the father of our devoted Benefactor and Founder, Herbert Lindenbaum. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier, Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

description: Among the 10,300 students who graduated from Rutgers University this year were a mother and daughter.

description: SINCE they finished finals at the end of April, Ben Royal and three fellow University of Michigan students have been driving around the Northeast in a green 1992 Toyota Corolla, trying to make a movement.

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Sex With Student Is Charged In Arrest of Queens Teacher
description: A 50-year-old high school English teacher in Queens was arrested yesterday and charged with engaging in a series of sexual encounters with one of his students, a 15-year-old sophomore at Martin Van Buren High School, over a 10-month period in 1996 and 1997, the authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Preschool Plan Stalled
description: Lawyers for children in low-income districts involved in the Abbott v. Burke school-financing case asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to order the state to move more quickly on a preschool plan first ordered three years ago. They also asked that a special judge be appointed to oversee the case. The State Department of Education declined to comment on yesterday's motion. Last month, an administrative law judge said the agency was not complying with the order. Robert Holster, the schools superintendent in Passaic, one of the 30 poor districts involved in the Abbott case, said more than 2,000 preschool students wanted placement in September for programs with only 1,200 seats. ''It's just havoc,'' he said.

title: The President's Lawyer, and the Court's
description: The job of solicitor general is one of the most eminent in American law. Part advocate, the S. G., as he is called, represents the United States before the Supreme Court, where the federal government is involved in about two-thirds of all cases decided on the merits (as opposed to procedural grounds). Part judge, he chooses when the government should appeal a case it has lost in a lower court, file a friend-of-the-court brief, or defend an act of Congress. Most S. G.'s have influenced rulings in landmark cases; many have become judges; four have risen to the Supreme Court. Yet for most of this tiny office's history since it was created in 1870, the S. G. drew little public or even scholarly attention.

title: I.B.M.'s Chief Talks of Probable Successor
description: Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman and chief executive of I.B.M., formally acknowledged for the first time last night that he expected Samuel J. Palmisano to succeed him. But Mr. Gerstner declined to confirm widespread speculation on Wall Street that the succession would take place next spring when he turns 60.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Scholar Charged as Spy

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Kindness Shared Amid Murder Trial
description: For nearly two weeks, two families at opposite ends of a murder trial in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn have gathered each day and somehow found a way to share their pain and empathize with one another.

title: Hong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens Over Flu Virus
description: HONG KONG, May 18  With chickens dying by the hundreds and public alarm mounting, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 1.2 million chickens and other poultry to halt the spread of a deadly flu virus.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Infant's Autopsy Opposed
description: The autopsy of an infant whose parents had opposed the procedure for religious reasons did not immediately reveal a cause of death, the authorities said yesterday. Muhammad Tahir Ali, 4 months old, died Tuesday morning. His parents have not been charged with a crime. They had opposed the autopsy, saying Islam prohibited such procedures, but a judge in State Superior Court ruled against them. Toxicology and other test results are pending. The boy's mother, Sabrina Devine, told the police that she fell asleep with the baby resting between her legs, and awoke to find that he had stopped breathing. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Sale Talks
description: General Motors officials arrived in Seoul yesterday for what may be the final round of talks with the creditors of Daewoo Motors over a takeover of the bankrupt carmaker. Hopes for the deal rose when Daewoo's main parts supplier, Korea Delphi Automotive Systems, ended a month of intermittent strikes and slowdowns yesterday by giving unions a no-layoffs pledge. Daewoo said yesterday that an internal survey found 60 percent of its workers favored a G.M. takeover. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Execution Postponed
description: A day before a North Carolina man was scheduled to be executed for a 1987 stabbing, the State Supreme Court postponed the execution because of concerns that Gov. Mike Easley, the former attorney general, might have a conflict of interest in the case. The court said it would hear arguments on June 7 on the legality of the governor's role in deciding whether to grant clemency to Robert Bacon and other death row inmates, because in his previous job, Mr. Easley was responsible for arguing against death-penalty appeals. The issue could also affect more than 100 other death-row cases in which Mr. Easley participated. David Firestone (NYT)

title: As Retro as a New Ford Can Be
description: FORD is hard at work on a vehicle that stands nearly 7.5 feet high, has a folding top and can reach 50 miles an hour. It is not an S.U.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, SUZANNE
description: FISHER-Suzanne. It is with great sadness that the Board, staff and friends of Lincoln Center mourn the passing of Suzanne Fisher. Our thoughts and prayers are with her husband, Richard L. Fisher, a cherished member of the Lincoln Center Board of Directors. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Richard and to the Fisher family and friends. Beverly Sills, Chairman Gordon J. Davis, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts Inc.

title: Lawmakers Press Investigation Into Intern's Disappearance
description: The parents of a 24-year-old Washington intern who disappeared more than two weeks ago sought help from their California senators today and met for a second day with the District of Columbia police.

description: Revealing a Twist of Nature

title: Unit of Saks Parts From West Wayne
description: The Saks Department Store Group unit of Saks and West Wayne in Atlanta said yesterday that they had parted ways after just five months. West Wayne handled advertising for the group, including 250 stores in 24 states operating under names like Carson Pirie Scott, Parisian, Proffitt's and Younkers, with billings estimated at $35 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONFA, STANLEY N.
description: FONFA-Stanley N. Age 79 of Palm City, FL died after a brief illness on May 16, 2001 at Martin Memorial Hospital. Beloved husband of Greta, cherished father of Ann, Gudrun, Andrew and stepson Scott, dear father-in-law of Jodi Fonfa and Steve Wolman, and darling grandfather of Raven, Brett, Evan and Haley Fonfa, and Casey Manning. Stanley was a very special human being who cared deeply about people and justice. He will be missed by friends and family, and by all who knew and loved him.

title: Large Internet Fund to Reopen
description: The Munder NetNet fund, the largest and one of the oldest Internet-focused mutual funds, will reopen to new investors on Wednesday.

title: Paying an Informal Call on the Master
description: Art lives a charmed public life in New York City. The world's great classical traditions are on permanent view in museums; master artists of the past put their best foot forward for all to see.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ORTHODONTIC CENTERS OF AMERICA, Metairie, La., which provides practice management services to orthodontists, has agreed to buy OrthAlliance Inc., Torrance, Calif., for as much as $56 million in stock.

title: McVeigh's Lawyer Known as a Stickler for Detail
description: DENVER, May 12  From the time he was appointed by a federal judge to represent Timothy J. McVeigh, Nathan D. Chambers had little more than a straight legal path to follow. His task was to manage Mr. McVeigh's appeals after his conviction and death sentence for his role in the Oklahoma City bombing six years ago.

title: Early Boulez Opus Seems More Approachable Now
description: In the late 1950's, when it was new, Pierre Boulez's ''Marteau Sans Matre'' was hailed within the contemporary music avant-garde as a breakthrough work of genius from a composer still in his 20's and decried by most mainstream concertgoers (few of whom had actually heard it) as just another offputting exercise in serialism. But even the work's champions admitted that the music was terribly difficult to perform.

title: New Video Releases
description: Best in Show

title: In a State Short of Power, Scant Praise for Bush Plan
description: A speech that may have seemed abstract to many Americans was intensely personal today for most Californians because of the state's power crisis, with many politicians and experts expressing disappointment that President Bush's energy plan would do nothing to eliminate the threat of blackouts this summer.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Board Member Resigns
description: Candice Carpenter, who came to epitomize the hard struggle to establish Internet companies in Silicon Alley, has resigned from the board of iVillage, according to the company's latest filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The resignation was first reported in AdAge on Wednesday. Ms. Carpenter, a veteran of American Express and QVC, founded iVillage in 1995 as an Internet site focusing on topics of interest to women. But the company had a hard time raising venture capital. In February, it announced that it was merging with Women.com. In December, Ms. Carpenter stepped down as chief executive of iVillage. She will remain an employee and received a cash payment of $1.3 million in lieu of a salary, bonus and other payments set up during a previous agreement. She will also receive a salary of $3,100 per month until Dec. 31, 2002.

title: Nine Hurt as Train and Crane Collide on L.I.
description: Nine people suffered minor injuries yesterday when a Long Island Rail Road train approaching the Hewlett station in Nassau County collided with a maintenance crane that was on a track, the authorities said.

title: Chemical Company to Sell Unit
description: Hercules, a chemical maker that is in a proxy fight with its largest investor, will sell Betz-Dearborn, a unit that makes water-treatment chemicals, before it sells the rest of the company, its chairman said today.

title: G.E. CHIEF SAYS HE IS SURPRISED BY SCRUTINY OF A DEAL
description: John F. Welch Jr., the chief executive of General Electric, said yesterday that he was surprised by the level of scrutiny that European regulators gave to G.E.'s proposed $43 billion acquisition of Honeywell International. He said, though, that he was willing to take steps to assuage their concerns. Mr. Welch, in an interview, said that G.E. would agree not to bundle aircraft engines and avionics in packages that its competitors could not match.

title: Intimate Glimpses of Life On the American Margin
description: Not many photographers of the American scene today can escape the influence of Robert Frank or Diane Arbus. Arbus (1923-1971) is noted for her voyeuristic concentration on the freaks and the far-out of our society, Mr. Frank (born 1924) for his documentary focus on the ways and wheres of ordinary Americans in the mid-20th century.

title: $22.5 Million Sale Breaks Contemporary-Art Records
description: Seminal contemporary artworks, by masters like Bruce Nauman and rising stars like Maurizio Cattelan who were little known to the public two years ago, became expensive objects of desire at Christie's last night.

title: Valentine Keeps Vow Amid Routs
description: Bobby Valentine sat behind his desk after this horrific game, an unhappy man fiddling with a pocket knife and trying to figure out novel ways to describe this latest embarrassment. Valentine occasionally criticizes the Mets, but he destroyed Steve Trachsel last night. The manager said that Trachsel was trying, but he instantly added that there were 20,000 fans at Shea Stadium who could try. Get it? The Mets need some results with Trachsel's effort.

title: Ford Is Said To Consider Seeking Recalls Of More Tires
description: The Ford Motor Company has concluded that there are safety problems with a number of Firestone tire models beyond those recalled last year and is leaning toward demanding that Firestone recall more tires, three people close to Ford's deliberations said today.

title: Better U.S. Access To Oil Is a Goal
description: The Bush administration's energy policy recommends expanding world production of oil, especially in Latin America and Africa, while rethinking American support for sanctions against energy-producing nations and deepening links to resource-rich Canada and Mexico.

title: Hybrid Cars Should Merit A Tax Credit, Report Says
description: People shopping for appliances could find that the canary-yellow energy-consumption stickers now on the front of every new refrigerator and air-conditioner will begin appearing on microwave ovens and clothes dryers as well.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ALTON M.
description: JOHNSON-Alton M. Born October 18, 1928 in Calumet, IL. Died peacefully May 16, 2001, Lenox Hill Hospital, New York City of Asbestos. Enlisted in U.S. Marine Corps 1944-1949, and U.S. Air Force 1949-1969. Served in Pacific Theater of WWII, The German Army of Occupation, The Korean War and Viet Nam. Recipient of numerous decorations including Bronze Stars & Purple Hearts. National Service Manager, Cavitron Electronics, 1969-1979. Much beloved by his life companion, Louise S. Horowitz, sister Judy Summers, nephew Leo Shanks, step grandchildren Marilyn, Roger and Diana Horowitz, & grandchildren Jason Horowitz, Benjamin Shanks and April Lee Shanks. Memorial service will be held Sunday, May 20th, 2 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANA, CHARLES A. JR.
description: DANA-Charles A. Jr. The faculty and staff of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons mourn the loss of our dear friend and generous benefactor, Charles A. Dana Jr. Mr. Dana supported numerous programs at Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons, including the Dana Post Doctoral Program in Brain and Behavior-a training program that brings new investigators into brain behavior research, primarily in the area of cognitive neuroscience. Mr. Dana actively served on the board of the Charles A. Dana Foundation, which encourages health, education, and research in the field of neuroscience, seeking better ways to diagnose, treat, and prevent diseases and disorders that afflict millions of Americans. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mr. Dana's family and friends. Gerald D. Fischbach, MD Vice President For Health and Biomedical Sciences, Dean of the Faculty of Health Sciences, Dean of the Faculty of Medicine, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons

title: SENATE COMMITTEE IS SPLIT BY PARTY ON A BUSH NOMINEE
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee deadlocked along party lines today on the selection of Theodore B. Olson to be solicitor general, with Democratic opponents complaining that Mr. Olson had earlier misled the committee about his involvement in anti-Clinton activities.

title: Columbine Panel Blames Lack of Action for Deaths
description: The massacre at Columbine High School two years ago might never have happened had school officials and the local sheriff acted on clear signs that the two killers were prone to violence and familiar with lethal weapons, according to a report made public today by Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado.

title: Duke's Williams Resists Lure of the Pros for College
description: The question from the high school coaches assembled at St. John's University yesterday might have been a test for Jason Williams, the Duke point guard, but he has become adept at avoiding such obstacles. What, Williams was asked, was his favorite subject during the last schoolyear?

title: ANTIQUES; New Breezes Rejuvenate Old Yachts
description: The first sailboat I raced was a wooden Lightning at Echo Camp on Raquette Lake in the Adirondacks. It was the summer of 1962, and I was expected to play tennis, ride horses, paddle a canoe. But I would sneak away to take the 19-foot sloop for a sail. Her hull was scarred with repairs, a physical record of generations of novice sailors. Her sails, cotton I think, were yellowed by the sun. To me, she was beautiful. And she was fast: in a stiff breeze my young mates and I struggled to reach our feet down to the hiking straps so we could lean far out over the rail, the wind and spray in our faces.

title: Woman Is Convicted of Killing Her Fetus by Smoking Cocaine
description: A 24-year-old South Carolina woman has been sentenced to 12 years in prison for killing her unborn fetus by smoking crack cocaine. Legal experts said it was the first such homicide case in the country.

title: Technology Called Safer Than in Past
description: Nuclear power plant construction has been dormant in the United States for the last two decades, but as President Bush pointed out, existing plants provide 20 percent of the nation's electricity with 103 plants functioning. Still, the last American nuclear power plant to enter operation was ordered in 1973.

title: China Charges U.S. Citizen With Spying For Taiwan
description: A Chinese-born American citizen and business professor who was mysteriously detained in February has been charged with spying for Taiwan, the American Embassy and his relatives said today.

title: Our New National Menu
description: To the Editor:

title: Sloan-Kettering Seeks to Build Research Unit
description: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center is seeking to build a large new research center on its Upper East Side campus that would replace the dilapidated building that currently houses its research laboratories.

title: Looking Beyond Plan Colombia
description: The Bush administration has proposed a counternarcotics strategy for Latin America that seems to reflect an understanding of the limitations of the plan it inherited from Bill Clinton, which relies overwhelmingly on military aid to Colombia. The Bush proposal wisely stresses a broader regional approach along with economic development and crop substitution. If that approach can lead to a genuine reorientation of drug policy, it will deserve Congressional support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAROSLOW, JEROME
description: JAROSLOW-Jerome. a/k/a Jerry Jarrett. On May 16, 2001. Adored father of Risa, Abby, Lori and father-in-law of David Tobis and David Robinson. Beloved grandfather of Mara, Leah, Samuel and Daniel. Dear brother of Ruth I. Jaroslow and Fred Jaroslow. Former husband of Sylvia Walter Jaroslow. Services Sunday, May 20th. 10AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal by Britain and the United States to lift the 11-year ban on international trade with Iraq misstated the reason for the departure of international inspectors there in 1998. It occurred -- that December, before the United States and Britain began bombing raids on Iraq -- because the United Nations feared that they might be harmed or taken hostage. They were not expelled.

title: A Misguided Energy Proposal
description: President Bush's long-awaited energy plan is as flawed and one-sided as its advance notices suggested it would be. Its 105 separate provisions include several potentially useful proposals aimed at improving energy efficiency and modernizing the country's power grid and pipelines. It also challenges Congress and the country to a long-overdue debate about nuclear power. But on the whole it is an alarmingly unbalanced piece of work whose main objective seems to be to satisfy the ambitions of the oil, gas and coal industries, either by easing environmental rules or by opening public lands for aggressive exploration.

title: Strong Instinet Debut Signals Some Life Returning to I.P.O. Market
description: Providing a sign that the moribund market for initial public offerings may be coming back to life, shares of the Instinet Group surged as much as 34.5 percent today as the company made its debut on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGARTEN, DR. RUTH
description: WEINGARTEN-Dr. Ruth. On May 15, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morris Weingarten. Loving mother of Alex and Meryl Weingarten, Karen and Sheldon Schwartz and Julian and Sidney. Sister of Florence Maslow, Leonard Weinberger and the late Miriam Wertentheil. Cherished by six grandchildren. Graduate of the Medical College of Pennsylvania, Class of 1952. Bibliophile and lover of the arts. Lifetime member of Amit and Agudath Israel. May her memory be a blessing.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Comverse Sales In China Authorized
description: Comverse Technology Inc., based in Woodbury, N.Y., the largest maker of telephone-messaging systems, is the first foreign vendor to receive authorization from China's Ministry of Information and Industry to sell voice-mail and short-message systems to China's service providers. The authorization will give Comverse, which has been selling its messaging systems in China since 1993, an added sales tool, a company spokesman said. Six mobile operators sell Comverse's services in China, the company said.

title: Corrections
description: An Inwood Journal article on May 6 about the closing of the Tara Irish Gift Shop after 35 years misspelled the name of a cereal sold there. It is Weetabix, not Wheetabix.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Parses Museum Dispute
description: Commenting on a growing dispute over a Yasir Arafat wax figure at Madame Tussaud's in Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that unlike publicly financed institutions, private museums have broad discretion over what they can display. Noting that he once barred the real Palestinian leader from a United Nations event, Mr. Giuliani also said Madame Tussaud's was not a hall of honors. The museum features ''some of the worst villains in the history of humanity, right?'' the mayor said. ''They have Jack the Ripper and they have serial killers.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: A Trail of Misery as Macedonia Fights Albanian Insurgency
description: The hills above this town lay quiet today as a noon deadline passed for rebels to withdraw from mountain villages along Macedonia's northern border, and the government said it was suspending its threatened offensive in the interests of peace.

title: Battle Lines in Congress Are Quickly Drawn by Republicans and Democrats
description: While there was bipartisan agreement on Capitol Hill that the nation faced an energy crunch and that the White House and Congress needed to do something about it, the partisan divide over the energy plan unveiled by President Bush could hardly have been sharper today.

title: Nasdaq Halts Trading in Software Company
description: Trading in shares of the AremisSoft Corporation was halted yesterday by the Nasdaq Stock Market amid a controversy about the company's accounting and business practices.

title: Resort Is to Rise on Concord Site But Without the Concord Name
description: The Concord Hotel, once the largest and one of the most famous of the Catskill resorts, will soon disappear.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Airline Start-Up Of Princely Origin; Wandering Cambodian Sees Revenue Ahead in Tourism
description: Prince Norodom Chakrapong is famous here for his arrivals and departures. In 1991, after spending a decade warring against the regime in power, he arrived in this capital to join it. Three years later, he departed on a flight to Malaysia, accused of plotting a coup d'tat.

title: Seeing Red
description: What could be more romantic and depressing than a fling in old Montmartre? Nicole Kidman and Ewan McGregor, below, are the unfortunate lovers in Baz Luhrmann's time warp of a musical, ''Moulin Rouge.''

title: Israel Retaliates for Suicide Blast
description: NETANYA, Israel, May 18  A suicide bombing in this coastal town provoked Israel to use warplanes against targets in the West Bank and Gaza Strip today for the first time since the 1967 war. Six Israelis and at least eight Palestinians were killed, making this the deadliest day of the year.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Crisis Worsens, U.N. Says
description: A three-member United Nations team evaluating the impact of sanctions on the war-ravaged, drought-afflicted country concluded after a visit that the crisis there is worsening but declined to say whether the sanctions have contributed to the situation. Andrew Cox, a member of the team, said its findings would be made public next month. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Penn State Without All the Penn Staters
description: The biggest thrill in town costs only $1.75. For a buck and change, a visitor to the University Creamery on the campus of Pennsylvania State University can get two heaping scoops of gloriously rich ice cream with a diet-busting butterfat content of 14.1 percent, packed tightly into a cone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIPPERGER, HELEN
description: RIPPERGER-Helen. On May 16, 2001 at age 91. Beloved wife of the late William Ripperger. Loving mother of Deborah Bacon. Cherished grandmother of Todd Bacon and great-grandmother of Ryan, Emily and Madeline Bacon. Graveside service at Lutheran Cemetery, Friday, May 18, 10:30 AM.

title: INSIDE ART
description: New Museum To Open in Fall

title: Metro Business Briefing | Low-Fare Flight Added
description: JetBlue Airways has added a second low-fare daily nonstop flight between Kennedy International Airport and Ontario, Calif., because of increased demand. JetBlue began service on the route last July. The carrier this month also began service between Seattle and Syracuse.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Tajikistan: New Partner For NATO
description: The government has agreed to join NATO's Partnership for Peace, a program created for countries that aspire to join the alliance. Gen. Tommy Franks, chief of the United States Central Command, said a delegation from the Tajik defense ministry would be invited to observe a NATO exercise in Germany. Russia has been eager to bring the former republic back into its own sphere of influence. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Cyber Law Journal: Hacker Gadfly at Center of New Suit
description: Eric Corley is in the legal soup again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DOROTHY
description: KAPLAN-Dorothy. Beloved mother of Cole (Sandy) Kaplan, his wife Sara, daughter Adele (deceased), grandmother to Marley and Keri and son-in-law Jay Kaplan. Sister of Bella Kono and Dave Blumstein (deceased), beloved aunt to Roberta and David Geula, Carl and Jean Kono, Harvey (deceased) and Fran Kono. We mourn the loss of a beautiful, kind and much beloved woman. Please rest in peace, dear auntie. Roberta Geula

title: National Briefing | Washington: Debating Campaign Finance Reform
description: Speaker J. Dennis Hastert pledged to bring campaign finance legislation to the House floor in early July. Representative Christopher Shays, a Connecticut Republican who had been pushing for action this month, said that while he had wanted to move faster, ''I firmly believe we can make the timetable work.'' Alison Mitchell (NYT)

title: Panel Backs Naming Donors to Libraries Of Former Presidents
description: A House committee today approved a measure that would require presidential libraries to publicly disclose the names of donors and the amounts of their contributions.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Flemington: Schluter To Run For Governor
description: Attacking both major parties as obsessed with raising money from special-interest groups, State Senator Bill Schluter, a Republican, said yesterday that he would run for governor as an independent to attack ''the cancer of campaign finance abuse.'' Mr. Schluter has represented Warren County and parts of Mercer and Hunterdon Counties since 1991. David M. Halbfinger (NYT)

title: Article 2001051893563145593 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Northwest Follows Discount Fare in Coach With One in First Class
description: Northwest Airlines introduced a first-class air fare this week that was 50 percent cheaper than its previous first-class fares in the United States and required a 14-day advance purchase.

title: Through the Eyes of the Beholder
description: ''Blur,'' a harmless new play by Melanie Marnich, is about a 17-year-old girl who, at a sad Thanksgiving dinner with her dotty mother, discovers that she can't see her feet. This is the sudden onset of a rare eye disease that seriously compromises her vision and threatens to leave her entirely blind.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose as a rally in Japanese stocks increased demand for the currency among international investors. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.56 yen, down from 123.54 yen on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORNSTON, SIDGE
description: ORNSTON-Sidge. Our dear friend for over 35 years. We will miss your piercing intelligence, humor and loyalty. Your support during our most difficult hour will never be forgotten. The Buckler Family

title: Addenda: Management Changes at Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam Inc. unit of the WPP Group , made several changes in executive management yesterday.

title: Role of U.S. Companies in Colombia Is Questioned
description: Their presence grew as Colombia's drug war intensified in the 1990's, with the United States hiring American pilots, radar operators, former Army Special Forces trainers and other former military personnel to carry out important missions.

title: Sports of The Times; Let Somebody Else Play These Games
description: GOT to thinking about the Olympics the other day. Had plenty of time to think, since I was trying to merge my car onto West 43rd Street.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in House & Home yesterday about an Oregon measure granting adoptees access to information about their birthparents misstated the title of a book that tracked the adoption rights movement. It is ''Adoption Nation,'' by Adam Pertman (Basic Books), not ''Adopted Nation.''

title: 2 Finalists Are Left In Jiffy Lube Review
description: Jiffy Lube International, part of the Pennzoil-Quaker State Company, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its account to two agencies from four. Billings were estimated at $20 million. The account had been handled for one year by the Richards Group in Dallas, which did not take part in the review.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COOPER, ABRAHAM
description: COOPER-Abraham. Born May 18, 1919. K.I.A. France, July, 1944. Forever, your loving sister, Estelle.

title: Jerome Brody, 78, Is Dead; Guided Elegant Restaurants
description: Jerome Brody, who transformed the restaurant culture of New York as operator of a series of glittering restaurants like the Four Seasons, the Rainbow Room, Gallagher's Steak House and the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Terminal, died on Tuesday at his home in Miami. He was 78.

title: Quietly, a Russian Oil Producer Tries to Consolidate Its Holdings
description: The Tyumen Oil Company, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer, is pushing ahead with a plan to streamline its assets, one of the industry's last and quietest corporate revampings.

title: Nissan's Head Says Revival Is a Success
description: Like a triumphant general reporting a sweeping victory, the president of Nissan Motor, Carlos Ghosn, announced his company's annual profits today and declared his 19-month revival plan for the company a great success.

title: As Carter Goes, So Do the Raptors
description: Billy King, the 76ers' general manager, was all smiles after Philadelphia's 121-88 demolition of the Toronto Raptors on Wednesday night, and joked after today's practice about a phone call he had just received from a friend.

title: Shared Interests Bring Out Protective Feelings of Residents at a Redistricting Hearing
description: New Yorkers got their first chance yesterday to wax creative about what does and does not make up their community. They hoped that the state legislators sponsoring a public hearing in lower Manhattan would take their testimony to heart in the high-stakes, rough-and-tumble battle to reconfigure Congressional and state legislative districts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bridge Path To Open
description: A new mile-long pedestrian and bicycle path on the Manhattan Bridge is scheduled to open June 25. The City Department of Transportation is completing the path, which runs on the south side of the bridge. When it first opened in the early 1900's, the bridge had north and south paths. They were closed in the 1960's, said a spokeswoman for a bicycling advocacy organization. Barbara Stewart (NYT)

title: AMTRAN SHARES RISE 57% ON NEWS OF CHAIRMAN'S OFFER
description: Amtran Inc. said yesterday that its chairman and majority shareholder, J. George Mikelsons, offered $21 a share to buy the rest of the company and take it private, setting off a 57 percent rise in its share price. Amtran, the parent of American Trans Air, said that a special board committee would consider the offer. Mr. Mikelsons, who founded Amtran, owns about 72 percent of the company's outstanding stock, a spokeswoman said. The carrier provides service from Chicago and Indianapolis to 30 destinations and has a fleet of 56 aircraft. The offer values the company at $239 million, based on 11.4 million outstanding shares. Amtran's stock rose $7.15, to $19.75 a share.

title: Big Car-Theft Empire Broken Up, Police Say
description: For the last year, police investigators regularly tried to visit Ernest Varacalli at what they called the headquarters of his auto theft empire in Brooklyn. Each time, he met them at the door and told them the business was shut for renovations.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Strike Paralyzes Athens
description: Furious at the government's plan to reform the troubled state pension system, labor unions led thousands of protesters to the streets of Athens in a huge strike that froze buses, taxis and the subway, and also closed government agencies and newspaper offices. Rail, air and shipping services were severely restricted, and radio and television stations cut off their programming. Unions see the plan as an effort to cut benefits and increase workers' contributions, and demand that the government bail out the system. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Patient's Wife Found Slain
description: A Brooklyn man who had checked into a psychiatric hospital on Wednesday told his doctor yesterday that the authorities should check on his wife, because the last time he saw her, she was ''laying in a pool of blood,'' officials said.

title: Local Party Aid In Torricelli Bid Under Scrutiny
description: Until 1996, the Bergen County Democratic Organization was a fairly modest New Jersey political operation. Its money came mostly from small donations by county workers and local businesses, and it spent carefully to help candidates for offices like freeholder and sheriff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALINSON, DANIEL
description: GALINSON-Daniel. Died peacefully on May 18 at the age of 72. Cause of death was kidney cancer. Survived by his wife Rosalind, his children Paul and Lisa Galinson, Susan Zamanian. Grandchildren Laura, Melissa, Melanie, Marissa, Maya, Peyton and Benjamin. Services will be held Sunday 12:30 at I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: In His Return, Leiter Takes Control in the Clubhouse and on the Mound
description: After 27 agonizing days of watching helplessly as the Mets faded, Al Leiter got to place a Bruce Springsteen compact disc in the stereo yesterday because the starting pitcher gets to choose the music in the clubhouse. Leiter was finally back to being a starter, and he smiled as he adjusted the volume control and the beginning strains of ''Thunder Road'' filled the air around him.

title: Judge in Alabama Imposes Deadline on Prison System
description: In a strongly worded ruling, an Alabama judge gave the state prison system exactly one month today to find room for nearly 2,000 inmates who are now crowded into county jails across the state.

title: Are Graduate Students Workers?
description: Last year, in a dramatic reversal, the National Labor Relations Board held that graduate teaching assistants at New York University are ''employees'' and affirmed their right to form a union and to bargain collectively with the university.

title: How Crit Finally Won Out Over Lit
description: W. W. Norton & Company, the maker of literary canons, the publisher of numerous anthologies and critical editions of masterworks, is about to release a self-deconstructing bombshell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, ALTON M. (''AL'')
description: JOHNSON-Alton M. (''Al''). Born October 18, 1928 in Calumet, IL. Died peacefully May 16, 2001, Lenox Hill Hospital, New York City of Asbestosis. Enlisted in U.S. Marine Corps 1944-1949, and U.S. Air Force 1949-1969. Served in Pacific Theater of WWII, The German Army of Occupation, The Korean War and Viet Nam. Recipient of numerous decorations including Bronze Stars & Purple Hearts. National Service Manager, Cavitron Electronics, 1969-1979. Much beloved by his life companion, Louise S. Horowitz, sister Judy Summers, nephew Leo Shanks, step children Marilyn, Roger and Diana Horowitz, & grandchildren Jason Horowitz, Benjamin Shanks and April Lee Shanks. Memorial service will be held Sunday, May 20th, 2 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: White Slate For Democrats In New District
description: Two weeks after New Jersey's Democratic leaders convinced the courts that their legislative redistricting plan would not hurt black candidates' chances of getting elected, the party is embroiled in a bitter internal fight over the absence of minorities on its leadership's ticket for the primary in a key new district here.

title: Man Is Sentenced to 5 Years In Attacks in Central Park
description: The last man convicted of attacking women in Central Park last summer after the National Puerto Rican Day Parade was sentenced to five years yesterday, the longest prison term resulting from the melee.

title: Article 2001051990146852086 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a proposal by Britain and the United States to lift the 11-year ban on international trade with Iraq misstated the reason for the departure of international inspectors there in 1998. It occurred -- that December, before the United States and Britain began bombing raids on Iraq -- because the United Nations feared that they might be harmed or taken hostage. They were not expelled.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Delay Over For Tobacco Payments
description: The state received its first payment under the 1998 national tobacco settlement after legal challenges from groups seeking a share were dismissed. Missouri is the last state to get money in the settlement, which awarded $206 billion to 46 states for Medicaid money spent treating diseases related to smoking. The City of St. Louis, a hospital and several groups had made claims on Missouri's share, but the State Supreme Court dismissed those claims in December. The state expects to receive $4.5 billion over 25 years. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Tiny Giant Bailey Casts Shadow on the Preakness
description: Over the past three days, he has worn out the remote control of his videocassette recorder while watching a tape of the Kentucky Derby in an attempt to gain insight into how to beat Monarchos in the 126th running of the Preakness Stakes. He has stopped and started on isolation angles of the steel-gray Derby winner, and has zeroed in on his own mount in Saturday's race, the Derby's third-place finisher, Congaree.

title: Tax Analysts See Big Gains For Top 1% Of Taxpayers
description: Under the tax cut plans now moving through Congress, the tax breaks for the wealthiest Americans gain value over time while most of the breaks for everyone else lose value, according to both supporters and critics of these plans.

title: Two Tastes of Texas With Distinctive Flavors on One Stage
description: Two Texas songwriters shared a bill at the Village Underground on Tuesday night, one reflecting on a wild past, the other taking a hard-nosed look at the present.

title: Hyundai Engineering Approves Debt Plan
description: Hyundai Engineering and Construction, the parent company of the giant Hyundai conglomerate, moved a crucial step closer to total separation from the group today by approving a plan to swap equity for $1.08 billion of its debts.

title: The Art Trade Cleans Up Its Act
description: This is not the best of times for auction houses. Sir Anthony Tennant, chairman of Christie's in the early 1990s, and Alfred Taubman, chairman of Sotheby's until he resigned last year, were indicted earlier this month for price fixing. Diana D. Brooks, chief executive of Sotheby's until she resigned along with Mr. Taubman, has pleaded guilty to a similar charge. It does seem to be a dirty business.

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTODESK STOCK FALLS 11% AFTER WARNING ON PROFIT
description: Autodesk Inc.'s shares fell 11 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of design software for architects, said its second-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates. The shares fell $4.02, to $33.60. Autodesk is selling less to large corporate customers in the United States and Europe, who have reduced spending because of the slowing economy, said Steve Cakebread, Autodesk's chief financial officer. Some are waiting for new products to be released, he said. The company, which is based in San Rafael, Calif., said late Thursday that it expected earnings, excluding certain charges, of 40 cents to 50 cents a share for the quarter ending in July, below the 56 cents expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Shares of Software Company Slide After Trading Resumes
description: Shares of the AremisSoft Corporation skidded yesterday after the company's stock began trading for the first time following articles critical of it in TheStreet.com and The New York Times.

title: Reno Considers a Race
description: Janet Reno, the often embattled attorney general of the Clinton administration, said she was seriously considering running for governor of Florida next year, which could pit her against the Republican incumbent, Jeb Bush, the brother of President Bush.

title: Juror in Bombings Case Asks for a Recess, Outside
description: The jury in the embassy bombings trial was sent home yesterday without reaching a verdict, but not before one juror asked the judge for a bit of fresh air.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Quiet Birthday, With A Treat
description: Pope John Paul II turned 81 yesterday without fanfare, spending a routine day at the Vatican that included meetings with new ambassadors, Pakistani bishops and an audience for 120 members of the European Automobile Manufacturers Association. The pope, who will preside over a gathering of cardinals next week, did receive a birthday torte at a small lunch with Vatican aides.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the performance of fourth graders on a statewide reading test misstated the comparison between New York City pupils and those in the state's other large cities. While New York indeed outperformed Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, its scores were lower than those in Yonkers.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Mitsubishi
description: The Japanese automobile manufacturer Mitsubishi Motors reported its worst loss ever for the year ended March 31. A huge recall, a cover-up scandal and charges arising from restructuring contributed to 278 billion yen ($2.3 billion) in net losses for the year while sales fell 2 percent, to 3.28 trillion yen. A 15 percent decline in vehicle sales at home was offset by improved sales overseas. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEXT LEVEL COMMUNICATIONS INC., Rohnert Park, Calif., a provider of broadband access systems, said it would receive a two-year, $60 million loan from Motorola Inc., Schaumburg, Ill., a wireless technology giant and major shareholder.

title: Officer Found Liable in Death Of a Cyclist
description: A federal jury in Manhattan found a police officer liable for damages in an incident involving a cyclist who died in 1998 after the officer threw his radio at the man and fractured his skull.

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: California Utility Says Gas Company in State Inflated Prices
description: In the effort to determine what or who -- is at fault for soaring natural gas prices in California, Southern California Edison, one of the chief finger-pointers, is now also blaming the Southern California Gas Company for helping drive up prices.

title: More Counseling For Rangers' Fleury
description: Rangers forward Theo Fleury has completed his stay in a rehabilitation center and will spend most of the summer at a center in the Southwest undergoing further counseling, a person with knowledge of Fleury's situation said yesterday.

title: City Fined on Failing to Shelter AIDS Patients
description: A state judge has fined the Giuliani administration for violating a court order requiring the city to provide prompt and proper shelter for homeless people with AIDS.

title: Article 2001051991334606727 -- No Title
Anita Moore, 51, Singer in Ellington's Band
description: Anita Moore, who sang with Duke Ellington in the early 1970's in his last years and later with Mercer Ellington's band, died on April 28 in Houston. She was 51 and lived in Houston.

title: Religion Journal: Catholic Prelates Press Effort Against Execution
description: When federal officials postponed the execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, the Oklahoma City bomber, last week, they also allowed more time for death penalty opponents, particularly some prominent religious leaders, to state their case.

title: Carmencita Romero, 87, Dancer, Choreographer and Film Actress
description: Carmencita Romero, who performed with Katherine Dunham in her first company, the Negro Dance Group, in the mid-1930's, died on May 6 at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in Manhattan.

title: Devils Seem Determined To Win This Game 4
description: As thoroughly impressive as the Devils looked in their 3-0 dismantling of the Pittsburgh Penguins on Thursday night, there is precedent for a letdown in Game 4.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Times have changed. None of the dealers in the Bronx are smoking joints and discussing Nietzsche.''

title: If Richer Isn't Happier, What Is?
description: One of the most often-repeated parts of the Declaration of Independence may also be one of the least influential. People march in Washington protesting various assaults against the first two unalienable rights, life and liberty. The third, however, rarely merits mention beyond the simple recitation of the Declaration's most famous sentence.

title: An Endplay Makes a Slam, But the Victory Was in Vain
description: One of the most spectacular turnarounds in New York bridge history occurred two weeks ago in the semifinal of the Grand National Teams. With 14 deals left, Glenn Milgrim, Jared Lilienstein, Chris Willenken, Aaron Silverstein, Bob Blanchard and Sam Lev trailed by 47 imps against a group led by Brady Richter, yet snatched a 5-imp victory.

title: The Settlement Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Facing Murder Charge in Classmate's Death, Hofstra Student Is Held on Suicide Watch
description: The Hofstra University student charged in the murder and mutilation of a classmate was under suicide watch in a jail psychiatric ward today as his lawyer said he was busy preparing a psychiatric defense.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Role For Governor's Spouse
description: Another sex stereotype has fallen in Massachusetts. Jane M. Swift gave birth to twins this week, a month after becoming the first woman to govern the state, and now her husband, Charles Hunt, has agreed to a role traditionally given to the state's first lady. Mr. Hunt, a stay-at-home father, will be president of the Doric Dames, a group of historically minded women -- and a few men -- known mainly for giving tours of the State House and compiling local recipes. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: The Rural Life; New Woods
description: Last weekend, I woke up at 4 in the morning to the smell of rain. Perhaps it was a dream scent. Perhaps a few drops really fell, enough to remind me that the smell of rain is the catalyzed smell of the local earth and everything on it. By the time I got up for good, the ground was as dry as it was when I went to bed the night before, a month dry, after a month without any precipitation. Dust rises from the horses' hooves when they run across the pasture. Manure dries the way it does in Colorado, to half its weight, then half of that in a day or two. A storm gathered later that afternoon, portentous clouds, and then, as a neighbor with a computerized weather station reported, there came nine-hundredths of an inch, just enough to leaven the upper layer of dust. We have what might be called a big-gulp rain gauge, and it registered no such thing.

title: Hartford's Sex-Offender Registry Shut Down After Judge's Order
description: State officials shut down Connecticut's online sex-offender registry this morning, complying with an permanent order from a federal judge who had ruled that the state's method of placing people on it was unconstitutional.

title: Bush Shows His Green Side to Sell Agenda
description: To sign his executive orders speeding federal approval of energy projects around the country, President Bush came to a Depression-era hydroelectric station today that stretches across the Susquehanna River and marveled at the ''fish lift'' that now enables shad to take an elevator ride over the huge dam to their spawning grounds.

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: Reno Says She Is Considering Race for Governor of Florida
description: Former Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she was considering running for governor of Florida next year when President Bush's brother Jeb Bush is up for re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KRAMER, DR. ALAN D.
description: KRAMER-Dr. Alan D. Died May 19, 2000. It has been a hard year without you. We think of you every day. Love, Joyce and Irv

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Wednesday about the animated feature ''Shrek'' misidentified a screenwriter. He is Roger S. H. Schulman, as shown in the list of credits; John Powell wrote some of the music.

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil, Fearful of Blackouts, Orders 20% Cut in Electricity
description: Faced with a rapidly worsening energy crisis that threatens to cripple Latin America's largest economy, the government ordered consumers and businesses today to cut electricity consumption by 20 percent or prepare for California-style blackouts.

title: Violent Crimes Undercut Marijuana's Mellow Image
description: Police officials in New York City, who spent years battling a crack scourge that sent the murder rate soaring, say they are now seeing increasing violence among dealers of marijuana, a drug that they say no longer fits its laid-back image.

title: What Prosecutors Can't Hold Back
description: The debacle of missing files in the Timothy McVeigh case has suddenly turned the public's eye on the rule that prosecutors must disclose exculpatory evidence to the defense. Yet the rule is hardly new, and prosecutors' occasional (or perhaps frequent) failures to comply are as old as the rule.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education Page on Wednesday about the strategy of breaking up low-performing high schools into smaller ones misspelled the name of a high school on the Upper East Side where the strategy was used. It is Julia Richman High School, not Richmond.

title: French Oil Executive Calls Commissions Routine
description: A former head of France's state-owned oil company, now on trial for corruption, has told two French newspapers that paying millions of dollars a year in ''secret commissions'' was a routine part of his job and had the approval of the Elyse Palace.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bridgestone Disputes Need For a Broader Tire Recall

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: Borough Divided Over Plan to Raze Woods for Ball Fields
description: New York City's plan to clear 1,500 trees and other vegetation from a Staten Island park to build ball fields has split residents, pitting the need for new recreation space against the the desire to preserve increasingly scarce woodlands.

title: Beleaguered Penguins Begin Hunt for Solutions
description: After losing to the Devils, 3-0, Thursday night, the Penguins tried to find a few fighting words today. But down by 2-1 to the defending Stanley Cup champion Devils in the Eastern Conference finals, Pittsburgh sounded more like a team searching aimlessly for some urgency, some energy, some goals and, mostly, some answers.

title: VERISIGN WINS INTERNET ADDRESS CONTRACT
description: The Commerce Department approved a new contract yesterday between the organization that oversees the Internet's address system and VeriSign Inc., the company that once held a monopoly over the system. The new contract, negotiated by VeriSign and the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, allows VeriSign to maintain control over the registry database for dot-com addresses through 2007. VeriSign will not be required to sell its domain name registration business, a provision that has been criticized for allowing VeriSign to retain a privileged position. VeriSign also agreed to relinquish control over the dot-net registry in 2005, or earlier if criteria indicating competition in the market are not met. Susan Stellin

description: To the Editor:

title: Bush and Putin Agree to Meet in Slovenia
description: President Bush and Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, will meet for the first time in Slovenia on June 16 at the end of a European trip by Mr. Bush, the White House said today.

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: Bargain Braiders Battle for Heads; Hair Stylists From Africa Arrive, Driving Down Prices
description: Two decades ago, a black American looking to get her hair braided into a head of plaits thinner than a knitting needle could spend $100. It could, after all, take up to 12 hours to get the job done.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROMAN, JOSEPH
description: ROMAN-Joseph. Dear Joe, thank you for the many wonderful years you were an important part of our lives. We will never forget how fortunate we are. Ted and Bill

title: Solicitor General's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Highs then Lows For Notre Dame
description: The junior Jason Bush pitched a seven-hitter as Virginia Tech defeated Notre Dame, 5-2, to eliminate the top-seeded Irish in the double-elimination Big East tournament.

title: Sky Watch: A Friend to Stargazer and Navigator
description: At chart time, the stars of the Big Dipper are almost directly overhead. Here are seven bright stars, which render a convincing tin dipper with its handle bent downward.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: Nearly 100 Migrants Die In Desert
description: The bodies of at least 93 African migrants were found in the Sahara in southern Libya near the Niger border, according to the state news agency. Crossing the Sahara is one of the most popular and dangerous smuggling routes for economic migrants from West and Central Africa, who want to work in Libya or use it as a springboard to Europe. They travel in old, overloaded trucks that often break down during the long journey through the desert.

title: Ah, the Good Old Days, Even Those That Were Pretty Awful
description: Memory, Svetlana Boym points out in this remarkable book, is born of trauma. The legend is that the Greek poet Simonides attended a banquet where he sang lyrical hymns to the gods and his host. He was called away by a mysterious messenger, but no sooner had he left than the roof collapsed. The guests were so mangled under the ruins that their bodies could not even be identified. But Simonides was able to recall where each of the many guests had been sitting; he could reconstruct the living world in the face of death's disorder.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Takeover Cleared
description: Antitrust regulators, who have rejected previous airline mergers, gave Qantas Airways, the country's largest airline, permission to take over the operations of a bankrupt discount competitor, Impulse Airlines, on condition that Qantas ease its rivals' access to takeoff and landing slots during peak hours in Sydney. Air New Zealand, owner of Qantas's largest competitor, Ansett Australia, may challenge the deal anyway, its chief executive, Gary Toomey, said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Race-Based Crime Statistics To Be Released by the City
description: Amid charges that the New York Police Department singles out minorities for searches on the street, the Giuliani administration said yesterday that it would begin releasing monthly statistics showing the race of crime victims, suspects, people who are stopped and frisked, and those who are arrested.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, RUTH
description: GREENBERG-Ruth. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Martin and Lisa, Edward and Jeannette and Marcia and Mickey Lyons. Cherished grandmother of Diana, Garen, Bradley and Alexis, and three great grandchildren. Dear sister of Harry Weiss and Sylvia Subin. Services 12 noon Sunday, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Senate Campaign Is Ruled Out
description: Representative Robert E. Cramer, a conservative Alabama Democrat, has announced that he will not challenge Senator Jeff Sessions, a first-term Republican. ''At this time I can best serve Alabama by remaining in the Congress,'' said Mr. Cramer, who has represented a north Alabama district for five terms.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Asylum For Vietnamese Refugees
description: The United Nations high commissioner for refugees said Cambodia had agreed to give temporary asylum to hill tribe people fleeing central Vietnam. The Vietnamese government had been demanding that they be sent back, and United Nations officials feared that some were forced to return to an uncertain fate. Several hundred of the hill tribe people, known as Montagnards, fled Vietnam in recent months after the government put down protests and stationed more troops in hill communities to keep order.

title: An Honor Too Long Delayed
description: How to honor our nation's heroes is always a contentious subject. It defines us as a people -- who we are, who we owe. Everyone has an opinion, passionately held and expressed. We have gone through a long process in deciding how and where to build a memorial to the men and women who fought and won the Second World War. All those who wished to be heard on the subject have been heard. If we don't get the memorial built soon, as Bob Dole warns, the only World War II veteran around to appreciate it will be Senator Strom Thurmond.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Settlement Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: that typing cockroach strikes again, poetically
description: Mehitabel, an alley cat living in New York, says she was Cleopatra in a past life. But when her pal Archy the cockroach asks her about Marc Antony and Julius Caesar, she's never heard of them. Doesn't matter. Mehitabel is the feline equivalent of a spunky dame with a heart of gold (''I ain't vindictive, Archy. I don't hold grudges. No lady does.''), and you've got to love her.

title: Gift Set for Anniversary of Wendy's Slayings
description: The new owner of the former Wendy's building in Flushing, Queens, will donate $18,000 to the Queens Borough Public Library branch in Flushing on Thursday to mark the one-year anniversary of the killing of five workers at the fast-food restaurant.

title: Yanks Pound Mariners To End Four-Game Skid
description: It is probably impossible to define precisely what has driven the Yankees the past six years, anger or fear of failure or a greedy desire to win. But once they start to lose games, fray and unravel, it's as if an automatic five-alarm internal response system goes off, and the Yankees retrench and react.

title: Home of Ousted Hale House Leader Searched
description: The state attorney general's office executed a search warrant on Thursday evening at the home of Dr. Lorraine E. Hale in Scarsdale, N.Y., hours after she was ousted from the presidency of Hale House, the nationally known children's shelter in Harlem, a lawyer for Dr. Hale said.

title: Albany's Spring Freeze
description: New York's State Legislature stands still these days, 200 lawmakers on pause while their three leaders circle one another warily. The issue, of course, is the budget, which is late as usual. But even Albany's veterans are finding this year's delay unsettling. Because the state's byzantine education formulas need fixing, and because a federal court order requires more support for New York City schools than upstate legislators want to provide, the budget is stalled, and other legislation is stacked up behind it. The main activity is the scapegoating and finger-pointing over who exactly is responsible for this latest legislative malfunctioning.

title: World Briefing
description: AMERICAS
