description: More Than a Palmtop, Not Quite a PC

title: Push for Oil Prompts Review of Pollution Law
description: At least half of the country's 152 oil refineries are believed to be violating air-pollution laws, federal officials say, but with the refineries stretched near capacity, the Bush administration is debating how hard to crack down.

title: NAKED CAPITALISTS
description: Pornography takes in $10 billion a year, and the men and women who create it are not the gold-chained lechers of days gone by. A report by Frank Rich in The Times Magazine.

title: Hong Kong Slaughters Chickens to Halt Spread of Flu Virus
description: With chickens dying by the hundreds and public alarm mounting, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 1.2 million chickens and other poultry to halt the spread of a deadly flu virus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, GEORGE A.
description: FOX-George A. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Cooper Union mourn the passing of our treasured friend, Chairman Emeritus, benefactor and alumnus (Civil Engineering 1940), George A. Fox. He first served as president of his class, deepening his relationship with The Cooper Union over 60 years. He served as Chairman of the Board of Trustees from 1987-1995, and as a member since 1975. He is a past president of the Alumni Association and recepient of Cooper's Alumnus of the Year award and a Presidential Citation in Engineering. Awarded Cooper Union's Builder of the City Award in 1996 for his lifetime achievements and contributions to New York City and his profession, his friendship and presence at Cooper is a great loss. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Cecily, and to his children, and his grandchildren. A service will be held on Sunday, May 20, 2001 at 1 PM in The Great Hall at Cooper Union, East 7th Street at 3rd Avenue. Robert A. Bernhard, Chairman Board of Trustees Dr. George Campbell, Jr. President, The Cooper Union

title: The Energy Plan: Points of Light, and Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Tries to Broker Compromise on Nomination
description: Bush White House officials moved swiftly today to save the nomination of Theodore B. Olson to be solicitor general, pressing Republicans in the Senate to offer concessions to the Democrats.

title: AOL TIME WARNER AGREES TO ACQUIRE INFOINTERACTIVE
description: AOL Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy InfoInterActive Inc. of Canada for $28.2 million to gain software that alerts people that they have a phone call while they are on the Internet. AOL Time Warner, based in New York, will pay 2.18 Canadian dollars ($1.42) for each InfoInterActive share, the company said. The price is a 45 percent premium to Thursday's closing share price of 1.50 Canadian dollars. InfoInterActive, based in Bedford, Nova Scotia, provides a service to phone companies known as Internet Call Manager. Its customers include Verizon Communications Inc.

title: After Years of Avoiding Yale, Bush Renews Old School Ties
description: Three years ago, when Yale University held the 30th reunion for the class of 1968, George W. Bush was conspicuously absent.

title: S.I. Republicans Pick Their Man, but He's Not in G.O.P.
description: Three months ago, Assemblyman Robert A. Straniere announced his candidacy for Staten Island borough president, news that was greeted by the enthusiastic support of the firmament of local Republican Party leaders.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Raising The Sunken Sub
description: Russia announced plans to raise the nuclear submarine Kursk from the floor of the Barents Sea in an operation by a Dutch salvage company than would run from mid-July to mid-September, Deputy Prime Minister Ilya I. Klebanov said. Divers will cut away the front section of the submarine, which was destroyed on Aug. 2 by a still unexplained internal explosion. All 118 crewmen died. Hydraulic lifts on a barge will hoist the submarine, and the vessels will be towed 60 miles to shallower waters.

title: Article 2001051992774718070 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Offense Taken To Extremes On Our Behalf
description: NEW YORKERS love to brag about how they can put up with anything. Fortunately, the city is blessed with a cadre of vigilant people who don't buy that guff. These are the men and women who stand guard for the rest of us, ferreting out works of art so offensive to one group or another that they cry out for banishment.

title: Susan Stroman A 3-Time Winner
description: Susan Stroman is the winner of the 2001 T.D.F. Astaire Award for choreography for ''The Producers,'' with best-dancer awards going to Kate Levering and Michael Arnold for ''42nd Street.''

title: Article 2001051991750783254 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: St. John's Athletic Director to Leave for Sports Marketing Job
description: St. John's has seemingly lived the past year hoping that it would not lose its men's basketball coach, Mike Jarvis, to a professional team. Yesterday, the school lost its highest-ranking member of the athletic department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURDING, MARGARET A. (PEG)
description: BURDING-Margaret A. (Peg), 57. Died in Orlando, FL May 15, 2001, after a short illness. Originally from Bronxville, New York, she graduated from Colby College. She was a Sales Promotion Specialist spending most of her career in the New York metropolitan area with consumer product companies, Sales Promotion agencies and 16 years with T.J. Lipton. She joined Tupperware Inc. in Orlando in 1994, followed by Try-Foods, and subsequently ran her own sales promotion agency. She was predeceased by her husband, Frank O'Connor and is survived by her sister Barbara B. Kemp of New York City, a brother William D. Burding of Scottsdale, Arizona, four nieces and nephews, eight grandnieces and nephews and her fiance James P. McCaffrey of Orlando. A Memorial service will be held at the Dutch Reformed Church, Pondfield Road, Bronxville, New York at 4:00 P.M. on June 15, 2001. In lieu of flowers her family request that contributions made to Leukemia Research, C/O of the Society of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, 1233 York Ave., N Y, New York 10021.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 11 about Nikos Giorgiades Sampson, who was briefly the president of Cyrpus after a military coup in 1974, misstated his date of birth. It was Dec. 16, 1934, not 1935.

description: Cyber Law Journal: Hacker Gadfly at Center of New Suit

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Kabila Meets U.N. Delegation
description: President Joseph Kabila told visiting members of the United Nations Security Council that negotiations, not further fighting, would end the nearly three-year war in his country. But he reportedly emphasized that a peace accord backed by the United Nations could not be carried out unless troops from Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi left Congo.

title: Toward an AIDS Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about political contributions in the New York mayoral campaign from real estate partnerships associated with Charles J. Kushner, a New Jersey developer, referred incorrectly in some copies to the total of such donations last June to City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. It was $10,000, not $10.

title: Man Convicted in '99 Murder Of Social Worker From Kansas
description: A 28-year-old man was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday in the death of Amy Watkins, the graduate student who was fatally stabbed during a botched robbery as she walked from the subway to her Brooklyn apartment in March 1999.

title: Shareholders Vote to Make De Beers Private Concern
description: Almost unanimously, shareholders approved a sweetened bid today to turn De Beers, the colossus of the world's diamond trade, into a private company with fewer formal obligations to report on its business.

title: Lucent and Alcatel Said to Re-assess Possible Deal
description: Critical reaction yesterday from investors about Alcatel's plan to acquire Lucent Technologies prompted the two communications equipment companies to consider re-evaluating the terms of a possible merger, executives close to the talks said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Tibetans Accused Of Plot
description: The Chinese police have arrested two Tibetan men whom they accuse of plotting a public immolation in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, under orders from the exiled Dalai Lama. The New China News Agency said the men had sneaked into Tibet from Nepal and that one, a former monk, planned to burn himself in front of Lhasa's main temple while the other videotaped the act to publicize their cause abroad. A spokesman for the Dalai Lama's government in exile said that the charges were false and that the Dalai opposes violence and suicide. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Ralph Miller, 82, a Hall of Fame Coach
description: Ralph Miller, who learned basketball from the pioneers of the game and went on to become a highly successful head coach at major colleges for 38 years, died Tuesday at his home in Black Butte Ranch near Bend, Ore. He was 82.

title: Gods and Goddesses, At It Again
description: Dance Brazil offered three ambitious premieres at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. Each of these works by the New York company sought to express some aspect of Brazil's cultural heritage in a fresh, contemporary manner. Although the experiments were not totally successful, the program held the attention, thanks to the dancers' energy.

title: Stocks Climb; Gold Prices Set 11-Month High
description: Stocks moved slightly higher yesterday, finishing a positive week highlighted by a big rally on Wednesday, the day after the Federal Reserve made its fifth half-point rate cut of the year. And a new public offering of an electronic stock market, Instinet, went well.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST</b

title: Energy Crisis Levels California Political Playing Field
description: Six months ago, there were few states so dominated by a single party and a single politician as California. Gov. Gray Davis and the Democrats controlled the government to such a degree that the demoralized Republicans could only nod quietly in approval when Mr. Davis dictated that everyone support his top three priorities, all of them, as he liked to say, education.

title: Georgi Shakhnazarov Dies; Soviet Propagandist Was 77
description: Georgi K. Shakhnazarov, a propagandist and political scientist of the Soviet era who rose to become a pro-reform assistant to Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the final years of the Soviet Union, died on Tuesday. He was 77.

title: Pavin Leads Colonial By a Stroke After a 64
description: Corey Pavin seems ready to end his five-year slump.

title: UConn's Thomas Wins Decathlon
description: William Thomas, a freshman at Connecticut, won 4 of the 10 events outright and scored 7,363 points to win the decathlon yesterday, the first final in the 125th annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America championships in Princeton, N.J.

title: Delhi Journal; Beware Monkey-Man, Scourge of the Gullible
description: In teeming narrow lanes where rumors spread like a contagion, bands of excited young men brandished tridents, bamboo poles and iron rods in the wee hours this morning, ready to battle an elusive apparition known as the monkey-man, which has terrorized large swaths of this sprawling metropolis for the last week.

title: Those Postwar Anti-Verities, So Thorny and So European
description: American music is often at the heart of the New York New Music Ensemble's programs, but on Monday evening the group turned its gaze on the more rigorous side of the postwar European repertory. It was probably fitting that Pierre Boulez had pride of place, given the degree to which his ideas about sound and compositional organization influenced some if not all of the other composers in the concert, called ''Over There: European Music.''

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Inaugural Message For Berlusconi
description: Giving Silvio Berlusconi, the conservative prime minister-elect, a taste of conflicts to come, 65,000 metalworkers took to the streets in major industrial cities to protest a wage increase offer that is less than the 3.1 percent inflation rate. Their contract expired in December and negotiations resumed in February. Protesters held banners saying, ''Comrade Berlusconi, we've done our part, now you sign the contract.'' Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Browser column of Circuits on Thursday for an online chat with Anita Shreve, the author of ''The Pilot's Wife,'' misstated the date. The chat, on www.ipublish .com, will be at 7 p.m. on May 29, not this Tuesday.

title: National News Briefs | West: California: DNA Test Set In 1960'S Killings
description: More than 30 years after the ''Zodiac'' serial killings in the San Francisco Bay area, the authorities are trying to match DNA from the killer's saliva to a sample from a leading suspect in the case. The San Francisco Examiner reported that the saliva came from the envelopes of letters to local newspapers providing details of the crimes. The suspect is Arthur Leigh Allen, a former teacher who died in 1992. The Zodiac killer claimed 37 killings; officials positively linked the killer to 6. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: Hoping to Mirror Jones, Trachsel Goes to Minors
description: Steve Trachsel said he was shocked when he heard what the Mets wanted to do with him after Thursday night's game. He knew there might be repercussions for his abysmal start that night and also for his season-long struggles, but he thought he might be skipped in the rotation or moved to the bullpen. He never expected to be asked to accept a minor league assignment.

title: Remembering A Good Student And a Good Son
description: On the day that Max Kolb was mourned and buried here, at a private service at Temple Emanuel, friends and relatives spoke glowingly not only of an exemplary young man but also of the exemplary, if unconventional, family that produced him.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Minority Leader Will Run For Mayor
description: The State House minority leader, Kwame Kilpatrick, said he would run for mayor of Detroit. Mr. Kilpatrick, 30, a Democrat known for aggressive fund-raising, is the state's first black House minority leader. He was elected in 1996 and is in his third term. He faces at least four opponents to succeed Mayor Dennis Archer, who announced in April that he would not seek a third term. The City Council president, Gil Hill, 69, is considered an early front-runner.

title: Away From Haiti, Discovering the Politics of the Possible
description: AS a child, Josaphat Celestin never thought much about voting, much less becoming a politician. In his native Haiti, he said, the stakes were too high for anyone on the losing side of a political fight.

title: White House Vandalism Caper Was Overblown, a Report Finds
description: Accounts that departing Clinton administration officials destroyed office equipment and committed other acts of vandalism in the White House during the presidential transition were significantly overblown, a manager at the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said today.

title: Temporary Jobs Have Become the Victims of a Slow Market
description: For most of the last three years, the dozens of temporary-employment agencies in this city have had a problem. They could not find enough qualified workers for the openings that local companies needed to fill.

title: Bleak Statistics Tarnish Nevada's Glitter
description: In this town of neon rainbows, where money gushes, time stands still and dreams endure despite the obvious odds, it is easy enough to think of Nevada as an adult version of Oz, and Las Vegas as its glittering Emerald City. But statistical realities in the nation's fastest-growing state are sepia-toned and stark.

title: Will O'Neal Eclipse Spurs' Twin Towers?
description: They have two of the premier big men in the game, pro basketball's best record and home-court advantage. The San Antonio Spurs should be trumpeting their dominance and the chance to win their second title in three years, but they awkwardly shuffle around the Alamodome, answering the daily inquiry: ''How can you possibly stop Kobe and Shaq?''

title: Peruvians Considering Vote for 'None of the Above'
description: Mari Arredondo, a street vendor of fried bananas and sweets, said she once thrilled at the sight of Alejandro Toledo as he campaigned for president dressed as an Indian and embracing the Andean customs of her childhood.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROAD, MONROE MAXIMILIAN, MD
description: BROAD-Monroe Maximilian, MD Physician, Surgeon, Soldier 25 February 1909-19 May 1987 In Loving Remembrance

title: Powell, With Urgency, Seeks End to Violence
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell made an impassioned appeal today for ''an unconditional cessation of violence'' in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but he said the time was not ripe for the United States to sponsor peace talks.

title: Bridgestone Disputes Need For Bigger Firestone Recall
description: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc. lashed out today at the Ford Motor Company for having concluded that there are problems with Firestone tires that were not covered by the recall last August.

title: Special Education Teachers Win Suit on Union Activity
description: A federal jury has awarded nearly $3.8 million to seven teachers and aides who worked for a special education district in Greenburgh after finding that administrators had violated their constitutional rights in 1995 by disciplining them for union activities.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Mine Deal Approved
description: Shareholders of BHP Ltd., Australia's largest natural resources company, voted overwhelmingly to approve a $28 billion merger with Billiton P.L.C., a South African mining company, whose shareholders approved the deal earlier this week. The deal, the largest merger ever in Australia, still needs various regulatory clearances, but Australian antitrust regulators said they would not intervene. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: SHARES OF PALM DROP AS SALES OF HAND-HELD DEVICES FALL
description: Shares in Palm Inc. fell yesterday after the maker of hand-held electronic organizers said its quarterly sales would be about half its already reduced forecasts. Palm fell $2, to $5.05, on Nasdaq, where it was one of the top percentage losers. The stock has declined 83 percent this year, making it the worst performer in the Standard & Poor's 500 index. The company's new m500 device was delayed by a defect, and customers waited for that model instead of buying older versions, Palm's chief executive, Carl Yankowski, said Thursday. Palm was already struggling to lift sales by reducing prices to clear out inventory after slowing economic growth crimped demand.

title: BID MADE FOR ALL OF ARGENTINE CIGARETTE MAKER
description: The Philip Morris Companies offered to pay $34.7 million for outstanding shares it does not already own in Massalin Particulares , Argentina's biggest cigarette maker. FTR Holdings, a unit of Philip Morris, plans to pay Reemtsma Cigarrettenfabriken of Germany a minimum of 80 centavos a share with a nominal value of 10 cents each, or 8 pesos per 10 shares, for Reemtsma's 5.33 percent stake in Massalin Particulares, bringing its ownership to 100 percent. Massalin Particulares has about 64 percent of the Argentine cigarette market. Nobleza Piccardo, a subsidiary of British American Tobacco, holds the remainder.

title: Death Penalty Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Still No Welcome For Sheffield at Shea
description: It was not so much Gary Sheffield's decision to open his mouth in spring training that made him cringe, Robin Ventura said, but what came out.

title: Facing a Teacher Shortage, American Schools Look Overseas
description: In ordinary times, Iris J. Moran, the principal at Oak Knoll Elementary in East Point, Ga., would not have to look far afield to find a Spanish teacher for her fourth- and fifth-grade classes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Job Growth Slows
description: As slowing global economies cut into France's exports, the growth of new jobs is beginning to slow. In the first quarter, the number of new jobs, excluding government and farm employment, grew by 124,000, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, compared with 136,600 in the fourth quarter of last year, according to government statistics. Vigorous growth, coupled with easier hiring rules, caused unemployment to drop in March to 8.7 percent, its lowest level in almost two decades. But in April, exports declined to an eight-month low, and earlier the government said it expected growth this year of 2.9 percent, against a previous forecast of 3.3 percent. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Twin Peaks of Delight, With Squealing
description: Don't believe what your mother told you: Looks do matter. Just ask Evan and Jaron, the identical twins who performed on Monday night at Irving Plaza. Mixing elements of power pop, jangly folk and adult-contemporary rock, the duo's music (most of which it writes itself) couldn't have been any further from that of 'N Sync. Yet, after three unsuccessful albums, Evan and Jaron sneaked into the teenage-pop party with a hit, ''Crazy for This Girl,'' from its fourth album. Thus, hundreds of squealing schoolgirls packed into Irving Plaza to cheer them on as they strummed through an impressively long 14-song set.

title: Teamwork That Rivals Star Turns
description: There were no solo bows after the performance of Handel's ''Rodelinda,'' presented by the Opera Theater Company of Ireland on Wednesday night at the Harvey Lichtenstein Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The conductor, Laurence Cummings, and the six cast members just lined up onstage and, hands clasped, took a collective bow. The gesture characterized the production: however one assessed the singers, sets and staging, a clear musical-dramatic concept was present, and everyone, including the superb musicians of the New York Collegium, worked toward realizing it.

title: Big Jump in Trade Gap in March May Be Sign of Slower Economy
description: After a steep fall in February, the United States trade deficit expanded widely in March, producing a record first-quarter gap, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: National Briefing | Washington: 3 Nominations Announced
description: President Bush announced his intent to nominate 3 people for his administration and formally nominated 12 others this week. Among the 104 nominations awaiting Senate confirmation is Mr. Bush's choice for ambassador to the United Nations, John Negroponte. The Senate confirmed 4 nominees, bringing the total to 55; 290 positions remain open.

description: The unforgiving sea, writers like to call it, but for one moment 62 years ago, it did forgive.

title: Xavier High Wins Two at Nationals
description: Xavier High School of Manhattan won twice yesterday in the national high school rugby championship in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Ida Fisher Davidoff, 97, an Expert on Aging
description: Ida Fisher Davidoff, a family counselor and expert on aging, died on May 11 at a chronic care center in New Canaan, Conn. She was 97.

title: National Briefing | West: California: $131 Million To Go To Juvenile Jails
description: The State Board of Corrections has allocated $131 million to build or renovate juvenile jails, despite objections from community groups that said the money should be used for education, counseling and employment programs, especially for minority youths. The plan is the largest in decades. State officials said it was badly needed because at least a dozen juvenile jails run by counties were so dilapidated that state and federal authorities were close to citing them as unsafe. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLIENSIS, SHELDON
description: OLIENSIS-Sheldon. On May 14, 2001 at age 79. Husband of Lyn. Father of John Oliensis and Lucretia Moroni, Jane Oliensis, Ellen Oliensis and John Shoptaw. Grandfather of Melina and Chiara Bernardi, Rebecca Shoptaw and Adrian Oliensis. Brother of Doris Woldow and Dr. Asher Woldow. Also survived by many nephews, nieces, grand nephews and grand nieces. The funeral services will be private. A memorial service will be held later. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Sheldon Oliensis Scholarship Fund at the Harvard Law School or to a charity of your choice.

title: Nichols Lawyer Claims F.B.I. Hid Evidence
description: The lead lawyer for Terry L. Nichols, Timothy J. McVeigh's conspirator in the Oklahoma City bombing, has told the Supreme Court that he suspects the Federal Bureau of Investigation is still holding back investigative material from the case, even from prosecutors.

title: Suit Against Drug Maker
description: TAP Pharmaceutical Products, a joint venture of Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries, was sued over accusations that it was overcharging for its prostate cancer drug Lupron. The Philadelphia law firm of Spector, Roseman & Kodroff said it filed the suit on behalf of beneficiaries of Medicare. The suit, which seeks class-action status, accuses the company of illegally inflating the average wholesale price of Lupron sold to Medicare beneficiaries. TAP officials were not available to comment. The suit was filed in Boston.

title: A Gathering Storm in the Mideast
description: Whatever illusions the Bush administration may entertain about a more detached American role in the Middle East should be erased by the rapidly escalating violence in the region, including yesterday's deadly terrorist bombing in Israel and the retaliatory Israeli air strikes. Only assertive, sustained American diplomacy is likely to keep the conflict from turning into a ruinous ordeal for both Israelis and Palestinians and a damaging setback to American interests in the region. Secretary of State Colin Powell, who is planning to travel to Africa and Europe later this month, should add the Middle East to his itinerary to see if he can at least persuade the two sides to diminish or end the bloodshed.

title: A Light and Sound Show, Bright, Flashing and Loud
description: The three collaborative sets during the Amplify 2001 festival on Monday night at Tonic grew from austere to earthy. They amounted to a sort of primer, if you were seeking a grip on the new abstract, improvised electronic music.

title: U.S. Guns Smuggled Into Mexico Feed Drug War
description: Though public attention focuses on the drugs smuggled from Mexico to the north, officials here are increasingly concerned by an ever more lethal flow of guns south from the United States.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Posts Results
description: Germany's largest electricity company, E.ON A.G., said first-quarter operating profit in its main energy unit fell 6 percent, burdened by rising fuel prices and domestic taxes promoting renewable energy. Earnings before interest and tax in the company's energy business fell to 490 million euros ($430 million) from 524 million euros. Total operating profit rose 37 percent, to 949 million euros, helped by three units it plans to sell. E.ON is selling businesses unrelated to energy to pay for purchases in faster-growing markets like Spain and the United States. First-quarter sales rose 1 percent, to 22.7 billion euros ($20.1 billion).

title: Are Graduate Students Workers?
description: NEW HAVEN -- Last year, in a dramatic reversal, the National Labor Relations Board held that graduate teaching assistants at New York University are "employees" and affirmed their right to form a union and to bargain collectively with the university.

title: Bloomberg Wins Approval Of Manhattan Republicans
description: Republican party leaders in Manhattan yesterday endorsed Michael R. Bloomberg for mayor of New York City, calling him an ''authentic mensch'' and a ''warm and caring human being'' who had the best chance to beat the Democratic nominee in the November election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEROWITZ, HOWARD
description: BEROWITZ-Howard. Of North Caldwell, N.J., on May 17, 2001 at home. Howard was a prominent attorney in Clifton, New Jersey for over 40 years. We will cherish his continued love of his family, friends and colleagues, his generosity, his love of music and his daily read of The New York Times. He leaves a family and many friends far and wide: wife Janet, daughter Deborah, daughter Susan and sonin-law Chris, son David and daughter-in-law Danette, mother Sophie & grandson Jacob. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Clifton Memorial Library, or the West Essex First Aid Squad. Sweet dad. We'll miss you, but your songs will live in our hearts forever. Rest in peace.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 5; Israel Retaliates in Jet Strikes
description: A Palestinian suicide bomber killed at least 5 Israelis and wounded more than 100 at a bustling shopping mall here this morning. By evening, Israel had retaliated by unleashing warplanes against the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the first time since the 1967 war.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: New Foreign Minister
description: Ahmed Maher, a former ambassador to Washington, Moscow and the United Nations, has been appointed foreign minister, succeeding Amr Moussa, a figure of immense popularity who is becoming secretary general of the Arab League. President Hosni Mubarak has a history of replacing officials if their domestic popularity soars, and Mr. Moussa's criticism of Israel's treatment of the Palestinians has made him beloved. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

title: Polish Ex-Chief Is Given Delay Of His Trial
description: The trial of a former Polish ruler, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, on charges that he ordered the shooting of protesting workers in 1970 was delayed an additional month today, after the general's lawyers resigned.

title: A Little Shakespearean Traveling Music
description: When Ben Jonson eulogized Shakespeare as being not of an age but for all time, he had no way of knowing about the 1960's. But it has been the proof of Jonson's tribute that Shakespeare's plays have survived transportation to just about every decade since, although admittedly some travel better than others.

title: Rising Fuel Costs Join Growing List Of Troubles for Struggling Farmers
description: The green tractor buzzed like a giant wasp, plowing over a cornfield in a cloud of brown dust, burning gallons of diesel on a spring evening, the sun sinking toward a blue horizon.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Justice Gets A Ticket
description: The chief justice of the State Supreme Court was fined $300 after receiving a ticket on Thursday night for leaving the scene of an accident and driving too fast for conditions. The chief justice, Jean Toal, 58, told The State newspaper in Columbia that she did not realize she had sideswiped a neighbor's car while driving home until police officers knocked on her door about an hour after the accident. Ms. Toal said she did not hear the cars scrape because she had her air conditioner on, her windows up and a tape player on. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Off With The Head
description: On the eve of the Victoria Day holiday weekend honoring the British monarchy, Foreign Minister John Manley said in a radio interview yesterday that he opposed the idea of Prince Charles becoming King of Canada when Queen Elizabeth's reign ends. Mr. Manley called the monarchy ''an institution that is a bit out of date for Canada'' and said its next head of state should be a Canadian. The Queen's role in Canada is largely ceremonial. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: 2 Walk Away From Plane Crash in a Backyard
description: A six-passenger airplane bound for Long Island MacArthur Airport crashed on its runway approach shortly before 5:30 p.m. yesterday, resulting in minor injuries to the two men on board, according to the Suffolk County police.

title: Sports of The Times; When Work Becomes A Passion
description: IN the darkness of early morning, you could not initially tell whether the two women walking in the barn area were sisters, good friends or co-workers in the stable. They headed toward the stable where Monarchos, the Kentucky Derby winner, was preparing for his morning gallop. One of the women walked toward the horse and began to take charge. She set things in motion: making sure other horses had their exercise schedules, and that grooms and exercise riders were ready for the day.

title: 19 Days in Turkey
description: For travelers 50 or older, Grand Circle Travel has a 19-day tour of Turkey starting at $1,495 a person, double occupancy, including air fare from the United States. The Crossroads of Turkey tour begins in Istanbul and stops at Antalya, a city on the Mediterranean famous for its museum of archaeological treasures; Ephesus, with its Greek and Roman ruins; Cappadocia, which has a network of cave houses; Kusadasi; Ankara and Canakkale. The price includes accommodations, all ground transportation, 17 breakfasts and 17 dinners and 18 sightseeing tours. Information: (800) 248-3737.

description: After six consecutive games at home for the MetroStars and three in a row at home for the Power, both teams will play in California this weekend.

description: Secretary of State Colin Powell leaves on Tuesday for five days in Africa, visiting Mali in West Africa, South Africa, and Kenya and Uganda in the east. The tour of the huge continent is a considerable commitment at a time of stress in the Middle East and elsewhere. Why is he doing it? I asked the secretary that in a telephone interview.

title: Detroit Splits the Difference; Car-Based S.U.V.'s Are Unlikely to Stem Slide In Fuel Economy
description: Auto sales are shrinking and discounts have spread even to the largest sport utility vehicles. But sales have nearly tripled this year for one category of vehicles that is being marketed with virtually no discounts at all: sport utility vehicles based on car designs.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a proposal by Britain and the United States to lift the 11-year ban on international trade with Iraq misstated the reason for the departure of international inspectors there in 1998. It occurred  that December, before the United States and Britain began bombing raids on Iraq  because the United Nations feared that they might be harmed or taken hostage. They were not expelled.

title: Cuttings: When Plants Are Forgiving of Pruning
description: BECAUSE deciduous shrubs like lilac, forsythia, mock orange, rose of Sharon, butterfly bush and spirea are always growing new stems at or near ground level, they are forgiving plants to prune. New growth, wherever needed, can eventually correct any mistakes. Still, this forgiving nature is no excuse for the butchering that is often seen when, for instance, forsythia is given an annual haircut with hedge shears.

title: Mets Find Their Stroke Against Brown and Dodgers
description: Al Leiter had been waiting four weeks for this, four weeks for a chance to pitch again and to help resuscitate his lifeless team. He was so eager, he said last week, that he hurried his comeback from an elbow injury when he otherwise might have held back. Leiter is the Mets' No. 1 starter, and an ace is supposed to be a superhero.

title: Concert Selections in Masquerade
description: The Eos Orchestra knows how to make a concert an event. Its Thursday night program at the Ethical Culture Society, ''Song(Writer)s Without Words,'' presented two world premieres, had Stephen Sondheim in the audience and went down easy, as its opening piece, Wagner's ''Siegfried Idyll,'' proved to be the most demanding thing on the program.

title: May 13-19; No Shame
description: Impotence was taboo in American political discourse until Bob Dole, the former presidential candidate and senator, began starring in Viagra commercials. Now comes New York City's law-and-order mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, and his say-anything divorce lawyer, Raoul L. Felder, and the revelation of Mr. Giuliani's impaired sexual function.

title: A Mythical Metropolis Materializes in Queens
description: IN Italo Calvino's ''Invisible Cities,'' Marco Polo and Kublai Khan conjure imaginary destinations out of thin air. A similar trick is being pulled off with industrial-strength nylon canvas and aluminum tubing by Alexandre Arrechea, Dagoberto Rodrguez and Marco Castillo, three young Cuban artists known as Los Carpinteros (the Carpenters). Their ''Ciudad Transportable'' (''Transportable City''), which opens today at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Queens, is a mythical metropolis situated at the intersection of sculpture and architecture -- a blurry meeting place where distinctions between art and work fall away.

title: Navigating the Navigation Aids
description: MY tipoff that the Infiniti Q45 isn't entirely comfortable with technology came even before it hit the road. As I closed the trunk, the hinges, which protrude nearly a foot into the cargo area -- in the low-budget style of a Korean econobox -- nearly crushed the laptop computer nestled atop the duffel bags, dirty laundry and provisions for the weekend house.

description: Tuberculosis, one of the world's major killers, could be brought under control within five years if nations would commit an additional $400 million a year, say officials of the World Health Organization, which announced a new plan this week to combat the disease.

Emblems of the Joy So Long Denied Them
description: THE watercolor documents and drawings of the Schwenkfelders, a little-known Pennsylvania-German sect that came to America in the 1730's, vividly express the worldly and spiritual joys that were often denied them in their homeland of Silesia, a region then in Austria-Hungary and now in southern Poland. After two centuries of enduring intolerance and persecution, 200 Schwenkfelders left Silesia to seek refuge and a place to worship openly, traveling first to Saxony and then to the Netherlands, where they boarded ships for America.

title: Anne Frank's Story, This Time Told by Disney
description: WORLD WAR II ended 56 years ago, but apparently it is still springtime for Hitler. ''The Producers,'' with its hotsy-totsy Nazis, swept the Tony nominations and has ticket buyers queued up on Broadway. On HBO, Nazi leaders map out their plan to annihilate the Jews on ''Conspiracy,'' a taut, intelligent dramatization of the Wannsee Conference showing several times through June 13. ''The Sorrow and the Pity,'' Marcel Ophuls's monumental 1972 documentary on the German occupation of France, is being shown on Turner Classic Movies on June 6. And, in addition to its usual voluminous coverage of the war, the History Channel is offering ''Hitler's Holocaust,'' a six-hour German mini-series, which begins June 18.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Infiniti Q45; Once Again, a Q-Ship That Makes Waves
description: REMEMBER the Infiniti commercial with the rocks, the enigmatic voice-over -- and no vehicles in sight? The idea, back in 1989, was to stir interest in Nissan's new luxury-car line. But the Zen tease seemed to mystify as much as titillate. By the time Infiniti's flagship, the Q45, actually made an appearance, the marketing message was blurred.

title: Private Sector; Deft Hand at Helm of Pilots' Union
description: FROM his eighth-floor office window here, Duane E. Woerth can see airplanes descending over the Potomac River on their final approach to Reagan National Airport. If a jet is too far above the dome of St. Matthew's Cathedral, a few blocks south of him on Rhode Island Avenue, he says, then it is coming in too high and the crew will ''have an interesting landing.''

McQuaid of Walled Lake, Mich. The Rev. Dawson Ambosta performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: 2 Years Later, Harlem Still Waits for a Supermarket It Needs

Two years is hardly a long time when zoning or not-in-my-backyard issues are involved, but in this case, no such thing stood in the way.

Discussions at the Saturday symposium will not be in botanical Latin. There will be no rhapsodizing over the floral splendors of Sissing hurst, no earnest advocates for two-tufts-of-grass minimalism in the garden.

title: The View From/Greenwich; Powering the Trains, And Doing It Gracefully

description: After months of jockeying and rivalry between potential candidates, the Bronx Democratic Party organization reached a decision early yesterday to support Councilman Adolfo Carrin Jr. for Bronx borough president.

title: Ferris Wheel Comes Full Circle

On the ground below, small children hold their parents' hands as they look up at the enormous steel structure, anticipating what for many will be their first amusement park ride ever.

title: Getting on Board The Mule Train

Parents Shirley and James; brother Ted; sister Catherine and her husband Henry Roberts, children Andrew, James, Sarah; companion Steve Weinstein; and many friends mourn a special man who cherished life's wonders, opera above all. Memorial May 29 at 6 PM, Grace & St. Paul's Church, 123 West 71st Street. Donations in his memory to Brooklyn Botanic Gardens, 1000 Washington Ave., Brooklyn 11225.

The latest releases of Britney Spears, Madonna, U2 or the Back Street Boys can cost up to $14.50 in record shops here, but that doesn't stop anyone from hearing them. Street vendors, operating from simple metal stands, offer the same titles for $2.75.

title: Hanging Out With Butterflies
description: I'VE seen fairies. In the Transvolcanic Mountains in central Mexico of all places. It was late afternoon and thousands of them were flitting among the pencil-straight oyamel fir trees. Now it could be that the altitude of 10,000 feet had made me delirious, but I'm not the first person to think a butterfly might be more than an insect. The Aztecs believed butterflies were the souls of the dead. When I visited the monarch butterfly sanctuary of El Rosario and saw these delicate creatures dancing in the air, a childhood dream of mine was fleetingly realized. I'd stumbled upon a fairy glade.

description: This season, key rings are jumping through loops, with straps that can be worn around the neck or hooked onto a finger. In Los Angeles, where gym-teacher chic has hit the streets, Phillip Bloch, a Hollywood-stylist-cum-designer, has created a diverse line of key lanyards made from bright, graphic ribbons of Marimekko fabric and flashy leathers like python and pony ($29 to $36 at Henri Bendel). Old Navy's key ring is a bit more sporty, made from plastic ($3.50) or cotton ($2.50), in red, aqua, navy and yellow.

They went to the Web site with the homework assignment from the night before, a magazine article on the colonial slave trade. Mrs. Anthony guided them through a review of their homework notes, which they had submitted to her by e-mail. She had them compare what they found on the Internet with information from their textbook.

Through the crack came a thin band of light and a whiff of horse manure. I put my eye up to the crack and peered in at a long, narrow stable. Bales of hay lay neatly stacked in a loft near the back. Half a dozen horses idled in stalls along either side.

title: Scandal at Hale House
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, using his power to investigate and restructure nonprofit organizations that skirt the law or misuse money solicited from the public, has begun to resolve the scandal surrounding Hale House, a venerable Harlem charity founded 30 years ago to care for homeless infants and toddlers. Over the last several weeks, Hale House has been damaged by revelations that its director, Dr. Lorraine Hale, may have permitted the organization to divert hundreds of thousands of dollars toward wasteful or self-serving projects unrelated to the group's mission. There have also been charges that cases involving children and their imprisoned mothers were handled improperly. The investigation is yet to be completed. But the interim board appointed by Mr. Spitzer made the correct decision last week when it dismissed Dr. Hale as president and chief executive officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, DR. ROBERT ANDREW
description: JOHNSON-Dr. Robert Andrew. Of New Castle, NH, died on May 18, 2001. Born in Pittsfield, NH, on September 21, 1914, he was a graduate of Bates College and Albany Medical School. He served overseas in the United States Air Force from 1943 until 1946, receiving the Bronze Star. A member of the American Board of Surgery and the Board of Neurological Surgery, he trained at Bellevue Hospital, Jersey City Medical Center, Children's Hospital Boston, Hartford Hospital (CT), and New York Hospital. He was attending neurosurgeon at the major hospitals in Worcester, MA, for 37 years and retired as Associate Professor of Neurosurgery at the Univeristy of Massachusetts Medical School. His wife of 55 years, Minna Flynn Johnson, survives him; as does a daughter, Amy E. Johnson of St. Johnsbury, VT; two sons, Robert Flynn Johnson of San Francisco and Richard Andrew Johnson of Milton, MA; six grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. Funeral private; flowers to be omitted.

title: May 13-19; Pacifying the Pacific
description: Under Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, the Pacific is now the key arena for military planning. A Pentagon review being drafted by a top Rumsfeld aide asserts that Beijing's strategy is to keep American forces far from the mainland in a conflict and so is improving its ability to attack American aircraft carriers and bases in Japan with surface-to-surface missiles. The review suggests that the Pentagon counter by developing longer-range arms. But key U.S. military officers in the Pacific believe the review overstates Chinese capabilities, underplays U.S. relations with allies and exaggerates the promise of new arms. Michael R. Gordon

Still, this forgiving nature is no excuse for the butchering that is often seen when, for instance, forsythia is given an annual haircut with hedge shears.

title: They Do Write 'Em Like They Used To

The goal each year is to choose at least four scores for consideration. But even the Tony nominating committee has its pride. title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: Each of us who lived through the Vietnam War is haunted by memories of that time. Barbara Tuchman called it a ''march of folly.'' None were in control -- Lyndon Johnson, Ho Chi Minh, Vo Nguyen Giap, Richard Nixon -- all players in a hellish script. One United States senator, Bob Kerrey, tortured in soul; another, John McCain, tortured in body; all of us humbled in our collective fallibility. Many began with the concept of a just war. Most knew, by the Tet Offensive of 1968, that it was all senseless carnage. As a psychiatrist in the Navy Medical Corps in the early 1970's, in the safety of Pearl Harbor, I listened to the tale of our corpsman who had jumped through the window of an up-country Vietnam medical dispensary as a 5-year-old blew up with the hand grenade he carried into the place like a death toy.

title: Familiar Foot Is in the Door
description: Wedgies, the 1970's-inspired shoes, not the locker-room variety, are back in full force in a wide range of materials and styles. At Herms, the season's stock of Chane slip-on wooden wedges with a woven leather H-strap in dark brown or bone ($275) are nearly sold out. Robert Clergerie offers leather wedgies with gold-padded leather straps ($365), and Sergio Rossi wraps his in snakeskin with ankle ties ($590), both at Saks Fifth Avenue. And traditional companies like Coach are giving the once-hippie look a classic spin, in camel or black-leather wedge sandals with a conventional strap that buckles around the ankle ($180, from the Garnet Hill catalog). Nonetheless, the wedge of the moment is from Hogan, the accessories company owned by the designer Diego Della Valle, of J. P. Tod's. With a steep cork-wedge heel in a slide (below) or espadrille style (left) (both $275 at all Hogan stores), the shoe will arrive in stores on Monday, and there's already a celebrity-studded waiting list of 300 strong, according to the company. That roster includes Sarah Jessica Parker, Minnie Driver, Selma Blair and Chlo Sevigny. Apparently, women cannot live on Blahniks alone.

title: May 13-19; Guilty in Teacher's Murder

The boy, Nathaniel Brazill, faces 25 years to life, though because of his age the judge has leeway in sentencing. Nathaniel, who was 13 at the time of the shooting, is the second black 14-year-old in South Florida in five months to be tried as an adult for first-degree murder. The first, Lionel Tate, was sentenced to life for beating a 6-year-old playmate to death; he now awaits a clemency hearing. Dana Canedy

However, the hooch stood there; now what to do? Kerrey's decision was to kill its inhabitants.

title: The Braided Bunch
description: It is an art that has been immortalized in African sculpture for centuries, and yet each work is ephemeral, meant to last a day, a weekend, a week or two at most. Historically, the configuration of coils and curls is a language indicating tribe, marital status, wealth and occasion. In Nigeria in the 50's, the photographer J. D. 'Okhai Ojeikere noticed that the hairdos were disappearing, giving way to glossy wigs. Then, just as suddenly as they started to vanish, they came back, but the language had altered. It was less tied to rural tradition, more in tune with urban life. Jazzy towers of braids mimicked the first skyscrapers in Lagos. There were swirls and spikes, symmetry and asymmetry. Realizing that this evanescent art could vanish again, Ojeikere began documenting it. And last year, his portfolio -- J. D. 'Okhai Ojeikere/Photographs'' -- was published by Scalo.

title: Things That Cannot Be Painted
description: Imagine an erudite text about a single artwork that is as readable and riveting as a first-rate spy thriller. This rare mix is achieved by Michael Francis Gibson in THE MILL AND THE CROSS: Peter Bruegel's ''Way to Calvary'' (Acatos, $65). In lively prose unusual for such a scholarly work, Gibson discusses every factor that contributes to the grip of this complex painting, completed in 1564. He considers the roles of weather conditions and vegetation. He relates the movement of the windmill to astronomical events, so that we understand the ramifications of its astrological symbolism. He examines the characters of the crowd with a novelistic sense of detail -- the significance of clothing and possessions, the precise moment in each person's life -- and writes vividly of the nature of the brushstrokes, and the effects of scale, composition and color in Bruegel's work. Gibson informs us about Bruegel's political attitudes and personal life, while mercifully sparing us gratuitous data. He properly links the aesthetic impact and narrative function of essential elements of the painting, as in his description of the large rock in the background as ''dominating a devastated zone set between the luminous order of the town and the darker region of death'' and his trenchant analysis of this looming formation as representing ''the dominant power of the Law. . . . Frozen in mineral timelessness, it . . . embodies the archaic power that remains to be circumvented.'' In the tradition of fine-art historians like Erwin Panofsky and Meyer Schapiro, Gibson, an independent scholar, successfully delves beneath the surface, while simultaneously honoring and exploring that lush surface in all its magnitude. Nicholas Fox Weber

title: That Cool, That Suit: Sotheby's 007
description: I WAS so nervous that my mouth dried up completely and I was unable to speak,'' Tobias Meyer said, recalling the terror of conducting his first auction eight years ago during his first week on the job at Sotheby's in London. ''I had to say, '13,000' and I couldn't. There was a glass of water on the rostrum and I was shaking so much I couldn't pick it up.''

title: Setting Rates By the Numbers
description: ELIMINATE Alan Greenspan.

title: Latvians Can't Escape Cold War's Divisive Legacy
description: Visvaldis Aivers's father built his family's house with his own hands.

title: In His Top 12, A Telling 5 From the 20th
description: AT a recent preconcert interview in Alice Tully Hall, Fred Sherry -- better known as a cellist than as a talk-show host -- was putting questions to Charles Wuorinen, whose Fourth String Quartet was about to be performed. Knowing Mr. Wuorinen's disinclination to verbalize his musical intentions, Mr. Sherry kept to general issues. But as so often, the general turned out to be just a special case of the particular, and Mr. Sherry's most general question of all got by far the most provocative and informative response. (With Mr. Wuorinen, information and provocation tend to go together.)

title: Virginia Race Is Seen as a Bellwether for House Elections
description: Next year's Congressional elections are almost 18 months off. But an answer of sorts to the question of whether Republicans can retain control of the House might come next month when a special election will be held in Virginia's Fourth Congressional District.

title: Is Greenspan's Salary A Bit Irrational?
description: ''Irrational exuberance,'' of course, is the phrase once used by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to allude to the runaway bull market in stocks.

title: Floral Gems in Pretty Packages
description: GARDEN lovers in the tristate area are lucky. Horticultural showplaces like the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, Skylands and Old Westbury Gardens are within easy driving distance.

title: A Couple of Regular Guys Bonding, Onstage and Off
description: THEY are a couple of unemployed steelworkers kicking around haplessly in Buffalo, their mill closed, their gutted manhood defined by a few lines of Terrence McNally's script right at the top of the show:
