title: Lord, Won't You Buy Me a Mercedes-Benz?
description: Our text today is ''The Prayer of Jabez: Breaking Through to the Blessed Life.'' This inexpensive, shirt-pocket-size volume (Multnomah Publishers, $9.99) has sold more than four million copies in the past year, and is the best-selling book in America right now. It has attracted a prodigious following among people who have chosen to repeat every day the one-sentence prayer that gives the book its title. (''Oh, that you would bless me indeed, and enlarge my territory, that your hand would be with me, and that you would keep me from evil, that I may not cause pain!'') Jabez enthusiasts have risen up in churches and private homes and on the Prayer of Jabez Web site (www.prayerofjabez.com) to testify to the changes the sentence has wrought in their lives. National publications have made note; experts have been consulted; videos have been made; a sequel has been published, and others, including ''The Prayer of Jabez for Teens'' and ''The Prayer of Jabez for Women,'' have been commissioned. ''The Prayer of Jabez'' has also been taken up by the mighty. The author, an Atlanta-based evangelical minister named Bruce Wilkinson, who was one of the leaders of the Promise Keepers movement, was recently invited to the White House.

title: French Trains: Fast and Faster
description: AAH, springtime in Paris. Sidewalk cafes, music in the air -- and day after day of rain. Luckily, Parisians will soon get relief from one of the wettest years on record. It comes in the form of a new high-speed rail line that will chop more than an hour off travel times from Paris to such sunny southern cities as Nice, Cannes, Marseille, Aix-en-Provence and Avignon.

title: A Crash Course in the World of Mel
description: EVEN Broadway's most maladroit impresario, Max Bialystock of ''The Producers,'' understands that to create a musical -- good or otherwise -- the appropriate creative team must be employed. For Bialystock, in Mel Brooks's current hit musical, the assured failure of his show, ''Springtime for Hitler,'' is dependent on securing the services of a director named Roger De Bris.

title: Ideas & Trends; Save the Environment! (And Turn Up the Air Conditioner.)
description: PARSING American attitudes toward energy conservation and the environment is no easy task, largely because they are governed by a fundamental ambivalence that runs something like this: the wilderness is sacrosanct, but so is my air conditioner. Researchers for the Department of Energy are currently in the field collecting data for the latest Residential Energy Consumption Survey, and results are expected by 2002. But a glimpse of America's complex energy attitudes can be gleaned from a combination of recent polls and trends revealed in the last Department of Energy survey, published in 1999. TOM ZELLER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALINSON, DANIEL
description: GALINSON-Daniel. The Kaplowitz Family mourns the passing of our beloved friend and partner, Dan Galinson. Dan was a very special person, caring and concerned about people & loyal and devoted to his family and friends. We will miss him forever. Ike & Gita Kaplowitz, Richard & Marji, Michael & Donna

title: Refreshing Pauses In Heat of Season
description: DRINKS define the season. You can enjoy Champagne all year, but warm weather is when you add peach juice to make a bellini. Many long, cool refreshers, both alcoholic and nonalcoholic, are just right for summer sipping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, EUGENIA
description: WEISS-Eugenia. We mourn with the Tetenbaum and Sobie families and embrace Roxana on the loss of her grandmother. Evelyn Sommer President, WIZO USA

title: Where the Rx Is Love and Fish Slurry
description: THE 2-year-old harbor seal known as NY2603 pressed against the transport cage looking dazed. Today's pickup ride to the beach was short, but bumpy.

title: Reckonings; Burn, Baby, Burn
description: Who knew that Dick Cheney had such a sense of humor?

title: Jennifer Sherman, Noah Sanders
description: Jennifer Ellen Sherman and Noah Robert Sanders were married last evening by Rabbi Jerome P. David at the Ritz-Carlton in Philadelphia.

title: Staging The Next New Thing
description: THE runaway success of Mel Brooks' hit musical ''The Producers,'' based on his 1968 film comedy, proves one thing: Broadway's newest formula for success lies in a treasure trove of classic 60's movies waiting to be adapted to the stage. Be on the lookout for:

title: Corrections
description: A dance entry in the Summer Festivals listing on May 6 for Massachusetts misstated dates for two companies at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival. The Jos Limn Company will perform June 20-24, not June 14; Buglisi/Foreman will perform June 21-24, not July 21-24.

title: Virginia Bonsal, Jeffrey Nickell
description: Virginia Purviance Bonsal, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Bonsal of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Tilman Nickell, the son of Karla Shook Nickell of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Newton Tilman Nickell of Marietta, Ga. The Rev. Dr. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Out-of-Sync Clocks Teach Wrong Lessons, Critic Argues
description: John Ciafone thinks schools need a fourth R -- the right time.

title: For Used Books, a Shelf in Cyberspace
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom notwithstanding, you can teach an old bookhound new tricks. Take the case of the Internet and the used book dealers of Connecticut. This would seem to be a clash of cultures, not unlike when the scribes of the 15th century were confronted with Gutenberg's press and told, ''This is the future.''

title: GOING OUT
description: Are we there yet? Not quite. But when summer finally does arrive, there will be no shortage of things to do do. Here's a calendar of selected events throughout the summer. It's just a starting point. The rest is up to you.

title: Betting On Winners And Losers In Energy
description: GREAT fortunes are often made -- and lost -- in times of crisis.

title: Arabs to Sever Political Contacts In Protest Against Israeli Tactics
description: Arab League foreign ministers, expressing their outrage a day after Israel used fighter jets to attack Palestinian positions in the West Bank, declared today that they were severing all political contacts with Israel until the violence stopped.

title: Irvington Design Firm Helps in Dyslexia Campaign
description: Dyslexia is a reading disability that affects roughly 15 percent of the population. Yet many people grow up without it ever being diagnosed. Ellen Shapiro, president of Shapiro Design Associates of Irvington, wants to change this.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Fairfield Market Reacts to Wall St. Ups and Downs
description: THE single-family housing market in Fairfield County, where shots fired from Wall Street land with particular resonance, is responding to the tumultuous stock market with corresponding ups, downs and inconsistencies. High prices resulting from months of low inventories have led buyers to bid above asking prices, in turn leading to more houses becoming available by newly motivated sellers seeking handsome profits.

title: Introduction
description: Our article on Bob Kerrey prompted hundreds of letters, many from those who served in Vietnam. Here, often citing their own experiences, some readers defend the young lieutenant's actions on that ''awful night in Thanh Phong'' while others condemn it.

title: A Wall Street Wizard Tends to His Garden
description: BEFORE Michael Steinhardt compiled one of the greatest records in history for a hedge fund manager, transforming himself into a living Wall Street legend, he was a boy from Brooklyn who never ventured off the pavement.

title: Canadians Proclaim A Year of the Bear
description: The national parks of the Canadian Rockies, home to perhaps 200 black bears and 200 grizzlies, are serving as host for a yearlong tribute to their majestic and fearsome inhabitants. Throughout this year, parks, museums, galleries and hotels across Alberta and British Columbia will hold more than 500 events to commemorate the Year of the Great Bear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIDLEY, KATHERINE RAUB
description: RIDLEY-Katherine Raub. The Preservation League of New York State mourns the death of our Staff Counsel, Katherine Raub Ridley, Director of the League's Legal Services Program. Kathie was known across our state and the United States for her singular role in advancing and defending preservation in New York State. The League's trustees have created a dedicated fund to maintain her extensive body of work and continue providing legal services. Contributions may be sent to the Preservation League of New York State, 44 Central Avenue, Albany, New York 12206 for The Katherine Raub Ridley Legal Service Fund.

title: This Showman Made The Garden Magical
description: On a frigid February afternoon in 1991, Dave Checketts received an offer he could not refuse. He was asked to oversee one of the National Basketball Association's charter franchises, the Knickerbockers.

title: A Great Musician
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the jargon used by medical residents misspelled the name of an antibiotic in a phrase of warning against excess dosage that might harm the kidneys. The phrase is ''Better watch that gentamicin,'' not gentamycin.

title: In South Africa, It's Press vs. the President, Black Executives Say
description: Leaping to the defense of President Thabo Mbeki, a group of prominent black executives has accused South Africa's white-owned newspapers of carrying out a relentless campaign to discredit the government.

title: Ideas & Trends: The Sandbox; Bully for You: Why Push Comes to Shove
description: SOME people are just fair game for being picked on and put down: lawyers, politicians, journalists, mothers-in-law and, now, bullies. These days, everybody is ganging up on bullies, blaming them for all that ails us.

title: Dominicans March for Voting Rights (on the Island)
description: Hundreds of Dominicans marched or drove a six-mile loop through Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood on Wednesday, demanding their rights to vote in the 2004 presidential election -- of the Dominican Republic.

title: Suit Over Foster Care Settled in Tennessee
description: The State of Tennessee has settled a class-action lawsuit against its foster care system, agreeing to sweeping changes in the tracking of the children in its system and accepting oversight by independent monitors.

title: Uneasy Being Green: Tourism Runs Wild
description: SUDDENLY, everyone is an eco-tourist, or so it seems. The traveler may be playing shuffleboard on a cruise ship, martini in hand, when a whale passes by, or hunting exotic species in a private wildlife park in Texas. Typical tourists? No, sir. To hear the marketers tell it, these activities are part of the fastest-growing segment of the world's dominant industry.

title: Private Sector; Imitating Mr. Ghosn in Japan
description: It was a Brazilian-born automotive executive from Renault named Carlos Ghosn who finally turned around Japan's Nissan Motor Company, which last week reported the biggest annual profit in its history after a staggering loss the year before. And because imitation is often the purest form of flattery in Japan, there is now speculation that other troubled Japanese companies may embrace a foreign chief like Mr. Ghosn.

title: Was This Soccer Mom A Terrorist?
description: When former General Teko's cell phone rang during our meeting at the People's Cafe, he politely punched the mute button and returned the phone to its holster. Then he smiled apologetically. Bill Harris, who has long since dropped his nom de guerre in the Symbionese Liberation Army, has a well-honed sense of irony, which comes as something of a surprise. His charming grin is also unexpected, not to mention the Honda Passport S.U.V. in which he drives his two young children to school every day.

title: Metamorphoses
description: THE LOVE-ARTIST

title: Making Sure Burglars Don't Steal Summer
description: SUMMER is the time when most home burglaries occur. This is understandable because many homeowners keep the windows open during the hot weather, the trees and bushes around the house are in full bloom and offer a screen to protect the would-be intruder. In addition, many homeowner go away for the summer, making the empty house an inviting target for robbers. You may feel safe or complacent if you live in a quiet neighborhood with no reported burglaries, but it's possible that thieves simply haven't discovered your area yet.

title: Seeing Red in the Fifth Borough: The Semiotics of Right Turns
description: If New York were a car, Staten Island would be the fifth wheel. It is stowed out of sight in the minds of most city residents, like a spare tire in a trunk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHRIST, WALTER
description: CHRIST-Walter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter Christ, associated with The Times from 1960 to 1993.

title: What? No Tail?
description: Touch, the poodle who narrates THE OTHER DOG (Books of Wonder/Sea Star, $15.95; ages 3 to 6), by Madeline L'Engle, just doesn't get it. The other dog has no pretty chrysanthemum-shaped tail, practically no hair and no household skills like letting the mistress and master know when the doorbell rings. Indeed, the new creature has one habit so appalling, the elegant Touch can speak of it only in politely veiled terms. ''When I have anything of that sort to do, I go out in the street,'' she sniffs. That's because the new dog, as young readers will quickly see, is a baby, and the habit that so affronts Touch involves diapers.

title: Stepping Off the Train Into the Arms of Summer
description: SUMMER does not truly arrive until school is out. It doesn't matter whether you are actually going to school any longer or not. It doesn't matter if you are sitting in an office all day or are on your way home, crammed in the middle of a three-seat bench in a commuter train. Because when you step off that train, summer has often come to the station to greet you.

title: Lovebirds
description: DODO GETS MARRIED

title: Last of the Rivermen
description: THIS is our world,'' said Robert Gabrielson, looking down at his battered fishing boat by the dock on the Hudson River waterfront in Nyack. ''This is all that's left of us.''

title: May 13-19; Deadly Day in Mideast
description: Friday was the deadliest day of the year in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. In the morning, a Palestinian suicide bomber killed at least 5 Israelis and wounded more than 100 at a bustling shopping mall. By evening, Israel unleashed warplanes against the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the first time since the 1967 war. At least nine Palestinians were killed in attacks on Nablus and Ramallah, and an Israeli army officer was killed in his car on a West Bank road.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Medical Offices Are a Growing Real Estate Niche
description: TUCKED into the rolling hills around Stony Brook University Hospital on the North Shore and within 15 minutes of three other Suffolk County hospitals is the 22-building Stony Brook Technology Center, constructed more than 20 years ago by the Tritec Real Estate Company. About 30 percent of the buildings are currently leased to medical offices, and the numbers are about to increase as three new buildings, geared to the medical profession, are about to be constructed.

title: Travel Advisory
description: In Belfast, a Merger of Science and Art The sprawling Odyssey Center complex in Belfast's docklands made headlines last year for two reasons. First, its arena housed the city's first and only ice-hockey team, the Giants, for its phenomenally popular opening season. And second, it wasn't the Millennium Dome. Despite the many parallels with the ill-fated London project, people so far have actually enjoyed going to the Odyssey Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, WANDA
description: WALSH-Wanda. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of NYU School of Medicine note with great sorrow the passing of Wanda Walsh, MD, a beloved pediatrician and teacher for generations of students and residents who trained at Bellevue Hospital. With deep connections to our institution, Dr. Walsh earned her medical degree at NYU in 1950, joined the faculty in 1953 and became Associate Professor of Clinical Pediatrics in 1971-a position she held with grace and dignity until her retirement last year. Early on, at Bellevue Hospital, she worked closely with Dr. Saul Krugman on measels vaccine development, and remained an attending pediatrician there for 50 years. Her work in the clinics at Bellevue with children and their families was exemplary. Our deepest condolences to her husband, mother and children, with warmest appreciation for a remarkable woman who will be sorely missed. Kenneth Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean NYU School of Medicine Wade P. Parks, MD, PhD Professor/Chairman of Pediatrics NYU School of Medicine

title: Private Sector; Laughing All the Way to the Banamex
description: Roberto Hernndez is not the richest man in Mexico -- not yet. But Mr. Hernndez, the president of Banamex, the banking branch of the Banacci financial group, had a very good day on Thursday, when Citigroup said it would buy Banacci for $12.5 billion. Mr. Hernndez and his family are said by analysts in Mexico to own at least half of Banacci's shares. (Mexico's disclosure laws prevent a more precise accounting.) In 1991, Mr. Hernndez, then regarded as the most successful stockbroker in Mexico, led investors who paid $2.3 billion for a controlling interest in Banamex. Tim Weiner

title: Structures
description: The more the rules of design are broken, the more we search for something sturdy. Within the fluid flux of fashion, we have found a little structure to hang on to. A Style Special

title: So Many Benefits, So Little Time
description: HIGH season in the Hamptons doesn't begin until Memorial Day. From then on, the calendar is so full of fund-raising events that partygoers are shuffling through decks of save-the-date cards and invitations deciding which to attend.

title: The Accidental Matriarch
description: BACK WHEN WE

title: Stevens Shows Critics, And Satisfies Himself
description: Just 17 months ago, Gary Stevens did not think he would be in this position again -- standing in front of a battery of reporters in a post-Preakness news conference, explaining how he had guided a colt to victory in a Triple Crown event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, CATHERINE C. (NEE REILLY)
description: RUSSELL-Catherine C. (nee Reilly), May 17, 2001. Beloved wife of the late David V. of NY and Rossmore in Jamesburg, NJ. Also survived by 4 nephews and 2 nieces. Relatives and friends are invited to attend her Funeral Mass Monday 11AM St. Joan of Arc Church, 82nd St. Jackson Heights, Queens NY. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Austria's Grape At Its Greatest
description: In Austria's finest hands, grner veltliner, its national grape, reaches equality with great German riesling and white Burgundy.

title: Judy Hong, John Limb
description: Judy Eun-joo Hong, the daughter of Sung Ae Hong and Jong Won Hong of Dallas, was married yesterday to John Joung-il Limb, a son of Dr. Eun Hai Limb and Dr. Sangjin Limb of Port Washington, N.Y. The Rev. Edward C. Horne performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church of Port Washington.

title: Score the Red Sox Caught Not Stealing
description: When he played -- 14 games in the major leagues and a few more than that in the minors -- Jimy Williams was no threat to the stolen-base record Lou Brock was amassing at the time. The team Williams now manages is hardly a threat to steal, let alone pose a threat to a stolen-base record.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, ALFRED HERBERT
description: MARKS-Alfred Herbert. Attorney, Veteran. July 9,1928-May 12,2001. Graduate NYU & Associate Editor Fordham Law Review. Beloved husband, father, brother, uncle. A man of integrity and compassion. Survived by loving family, wife, Sue, children Jackie and Eugene, sister Dorothy Bomser (Martin), nephews, Mark, David and nieces Anne, Ilene, and Tanya.

title: Outdoor Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Embracing Its Ancestors
description: DRUMS tell the stories on Caetano Veloso's ''Noites do Norte'' (''Northern Nights''), even when they're silent. Each rhythm is a memento of a place, a culture, a private memory or a public tradition, like a pin in a map or a marker in a diary. A sputtering hip-hop beat, volleys of hand drumming, the broad-shouldered swagger of Bahian sambareggae, a cymbal-crashing rock stomp or the whisper of bossa nova can all summon not just a song's immediate mood but its farflung ancestry. On ''Noites do Norte,'' the drums invoke Africa, the United States and the countless local styles in Brazil; when they are absent, Mr. Veloso is thinking about Europe or about an encompassing loneliness.

title: Storied History for Grande Dame of Hockey Arenas
description: The Montreal Forum had its nooks. Maple Leaf Gardens in Toronto had its crannies. Boston Garden had rodents and Chicago Stadium had that booming organ. The Olympia in Detroit had egg-shaped corners and a guy in the balcony who threw eggs onto the ice in the third period whenever Gordie Howe needed a rest. Madison Square Garden, the current one and the one before it, offered plenty of bad sightlines for hockey.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: I am troubled by a critical comment prompted by Vistica's article that ''reporters have been busy researching the rules of war as though it were a board game. The truth is there were no rules.'' Why not? Research by reporters and others even at this late date should be encouraged if the terrible physical and emotional scars of Vietnam are to be finally healed. Had more of this gone on during that conflict, including by Congressional and Pentagon staff members, the pullout might have begun a lot sooner and spared the country some of the grief being suffered by Bob Kerrey, a decent man, and countless others.

title: Anne Burton, Joseph Walsh IV
description: Anne Marie Burton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Burton of Ridgewood, N.J., was married on Friday to Joseph Manus Walsh IV, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh III of Bloomfield, Mich. The Rev. Charles Wrightington performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: And the Tony For Best Painting Will Go to . . .
description: MOST of the time, what we get in this life is art for commerce's sake. Sometimes we get art for art's sake. Recently, though, there's been a third alternative: art for the script's sake.

title: A Sleepover In Free Soweto
description: THE tour buses glide into Soweto and the foreign faces press against the glass windows, marveling at the storied black township. The tourists wander through the tiny house where Nelson Mandela lived. They sample South African staples like savory beef and cornmeal porridge. They admire the gleaming monuments to the liberation struggle that once engulfed these streets, just 20 minutes from downtown Johannesburg.

title: Sports of The Times; A Golden Opportunity For Silas and the Hornets
description: AFTER years of waiting and watching other men get the chances he knew he deserved, Game 6 came and went and was as bitter a defeat as Paul Silas could swallow. You could see the beads of facial sweat as he pursed his lips and watched his Charlotte Hornets lose a 15-point home-court lead Thursday night and the Milwaukee Bucks buzz off with their playoff lives. You could feel Silas's desperation to win, as if the opportunity, like some celestial phenomenon, might not be seen again for years.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Warehouse Market, Though Cooling, Is Still Healthy
description: THE nation's softening economy notwithstanding, warehouse distribution centers the size of football fields continue to sprout around exits of the New Jersey Turnpike, while older industrial buildings in the Meadowlands are being bulldozed to make way for new ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLICKMAN, NEWTON A.
description: BLICKMAN-Newton A. Age 83, died April 15, 2001, at his home in Pearl River, NY. Engineer (Cornell Class of '38), manufacturer and executive, recipient in 1969 of NASA astronauts' award for equiping the Lunar Receiving Laboratory for Apollo Eleven lunar samples. Survived by daughter Victoria Jacqueney and grandson Benjamin of West New York, NJ; son Stewart of Pearl River; sisters Beverly Yunich of Scarsdale and Gloria Horwitz, of Rochester. Predeceased by his brother Bernard and by his wife of 54 years, the former Nancy Copeland. For those wishing to make a charitable donation, the family suggests: Cornell University Office of Scholarship Development, 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850; or the Historical Society of Rockland; or Nyack Hospital Foundation.

title: A New Colossus Begins to Rise
description: IT HAS TAKEN twice as long to redevelop the site of the New York Coliseum -- 16 years and counting -- as it took the Romans to build the original. But today, fresh steel columns are finally sprouting on Columbus Circle where the Coliseum once stood.

title: Blood, Sweat And Fellowship
description: I THOUGHT my first job was the worst that existed; it was dirty and demeaning and included backbreaking physical labor. But it taught me important lessons.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: The moral complexity of Gregory L. Vistica's superbly nuanced article (April 29) serves to reveal the absurdity inherent in all the guff we keep hearing about the ''greatest generation.'' Those valiant foot soldiers of World War II reached middle age and sent their sons to die and kill in a war that no one dares call good.

description: To the Editor:

title: Little Current, Now 30, Still Likes His Sweets
description: The oldest living winner of a Triple Crown race is Little Current, who is pensioned at Maverick Veterinary Clinic in Monroe, Wash., 40 miles north of Seattle. In 1974 Little Current won the Preakness by seven lengths, and three weeks later he had a seven- length triumph in the Belmont.

description: ALL WE KNOW

title: The Island Is Rich in History, and in Places to Relive It
description: HAWKING the glories, distinctions and accomplishments of their individual communities, about 100 historical societies tell Long Island's story from Colonial days to the present. Add history museums run by counties, towns and villages and nonprofit groups commemorating specific people and industries (for example, the Indian Museum in Southold and whaling museums in Cold Spring Harbor and Sag Harbor) or immortalizing special families (like Raynham Hall in Oyster Bay that keeps the Townsends alive for posterity) and Long Island is a veritable map of historic steppingstones that in many cases are only a few miles apart.

description: THE TOMB OF THE BOY KING

title: A Horse Mystery Puts Kentucky on Edge
description: Across the fields of bluegrass, the mystery of what has been aborting this year's crop of thoroughbred foals at an alarming rate finds Jimmy C. Henning, the lead agronomist on the detective team, painstakingly combing pastures where the suspects range from stealthy mycotoxins to ubiquitous tent caterpillars.

description: JI BAEK remembers her panic the moment she realized that in all the planning for her wedding, one crucial detail had escaped real scrutiny: the officiating judge.

description: Theories abound as to why skunks are suddenly sweet on Buffalo.

title: Eleanor D'Aponte, Garrett Bywaters
description: Eleanor Hayes D'Aponte and Garrett Lee Bywaters were married yesterday at the Oratory Roman Catholic Church of St. Boniface in Brooklyn. The Rev. Mark Lane performed the ceremony.

title: Former Onassis Yacht Now Takes Bookings
description: The yacht Christina O, which once belonged to Aristotle Onassis, will take up to 36 passengers through the Greek Isles between Aug. 30 and Oct. 19. For $8,750 a person in double occupancy, Tauck World Discovery of Westport, Conn., offers 10-night packages that include seven-night voyages on the vessel. A similar program is planned next spring and fall, and the 325-foot yacht is available for charter at other times of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLINS, THOMAS
description: MULLINS-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Mullins, associated with The Times since 1993.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, ROSE S.
description: SINGER-Rose S. On May 18, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Henry and Amy Singer, Elizabeth and Dennis Hevey, Margery and Steven Honig. Adoring grandmother of Priscilla and Jamie Halper, Andrew and Nancy Singer, Stephanie and Brad Ebner, Lauren Singer, Gillian and Jennifer Mosely and Casey Honig. Cherished great-grandmother of Paige, Maxwell, Matthew, Adam, Daniel, Sabrina, Brooke, Alexa, Grant and Samantha. Nana Rose will be missed by everyone whose life she touched. Service private.

description: TEITELBAUM-Lucia M. (nee Helmick). On May 16, 2001, of Orangeburg, NY. Visiting hours Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Moritz Funeral Home, Tappan, NY; 845-359-0890.

title: Victoria Bulkley, Nicholas Banks
description: Victoria Grosvenor Bulkley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Jack Bulkley III of Lawrence, N.Y., was married last evening to Nicholas Henry McMichen Banks, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Nelson Lee Banks of Dunkirk, N.Y. The Rev. Craig D. Townsend, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in New York.

title: May 13-19; U.N. May Ease Iraq Embargo
description: Facing the fact that support for sanctions on Iraq has eroded and that Saddam Hussein is winning what Secretary General Kofi Annan once called the ''propaganda war'' over the damage to Iraqi people, Britain and the United States are proposing an end to a trade ban in civilian goods. Iraq would not be able to import weapons, however, and would still have to deposit oil earnings in a U.N. escrow account. ''What we're not going to do is give Saddam back the money to spend on what he wants,'' a diplomat said.

description: Florida and national Democratic Party officials today were polite but skeptical that former Attorney General Janet Reno could raise their chances of unseating Gov. Jeb Bush, the president's brother, in next year's election.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: I wish that your writer and all those involved in publishing this article had been in Kerrey's boots -- those of an inexperienced 25-year-old lieutenant afraid, that night in the muggy darkness, that he and his men would be ambushed by the Vietcong and never make it out of that jungle alive if they didn't take some action. Whose lives would Kerrey have been responsible for if all of his men had died?

title: Susannah McCorkle Dies; Pop and Jazz Singer Was 55
description: Susannah McCorkle, the sultry voiced pop-jazz singer who brought a rare literary refinement to popular standards, was found dead outside her apartment at 41 West 86th Street early yesterday morning. She was 55.

description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY had Paris in the 20's. Judy Garland headlined at the Palace. Neil Armstrong got a walk on the moon. And Gary Beach and Roger Bart will always have ''The Producers.''

title: In Belfast, a Merger of Science and Art
description: The sprawling Odyssey Center complex in Belfast's docklands made headlines last year for two reasons. First, its arena housed the city's first and only ice-hockey team, the Giants, for its phenomenally popular opening season. And second, it wasn't the Millennium Dome. Despite the many parallels with the ill-fated London project, people so far have actually enjoyed going to the Odyssey Center.

title: In Congers, a Kitchen Performs at Its Peak
description: SOME diners might consider pairing dining at Restaurant X with a trip to the nearby Palisades Mall or with a weekend vacation in the mountains or the lake lands beyond. But not 10 miles from the Tappan Zee Bridge, Peter Xaviar Kelly's restaurant, with its comfortable chairs, sophisticated dcor, attentive service and finely crafted fare, is splendid enough to be a destination in itself.

title: When in Rome, Do What You Always Do
description: IT was hard, at the start of our honeymoon in Bali, explaining to my wife why I wanted to go back to the hotel room for my running shoes after a morning on the beach. I had the same trouble, while staying with a friend in Kyoto, when I insisted on lying down after lunch. Or trying to find a serviceable typewriter some years ago in Guadalajara. Don't get me wrong: I like exotic locales -- take me to the marketplace in Bukkitingi, lead me to the Mayan ruins -- but I'm also a creature of habit.

description: AFTER graduation ceremonies are over today at Quinnipiac University in Hamden, things will settle into summer mode. But while the setting may be bucolic, things will not be quiet, because construction is under way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEARS, SALLY
description: SEARS-Sally. A producer of Broadway and off-Broadway theater for almost thirty years, died April 15, 2001, Easter Sunday, at her home in New York City. Ms. Sears was a patron of the arts and was especially devoted to the performing arts. She was a co-producer of the Broadway revival of ''Royal Society'' with Eva LeGallienne, Rosemary Harris and Sam Levene, was associate producer of ''Night of the Tribads'' with Max von Sydow and Bibi Andersson, and ''An Almost Perfect Person'' with Colleen Dewhurst. Individually and through her production company, Primavera Productions, Ltd., she produced seven offBroadway plays, including ''Nellie Toole'' with Sylvia Miles and Stefan Gierasch, and ''Please Don't Cry and Say No''. Ms. Sears also developed a number of cabaret productions that featured and fostered the careers of young and aspiring writers, musicians and performers. Ms. Sears was a granddaughter of Congresswoman Ruth Baker Pratt. She was a graduate of Milton Academy and studied ballet with Marie Lambert in London and with Margaret Craske at the Metropolitan Opera Ballet School. She is survived by her brothers, Robert H. Thayer, Jr. and Steven B. Thayer.

title: Wendy Prior, Andrew Fentress
description: Wendy Elizabeth Prior, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Prior of Quogue, N.Y., was married last evening to Andrew Dodd Fentress, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Lee Fentress of Washington. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker, an Episcopal priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Marks Church in Westhampton Beach, N.Y.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: If one of the dead in Thanh Phong could give her view of events, a painful real-life remake of Kurosawa's film ''Rashomon'' would be complete. In the Japanese movie, four people give four versions of a murder, including the victim, who speaks through a medium. In the end, none of the stories, not even the victim's, seem fully reliable. As in the Thanh Phong incident, guilt or innocence becomes less important than each storyteller's desire to salvage self-respect.

title: INVESTING WITH/Maura A. Shaughnessy; MFS Utilities Fund
description: NORMALLY, Maura A. Shaughnessy has close to $1 billion, or 35 percent of her fund's portfolio, invested in foreign utilities. But these days, with a power crisis in parts of the United States, she figures that there is much less reason to look overseas. So Ms. Shaughnessy, who runs the $2.66 billion MFS Utilities fund, has trimmed her international holdings to just 15 percent of the fund's assets, the lowest level since December 1996.

description: WORLD War I was so vile that nobody expected to see anything like it ever again. The lads who marched into fire, bombs, mud and poisonous gas would never be forgotten.

Much loved cousin, aunt and great aunt. We will always remember her for her remarkable spirit, joy for life and love of family & friends. Services were held in Florida.

title: Another Civil War Battle: Buying Hallowed Ground
description: HARPER'S FERRY, W.Va., is best known for John Brown's uprising against slavery. But in 1862, it was also the place where Gen. Stonewall Jackson of the Confederacy took the surrender of 12,500 Union troops, the largest capitulation of the Civil War.

title: May 13-19; Fear Itself
description: It bounds across moonlit rooftops above the teeming narrow steets of Delhi, snakes its clawed fingers through locked doors and gated windows, mauls victims with terrifying speed and disappears without a trace.

title: Political Briefing; Willie Brown Backers Criticize Newspaper
description: Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco has had his differences with The San Francisco Chronicle through the years. The paper did not endorse him when he first ran in 1995, but it backed him when he sought re-election in 1999.

title: The Amazin' Mr. Met Suits Up Again
description: DAN REILLY remembers the exhilaration of putting on his New York Mets uniform for the first time in 1964, the roar of the Shea Stadium crowd as he stepped onto the field. He recalls the weight on his shoulders as children cried out to him, desperate for an autograph. But Mr. Reilly, a weathered leprechaun of a man who at 60 still exudes childlike good cheer, was never a player; he was the original Mr. Met, Major League Baseball's first human mascot. And the burden he shouldered was literal, a gargantuan plaster of paris head shaped like a baseball and adorned with a winning grin.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-20-01: Five from Stevie Nicks; Tuning In
description: What makes a rock 'n' roll album great? According to Stevie Nicks, the former Fleetwood Mac singer whose new solo album, ''Trouble in Shangri-La,'' was released earlier this month and quickly entered the Billboard Top 10, the songs have to tell real stories. ''If the lyrics are not saying something important,'' she says, ''it's going to be a song that you like for a couple weeks and then never think about again.'' Here, Nicks lists the best rock 'n' roll albums from the 1970's and thereabouts.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: To paraphrase a line from the movie ''A Few Good Men,'' ''We can't handle the truth.'' The truth is that Vietnam was a blood bath for both sides. A madness reigned there, a madness that was missing from the gulf war and the Balkans. There are many, many more of these incidents that will never come to light, and perhaps that is best. For there is no worse retribution than the daily payback these Vietnam vets endure. Another truth is that most vets have tried (against the odds, in some cases) to live meaningful lives, lives that make up for what went on in Vietnam, as Bob Kerrey has.

title: Personal Business Diary: When an Interviewer Crosses the Line
description: College students often spend much time preparing for the onslaught of corporate recruiters who visit their campuses each spring. After all, how the students present themselves during interviews may affect their careers.

description: What was Gregory Vistica's motive in writing this expos of Kerrey? It would appear that it may have been to garner a ''medal of honor'' for himself from his journalistic cadre.

title: Rewarding the Crew Aboard a Sinking Ship
description: WHEN he learned that roughly 6,000 employees at Pacific Gas and Electric had received pay raises and portions of their annual bonuses just days before the company filed for bankruptcy in April, Harvey Rosenfield was outraged. ''These people shouldn't even have a job,'' said Mr. Rosenfield, president of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, an advocacy group in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Fidelity Also Buys, a Lot
description: Fidelity Investments, the nation's biggest mutual fund manager, attracted much attention last week in reporting wholesale divestment of high-technology favorites in the first quarter -- 49 percent of its stake in EMC, 45 percent of its Oracle shares and 44 percent of its shares of Cisco Systems. That left Fidelity's funds with smaller weightings in these stocks than they represent in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

title: An Exhibit's Novel Theme: The Artists Own Hard Hats
description: High in a corner of a toilet stall at the Brooklyn Arts Exchange, a tiny white head surveys the goings-on below. The head has been there two years, ever since a couple of construction workers came across a discarded fist-size clump of plaster, fashioned it into a bald head with a winking face and stuck it on the wall.

title: Ideas & Trends; Matrimony: The Magic's Still Gone
description: THE social contract was straightforward when Jane Austen examined the manners and mores of upper-class England nearly 200 years ago. It was a truth universally acknowledged back then that a single man in possession of a good fortune must be in want of a wife. And a single woman, by definition, must be in want of a husband, preferably one in possession of a good fortune.

title: Stendhal's Florence, With E-Mail and Pucci
description: I HAD no illusions about Florence: It is one of the biggest box office draws in tourism. And while my dream was to wander in silent reverie among Renaissance treasures and elegant palazzi, I knew it was more likely I'd be struck by Stendhal's syndrome in the company of busloads of tourists. Still, I was not prepared for the crowds -- no, throngs -- I encountered in the city on my four-day April visit.

Walden, the youngest son of the late Ben Walden Sr., grew up on his father's Dearborn Farm near Lexington in the heart of Bluegrass country.

title: Weighing Options in Alarm Systems
description: THE effectiveness of home burglar alarms is still open to debate. Whether an alarm system works to deter break-ins largely depends on the system itself. It seems that an alarm system with lights and sirens may not be as effective as one that is connected to a law enforcement agency.

title: Wines Aplenty to Top Off the Season
description: IN summertime, the fish are jumpin', as the ''Porgy and Bess'' libretto by DuBose Heyward and Ira Gershwin reminds us. Nobody, I think, has interviewed any fish -- not even the notoriously talkative dolphins -- to learn why they start jumpin' joyfully at the summer solstice. In Long Island waters, perhaps those jumpin' fish are sayin' it is better to swim in a sauce with white wine than in chilly waters. They'll find out soon enough, as will their shellfish brethren.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: JUDY BENJAMIN is 29, a happily pampered suburban princess who has just basked in all the attention of being a second-time bride. Then her new husband drops dead during their honeymoon. Understandably depressed, Judy (Goldie Hawn at her most adorable) falls prey to a persuasive Army recruiter. Only after she arrives at boot camp does she realize that the ''new army'' is pretty much like the old one. PRIVATE BENJAMIN (1980) is one of Ms. Hawn's finest comedies -- and one of the few truly feminist mainstream films of the last couple of decades. Howard Zieff directed the script by Nancy Meyers, Charles Shyer and Harvey Miller. Armand Assante is memorable as the sexy European who may become Judy's third husband. Eileen Brennan is priceless as the sadistic commanding officer, who can't wait to get her hands on a real-live rich girl -- Friday at 10:30 p.m. on TBS.

Brutal honesty is the plat du jour in this searing, often hilarious expos of the Manhattan restaurant business (and the cooking life) by the executive chef at the Brasserie Les Halles. Thompson, Iggy Pop and a little Jonathan Swift, Bourdain gleefully rips through the scenery to reveal private backstage horrors little dreamed of by the trusting public,'' Thomas McNamee wrote here last year.

title: A Much-Scuffed Monument to Genius
description: LEONARDO DA VINCI'S ''Last Supper'' in the refectory of Santa Maria Delle Grazie, completed in 1498, counts among a handful of images that divide art history into Before and After. Yet its original glory soon fled. Painted in an experimental and, as it proved, highly perishable fresco technique, the work began to show marked deterioration by 1517. Another half century later, Giorgio Vasari, author of ''The Lives of the Most Eminent Italian Architects, Painters and Sculptors,'' considered ''The Last Supper'' no more than a ''macchia abbagliata,'' a phrase difficult to interpret, perhaps best rendered as a ''bewildering smudge.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMITT, KATHLEEN
description: SCHMITT-Kathleen. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Kathleen Schmitt, associated with The Times from 1947 to 1957.

title: How to Hide a House
description: It's not the sort of house you'd expect to find in a leafy New Jersey town: a big, galvanized-steel shed that would seem more at home in an industrial park. But that's only the beginning. Lift up one of the shed's big garage doors, and you find a tiny clapboard cottage -- much more in keeping with this part of the world -- at one end of the cavernous space. But at the other end is a 27-foot-high, 33-foot-wide grid of nine rooms that looks like a cross between a 1950's elementary school and the set of ''Hollywood Squares.'' In the space between the cottage and the grid, there is arranged the kind of elegant furniture that you find in a nice suburban house -- where the owners could avail themselves of the services of a very good decorator. So what is this place?

title: Ideas & Trends; Birds Do It. Bees Do It. Some People Do, Too.
description: CHILDREN, sit up straight and stop canoodling in the back there! This is Sex Ed revision and there's a lot to take in. The curriculum is entirely different from last year because of all we have been learning from the studies of evolutionary biologists.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Somerset, N.J.; Diversity, Stability and Convenience
description: WEDGED between the city of New Brunswick and the more rural southern section of Franklin Township, Somerset, N.J., is a model of diversity. The village's neighborhoods vary from tightly packed urban areas along the New Brunswick city line to sprawling, tree-lined suburban developments of hundreds of houses on half-acre lots. Although one-third of its school population lives in poverty, Somerset is also a magnet for young professionals, who are drawn to its stable neighborhoods, convenient shopping and easy commuting to Manhattan.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: Bob Kerrey went to Vietnam to serve his country. I did not. I am a month younger than he is. I protested the war and refused to participate. Is Kerrey now to be shamed because he went there, did what the United States government told him to do (by implication), won honors for losing his leg and came home a hero? Does my avoidance of service in Vietnam mean I am disloyal? I'd say no -- to both questions.

title: Business; For Warner Music, Online Opportunities
description: THE headquarters of Warner Brothers Records, home to Madonna and the Red Hot Chili Peppers, could symbolize the troubled company's fate. Designed in the mid-1970's by a trend-setting West Coast architect, the building, in Burbank, Calif., once echoed Warner's huge success as an artist-friendly label. Now it is known derisively as the ski chalet or the country club to its critics -- including Roger Ames, head of the Warner Music Group, the AOL Time Warner unit that includes the Warner Brothers, Atlantic and Elektra labels.

title: For Wildlife, Some Reasons to Celebrate, and to Join the Party
description: LARGE, brown pelicans can often be seen gliding above the breakers just offshore or perched on wooden pilings. Atlantic bottlenose dolphins can be spotted giving birth just off the beach, and even, on rare occasions, a manatee can be seen swimming along the shore.

title: The $4 Trillion Tax Cut
description: Soon after the Congress passed President Ronald Reagan's big tax cut in 1981, a few in the administration realized that their achievement amounted to a Pyrrhic victory. The tax cut, as it was taken up by lawmakers, grew out of all proportion, creating huge deficits that strangled the budget and the economy for nearly 15 years. Exactly the same prospect is in store if Congress approves the misshapen, misconceived tax cut now racing through Capitol Hill. The Senate is aiming to conclude its version of the tax cut this week, with President Bush hoping to sign it into law by Memorial Day. Yet with every passing day, the tax cut's flaws become more obvious.

The number of days each summer with the most severe ozone smog is typically no more than a third of what it was in the early 1980's.

title: What Happened in Thanh Phong
description: As a 23-year-old lieutenant, I was sent to Vietnam to lead men (more precisely, boys) in combat. Upon arrival, I, too, was presented with a manual on the ''rules of engagement'' and taught the meaning of a ''free-fire zone.'' I soon learned that the name of the game was the body count, which was reported ''upstairs'' weekly in a statistical scorecard. I had no desire to go to Hanoi with a knife clenched in my teeth. My ambition was to be a good soldier, take care of my men, get us all home to our families and, most of all, not to mess up.

Policy wonks who salt their op-eds with pop-culture references in order to simulate youth now have a new catch phrase, ''disrespecting the Bing,'' to kick around. (For those benighted folk who don't keep up with ''The Sopranos,'' the reference is not to Bing Crosby but to the Bada Bing, a strip joint which is prominently featured in the series.) President Clinton was hounded for not wanting to serve, yet every man and woman who did fight in that war is tainted by the killing that went on there. What is the point of all this now? title: CRIME

Matt McBride, a New Jersey real estate broker and contented family man, goes nuts when an exotic young artist he barely knew disappears, leaving a diary identifying him as her secret lover. Instead of clearing himself with the police and his frantic wife, Matt falls apart, obsessed with his relationship with the woman (''Was he inventing? Imagining?''), who puts him in mind of another missing girl he once knew. Real or imagined, Matt's sense of involvement leads to paroxysms of guilt and desire and a reckless search for the ''artist'' who killed them.

title: Ellsworth Kelly's Little Patch of Eden
description: The latest from Ellsworth Kelly -- more blasts of dizzy color married in rectangular combinations of sublime geometry -- is the epitome of civilized discourse. Based on the subtlest distinctions of form and color, wherein the difference of an inch in size or the position of a panel on a wall comes to resemble a moral choice, Kelly's works presume that we are the sort of people attuned to such subtleties. They seem to say, ''You are clever because you see that simplicity is never easily achieved.'' But they do not insist that we pay attention. They are simply there, holding the door open to a better world, a world washed clean and untroubled, leaving up to us the decision whether to cross the threshold.

title: May 13-19; Spy-Plane Papers Survived

Officials concede that China gained information about how the surveillance flights operate from papers not pushed out a hatch or coated with acid. But the pilot's efforts to wrestle the damaged plane to a safe landing on Hainan Island, where it remains, and the crew's efficiency in destroying as much as it did, earned them a visit to the White House and medals. title: What Has Become of William
description: It is only when you get inside the British Parliament that you understand why it is called the ''Palace of Westminster.'' An enormous late-Victorian pile of pretension, it is built to look like some medieval cathedral rather than a modern Parliament. Giant pre-Raphaelite murals bear down on you; apparatchiks in white tie and tails ferry you about; stained-glass windows give the complex a funereal air. In the central meeting place, I wait under a huge bust of Gladstone, the towering figure of 19th-century English liberalism. And as if in some odd dream, I'm greeted by Sebastian Coe, the Olympic gold-medal-winning runner of the 1980's, and ushered through winding stairways and corridors into a guest seat on the floor of the Commons. Lord Coe, as he is now known, is private secretary for William Hague, the leader of the opposition.

title: Last Right
description: Last fall, a friend asked if she could jump out my 11th-floor window. She had esophageal cancer and was planning ahead. If the chemotherapy didn't shrink her tumor, and if surgery didn't offer her continued life, she wanted something ''swift and certain.'' Pills wouldn't be an option if she couldn't swallow anymore. She didn't have a doctor to assist her dying, so injectible morphine would be harder to get. Five years ago, she was hit by a vehicle in Mexico. ''The impact didn't hurt,'' she told me, and she figured that hitting the ground wouldn't either.

title: For Artists, Vacation Just Means a New Landscape
description: BY and large, artists shed the bohemian image long ago. They lead regular lives, which means that they take vacations like everybody else. But there's the conundrum: art is not a job, but a calling that's not easily switched off. Several New Jersey artists were asked whether they can take a vacation from art, and if not, how do they satisfy its demands when their art follows them out of the studio.

description: As an observant Hindu, Brij Sharma considers cows sacred. He believes the gentle creatures are helpmates to human beings, and it would be as unthinkable for him to eat beef as it would for a cowboy in Montana to eat his own horse.

title: Nai Soi's Long-Necked Women
description: THE tourists had gone for the day, pictures taken, souvenirs in hand, and the little settlement of Nai Soi near the border of Myanmar had reverted to the ordinary rhythms of village life. One woman rocked a baby in a hammock. One lay back in a chair and strummed a guitar. A group of small girls played jacks. And in the hot late-afternoon sun eight barefoot women played a noisy game of volleyball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWSTER, HERBERT DANIEL
description: BREWSTER-Herbert Daniel. Retired foreign service officer, died April 29 with complications from pneumonia & prostate cancer. He had held posts in Beirut, Athens, Paris, Berlin and Naples. Most of his 34 year career focused on Greece. Appointed Greek Country Director in 1966, Brewster spoke out against the 1967 Greek ''junta'' and urged vigorous U.S. opposition. He is survived by his wife Susan Holleran at their Washington, D.C. home, & 3 children: David of Chicago; Robert of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; and Tisha of Berkeley, California. and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 1PM, Saturday, May 26, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 2430 K Street N.W., Washington, D.C., reception to follow. The family requests that donations be made in his name to: The American Farm School, 1133 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10010; or Anatolia College/American College of Thessaloniki, 130 Bowdoin St, Suite 1201, Boston, MA. 02108.

title: Club Meeting Today
description: From granddaughters to grandmothers, women are wearing a spring jacket or coat in a black or white fabric with novelty pinstripes of miniature sequins as a subtle embellishment. The spongy synthetic camellia can easily be removed if the wearer tires of it. The success of this design by Karl Lagerfeld for Chanel lies in its variations of length, flattering cut, square pearlized buttons, and practicality -- for office, lunch or black-tie events.

title: A Boost for Booster Seats
description: THE nightmare that hovers over everyone who loves a child was nearly played out for me almost 40 years ago, when I had the morning route on a five-child car pool from Upper Manhattan into the Bronx. Our younger son, Ben, was not old enough for school, but I could not leave him alone. Cars then had no seat belts, so he rode home in the back seat unsecured. When I jammed on the brakes because a car ahead of us stopped short, the passenger seat flopped forward and Ben hurtled over it into the space under the dashboard. He howled but was not injured. We got home somehow, but to this day I annoy my family by extending my right palm onto any passenger's abdomen when I brake suddenly. ''We have belts on!'' they cry. ''This is not 1962!''

title: Oporto
description: The jury is still out in Oporto. For some Portuenses, the designation of their city as Europe's Cultural Capital this year -- in tandem with Rotterdam -- is their proudest moment since Oporto won the European soccer championship in 1987. For others it's a catastrophe, because much of the city is a construction site.

title: Europe by Car
description: One more variation on the familiar European fly-drive plan: The IMTC-Pegasus Good-Buy package includes a seven-day rental of a Europcar economy-size car, with unlimited mileage, the VAT and collision-damage waiver and theft-waiver insurance (but no air-conditioning or automatic transmission). And there's round-trip air fare to any of six European cities (Brussels, Amsterdam, Paris, Budapest, Prague or Vienna) from major East Coast cities as well as Chicago and Dallas. The price: from $699 to Brussels to $770 for Vienna, per person based on two people sharing one car. Information: (800) 790-4682 or www.imtc-travel.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVENNEY, RAYMOND K.
description: DEVENNEY-Raymond K. On May 17, 2001 at his Manhattan home at age 84. A valued member of The Olayan Group for 24 years, Mr. Devenney was Executive Vice President of the group's U.S. subsidiary, Olayan America Corporation, at the time of his passing. He joined the group's New York office in July 1977 following a career as a financial executive with the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) in Dhahran, Saudia Arabia, and Houston, TX, that spanned some three decades. Originally from Kansas, he held a B.S. in finance from the University of Kansas. Mr. Devenney is survived by his wife of 54 years, Kay; their daughter Bunny Devenney of New York City; nephew Scott Devenney of Hawaii; niece Pamela Devenney-Peppers of New Canaan, CT; her husband Donald Peppers; and their children, Tess, Margot, and Bryce. A memorial service will be held at 5 PM on May 30, 2001 at the Church of Our Lady of Peace on 62nd Street in Manhattan, NY between Second and Third Avenues. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to the Wolk Heart Foundation, 520 East 72nd St., NY NY 10021

title: New Yorker Has Low Hopes for New Peru Trial
description: It is Sunday at the high-security women's prison in the grimy neighborhood of Chorrillos. Visitors bring corn on the cob, spicy rice dishes and stories from home to relatives and friends, many of whom have been convicted of terrorism. Sweet love songs play on radios and there are laughter and hugs in the courtyard.

title: Schools Get Tool to Track Students' Use of Internet
description: Like millions of American high school students, Matthew T. Veck spends a good deal of time on the Internet, both for classwork and for fun. And like any other high school student being interviewed by a newspaper reporter on the record for a national publication, he says that he would never, ever look for pornography online using his school's computers. Even if the Shoshone, Idaho, student's curiosity threatened to overcome his better impulses, he says he would think twice about acting on his newfound interest at school, ''because I know for a fact I would be caught right away.''

I don't spend all my time reading Danish philosophy in my room. I'm much more at home with a beer watching the basketball playoffs.'' E3

title: Europeans Dominate the Awards, Sometimes Unexpectedly, as Cannes Ends
description: European films dominated the closing ceremony of the 54th Cannes International Film Festival this evening. The festival jury, presided over by Liv Ullman, gave the Palme d'Or, its highest award, to ''The Son's Room,'' a film by the Italian director Nanni Moretti about a middle-class family struggling to cope with its grief after the death of a teenager in a scuba-diving accident. ''The Piano Teacher,'' a French-language movie set in Vienna and directed by Michael Haneke, who is Austrian, scored a minor sweep, winning both acting awards -- for Isabelle Huppert and Benot Magimel -- and the jury's Grand Prix for Mr. Haneke.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: School Budget Approval
description: Voters' approval rate of school construction rose sharply after passage of a law last year to help projects in poor districts, a new study reported. The analysis by the New Jersey School Boards Association found that 80.9 percent of school projects were approved last year, up from 71.4 percent the year before. But David Sciara, a lawyer for students in the 30 low-income districts that were to benefit from the new law, said that no projects for the districts had been approved. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DITTELMAN, LAWRENCE R.
description: DITTELMAN-Lawrence R. 58, on May 18, 2001, after a heroic battle against multiple myeloma. Beloved husband of Sharon, cherished father of Andrea, Robin, and Kenneth, loving grandfather of Jacob and Jordan and adoring son of Jean and the late Harold. A kind, sweet man held dear by all who knew and loved him. A pillar of the legal community, Mr. Dittelman was a senior partner in the law firm of Wormser, Kiely, Galef & Jacobs, and managing partner of the firm's White Plains office since 1982. A dean of the municipal and land use bar of Westchester County, he served as counsel to the Town of New Castle for 27 years and represented numerous other local governments and real estate developers throughout the Hudson Valley region. Brilliant, ethical and compassionate, he symbolized the highest traditions of the legal profession earning the unswerving loyalty of his clients and the utmost respect of his colleagues and adversaries. Mr. Dittelman graduated cum laude from both Union College where he was a member of Phi Beta Kapa, and from Columbia Law School where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar and editor of the Journal of Law and Social Problems. He was a past president and member of the Board of Directors of the Westchester Legal Aid Society and a founding member of the Edwin G. Michaelian Municipal Law Resource Center of Pace University. Services will be held on Monday, May 21, at 12:30 PM at Congregation Sons of Israel, 1666 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 12650 Riverside Drive, North Hollywood, CA 91607.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Survey Details Bias Against Gays
description: About a third of homosexuals surveyed across New York State report discrimination on the job, from harassment to dismissal, according to a new poll commissioned by the Empire State Pride Agenda, a gay and lesbian advocacy group. About half of the 1,891 people surveyed also reported being harassed or denied service in public places in the past five years. The survey was conducted between January and March and was released yesterday, on the eve of a rally to urge passage of an anti-discrimination law. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Wilmington: Santa's Workshop Sale

Cunningham, was negotiating to buy Santa's Workshop last month when he was charged with stealing more than $63,000 from a construction company where he worked as a consultant. Robert Reiss, the owner of the theme park, called Mr. Cunningham's indictment unsettling, but said the sale should close in two weeks. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

The category includes high-resolution monitors that require a separate digital receiver or set-top box, fully integrated digital sets with built-in receivers and wide-format high-definition digital TV sets. When deep in thought at the table, which he often was, it was his habit to twist a lock a hair between finger and thumb. Not knowing that he was multilingual, a Frenchwoman playing against him asked her partner if she should ''offer the poor man a bobby pin.'' She was highly embarrassed when von Zedtwitz responded in perfect French: ''Thank you. I do not think that will be necessary.''

title: Attack on the International Court
description: Unhappy that President Clinton signed the global treaty creating an international criminal court, some officials in the Bush administration and some members of Congress are trying to get Washington to pressure other countries to reject it. This effort would strain America's already uneasy relations with its allies and limit the administration's flexibility on important national security matters. The Bush administration would better serve American interests by trying to change the provisions of the court it considers harmful.

title: Woody Allen, So Sorry He's Funny
description: Woody Allen has built a brilliant career out of self-deprecation. In film after film he has played the hapless nerd and with implausible regularity managed to wind up with the girl and win over the critics. On Saturday in a rare formal public appearance at the New York Public Library, he demonstrated how the same comic diffidence that has served him on the big screen can work to his advantage in the court of public opinion.

description: Living in a small town may provide fresh air, friendly townsfolk and a relaxed lifestyle, but it could not provide identical twins and budding track stars with the feeling of individuality they so desperately wanted.

title: AIDS in Prisons
description: Tens of thousands of prisoners around the country are infected with the virus that causes AIDS, making prisons one of the most potentially dangerous incubators of the epidemic. The infected inmates need health care that is often unavailable in prison, and their fellow prisoners need protection from contracting the virus. The concentration of people with the AIDS virus in prisons means that healthy inmates run an increased risk of catching the disease by having sex or sharing hypodermic needles with them -- behaviors that are illegal but widespread in American prisons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRY, ROBERT EMMET
description: CURRY-Robert Emmet. Husband of the late Rose (Mooney), father of Robert Emmet Curry Jr., father-in-law of Margaret Kennedy Curry, grandfather of Robert Emmet Curry III and Bevin Kennedy Curry, brother of Bernard F. Curry and the late John F. Curry Jr., Veronica C. McCarthy and Francis R. Curry, and brother-in-law of Katherine M. Mooney and the late Florence M. Halleran, Daniel J. Mooney Jr., and Helen M. Gretsch. He is also survived by numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. A son of John F. and Mary Curry, he was born at home on April 4, 1913. His father was a leader of Tammany Hall from 1929 to 1933. He graduated from the Collegiate School, where he was captain of the basketball team, and from Georgetown University. He served in the US Army from 1935 through 1946, with a two-year hiatus, and was discharged as a Lt. Colonel while an instructor at West Point. Thereafter he spent his career at the John F. Curry Agency, an insurance brokerage, retiring as Chairman of the Board. Active in civil affairs, he served as Vice Chair of the first Board of Corrections of the City of New York from 1957-1960, and as Chairman through 1964. In addition to being a former President of the Catholic Big Brothers of New York, he was a founder and director of the Big Brothers/Big Sisters of America. He also founded and later served as President of the Georgetown University Club of Metropolitan New York. He was a life member of The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York and for over 40 years, a member of the Rockaway Hunting Club. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Lexington Ave. at 66 St., Wednesday, 10:30 AM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, GEORGE A.
description: FOX-George A. United American Energy Corp. (UAE) celebrates the life of George A. Fox, who, with three other engineers, helped create a vision of building environmentally sensitive electric power generating plants as private sector businesses. George Fox was a founding member and served on the Board of Directors of UAE between 1980 and 1998. George Fox's wisdom, advice, and tenacity were instrumental in creating a sound direction for UAE and guiding the company through its start-up phase. Most importantly, George modeled a profound respect for engineering and business principals and ethics, attention to details and dignity in dealing with employees, other stakeholders and the public. George was an extraordinary engineer and a superb artist, who combined these talents to bring people together to accomplish ambitious goals. He has been a great teacher and has inspired us all. UAE has lost a valued advisor, a brilliant businessman and engineer, and a kind and special friend. David Goodman, Chairman, CEO United American Energy Corp.

description: SEGGERMAN-Harry G.A. Of Fairfield, CT, died Saturday, May 19, 2001. He was the beloved husband of Anne Crellin Seggerman. Born in New York City, Harry Seggerman was a 1949 graduate of Princeton University and began his career as a securities analyst at Dominick & Dominick on Wall Street, subsequently working for the Capital Research Group. President of the Japan Fund, launched by PaineWebber and Prudential Bache. Seggerman was co-founder and Vice Chairman of Fidelity Pacific. In 1992, he founded International Investment Advisers, which manages the Korea International Investment Funds. Devoted father of Patricia Seggerman of Fairfield, CT, Marianne Seggerman of Westport, CT, Yvonne Seggerman Beauregard of Cumberland, RI, Suzanne Seggerman of New York, NY, Henry Seggerman of West Los Angeles, and John Seggerman of Arlington, VA and brother of Frederick Seggerman of Milford, CT. Friends may call at the Redgate-Hennessy Funeral Home, Main St. and Gorham Place, Trumbull, CT on Friday, May 25 from 4-8PM. Funeral services will be held Saturday, May 26, 2001 at 11:00 AM in Holy Family Church, Fairfield, with a Mass of Christian Burial.

title: Robert LaChapelle, Marlborough Gallery, New York, May 7, 2001
description: e were moving nine pieces into the Marlborough Gallery for the exhibit of Botero's sculptures. We've worked for the Whitney, Sotheby's, the Met. We've moved Rembrandts. That's more money than me and a lot of other people put together make. But we can't take the time to think about how valuable it is. We handle it all the same. We were picking the pieces up off the trailer with a crane. First, we set them down in the garden, and then the artist's representative would tell us where to move them so they look nice. People were slamming on the brakes thinking, What's that on the truck? I'm on more strangers' video cameras than I care to know about. But you wouldn't believe how stupid half of New York is. We'll be hanging something that weighs tons, and they roll a baby carriage underneath. The typical New Yorker never looks up."

Lauren Torrelli, a sophomore, led the Vikings with victories in the 100-meter hurdles (16.0 seconds) and 400-meter hurdles (68.7 seconds). title: World Briefing | Asia: Mongolia: Ex-Communist Re-elected
description: President Natsagiin Bagabandi has been re-elected by a large majority, further consolidating the return of the reformed version of the Communist Party, which once ruled the country with a tight grip. The party, which now pledges allegience to ''social democracy,'' lost parliamentary power in 1996 when democratic reformers swept the legislature but regained it last year after voters became fed up with political instability, a declining economy and corruption. Its leaders brush off fears of a return to authoritarian rule, but are divided on the pace of privatizing state-owned industries. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Survey Finds Deficient Buildings
description: An audit of 23 buildings leased by the New York City Board of Education for use as schools found that more than one-quarter of them had serious deficiencies, including leaky roofs, fire and safety code violations and rats, the state comptroller's office said yesterday. Though the majority of leased buildings were in good condition, H. Carl McCall, the comptroller, said the Board of Education had in six cases continued to pay rent while failing to force landlords to correct the problems. A spokeswoman for the Board of Education said the problems noted in the report had been repaired or were being repaired.

title: A Growing Brain, Even in Middle Age
description: A study has found new evidence that the human brain continues to develop into the late 40's. The study, from the Department of Veterans Affairs, appears this month in The Archives of General Psychiatry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, ROBERTA A.
description: SMALL-Roberta A. Of Clinton Corners, New York, & Manhattan. Devoted mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, sister and aunt, died on May 21, 2001 from complications due to cancer. An advertising executive before retiring to the country life where she became active in local politics and assumed a seat on her town Board of Appeals. Her life was guided by her strength of character, love for family and pride in community. Her last months were defined by bravery, humor and a continued concern for others. She will be deeply missed.

title: Albanian Rebels to Quit Serbia This Week
description: Chatting and joking, a group of armed Albanian rebels in southern Serbia embraced and posed for photographs today outside their headquarters. By Thursday, these rebel fighters in the Presevo valley region will leave, for on that day NATO will allow the Yugoslav Army back into the last section of a three-mile-wide buffer zone along Kosovo's eastern boundary with Serbia proper.

title: Fossil Findings May Force Revisions in the History of Life
description: After the most devastating mass extinction swept the planet 250 million years ago, the earth witnessed a nearly unabated increase in the variety of living organisms leading to unparalleled heights of diversity -- or so paleontologists have long thought.

title: Foreign Affairs; It Only Gets Worse
description: The long-awaited Mitchell commission report about Israeli-Palestinian violence was released yesterday, and now there is a debate over what to do with its recommendations. I have a suggestion. It's kind of a two-for-one deal. Take all the Mitchell reports, make a big pile out of them, and set them ablaze into a gigantic bonfire. It would surely generate enough heat, and light, to make a small contribution to the Bush energy plan.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Progress In Park Project
description: The New York City Economic Development Corporation has selected landscape designers to redevelop the Bush Terminal Piers in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, into a public recreation space. A team headed by Donna Walcavage Landscape Architecture and Urban Design will prepare plans for Bush Terminal Piers 1 through 5, a 24-acre parcel between 44th and 50th Streets. The planning and design will be paid for with a $1.3 million grant from the New York Department of State, the Brooklyn borough president, City Councilman Angel Rodriguez's office and the city's capital budget.

title: Times Names Raines as Successor To Lelyveld as Executive Editor
description: Howell Raines, the editor of the editorial page of The New York Times for the last eight years, has been chosen to succeed Joseph Lelyveld as executive editor of the newspaper in September. The change was announced yesterday by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The Times and chairman of The New York Times Company.

title: The American Mideast Initiative
description: After a weekend of dangerously escalating violence in the Middle East, the Bush administration has wisely decided to play a more active role in trying to restore a semblance of peace. Secretary of State Colin Powell yesterday ordered American diplomats in the region to hold urgent consultations with Israeli and Palestinian leaders. The effort is meant to build on the report of a commission headed by former Senator George Mitchell that outlines steps both sides can take to halt the bloodletting, rebuild confidence and move toward renewed peace talks.

title: Vince Carter Got It Right
description: The annals of sport are littered with the names of athletes who fail to graduate from college and end up lost when a professional sports career fails to materialize or ends prematurely. The National Basketball Association will probably accelerate this pattern in next month's draft, where several of the top 10 players selected could be high school students who have never set foot in a college classroom. But Vince Carter, the Toronto Raptors basketball star, made a powerful symbolic statement last weekend when he attended his college graduation ceremony at the University of North Carolina on the morning of a crucial game. He was right to shrug off criticism from those who accused him of not taking seriously his role in the N.B.A. playoffs.

title: Critics, Recalling Democrats' Events, Fault Cheney
description: Vice President Dick Cheney opened his official residence tonight for a reception of hundreds of Republican donors, an event that drew criticism from Democrats and campaign-overhaul advocates who said it was improper for Mr. Cheney to use government property for gatherings linked to political fund-raising.

Two recent projects, both realized in ephemeral forms, have expanded the New York audience for the work of these gifted space-timers.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A Caution For Internet Users
description: New York State officials warned Internet users yesterday not to assume that an Internet access number with the same area code as their own phone involves local phone charges. Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said users should confirm costs with their local phone companies. He said that in parts of the state where an area code covers a large region, an Internet access number can involve more expensive regional calling charges even if its area code matches the Internet user's code. A spokesman, Brad Maione, said that Mr. Spitzer's office had received hundreds of complaints from consumers who had incurred long-distance charges after unwittingly selecting an access number they thought was local. Mr Spitzer said 25 Internet service providers had agreed to place a prominent warning on their access number selection pages.

James Gandolfini was, as he has been from the start, astonishingly good at balancing the vile and sympathetic elements of the character, but the show's huge popularity was starting to deliver a mob boss who was too cuddly for a hard-edged series.
