title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Offers New Low-Power Chips
description: The Intel Corporation began selling four new microprocessors that use less power than its current laptop chips. Jostling with Transmeta and Advanced Micro Devices for placement in smaller and lighter computers, Intel said 12 computer makers had made laptops with the new chips. The new Intel chips include two new Pentium III's, one using less than 1 volt of power, and two Celerons, all running at speeds of 600 to 750 megahertz. Donald McDonald, an Intel marketing director, said that 60 percent of today's laptops weigh more than six pounds but that he expected the number to decline to 20 percent in two years. Intel, based in Santa Clara, Calif., also made available a faster version of its mobile Celeron chip, running at 800 megahertz but not designed specifically for low-power consumption.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Lechters Files For Chapter 11
description: After announcing store closings and layoffs and then being delisted from the Nasdaq for low share prices, Lechters Inc., the housewares retailer based in Harrison, N.J., filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday. The company has run up $100.9 million in debt against $128.9 million in assets, but is hoping to restore its financial stability by borrowing $86 million from two current lenders, Fleet Retail Finance Inc. and Back Bay Capital Funding, to continue paying its bills, said Wendy Kopsick, a company spokeswoman. Lechters was delisted on April 16, after share prices became measurable in nickels and dimes. In February, Lechters announced that it was laying off more than 700 employees and closing 166 of its 490 stores nationwide, including 35 of its 126 stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Welfare's Next Phase
description: For Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, dramatically reducing the number of people on New York City's welfare rolls has been one of his proudest achievements. For many former welfare clients who have finally become self-sufficient, earning a paycheck has brought personal pride. But for many others who still need public assistance, the end of a five-year lifetime limit on federal welfare support is now looming, effective at the end of the year. This transition would be hard enough under any circumstances, but it will be especially hard if the city and state fail to provide the support already promised.

title: World Briefing | World: Racism Talks Resume
description: Delegates in Geneva began trying to hammer out a draft declaration to be adopted at a United Nations conference on racism this summer. Earlier negotiations stumbled, mainly over the issue of whether former colonial powers should pay compensation to victims of slavery. Western countries have said the issue of reparations is too complex and contentious to be put on the agenda. The United Nation Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, who also leads the racism conference, urged that consensus positions be found. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Surge In Imports
description: Japan's global trade surplus shrank to 666 billion yen ($5.4 billion) in April, an unexpectedly steep decline of 41.6 percent from April 2000 and the 10th consecutive month in which the surplus has contracted. The biggest factor in the decline was a strong increase in imports, which grew 13.2 percent. Trade with the United States was less notably affected, with Japan's surplus shrinking 7.4 percent from the April 2000 level. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Ford to Replace 13 Million Firestone Tires on Its Vehicles
description: DEARBORN, Mich., May 22  The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would replace 13 million Firestone Wilderness AT tires installed mainly on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles, including 1.5 million Wilderness tires that were mounted on the vehicles as replacements during the Firestone tire recall last fall.

title: Hope Before Hype
description: The recent scandal surrounding the venerable Harlem-based Hale House is a telling story of a high-profile nonprofit organization being consumed by the very media forces that helped bring it national attention. Mother Clara Hale, the late founder of Hale House, was depicted as the Mother Theresa of Harlem. This characterization not only served to offer a glimmer of hope in a drug-ravaged New York, but helped crystallize the image of Harlem as a den of hopelessness, a Western Calcutta. Hale House in turn was able to leverage the cult of personality around Mother Hale into immense philanthropic support and recognition. It's a trade-off.

title: MERCURY INTERACTIVE TO BUY FRESHWATER SOFTWARE
description: The Mercury Interactive Corporation, whose software keeps Internet sites running, agreed to buy the closely held Freshwater Software for $147 million in cash to add programs that monitor network performance. But five different therapeutic combinations failed as the painful cancer grew to the size of two footballs, spread to his liver and so weakened him that his wife had to lift him out of bed.

title: Robert LaChapelle, Marlborough Gallery, New York, May 7, 2001
description: e were moving nine pieces into the Marlborough Gallery for the exhibit of Botero's sculptures. We've worked for the Whitney, Sotheby's, the Met. We've moved Rembrandts. That's more money than me and a lot of other people put together make. But we can't take the time to think about how valuable it is. We handle it all the same. We were picking the pieces up off the trailer with a crane. First, we set them down in the garden, and then the artist's representative would tell us where to move them so they look nice. People were slamming on the brakes thinking, What's that on the truck? I'm on more strangers' video cameras than I care to know about. But you wouldn't believe how stupid half of New York is. We'll be hanging something that weighs tons, and they roll a baby carriage underneath. The typical New Yorker never looks up."

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Says Press Isn't Liable For Use of Ill-Gotten Tapes
description: In an important First Amendment decision weighing personal privacy against the public's right to know, the Supreme Court ruled today that the press may not be held liable for publishing illegally intercepted information as long as the subject is one of ''public importance'' and the press itself did not participate in the interception. The vote was 6 to 3.

title: THE CENSUS -- New York; Households Grow and Fewer People Live Alone, Data Show
description: The immigrant influx and a tight housing market appear to be reshaping the way many New Yorkers live, according to census figures released yesterday that show more city residents doubling up, a drop in the percentage of people living alone and the biggest increase in average household size in 50 years.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Postmaster General Chosen
description: John E. Potter, left, a 23-year veteran of the post office, was chosen to be the next postmaster general, officials said. The nine-member board selected Mr. Potter to succeed William J. Henderson, who will step down on May 31. Mr. Potter, the chief operating officer and a former head of labor relations for the Postal Service, will be the sixth career postal employee to head the agency.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: No More Executions
description: President Leonid D. Kuchma formally abolished the death penalty by signing into law a new criminal code that brings Ukraine into line with other European countries. The new code takes effect June 1. Ukraine promised to abolish the death penalty when it joined the Council of Europe in 1995 but about 180 executions took place from 1995 to 1997, when it began observing a moratorium. The Constitutional Court ruled death sentences unconstitutional in 1999, and Parliament formulated a new criminal code sent to Mr. Kuchma last month. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: GRANITE CONSTRUCTION TO BUY HALMAR BUILDERS
description: Granite Construction, a California-based construction contractor, plans to buy Halmar Builders of New York Inc. to enter the New York metropolitan area. The transaction will be financed with a combination of bank credit and cash, but specific terms were not disclosed, Granite said. Halmar is a closely held construction company; its major customers include the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the Metropolitan Transit Authority of New York and other transportation-related agencies. The company, based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., had 2000 revenue of about $206 million. Granite is based in Watsonville, Calif.

title: Summer Deals Along Mexico's Pacific Coast
description: Summer is off season in Puerto Vallarta, along Mexico's Pacific Coast, and even higher-priced hotels find the need to cut prices. The 67-room Hacienda Cora, a cluster of pink villas overlooking the Marina Vallarta Golf Club, cuts room rates by $50 a night, to $211 and up. A one-bedroom villa with its own plunge pool is $310 a night, a $55 reduction. Even cozier is Majahuitas, with seven casitas, accessible only by boat, overlooking the ocean. There are swimming, snorkeling, kayaking and hiking to reduce the chances of boredom. Rates are $200 a night for two, including all meals. Rates at both hotels are subject to tax and can be changed without notice. Valid through Sept. 30 at Majahuitas and Dec. 20 at Hacienda Cora. Inquire by fax at 011 (523) 221 2255. On the Web: www.mexicoboutiquehotels.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, GEORGE A.
description: FOX-George A. United American Energy Corp. (UAE) celebrates the life of George A. Fox, who, with three other engineers, helped create a vision of building environmentally sensitive electric power generating plants as private sector businesses. George Fox was a founding member and served on the Board of Directors of UAE between 1980 and 1998. George Fox's wisdom, advice, and tenacity were instrumental in creating a sound direction for UAE and guiding the company through its start-up phase. Most importantly, George modeled a profound respect for engineering and business principals and ethics, attention to details and dignity in dealing with employees, other stakeholders and the public. George was an extraordinary engineer and a superb artist, who combined these talents to bring people together to accomplish ambitious goals. He has been a great teacher and has inspired us all. UAE has lost a valued advisor, a brilliant businessman and engineer, and a kind and special friend. David Goodman, Chairman, CEO United American Energy Corp.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Red Cross Resumes Flights
description: The International Committee of the Red Cross resumed aid flights in southern Sudan after determining that an attack on a plane this month that killed a pilot was not aimed at the Red Cross itself. A statement from the group said the plane's shooting was ''the result of a fatal combination of circumstances and not a deliberate attack targeting the Red Cross.'' It has not been determined who fired on the plane, which had dropped to a relatively low altitude because of technical problems. Sudan has had a long-running civil war and the Red Cross statement noted that the area is populated by ''a diverse range of armed groups.'' Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: White House Confronts Efforts To Modify Bush's Education Bill

title: Technology Briefing | Research: S.E.C. Ends Web Survey Early
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had received more than 3,000 responses to its Internet survey of investors and would end the polling this week. The survey, announced earlier this month, was intended to help the agency learn how people use the Internet, television and other technology to make investment decisions. The S.E.C. also hoped to find out how much investors knew about the market, what they expected from brokerage firms, how they analyze data and how often they trade stocks. The agency had planned to accept responses until July 1. A spokesman for the commission said the survey would allow officials to gauge ''how 60-year-old regulations apply in an electronic age.'' The S.E.C. will issue a report in about two months, he said.

description: Two of Timothy J. McVeigh's original lawyers have rejoined his defense team. title: Letting Mahler's Point Unfold, Not Overwhelm at the Start
description: Robert Spano and the Brooklyn Philharmonic closed their season on Saturday night with a performance of the Mahler Third Symphony at the Brooklyn Academy of Music that, in purely technical terms, was a few notches short of ideal. But it was eloquent enough to point up one of the great paradoxes of Mahler's grandly scaled symphonies. Even in a comparatively optimistic work like the Third, Mahler's view of humanity's smallness in the universe is never far from the surface; yet that sense of cosmic insignificance is conjured in a supremely transformative act of human creativity. The bits of wood, wire, metal, skin and horsehair that make up the orchestra's instruments are manipulated to produce a vast and subtly balanced palette, with which Mahler evokes the power of nature and the otherworldly serenity of heaven.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Lawmakers Arrested In Protest
description: The police arrested six Democratic state lawmakers yesterday for blocking a van carrying nonunion replacement workers from entering a Windsor nursing home, one of 39 homes where unionized workers walked out, demanding higher pay and staffing levels. The arrests came on the same day that the union, New England Health Care Employees Union, District 1199, said it had reached an accord with Roncalli Health Care, which operates seven nursing homes and which had hired hundreds of replacement workers last week. HCA said CCN, based in San Diego, manages group health, worker's compensation and auto injury insurance benefits. HCA bought CCN in 1997 when it acquired Value Health Inc. HCA has sold Value Health units that offered disease-management, psychiatric and prescription-drug services. First Health provides group health and worker's compensation benefits for employers and management services to insurers and state Medicaid programs.

title: Critic's Notebook; To Dress for Today, Many Start From the Sofa Up
description: Every few months, it seems someone with a lot of bucks comes along to revive a fashion house that nobody needs. The latest entry into this dead-horse category is Jaegar. I remember going into Jaegar shops with my mother, when she was about the age I am now, and, well, need I say more? I doubt those 20-year-old girls bobbing into H&M on their lunch hours for $7.50 string bikini tops are interested in the rich history of genteel sportswear that a Jaegar publicist would gladly impart, if given half a chance. They are not interested for one simple reason: It will not change their lives.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Layoffs At Audiobook Company
description: MediaBay Inc., a seller of audiobooks and classic radio and television shows whose shares had fallen 56 percent this year, has dismissed 14 people, or 17 percent of its work force, as it tries to become profitable. The owner of Audio Book Club began making the cuts in November, said the chief financial officer, John Levy. The total includes six managers and two consultants. MediaBay, based in Cedar Knolls, N.J., now employs 68 full-time workers. The company said its first-quarter loss, excluding an income tax benefit, was $2.4 million, or 17 cents a share.

title: Strikeouts Are Down, But So Are the Walks

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Bush Says He's Not Surprised  About Reno
description: Gov. But Mr. Bush, who could become the first Republican in more than a century to win a second term as Florida governor, said his decision did not hinge on any Democratic candidates. ''In all honesty, who else aspires to serve as governor won't be part of my decision-making process,'' Mr. Bush said. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: RAYTHEON ORDERED TO PROVIDE AUDIT TO RIVAL IN DISPUTE
description: The Raytheon Company has until next Tuesday to give Washington Group International an audited balance sheet of a business Raytheon sold to Washington Group, an Idaho judge ruled. The information is needed to help an arbitrator decide if Washington Group is entitled to a $400 million refund, a Washington Group spokesman, Brent Brandon, said. If Raytheon, a leading military contractor, or its auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, miss the deadline, the judge, Deborah Bail, will appoint an auditor. Washington Group of Boise, Idaho, filed for bankruptcy protection last week, about 10 months after it bought Raytheon's construction business for $53 million and assumed $450 million in liabilities. Washington Group filed suit in March, saying Raytheon, which is based in Lexington, Mass., committed fraud and seeking a cancellation of the purchase.

description: Moving to strengthen its position in a rapidly consolidating cellular market, Portugal Telecom offered to acquire the shares it does not already own in Brazil's largest mobile phone company, Telesp Celular Participaces. In an all-stock deal, the company said it had offered a 40 percent premium over last week's average value to buy 58.8 percent of the outstanding shares and American depository receipts in the Brazilian company. The value of the deal was not disclosed.

Powell instructing a senior aide to work with both sides in establishing a ''time line'' for a series of measures he hopes will culminate in the resumption of peace talks.

title: A Wrestler Who Prefers the Pen to the Pin
description: This month Mankind, the wrestler, published the second volume of his memoirs, which will be the No. 1 nonfiction book on the New York Times best-seller list on Sunday. The book, ''Foley Is Good: And the Real World Is Faker Than Wrestling'' (the title refers to Mankind's real name, Mick Foley), has surpassed George Carlin's ''Napalm and Silly Putty,'' Laura Hillenbrand's ''Seabiscuit'' and Tom Brokaw's ''Album of Memories.''

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Dot-Biz Domain Name Opens Its Doors
description: Companies that register Internet addresses yesterday began accepting applications from trademark owners for addresses in the new dot-biz domain. The process is intended to give intellectual property owners a chance to make claims on proprietary addresses in the dot-biz domain before it is opened to general registration. After this property claim period ends on July 9, companies will be able to apply for dot-biz addresses that do not include trademarked names. When competing applications are made for an address, the company that operates the dot-biz registry database, NeuLevel of Sterling, Va., said one winner would be randomly selected. Addresses in the dot-biz domain are expected to go live in the fall.

description: Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg and Senator Joseph F. Vitalea yesterday called for the General Assembly to pass a bill that would require gun manufacturers to sell only childproof ''smart'' handguns once those weapons are commercially available. Smart guns feature locks that can only be deactivated by authorized users.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Teligent Files For Bankruptcy Protection
description: Teligent filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, becoming the latest company to succumb to the austere financing climate for smaller communications companies. Teligent, which sought to compete with large local telephone companies by providing wireless communications services using rooftop antennas, failed to meet a deadline yesterday for obtaining $350 million in short-term financing. The company had already cut 795 jobs, or 35 percent of its work force, to reduce expenses. The company, based in Vienna, Va., has never reported a profit since it first sold shares in 1997. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Before the Big Bang, There Was . . . What?
description: What was God doing before he created the world? The philosopher and writer (and later saint) Augustine posed the question in his ''Confessions'' in the fourth century, and then came up with a strikingly modern answer: before God created the world there was no time and thus no ''before.'' To paraphrase Gertrude Stein, there was no ''then'' then.

description: At 5 feet 11 inches, Brenda Matsie is plenty tall. What gave her trouble were her ''hips,'' as a euphemism here goes. That is a nice way of saying that a certain judge of a beauty contest all the way from South Africa thought her behind was half an inch too big.

description: The first three-city Verizon Music Festival, which is to include free outdoor concerts in New York in August, was announced yesterday by Verizon and Festival Productions, the event's producer.

title: HEALTH RISK MANAGEMENT REPLACES ITS AUDITORS
description: Health Risk Management, a managed care company, said yesterday that it had replaced its auditors after learning it might need to increase reserves for medical claims in a Medicaid health plan, setting off a 39 percent decline in its stock price. The shares fell $3.05, to $4.75 a share, on Nasdaq, where Health Risk led the list of percentage losers. Health Risk replaced Ernst & Young after the auditors said the company needed to raise reserves by $5 million to cover claims in the fourth quarter and first quarter, the company said. Health Risk said its fourth-quarter loss would widen to $6.52 from $5.92 and its first-quarter loss would widen to $1.32 from 85 cents if the recommendation were followed. Health Risk is based in Minneapolis.

description: The night light has long been a source of comfort for the young, to say nothing of the guidance it provides those adults who would otherwise stumble through the dark. But some researchers had theorized that the lights might cause nearsightedness in infants.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Joining Race For Governor
description: The Democratic whip in the United States House, Representative David E. Bonior, left, said he would join the 2002 race to replace Gov. John Engler. Mr. Bonior filed papers to form a campaign committee, joining four other candidates in the race for the Democratic nomination. While primary polls show Mr. Bonior trailing Attorney General Jennifer M. Granholm and former Gov. James J. Blanchard for the nomination, he is expected to win the endorsement of most of Michigan's organized labor. Two state senators, Gary Peters and Alma Wheeler Smith, are also in the Democratic race. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Mario Delamo, 55, 70's Dancer With Martha Graham Troupe
description: Mario Delamo, who performed with the Martha Graham Dance Company in the 1970's, died on May 13 in Los Angeles. He was 55 and lived in West Hollywood.

title: Deficit Estimate In New Jersey Now Reaching $1.6 Billion
description: Just a year ago, New Jersey was reveling in the budgetary equivalent of a winning Powerball ticket: a huge windfall of tax revenue allowed state officials to draft a budget with a 10 percent spending increase and a record $870 million surplus. But with just six weeks to go before the next budget must be adopted, the state has gone from counting its spoils to pinching its pennies.

title: Robert Emmet Curry; Ex-Leader of Big Brothers, 88
description: Robert Emmet Curry, former president of Catholic Big Brothers of New York, died on Saturday at his son's home in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Ruling In Art Dispute
description: A state-run art museum has decided to let a computerized photo collage of Our Lady of Guadalupe in a rose-covered bikini remain on display through the fall. The Museum of International Folk, which operates under the state-run Museum of New Mexico, has displayed the collage since February. Roman Catholics have denounced the collage as sacrilegious and demanded its removal, while proponents say removing it would be censorship of artistic freedom. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Schools Show Jump in Reports Of Sex Abuse
description: Complaints of sexual misconduct on the part of teachers and other employees in the New York City school system have more than doubled since three well-publicized sexual abuse complaints were lodged against teachers or administrators earlier this month.

title: VERIZON TO BUY CANADIAN DIRECTORY SERVICES FROM TELUS
description: Verizon Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Telus Corporation's directory-information service, the second largest in Canada, for $520 million, and combine it with businesses in British Columbia and Quebec. The new division, Dominion Information Services, will have 2001 sales of $232 million and produce 118 directories. Verizon, the local telephone service provider in New York, is seeking to add businesses that generate steady revenue in wireless, long-distance and high-speed Internet service ventures, analysts said.

title: ISRAEL TELLS ARMY TO WITHHOLD FIRE UNLESS IN DANGER
description: Israeli military officials have ordered troops to open fire only when their lives are endangered and to otherwise ''cease fire,'' the Defense Ministry said late tonight.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Index Of Chip Orders Plummets
description: Illustrating the semiconductor market's steep decline, a closely followed measure of demand for chip-making equipment has reached its lowest point since its creation in January 1991. Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, a trade group, said the book-to-bill ratio was 0.42 in April, meaning North American equipment makers took $42 in orders for every $100 in shipments. A ratio below 1 indicates a shrinking market. Orders were $712 million, down 41 percent from March and 76 percent from October, when they peaked at $2.99 billion. The association attributed much of the decline to canceled orders by chip makers with excess inventory. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Court Restricts Prenatal Care For Immigrants
description: Pregnant women who are in this country illegally have no right to prenatal care under Medicaid, a federal appeals court decided yesterday in a ruling that strengthened the cutback of benefits for illegal immigrants and raised anew the issue of whether a fetus is a person with rights.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Inquiry In Reporter's Shooting
description: Justice Ministry investigators are collecting evidence on the shooting by an Israeli soldier of Bertrand Aguirre, a French television correspondent, last week in the West Bank, including videotapes from three news organizations that appear to show a soldier shooting Mr. Aguirre at close range with a rifle equipped to fire both rubber-coated steel pellets and live ammunition. The bullet lodged in Mr. Aguirre's protective vest. He had minor injuries. William A. Orme Jr. (NYT)

description: Andrew J. Spano, the county executive in Westchester, announced today that he would run for a second term, capitalizing on what is expected to be a weak challenge from the Republican Party, which once dominated the post.

title: A Big 'Sopranos' Finale
description: ''The Sopranos'' continued its remarkable assault on ratings records for HBO, finishing its season with its highest rating yet for any of its final episodes and improving by almost 30 percent in its showing for the entire season.

title: Frustrated Zeile Sees Hope Despite Losing
description: There were so many things about tonight's game that frustrated Todd Zeile, and he showed it in his body language. Zeile, the Mets first baseman, closed his eyes and grimaced after striking out on a slider well off the plate. He bopped his fist on second base when he was thrown out there trying to advance on a single.

title: Where Oompah Meets Hip in the East Village
description: AS a neighborhood, the East Village is like the would-be rockers who walk its streets carrying guitars. As a cuisine, German food is like a guy in lederhosen carrying a tuba.

title: Single No More, and Still Wedded to the Cause
description: GLORIA STEINEM let her hair down a long time ago, and it's still down, still ash-blond, still fanning out in free-for-all form above her pinstripe narrow shoulder blades -- having had a 300-pound father and a runaway sweet tooth is why she watches her weight like a hawk through those oversize smart-gal glasses she seems to have temporarily misplaced. Hence her squint and an apologetic admonition to ''sit close.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Slows
description: Germany provided more evidence today that its growth was slowing even as prices increased faster than expected. German business confidence, a closely watched indicator of future growth, declined more sharply in April than most economists had predicted. The decline, the 10th consecutive monthly drop, caused some economists to predict that Germany, which is Europe's biggest economy, might not meet the lowered expectations of growing by 2 percent this year. Making matters worse, the German state of Brandenburg reported that its inflation rate had jumped to an annual rate of 4.1 percent. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: An NBC Petri Dish
description: In September 1999, NBC took an ownership stake in the tiny Pax network in a bid to win access to a second, national broadcast outlet. But the deal with Pax has brought NBC an unexpected benefit. The smaller network has actually been serving as a sort of programming development petri dish for the bigger one, giving NBC ideas for two of its new shows.

title: L.I. Man Is Killed in Crash
description: A man was fatally injured on a Long Island highway on Monday morning after he stopped his car in the emergency lane, apparently to use a cell phone, and a newspaper delivery truck crashed into the rear of the car, the police said yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer's Profit Falls
description: Marks & Spencer, Britain's ailing Main Street retailing giant, reported its third successive fall in full-year earnings, but the decline was less than analysts had forecast, and its stock rose as much as 2.6 percent, compounding a 41 percent rise this year. The chief executive, Luc Vandevelde, said adult clothing sales had remained ''unacceptable.'' The company said pretax profit before exceptional charges was 480 million ($692 million), compared with 517 million last year. Marks & Spencer took a $482 million charge to carry out its decision in March to pull out of money-losing European businesses and to sell the profit-making Brooks Brothers clothing chain and Kings supermarkets in the United States. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Lernout Offers Divestiture Plan
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, the beleaguered Belgian speech technology company, has proposed divesting itself of its main speech and language technology in order to pay creditors and emerge from bankruptcy. According to a restructuring plan submitted in Ieper, Belgium, the company could either sell the technology or create a new company where creditors, who are owed around $500 million, would become shareholders. The new company would receive Lernout's technology and personnel, including assets from the former Dragon Systems. Creditors will vote on the proposal on June 5. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

description: A firefighter collapsed, apparently with a heart attack, while battling a blaze in a house yesterday and later died, a spokesman said. The firefighter, Lawrence Webb, 37, of Newark, was a 15-year veteran of the Fire Department, said Matthew Greimel, a department spokesman. The two-alarm fire, at a house at 47 Beaumont Place, was called in at 4:15 p.m. and was under control within 45 minutes.

title: Little Adult Criminals
description: Spurred by news of teenagers with easy access to guns and other weapons committing increasingly violent crimes, all but three states have made it easier in recent years to try minors as adults. The idea was that certain types of violent crime are so serious that they do not belong in a juvenile court system designed not only to punish delinquents but to rehabilitate them before they reach adulthood. Two high-profile murder trials in Florida this year have sounded a warning that the trend may have gone too far.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Citigroup will drop the Salomon name from its brokerage and banking units.
description: SALOMON, a name once equated with swaggering bond traders but later tarnished by a Treasury bond-trading scandal, will soon disappear from Wall Street. Citigroup Inc., the conglomeration of the former Salomon Brothers investment bank and several other financial-services companies, told its employees yesterday that it planned to rename its corporate banking and brokerage operations early next year.

description: WALETZKY-Jacob Peter. Died unexpectedly on Sunday, May 20, 2001. He was 29 years old. In early May 2001, he completed the coursework for his M.F.A. in the Writing Division at Columbia University. He is survived by his ever loving parents, Lucy Waletzky and Jeremy Waletzky, his adoring sister Naomi Waletzky, his loving grandfather Laurance S. Rockefeller and his beloved girlfriend Dana Goodyear. We can't imagine life without him. A memorial service will be held at the Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive at 120 Street, New York City, Thursday, May 24th, at 4 P.M. Family will receive written tributes at www.mem.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, MILTON A.
description: SEYMOUR-Milton A. 91, of Sarasota, FL and Southbury, CT, died peacefully at his home in Southbury Tuesday, May 22. He practiced law from 1932 to the present, holding many positions with Bar Associations in New York, including as President of the Bronx Country Bar Association. He was an Honorary Life Member of the AntiDefamation League and Chairman, Bronx Division UJA. He was an Honorary Life Trustee of Bronx Lebanon Hospital. He loved law, travel, music and people. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Mary A. Seymour. A dear friend spoke for all of us when he wrote, ''Every encounter I have with you is a tonic to my spirits.'' He will be missed by all. Donations may be made to ADL. Services Friday 11AM at Munson and Lovetearre Funeral Home, 235 Main St, Southbury, CT.

title: Giuliani Calls Taiwan a 'Country' During Leader's Visit
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani met yesterday morning with the president of Taiwan, referred afterward to the island of 22 million people as a ''remarkable country,'' then scoffed at Chinese reporters who heatedly asked if the mayor planned to recognize Taiwan as its own nation.

title: Target's Net Rises 6.3% as It Expands to New Areas
description: MINNEAPOLIS, May 22  The Target Corporation said today that profit in its most recent quarter rose 6.3 percent as it pushed its expansion outside the Midwest and into big markets like New Jersey and Texas.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Bayonne: Mystery Of Slain Businessman
description: The authorities are investigating the kidnapping and killing of Magdy El-Sayed, 39, a businessman from Queens who was found dead in his Mercedes-Benz Saturday in Bayonne. Mr. El-Sayed's former wife told investigators that she saw three men in a sedan abduct him on May 14 after he pulled into his driveway. She said she got a phone call from him two hours later, saying he was in F.B.I. custody and needed money, but she did not call the police. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Injury Gives Wall No Relief
description: If it has been difficult at times for fans to watch Donne Wall pitch, it has been even harder for Wall. Wall, a right-handed reliever, is not the same pitcher he was with the San Diego Padres the past three years, and now he has acknowledged the reason: he is still not fully recovered from off-season shoulder surgery.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST The former headquarters of the neo-Nazi Aryan Nations will become a retreat center, the new owner has decided. The owner, the Internet millionaire Greg Carr, said he decided over the weekend to destroy the buildings on the wooded, 20-acre site in northern Idaho and build a site where people will gather by appointment to discuss human rights, The Spokesman-Review of Spokane, Wash., reported. Mr. Carr cited the remoteness of the spot and security concerns in announcing the decision. A public education center and human rights museum will be built in Coeur d'Alene, about 15 miles from the compound, the newspaper reported.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Chancellor's Secret Cousin
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder has a first cousin who worked for the Stasi, the intelligence service of the former East Germany. Research on the fate of Mr. Schrder's father, Fritz, who was killed in World War II, found that he had a brother whose three daughters were raised in the former Communist state. One of them, identified in the press as Renate G., worked as an English-language interpreter for the Stasi. Mr. Schrder, who met Renate's sisters this month, said he had met her and forgiven her. Roger Cohen (NYT)

title: Musicians Who Trust Composers Under 30
description: Since 1984 the adventurous New York Youth Symphony has presented a premiere performance of a new work by a composer under 30 on every one of its programs. This means that an orchestra of students ranging in age from 12 to 22 has arguably the best record for commissioning new music of any ensemble in the United States.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Extradition Deal Proposed
description: China has pledged to Canada that it will not execute two Chinese fugitives if they are extradited to face charges in the country's largest smuggling case, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji said. One fugitive, Lai Changxing, is accused of masterminding a multibillion-dollar operation that has resulted in the executions of more than 10 officials. In 1999, he and his wife, Tsang Mingna, fled to Canada, where the authorities do not want to grant asylum, but the law does not allow extradition of people who face execution. His lawyers say China's pledge is not credible. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Prosecutors Seek Local Records About Torricelli
description: Federal prosecutors have subpoenaed hundreds of pages of documents from the Morris County Democratic Committee as they try to determine whether Senator Robert G. Torricelli's 1996 campaign improperly used county organizations to evade restrictions on corporate donations, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: G.A.O. Report Faults Cybersecurity
description: The National Infrastructure Protection Center, which gathers information on cyberspace threats and assists the federal government in responding to computer-based incidents, has a limited strategy for analyzing data, and is thus not capable of providing timely warnings of imminent attacks, the General Accounting Office said. The center lacks adequate staff and technical expertise, the audit said, to alert the public to dangerous or disruptive incidents.

title: One Slam-Bang Show (Literally)
description: Industrial-strength entertainment whizzes, whirs, whacks, flies, floats, skates and hops around the stage of the New Victory Theater in the artfully chaotic blend of circus, dance, mime, music and sheer athleticism that goes by the title ''Antigravity's Crash Test Dummies.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an increase in the average household size in New York City referred incorrectly to efforts by the Department of City Planning to update the Census Bureau's address list before the 2000 Census. The department found that several hundred thousand addresses, not several hundred, were missing.

title: Metro Business Briefing | May Sweeps Ratings
description: WNYW-TV, with only two days left in the May sweeps, appears on the verge of losing the top spot in the New York market's 10 p.m. news race for the first time, according to data released yesterday by Nielsen Media Research. The station, Channel 5, stands one-tenth of a ratings point behind WWOR-TV, Channel 9. WNBC-TV, Channel 4, the leader in the prime-time news ratings in the November sweeps, will probably come in second in the 5 p.m. and 6 p.m. newscasts to WABC-TV, Channel 7. But WNBC will probably remain first in the 11 p.m. news slot and in the morning news race. Officials at WXTV, Channel 41, an affiliate of Univision, a Spanish-language broadcaster, report a 50 percent increase in viewers for its 11 p.m. newscast. In the first time the two shows have gone head to head in the New York market, the reruns of ''Friends'' on WPIX-TV, Channel 11, are decisively ahead of the reruns of ''Seinfeld'' on WNYW at 11 p.m. The sweeps period began on April 27 and will end tomorrow.

title: All Bets Are Off; Bali Is On
description: IT has been six months since I first wrote about Jill and Brandon Lowitz, the starry-eyed newlyweds in Manhattan who vowed to step out of the rat race twice each month and meet for lunch. When their friend Richard Ellenson laughed at the idea that love could triumph over work, a wager was born.

title: Oil and Human Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Art Scholars Protest Plan To Restore A Leonardo
description: More than 30 scholars of Renaissance art, including some of the top names in the field from the United States and Italy, have signed a petition urging the Uffizi Gallery in Florence to postpone a planned restoration of ''The Adoration of the Magi,'' an unfinished painting by the young Leonardo da Vinci.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about ideas on the origin of the universe misstated the affiliation of Dr. Burt Ovrut, a scientist who speculated that the Big Bang was ignited by a clash of island universes. He is at the University of Pennsylvania, not Penn State.

title: A Trial for Idi Amin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arnold Worldwide Wins 3 Kelly Awards
description: Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, won the most awards, three, including the top honor, at the 20th annual Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America in New York.

title: People
description: Sander Flaum and Ron Pantello were named the co-chairman of Euro RSCG Health Care, New York, a recently reorganized unit of Euro RSCG Worldwide, which is part of Havas Advertising. Each executive will continue to hold his present position, Mr. Flaum as chairman and chief executive at Robert A. Becker/ Euro RSCG and Mr. Pantello as chief executive at Lally McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG. Both of those agencies are part of Euro RSCG Health Care.

title: Siberian Ice Jam Bombed
description: With a pounding by air force bombers, the Russians may have finally defeated a stubborn mass of ice floes that have backed up the Lena River in Siberia, flooding the town of Lensk and inundating part of the regional capital, Yakutsk, in the worst flooding in the area in 100 years.

World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCORKLE, SUSANNAH
description: McCORKLE-Susannah. Thanks for the memories. And all the songs. It was a privilege to amplify your sweet voice. Nancy and William O'Shaughnessy Whitney Radio WRTN and WVOX

title: Nuclear Power Gains in Status After Lobbying
description: As the White House was putting together the energy plan that President Bush released last week, there had been almost no talk of nuclear power as a component of the nation's energy strategy. The nuclear industry thought this was a glaring omission, and a handful of top nuclear industry officials decided they needed to take their case to the administration.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: A Farewell Between Friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, JEROME
description: BRODY-Jerome. We at Grand Central Neighborhood Social Services Corp mourn the passing of restauranteur Jerome Brody. He was a founding Board Member and loyal supporter. His sincere attention to the needs of homeless people in Midtown Manhattan has restored many lives.

title: Out of Africa And Great for the Patio: A Basket That's a Table
description: When guests arrive for dinner, some Ethiopian families gather around a mesob, a hand-woven basket table with a removable conical cover. The 28-inch-high table, above, holds a communal plate for food, right, which is typically eaten with flat bread rather than utensils.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Prison Crowding Crisis
description: Gov. Donald Siegelman said the state might have to build a new prison and consider alternative sentencing programs to ease a prison overcrowding crisis. At a news conference, the governor raised the possibility of creating drug courts, as many states have, to funnel those convicted of drug-related crimes into other facilities, and said the state would review its pardon and parole procedures. He said he did not know how the state would respond to a court order last week requiring the prison system to accept nearly 2,000 prisoners backed up into county jails in a month, but he said a first step would quickly create 300 new beds in the prisons. David Firestone (NYT)

title: The Graduate
description: To the Editor:

title: German Industry Clears Way To Pay Nazi Slave Workers
description: German industry, convinced at last that it has protection in the United States from suits relating to the Nazi era, said today that compensation to people forced to work by the Third Reich could begin.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an employee at the Carlyle Group, the private equity firm, who was forced to resign after boasting in an e-mail message about his sexual exploits and lavish lifestyle misstated his given name. He is Peter Chung, not Paul.

title: Cool Is Better Than Numb
description: IT was a mildly warm afternoon, one of the last before we drop off into the three-month inferno. I was sitting at the bar at Pastis, and ordered a Sazerac. The barman muddled wedges of lemon with pink Peychaud bitters and sugar. He scooped ice into the glass; poured over bourbon; shook it so quickly his arm was a blur, shattering the ice into flinty pieces; and strained the drink into a Pernod-stained glass.

title: Japan Finds Diplomacy Can Turn A Bit Unruly
description: Japan's new foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka, a fiery reformer, has never been known for her diplomatic skills. And in her first weeks in office she has committed a number of gaffes that have made her critics question her ability to do the job.

title: Robert LaChapelle, Marlborough Gallery, New York, May 7, 2001
description: e were moving nine pieces into the Marlborough Gallery for the exhibit of Botero's sculptures. We've worked for the Whitney, Sotheby's, the Met. We've moved Rembrandts. That's more money than me and a lot of other people put together make. But we can't take the time to think about how valuable it is. We handle it all the same. We were picking the pieces up off the trailer with a crane. First, we set them down in the garden, and then the artist's representative would tell us where to move them so they look nice. People were slamming on the brakes thinking, What's that on the truck? I'm on more strangers' video cameras than I care to know about. But you wouldn't believe how stupid half of New York is. We'll be hanging something that weighs tons, and they roll a baby carriage underneath. The typical New Yorker never looks up."

title: Korean Chip Maker Moves to Raise Cash
description: Hynix Semiconductor is opening a global capital-raising campaign with an unusual selling point: its leading shareholders agreed today to surrender all their shares to the creditor institutions to which Hynix owes more than $4 billion.

title: In Radio Debate, New Jersey Republicans Talk Taxes and Truthfulness
description: The first broadcast debate between Bret D. Schundler and Bob Franks turned into a spirited slugfest yesterday as the two candidates for the Republican nomination for New Jersey governor bashed one another on a talk-radio show as tax-and-spend liberals in fiscally conservative clothing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVOK, RUTH H.
description: NOVOK-Ruth H., 5/21/01. Loving wife of the late William Novok. Cherished mom of Judy and Donald; mother-in-law of Walter and Anna-Marie; surrogate mom of Nell and Aaron; stepmom of Andy and Eileen; grandma of Liz, Cyndi and Bob, Loren and Mike, Mark and Stenin; great-grandma of Christine. Retired teacher but never retired from learning and living. Her spirit, courage, intelligence, creativity, honesty, and sense of humor inspired all. At 89, still a feisty adventurer, loving theatre, books, movies, writing class, Scrabble, South Wind summers, birthdays, the beach, shopping, lotteries. A caring problemsolver for family and friends. She will always be remembered by those whose lives she touched. Memorial service Sunday, 6/24, 2 P.M., Beth Am, 510 Claremont Avenue, Teaneck. Family at home Sunday night 6/24. Contributions Ruth H. Novok Large Print Book Fund, Teaneck Library, 840 Teaneck Road, Teaneck, NJ 07666.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Stella Sculpture to Get Its Own Washington Space
description: Starting late next month, the National Gallery of Art in Washington will dig a large hole in the ground on the northeast corner of its East Building, where Pennsylvania Avenue meets Third Street, preparing for the installation of a major sculpture by Frank Stella in mid-August.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: $1.7 Million Award In Firings
description: A fired Cicero police chief and his former top deputy were awarded a total of $1.7 million by a federal jury on Monday in a suit against the Chicago suburb. The former police chief, David Niebur, and his former deputy, Philip Bue, had sued Cicero as well as the town president, Betty Loren-Maltese, and onetime town attorney, Merrick Rayle. The two maintained that they were wrongfully fired in 1998 for cooperating with an F.B.I. investigation into links between town officials and a towing company that was accused of towing cars too quickly and overcharging motorists to recover their vehicles. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Rieslings as Light as Spring
description: NO wines taste more of spring to me than riesling kabinetts from the Mosel-Saar-Ruwer region of Germany. Graceful and delicate, they capture the fresh feeling of those ideal sunny days of May, when the temperature has warmed enough to coax out flowers, but is not yet oppressive.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: W.H.O. Cuts U.S. Payments
description: The United States won reduced payments to the World Health Organization, although the head of the United Nations agency warned in Geneva that some programs could suffer. Washington had sought to lower the sum by the same percentage as the formula negotiated by the Clinton administration for United Nations payments. That deal called for lowering dues for the administrative budget, from 25 percent to 22. W.H.O. presented a test of whether the extra reduction would apply to United Nations agencies. The proposal to trim the American share of the $842.6 million two-year budget by $25 million set off a row at the annual W.H.O. meeting. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE<br OF CHIP ORDERS PLUMMETS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, DAVID
description: LEEDS-David. 86. Of Ryebrook, New York, May 20, 2001. Survived by beloved sons, Michael and his wife Elaine Leeds, and Paul Leeds. Devoted grandfather to Eric, Melissa & Tracy. Services will be Thursday, May 24, 2001 at 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Interment at Sharon Gardens.

title: Nets Look at Four Prospects
description: Seton Hall center Samuel Dalembert was one of four players to visit the Nets yesterday in a predraft workout, Rod Thorn, the team president, said.

title: Woody Allen, So Sorry He's Funny
description: Woody Allen has built a brilliant career out of self-deprecation. In film after film he has played the hapless nerd and with implausible regularity managed to wind up with the girl and win over the critics. On Saturday in a rare formal public appearance at the New York Public Library, he demonstrated how the same comic diffidence that has served him on the big screen can work to his advantage in the court of public opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCHSBAUM, MYRON G.
description: BUCHSBAUM-Myron G. The City Athletic Club announces with profound sorrow the death of esteemed member, Myron Buchsbaum. Michael Todres, President

title: Sixers' Drive Reminds Cheeks of Past Glory
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 22  From the bench or the rafters, Maurice Cheeks serves as the Philadelphia 76ers' living link to the glorious past, the ugly recent past, and now, the promising present.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Following Up column on May 6 about Charles Poletti, the governor of New York for one month in 1942, misstated the precedent for a governor of Italian descent. According to research published by the National Italian American Foundation, Mr. Poletti was the nation's first governor of completely Italian ancestry; four earlier governors were of partial Italian ancestry.

title: Ford Intends to Replace 13 Million Firestone Wilderness Tires
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would replace 13 million Firestone Wilderness AT tires installed mainly on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles, including 1.5 million Wilderness tires that were mounted on the vehicles as replacements during the Firestone recall last autumn.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Ask Jeeves Buys Etour Assets
description: Ask Jeeves Inc., publisher of the Ask.com question-and-answer search site, said it had acquired the assets of eTour Inc., an online marketing company, in an effort to bolster its Web offerings and improve its profitability. The terms were not disclosed. ETour's products include etour.com, a personalized Web navigator with nearly 400,000 daily visitors, direct e-mail marketing technology, a site registration system that collects demographic data on Web customers, and a base of online advertisers. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Business Travel; Even experienced and prepared travelers can find themselves caught up short from time to time.
description: THERE was Ronni Eisenberg on the phone early last Wednesday morning, trying to direct the wayward airport car-service driver to her house like an air-traffic controller talking a lost pilot in on a wing and a prayer.

title: Sales Tactics Lead to Fine Of $3.3 Million
description: The brokerage firm Josephthal & Company and two of its executives were ordered today to pay more than $3.3 million for pressing customers to buy a stock owned by the firm.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Foot-And-Mouth Cases
description: Restrictions on animal movements were imposed on nearly 1,000 farms in northeastern England after 17 cases of foot-and-mouth disease were confirmed in Yorkshire Dales National Park, a major tourist area, at a time when the incidence of the disease is falling elsewhere in Britain. Prime Minister Tony Blair denied Conservative contentions that the government had been premature in announcing eradication of the disease. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Bush vs. the American Landscape
description: Listening to President Bush's speech on energy last week left me yearning for a straight story. His rhetoric seemed intended either to frighten or to lull one into a false sense of security. It didn't help that as he presented an energy plan -- developed with help from lobbyists for oil, coal, gas, mining and nuclear power -- the president buttoned up his speech by asking all of us to stop bickering, to set a new tone and listen to each other. Since Vice President Dick Cheney refused even to meet with environmental groups, it seems a rather curious, if not disingenuous, request.

title: New Jersey Parolee Is Arrested in Killings of 3 Above Carnegie Deli
description: New York police officials yesterday announced the arrest of a parolee in the killing of three people above the Carnegie Deli, saying that the parolee, a convicted felon, would not have been free to commit the crime but for an oversight by New Jersey parole authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, FLORENCE (NEE HECHT)
description: MILLER-Florence (Nee Hecht). 89. Beloved wife of the late Maurice J. Loving mother of Madeline and Edward Redstone, Charles & Lee Miller. Adoring grandmother of Steven (Michele), Lawrence (Jennifer), Howard (Jennifer), Adam and Pamela. Cherished great-grandmother of Amanda, Melissa and John. Services on Thursday, May 24, 10:30AM at the Jewish Memorial Chapel in Clifton, NJ. Donations in her memory can be made to Temple Emanuel, Lafayette Avenue, Passaic, NJ.

title: Senator From Vermont Says He Is Leaving G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont said today he would leave the Republican Party, a move that would vault Senate Democrats into majority status and weaken President Bush as he tries to turn his goals into legislation.

title: For Now, Peace in Mideast Lacks a Constituency
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Free Internet Access for Those Without
description: Prodded by high-profile efforts to close the gap between students with access to technology and students without, 98 percent of the countrys public schools have been wired for Internet connections. But for many low-income students, that access disappears once schools close their doors for the summer.

title: CALENDAR
description: Wine Plus Cheese

title: Jeffords: A Maverick to G.O.P but Not to Fellow Vermonters
description: It seems appropriate that Senator James M. Jeffords, despite working in Washington for the last 27 years, would return to his native Vermont to announce the major decision of his political career: whether to leave the Republican Party and join the Democrats across the Senate aisle, or, more likely, to become an independent.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Rebel Leaders Surrender
description: Three of the most militant commanders of the Albanian rebel force in the Presevo Valley of Serbia surrendered to NATO-led peacekeepers at the border with Kosovo and left the region, signaling the end of the rebel force that has fought Serbian forces for more than a year. NATO offered the rebels an amnesty if they left the area by tomorrow. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Fine China Outdoors? Sooner a Cummerbund at the Beach
description: THE heart and soul of summertime is casualness. And entertaining -- pleasing friends in the shade of an umbrella -- needs to capture that essence with a spirit that almost completely disregards the rules. No formality. Creativity is what's wanted.

title: Devils Beat Penguins And Return to Finals
description: Jason Arnott scored two goals as the Devils defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 4-2, last night at Continental Arena to win the Eastern Conference finals, four games to one.

title: The Chinese See 1-2 Punch in Asian Visits
description: It is just a coincidence, of course, that President Bush will have a well-publicized ''private meeting'' with the Dalai Lama on, of all days, May 23.

title: An Iced-Tea Pitcher Yields the Taste But Not the Leaves
description: Connoisseurs know that the best tea is made with whole-leaf teas, not tea bags. That goes for iced tea, too. But making a pitcher of iced tea using leaves means straining the brew, and few tea filters can hold enough leaves for six or eight cups.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Yorktown: Spill Kills Trout
description: A major Westchester trout stream, Amawalk Outlet, was fouled and more than 1,000 trout died over the weekend when chlorine seeped from the Yorktown Town Pool into a lake that feeds the stream, New York City officials said. There is no immediate health threat, officials said. But Charles G. Sturcken, chief of staff of the New York City Department of Environmental Protection, said New York may sue Yorktown because other chemicals might have entered the water supply. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: Profile: James Merrill Jeffords
description: NAME: JAMES MERRILL JEFFORDS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMPULLA, PHILIP V.
description: RAMPULLA-Philip V. Of Staten Island on May 21, 2001. Beloved husband of Libera (nee Pistilli). Loving father of Leonard, Philip L., Robert and Janet Healy. Dear brother of Rose Brennan and Anthony. Devoted grandfather of Leann, Peter, Nina, Samantha, Amanda, Emily, Claire, Sarah, Robert and Philip. Funeral from Matthew Funeral Home Inc., 2508 Victory Blvd at Willowbrook Rd, S.I. on Friday 9:15 AM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Thomas the Apostle Church, 10AM. Interment Moravian Cemetery. Friends may call Wed and Thurs 2-4 & 7-9.

title: Airline Based At Kennedy Expands West
description: The slow pace of development at Kennedy Airport by the Port Authority is pushing JetBlue Airways, the fast-growing low-fare airline, to expand near Los Angeles.

title: AOL Raising Monthly Rate 9%; a Rival May Follow Suit
description: America Online said yesterday that it would increase the price of its flagship online service by 9 percent, to $23.90 a month, in a striking show of confidence that its customers would remain loyal as its price rises further above those of its rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, NORMAN
description: GOLDBERG-Norman, 77, beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother and friend. Passed away on Monday, May 21, 2001, losing a noble seven month battle with pancreatic cancer. Norman was a tough, strong-willed, generous provider and is again with his beloved Sally Ann. Norman passed at home in the company of his family. Shiva will be observed through Thursday, May 24, at his home in Stony Point, New York.

title: A New Fund-Raising Season
description: Just as the House prepares to take up campaign finance reform, along come President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney to give the cause an inadvertent assist. This week Mr. Bush has been participating in precisely the kind of fund-raising events that the Republicans deplored during the Clinton years. Mr. Cheney even held a reception for 400 activists and donors at his home, defending the use of his official residence just as President Clinton defended the White House coffees and sleepovers. Clearly, Congress needs to force the administration to fulfill its pledge to restore honor and integrity in Washington by passing the campaign finance bill in July.

title: Sudan War On Agenda For Powell In Africa Visit
description: During his weeklong trip to Africa that begins on Wednesday, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will discuss the issues of AIDS and regional conflicts, including one in Sudan that has become the focus of an unusual domestic alliance.

title: Analyst Sees Slow Quarter For Australia
description: The fallout from the collapse in March of Australia's second-largest general insurer, HIH Insurance, is spreading across the economy, threatening to retard economic growth in the second quarter, an economist said in a report today.

title: Colin Powell Visits Africa
description: Sub-Saharan Africa is an unstable region of 48 countries and 600 million people that Washington cannot afford to ignore. Secretary of State Colin Powell's visit to the continent this week is a welcome recognition of that reality. But as the Clinton administration learned in eight years of energetic but often futile engagement, good intentions are not enough to help resolve Africa's formidable problems. Demonstrations of concern must be matched by sustained diplomacy with a clear emphasis on promoting humane and accountable government.

title: Bush at Yale: A 'C' Student's Path
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Bush Cabinet Members Drop Meetings With G.O.P. Donors
description: While President Bush greeted Republican donors at a $23.9 million fund-raising dinner tonight, at least three members of his cabinet backed out of private meetings that had been set up with some of the donors for later this week.

title: A Shower of Shells: A Palestinian's Close Call
description: Reporters traipsed through the master bathroom of Jibril Rajoub's house today, getting a highly unusual glimpse of a Palestinian security chief's jacuzzi and shampoo collection. The marble floor was still littered with the brown glass that blew from the windows when Israeli tank shells struck on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAULT, ROSEMARY FORD
description: GAULT-Rosemary Ford, peacefully at home on May 19, 2001 after a long illness. Leaves her husband Matthew Gault, daughters Rosette Ford Gault and Virginia Gault, grandson Matthew Freeman, sister Patricia Ford Smith, predeceased by her daughter Harriet Gault Freeman and parents Henry W. Ford and Harriet Cramp Ford. A loving wife, mother and loyal friend. No calling hours. Interment private. Memorial Service at 11:30AM, Saturday, June 9, 2001 Trinity Church Princeton. Contributions may be made to the Medical Center at Princeton.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecommunications Privatization
description: The Australian government said that it would delay any further privatization of the Telstra Corporation, the nation's leading telephone company, until the fiscal year ending June 30, 2004. The government has already sold 49.9 percent of the company, but opposition has developed to a further sale because of concern about telecommunications in rural areas.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some copies on Sunday with a column about men's collegiate lacrosse misidentified the player holding the ball. He was Jay Abendroth of Syracuse, not Michael Bennett, who played for Hofstra.

title: Elder Disappointed He Was Passed Over for Captain's Job
description: On a rainy day at Ridgewood Country Club, Lee Elder was more interested in making a point than he was in making putts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELLIOT E.
description: COHEN-Elliot E., 85. Of Williamsburg, VA., formerly of New York City, on May 21, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Helen, devoted uncle and great-uncle, and greatgreat uncle. Graveside service Thursday, May 24, 2:00 PM, Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions may be made to The Elliot and Helen Cohen Forum, care of: Joel Schwartz, Charles Center, P.O. Box 8795, College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Virginia 23186.
