description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Far Hills Journal; The Hills Are Alive With Sounds of Money
description: The people who make jokes about New Jersey are not typically acquainted with the verdant enchantments of Somerset County.

title: ING, DUTCH INSURER, REPORTS 11% JUMP IN QUARTER PROFIT
description: Largely because of successful acquisitions in the United States, ING, the giant insurance and banking company based in Amsterdam, reported a 10.6 percent increase yesterday in net profit from operations in the first quarter. Though the figure fell short of the company's 12 percent target, it was much better than the 5 percent consensus forecast of analysts, and investors bid up the company's stock by 1.7 percent, to 117 Swiss francs a share. Ewald Kist, ING's chief executive, said in an interview that the company was beginning a major American ad campaign this week. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: When Appetites Have an Edge, And Need One
description: For multitasking, there's nothing like the trusty Swiss Army knife on a picnic. But when it comes to style, there's competition from Japan this summer: an elegant knife that comes in a sleek honey-colored wood sheath with black trim. The blade, almost four inches long, is razor-sharp, ready to tackle that salami or hunk of cheese, and it's broad enough for slathering mustard. The knife is $8 at Williams-Sonoma stores.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Response To Miners' Deaths
description: After a series of accidents that left at least 51 miners dead, the Coal Mine Safety Inspection Bureau has ordered local authorities to close small coal mines around the country by next month, China Central Television reported. Unsafe conditions, especially in smaller, poorly equipped mines, result in close to 10,000 deaths each year, officials say. Previous efforts to impose safety standards have met little success. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: Robinson Holds a Key To the Spurs' Recovery
description: The tale is less than a year old, but it is already part of franchise lore. David Robinson flew back from his Hawaiian vacation last summer to spend quality time with his teammate Tim Duncan, helping persuade him to stay in San Antonio rather than move to Orlando.

title: Foreign Graduates Ask, 'What Now?'
description: As an undergraduate at the University of Virginia here for the last four years, Rasha Shaath, a Palestinian, learned Hebrew. She thrived in classes that made her examine her views and the troubles of her region from many angles.

title: A Host's Worst Nightmare: When Dinner Bites Back
description: THE menu was adventurous and full of exotic ingredients. But that was expected at the annual Explorers Club dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. What was not expected was a follow-up questionnaire from the Health Department.

title: Testing Requirement to Stay In House Bill on Education
description: Fending off conservatives and liberals, the House voted today to support annual testing of schoolchildren in grades three to eight, the cornerstone of President Bush's education proposal.

title: Deal Reached On Sale of Jets To Chileans
description: The Bush administration has reached a deal with Senate Democrats that would allow the sale of 10 F-16 jets to Chile, the first transfer of sophisticated American fighter planes to Latin America in nearly two decades, Congressional officials said today.

title: Bush Is Putting Team in Place for a Full-Bore Assault on Regulation
description: Across an array of federal agencies, the Bush administration has begun to make good on its commitment of broad deregulation, promoting a policy transformation long sought by the business community and opposed by consumer, labor and environmental organizations.

title: NBC Triumphs In Ratings Race
description: The May ratings sweep -- and the official television season -- ends tonight, but the results for both are pretty well settled.

title: Trading on Their Names; Turning Government Experience Into Corporate Advice
description: The promotional materials say it all: William S. Cohen, the former defense secretary, is shown chatting with King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, sharing a smile with Nelson Mandela, standing shoulder to shoulder with President Jiang Zemin of China and in a ''grip and grin'' pose with President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, resplendent in his African robes and dark sunglasses.

title: Web Sites Inconsistent On Health, Study Finds
description: A new study has found that most of the time, health information on the Internet is hard to find, hard to read and often incorrect or incomplete, even on the best sites.

title: Grilled Salmon, No Bones About It
description: WHEN I entertain, I want to have fun. But I'm also a control person. I don't go in for those everyone-in-the-kitchen cooking scenes. So if I want to be with my guests, I have to do everything -- or nearly everything -- in advance.

title: Harry G. A. Seggerman, 73, a Pioneer Investor in Asian Companies
description: Harry G. A. Seggerman, a pioneer in investing in Asian companies, died on Saturday in Fairfield, Conn., where he lived. He was 73.

title: Councilwoman Joins Crowded Race in Bronx
description: June M. Eisland, a city councilwoman from the Bronx, announced yesterday that she would run in the Democratic primary for Bronx borough president. Ms. Eisland becomes the fourth person to formally enter a race that is filled with ethnic politics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, BETTY
description: WECHSLER-Betty. We extend our sincerest condolences to Marcel Wechsler, Benny Wechsler and Susan Rhein on the passing of their beloved mother. A true ''Eishes Chayil'', she embodied the qualities of elegance, charm and kindness. Betty and her late husband, Sammy, a Founding Board Member and past Treasurer, were Silver Founders of the Medical Center. She was a devoted member of the Shaare Zedek Ladies Auxiliary and personified the highest standards of Tzedakah and Chesed, in her love and support of important Jewish causes that build and strengthen Israel. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Amer. Comm. for Shaare Zedek Jerusalem Med. Ctr.

title: Stocks Slide as Investors Take Profits from Recent Rally
description: Stock prices fell today as investors pulled back in the absence of economic news and took some profits from the market's recent rally.

title: Other Nations Balk at Picking Up Tab : UN Health Agency Reduces U.S. Dues
description: GENEVA  The U.S. government on Tuesday won a reduction in its budgetary contributions to the World Health Organization, although the head of the United Nations agency warned that some health programs could suffer as a result.

title: Bush at Yale: A 'C' Student's Path
description: To the Editor:

title: It Feels Like a California Mother's Day With Disaffected Youth
description: There are several promising young actors in ''Blood Orange,'' a play by David Wiener at the Blue Heron Arts Center near Gramercy Park. They include Pablo T. Schreiber as Clinton, a 19-year-old bully with a softhearted concern for his embittered mother; Julienne Hanzelka Kim as his 14-year-old girlfriend, who has romantic dreams and far too much sexual experience and frets about her mom, a desperate gold digger; and Brian Sacca as Ray-Ray, Clinton's neighbor and friend of sorts, who is more like an object of ridicule and a punching bag and who has a grave sympathy for his mom, who is dying of cancer.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Judicial Nominations
description: President Bush nominated Sharon Prost for the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, in Washington and Lavenski R. Smith for a seat on the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in Little Rock, Ark. Ms. Prost is the chief counsel for the Republican majority on the Senate Judiciary Committee, a senior aide to Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah. The federal circuit has a specialized nationwide jurisdiction, financial claims against the federal government. Mr. Smith is a black conservative Republican who has served appointed terms on the Arkansas Supreme Court and on the State Public Service Commission. He would replace Richard S. Arnold, the former chief judge of the circuit. Neil A. Lewis (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Getting Better At EMI
description: Buoyed by sales of a top-selling Beatles compilation, the EMI Group, the world's No. 3 music company, said it had increased market share in the United States and around the world, positioning itself as a stand-alone business after failed mergers with AOL Time Warner and Bertelsmann. EMI said global market share was up 1.6 percentage points, to 14.1 percent, and its slice of the United States market had grown to 10.8 percent from 9 percent, gains ascribed by the company in part to the sale of 23 million copies of the Beatles 1 compilation. Full-year pretax adjusted profit rose 5.7 percent, to $373 million, but net income was down 48 percent, to $118 million, because of the costs of its failed merger with AOL Time Warner, the company said. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Cone Is Comfortable Playing Joe Hardy
description: The audacious suggestion was made here last year that David Cone had sold his soul to the devil. How else to explain his perfect game against the Montreal Expos on July 18, 1999, followed by the worst pitching of his career, a record of 6 victories and 19 losses in 42 starts. And if there was any doubt, there he was, set to become the No. 2 starter behind Pedro Martnez in the Boston Red Sox rotation when a shoulder ailment knocked him out for two months this year.

title: Trivia Question:
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. For more baseball trivia questions, subscribe to The Baseball Report , a weekly e-mail newsletter.

title: A Fearless Chef With an Artistic Streak
description: OFTEN, when a chef has been running a top-flight restaurant for more than five years, one of two bad things happens. Either the chef settles into a routine, and a formula, and the kitchen starts to sag, or the chef goes stir-crazy and indulges in strange experiments.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arraignment In St. John's Case
description: Carmine Galante, a nephew of the former Bonanno crime family boss, was arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn in the 1999 murder of a St. John's University student. The police say Mr. Galante, 23, stabbed the student, William Manolis, 18, during an argument over a woman in a Bay Ridge bar. Mr. Galante is charged with second-degree murder; if convicted, he faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life. Nichole M. Christian (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENCRANS, BARBARA
description: ROSENCRANS - Barbara. The Board of Directors and Administration of CNR Health Care Network note with sorrow the passing of Barbara Rosencrans, wife of our past Board Chairman and President, and extend sincere sympathy to the family. Kenneth Fuld, Chairman Joel E. Cohen, President Michael S. Fassler, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARONSON, HOWARD
description: SARONSON - Howard. Beloved husband of the late Ruth. Devoted father of Paul and Sharon Saronson, David and Betty Saronson. Cherished grandfather of Matthew, Robert, Daniel and James. Services Wednesday, 10:45, at Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel, Inc., 1978 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Visitation 7-9 PM, Tuesday, May 22nd. Burial to follow Wednesday after the services at the Rosehill Memorial Park Cemetery, Putnam Valley, NY.

title: More Than One Way of Looking at Software Maker's Earnings
description: Computer Associates International offered investors a choice of earnings reports yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Bail Granted In Killing Of Reputed Thief
description: A Bronx man charged with killing a man who he said was breaking into his car was freed Monday on $15,000 bail. The man, Victor Vicenty, 53, of Lacombe Avenue, had been held without bail. He was indicted May 14 on a second-degree manslaughter charge in the shooting of Kevin Bethea, 43, on May 7. Bail was set by Justice John N. Byrne of State Supreme Court in the Bronx after prosecutors argued for a $100,000 bond. If convicted, Mr. Vicenty faces up to 15 years in prison.

title: Panel Still Split on Solicitor General Nominee
description: Senate Republicans said today that they would push for a final vote this week on the nomination of Theodore B. Olson as solicitor general, while Democrats said they were unsure if they had been given enough time to examine accusations that Mr. Olson had misrepresented his role in anti-Clinton activities.

title: A Proud Garden Where a Dozen Playwrights Grow
description: Beaming out from a row of congratulatory bouquets in the lobby of his Victory Gardens Theater recently, Dennis Zacek greeted a visitor by shouting, ''Over the moon!''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: O'Connor Announces For Executive
description: James P. O'Connor, 38, a Republican town councilman from North Hempstead, formally announced yesterday that he would seek his party's backing in the race for county executive this year. The Republicans are to hold a convention tomorrow to pick their candidate. Bruce R. Bent, a Republican financier, said that if Mr. O'Connor was chosen by party elders, he would force a primary. Al Baker (NYT)

title: INHALE, MAKER OF DRUG-DELIVERY SYSTEMS, BUYS COMPANY
description: Inhale Therapeutic Systems, which makes drug-delivery devices, said it would buy the closely held Shearwater Corporation for about $191 million. Inhale will pay for the acquisition with $72.5 million in cash and four million shares, based on Monday's closing price of $29.57, the company said. The purchase is the second this year by Inhale, which is based in San Carlos, Calif. Shearwater, based in Huntsville, Ala., makes a delivery system used in drugs like Roche Holding's hepatitis treatment Pegasys, which allows patients to take the drugs less frequently.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROTTA, HAROLD E.
description: GROTTA-Harold E. Of Llewellyn Park, NJ. Beloved husband of Jane (nee Meyer). Loving father of Toni G. Wolfman and James C. Grotta, most precious grandfather and great grandfather. Funeral services at Temple Bnai Jeshurun, 1025 So. Orange Ave., Short Hills, New Jersey, Thursday, May 24, 2001 at 3 PM. Should friends desire contributions may be made to the University of Virginia Law School. For additional information please call ''Kreitzman's Memorial Home'', 1-888-351-4414.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLNICK, DOROTHY
description: SOLNICK-Dorothy. On May 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving aunt to Stanley Guss, Allene Grognet, Joan Friedman and Jess Edwards. She died peacefully in her sleep at 107 years. She will be long remembered by her family, friends and mostly by her former students. Graveside services at 11 AM, Thursday, May 24, Mount Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: College Entrance in China: 'No' to the Handicapped
description: When Liu Wenxiu was growing up in central Hunan province, she never thought of herself as disabled. She limped, as a result of a misplaced injection when she was a toddler, but she was smart and popular -- that was who she was.

title: Everyone Out of the Kitchen!
description: THERE'S a reason hot dogs and hamburgers are what everyone serves at a backyard party: Calling the classic barbecue ''easy'' is an understatement, and if you serve the basics, at least you get the pleasures of outdoor cooking without an overwhelming amount of work.

title: INSIDE
description: Ford Begins Tire Recall

title: California Leaders Sue to Force U.S. Energy Agency to Limit Power Prices
description: California's Democratic legislative leaders filed suit today in federal appeals court seeking to force the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to limit wholesale power prices on the grounds that failure to do so threatens health, safety and drinking water supplies in the nation's most populous state.

title: FASSEL HAS SURGERY
description: Coach Jim Fassel of the Giants underwent surgery yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan to have bone spurs removed from his neck. He is expected to be released today. He will recuperate at home the rest of the week, and is expected to return to work after the Memorial Day holiday and be at work for the Giants' minicamp, which begins June 4.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ITZKOWITZ, PHIL
description: ITZKOWITZ-Phil. The National Officers of EMUNAH of America and the entire membership extend sincere condolences to our Honorary National Vice President Eleanor Itzkowitz upon the passing of her beloved husband, Phil. Deepest sympathy to the children; Helen, David and Alan, his grandchildren and to his sisters. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marcia Genuth, Nat'l Pres. EMUNAH of America

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTIN, DOROTHY (NEE SEGAL)
description: BERTIN-Dorothy (nee Segal). On May 21. Loving wife of Sidney Bertin, sister of Joan Hirst, mother of Michael and Susan. She was the grandmother of Amy, Laura, Sarah and Anna. Dorothy was the great grandmother of Ted, Allison, Nathan, and Jeffrey and she had many nieces and nephews. She was unselfish, giving and kind, and always had time and patience for her family and friends. Dorothy, we miss you. Funeral services will be May 24th at noon at Garlick Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Road, Bronx, NY (718) 892-9400.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Police Sign Up For Community Course
description: More than 600 officers and supervisors have signed up for a tuition-free college course at the City University of New York on how to better serve the neighborhoods they patrol. The course, ''Policing a Multicultural City,'' will be given at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice starting tomorrow. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: VA Linux Loss Widens
description: VA Linux Systems, once a symbol of the challenge open-source software posed to Microsoft, said weak sales caused its operating losses to triple in the latest quarter, compared with a year earlier. Revenue declined more than 50 percent as start-up and dot-com customers ''evaporated,'' said Larry M. Augustin, the company's chief executive. For its fiscal third quarter, ended April 28, VA Linux reported a loss, excluding one-time items, of $19 million, or 38 cents a share. The report beat analysts' forecasts by 2 cents a share and compared with a loss of 13 cents a share in the 2000 quarter. Including special items like a $46.8 million restructuring charge, the net loss soared to $109.7 million, or $2.21 a share. The company's stock gained 34 cents, to $4.70. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Talks On Nuclear Site
description: A team from the International Atomic Energy Agency is to open talks today to try to persuade the North to provide full access to its nuclear complex at Yongbyon. North Korea is expected to press its demand that a consortium led by the United States stop delaying construction of twin nuclear reactors to fulfill the North's energy needs, as provided in a 1994 agreement. It has threatened to resume work at the site, where it was suspected of making weapons-grade plutonium, if the reactors are not built by 2003. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: When Colorblindness Cramps Careers
description: Dr. Jay M. Cohen has heard it all at the clinic on West 42nd Street in Manhattan. Patients vent about workplace frustrations, stalled careers and shattered dreams.

title: Mayor Says Mother Is 'Doing O.K.' in Hospital
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his mother, Helen Giuliani, 91, was ''doing O.K.'' at Mount Sinai Hospital, where she was taken Monday evening after fainting in her apartment.

title: Dogged Fight by Senate Democrats Delays Tax Cut Bill
description: Lacking the votes to block the $1.35 trillion tax cut moving through Congress, Democrats in the Senate delayed its passage today to make their argument one final time that the plan was fiscally irresponsible and excessively tilted to the wealthy.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At Airline
description: Reversing its first annual loss as a publicly traded company last year, British Airways reported a full-year profit of 114 million ($164 million). It said it had reduced the number of cheap-seat passengers to focus on business class fliers paying top prices. The turnaround came despite the economic slowdown in the United States and Britain's outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, which deterred some travelers. Shares of British Airways rose 6 percent, to 377 pence ($5.43). The company also said it expected its supersonic Concorde flights to the United States to resume in late summer. The airplanes have been grounded since the crash last July of an Air France Concorde near Paris in which more than 100 people died. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Hutu Attack From Congo
description: Two years of relative peace in Rwanda splintered as Hutu rebels attacked in the northwest from bases in Congo. Rwandan Army officials said 35 rebels had been killed and 22 captured. Regional experts speculate that the attacks and similar violence in Burundi are byproducts of the peace effort in Congo. Militant Hutu who have been fighting there for a few years appear to be moving back toward Rwanda and Burundi now that most other combatants in Congo have moved to end the multination war there. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Warnaco Reports Loss of $62.5 Million
description: The Warnaco Group, whose stock has lost almost all its value in the last year, reported a loss for its most recent quarter yesterday as investment income fell, borrowing costs rose and the company sold less off-price and close-out merchandise.

title: A Chinese Exile Traces Every Fault to Himself
description: A MEMOIR OF MISFORTUNE

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Budget Standoff
description: After weeks of feuding with Gov. Jesse Ventura over how to spend the state's $2.4 billion budget surplus, state legislators ended their five-month session on Monday night without agreeing on a budget. At stake is a two-year, $27 billion state budget that would allow courts, prisons, schools and other programs to operate after July 1. The Legislature must also decide the fate of Mr. Ventura's proposal to have state assume all basic school costs in order to reduce schools' dependence on property taxes. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: TV Notes: NBC Triumphs in Ratings Race
description: The May ratings sweep  and the official television season  ends tonight, but the results for both are pretty well settled.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Law Firm To Move
description: The law firm Thelen Reid & Priest signed a deal this month to move from its longtime home on 57th Street, between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, to a tower at 875 Third Avenue, between 52nd and 53rd Streets. In the largest lease negotiated so far this year by a law firm, Thelen Reid & Priest will move its 425 lawyers to 178,000 square feet on seven floors in the 29-story tower by November 2002. The deal was wrapped up in two weeks, said Insignia/ESG, the real estate broker that represented the law firm and the landlord, Boston Properties. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: A Sensible Plan for Kosovo
description: We bombed Yugoslavia for 78 days because of Kosovo. For the last two years we have been pumping money into this benighted province by the millions; thousands of European and American soldiers are stationed there. Ever since the end of the war we have all been wondering, what are we to do with Kosovo?

title: Colony Beach and Tennis Resort
description: Tennis players looking for a getaway in Florida may want to consider a package offered by the Colony Beach and Tennis Resort on Longboat Key, near Sarasota, Fla. The Colony, one of the country's top tennis resorts, has an Ultimate Fun and Sun program for four nights (starting at $865 for two) and seven nights (from $1,480 for two). These prices include a one-bedroom suite, daily Continental breakfast, a $10 dinner credit ($20 for seven nights) and a one-hour tennis clinic (two for the longer stay). Children under 18 stay free when sharing a room with adults. The hotel's rates include tennis court time, supervised recreation programs for children ages 3 to 12, separate men's and women's health spas and an exercise center. Information: (800) 426-5669 or www.colonybeachresort.com .

title: A Rivalry Fought Out In Dueling Lobster Rolls
description: DO not invite Rebecca Charles and Mary Redding to the same clambake.

title: Arnott Awakens, As Does His Line
description: Jason Arnott missed the Devils' first 19 games this season because of a contract dispute.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Wins First AT&T Order
description: The Ciena Corporation, the nation's second-largest maker of fiber optic equipment, reached its first supply agreement with AT&T. Terms were not disclosed, but the companies said they had also agreed on prices for future orders. Shares of Ciena rose $3.51, or 5.8 percent, to $64.30 on the strength of the news. AT&T, the nation's No. 1 long-distance phone company, has tested and installed Ciena gear that beams and directs information through citywide optical networks.

title: Fires Believed Set as Protest Against Genetic Engineering
description: One fire gutted a research laboratory at the University of Washington Center for Urban Horticulture here, while the other destroyed two buildings and several vehicles at a poplar tree nursery in the northwestern corner of Oregon. Both were reported shortly after 3 a.m. Monday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bids On Gas Project
description: The PetroChina Company, the largest oil producer in China, said it had received proposals from 12 companies to invest in a $14 billion project to build a natural gas pipeline to span the country. The world's top three publicly traded oil companies, Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell and BP, each submitted bids to build the 4,000-kilometer pipeline, which will stretch from China's northwestern province of Xinjiang to Shanghai on the east coast. TotalFinaElf, the No. 4 oil company, did not bid. Few companies are attracted by the pipeline project itself, which is expected to generate poor returns. But many are interested in exploring for oil and gas in China's western regions. To entice investors, PetroChina said foreign drilling in the country's largest gas field would be limited to companies that are involved in building the pipeline. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Vivendi Said to Be in Talks About Acquiring Houghton
description: Vivendi Universal of France is in preliminary talks to acquire Houghton Mifflin, the venerable United States publishing house, people close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMALL, ROBERTA A.
description: SMALL-Roberta A. Of Clinton Corners, New York, & Manhattan. Devoted mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, sister and aunt, died on May 21, 2001 from complications due to cancer. An advertising executive before retiring to the country life where she became active in local politics and assumed a seat on her town Board of Appeals. Her life was guided by her strength of character, love for family and pride in community. Her last months were defined by bravery, humor and a continued concern for others. She will be deeply missed.

title: KING PHARMACEUTICALS LIFTS PROFIT AND SALES OUTLOOKS
description: King Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that its second-quarter and 2001 profit and sales would be higher than forecast because of increased demand for the heart drug Altace and other brand-name medications. King expects second-quarter earnings of 29 cents to 30 cents a share, before charges, on sales of $190 million to $200 million, beating its earlier forecast of 26 cents to 27 cents on revenue of $180 million to $190 million. King increased 2001 earnings projections, before charges, to $1.21 to $1.24 a share from $1.18 to $1.21. King, based in Bristol, Tenn., raised its 2001 sales forecast to a range of $781 million to $811 million from $771 million to $801 million.

title: Hevesi Criticized for Suggesting Changes in State Antistrike Law
description: Alan G. Hevesi came under attack by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and one of Mr. Hevesi's Democratic opponents for mayor yesterday for declaring at a labor forum that he would support changing a state law that prohibits strikes by public employees.

title: Care Is Challenged for Mentally Ill Inmates
description: New York City says more than 16,836 inmates have been released from its jails since a court ruled in March that it must arrange continuing mental health care for former inmates in need of it. But the city and lawyers for the mentally ill inmates disagree about how many received more than the city's standard parting gifts to released inmates: a MetroCard, $1.50 and a bus ride to Queens Plaza.

title: PEABODY ENERGY STOCK SOARS AT INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
description: The Peabody Energy Corporation's shares rose 31 percent in their first day of trading as the company, the biggest coal miner in the nation, benefited from rising energy prices and the Bush administration's efforts to promote coal. Lehman Brothers Holdings, which owned 87 percent of Peabody before the initial public offering yesterday, sold 15 million shares at $28. The coal company's stock closed at $36.80. The offering raised $420 million, $99 million more than Lehman had predicted. Coal prices are the highest in 17 years because of surging power consumption and rising costs for competing fuels like natural gas.

title: Miller to Remain a Democrat
description: Senator Zell Miller, a conservative Georgia Democrat who has come under Republican pressure to switch parties, reiterated today that he would not do so despite Senator James M. Jeffords's apparent decision to leave the Republican fold.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE<BR BRITAIN: GETTING BETTER AT EMI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAUS, CARL
description: CLAUS-Carl. Of Chappaqua, New York, died on May 20. He was 92. He was born in Berlin, Germany and emigrated with his parents, the late Dr. Carl Claus and Elsie Regling Claus, to the United States when he was an infant. He graduated from Plainfield High School in Plainfield, NJ in 1927 and Lehigh University in Bethlehem, PA in 1931. After graduation from college, he began a career with the Babcock & Wilcox Company that spanned 43 years and culminated in his retirement in 1974 as Corporate Vice President. During his tenure with Babcock & Wilcox, he served in various positions in Barberton, OH, Bayonne, NJ, Augusta, GA, and New York City. He is a former member of the Delta Upsilon fraternity, the Augusta Country Club, the Augusta Rotary Club of which he was a past president, and the former Cloud Club of New York City of which he was also a past president. He was a longstanding member of the Whippoorwill Country Club in Armonk, NY and served on its Board of Governors and as the Club's 'Santa Claus' for many years. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Ruby Miller Claus, his son, Carl M. Claus, and two grandchildren, Lois F. Claus and Carl R. Claus. Interment will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the New Castle Police Benevolent Association or to the Chappaqua Volunteer Ambulance Corps.

title: After 5 Years of Fiscal Success, City Public Hospitals Face Deficit
description: New York City's public hospital system, after five years of operating in the black, is poised to end its fiscal year with a $210 million deficit stemming from the very strategy adopted in recent years to assure its long-term fiscal health: moving a lot of patient care away from hospitals and into primary care clinics.

title: In 2 Years, Mt. Vernon Test Scores Turn Around
description: Three years ago, fourth-grade reading scores here were among the worst in the state. At one school, just 12 percent of students met the state standards. Over all, one-third did.

title: Boardroom Intrigue With Marc Rich
description: Marc Rich's retirement from the commodity trading business and the controversy over his pardon by President Bill Clinton do not seem to have dimmed his appetite for making deals.

title: G.O.P. Senator Is Considering A Party Switch
description: Senator James M. Jeffords, a Vermont Republican, indicated today that he was seriously considering changing parties after a series of disputes with the Bush White House. Through the day, Republicans including the president worked urgently to dissuade him from giving control of the evenly divided Senate to the Democrats.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Tribes Lose Protest
description: Despite protests by environmentalists and American Indians, the Bureau of Land Management ruled this week to allow exploratory drilling of one oil well in southern Montana. A decision in February to allow the Anschutz Exploration Corporation to drill was appealed by 10 tribes and environmental groups. Officials at the land bureau note that the drilling site is a quarter-mile from ancient rock art or other historic places. Tribal leaders from Oklahoma and Montana have compared the site to the Sistine Chapel and continue to hold religious ceremonies in the area they consider sacred. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Our Towns; You Don't Need Hands To Paint, or Eyes to Inspire
description: AS an abstract artist, Tim Lefens always viewed art as pure expression, liberated from fads, expectations, conventional thinking.

title: Taliban Propose an Identity Label for the 'Protection' of Hindus
description: The Taliban rulers, worldwide pariahs for their harsh treatment of Afghan women and Buddhist statues, face further scorn with a proposal that would force Hindus to wear an identity label on their clothing to distinguish them from Muslims.

title: Tibetans Going to Meeting
description: Two Tibetan exile organizations usually barred by China from international events got the go-ahead today to participate in a United Nations conference on racism and other forms of discrimination to be held this summer in Durban, South Africa.

title: Article 2001052394132316223 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Senate Tax-Bill Delay
description: Lacking the votes to block the $1.35 trillion tax cut moving through Congress, Senate Democrats delayed its passage to make their argument one final time that the plan was fiscally irresponsible.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON SLUMPS. Cotton fell as wet weather in the Southeast improved prospects for the United States crop. In New York, cotton for July delivery fell 0.63 cent, or 1.5 percent, to 42.56 cents a pound.

title: Researchers Debunk Placebo Effect, Saying It's Only a Myth
description: In a new report that is being met with a mixture of astonishment and, sometimes, disbelief, two researchers say that the placebo effect is a myth.

title: Article 2001052390143056135 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Target's Net Rises 6.3% As It Expands To New Areas
description: The Target Corporation said today that profit in its most recent quarter rose 6.3 percent as it pushed its expansion outside the Midwest and into big markets like New Jersey and Texas.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell again after German business confidence declined more than expected in April. In New York, the euro settled at 86.53 cents, down from 87.69 cents on Monday.

title: Uneasy Death-Penalty Trial in Washington
description: In the relentless national agenda that envelopes this city, the trial of Tommy Edelin, the accused principal in 11 local drug-war murders, is an unremarkable event barely noticed, except that his life is at stake.

title: BULLETIN BOARD
description: Fund-Raisers Ignore Market Swings

title: Loften Mitchell, 82, Dramatist and Writer on Black Theater
description: Loften Mitchell, a playwright, author, teacher and an early leader of the black theater movement, died on May 14 in Queens, where he lived. He was 82.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday with the Market Place column, about a decision by Staples to buy back shares of Staples.com, referred to the online business incorrectly. While a planned initial public offering for Staples.com was shelved, it is not ''a failed dot-com.''

title: New Yorker Has Low Hopes for New Peru Trial
description: LIMA, Peru, May 20  It is Sunday at the high-security women's prison in the grimy neighborhood of Chorrillos. Visitors bring corn on the cob, spicy rice dishes and stories from home to relatives and friends, many of whom have been convicted of terrorism. Sweet love songs play on radios and there are laughter and hugs in the courtyard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, FREDA AARON
description: GOODMAN-Freda Aaron. On May 21, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Jack Aaron. Loving mother of Michael and the late Alan Aaron. Devoted sister of Bell Rogat and the late Molly Berns, Lottie Dinnerstein and Milton Rogat. Cherished grandmother of Alexander Aaron, Abigail Neave and greatgrandmother to Nicolson Neave. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Comptroller Blocks Contracts For Pataki's Charter Flights
description: The state comptroller's office has decided to reject contracts that the state police signed with eight charter airplane companies to transport Gov. George E. Pataki around the state, officials said.

title: Outdoor Bars: Drinking in the Sun
description: First Line --> Open space may be at a premium in New York, but many bars, restaurants and nightclubs manage to find a little room (on the sidewalk, out back, on the roof) for customers to enjoy a summer breeze while throwing back a few. Here is a list of establishments where drinking alcohol outside is not only possible, but suggested.

title: TROUBLED DEVIL RAYS GETTING HELP
description: The Tampa Bay Devil Rays yesterday named John McHale Jr. as their chief operating officer. McHale, who had been president and chief executive officer of the Detroit Tigers for six and a half seasons, was the personal choice of Commissioner Bud Selig to resolve the nasty conflict that had arisen between Vincent Naimoli, the team's managing general partner, and his five partners. Michael Ilitch, the Tigers' owner, acknowledged yesterday that Selig had called him and asked him to let McHale go to the Devil Rays.

title: The Graduate
description: To the Editor:

title: Troubling Signs of a Slowdown Emerge in Europe's Economy
description: FRANKFURT, May 23  The European economy showed troubling new signs today of slower growth and faster inflation, a toxic mix that helped drive down the value of the euro to its lowest level this year against the American dollar.

title: Heady Scent From the Grill: The Wood of the Fig
description: Chefs love hardwoods for grilling. Fig wood, which burns hot and fast and sends a heady, almost sweetly floral aroma into the air, is the latest one gaining their favor.

title: LABRANCHE, A FLOOR TRADER ON THE BIG BOARD, BUYS A FIRM
description: LaBranche & Company, the biggest New York Stock Exchange floor-trading firm by listings, agreed to buy Bocklet & Company in its fifth acquisition since going public in 1999. Smaller trading firms like Bocklet, faced with mounting capital requirements and bigger rivals, are increasingly selling out. In the last five years, the number of specialists has more than halved, to 17. The purchase of Bocklet, which makes markets in 60 companies, including Nike, DaimlerChrysler and Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, would expand LaBranche's list to 572 companies.

title: Lessons; How to Ease the Burden Of Homework for Families
description: IT is a ''second shift.'' In better-off homes, parents often return from work to preside over long and contentious homework sessions. As talk at suburban soccer and baseball fields makes clear, expansion of homework has provoked great middle-class angst.

title: A Rockefeller Ranch Is Given to Grand Teton Park
description: Laurance S. Rockefeller, the conservationist and scion of one of the nation's most famous industrial families, plans to donate his 1,106-acre ranch in Jackson, Wyo., to the Interior Department for inclusion in Grand Teton National Park.

title: Frank Slaughter, Novelist Of Medicine, Is Dead at 93
description: Frank G. Slaughter, a surgeon who became a prolific best-selling novelist, publishing 56 books that sold an estimated 60 million copies and were translated into all major languages, died on May 17 in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 93.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Project Near Kennedy
description: Construction will begin next month on a $100 million office, cargo and warehouse development in Jamaica, Queens, near Kennedy Airport. International Airport Centers L.L.C. of Highland Park, Ill., is planning four buildings totaling 530,000 square feet on 25 acres along Rockaway Boulevard. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs the airport, said it had granted a waiver for use of the land. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; Asking Rents for Stores Stay Level in Manhattan
description: The rents that landlords are seeking for stores held steady in Manhattan, and increased in some districts, despite a weakening national economy, according to a survey of space availability and asking rents focusing on September 2000 and March 2001.

title: Liberties; From A to Y at Yale
description: The driven hippie chick came back to Yale, with straight blond hair instead of frizzy brown, and pumps instead of sandals. But she was still earnestly preaching 60's feminism and activism.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS INC., Burnaby, British Columbia, a developer of fuel cells in Canada, has agreed to buy the carbon products unit of Textron Systems, Wilmington, Mass., for $12.8 million, gaining a business that makes components for fuel cells.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Energy Conservation Urged
description: Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and his Democratic colleagues called yesterday for a $300-million-a-year increase in state spending on energy conservation to nearly half a billion dollars. New York's conservation spending, by state agencies and utilities under state-mandated programs, dropped in the mid-1990's, then rose, and now totals $182 million a year. The plan to increase conservation was one of several proposals the Democrats made to address the state's electric power situation, including lowering residential rates. Richard Prez-Pea (NYT)

title: Article 2001052390745296048 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Metro Business Briefing | Casino Sale Progresses
description: The sale of the bankrupt Claridge Casino Hotel in Atlantic City could clear its last regulatory hurdle next week, state officials said yesterday. On Monday, a federal judge, Judith H. Wizmur, approved the sale to Park Place Entertainment Corporation of Las Vegas as part of a reorganization plan in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Camden, N.J. Bondholders would get back 83 percent of the $90.5 million they sought from the Claridge, while unsecured creditors would get 61 cents on the dollar. The transfer of the Claridge's gambling license to Park Place, the final approval needed for the sale, is scheduled for a vote by the State Casino Control Commission on May 30, said Daniel Heneghan, a commission spokesman.

title: Jets Promote Salary-Cap Planner
description: The Jets announced the promotion yesterday of their salary-cap manager, Mike Tannenbaum, to the newly created position of assistant general manager/director for pro personnel. Tannenbaum, 32, has been with the Jets since 1997, and has been the lead negotiator on contracts for the past four seasons. He most recently held the title of director for pro player development/contract negotiations, and in recent years has been viewed as an eventual candidate for a general manager's job.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Trial For Protesters
description: Twenty-six peace advocates charged with trespassing last November at the Army's School of the Americas in Fort Benning went to trial. Among them are a mother and daughter as well as a 88-year-old nun. The school, a military training site for Latin American soldiers, reopened in January as the Western Hemisphere Institute for Security Cooperation. If convicted, the protesters face up to six months in jail and a $5,000 fine.

title: Hofstra Death May Be Made Capital Case
description: Prosecutors in Nassau County are considering upgrading the charges against Shaun T. Alexander, who is accused of killing Max B. Kolb, his classmate at Hofstra University, from second-degree to first-degree murder.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrest In Fatal Stabbing
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested last evening and charged with the fatal stabbing of another man at a Midtown recording studio, the police said. The suspect, William Strawder, 34, was charged with second-degree murder after being picked up in Harlem, said a police spokesman, Officer George Jensen. The victim, Tonnie Sheppard, 36, also of Brooklyn, was stabbed at 1 a.m. Sunday at the Planet to Planet studio and died 24 hours later, Officer Jensen said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFER, GERALDINE
description: SCHAFFER-Geraldine. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Gerry Schaffer, for 66 years the beloved wife of our cherished friend, Irving Schaffer, a former member of the UJA-Federation Board of Directors. A stalwart supporter of our mission, Gerry was active in the Westchester Women's Campaign. She and Irving earned enormous respect and admiration with their constant philanthropic commitment to the Jewish community. Their extraordinary devotion will be felt for years to come. Irving, an outstanding supporter of UJAFederation, was honored last year by the organization on the occasion of his 90th birthday. We extend our deepest sympathies to Irving; son Peter, a past chair of the Paper Division of the UJA-Federation Office Products Division, and his wife, Eve-Marie; son Andrew and his wife, Kiki; son Rick and his wife, Barbara; and son Robin and his wife, Queenie; and to the 15 Schaffer grandchildren. May her memory be a blessing. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair and President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO Ernest W. Michel, Exec VP Emeritus

title: THE BOSS; A Job and a Life Intertwined
description: Three days after graduating from the all-women Smith College in 1968, I entered Columbia Business School where I was one of four women in a class of 275. I felt both special and out of place. I simply wanted to earn money and not type (someone said an M.B.A. would save me from the typewriter) so that my husband-to-be, George, who was in medical school also at Columbia (yes, I followed him there), and I could be married.

description: A Dairy Closes

title: Bowman Capital Is Shutting Its Technology Hedge Fund
description: Bowman Capital, one of the nation's largest hedge fund groups, is shutting down its $2 billion Bowman Technology fund and returning more than $1 billion in cash to investors.

title: Thatcher Plunges In
description: Former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher made her first appearance today in the campaign for the June 7 election, praising the embattled Tory leader William Hague as the man to lead Britain and criticizing Tony Blair as a man ''with a residue of socialism in his blood,'' his government as ''rotten'' and his policy of integration with Europe as ''utterly repugnant.'

title: New Troubles for Chief of Aer Lingus
description: In just eight months as chief executive at Aer Lingus, the Irish airline, Michael Foley has been confronted with soaring fuel costs, sputtering labor disputes that grounded the company's planes on and off for almost five days, and a swoon in reservations of more than 10 percent because of worries about foot-and-mouth disease.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Impasse On Controlling Growth
description: After a 12-day special session that cost taxpayers more than $100,000, the Legislature adjourned until next year without reaching an agreement on any bills to control development. Republicans control the House and Democrats run the Senate and each side blamed the other as failing to compromise. Gov. Bill Owens, a Republican, said last year that controlling growth was a priority of this legislative session and is now speculating whether it will return as a ballot initiative in 2002. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Clergy Members Arrested
description: The state police arrested five church leaders on charges of disorderly conduct as they knelt in prayer before the entrance to Gov. John G. Rowland's Capitol office yesterday. The clergy members, representing churches in Hartford, Bloomfield, New Haven, Danbury and Enfield, were protesting Mr. Rowland's refusal to take a leading role in the impasse between nursing homes and the union workers who went on strike for two weeks to protest wages and staffing levels. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

description: PENN-Jacques Paul, Ph.D, 88. In Scarborough, N.Y. description: First Line --> Open space may be at a premium in New York, but many bars, restaurants and nightclubs manage to find a little room (on the sidewalk, out back, on the roof) for customers to enjoy a summer breeze while throwing back a few. Here is a list of establishments where drinking alcohol outside is not only possible, but suggested.

title: On the Block, $2.4 Million for 'On the Road'
description: The scroll on which Jack Kerouac composed ''On the Road'' 50 years ago was auctioned yesterday at Christie's in Manhattan for $2.4 million, setting the world auction record for a literary manuscript and significantly eclipsing its presale estimate of $1 million to $1.5 million.

description: Allen Iverson's fadeaway jumpers were shrinking from the basket, his layups were wandering off the rim. He had missed all nine of his shots in the opening quarter.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON COULD PAY $60 MILLION TO SETTLE SUIT
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had agreed to pay up to $60 million to settle claims by 32 states that accused contact lens makers of colluding to inflate their prices. The company will provide discounts of up to $100 for purchases of contact lenses and eye exams, said the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, and pay $25 million to a settlement fund. Vistakon, a Johnson unit, denied it colluded or caused prices to exceed competitive levels. The company is based in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: $1.75 Million Fine Levied in ValuJet Crash
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that the maintenance company whose errors contributed to the ValuJet Airlines crash had agreed to a record $1.75 million fine for violations of rules on hazardous materials. In a separate case, a federal appeals judge cast doubt on some of the charges on which the company was convicted.

title: Prince Charles Reported Upset by Father's Published Criticism
description: LONDON, May 23  Prince Philip regards his son, Charles, as delicate, wasteful and unlikely to be an effective King. Charles is so upset at hearing Philip express this view that he has scrapped plans to write a warm tribute for his father's gala birthday next month.

title: Downturn and an Ouster Detour a Run to the Top
description: When Deborah C. Hopkins faced analysts last May, one month after joining Lucent Technologies as chief financial officer, she was asked how the job differed from the same position she had just left at Boeing.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Kuwait: Mending Postwar Fences
description: King Abdullah II of Jordan ended a visit that resulted in an accord to let Jordanians work in Kuwait again, reversing one effect of the Persian Gulf war. After the war, Kuwait, furious at Palestinians and Jordanians for backing Saddam Hussein, expelled all but 30,000 of the 400,000 Jordanians who lived in the emirate. Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Solemnity of the Ascension, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Now, Who Won the Race? For the Head, Not the Hips
description: If someone had been pulled from the crowd at the Tortoise show at Irving Plaza, transported to ''American Bandstand,'' circa 1960, and asked by Dick Clark to evaluate the music of this Chicago band, she might have said, ''It's got a great beat, and you don't have to dance to it.''

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Fighting Prostitution
description: The Legislature approved a bill on Monday that would broaden state laws against prostitution, which cover only pimps and madams. The bill, introduced by Senator George Callahan, a Republican, makes it illegal to sell sex or to offer money for sex. The bill would make prostitution a crime in areas not covered by local statutes.

title: Moving the United Nations, But Keeping the Benefits
description: AS it does every now and then, New York City settled yesterday on a foreign policy that does not quite match the one shaped by Washington, which fancies itself as speaking for Americans on international affairs.

description: A leaked diplomatic cable from the German Embassy in Washington has strained German-American relations, raised questions about Germany's relationship with the Libyan leader, Col. title: New Jersey Boy Last Seen at Carnival Is Found Slain Near Tracks
description: The body of a 10-year-old Morristown, N.J., boy who was last seen at a church carnival on Sunday evening was found yesterday morning near the tracks of a New Jersey Transit rail line not far from his home. The boy's death has been ruled a homicide, the authorities said.

title: Federal Judge in Brooklyn Is a Finalist for F.B.I. Post
description: The Bush administration has widened its search for a new F.B.I. director to include Sterling Johnson Jr., a federal judge in Brooklyn who, if selected and confirmed, would be the first black to head the bureau, law enforcement officials in Washington and New York said today.

title: Madden's Tricks Fluster Lemieux
description: John Madden had one more trick left for the Pittsburgh Penguins, and Mario Lemieux served as his chump. Madden, the Devils' creatively annoying center, had been caught in a corner, badly out of position, so he yelled to Lemieux for him to pass him the puck. And Lemieux did. And he put it right on the tape of Madden's stick.

title: Ukrainian Will Pick an Ally as Prime Minister
description: Seeking a way out of political crisis and to secure his own rule, President Leonid D. Kuchma of Ukraine said today that he would nominate a close ally and industrialist, Anatoly Kinakh, to be prime minister.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the New York City visit of Chen Shui-bian, the president of Taiwan, referred incorrectly to green and white flags waved by his supporters. They were flags of the Democratic Progressive Party, not the national flag.

title: Plan for Lifting Iraqi Controls Is Delayed
description: Russia threw an unexpected roadblock today in the path of an American and British proposal to allow free trade in civilian goods with Iraq while tightening controls on military imports.

title: Reruns may become a testing ground for digital insertion of sponsor's products and images.
description: DIGITAL technology may be used for the first time to place ''virtual'' products and other advertising images regularly in scenes of a syndicated television series to be watched by American audiences.

title: Hartlepool Journal; On Doorstep, Asking Votes: Blair's Fallen Friend
description: Come spring, Britain's front yards burst with flowers. Come election season, Britain's front steps sprout politicians.

title: Owners Approve N.F.L. Realignment
description: When National Football League owners convened early this morning to discuss realignment, a thorny topic that some expected to generate shouting matches, the room was surprisingly calm. Several owners expressed their opinions, but the Giants co-owner Wellington Mara, who was present the last time the league realigned three decades ago, put the matter in perspective.

title: A Summer of Reality
description: The networks are preparing for what may be the most competitive summer in memory thanks to another influx of reality shows.

title: Food Stuff: For Every Month, a New Belgian Toast
description: Hapkin is a strong golden ale named after a 12th-century count of Flanders. Limburgse Witte, a wheat beer, is seasoned with Curacao, orange peels and coriander. Grottenbier, a rich, dark brew, is made using Champagne techniques. These beers, all Belgian, are not usually available in stores here, but aficionados can get them by joining Michael Jackson's Great Beers of Belgium, a new beer-of-the-month club at Real Beer, an online emporium. The beers are selected by Mr. Jackson, the English beer authority.

title: Islanders to Name Laviolette
description: Peter Laviolette, an assistant coach with the Boston Bruins, will be introduced as the Islanders' head coach at a news conference today.

title: Reckonings; My Beautiful Mansionette
description: For most of the past year my wife and I lived in a rented house in central New Jersey -- a McMansion, also known as a mansionette. It was in a brand-new development, in what used to be a cornfield, that looks like a textbook illustration of turn-of-the-millennium urban sprawl. These days they aren't little boxes on a hillside, they're big boxes on flat ground. But they're all still made out of ticky-tacky, and they all look just the same.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPILLO, REV. JOHN D.
description: CAPILLO-Rev. John D. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the Parochial Vicar of Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, 2805 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, on May 21, 2001. Reposing at Immaculate Heart of Mary Rectory, on Wednesday May 23rd from 3-5 and 7-9 P.M., and Thursday, May 24th, from 2-5 P.M. A Mass of Transferral on Thursday May 24th at 7:30 P.M. Funeral Mass on Friday May 25th at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily, Bishop of Brooklyn

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Boesak Leaves Prison
description: The for-mer anti-apartheid campaigner and cleric Allan Boesak was released from prison after serving a year and seven days of a three-year sentence. Mr. Boesak, former head of the Geneva-based World Alliance of Reformed Churches, was convicted of stealing thousands of dollars given by foreign donors meant to help needy children and educate black voters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWSTER, HERBERT DANIEL
description: BREWSTER-Herbert Daniel. Retired foreign service officer, died April 29 with complications from pneumonia & prostate cancer. He had held posts in Beirut, Athens, Paris, Berlin and Naples. Most of his 34 year career focused on Greece. Appointed Greek Country Director in 1966, Brewster spoke out against the 1967 Greek ''junta'' and urged vigorous U.S. opposition. He is survived by his wife Susan Holleran at their Washington, D.C. home, & 3 children: David of Chicago; Robert of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.; and Tisha of Berkeley, California. and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 1PM, Saturday, May 26, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 2430 K Street N.W., Washington, D.C., reception to follow. The family requests that donations be made in his name to: The American Farm School, 1133 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10010; or Anatolia College/American College of Thessaloniki, 130 Bowdoin St, Suite 1201, Boston, MA. 02108.

Cherished great grandmother of Oakley, Zoe, Eva, and Lucy Friedberg. We mourn the loss of our incomparable Fritzie, a prolific artist who lived the vibrant colors of her palette. She was generous to all and a woman very much ahead of her time. Services are on Wednesday, 9:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Who's Up Third? It's Still O'Neill
description: Mike Stanton tossed a ball in the outfield at Yankee Stadium yesterday and felt the vicious wind and the persistent rain striking one side of his face. Ten seconds later, Stanton found that the wind and the rain had suddenly reversed course and were pelting the other side of his face. It was a raw day in the Bronx, which is why the Yankees postponed their game against the Red Sox.

title: Architects Building Castles in the Clouds
description: The sky above Lake Neuchatel was dotted with puffs of gray, but as far as Elizabeth Diller and Ricardo Scofidio were concerned, it was disappointingly cloudless. One crucial cloud, it seemed, was missing from the vista: their cloud, the one that these two New York architects had dreamed of and argued over and obsessed about for two years.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Sewer Rules Extended
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco has blocked a plan by his predecessor that was meant to discourage suburban sprawl. Gov. Christie Whitman had proposed a new process for approving sewer permits that promoted development mainly in cities and existing suburbs. But Mr. DiFrancesco decided last month to extend existing rules until April 30, 2002. A spokeswoman for the governor said that Ms. Whitman's plan did not coincide with Mr. DiFrancesco's development strategies and that the extension would allow time for public hearings.

title: Stocks End Lower as Investors Take Profits From Recent Rally
description: Stock prices fell today as investors pulled back in the absence of economic news and took some profits from the market's recent rally.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Zones Urged For Livery Cabs
description: City Council members Guillermo Linares and Ronnie M. Eldridge introduced a bill yesterday that would allow New Yorkers in designated areas to hail certain livery cabs in the same way that they now hail yellow medallion taxis. The zones would be created in neighborhoods citywide that are underserved by yellow cabs, except Manhattan below 96th Street and airports where yellow taxis have exclusive rights to pick up passengers, Mr. Linares said. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Asia: PC Sales
description: Sales of personal computers in Asia grew 2.9 percent, to $13.9 billion, in the first quarter, according to preliminary estimates by the market research firm IDC, the slowest growth since the Asian financial crisis in 1998. PC's are a bellwether for other technology sales, especially in Asia where the machines are less widespread than in the United States. Technology companies normally count on Asia to deliver rapid sales growth, but because the region's economies also depend on supplying the industry with parts, the slump in the United States and Japan has crimped Asia's normally keen appetite for technology. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Georgia Democrat Vows to Stay in Party's Fold
description: Senator Zell Miller, a conservative Georgia Democrat who has come under Republican pressure to switch parties, reiterated yesterday that he would not do so despite Senator James M. Jeffords's apparent decision to leave the Republican fold.

title: Wireless Wanderer: A Field Study
description: I'M not much of an apostle for the wireless cause. Whether it's because I feel my life is busy enough or because of my upbringing in rural New Mexico -- my family didn't get a telephone until I was 8, and then it was a party line -- I seem to have an inherent skepticism of new devices.

title: SWISS SEA-FREIGHT COMPANY BUYS USCO LOGISTICS
description: Kuehne & Nagel International, a sea-freight company based in Switzerland, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy USCO Logistics for about $300 million. title: Laptop Getting Too Hot? Better Call the Plumber
description: Anyone who has tried using a late-model portable computer without a table while wearing shorts knows that ''laptop'' has become something of a misnomer. Current processors may be fast but they also generate a lot of heat. Dr. George Chiu, a senior manager of advanced hardware systems at I.B.M., estimates that processors have gone from using about 5 watts of energy to using about 26 watts. ''If you touch a 50-watt light bulb, you know how hot that is,'' he said.'

title: Sheer, Summery Curtains For the Gossamer Budget
description: Susan Kirshenbaum, a headhunter in New York, needed almost a hundred yards of fabric to drape over the windows in her Long Island beach house. ''I wanted curtains sheer enough to let some light in, but opaque enough for privacy,'' she said. ''And they had to be fluid and blow in the wind.'' On top of that, she had a very low budget. Humble drapery-lining fabric, either pure cotton or a cotton and polyester blend, met all her requirements. ''Lining is perfect for a summery look that is economical,'' said Stan Fradin, president of Rockland Mills, a manufacturer of the fabric. Treated so it won't fade or discolor, it can be made water-repellent. Some weights will block light and provide some temperature control. Lining is as good for pinch-pleated draperies as for cafe curtains or flat panels. It's available in many colors as well as white, and costs from $3 to $6.50 a yard at Joe's Fabrics Warehouse, 102 Orchard Street (Delancey Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: What to Read in the Hammock? A Hamptons History, of Course
description: First came the artists, then the clergymen, then the industrialists. Those successive waves of Hamptonites are described in Alastair Gordon's ''Weekend Utopia: Modern Living in the Hamptons,'' to be published next month by Princeton Architectural Press ($45). One group seldom welcomed the next. ''There is something about the landscape, light and sky that makes people proprietary, and brings out their territorial responses about not letting other people in,'' said Mr. Gordon from his home in Princeton, N.J. And something about the landscape that inspired innovative architecture for those successive waves.

description: The House today overwhelmingly passed a bill that would reshape the federal government's role in education by requiring states to conduct annual math and reading tests for students in grades three to eight and holding accountable those schools that fail to make progress.

The chief executive, C. Michael Armstrong, sought the reduction to a majority of shares outstanding from two-thirds. AT&T said shareholders representing 62 percent of outstanding shares voted. Of those who voted, 96 percent approved the plan. Lower calling prices and a declining stock price led the 116-year-old telephone provider to propose a breakup.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gas Station Accused Of Fraud
description: The City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it had padlocked a gas station for selling gas with a lower octane rating than advertised. The station, 1255 Service Gulf, at 1255 East Gunhill Road in the Bronx, was shut down after inspectors found that gas sold as 93 octane, which commands a higher price, had only a 91.4 octane content. The allowable error margin is 0.6. The padlocked station faces penalties of up to $60,000 and must bring its octane levels up to code to reopen. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Monkey-Man? Relax, Relax

Panicked residents have leapt from rooftops to escape ''the beast,'' and three people have died in falls.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Affidavits In Secret Service Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for black Secret Service agents who have filed a class-action suit accusing the agency of racial bias have obtained more affidavits from current and former agents, including one that said white agents used a racial slur to refer to the presidents of Senegal and Grenada, whom they were assigned to protect. The lawyers filed 19 new affidavits signed by black agents who have charged the agency with discrimination in promotions, transfers and assignments. Agency officials say the Secret Service does not tolerate a racially insensitive work environment. David Johnston (NYT)

The new line includes beds, benches and dining tables as well as outdoor lounges. The store also represents Capo d'Opera, an Italian company that offers custom lacquered pieces. title: Flacking for Governor Pataki
description: Surely any governor's job description includes trying to lure tourists into one's state to spend money and boost the home economy. While most states attempt to entice people from elsewhere to come visit, however, Gov. George Pataki and his tourism team spend a large chunk of New York State's advertising budget pitching the state to fellow New Yorkers. Mr. Pataki's aides explain that most people in New York haven't seen the entire territory -- such as people from the Bronx who haven't visited the Adirondacks or those from Buffalo who have missed Times Square. Maybe so. But while Mr. Pataki is promoting New York, there is little doubt that he is also promoting Mr. Pataki.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Razorfish Suit To Be Thrown Out
description: The New York-based Internet consulting company Razorfish Inc. said a Federal District Court in Manhattan had informed the company that a class-action lawsuit filed against Razorfish by shareholders would be dismissed. The suit contended that Razorfish executives and directors misled investors about the integration of a company it had acquired in late 1999, i-Cube, to inflate the Razorfish share price. The suit's dismissal, which will be issued in an opinion later, was good news for Razorfish, which recently announced disappointing earnings and the departure of the company's two founders. Its shares rose 19 cents, to $1.13. Susan Stellin (NYT)

At the Milan Furniture Fair, they are treated like returning heroes, with their names on banners strung across the busiest streets. In London, Fleet Street reporters canvass prominent designers about their favorite restaurants and their bedtime reading to the children. But in name-dropping New York even the most talented European designers -- except, of course, the irrepressible Philippe Starck -- go incognito.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, HENRY L.
description: MICHEL-Henry L. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Parsons Brinckerhoff mourn the passing of Henry L. Michel, former president and chairman of Parsons Brinckerhoff Inc. Henry's 50 year career as a civil engineer and manager earned him an international reputation as a leader and innovator. He directed the firm's engineering services on some of the most significant transportation projects of the 20th century. Henry joined Parsons Brinckerhoff in 1965. He served as president and chief executive officer from 1979 to 1990 and as chairman from 1990 to 1994. Henry was a member of the National Academy of Engineering and an Honorary Member of the American Society of Civil Engineers. He was honored by the American Consulting Engineers Council with the organization's highest individual honor, the Distinguished Award of Merit, in 1997. He was a founding member of the Civil Engineering Research Foundation, a research organization of ASCE. His alma mater, Columbia University, honored Henry with the Alumni Federation Medal, the highest honor given to alumni, in 1991, and with the Egleston Medal for Distinguished Engineering Achievement in 1982. He was a senior lecturer at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Industry Professor of Construction Management at Polytechnic University of Brooklyn, New York. We extend our sympathies to Henry's wife, Mary Elizabeth, of NYC and his daughters, Eve Michel and Ann Elizabeth Wilde, and granddaughter, Ava Elizabeth Milanese. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Thomas J. O'Neill, President & CEO Robert Prieto, Chairman of the Bd Parsons Brinckerhoff

title: E.D.S. TO BUY STRUCTURAL DYNAMICS RESEARCH
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Structural Dynamics Research Corporation for $950 million in an effort to expand its presence in software that helps manufacturers create and distribute their products. E.D.S. said it would pay $25 for each share of Structural Dynamics, a 42 percent premium to its closing price of $17.56 yesterday. In addition, E.D.S., a computer service company based in Plano, Tex., said it intended to bring its software subsidiary, Unigraphics Solutions, back into the fold and combine it with Structural Dynamics. E.D.S. offered $170 million, or $27 a share, to buy the 14 percent of Unigraphics that is publicly traded, a 27 percent premium. Unigraphics closed at $21.31, up 6 cents. E.D.S. said it expected the combined unit to contribute $1.2 billion in revenue next year. Chris Gaither

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEYMOUR, MILTON A.

title: If Mr. Jeffords Jumps
description: When they come every few years or so, dramatic transformations of the political landscape usually result from the votes counted on Election Day, not from the actions of one person. But by indicating that he will leave the Republican Party, Senator James Jeffords of Vermont has singlehandedly redrawn the legislative map on Capitol Hill. Unless the White House can change his mind before his press conference this morning, Mr. Jeffords has also given President Bush and his suddenly clumsy-looking operatives an embarrassing lesson on how not to take someone for granted. His expected shift would put the Senate back in Democratic control for the first time since 1994, potentially blocking or slowing down the Bush administration's conservative policies and appointments, and weakening its ability to dictate the Senate agenda.

title: Flying on Top of the World:A Radiation Risk
description: HONG KONG  Passengers and crew members flying on the recently inaugurated North Pole route between New York and Hong Kong are exposed to unusually high levels of cosmic and solar radiation, according to international experts, provoking concern among airline unions and scientists.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New City: Vanderhoef Announces Run

Mr. Vanderhoef, 52, a Republican, said he would expand his goals of creating more parkland and cutting taxes. His announcement comes as the Democrats scramble to find a challenger. Their chairman, Paul Adler, pleaded guilty of federal mail fraud and extortion in a real estate project. Vincent Monte, the new Democratic Party chairman, said that Charlie King, a former Housing and Urban Development official, was considering a run. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Finance Chief At Swissair
description: The Swissair Group has named a new chief financial officer. Jacqualyn Fouse will become the first woman in the company's top management. She will leave her job as group treasurer for Nestl to head the finances of the troubled airline. Her boss, Mario Corti, Swissair's chairman and chief executive, also came from Nestl. Swissair's current finance chief, Georges Schorderet, will take charge of the special audit of the company that was approved at the recent shareholder meeting. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Jeffords's Move Would Echo Trend Toward Independents in His Region
description: If Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont abandons the Republican Party and becomes an independent, as expected, it will mark the convergence of two political trends in New England: the region's alienation from a national Republican Party dominated by Sun Belt conservatives and its growing comfort with independent, or third party, politics.

title: People
description: * Gary S. Laben, executive vice president for sales and marketing at KnowledgeBase Marketing, Dallas, part of Impiric, was named president and chief executive, succeeding Mike Hail, who is retiring, the agency said. Impiric is the direct marketing unit of Young & Rubicam, owned by the WPP Group.
