description: HAY-Harold F., Esq. Educator and attorney. Graduate of St. John's College Law School, graduate degree Labor Law, LLM NYU Law School. On May 21, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Catherine. Long-term employee of New York City Board of Education 1937-1972, as clerk, teacher, assistant superintendent, board secretary, and counsel in private law practice. Represented local and suburban boards in litigation and collective bargaining. Longtime trustee of Mary Immaculate Hospital and Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens. Survived by three children, ten grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

title: Bucks Must Look At, Not Past, Mutombo
description: Looking past Dikembe Mutombo may be like driving through the Redwood Forest and seeing only birds. His 7-foot-2 presence in the paint defines the landscape of any game he plays.

title: F.D.A. Panel Considers Warning Label for a Heart Medicine
description: An advisory panel at the Food and Drug Administration will hear arguments today on whether to add a warning to the label of Cardura, a popular blood pressure medication, telling doctors and patients that it may be less effective than a much cheaper generic drug.

title: Food Beats Sex In Best Sellers
description: A hundred years from now anthropologists and other descendants, upon looking back on our best-selling reading lists, will be curious to know just when it was that food and chefs and things culinary, and books about them, replaced sex as our main sensuous nourishment.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip-Equipment Sales Seen Falling
description: Shipments of chip-making equipment, a measure of demand for computer products, are expected to decline 27 percent this year, a sharp drop from the 87 percent growth last year, according to a forecast released yesterday by an industry trade group. Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, which tracks companies like Applied Materials, predicted that worldwide shipments would drop to $35.0 billion in 2001, from $47.7 billion in 2000. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Nicklaus Is Hoping His Hard Work Will Pay Off
description: Jack Nicklaus is not sure how many more years he will continue to play tournament golf. He has been frustrated by his game recently, unable to play as consistently as he once did, unable to produce the brilliant rounds that he once shot with regularity.

title: India Ends Kashmir Truce; Seeks Top-Level Pakistan Meeting
description: India announced tonight that it was ending its unilateral cease-fire in Kashmir, and said that Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee would invite Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to restart negotiations between the two hostile nuclear powers.

title: Moments of Daring In a Night of Debuts
description: Who needs ''42nd Street'' with the New York City Ballet around? On Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, Ashley Bouder, 17, a corps dancer who joined City Ballet only last fall, stepped into the title role of ''Firebird'' after learning the demanding new part in a matter of hours. A rather Draconian way to develop talent, it would seem; and why was no one else available after illness forced the principal dancer Margaret Tracey to withdraw? No matter. Ms. Bouder did herself and her company proud.

title: No More Room? The Thing to Do Is Open a Store
description: Mariette Himes Gomez practices interior design on the third floor of a building on East 74th Street, and until last month, she was short on space. One room held mostly chairs -- her own designs and antiques -- stacked on floor-to-ceiling shelves: quite at odds with Ms. Gomez's reputation as a designer of airy, open rooms and furniture she describes as ''architectural and tailored and never fussy.'' Now, she has more space, having moved the furniture to the ground floor, which she painted pristine white and opened as a store called the Shop. Above, an 1890 French country walnut table, 54 inches in diameter ($7,000), is flanked by rush-seated country chairs from the same period. The pair at left are French faux rosewood ($1,950 for two), and the chairs at right are English mahogany ($1,400 for the pair). The abstract painting ($36,000) is by Frank Owen, a New York City artist. Left, 19th-century English mahogany hall chairs are priced, from left, at $1,700, $2,000 and $1,900. Ms. Gomez's own designs range from $200 for a pillow to $12,000 for a hand-tufted sofa. The Shop, 504 East 74th Street (York Avenue); (212) 288-6856.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Excelon Buying A Consultant
description: EXcelon, a developer of business-to-business Internet software, said it would merge with C-Bridge Solutions, a Boston-based technology consultant. Terms of the deal call for the exchange of 1.215 shares of eXcelon stock for each C-Bridge share. The deal values C-Bridge, which has 22.04 million shares outstanding, at $48.5 million on the basis of eXcelon's closing price yesterday of $2.20. Shareholders of the two companies will each own 50 percent of the combined company when the merger is completed. Ed Thomas, a spokesman for EXcelon, which is based in Burlington, Mass., said the merger was an effort to gain clients through C-Bridge's customer base. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Shoe Designer Pleads Guilty To Charges of Stock Fraud
description: Steven Madden, a designer and retailer of shoes for young women and the founder of Steven Madden Ltd., pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges of securities fraud and money laundering.

title: Gender-Scrambled and Fleeing Violence
description: Bob, ne Roberta (''Nobody ever called me Roberta, ever''), would be a normal teenager -- blabby, confused, music-besotted -- if she weren't psychotic. In ''See Bob Run,'' a one-woman play by Daniel Mac Ivor at the Rattlestick Theater in Greenwich Village, she is hitchhiking, fleeing from a real act of violence and toward a delusional safe haven.

title: GLENAYRE TO CUT 55% OF WORK FORCE AND SHUT UNIT
description: Glenayre Technologies, a maker of wireless-communications equipment, said yesterday that it would eliminate about 700 jobs, or 55 percent of its work force, and shut its wireless-messaging unit. The cuts will be made over the next two quarters and affect the company's entire Santa Clara, Calif., work force, 95 percent of its employees in Vancouver, British Columbia, and 55 percent in Quincy, Ill., its chief executive, Eric Doggett, said during a conference call with investors. Glenayre, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., will exit wireless messaging within the next year, and plans to move to Atlanta to concentrate on products that allow people to use voice mail, e-mail and text messaging, Mr. Doggett said. Last week, Research in Motion of Waterloo, Ontario, sued Glenayre, accusing Glenayre of copying its BlackBerry two-way pager and its recently patented e-mail technology.

title: Investors Seem Wary on Alcatel-Lucent Deal
description: As Alcatel and Lucent intensify their merger talks, investors and industry analysts seem to have oddly divergent views about the merits of such a combination. Investors have battered shares of both companies, while analysts have begun to applaud the possibility of a deal.

title: Facing Uphill Battle, G.O.P. Will Back Financier for Nassau County Executive
description: Republican leaders in Nassau County decided today to back a multimillionaire financier, Bruce R. Bent, for county executive. The move is likely to prevent a primary battle that threatened to throw the once-mighty county organization into further disarray, top Republicans said.

description: The Democratic leadership of the State Assembly introduced legislation today to revamp the state's mandatory drug sentencing laws, expanding judicial discretion over the sentencing of drug felons and adding thousands of treatment slots in the state prison system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAFFER, GERALDINE
description: SCHAFFER-Geraldine. I read of a man who stood to speak at the funeral of his wife. With strength and courage he referred to the dates on her tombstone from the beginning to the end. He noted that first came the date of her birth and spoke of the second with tears, but he said that what mattered most of all was the dash between those years. For that dash represents all the time that she spent on earth and now only those whose loved her know what that little line is worth. For it matters not how much we own, the cars, the house, the cash. What matters is how we lived and loved when we're living out the dash. If we could just slow down enough to consider what is true and what is real and always try to understand the way other people feel and be less quick to anger and show appreciation more and love the people in our lives like we never loved before. If we treat each other with respect & often wear a smile, remember that the special dash will only last a while. So when your eulogy is being read, your life's actions to rehash, will you be pleased with what there is to say, about how you spent your dash? She was truly an AISHES CHAYIL (a woman of valor). A Jewish woman married to her beloved husband for over six decades, a caring and loving mother and grandmother. She exemplified to all what a true and loving person she was. Her star is not extinguished. Her star is just diminished. When her family and friends look up to the sky her light will shine down and continue to guide the family. She will be a liaison between HASHEM and her family & friends. She will speak on our behalf. Heartfelt condolences to the family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and may her memory always be a blessing to all. The Feldman Family

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Online Fraud Grows, F.T.C. Says
description: The ''boom of e-commerce has created fertile ground for fraud,'' Federal Trade Commission officials told a Congressional panel. The number of Internet fraud complaints rose from under 1,000 in 1997 to nearly 10,000 a year later. In 2000, more than 25,000 fraud complaints -- about a quarter of the total -- involved online fraud and deception, agency officials told the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Trade and Consumer Protection. ''The need, and the challenge, is to act quickly to stem this trend while the online marketplace is still young,'' said Eileen Harrington, associate F.T.C. director for consumer protection.

title: Legislators Seek Way to Restore Prenatal Care For Immigrants
description: The morning after a federal appeals court ruled that illegal immigrant women are not entitled to federally financed prenatal care, New York lawmakers and health care advocates today began reviewing ways to help restore coverage using only state money.

title: New Yorker Has Low Hopes for New Peru Trial
description: LIMA, Peru, May 20  It is Sunday at the high-security women's prison in the grimy neighborhood of Chorrillos. Visitors bring corn on the cob, spicy rice dishes and stories from home to relatives and friends, many of whom have been convicted of terrorism. Sweet love songs play on radios and there are laughter and hugs in the courtyard.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Cut Vote
description: Concerned about slowing growth in Britain as a result of the United States downturn, the Bank of England said its experts had voted 8 to 1 to lower interest rates by a quarter-point this month, with the sole dissenter arguing for a bigger cut. The vote, published in the monthly minutes of the bank's monetary policy committee, was taken as a sign that the benchmark rate, now 5.25 percent, might well fall a further quarter-point in midsummer. The minutes said it was unlikely that the slowdown in the United States would be offset by growth in other regions and that the United States economy might slow further. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: State of the Art: Zeroing In on Wristwear
description: As the information age chugs along, most of us have accepted three inexorable trends in consumer technology: personal electronics get cheaper every year, they get smaller every year, and if any two products can be combined, they will be. At this rate, by 2020 we can expect high-definition cell-phone/camcorder/MP3-player/organizers that cost $1.99 and are no bigger than lima beans.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Control
description: In the battle for control of Russia's biggest company, Gazprom, the representative of the company's minority shareholders, Boris Fyodorov, said he expected to win a court case and retain his seat on the company's board. Mr. Fyodorov, a former finance minister and leading market reformer, has long been calling for a change in the company's management, which he says has been stripping assets. This month, a local court struck his name from the list of candidates for the board, though the final decision will be made by board members at a meeting next week. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Wide-Open Mayor's Race In Cleveland

Mr. White, a Democrat, said that at age 49 he had achieved his highest political hopes in the office. In a nonpartisan primary on Oct. 2, two finalists will be selected for the election on Nov. 6. The list of candidates, now likely to grow, includes two Democrats, State Senator Dan Brady and Raymond Pierce, a former member of the Clinton administration. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: Robert LaChapelle, Marlborough Gallery, New York, May 7, 2001
description: e were moving nine pieces into the Marlborough Gallery for the exhibit of Botero's sculptures. We've worked for the Whitney, Sotheby's, the Met. We've moved Rembrandts. That's more money than me and a lot of other people put together make. But we can't take the time to think about how valuable it is. We handle it all the same. We were picking the pieces up off the trailer with a crane. First, we set them down in the garden, and then the artist's representative would tell us where to move them so they look nice. People were slamming on the brakes thinking, What's that on the truck? I'm on more strangers' video cameras than I care to know about. But you wouldn't believe how stupid half of New York is. We'll be hanging something that weighs tons, and they roll a baby carriage underneath. The typical New Yorker never looks up."

title: Iomega Builds a Bigger Pen To Corral Those Digital Hogs
description: With megabyte-hoarding digital video and audio becoming more popular with home users, the storage space to keep all those wonderful creations around becomes a real need. As it did with its Zip disks, the Iomega Corporation has upped the ante (and capacity) for portable storage with its new Peerless drive system.

title: Clemens Said to Settle Fine for Throwing Bat
description: Roger Clemens has donated money to charities as a settlement of the $50,000 fine assessed by Major League Baseball for throwing a shattered bat in Game 1 of last year's World Series. The case was resolved during spring training, a high-ranking baseball executive said, with Clemens agreeing to donate the sum of his fine.

Introduced in front of City Hall by former Mayor Edward I. Koch, Ms. Gotbaum stressed the need for someone with her experience in a city about to get ''a whole new government.'' Diane Cardwell (NYT)

Stacks of clothes -- a million pairs of underwear, a billion pairs of socks, a zillion pairs of shorts -- covered the floor in heaps so high that we had to hop from one bare spot to another like frogs on a lily pond.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Paterson: Officer and Tenant Found Dead
description: A police sergeant and a tenant in a building he owned were found shot to death in the tenant's apartment yesterday, the authorities said. The case has been classified a murder-suicide. The sergeant, Enrico Venditti, disappeared while on duty, causing concern among his colleagues. Several hours later, his body was found in the front of the apartment at 224 Clinton Street, said Boris Moczula, the acting Passaic County prosecutor. The tenant, Eugene Goldsmith, was found in a back room, the victim of a self-inflicted gunshot, Mr. Moczula said. Sergeant Venditti, 47, a 25-year veteran of the force and a resident of Kinnelon, was in uniform, and his revolver was in its holster, the prosecutor said. Daniel J. Wakin

description: Japan's two leading electronics manufacturers, Matsushita Electric Industrial and Hitachi Ltd., said today they had agreed to join forces to develop new technology in three areas: smart cards, home network systems, and recyclable and energy-efficient consumer electronics.

When he talks, his hands are always busy -- twisting a rubber band, playing with pocket pliers or massaging a Swiss Army knife he has kept for 20 years. Its red paint has worn to a shiny silver.

title: EBay Irritates Some Sellers By Banning Links to Home Sites
description: EBay and its sellers may need each other to survive, but that doesn't exactly mean they are best friends. The relationship took another rocky turn recently as eBay announced that starting May 31, it would prohibit sellers from linking to their own home pages from eBay pages that list items up for bid. A seller is allowed to provide text descriptions of items, as well as photographs and graphics, but it cannot link to a separate Web site that may provide more information about that item, or any other.

title: If It's Too Pretty to Be True, Then It's Probably Not
description: Airbrushing has long erased wrinkles and other blemishes in fashion magazines. Now, Photoshop can do the job so quickly and convincingly that altering reality is just a click away. Which is why a dozen readers of the June House & Garden called the Maison Gerard antiques gallery in New York looking for a lilac daybed shown on the magazine cover -- only to find that it doesn't exist. ''One woman said: 'I love that color! Where can I get it?' '' said Benoist F. Drut, a partner at Maison Gerard. He had a 1930's Samuel Max piece reupholstered in camel-colored cashmere, above, at the magazine's behest. But Dominique Browning, its editor, wanted more ''panache.'' She had the piece reupholstered again -- this time digitally. (And she added flowers to the twigs.) ''Everybody does it,'' she said. ''It's a yawn.''

But they did not use their trusty No. 2 pencils to fill in dots; instead, they practiced their test-taking skills on the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, BELTON KLEBERG
description: JOHNSON-Belton Kleberg. Greatgrandson of the founder of the King Ranch and a San Antonio businessman, lost his hard-fought, courageous battle with cancer May 19, 2001, surrounded by his family. Johnson was well known throughout the country and abroad as a rancher, investor, philanthropist and scion of one of the largest ranching families in the world. He was born in Baltimore November 23, 1929, to Sarah Spohn Kleberg and Henry Belton Johnson, Jr. and was orphaned at an early age. He was raised on the ranch at Kingsville, Texas by his uncle & aunt, Robert J. and Helen Kleberg, Jr. Johnson was educated at Deerfield Academy, Cornell University and Stanford University School of Business. After service in Korea as a U.S. Army lieutenant, he returned to manage the King Ranch headquarters division. Johnson was as comfortable in the boardroom of corporate America as he was at home on the ranch. He was the senior director of AT&T for many years, and chaired the Public Policy committee. Other directorships included Tenneco, Campbell Soup, Signal Companies, United States Trust Co., Hamilton Brothers Oil Co., Texas Research & Technology Foundation, Southwest Foundation for Biomedical Research, National Cowboy Hall of Fame & Western Heritage Center, and several Texas banks. Active in charitable causes, Johnson was a leader for years in the San Antonio United Way campaigns and served on the board of governors of United Way of America. He endowed a distinguished leadership lecture series at Virginia Military Institute in memory of his father, a 1926 graduate. Johnson purchased the Chaparrosa Ranch west of La Pryor, Texas in 1959, where he lived and raised his family. He made vast improvements on the Chaparrosa property including farming, feedlot, pasture and trophy hunting. Chaparrosa was also the home of the most prized Santa Gertrudis purebred cattle herds in the breed and, for 14 years, hosted the largest annual auction of Santa Gertrudis breeding stock. Johnson also served as president of Santa Gertrudis Breeders International during 1971-1973. In 1976, Johnson sold his interest in the King Ranch and established his own enterprise, Belton K. Johnson Interests. In addition to the Chaparrosa, he established Carmel Ranch Company in California, and acquired the historic Rancho La Puerta de Agua Dulce, and the Black Creek Ranch. Johnson's business ventures over the years included investments in oil, real estate, banking, plastics manufacturing, & a major video franchise. Two notable projects were San Antonio hotels: the Hyatt Regency, dedicated in 1981, and the Fairmount, which he had moved across town and restored in 1986. The most recent Johnson project was his biography authored by Martin Booth, entitled ''B.-The Life of Belton Kleberg Johnson''. Johnson was a member of the Bohemian Club, San Francisco; Clove Valley Rod & Gun Club, La Grangeville, NY; Club Giraud, San Antonio; Cypress Point Club, Pebble Beach, CA; Loch Lomond Golf Club, Scotland; Mark's Club, London; Metropolitan Club, New York; Plaza Club, San Antonio; San Antonio Country Club; The Argyle, San Antonio; The Order of the Alamo, San Antonio; and The American Club, Hong Kong. With his death, not only has everyone who knew him lost an admired and dear friend, but Texas is poorer for the passing of a rare spirit and a person who is (not was) in every sense a part of the state's history. It will not see the likes of him again. Johnson was preceded in death by his parents, his infant sister, Sarita, his brother, Robert Richard Shelton, his son, Belton K. Johnson, Jr., and his wife Lynne. He is survived by his loving wife, Laura McAllister Johnson of San Antonio; daughter-in-law Cecilia Johnson Hager of Kerrville and grandchildren Alice and Henry; daughter Sarah Johnson Pitt and husband Steve of Houston and grandchildren Sarita, Allegra and Stephen; daughter Cecilia Johnson McMurrey and husband, Mark, of San Antonio and grandchildren Harry, Belton and Estella. Funeral services were held at the First Presbyterian Church, 404 N. Alamo, San Antonio, Texas at 2PM Wednesday, May 23rd, with the Rev. Dr. Louis Zbinden officiating, followed by burial in the family cemetery at Kingsville, Texas on Thursday, May 24th, at 12 noon. Pallbearers were John Alexander, Jr., Truman Arnold, Dudley Campbell, Sir Rupert Clarke, James Clement, Jr., Andrew Connell, Harold Cooper, Ed Copley, Tom Frost, Wes Frye, John Howe, Richard King III, Richard Kleberg, III, Mark McMurrey, Bud Middaugh, Peter Milton, Baillieu Myer, Howard Nolan, Steve Pitt, Campbell Smith, Ed Stanfield, John Steen, Jr., and Seagal Wheatley. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the United Way of San Antonio, First Presbyterian Church of San Antonio, or Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA. 01342.

description: In a new report that is being met with a mixture of astonishment and disbelief, two Danish researchers say the placebo effect is a myth.

description: ConAgra Foods Inc. said yesterday that it would restate its financial results for fiscal 1998, 1999 and 2000 amid a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the company's accounting practices. ConAgra began looking into the matter at its United Agri Products unit last year and later received an informal inquiry for the S.E.C. concerning accounting practices at the seed and fertilizer company, it said in a news release. The company estimates that it will restate fiscal 1998 profit to $1.32 a share from $1.35, 1999 profit to $1.41 a share from $1.46 and 2000 profit to $1.60 a share from $1.67.

The student, Lindsay Brown, 18, is expected to receive her diploma, school officials say, but the principal has forbidden her from attending the commencement on May 29. title: FEDEX ELIMINATING 130 JOBS IN AUSTIN, TEX., AREA
description: The FedEx Corporation is eliminating 130 jobs in the Austin, Tex., area as it reorganizes a unit and ends a contract to manage warehouses for the Dell Computer Corporation. The move at the delivery company's FedEx Supply Chain Services unit comes after about 120 job cuts last month at the unit's centers in California, Colorado, North Carolina and Ohio. The Texas jobs will end between May 31 and July 31, according to documents filed at the Texas Workforce Commission. FedEx decided the supply chain unit would no longer oversee warehouses for clients. Many of the employees in the Austin area who will lose their jobs will be hired by the Eagle Global Logistics unit of EGL, which is taking over the Dell contract, FedEx said.

title: Essay; 'Stab In the Back'
description: The medieval German hero Siegfried, pursued by his enemies, stooped down to drink at a spring and was killed by a spear thrust in his back. This Dolchstosse in den Rucken gave rise to the Dolchstosslegende that Prussian officers used to explain their 1918 defeat.

title: Kerouac on the Block
description: If Jack Kerouac had written only a single paragraph -- that last glimmering moment in ''On the Road,'' that scattering echo of Fitzgerald -- we might remember him anyway. But Kerouac did not measure out his prose by the paragraph. On Tuesday the first draft typescript of ''On the Road,'' composed in just three weeks in April 1951, was sold at Christie's in New York for $2.43 million. The very form of this typescript is a declaration of artistic intent, a manifesto of sorts. It is 119 feet 8 inches long and 9 inches wide, which means that it sold for roughly $186 a square inch. If ever there was a writer who would have enjoyed thinking of his typescript as a kind of real estate -- ''all that raw land that rolls in one unbelievable huge bulge over to the West Coast'' -- it is Kerouac.

There is usually a gumdrop-shaped boxwood on either side of the door, as if to say, ''Be it ever so humble, this is Versailles to us.''

title: National Briefing | West: California: Meeting With The President
description: President Bush and Gov. Gray Davis, left, who have had sharp disagreements over energy policy, have a new dispute: who invited the other first to a meeting next week. White House officials said the governor accepted an invitation from the president. Aides to Governor Davis said he called the White House first and asked for a meeting. What both sides agree on is that they will discuss energy. Governor Davis has criticized the Bush administration harshly for not capping soaring wholesale power costs, and the president has insisted that such caps would only worsen the power shortages. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Objects Designed to Foster A Little Havoc in the Home
description: Here's a chance to swing on a chandelier or throw a vase with impunity. Droog Design, the collective based in the Netherlands, collaborated with a company called Do to produce Do Create, eight decorative housewares that double as entertainment. The Do Break porcelain and rubber vase ($150, inset) cracks but does not shatter if it hits the floor. ''You can 'break' it a thousand times,'' said Frank Tjepkema of Amsterdam, who designed the vase with Peter van der Jagt, and it still looks like a gently cracked hard-boiled egg. ''But jumping on it is another story,'' he continued. ''Then it falls apart.''

title: Metro Business Briefing | A Pinnacle For Pickles
description: A subsidiary of the Dallas buyout firm of Hicks Muse Tate & Furst completed a deal yesterday to buy Vlasic Foods International Inc. for $370 million in a sale approved in United States Bankruptcy Court on May 9. Vlasic, which is based in Cherry Hill, N.J., filed for Chapter 11 protection in January, three years after it spun off from the Campbell Soup Company and took the Swanson frozen foods and Open Pit barbecue sauce brands along with its famous pickles. The three brands were purchased by a new Hicks Muse subsidiary, Pinnacle Foods, a sign that Vlasic, Swanson and Open Pit, which were not Campbell core brands, can stand on their own, said David Pauker, a turnaround specialist with Goldin Associates of New York, who had been hired by Vlasic as its acting chief executive while it sought a buyer. Mr. Pauker said 100 of Vlasic's 3,000 employees would lose their jobs and secured debt of $322 million would be repaid. An additional $210 million in unsecured debt will be repaid to bondholders. Vlasic's overall reorganization plan still needs court approval. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Riga Journal; What's Maroon and White and Proud All Over?
description: Nobody had to tell the police that the mob was approaching. They could hear it blocks away.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Utility Struggle
description: A struggle for control of the Italian electricity business escalated after Europe's biggest power utility, lectricit de France, raised the stake it holds in the second-biggest Italian power company, Montedison, to 20 percent. The move brought complaints from Italy and the European Union, which accuse the government-owned lectricit de France, the supplier of 90 percent of French electricity, of expanding abroad even as Paris blocks entry of foreign utilities into France. France has dragged its feet on energy deregulation, surpassing by a year the deadline for adopting European Union deregulation rules and taking steps in March to block acceleration of the opening of Europe's national electricity markets. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Electronic Leashes for Teenagers
description: PARENTS frantically trying to insulate their adolescent progeny from the all-engulfing darkness are resorting to tracking devices, hidden cameras, Internet monitoring software and even automotive transponders. The benign paranoia that began with the baby monitor and the nanny cam a decade ago has spawned a cottage industry specializing in products for the well-heeled, middle-aged neurotic. These are the middle-aged parents who now stand, mouths agape, as their once-cuddly tykes morph into duplicitous, untrustworthy teenagers. Their response is to put a tail on them.

title: Switch by Jeffords Would Give 51-to-49 Majority to Democrats : Senator Set To Defect From the Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  In a serious threat to President George W. Bush's hopes of keeping control of the legislative agenda, a moderate Republican senator, James Jeffords of Vermont, was poised Wednesday to abandon his party, recast himself as an independent, and vote to reorganize the Senate under Democratic control.

title: Handspring Adds Net Services But Trims Price for VisorPhone
description: Handspring's VisorPhone has been on the market for about six months and now features are being added to the basic package. The most obvious enhancement for consumers is that the price of the phone has been cut by $50, to $249 plus the cost of the monthly phone service. The VisorPhone also now comes with software to surf the Web and get e-mail. The default home page for the VisorPhone is MSN.com, and Google is used for Web searching. Its browser, called Blazer, automatically reformats Web pages for viewing on the organizer's screen. Unlike WAP-enabled phones, the screen on the Visor is large enough to display multiple lines of text and graphics.

Contributions may be sent to Congregation Ohab Zedek, 118 West 95 Street, New York, New York 10025.

The whole neighborhood, sitting in folding chairs and on porch stoops, is turned out for the screening of ''Our Song'' on a breezy night. The film's central ensemble is a high-stepping marching band called the Jackie Robinson Steppers. Mr. Brown is the band director.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Easier Way To Pay Tax Estimates
description: Official Payments Corporation of Stamford, which provides electronic tax-payment services in 45 states, began a service that lets New York residents pay their estimated state tax over the phone or the Internet. The company charges a fee of 2.5 percent of the tax payment and said in a statement that customers could pay using their American Express, MasterCard or Discover cards. Official Payments said it already had thousands of customers in New York who used the service to pay their estimated federal taxes or to make balance-due payments and extension filings to New York. A spokesman for Official Payments said New York State expects to have $5.2 billion in estimated tax payments this year.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Trade Center Management
description: Geoffrey P. Wharton, the executive who revamped Rockefeller Center for Tishman Speyer Properties and directed the renovation of the Chrysler Building, is taking on a bigger challenge: the 110-story Twin Towers and the World Trade Center complex. Mr. Wharton, a senior managing director at Tishman Speyer, surprised many people in the real estate industry when he decided to leave that organization after nearly 19 years, to join the developer Larry Silverstein's organization. Mr. Silverstein is buying control of the trade center for $3.2 billion. Although Mr. Silverstein owns a number of downtown skyscrapers, real estate executives said the developer still needed a top manager like Mr. Wharton to take on such a vast complex. Mr. Silverstein would not comment.

title: Honey, You Left Baby In a Cheese Bin at Zabar's?
description: ''The Right Way to Sue'' has nothing to do with legal advice. The title just happens to be an awkward pun; the play is a loopy farce about two families knitted together by characters named Sue, one a teenage girl, the other an infant who is actually named Victoria as the play begins. What the playwright, Ellen Melaver, seems to have in mind is a contemporary social commentary, something about the disintegration of the conventional nuclear family and the emergence of more idiosyncratic arrangements.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Smear Campaign Inquiry
description: A deceptive telephone campaign against the former Assembly Speaker Antonio Villaraigosa in last month's Los Angeles mayoral primary was the work of a rival campaign, but no laws were broken, the district attorney has found. An investigation linked about 80,000 anti-Villaraigosa phone calls from someone claiming to be County Supervisor Gloria Molina to the campaign of Representative Xavier Becerra. Mr. Becerra denied any involvement, but he apologized to Mr. Villaraigosa and Ms. Molina. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

description: Strike a glass ceiling hard enough and it will break. At least that was the feeling more than a decade ago at Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., when Eve Atkinson was appointed the athletic director. She was the first woman hired to that position at a Division I school with combined men's and women's athletic programs and a Division I-AA football team.

State power managers would have to give 48 hours' notice of possible blackouts, with hourly updates; utilities would have to give neighborhoods 24 hours' notice of possible blackouts and an hour's warning before any begin.

description: With the departure of Senator James Jeffords of Vermont from the Republican Party, a historic moment will have arrived. For the first time since the party's creation in 1854, there will be no Republican member of Vermont's Congressional delegation in Washington.

title: PRIDE TO ACQUIRE RIVAL OIL AND GAS DRILLING COMPANY
description: Pride International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival oil and gas driller, the Marine Drilling Companies, for $1.9 billion in stock. Investors in the companies will get one share of a new company for each share held. The offer valued Marine at $32.65 a share, 18 percent more than Wednesday's closing price. Pride's stock fell $5.15, or 16 percent, to $27.50. Marine fell $1.17, to $26.55. After the Marine acquisition, Pride will have 246 land rigs and 77 rigs in the gulf and other waters, and employ more than 10,000 people worldwide. Shareholders of Pride will own 56 percent of the new company, which will retain the Pride name and keep its headquarters in Houston. Marine is based in Sugar Land, Tex.

The exhibition, scheduled to run until Aug. 13, indeed closed early, on July 17, but it reopened on Aug. 7 and ran until Sept. 24.

title: Private: Knock Before Entering
description: The difference between a normal chamber recital and Sunday night's concert by Martha Argerich and Ivry Gitlis was like that between a love scene in a movie and real-life lovers in action. The film is moving but calculated, while the real lovers are genuine but do things that the outside world probably doesn't want or need to see. Watching Ms. Argerich and Mr. Gitlis, the Carnegie Hall audience became voyeurs, rubbernecking on a fascinating and profound conversation, warts and all, given a choice between suspending judgment to get out of it all that it had to offer or being turned off altogether. People went both ways, to judge from a lot of head shaking in the audience on the one hand and four encores on the other.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 7 about a South Korean tax investigation of several conservative newspaper companies referred incompletely to the history of one reformist newspaper, Han kroyeh. It was organized in 1987 and has long espoused the views of President Kim Dae Jung. But it did not begin publication until the next year and so did not support Mr. Kim in the election of 1987.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Coin Dealers Charged
description: Six Suffolk County coin dealers were charged yesterday by the state attorney general's office with bilking more than 1,000 customers across the nation, most of them elderly, out of at least $25 million in a telemarketing scheme that lasted seven years. Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer called the scheme a ''classic boiler room operation,'' involving high-pressure sales calls, collusion among the dealers and huge markups, sometimes 10 times the value of the coins. The dealers pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Court in Riverhead.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican: Pope's Message To Cardinals
description: John Paul II wrapped up a four-day meeting of cardinals who had gathered to chart the future of the Roman Catholic Church. Some cardinals called for more power-sharing and frank debate at bishops' synods, but the pope said that existing systems are ''valid and effective.'' Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

Esther was a teacher and guidance counselor in New York City schools for 37 years. Her love of literature, learning and young people lasted throughout her life. She was a generous, caring friend and mentor.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Government Declares Bombing Halt
description: The government said it would halt bombings in the south, a tactic in the long-running civil war that has drawn much criticism because civilians are often killed. It has suspended bombing in the past, and did not give a reason or say how long the new halt would last. The announcement came before Secretary of State Colin L. Powell visits two of Sudan's neighbors, Kenya and Uganda, where he is expected to discuss the 18-year civil war in which an estimated two million people have died from fighting and famine. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Divine In Stock Deal For Rowecom

The agreement is a stock-for-stock exchange in which RoweCom shareholders will receive three-quarters of a share of Divine stock for each RoweCom share. RoweCom shares jumped 15 cents, to $1.13, while shares of Divine dropped 3 cents, to $2. The deal values RoweCom at $18.7 million based on Divine's closing price. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: Two Trumpeters, Sorely Out of Tune
description: ''Bump it with a trumpet,'' advised Miss Mazeppa, the horn-blowing stripper from the musical ''Gypsy.'' Her suggestion that a touch of brass could brighten up an act, or at least make it look new, was confirmed two years ago when a little-known dramatist named Warren Leight shot to fame with ''Side Man,'' an elegiac memory play infused with the haunted strains of its title character's trumpet music.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Exchange Cutting Jobs
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange plans to eliminate jobs to cut costs after transforming itself into a for-profit company from a member-owned one. The exchange's 540 employees were informed on Monday that severance packages would be available to those volunteering to resign, said a spokeswoman, Nachamah Jacobovits. The number of actual job cuts will depend upon how many employees opt for severance and where they work, she said.

title: Mr. Bush's Fumble
description: The belated efforts to keep Senator James Jeffords of Vermont in the Republican Party were botched on two levels. His departure reflects a historic ideological shift in the G.O.P. resulting from President Bush's mistaken choice since taking office of trying to placate the conservatives to whom he feels he owes his nomination and election, at the risk of alienating party moderates who hold the balance of power in Washington. On another level is the torrent of tactical errors by the White House in ignoring and disrespecting Mr. Jeffords with snubs and oversights. On both levels, Mr. Jeffords's action sends a signal to Mr. Bush and Congressional Republicans to change their ways.

title: Is Baghdad's Tiger a Literary Lion?
description: Winston Churchill painted landscapes. Mao Tse Tung wrote poetry. Bill Clinton played the saxophone.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Evidence Review Set
description: State law enforcement officials have agreed to retest forensic evidence in the case of a death row inmate, Dewey George Moore. The decision comes as officials investigate cases involving an Oklahoma City forensic scientist whose laboratory work in hundreds of cases is being reviewed. The Moore case involves the work of a second chemist in the Oklahoma City police laboratory, Janice Davis, who has died. Investigators will re-examine the hair and fiber evidence used in Mr. Moore's conviction in 1985 for the death of a 12-year-old girl. Jim Yardley (NYT)

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Elwood City Visits New York

title: 'Ladies' in Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Republicans Step Out and Democrats Jump In
description: With Republicans conceding that they had lost control of the Senate, Democrats moved quickly today to map out a legislative agenda after Senator James M. Jeffords upended the political status quo by quitting the Republican Party and becoming an independent.

title: America's Political Terrain, Jolted by One Man
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Political Terrain, Jolted by One Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 2001052590736914662 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Sports of The Times; Jordan Has a Model for Showing the Kids
description: MICHAEL JORDAN, age 38, may have never heard of Jimmy Caras, age 92, but they have more in common than one might, at a glance, imagine.

title: Health Care Industry Braces For Change in Senate Focus
description: The health care industry is bracing for changes that could affect the costs and profits of drug companies, insurers and, ultimately, employers as the Senate prepares to reorganize with Democrats in control.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron Buys Box Maker
description: The Solectron Corporation, the biggest contract manufacturer of electronics, agreed to buy the closely held Singapore Shinei Sangyo to add production capacity for housings for servers, cell phones and other devices. Terms were not disclosed. It was the second acquisition of a Singapore-based electronics company this year by Solectron. It bought NatSteel Electronics for $2.4 billion in January.

title: With a Growl, Pakistan Accepts an Invitation
description: Pakistan's foreign minister accused India today of ''state terrorism'' and ''repression'' as well as massacring 75,000 Kashmiris. And he said all this in a brief public statement, announcing that his nation would accept New Delhi's invitation for talks ''in a positive spirit.''

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: York Mayor Quits Contest
description: A week after being charged with homicide in a 1969 race riot, Mayor Charles Robertson announced that he was ending his bid for a third term. ''The city is a better place than it was when I took office,'' he said in a letter to his party leaders in which he said the pending case had rendered the November campaign impossible. Mr. Robertson, a Democrat, stands accused of encouraging white racists and supplying them with ammunition in the disturbance in which a black woman was shot to death. Last week, he won the Democratic nomination. The Republican candidate is Betty Schonauer, a former school board member. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: 'A Struggle for Our Leaders to Deal With Me and for Me to Deal With Them'
description: Following is a transcript of Senator James M. Jeffords's announcement yesterday in Montpelier, Vt., that he was leaving the Republican Party, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Powell, in South Africa, Finesses the AIDS Issue
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell discussed Africa's regional conflicts with President Thabo Mbeki tonight but the two officials danced around the even more deadly problem of AIDS, which has struck more people in South Africa than any other country.

title: Sharp's Bargain Has Paid Off
description: When Scott Sharp was studying finance at Babson College in the suburbs of Boston, his mother, Carol, would call from the family home in Wilton, Conn., and implore her son to consider working some day ''for I.B.M., or someplace like that.''

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages yesterday about a ukulele festival on Saturday and Sunday at Joe's Pub in Manhattan misstated the night that nontraditional performers are to be featured. It is tomorrow; the festival is not playing tonight.

title: Where Bison Meets Oil Rig, Talk of Cooperation
description: In the green hills of northern Oklahoma, free-roaming bison lumber through the wildflowers of a tallgrass prairie, a 19th century vista cultivated by private conservationists and disturbed only by the presence of a hundred or so aging oil wells, creaking in the breeze.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, HENRY L.
description: MICHEL-Henry L. The Faculty and Staff of the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University mourn the loss of Henry Michel, the distinguished former President and Chairman of Parsons Brinckerhoff, Inc. Henry L. Michel directed the Development Board of the Institute for Civil Infrastructure Systems (ICIS), a center of excellence for urban infrastructure at the Wagner School. His distinguished career and his commitment to the future of livable cities made him an invaluable leader for ICIS and a committed supporter of its mission. We will miss his wisdom and colleagueship.

title: Gravano and Son Are to Enter Guilty Pleas in Ecstasy Case
description: Salvatore Gravano faced the prospect of hearing his own voice played in court in nearly 150 wiretapped phone conversations. He faced the embarrassment of hearing his desert drug empire detailed on the witness stand by a government turncoat. So the gangland killer known as Sammy the Bull has decided to plead guilty to running a multimillion-dollar Ecstasy ring in Arizona.

title: Article 2001052590161210707 -- No Title
description: Wariness Yields to Motivation in Baltimore Free-Computer Experiment

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Eager For 2nd Summit . . .
description: President Kim Dae Jung made plain his eagerness for the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, to come to Seoul, suggesting that the northern leader announce a date on June 15, the first anniversary of their summit meeting in North Korea. His remarks reflected his concern that the peace effort has been stagnating. The North has canceled a number of North-South meetings since the southern leader went to Washington in early March for a meeting with President Bush, who expressed skepticism about the North Korean leader. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Miles Davis: Restless Grooves
description: I'VE changed music five or six times,'' Miles Davis wrote in ''Miles: The Autobiography'' (1989), a book that offers a great modern example of the untrustworthy narrator. All the huffing and bluffing and posturing one ever suspected to be within him was collected in that volume; much of it was graceless and thickly applied, an older man's attempt to reassert his place in history when he may have been losing it. His new music wasn't what it used to be, and his discography was a shambles.

title: Two Lives In China, With Mao Lurking
description: Zhang Yimou's tenderhearted film ''The Road Home'' is a cinematic ballad of such seamless construction and exquisite tonal balance it transcends most of the pitfalls of movies that aspire to a classic, lyric simplicity. The one grating element is a redundantly schmaltzy soundtrack by San Bao that shamelessly imitates James Horner's quieter theme music for ''Titanic'' and nudges ''The Road Home'' toward an emotional grandiosity. But that pushiness, thankfully, does not extend to the rest of the movie.

title: Neighbor Held in Killing of East Village Woman
description: A woman who lives in the East Village was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the stabbing death a 79-year-old neighbor who often allowed the woman to use her telephone, the authorities said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nazi-Looted Art Returned
description: The first painting from a Dutch art collection looted by the Nazis and almost sold at auction was returned to the owner's only heir in Manhattan yesterday. The painting was presented by Christie's to Marei von Saher, the widow of the son of the collection's owner, Jacques Goudstikker, who died escaping the Nazis. The estate of Hertha Katz, which had consigned it for sale in January at Christie's, returned the painting. The painting, ''The Temptation of St. Anthony,'' by Jan Wellens de Cock, is valued at $15,000. Kathryn Shattuck (NYT)

title: Power Trader Tied to Bush Finds Washington All Ears
description: Curtis Hbert Jr., Washington's top electricity regulator, said he had barely settled into his new job this year when he had an unsettling telephone conversation with Kenneth L. Lay, the head of the nation's largest electricity trader, the Enron Corporation.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Utility Buys Fuel Cells
description: An unnamed utility has awarded Plug Power Inc., a fuel cell maker, a $7 million contract for 75 fuel cells and related maintenance and services, giving the company its first commercial sale. The utility will use the cells to increase electricity production and will announce the purchase in the coming weeks, said Mark Sperry, Plug Power's chief marketing officer. Plug, based in Latham, N.Y., had forecast 2001 revenue of about $7 million. Last year, the company had revenue of $8.4 million, mostly from government contracts. Shares of Plug rose $5.08, to $33.25.

title: Ida Applebroog -- 'Early Works'
description: Ronald Feldman

title: Allen's Fast Start Finishes Off Sixers
description: Ray Allen quickly hit his first four shots, his silky jumpers pouring through the net as smooth as brandy, a potion that might as well have been cyanide for the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: India's Premier Invites Leader of Pakistan to Discuss Peace
description: NEW DELHI, May 25 -- In a gracefully worded letter, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee today officially invited Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to India for the first talks between the two nations since earlier peace moves were ruptured by a violent conflict in Kashmir two years ago.

title: America's Political Terrain, Jolted by One Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Lucent and Alcatel Talks Said to Be Near Final Stage
description: Merger talks between Alcatel of France and Lucent Technologies moved into their final stages yesterday as executives from the two communication equipment makers convened in Paris to negotiate formal details of the transaction, executives close to the discussions said.

title: Judge Rejects Guilty Verdicts For Ex-Officers
description: A federal judge in New Jersey threw out conspiracy convictions late yesterday against five police officers from Orange in the beating and pepper-spraying of an innocent suspect who died in police custody after the 1999 killing of a policewoman.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When the owners of Marika decided to shop for a new chef just months after opening, they did not go bargain hunting.

title: Residential Real Estate; Student Suites and Luxury Flats Under One Roof
description: The slender 46-story residential tower nearing completion on East 55th Street is actually two buildings in one, a dormitory for Marymount Manhattan College topped by 40 upscale rental apartments.

title: Jacques-Louis Lions, 73, French Master of Equations
description: Jacques-Louis Lions, a French mathematician recognized internationally for his work with highly complex equations that underpin the physical sciences, died May 17 in Paris after a long illness. He was 73.

title: U.P.S. TO COMBINE SOME NEWLY ACQUIRED OPERATIONS
description: United Parcel Service Inc. said yesterday that it would combine the Fritz Companies and seven other recent acquisitions into a customs-brokerage and freight-forwarding business. The new unit would have annual sales of more than $750 million. U.P.S. completed its $437 million acquisition of Fritz yesterday.

title: Joe's Back, And Looking For a Ride; Hasbro Reaches For Some Coattails From 'Pearl Harbor'
description: It might be G.I. Joe's last stand.

title: INSIDE
description: More McVeigh Case Papers

title: 'Dear Dead Person'
description: Momenta Art

title: Jeffords, and Fellow Vermonters, Emphasize Tradition
description: August Jaccaci came here to cheer Senator James M. Jeffords's break with the Republican Party dressed as a Vermont rebel from an earlier era, one of Ethan Allen's Green Mountain Boys.

title: Article 2001052592878858215 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: New Hispanic District
description: Westchester legislators approved a redistricting plan Wednesday night that creates a heavily Hispanic district in Yonkers while ensuring that no two incumbent legislators will fight over the same seat. The plan, which incorporates data from the 2000 census, now goes to Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester executive, who is expected to sign it. James Cavanaugh, the Eastchester town supervisor and chairman of the county's Republican Party, said the plan, which divides a few municipalities into different districts, tilts against the Republicans, the minority party.

title: Sixers' Brown Has Answers for Karl
description: PHILADELPHIA, May 24  Everybody, it seems, is on the defensive, and it is still early in the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference finals.

title: Families of Wendy's Victims Hold Vigil
description: If there was any relief yesterday in all the sadness in Flushing, Queens, it was that Benjamin Nazario did not have to board the Q25 bus on Main Street. Mr. Nazario's brother, Ramon, was among the five workers killed one year ago last night during an armed robbery at a Wendy's near the bus stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUMMOND, RACHEL LEE
description: DRUMMOND-Rachel Lee. Formerly of St. Louis, MO, died peacefully in Princeton, N.J. on May 21, 2001 at 97 years. Daughter of the late Eugene and Rachel Cuendet, widow of Kenneth Drummond, beloved mother of Jean Drummond Crane and Rachel Lee Drummond MacNeil, grandmother of six, great grandmother of eight. A memorial service will be held at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, N.J., Wednesday, May 30 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, if you wish, donations may be made to the Missouri Botanical Gardens, 2345 Tower Grove Avenue, St. Louis, MO. 63110.

title: James D. Ebert, 79, Biologist; Helped Develop Embryology
description: Dr. James David Ebert, a research biologist who helped upgrade embryology from an adjunct of anatomy to a modern discipline employing genetics, biochemistry and molecular biology, was killed on Tuesday in an automobile collision in Maryland. He was 79 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Levittown: Bent Chosen As Candidate
description: Nassau Republicans last night chose Bruce R. Bent, a multimillionaire financier who has never held elected office, as their candidate for county executive this year in a race many in the party say will be an uphill battle. Mr. Bent, 64, won the Republican backing after a week of mixed signals from a political apparatus recently thrown into disarray by a budget crisis. In the end, the party's leaders decided to back Mr. Bent, of Plandome, unanimously after he received the county's Conservative Party endorsement on Monday and threatened to split the ticket if the Republicans opposed him. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Argentina Plans Debt Swap in Billions, Delaying Payments
description: Argentina announced a voluntary plan yesterday to swap as much as $67 billion of existing debt for new, longer-term securities that would delay millions of dollars in interest payments for the government.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Increase
description: Worried about mounting inflationary pressure, the Brazilian Central Bank increased interest rates to 16.75 percent, a jump of half a percentage point and the third such move in the last three months. The currency, the real, has fallen 6.59 percent against the dollar this month, and 20.25 percent on the year, because of uncertainty over the economic stability of neighboring Argentina and a domestic energy crisis that may reduce Brazil's gross domestic product growth to around 3 percent from an estimated 4 percent this year, according to some economists. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: The Genome Gets to Meet The Family
description: Long-winded, repetitious, immensely hard to understand, the human genome would not obviously qualify as the ideal weekend guest. But for anyone who has been putting off that inevitable one-to-one meeting, the American Museum of Natural History has prepared a most pleasant surprise in a new exhibition entitled ''The Genomic Revolution.'' The show, which opens tomorrow, highlights the genome's elegance, power and decided air of mystery while playing down the awkward guest's most tiresome features.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Mogilny Not Fazed by Drought
description: Alexander Mogilny, the Devils right wing whose wrist shot is usually as true as a laser beam, has not scored a goal in 10 games. He said today that he does not go home at night and pound his pillow.

title: Devastating Picture Of Immigrants Dead In Arizona Desert
description: Local and federal officials painted a devastating picture today of a smuggling operation that killed at least 14 young Mexican immigrants in Arizona, saying a ''coyote'' had apparently abandoned more than two dozen men in one of the country's most brutal and desolate stretches of desert on Saturday with little water and no preparation.

title: Testing Service Error Lowered Some Scores on Entrance Exam
description: A scoring error by the Educational Testing Service early last year caused nearly 1,000 people to get lower scores than they deserved on the Graduate Management Admission Test, a widely used business school entrance exam.

title: Yamoussoukro Journal; For a Great White Elephant, a New Lease on Life
description: So rich is the soil in this swath of West Africa, so nourishing the sun that shines on this corner of earth, that the bush always threatens to smother what humans have raised. Villagers may travel for a few months and, unless they have taken proper precautions, return to find their homes sinking in weeds and shrubbery.

title: Rosa Beddington -- Embryologist, 45
description: Dr. Rosa Susan Penelope Beddington, an experimental biologist whose research produced insights into the way an embryo becomes a fetus in mammals, died on May 18 in Great Tew, Oxfordshire, England. She was 45 and had formerly lived in Edinburgh and London.

title: New Suit Filed To Bar Trading Music on Net
description: Continuing their legal attack on Internet companies that they say are stealing their music, the major recording companies filed a copyright infringement lawsuit yesterday against Aimster, a service that permits users of instant messaging services to exchange music and other files.

title: Makers Promote Psoriasis Drug
description: Xoma and Genentech said today that the drug Xanelim appears to ease symptoms of psoriasis in studies of 1,000 patients that could lead to regulatory approval of its treatment for the skin disorder.

title: 'American Groupie' -- Paintings by Helen Garber
description: Brownwyn Keenan Gallery

title: Indulgence Near Phoenix
description: Vacationers staying near Phoenix in the summer need a few indulgences to help deal with the heat, and the Fairmont Scottsdale Princess is providing some. Its Royal Indulgence Spa package, good June 22 to Sept. 9, starts at $385 a night, about 35 percent less than peak winter rates. Besides breakfast, it includes use of the staffed fitness center, with classes in pilates, yoga, step aerobics and aquatic aerobics. And there is a choice of spa treatments, including a body polish, body wrap, plus a massage and a salon service. The price is per room, for two people. Information: (800) 344-4758 or www.fairmont.com .

title: Finn to Direct Minnesota Orchestra
description: As the musical world continues to reel from the announcement of Lorin Maazel as future music director of the New York Philharmonic, and to await similar word on the possibility of James Levine at the Boston Symphony, another fragment in the kaleidoscopically shifting leadership of major North American orchestras fell into place yesterday in Minneapolis. The Minnesota Orchestra announced that Osmo Vanska would be its next music director, replacing Eiji Oue in 2003.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Parsippany: Teams Still Lack Name
description: Sports teams in the Parsippany-Troy Hills school district still lack a nickname after a vote to replace the name Redskins failed to produce a clear winner. On Wednesday, students voted on five options to the Redskins, which school officials decided was insensitive to American Indians. But none of the five proposed nicknames -- Titans, War Hawks, Scarlet Raiders, Red Hawks and Red Storm -- got a majority. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Rightist Party In Canada Being Torn Into Disarray
description: When Stockwell Day grabbed the reins of the official opposition less than a year ago, he appeared to represent a new breed of Canadian leader. He possessed a TV smile and enough confidence to hold a news conference while wearing a water skier's wet suit. He faced Prime Minister Jean Chrtien in the House of Commons and some people thought he could become prime minister himself.

title: Pill-Popping Max Loses to Lawrence Welk Again
description: Plays rarely get better when they move from stage to television, but Neil Simon's reworked ''Laughter on the 23rd Floor'' is richer and funnier than the Broadway version that got a middling reception eight years ago. Like the play, the new Showtime film is a behind-the-scenes look at the days, in the early 1950's, when Mr. Simon was a writer for ''Your Show of Shows.''

title: Yankees' Aces Outnumber Martnez
description: If the Yankees seem to throw a staff of All-Star pitchers at Pedro Martnez when he pitches against them, it's probably because they do.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLINS, DAVID
description: POLLINS-David. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing in Israel of our member, David Pollins, beloved husband of Charlotte, devoted father of Rebbetzin Vickie Riskin, father-in-law of our founding Rabbi, Shlomo Riskin. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Ken Cappell, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAPP, ROBINSON, ZYLPHA
description: MAPP-ROBINSON-Zylpha, 87. Human rights champion. Survivors: daughter, Juanita Thompson; grandson, Derek; sisters, Jo and Janice. Baha'i memorial services.

title: The Faces That Shine Beneath a Midnight Sun
description: For those who still think Scandinavian photography is all about fjords, snow, ice and the sea, ''Faces and Figures: Contemporary Photography in Scandinavia'' at Scandinavia House, the handsome new Manhattan showcase for Nordic art and culture, will come as an illumination. The theme here is not landscape but humanscape, a strong motif in Nordic photography for many years.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the future of Firestone tires after the recall begun by the Ford Motor Company misspelled the surname of the editor and publisher of Tire Business, who said the brand name could be salvaged. He is Dave Zielasko, not Zielasco.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Facing Impeachment, Senator Quits
description: Jos Roberto Arruda, the pivotal figure in a political corruption scandal and until recently the Senate majority leader, resigned his seat one day after his colleagues voted to begin impeachment proceedings against him for rigging computers so he would know how they voted in secret balloting. ''I didn't steal, I didn't kill, I didn't divert public funds,'' Mr. Arruda said in his farewell speech. ''But I made a big mistake.'' Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Leadership Changes At Industry Association
description: The International Advertising Association in New York has named Walter J. O'Brien Jr. its director general, effective July 1, succeeding Norman Vale, who has held the post since 1990.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Blackout Warnings
description: Gov. Gray Davis said he would order utilities to warn the public of rolling blackouts this summer. State power managers would have to give 48 hours' notice of possible blackouts, with hourly updates; utilities would have to give neighborhoods 24 hours' notice of possible blackouts and an hour's warning before any begin. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Deal Is Unlikely, but Davis Would Meet Knicks' Needs
description: For the Knicks, the ultimate off-season prize remains Chris Webber, but there is another frontcourt player on the market who would adequately fill Latrell Sprewell's demand for increased ''size and toughness.'' He is Antonio Davis, the burly and bruising center of the Toronto Raptors who played a key role in sending the Knicks to their earliest postseason exit in a decade.

title: Protesting the Vieques Bombing
description: People who commit civil disobedience to call attention to an issue do so knowing they will have to pay a penalty. But the punishment meted out by a federal judge in Puerto Rico to the Rev. Al Sharpton and other New York politicians for their demonstrations against military bombing exercises on the island of Vieques seems excessive. Moreover, lawyers for the group have raised serious questions about due process in the hasty scheduling of the protesters' trial. These questions warrant careful review by an appellate court.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From negotiating with car dealers to making a used car look snazzy, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: At Border, Fortification Conflicts With Compassion
description: With the death toll of illegal Mexican immigrants rising, the Bush administration is faced with a central conflict: How to create more humane conditions at the border while increasing enforcement with more guards and patrols.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Mets' Bats Revive and Put on a Show
description: The question for Mike Piazza was not if he would have homered under normal conditions last night, but how many he would have hit. Piazza crushed three balls, and all of them succumbed to a relentless wind blowing in from center field. How many homers? ''At least two,'' Piazza said. An 0-for-5 night never felt so good.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEISLOSS, STANLEY
description: NEISLOSS-Stanley. The Officers, Directors, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center express their heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Stanley Neisloss. He will long be remembered as a founding supporter and staunch advocate of our Center. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family. Joseph Gurwin, Chairman Lawrence J. Simon, President Herbert H. Friedman, Exec. V.P.

title: Treasures of Far Places And Unfamiliar Peoples
description: One of the best new group shows in the city is sitting smack in the middle of the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It's called ''African, Oceanic and Ancient American Art: Recent Acquisitions,'' and you've probably never seen the like of much of what's in it before.

title: Unhappy With City Tax Breaks, N.B.A. Drops Move to West Side
description: The National Basketball Association's plans to move its headquarters to a site at Ninth Avenue and 33rd Street behind the Farley Post Office died this week after the city declined to provide a large enough package of tax breaks, executives involved in the negotiations said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Teacher Pay Plan Signed
description: A plan linking teacher pay to performance was signed into law by Gov. Tom Vilsack. Education experts said the plan was the most extensive in the nation. The plan uses $30 million to link pay increases with a new evaluation system and a four-step career ladder. An additional $10 million is allocated to school bonuses, teacher mentoring and training of teacher evaluators. The State Education Association opposed the plan. Bill Dedman

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Action On Money Laundering
description: Legislation sought by the Kremlin to curb Russia's chronic money-laundering problem passed the first of three readings in the lower house of Parliament. The bill would impose federal controls on all cash transactions of 500,000 rubles (about $17,200) or more and on all real estate deals exceeding 2.5 million rubles (about $86,000), as well as require tighter internal controls in organizations that handle large sums of cash. The Kremlin estimates that launderers illegally move $20 billion abroad every year. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Article 2001052592573999694 -- No Title
Court Orders Dance Club To Hand In Its License
description: After nearly three years of attempts by various New York City agencies to shut down a popular Chelsea nightclub, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court yesterday ordered the club, Twilo, to hand over its cabaret license, effectively putting it out of business.

title: A Reference to Jews Heats Up Aid Debate
description: Two words spoken in testimony before a House subcommittee on Wednesday have set off a new furor over President Bush's proposal to channel government money to religious social service programs.

title: Center for Land Use Interpretation -- 'Formations of Erasure: Earthworks and Entropy'
description: Storefront for Art and Architecture

title: Home Video: 'Big Trouble': Big Comeback
description: ll of a sudden it became kind of this weird favorite," said the director John Carpenter. Video can do that for a movie like "Big Trouble in Little China," Mr. Carpenter's 1986 film set in and under the streets of Chinatown in San Francisco. Some Carpenter films  "Halloween," for example, and "Escape From New York"  earned reputations in theaters. But others in the 80's  "The Thing," "Prince of Darkness"  built audiences on tape.

title: Basque Separatists Are Blamed As Newspaper Executive Is Killed
description: A Spanish newspaper executive was shot dead today in the first attack attributed to the Basque separatist group E.T.A. since voters overwhelmingly rejected the group's political allies and re-elected a moderate nationalist government on May 13.

description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION
