description: To the Editor:

title: Ogre With a Heart of Gold And Lung Capacity to Match
description: Shrek

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: State Senator Expelled
description: David Jaye, a conservative Republican, became the first Michigan senator to be expelled from office. A 33-to-2 vote to expel him by the Republican-controlled Senate came after hearings into accusations that Mr. Jaye struck his fiance and verbally abused staff members. Mr. Jaye called the expulsion a ''railroad job.'' John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, LOUIS
description: SHAPIRO-Louis. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of an admired leader of the Jewish community, a longtime friend and generous supporter who was a YU Guardian with his beloved wife, Pauline. They established the Pauline and Louis Shapiro Reading Area in the Mendel Gottesman Library as well as the Pauline and Louis Shapiro Mishnayos Bekiyus Competition at RIETS. Holocaust Studies Fellows, RIETS Fellows, and High School Fellows, they sponsored the annual Cong. Beth Judah YU Breakfast for many years and established a scholarship in their name at Samuel H. Wang-YUHS for Girls. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Pauline; children, Martin (and Patricia) Shapiro, Harvey (and Eileen) Shapiro, and Sheila (and Mark) Rosler; grandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman, Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a federal Court of Appeals ruling that denied prenatal care to illegal immigrants misstated part of the court's reasoning. While the ruling said Congress had sought to bar such a benefit for illegal immigrants, the court acknowledged that providing prenatal care would reduce government costs. It did not say that eliminating prenatal care would cut costs.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: School Official Quits
description: The president of the Chicago Board of Education, Gery J. Chico, resigned, and the schools' chief executive, Paul Vallas, is not saying if he will remain. Mr. Chico and Mr. Vallas have been credited by many for improvements in the city schools, but the increase in test scores has stalled, and two-thirds of the city's third-graders still do not read at grade level. The two had been under pressure from Mayor Richard M. Daley to increase the pace of change. Bill Dedman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, LUCY BLOW JEFFCOTT
description: PELL-Lucy Blow Jeffcott. Cotty Pell died on May 22 at the age of 82 in her house in Porto Ercole. Diagnosed with terminal cancer 20 years ago, she beat the odds as she so often did. She is survived by two sons, Peter of Glen Cove, NY, and Haven of Washington, D.C., and by five grandchildren. Cotty will be buried in Porto Ercole on Friday, May 25, and there will be no memorial service. In lieu of flowers, please take a moment to do something you might have enjoyed doing with her.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: DISCRIMINATION CHARGED The Stop and Shop Supermarket Companies is investigating complaints that a Long Island branch store discriminated on the basis of race against employees and job candidates, a Stop and Shop spokeswoman said yesterday. The complaints were filed last month with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said Rick Ostrove of Leeds, Morelli & Brown, P.C., a lawyer for the complainants. In February, Mr. Ostrove said, three black teenagers asked a manager at the Stop and Shop supermarket in East Meadow, where "now hiring" signs were posted, for job applications. The manager refused their request, saying no jobs were available, Mr. Ostrove said. Later, he said, the manager gave an application to one complainant's stepfather, who is Indian, explaining afterward that the store was "selectively hiring." A fourth complainant, who works as a cashier, is charging that she has been disciplined more harshly than her white counterparts. An E.E.O.C. spokesman would not comment.

title: Big Moments, Beautiful but Mysterious
description: ''The Man Who Cried'' is a most peculiar movie, a series of sumptuous mounted tableaus showing off the prowess of the writer and director Sally Potter as she follows Suzie (Christina Ricci) across Europe, fleeing one kind of persecution in the Soviet Union only to find another kind in France. The movie has the grandeur of an epic, though clearly done with little money; it's as if Ms. Potter were determined to show she could make ''Titanic'' on $30. But it lacks an epic sweep.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merger Talks Intensify For Alcatel and Lucent

title: Microsoft and Cisco Lead A Rally on the Nasdaq
description: Stocks rallied yesterday after a Federal Reserve official said that the central bank's interest rate reductions should spur an economic rebound. Microsoft and Cisco Systems led the advance.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Takeover Talk
description: Shares in two Hyundai companies rose after rumors emerged that a group led by the American International Group was nearing a deal to buy one of them. Hyundai Securities, the focal point of negotiations by A.I.G. for months, rose 7.6 percent, and Hyundai Merchant Marine rose 6.8 percent, both on the Korean stock exchange. The companies denied a newspaper report that Hyundai Merchant Marine had agreed to sell its 16.6 percent stake in Hyundai Securities to ease an A.I.G. takeover. Chung Mong Hun, the Hyundai heir most closely identified with Hyundai Securities and two related investment companies, is reportedly resisting a sale unless Hyundai retains control. A.I.G. wants a controlling stake, with the government taking over a significant portion of shares to help relieve pressure on the three heavily indebted companies. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Naval Crew Maneuvers On the D Train; Sailors in for Fleet Week Are Befriending Natives
description: When in war, follow your leader. This is a basic prescript of military life. It is a rule that Joe Lafferty, a gas turbine machinist third class, forgot yesterday in the hurly-burly of Fleet Week. And it cost him.

title: Paddling on the Hudson With an Explorer's Spirit
description: When we lived on the West Side of Manhattan in the late 1970's and early 80's, my wife and I liked to walk along the Hudson. I used to imagine what it was like before it was bounded by cities, when Manhattan was covered with trees and wildflowers and the Palisades had no high-rises.

title: Judge Spares Shopping Addict From Prison
description: Elizabeth Randolph Roach could not stop shopping, her lawyer told a judge. She shopped for things she did not need, things she did not want, designer clothes and jewelry she never even wore.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend last Friday, about classic wooden sailboats, misstated the role of the yawl Bolero in the 1956 Bermuda Race. Although the boat came in first and set a time record, it did not win. (Boats are rated by weights and sizes, so one can cross the finish line first and not be the winner.) The article also misstated the longevity of Bolero's record; it lasted until 1980, not 1982.

title: Article 2001052593391398551 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Cyber Law Journal: Cool Sites for 2001
description: Every year about this time I like to reveal secrets of the cyberlaw guild by writing about some of the free legal Web sites that help or inspire me the most. I hope you can find time to saunter through them during the coming summer days. If you're like me, you'll visit them again and again with delight.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, JERRY
description: SILVER-Jerry. Formerly of Palo Alto, CA. On May 23, 2001 in Greenwich, CT. He was 80 years of age and a WW II Army Infantry veteran. He was the adoring husband of Gloria Newman Silver, and beloved father to Barbara J. Tavrow, Joan Silver Katsky, and Richard J. Silver and father-in-law of David L. Katsky and Richard L. Tavrow. He will be missed by his loving grandchildren, Joshua Michael Tavrow, Sara Hallie Tavrow, Clay Silver Katsky and Lee Silver Katsky. He was predeceased by a grandson, Peter Silver Katsky. He is also survived by a brother, Robert Silvers and a sister, Florence Lavantino. Services were private. Donations to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International, 120 Wall Street or the Peter Silver Katsky Book Fund at Brown University would be appreciated.

title: Despite Sextuple Bypass Surgery, Hill Takes Rutgers to N.C.A.A. Playoffs
description: In November, some members of the Rutgers baseball team gathered for off-season conditioning work, and as they arrived they saw the familiar grizzled face of their coach, Fred Hill. While he still looked the part of a coach from an old movie, with his crew cut and a muscular build little different from his playing days, the players were unsure what to expect.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: 6 Charged In Journalist's Killing
description: Six months after the assassination of Mozambique's best-known journalist, Carlos Cardoso, the authorities have arrested and charged six men with the crime, the state news agency reported. They include Ayob Abdul Satar, a prominent businessman and a bank manager. Mr. Cardoso investigated the business activities of Mr. Satar's wealthy family and wrote about the country's largest bank fraud, in which $14 million was siphoned out of the Commercial Bank of Mozambique on the eve of its privatization in 1996. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Report Says Economy Grew More Slowly Than Previously Thought
description: For the first time since 1995, the United States economy grew by less than 2 percent for two consecutive quarters, the government reported today.

title: State Will Appoint Manager to Run Camden's Government
description: New Jersey's yearlong effort to take over the drifting city government of Camden began to bear fruit today as Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco and local leaders announced an agreement to have a state-appointed manager with broad powers direct the city's affairs for the next five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, CHRISTOPHER
description: GORMAN-Christopher. On May 20. Throngs of family and friends on both coasts shall miss your unwavering courage, wicked wit, and most of all, true blue friendship. You are with us always. Joan

title: Report Says Economy Grew More Slowly Than Previously Thought
description: For the first time since 1995, the United States economy grew by less than 2 percent for two consecutive quarters, the government reported today.

title: On Tense Day, Israelis Down Civilian Plane From Lebanon
description: The Israeli air force shot down a small civilian airplane off the coast of Israel today, killing a 43-year-old Lebanese student pilot on what was the first anniversary of the Israeli troop pullout from southern Lebanon.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Tivo Wins Video Recording Patent
description: TiVo Inc. of San Jose, Calif., has been granted an additional patent covering many of the crucial technologies associated with personal digital video recording, a market that it shares with Microsoft and others. The patent, No. 6,233,389, filed in July 1998, was granted for what TiVo calls the Multimedia Timewarping System. The patent covers its method for recording one program while viewing another, its method for processing video and audio streams in a TV signal and its storage format, which enables users to pause, scan and replay live broadcasts. TiVo was the first to sell a system that allows consumers to modify the experience of viewing live TV. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Volkswagen Tries to Foil Suitor
description: Executives of the German carmaker Volkswagen said this week that they were considering several strategies to stave off a potential hostile bid, including selling or partly spinning off its Audi luxury brand.

title: Vallone and Hevesi Spar Over Fiscal Forecasts
description: A City Council budget hearing erupted yesterday into a testy exchange in a continuing quarrel between two mayoral candidates over whose financial projections were better.

title: Sports of The Times; Mussina Looks Like An Ace
description: THE suggestion that he has something extra to prove in his transition to the Yankees brings a certain squint to the Stanford-educated gunslinger eyes of Mike Mussina.

title: To End Gun Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Tells Naval Graduates to Embrace Innovation
description: WASHINGTON, May 25  President Bush told new naval officers today that the country will need a spirit of innovation and sensible risk-taking as well as old-fashioned patriotism to defend its shores and its ideals in the years ahead.

title: Addenda: Leadership Changes at Industry Association
description: The International Advertising Association in New York has named Walter J. O'Brien Jr. its director general, effective July 1, succeeding Norman Vale, who has held the post since 1990.

title: Senate Switch Alters Outlook For Businesses
description: The return of Senate control to the Democrats after more than six years will have a profound effect on a variety of business issues pending in Congress, slowing some deregulatory measures that had been moving through Capitol Hill and sharply rearranging the legislative agenda.

title: Ex-Port Authority Head Settles Conflict-of-Interest Suit Over Role With Hospital
description: Robert E. Boyle, the former Port Authority chief, acknowledged yesterday that as chairman of a hospital in Westchester County, he failed to reveal his financial ties to a company doing business with the hospital, a disclosure required by law.

title: Bush Defends His Stance Despite Stinging Defection
description: Stung by the loss of Republican control of the Senate four months into his term, President Bush said today that he ''couldn't disagree more'' with Senator James M. Jeffords's reasons for defecting from his party. Meanwhile Mr. Bush's chief of staff said he thought Mr. Jeffords acted out of ''personal interest'' rather than ideology.

title: Maurice J. Noble, 91, Animator For 'Bambi' and Other Films
description: Maurice J. Noble, a film animator whose award-winning design work can be seen in the Disney classics ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' ''Bambi,'' ''Dumbo'' and ''Fantasia,'' died on May 18 at his home in La Crescenta, Calif. He was 91.

title: Medical Costs Surge as Hospitals Force Insurers to Raise Payments
description: Many hospitals are winning sharply higher payments from insurers, and the efforts by insurance companies to pass those costs along to employers and consumers are contributing to the most rapid surge in medical costs in years.

title: Zhou Tiehai
description: Ise Foundation

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 4 Accused In Drug Ring
description: Four Brooklyn men were charged yesterday with running a 24-hour crack cocaine ring that employed children and operated out of an East New York housing project. The men -- Ruking Cummings, Tyrone King, Kareem Quattlebaum and Brandy Russell -- were ranking members of a group that called itself the Crime Family, federal prosecutors said. Aside from the drug charges, they were accused of committing one murder and five attempted murders since August 1997. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Article 2001052591232634943 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: War Is Hell, but Very Pretty
description: The Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor that brought the United States into World War II has inspired a splendid movie, full of vivid performances and unforgettable scenes, a movie that uses the coming of war as a backdrop for individual stories of love, ambition, heroism and betrayal. The name of that movie is ''From Here to Eternity.''

title: Phillies' Class A Team Plays in First-Class Park
description: While the final touches are being applied to new stadiums in Staten Island and Brooklyn, the eighth minor league franchise in New Jersey has already unveiled its $22 million facility. The Lakewood BlueClaws, a Class A affiliate of the Philadelphia Phillies and a member of the South Atlantic League, began play last month at GPU Energy Park.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: De Beers Steps Back
description: After the negotiations with the Angolan government broke down, De Beers, the world's leading diamond miner, said it had suspended investment and prospecting in the war-ravaged African country. The talks collapsed over issues like mining rights, marketing contracts and investment guarantees, De Beers said. Angola had already canceled a 1990 agreement between De Beers and Endiama, the state diamond company, and given marketing rights for its $800 million annual output to an Israeli-Belgian venture. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Discrimination Charged
description: The Stop and Shop Supermarket Companies is investigating complaints that a Long Island branch store discriminated on the basis of race against employees and job candidates, a Stop and Shop spokeswoman said yesterday. The complaints were filed last month with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, said Rick Ostrove of Leeds, Morelli & Brown, P.C., a lawyer for the complainants. In February, Mr. Ostrove said, three black teenagers asked a manager at the Stop and Shop supermarket in East Meadow, where ''now hiring'' signs were posted, for job applications. The manager refused their request, saying no jobs were available, Mr. Ostrove said. Later, he said, the manager gave an application to one complainant's stepfather, who is Indian, explaining afterward that the store was ''selectively hiring.'' A fourth complainant, who works as a cashier, is charging that she has been disciplined more harshly than her white counterparts. An E.E.O.C. spokesman would not comment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: . . . But One Kim Jong Il Is Enough
description: Bai Eun Shik can no longer surprise and amuse South Korean audiences with his portrayals of Kim Jong Il. The Korea Advertising Review Board has banned the Kim lookalike from appearing in commercials that rely on the similarity, saying, ''The public is not ready to accept the North Korean leader's being the subject of ads on public airwaves.'' Don Kirk (NYT)

title: RENT-WAY REVISES COST OF ACCOUNTING IRREGULARITIES
description: Rent-Way Inc., a leading operator of rent-to-own stores, said yesterday that downward noncash adjustments to its earnings, related to an investigation of accounting irregularities, will be $127 million, well above previous company estimates. Rent-Way shares fell 85 cents, or 11 percent, to $6.85 on the New York Stock Exchange. Adjustments will be made to both full-year 2000 and 1999 results, the company said. Rent-Way, which is based in Erie, Pa., said that it was also reviewing 1998 results for possible revisions.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Banks
description: One of the largest banking companies in Japan, the Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group, posted a loss totaling 124.6 billion yen ($1 billion) at its three subsidiary banks for the year ended March 31. The loss deepened as the banking group absorbed 800.4 billion yen ($6.7 billion) in loan-loss charges to reduce nonperforming loans on its balance sheet. Outstanding problem loans at the group stood at 4.46 trillion yen ($37 billion), up 55 percent from the previous year, as Mitsubishi Tokyo toughened its criteria for bad loans. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Rate Cuts Are Paying Off, Greenspan Says
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said tonight that the central bank's interest rate cuts this year are having their intended effect on the faltering economy, and he hinted that the most aggressive phase of the Fed's effort to ward off a recession might be over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, BENJAMIN C.
description: BERLINER-Benjamin C. Died peacefully at home on May 23 in Bloomfield, CT after a long illness. Born on February 1, 1917 to William and Anna Berliner, he was raised in Woodmere, L.I. where he graduated from Woodmere Academy in 1935. He went on to graduate from Yale University in 1939 and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. He completed his residency at Cincinnati Children's Hospital and embarked upon a career in pediatrics that spanned 50 years, dedicated to caring for children in need and teaching others to do likewise. He was also a world acclaimed orchidist, avid birder, devoted environmentalist, naturalist and staunch defender of human dignity. He will be missed by all who knew him. Beloved husband of Esther Ann (Skippy); brother of William, Robert and the late Herbert; father of Frank, Charles, Benjamin and Anna; grandfather of Nicholas, Samuel, Zachary, Nathaniel, Christopher and Daniel; great grandfather of little Sasha. We love you Papa Ben. Graveside funeral will be private. A memorial service is planned and will be announced at a later time. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Orchid Conservancy of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Every Rock Band Needs Roadies When It Tours
description: CONVINCED that the MTV generation wants cars that relate to their lifestyles, and to their rock styles, several automakers are becoming music promoters. Volkswagen did it with its DriversFest 2000, featuring the Barenaked Ladies. Ford, which is using a ''Detroit Techno'' advertising theme for the Focus compact car, kicks off the Focus Detroit Electronic Music Festival this weekend and a national music festival this summer. And Honda has sent two popular bands on the road for the 2001 Civic Tour in customized Civics: blink-182's simply displays its logo, while Everclear's pays homage to its favorite holiday -- Halloween.

title: CONAGRA SAYS A FARM UNIT REPORTED FICTITIOUS SALES
description: ConAgra Foods Inc. said that fictitious sales and irregular accounting at a unit caused the overstatement of profits for the last three fiscal years. ConAgra, which makes Chef Boyardee pasta, Bumble Bee tuna and Hunt's sauces, said it would reduce pretax profit by a total of $123 million, or 3.6 percent, for fiscal 1998 through 2000. The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting an informal inquiry into United Agri Products, a seed and fertilizer unit that represents 9 percent of ConAgra's operating profit, the company said. The fictitious sales were ''relatively small,'' a spokeswoman, Karen S. Lynn, said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about efforts at the United Nations to block the new British-American proposal on regulating trade with Iraq referred incorrectly to the nomination of John Negroponte as American ambassador to the organization. The White House has indeed acted; it sent the nomination to the Senate on May 14.

title: The Secret to Being Happier, if Not Richer
description: To the Editor:

title: The Illusion of a Grand Strategy
description: Today President Bush will deliver what has been billed as a major defense policy statement. Coming on the heels of a Pentagon ''top-to-bottom'' defense review -- the result of two dozen panels of experts meeting for several months behind closed doors -- his speech has been preceded by high expectations and not a small amount of controversy. Will he come to the Naval Academy armed with a revolutionary plan to transform the military, as his earlier statements have suggested? In the end, it may not matter. No plan, said Clausewitz, the Prussian strategist, survives the first battle; and the counterattacks have already begun.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Gets Big Service Contract
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will supply computer services to NTL Inc., Britain's largest cable television company, under a 10-year contract that could be worth more than $2 billion. The contract calls for I.B.M. to run NTL's computer operations in Britain and Ireland and is expected to save NTL more than $450 million before expiring in 2012. NTL said that the 483 NTL workers affected by the change would become employees of I.B.M. Separately, I.B.M. and the Seiko Epson Corporation said they had agreed to set up a venture to make chips for mobile, Internet and wireless computing devices. The venture will use an I.B.M. plant in Japan, the companies said.

title: In Setting Priorities, Democrats Give Up Confirmation Battle
description: The Senate voted today to confirm Theodore B. Olson as solicitor general by a narrow margin after Democrats, contemplating their imminent majority status, decided they did not want to defeat the nomination as the first exercise of their new power.

title: TV spots for women's basketball showcase the beauty and grace of the game and its players.
description: IT is a sport whose hallmarks are speed, teamwork and beauty -- the beauty of the plays and of the players themselves. And those are the qualities that have provided ESPN with a theme for its campaign promoting women's professional basketball and the 2001 Women's National Basketball Association season, the league's fifth, which will begin on Monday.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Firestone's Revival Strategy: Be Contrite and Attack Ford
description: Bridgestone/Firestone hopes to win back public confidence by quietly acknowledging that it has made some faulty tires while also trying to shift much of the blame for scores of accidents to the Ford Motor Company.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Railtrack
description: Burdened by the cost of repairing track across the country after a cracked rail was blamed for a fatal train wreck, Railtrack, the owner of Britain's railroad tracks and stations, said it lost money for the first time since its privatization in 1996. The net loss in the year to March 31 was 307 million ($435 million), in contrast to a net profit a year earlier of 295 million ($420 million). Track repairs after a crash in October north of London accounted for most of the company's charges, which totaled 733 million ($1.04 billion), Railtrack said. Railtrack also asked for government aid worth $2.9 billion to pay for a five-year program of repairs. But it also said it would pay a dividend, infuriating passenger advocacy groups. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: An article on Wednesday about efforts at the United Nations to block the new British-American proposal on regulating trade with Iraq referred incorrectly to the nomination of John Negroponte as American ambassador to the organization. The White House has indeed acted; it sent the nomination to the Senate on May 14.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Protest At New Terminal
description: More than 150 union members and their supporters held a protest rally yesterday during the ceremony opening Terminal 4, the new international arrivals terminal at Kennedy Airport. The rally, sponsored by the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, sought to protest a decision by a restaurant contractor, Restaurant Associates, to hire fewer than half the 100 food employees who had worked at the old terminal. Five demonstrators were charged with disorderly conduct.

description: Among the many sad trends in the Middle East today is the fact that Egypt, a nation that should be leading the Arab world into the 21st century, is in danger of becoming a banana republic.

title: White Sox Break Skid In Toronto
description: Kip Wells pitched six strong innings as the Chicago White Sox ended an eight-game losing streak by beating the Blue Jays, 3-1, last night in Toronto.

title: F.A.A. and Airlines See Clearer Skies for Travelers
description: The airlines and the government used the phrase ''cautiously optimistic'' today to describe how they felt about the summer travel season, which unofficially starts this weekend.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Fujimori Accused In Killings
description: Attorney General Nelly Caldern filed charges before Congress accusing former President Alberto K. Fujimori, left, of having approved the 1991 death-squad killings of 15 people in Lima. Investigators say the squad was organized by Peru's fugitive former intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, with Mr. Fujimori's knowledge and encouragement. The government's assertion that the victims were terrorists was never proved. As a former president, Mr. Fujimori has immunity from prosecution unless Congress lifts it. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: Uncovering a Small-Town Loser's Many Layers of Lies
description: A FEW CORRECTIONS -- A Novel

title: Report on Garden Job Denied
description: The president of the Staples Center in Los Angeles said yesterday that he has not met or talked with Cablevision officials about running Madison Square Garden.

title: Memos Point to Ties Between Auction Houses
description: Handwritten memos at the center of the collusion case of Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses suggest that the companies secretly altered time-honored and costly inducements used to attract sellers. Acting together, they dropped low-interest loans, ceased making donations to sellers' favorite charities and devised a system to increase their profits when art sold above a guaranteed minimum, according to the documents.

title: Big 3 Chase the Leader and a Dream
description: For a few special hours today, Arnold Palmer ignored being 71 years old and acted as if it were 1971. A 61-year-old Jack Nicklaus played as if he were the Nicklaus of old. And Jim Thorpe, a man who loves to gamble, improved his odds of winning his first major championship.

title: Crude Detentions in China
description: As the diplomatic climate has decayed between Washington and Beijing in recent months, China has singled out one group of Americans for particularly harsh treatment. A lengthening list of Chinese-born Americans have been detained by China's State Security Ministry. One of them has recently been charged with spying for Taiwan, exposing him to a potentially lengthy prison term.

title: America's Political Terrain, Jolted by One Man
description: To the Editor:

title: A Hostile Witness to the Inhumanity of the Human Condition
description: No one has ever accused Leon Golub of painting pretty -- or, for that matter, painting pretty well. But for him such niceties are hardly an issue. Substituting social awareness for the artier mainstream approaches of the last half-century, he has produced raw, awkward figurative works whose blunt, brute shapes with eroded surfaces serve to further his basic theme, man's inhumanity to man.

title: New-Home Sales Drop for First Time In Three Month
description: Sales of new homes in the United States fell in April for the first time in three months while holding at a level above the record number sold three years ago, a government report showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, GEORGE A.
description: FOX-George A. The Board of Trustees, President and staff of WNYC Radio wish to convey their deepest condolences to the family of George A. Fox, who served as Chairman of the WNYC Foundation from 1982-84. During a critical time in WNYC's history, he oversaw the comprehensive rehabilitation of the stations' broadcast facilities. His leadership, guidance and vision for WNYC and his ongoing support of the station's Independence Campaign were invaluable. He will be greatly missed.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Domain Discussion Forum Closed
description: Prompting complaints that it was trying to silence critics, VeriSign Inc. -- the company that maintains the registry of Internet domains ending in dot-com, dot-net and dot-org -- shut down an e-mail discussion forum whose subject was its domain policy. Critics said VeriSign had closed the list because it served as a forum for complaints about the company, based in Mountain View, Calif. Brian O'Shaughnessy, a VeriSign spokesman, said the company closed the list not because of criticism but because it had become redundant in view of the numerous other discussion forums. ''This is in no way an attempt to stop the discussion,'' he said. ''It's just going to happen in other places.'' Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Ashcroft Vows No Delay In McVeigh's Execution
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that he would not further delay the scheduled June 11 execution of Timothy J. McVeigh, but acknowledged that the F.B.I. had found about 900 more pages of documents related to the Oklahoma City bombing that the government had failed to turn over to Mr. McVeigh's lawyers for his trial.

title: Against the Best, Mussina Proves Even Better
description: The rhythmic clapping and a long, slow chant made Moose sound as if it had 50 letters instead of 5. All the while, Mike Mussina leaned forward on the mound in the seventh inning at Yankee Stadium yesterday, trying to maintain another uncanny Yankee edge over Pedro Martnez, rescue Chuck Knoblauch from having to explain the fly ball he lost in the sun and allow his team to continue tweaking the best pitcher in the world.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column yesterday, about culinary books as the best-selling successors to sex books, misstated the surname of a Rutgers anthropologist who commented on connections between sex and food. She is Helen E. Fisher, not Harris.

title: El Greco, Richly Repeating Himself
description: DESPITE the impressive gowns, does the Jacqueline Kennedy show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art ultimately strike you as bland and sentimental? On a more substantial note, do Frank Gehry's beautiful architectural models at the Guggenheim Museum sometimes seem a bit overbearing and overwrought? If so, you may need a little more old-fashioned art and a little less spectacle and commerce in your museum experience.

title: T.W.A. to Pay $2.6 Million to Settle Harassment Suit
description: Federal officials said yesterday that Trans World Airlines had agreed to pay $2.6 million to settle a lawsuit filed on behalf of women at the airline who said they had endured widespread sexual harassment by supervisors at its Kennedy Airport terminal and had faced retaliation when they complained.

title: 'Big Trouble': Big Comeback
description: ''All of a sudden it became kind of this weird favorite,'' said the director John Carpenter. Video can do that for a movie like ''Big Trouble in Little China,'' Mr. Carpenter's 1986 film set in and under the streets of Chinatown in San Francisco. Some Carpenter films -- ''Halloween,'' for example, and ''Escape From New York'' -- earned reputations in theaters. But others in the 80's -- ''The Thing,'' ''Prince of Darkness'' -- built audiences on tape.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Crow Infected With West Nile
description: The State Health Department yesterday reported the first confirmed animal case of West Nile virus in New York this year. A crow found dead in Yorktown, in Westchester, on May 10 was found to have been carrying the mosquito-borne virus, which sickens and sometimes kills humans. Health authorities said finding such evidence was not a sign of imminent risk to humans.

description: A lunchtime settling of accounts yesterday between two 9-year-old girls in a basement bathroom at Public School 155 in Brooklyn ended at St. Mary's Hospital, where one of the girls was pronounced dead.

title: East Side Journal; Visiting the Met, Led by a Maid in a Novel About Vermeer
description: At the head of flying wedges, the tour guides bull through the second-floor galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, pausing so their flocks can glimpse the small, treasured paintings of Johannes Vermeer and his contemporaries in Delft. Thousands of other visitors tramp the exhibit at their own pace, steered by learned spiels from the rented audio guides that are looped around their necks.

The company, Summit Aviation, received contracts from the state police to transport the governor on a Lear jet, according to vouchers.

description: The Chinese government said today that it had agreed to what it called an American plan to dismantle the damaged Navy surveillance plane now sitting on a southern Chinese island and ship it home in pieces.

Al Sharpton and three Bronx politicians scrambled to appeal their sentences for trespassing near the United States Navy bombing site on Vieques, the Justice Department agreed yesterday to transfer the four men from Puerto Rico to a New York jail to serve their terms.

title: Into Summer With a Roar
description: Josh Hartnett had the cell phone pressed tightly to his ear as he tried to hear over the roar of wind and machinery. ''I'm standing on the flight deck of the ship, and there's all sorts of stuff going on,'' he yelled into the phone. ''It's really amazing.''

description: Spiders Arrive, Puppy Departs

title: Investors Are Rushing to Mexico, Despite Slowing Growth
description: With the cooling of the United States economy, Mexico's mood this month has been generally dour. Unemployment is up, exports are slumping and the numbers show the country headed for a recession.

title: Israeli Hall Collapses; 25 Dead, Scores Injured
description: A festive Israeli wedding party turned into a national tragedy Thursday night as a crowded dance floor collapsed onto a packed dining hall one level below, killing at least 25 and injuring more than 350, according to official reports.

title: Corrections

description: COHN-Kate E. (nee Isaack), 94. On Thursday, May 24, 2001, of Rockville, Maryland, formerly of Elizabeth, NJ. Devoted wife of the late Heinz Cohn. Beloved mother of the late Warren I. The Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: Gravano and Son Plead Guilty To Running Ecstasy Drug Ring
description: Returning to the same federal courthouse where his turncoat testimony brought down nearly 40 members of the mob, Salvatore Gravano pleaded guilty yesterday to running a multimillion-dollar Ecstasy ring with his son in Arizona.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday with a front-page article about the deaths of 14 illegal immigrants in the southwest Arizona desert misstated the location of two bodies in some copies. A corrected map appears today, on Page A10.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hotels Sold
description: Completing the sale of its hotel businesses, the Compass Group of Britain said it would sell its 146 Le Meridien hotels in 55 countries to the private equity firm Nomura International Ltd. for $2.7 billion. Compass is abandoning hotels to concentrate on food services. Its stock rose as much as 3.1 percent, to 540 pence. Nomura, which was competing with Marriott of the United States for the chain, is a division of Japan's largest brokerage firm. It is led by Guy Hands, above, who has spent over $14 billion on cash-generating businesses like pubs and real estate. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Soldiers in Georgia Stage a Brief Near Mutiny
description: As many as 400 Georgian national guardsmen left their barracks today and took over a police station outside the capital, Tbilisi, to protest long delays in paychecks and other economic hardships, briefly raising fears of a coup.

title: Mets Come Out Swinging to Beat Angry Marlins
description: Timo Perez touched first, turned and bolted for second, even though his single had already won the game. Tsuyoshi Shinjo sprang from the dugout and chased Perez down, leaping on his back, two Mets reveling in the outcome of a wild night at Shea Stadium. Perez was the hero on Merengue Night, flawlessly fielding a Dominican flag tossed to him from the stands after the game. But the victory was for Shinjo.

title: Ditech Has Loss; Shares Tumble
description: The Ditech Communications Corporation, a designer of fiber optic network equipment, said sales would decline and it would have losses this quarter and next, setting off a 40 percent decline in its stock price.

title: India's Leader Speaks of Reconciliation in Letter to Pakistan
description: In a graceful letter, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee today officially invited Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to India for the first talks between the two nations since an earlier peace program was ruptured by a violent conflict in Kashmir two years ago.

title: Mighty Ducks Hire Murray as Coach
description: The Anaheim Mighty Ducks named Bryan Murray, the former general manager of the Florida Panthers, as their coach, replacing Guy Charron.

title: Bush Faces the Power of Subpoena
description: Teeth are still rattling over Senator James Jeffords's jump from the Republican party and the shift of Senate control to the Democrats. Many consequences have been widely noted. But one of the most important aftershocks has not yet been felt: The change in control means the Democrats will wield investigative power. The Bush administration will have to face, as its recent predecessors did, an array of committees with the power to peel back secrecy and probe controversy. The results may not be pretty.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Government Backtracks On Slaying
description: Ten days after proclaiming that the government had solved the killing of the opposition journalist Georgy Gongadze, Interior Minister Yuri Smirnov said he had spoken prematurely and was only expressing a personal opinion about the case. The killing has caused a long-running crisis for President Leonid D. Kuchma; secretly recorded audiotapes released by a former bodyguard appear to show Mr. Kuchma ordering Mr. Gongadze's kidnapping. Mr. Kuchma has denied any role.

title: President Calls for Flexibility And Innovation in Military
description: A day after President Bush discovered that a touch of political risk-taking cost him control of the United States Senate, he told new naval officers they needed the freedom to roam in new directions even if ''some of your ideas may fail.''

title: Reactivating The Echoes Of Old Times
description: One of the great British rock bands of the 60's collided with a rock band whose music typified the 70's on Thursday night at the Village Underground. For the first time since 1966, the keyboardist Rod Argent and the singer Colin Blunstone performed together onstage in the United States, playing as part of the Cavestomp series, which specializes in such retro reunions and will present encore performances tonight and tomorrow night. Mr. Argent and Mr. Blunstone were formerly members of the Zombies, whose pristine, infectious, harmony-laden rock culminated in one of the best misspelled albums of the 60's, ''Odessey and Oracle,'' released after the band's breakup.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on May 18 about the fall television schedule on the Fox network misstated Judd Apatow's role in the program ''Freaks and Geeks.'' He was the executive producer; the creator was Paul Feig.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Loss At Mazda
description: Mazda Motor said it lost 155.2 billion yen ($1.3 billion) in the fiscal year that ended March 31, its worst result ever. The company said it wrote off pension and retirement liabilities amounting to 155 billion yen during the year. But Mazda also reported weak sales around the world as sales fell 6.7 percent, to 2 trillion yen ($16.7 billion). For the coming year, Mazda expects to break even as its sales rise 6.2 percent, to 2.14 trillion yen ($17.9 billion). Ford Motor owns 33.4 percent of Mazda. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Journal; The Best Years of Our Lives
description: According to Hollywood's polling research, 95 percent of Americans are aware of ''Pearl Harbor,'' the movie. Never mind that a far smaller percentage knows about Pearl Harbor, the historical event. In the American marketplace of ideas, product recognition rules, and so this weekend's most prevalent patriotic tribute to those who fought and died for our country will be the lines for Disney's three-hour salute to The Greatest Generation. Pearl Harbor may have been a day which was supposed to live in infamy, but the infamy of 1941 is no match for the fame conferred by publicity in 2001. If ''Pearl Harbor'' racks up a $100 million opening, it's because more Americans have heard of Ben Affleck, a second-rung movie star, than Hirohito.

title: Currais Novos Journal; Pity the Donkey, a Beast That's Become a Burden
description: Consider the humble donkey. Hard-working, reliable, docile, it has been prized for centuries in the parched and barren northeast of Brazil as both beast of burden and loyal companion.

title: Boeing's Russian Edge
description: Ever notice that overhead compartments in Boeing planes now fit big rolling carry-on suitcases? Russian designers made it happen.

title: They Saved the Jews, But Few Were Heroes
description: Ever since the end of World War II, Bulgarians have been fighting over who deserves the credit for saving the nation's Jews from annihilation. The monarchists insisted King Boris III rescued them; the Communists claim they were the saviors, while most Bulgarians believe it was the citizens who came together to frustrate the Nazis' deportation plans in 1943.

title: New Chairmen Shift Priorities For the Senate
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts liberal whom Republicans love to vilify, is planning a swift vote on increasing the minimum wage. Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico wants to limit plans for more oil drilling in Alaska and instead encourage conservation. And Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut has his eye on President Bush's plans to relax rules on arsenic in drinking water, forest roads and mining sludge.

A pair of 13-day Caribbean and Panama Canal cruises in January are start from $2,495 a person, double occupancy. A nine-day trans-Atlantic trip sailing May 13, 2002, starts at $2,310 a person, double. On Sept. 14, a 10-day Alaska voyage is priced at $2,085 and up. The Crystal Harmony and Crystal Symphony each have a capacity of 940 passengers and are in the luxury category of cruise ships. Information: (800) 820-6663 or www.crystalcruises.com .

A press conference is convened, and senior officials, illustrating their numbers with colorful charts, disclose to the nation the latest income data. None gets more attention than the poverty level. A family of four that falls below $17,062 in annual income falls into poverty, the bureau declared last September.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Avoids Takeover
description: A group of would-be German corporate raiders apparently gave up their yearlong effort to force a merger or a major restructuring of Commerzbank A. G., Germany's fourth-largest bank. COBRA Beteiligungs, which owns 17 percent of the bank's shares, withdrew petitions that criticized the bank's executives at its annual shareholder meeting. COBRA, whose leaders include a former investment banker, Hansgeorg Hofmann, had been trying without success to orchestrate Commerzbank's sale to a larger bank. Martin Kohlhausen, who is retiring as Commerzbank's chief executive, fought off COBRA in part by issuing new shares to a friendly shareholder, Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. of Italy. Many analysts say that Commerzbank is too small to compete on its own and that the bank surprised shareholders earlier this month by reporting a big decline in first-quarter profits. At the meeting, Mr. Hofmann denounced Mr. Kohlhausen as ''a man of the past'' but expressed support for his successor, Klaus Peter Mller, and withdrew the hostile petitions. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Injustice in Egypt
description: Saad Eddin Ibrahim, Egypt's most prominent advocate of democracy and human rights, has been convicted by a Cairo court so impatient to pronounce sentence that it did not wait for defense lawyers to complete their case. The charges brought against Mr. Ibrahim, a sociologist who holds American as well as Egyptian citizenship, were flimsy and his trial failed to meet international standards of fairness and due process. Yet the 62-year-old Mr. Ibrahim now faces seven years' imprisonment unless Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak, exercises his constitutional power to set aside the verdict. He should do so promptly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRYNBAUM, BRUCE B..
description: GRYNBAUM-Bruce B.. The Faculty and Staff of The Howard A. Rusk Institute, NYU Hospitals Center and the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, NYU School of Medicine have lost one of its cherished leaders, treasured colleague and dear friend, Professor of Clinical Rehabilitation and Vice Chairman of the Department. Born in Russia, emigrated to the United States in 1939, M.D. from Columbia Residency at Mount Sinai, Baruch Fellow at Goldwater Memorial, NYU faculty since 1949, he served as Director of Rehab Service/Bellevue for 37 years. His half a century career involvement in rehabilitation medicine reflects the growth of this discipline in the many organizations he belonged to in the city and state of New York. Academically concerned with residency training, in 1987 he received the distinguished Physician Award from the AAPM&R. Bruce was a man of exceptional intellect and integrity and the dedication, commitment and dignity he extended to all his patients was unsurpassed. NYU and Rusk Institute lost a valued, kind and special physician and friend. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife Joan, and his family. Mathew H.M. Lee, M.D., MPH Howard A. Rusk Professor and Chairman Department of Rehabilitation Medicine Medical Director, Rusk Institute

Noting that the state is usually ranked near the bottom on national tests, Judge Collins Kilgore of Pulaski County Chancery Court cited experts who testified at a trial last year that the state needed to spend $450 million to $900 million beyond its current $1.7 billion education budget. title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Winemaker Stake
description: Allied Domecq P.L.C., a leading liquor maker, increased its stake in the Montana Group NZ, New Zealand's biggest winemaker, to about 27 percent. Lion Nathan Ltd., Australia's second-largest brewer, is competing for control of Montana and has raised its Montana stake to 62 percent this year, though its purchases are being scrutinized by New Zealand's market regulator and might be canceled. Allied wants to add Montana's highly rated sauvignon blanc wines to its global wine business, to help meet growing demand for premium wine.

title: Rights Groups Urge Change in Border Policy
description: As doctors said that the condition of the 12 Mexican immigrants who survived furnace-like conditions in the desert near here was improving, a number of immigrant rights groups said today that the death of 14 other illegal border crossers had caused them to consider stronger challenges to what they call hostile United States border policy.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Set Condition For Talks
description: As a condition for entering peace talks, rebels of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam have demanded that the government lift a ban on them imposed after the Tigers attacked the Buddhist Temple of the Tooth in 1998. But the state-run newspaper reported that it ''reliably understands'' that the ban will remain in place.

title: Barneys Loss Widens on Slump in Sales
description: Fiscal first-quarter losses at Barneys New York Inc. widened as sales declined, and the company, the retailer of luxury goods, said yesterday that it had adopted new merchandising methods to stem the drop.

title: Bloom Is Off the Brass for a Vindicated Ex-Police Chief
description: THIS former police chief tightens his grip around the leather steering wheel while cruising these sunny streets, his dark blue shades covering his mostly dry blue eyes.

title: THE CENSUS: The New Melting Pot; With an Asian Influx, a Suburb Finds Itself Transformed
description: It is hard to pin down the elusive tipping point when the old Fremont gave way to the new one.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Twins Face Rare Duel In National Semifinal
description: The twins John and Tom Glatzel will turn 22 Sunday. As far back as they can remember, they have been playing lacrosse.

title: Economy Grew Less Than 2% for 2 Quarters
description: For the first time since 1995, the economy grew by less than 2 percent for two consecutive quarters, the government reported yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Powell vs. Zimbabwean

title: Dodgers' Karros Put on Disabled List
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers placed first baseman Eric Karros on the 15-day disabled list yesterday with a sprained lower back, the team said.

title: REDBACK TO BUY MERLIN IN $57 MILLION STOCK DEAL
description: Redback Networks Inc., a maker of telephone and fiber optic networking equipment, agreed to buy Merlin Systems Inc. for $57 million in stock. The purchase will give Redback 37 engineers and an office in Fremont, Calif., where closely held Merlin is based, a Redback spokeswoman, Meera Agarwal, said. In January, Merlin helped Redback introduce its SmartEdge 100 fiber optic product, which directs traffic on fiber optic networks. Merlin, a developer of optical components for fiber optic networks, helped Redback with the product's customer trials.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Growth Slows
description: Hong Kong's economy felt the effects of the global economic slowdown in the first quarter of 2001, growing 2.5 percent, compared with 14.1 percent in the quarter last year. A government economist, K. Y. Tang, attributed the weak performance to lower exports to the United States and Europe. He warned that the territory could be further buffeted by the falling Japanese yen and other Asian currencies. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: At Home Abroad; A Political Surprise
description: A funny thing happened on the way to the British election June 7. When the Conservatives let it be known that they would cut taxes if they won, there was a sharp backlash. It turned out that in Britain today, tax cuts are political poison.

title: Smithsonian Group Criticizes Official on Donor Contract
description: A group of curators and scholars at the Museum of American History has accused Lawrence M. Small, the Smithsonian Institution's secretary, of jeopardizing the integrity of the institution and breaching standard museum practices because of agreements he has reached with multimillion-dollar donors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, ANN
description: EVANS-Ann. We note with great sadness the passing of Ann Evans. She was a devoted Trustee of The Henry Street Settlement for many years. Our deepest sympathy to the family. Board and Staff The Henry Street Settlement

title: A Political Quake and Its Aftershocks
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: A Deadly Anachronism
description: Hundreds of people in northern Afghanistan, living on tea and bread in a drought-hit region, have scurvy, which is caused by a lack of vitamin C and leads to skin discoloration, bleeding gums and eventually death, Doctors Without Borders reports. ''This disease should not exist in the 21st century,'' said Stephan Goedgebuur, the group's regional coordinator. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: As June Approaches, Hernndez Can't Win
description: The cornerstone of Orlando Hernndez's postseason brilliance was laid here, in a pivotal playoff game during the Yankees' record-setting season of 1998. Hernndez had the guts to throw Jim Thome a changeup with a full count and the bases loaded, got the strikeout and the first of eight consecutive October victories. He became El Duque, the pitcher who never loses a big game.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Sale Considered
description: HSBC Holdings may get another chance to bid for SeoulBank, acquired by the government in early 1998 at the height of Korea's economic crisis. HSBC, which had a preliminary agreement in 1999 to buy the bank, reportedly is a leading contender in a new effort by creditors, led by the government's Korea Deposit Insurance Corporation, to sell it. Six months after signing its initial agreement, HSBC pulled out in a dispute over the extent of nonperforming loans held by SeoulBank. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: At a Charity Game, Foes' Bid Is a Gift for a Bridge Scion
description: For more than three decades, the world's most successful charity game has been played in Manhattan each May. This year's event, played Monday at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, was ably organized by Marci Miron. A galaxy of stars was present, and more than $85,000 was raised for the UJA-Federation.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: Governor Apologizes
description: Saying ''I made a mistake,'' Gov. Bob Holden acknowledged that his inaugural celebration had cost over $1 million, more than the state had ever spent. Mr. Holden said he saw the event as a show of unity after a divisive presidential election. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Holiday on Monday -- Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Inmate Stabbed in His Cell on Rikers Island
description: An 18-year-old man in jail awaiting trial on murder charges was beaten and stabbed in his cell on Rikers Island, officials said yesterday.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY
description: ORGANS FOR SALE

title: Gawking at the Rugs In Apartment 3C; Open Houses Attract the Curious
description: Kate Frank Cohen admits it: She's curious. ''We all want to see the real inside of people's lives -- their decorating techniques, where they're shopping,'' Ms. Cohen said.

title: A Hobbled Iverson May Sit In Game 3
description: Allen Iverson boarded the Philadelphia 76ers' charter plane for Milwaukee this afternoon, and, saying his bruised tailbone had not improved, expressed strong doubt whether he would play against the Bucks in Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals on Saturday.

title: Walter Eytan, 90, Dies; Founded Israel's Foreign Service
description: Walter Eytan, an early British immigrant to Israel who developed a foreign service to meet the needs of a new state suddenly at war with its neighbors, died on May 23 in a hospital in Jerusalem. He was 90.

title: Chief of Hughes Electronics Resigns Amid Merger Debate
description: Michael T. Smith, the chairman of Hughes Electronics which has been in the midst of one of the most melodramatic corporate auctions in recent memory -- resigned from the company today and is being replaced by an executive from General Motors.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: About Those Beef-Flavored Fries
description: McDonald's has posted an apology on its Web site for any confusion it may have caused by not telling its customers that its french fries contained beef flavoring. McDonald's was sued on May 1 in Seattle on behalf of a vegetarian and two Hindus who do not eat beef. They claim that the company intentionally misled customers by announcing that the fries were cooked in 100 percent vegetable oil. The apology says, ''We regret if customers felt that the information we provided was not complete enough to meet their needs.'' Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: Article 2001052692163519303 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: A Fashion Twist:Asians See Hair to Dye For
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Years ago, when black was black, East Asians viewed light-colored hair as a mark of poverty, a sign of malnutrition or too much exposure to the sun.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: More Cow Trouble
description: Britain's food watchdog warned that cows that grazed near pyres used to burn animal carcasses during the foot-and-mouth disease outbreak could be producing milk that is contaminated with dioxin released by the fires. The group, the Food Standards Agency, said that tests were still being conducted, but that the milk most at risk was whole milk produced by cows from farms within about a mile of the pyres. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACK, JACOB BERNARD
description: ZACK-Jacob Bernard. Of Brooklyn, NY, on May 25th, 2001. Husband of the late Marion Millstein Zack. Father of Emily Tabuteau and Anne Miller. Grandfather of Jesse Miller. Brother of William and Nathan. Service BoulevardRiverside Chapel, 1895 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn, Sunday, 12:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the charity of your choice.

title: Levy to Award Merit Bonuses To Principals
description: In the first citywide application of merit pay in New York City public schools, Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced yesterday that he would award bonuses as high as $15,000 to principals and other administrators in the 300 schools that had the largest improvement in test scores.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, SYLVIA
description: KAHN-Sylvia. On May 24, 2001, Sylvia Kahn joined her beloved husband, Robert L. Kahn. She leaves behind her loving family who will miss her very much. Daughters; Ellen and Victor Goldsmith, Hastings-on-Hudson, Wendy and Dr. David Goldberg, Scarsdale; granddaughters, Emily Weber, Becky and Julia Goldberg; sisters, Florence Ritter, Leah Cooper. Funeral 11:30 Sunday, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave. White Plains, NY.

title: Stocks Are Dragged Lower by Sluggish Reports on the Economy
description: Stock prices fell yesterday as a series of economic reports showed that the American economy was still very sluggish.

description: 1st-Quarter G.D.P. Rose At a Sluggish 1.3% Pace

title: Royal Shakespeare Tells the Barbican Ta-Ta
description: Adrian Noble, artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, announced on Thursday here that it would dismantle its permanent company of actors and abandon its London base at the Barbican Center to attract bigger stars and present more productions in the showier West End.

title: Commencements; At Sarah Lawrence, 'Follow Your Bliss'
description: Barbara Walters asked today's graduates of Sarah Lawrence College for a show of hands: those who know what they want to do with their lives, and those who do not.

title: The Mets Watch As Wells's Value Falls
description: There is a sense among some people around the Mets that David Wells is like a hot potato, passed from team to team until someone, inevitably, gets burned. The team burning now is the Chicago White Sox, who are trying to trade Wells, a controversial, highly paid pitcher whose value sinks each time he pitches.

title: Pataki Seeks Balance to State's Democratic Tilt
description: He is a popular incumbent and a shrewd strategist, a prodigious fund-raiser and a moderate whose appeal crosses regional and ideological bounds.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Children In Spanking Case Are Returned Home
description: All but 14 of 49 children seized by state officials in an investigation of child abuse and excessive spanking at an Atlanta church were returned by a juvenile court judge. The release came after an investigation revealed that many had not been as seriously harmed as believed, and after several elected officials intervened. A state spokesman said the judge released the children after parents promised not to abuse them, although he relented on a condition that they not be spanked in public. David Firestone (NYT)

description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Latest Disaster Tests Resiliency of Jerusalem's Residents
description: This is a city accustomed to coping with crisis. But as sirens screamed through the night, with ambulances racing to a collapsed wedding hall in which at least two dozen people died, Jerusalemites struggled to deal with what some described as crisis overload.

title: School Fight Didn't Kill Girl, Official Says
description: A 9-year-old girl who died after a fight in the bathroom of a Brooklyn school Thursday had no external injuries and appeared to have succumbed to either an asthma attack or heart problems, a police official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LENNARD, FLORENCE
description: LENNARD-Florence. In life you were always there. Its been 15 years since you left-you are still here. Everlasting love, Jules

description: The Reuters Group will eliminate an unspecified number of management jobs as part of a reorganization, a Reuters spokesman said.

title: Producer Who Turned Con Artist Is Rearrested In New Fraud Case
description: Adela Holzer, who gained notoriety first as a bona fide Broadway producer and then as a con artist, is back. She lives in a well-appointed classic six on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, has changed her name and has been arrested in connection with a new scheme: prosecutors say she defrauded immigrants of at least $50,000 while saying she could help them stay in the country.

title: In Mexico, Grim Resolve After Deaths
description: So many have lost their lives crossing into the promised land that some in Mexico were simply numbed by news of the deaths of 14 more migrants abandoned in the Arizona desert.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Central Asia: Force To Fight Muslim Rebels
description: In a further sign of Russia's deepening military involvement in former Soviet republics, Russia and three Central Asian nations agreed to establish a rapid-reaction force to combat Islamic insurgency in the region. Meeting in Armenia, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his counterparts from Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan agreed on a joint force to be based in Kyrgyzstan's capital, Bishkek. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: MetroStars Take On Bayern In a Meeting of Tired Teams
description: The MetroStars can earn some prestige for Major League Soccer if they play a competitive match tonight against Bayern Munich, which won the European Champions League final on Wednesday.

title: Sorry, You've Got The Wrong Number
description: According to your book, it sounds as if we really have prostitutes to thank for the development of statistics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, DR. CATHERINE HUDGINS. DR.
description: TUCK-Dr. Catherine Hudgins. Dr. Catherine Hudgins Tuck, co-founder and Associate Director of the Naomi Berrie Diabetes Center at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, died Thursday of breast cancer. She was 39. A Magna cum laude graduate of Princeton University, she attended the University of Texas Southwestern Medical School in Dallas, and was Chief Medical Resident in Internal Medicine at Columbia Presbyterian. A clinician and medical educator, she was appointed to the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. She is survived by her husband Edward H.A. Tuck and her son Hallam, age 8 both of New York and loving family and friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81St on Sunday, May 27, 5-7PM. Funeral services will be held Monday, May 28 at 4P.M. at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Catherine H. Tuck M.D. Teaching Space Fund at Columbia University, C/O Mindy Schreier at 212-304-5492.

title: Corrections
description: Amap yesterday with a front-page article about the deaths of 14 illegal immigrants in the southwest Arizona desert misstated the location of two bodies in some copies. A corrected map appears today, on Page A8.

title: Ethnic Albanians Flee Drive By Macedonia Against Rebels
description: Thousands of ethnic Albanians lagers fled on foot this week from a government offensive against rebels in the northern hills, and an additional 1,000 followed today as the bombardment continued.

title: New Threats to Cleaner Air
description: One of the more troubling proposals in President Bush's new energy plan is a directive ordering federal officials to review an important law governing air pollution from power plants and refineries. The idea, pushed hard by such energy giants as Southern and Exxon, is to see whether this law should be applied more leniently or even suspended in order to increase supplies of electricity and natural gas. But there is no good reason to ease these rules. Keeping them in place will test the resolve of Christie Whitman, the Environmental Protection Agency boss, who has already had more than her share of run-ins with the White House.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. Happy birthday, Mom. Her song has ended but the melody lingers on. Joyce, Jason, Greg, Jordana

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Optimism On The War
description: Momentum is growing toward ending the war in Congo, envoys from the United Nations Security Council said as they ended a tour of eight nations involved in fighting or trying to settle the nearly three-year-old conflict. On their last stop, in Uganda, the team of envoys heard assurances from the main rebel leader, Jean-Pierre Bemba, that he would pull back from front-line positions, and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda repeated promises to all but end military assistance to Mr. Bemba.

title: At Yale, A Discourse On Hair
description: THE New York blonde in the United States Senate went to New Haven the other day and made one of the better cases for the importance of hair since the clip job done on Samson. ''Hair matters,'' Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton told the Yale College graduating class.

title: U.N. Worries That Afghans Export Terror
description: A panel on international sanctions in Afghanistan said today that border patrols of all neighboring nations needed to be strengthened to stop the export of Islamic militancy.

title: Bothered by Drought, Andretti Returns to Indy
description: The line was long, a trail of fans with pens, pencils and markers awaiting the autograph of Michael Andretti, who sat in the front of his Gasoline Alley garage bordering the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. At the back of the garage, leaning against a wall like a man waiting for his car to come out of the shop, was Mario Andretti.

title: Students' Report of Being Strip-Searched at Jail Is Investigated
description: Nine middle school students said they were strip-searched during a visit to the city jail, prompting a federal civil rights investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNICK, CELIA
description: HARNICK-Celia. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Harnick. Loving mother of Linda Feeney and the late Joan Tepperman. Dear sister of Natalie Gluckman, cherished grandmother of Ellen and Tracey, great grandmother of Jamie and Ross. Her strength and selflessness have set an example for all of us. Service Sunday, 2PM, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, BENJAMIN C.
description: BERLINER-Benjamin C. Died peacefully at home on May 23 in Bloomfield, CT after a long illness. Born on February 1, 1917 to William and Anna Berliner, he was raised in Woodmere, L.I. where he graduated from Woodmere Academy in 1935. He went on to graduate from Yale University in 1939 and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. He completed his residency at Cincinnati Children's Hospital and embarked upon a career in pediatrics that spanned 50 years, dedicated to caring for children in need and teaching others to do likewise. He was also a world acclaimed orchidist, avid birder, devoted environmentalist, naturalist and staunch defender of human dignity. He will be missed by all who knew him. Beloved husband of Esther Ann (Skippy); brother of William, Robert and the late Herbert; father of Frank, Charles, Benjamin and Anna; grandfather of Nicholas, Samuel, Zachary, Nathaniel, Christopher and Daniel; great grandfather of little Sasha. We love you Papa Ben. Graveside funeral will be private. A memorial service is planned and will be announced at a later time. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Orchid Conservancy of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Cuttings: From Brooklyn, Advice on Taming the Wisteria
description: Afamily friend gave us a wisteria about 10 years ago, a little whip of a thing, started from seed, and we planted it by the side of the smokehouse. Some vague warning bell went off in my head, about vines lifting roofs off and such, but I ignored it. This thing was so wimpy, I doubted that it would ever bloom.

title: Sports of The Times; There's Room For Song And Fight
description: ON a dreary, rain-drenched afternoon, Mookie Wilson and family revealed three dimensions of a baseball family's life.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Investigator Charged In Killings
description: A defense investigator reportedly working under an assumed name at the United Nations tribunal into the 1994 genocide in Rwanda was arrested on charges of having taken part in the killings. The authorities say that Simeon Nshamihigo, working for defense lawyers at the tribunal in Tanzania, had been a prosecutor in southern Rwanda at the time of the genocide, in which at least 500,000 ethnic Tutsis were killed. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Court Paper Talks of 'Survivor' Impropriety
description: CBS released a previously sealed deposition yesterday that could raise more criticism of ''Survivor,'' its top-rated reality show

title: In Orange, a Sense of Betrayal After Judge Rejects Verdicts
description: After two killings and more than two years of legal wrangling, peace, it seemed, had finally come to this fraying, working-class suburb of Newark.

title: 'Wind' Book Wins Ruling In U.S.
description: The United States Court of Appeals in Atlanta overturned a preliminary injunction yesterday blocking publication of ''The Wind Done Gone,'' a novel that revisits the plantation setting of ''Gone With the Wind'' from a slave's perspective.

title: School Failed To Tell Police Of Sex Attack
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy removed an assistant principal from a Bronx school yesterday after she failed to notify the police about a sexual attack this week on two fifth-grade girls by two sixth-grade boys in a school stairwell.

title: In Masur's Bruckner, A Spacious Serenity
description: Though Kurt Masur rightfully claims an affinity for the German Romantic repertory and conducts it with authority, there can be an overly emphatic quality to his performances, especially of Beethoven and Brahms, as if he had something to prove. Yet that assertiveness disappears when he conducts Bruckner. Something in Bruckner's serene and spiritual music touches Mr. Masur and calms him in the most beneficial way.

title: War in Sierra Leone Loosens Its Grip on Child Soldiers
description: The children, 424 of them, began filling the stands in the soccer stadium this morning just before the oppressive heat blanketed this town in West Africa. Most had been brought here to the center of Sierra Leone a few days earlier, in preparation for their big day today.

title: National Briefing | Florida: Seminole Leader Suspended
description: The chairman of the Seminole tribe, James Billie, has been suspended as he faces an internal audit of the tribe's finances and a sexual harassment lawsuit by a longtime employee. Tribal council members voted unanimously on Thursday to suspend Mr. Billie, who has been chairman for 22 years. Christine O'Donnell, the former director of administration, sued Mr. Billie, 57, saying he impregnated her, forced her to get an abortion and then fired her from her job. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: The Networks Haven't Forgotten Pearl Harbor, Either
description: The Pearl Harbor special on ABC tonight at 10 closes with the image of an oil drop bubbling in the placid water above the U.S.S. Arizona, sunk 60 years ago during the bombing, with 900 men entombed inside. ''A drop rises to the surface about every 20 seconds, sad and spooky, like a message floating up from an underwater grave,'' says David Brinkley, the program's narrator.

title: Evelyn G. Haynes -- Preservationist, 92
description: Evelyn G. Haynes, a preservationist and a former member of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, died last Saturday at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: U.S. Offers Iraq Sanction List
description: American officials have given the other 14 Security Council members a list of imports that should come under surveillance as the Council moves to debate lifting restrictions on sales of civilian goods to Iraq. In addition to standard international lists of prohibited weapons, the United States has devised a list of civilian items that could have military uses, like high-powered computers and transport vehicles able to carry equipment like tanks. American officials expect the lists to be debated next week.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON FALLS. Cotton fell 4.5 percent after a report showed April demand from U.S. mills at the lowest level since 1990. In New York, cotton for July delivery fell 1.91 cents, to 40.55 cents a pound, the lowest price since 1986.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PELL, LUCY BLOW JEFFCOTT
description: PELL-Lucy Blow Jeffcott. Cotty Pell died on May 22 at the age of 82 in her house in Porto Ercole. Diagnosed with terminal cancer 20 years ago, she beat the odds as she so often did. She is survived by two sons, Peter of Glen Cove, NY, and Haven of Washington, D.C., and by five grandchildren. Cotty will be buried in Porto Ercole on Friday, May 25, and there will be no memorial service. In lieu of flowers, please take a moment to do something you might have enjoyed doing with her.

title: Stock and Bond Funds Pull In Money
description: Investors put $22.1 billion into stock and bond mutual funds in April after pulling $8.6 billion out in March, as share prices retraced most of a double-digit first-quarter slide, a research firm said.

title: National Briefing | West: Nevada: Bahraini Royal Gains Green Card
description: The member of the ruling family of Bahrain who eloped with a United States marine and then tried to sneak into this country has won her fight to stay. The woman, Meriam Al Khalifa, married Pfc. Jason Johnson, who was granted an administrative discharge from the Marine Corps in September. She was granted a green card allowing her to remain permanently in the United States, where she says she wants to study accounting at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR RISES. The dollar rose against the yen on speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon lower rates for the sixth time. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.61 yen, up from 119.84 on Thursday.

description: SCAGLIONE-Rosalie. On May 24, 2001. Loving daughter of the late Anna (nee Conroy) and Salvatore. Beloved sister of John and the late F. Michael, Sr. Joseph Maria S.C. Church, Woodside, New York.

title: 35 Arrests in Gang Inquiry
description: In what officials said was New Jersey's most comprehensive investigation of gang-related crime, 35 people were arrested on charges that they conspired to deal drugs, buy guns, rob, steal and commit murder as members of the Bloods street gang, the authorities said.
