Giuliani's estranged wife, spent yesterday preparing their legal strategy in anticipation that Mr. Giuliani would shut down the Office of First Lady and reassign Ms. Hanover's staff before the end of the day. But shortly after 5 p.m., nothing had happened.

title: Senate Shift May Reverse Region's Fortunes of Late
description: The sudden shift of power in the United States Senate from Republicans to Democrats may help bolster the fortunes of the New York region's Congressional delegation after years in which its seniority and influence declined under Republican control.

title: Russell A. Nelson, 88; Led Johns Hopkins Hospital
description: Dr. Russell Andrew Nelson, who led Johns Hopkins Hospital in a period of robust growth in the 1950's and 60's, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Naples, Fla. A former resident of Baltimore, he was 88.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Nominations
description: The Senate confirmed 54 Bush administration nominations this week, for a total of 109. Sixty-five more await Senate action. President Bush announced his intention to nominate 8 people and formally nominated 13 others.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Cellular Bid
description: A wireless venture between Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd. and the Telstra Corporation will bid for MobileOne Asia, Singapore's No. 2 cellular company, Richard Li, the chairman of CyberWorks, said. Control of MobileOne, owner of a license for faster wireless Internet access, would offer an inroad to Singapore's $1.4 billion mobile-phone market.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Bombs Kill 4 In Bogot
description: Two bombs exploded outside a university in Bogot during the morning rush hour, killing four people. President Andrs Pastrana canceled a trip to France and called a meeting of top government officials as schools closed ahead of schedule, police officers set up roadblocks and workers left their offices early. The explosions came a week after eight people died in a bombing in Medelln and four days after a bomb was deactivated in front of the Bogot office of a Communist newspaper. The authorities said right-wing paramilitaries might be to blame. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Police Dept. Reports a Rise in Applicants
description: More than 13,000 people have signed up to take the next test to become a New York City police officer, a 13 percent jump in applications since the exam was last given five months ago, officials said yesterday.

title: Devils Can Move Closer to Becoming Dynasty
description: The Devils are not yet a dynasty, even in the loose usage of the term often heard in sports. Should they win their second consecutive Stanley Cup championship -- and their third in seven seasons -- they still would not rank with the Montreal Canadiens, basketball's Boston Celtics or baseball's Yankees as franchises that dominated their sports for a decade or more.

title: The Twists of Love Never Quite Requited
description: The second installment of Marathon 2001, the Ensemble Studio Theater's annual series of one-act plays, presents a quartet of stories about skewed romantic liaisons, all of which share a degree of wicked delight in the follies of the heart.

title: A Political Quake And Its Aftershocks
description: To the Editor:

title: A Retreat on Tax Havens
description: From Antigua in the Caribbean to Nauru in the South Pacific, offshore tax havens leach billions of dollars every year in tax revenues from countries around the world. Unfortunately, the Bush administration is backing away from a three-year effort by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to crack down on tax havens. The administration's decision to withdraw American support for essential elements of the effort undermines what had been a successful international campaign.

title: O'Neal and Bryant Combine To Continue the Lakers' Roll
description: Shaquille O'Neal squared his body and grabbed the rebound. Dropping back like a quarterback, he went long, aiming for his favorite receiver.

title: Indy Finishes Second On Stewart's Race List
description: It may be unlikely, but the driver Tony Stewart, in his attempt to race in both the Indy 500 and the Coca-Cola 600 on Sunday, could interrupt his run at Indy, hopping out of the car to get to North Carolina in time for his Winston Cup start. Stewart has made it clear that racing in the Coca-Cola 600 is his priority.

title: Another Round in the Skirmish for Italy's No. 2 Utility
description: Deregulation sometimes progresses fitfully in Europe, but rarely so explosively as in a battle for Italy's second-biggest utility, Montedison, that is being fought between French and Italian business interests around lectricit de France, the French national utility, and the wily Italian investment bank Mediobanca.

title: It's Time to Pass the Torch, Powell Tells Zimbabwe's President
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today called on President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to ''submit to the law and the will of the people'' in a fair and free presidential election next year instead of clinging to power.

title: Beliefs; The president, the veteran labor priest and the makings of a 'Catholic strategy.'
description: When Msgr. George G. Higgins, speaking at Sunday's graduation ceremony at the University of Notre Dame, declared that contrary to his usual practice, he wanted to make a few extempore remarks, not a few people on the platform stiffened.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the reaction of health care industries to the new Senate leadership misstated an estimate of spending on prescription drugs by Medicare beneficiaries. The Congressional Budget Office estimate is $1.5 trillion over 10 years, not 5 years.

description: IT'S Memorial Day, so I'm thinking stars and stripes, red-and-white-checked tablecloths, picnic baskets. On my fingernails, of course.

title: Mosquitoes? Sure. Spraying? Unclear.
description: IT is two years since mosquitoes carrying an Old World disease, West Nile virus, first infected people in New York City and spread to Connecticut mosquitoes and birds. Public health experts still aren't sure why so few people have suffered from the encephalitis and meningitis the virus can cause.

title: Another Look at Craftsmen
description: Officials of Peters Valley Craftsmen, which has been struggling to retire more than $200,000 in debt, said they welcomed a decision by the New Jersey State Council on the Arts, announced last week, to seek an independent review of their request for $35,000 in emergency aid. The review will be handled by the Nonprofit Finance Fund, which evaluates the health of New Jersey arts groups and makes loans.

title: It Was a Dark and Stormy Night ...
description: The elders of Jane Street in the West Village say there may be more published authors per square foot on its five short blocks than anywhere else in the city. The street certainly has lots of writers -- see below -- and many of them will exhibit their works at a fair on the street on Saturday, from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Can your neighborhood boast of more published authors in residence than Jane Street? Count them up, and let us know, at thecity@nytimes.com.

title: Tour for the Not-So-Skittish
description: Call it stargazing for the the morbid crowd. Hollywood it's not, but this annual tour of the historic Princeton Cemetery today and next Sunday has been called the tour of ''the Westminster Abbey of America.'' So many prominent people are buried here that it has been designated a historical site ''well worth preservation'' by the Delaware River Planning Commission.

title: Time to Evaluate Russell Prospects
description: It is time for investors who dream of spotting the next Microsoft or Cisco Systems to pay attention as Wall Street sharpies place their bets on the annual revamping of the Russell indexes, which will be based on prices when the markets close on Thursday.

title: In Kenya, Powell Repeats Call for New Generation of Leaders
description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met today with Kenya's longtime president, Daniel arap Moi, and urged him to step aside and let a new president be elected next year. That repeated a message General Powell had sent to the president of Zimbabwe earlier on his African tour.

title: Every Letter Counts

title: Putting Your Faith In Science?
description: EVERYONE has heard of urban legends, stories -- like alligators in the sewers or LSD on stickers handed out to schoolchildren -- that spread around the country, repeated so often that people swear they are true. Skeptics who try to track such tales to their sources find that the grapevine that transmitted them trails off into mist.

title: Sports of The Times; For Petke, New Souvenir From Old Team
description: MIKE PETKE hung Stefan Effenberg's damp shirt in his locker, after the traditional friendly gesture of trading shirts at the end of a soccer game. The two became friends last fall when Petke trained for a week with Bayern Munich.

title: Bluegrass That Can Twang And Be Cool, Too
description: BLUEGRASS couldn't be cool, right? Backwoods banjo pickers singing about love, death, Mom and Jesus in tight tenor voices -- what could be less hip? That's why the success of the soundtrack album to ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' came as such a surprise. For reasons known only to themselves, Joel and Ethan Coen, who are not exactly famous for their warmth or sincerity, chose to accompany their cinematic retelling of Homer's ''Odyssey'' with the utterly earnest sounds of bluegrass, gospel and ''old-timey'' country. All at once, large numbers of jaded ironists (not to mention George Clooney fans) found themselves downing a stiff dose of Alison Krauss, Emmylou Harris, John Hartford, Ralph Stanley and the Cox Family, and loving it. Weeks after the film vanished from first-run theaters, the soundtrack remains one of amazon.com's best-selling pop CD's.

title: Portuguese Flavor

At ll a.m. we suddenly smelled wonderful coffee brewing, but couldn't spot a coffee shop. Our friend went into the police station nearby to ask for directions, and soon was beckoning to us. We had smelled the police station coffee, and were invited to join them for ''elevenses.''

title: Where Missiles Bristled, Making Art Instead of War
description: Leonard DiNardo is an artist who works in glass. He is also an ex-Marine who served in Vietnam for five years. Mr. Di Nardo's studio is at the top of a hill in Riker Hill Art Park in Livingston in what used to be the launch room of a Nike Missile base. In 1974 the federal government sold the 42-acre base to Essex County for $1, and the county turned it into a park. In the mid-1980's, the county decided to lease the nine former military buildings, including barracks, electronics centers, a mess hall and offices, to artists and artisans as studio space, and about 50 people now work there. Mr. DiNardo, who arrived in autumn 1985, talked about his studio.

title: Article 2001052790443909785 -- No Title
Companies Try to Make Foreign Postings Easier
description: An overseas job assignment can certainly be a career enhancer, but with it comes many challenges, especially for people who take their families along. To stay competitive, and to ease the transition, many companies have been readjusting their benefits packages, according to a survey released last week.

description: The concert jazz band from William H. Hall High School in West Hartford had been hoping for a third victory this year at a competion sponsored by Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IT was not the best picture of 2000, no matter what Oscar voters may have decided, but Ridley Scott's GLADIATOR is visually rich, from gruesome battles to scenes of Caesarean wealth. Russell Crowe plays Maximus, the Roman general whose death is ordered by an inept and generally amoral emperor (Joaquin Phoenix), who has just killed his own father. Maximus escapes, is sold into slavery and ends up in the Colosseum fighting for his life for the entertainment of the populace. Mr. Crowe won the best actor Oscar, but the film's discovery is Connie Nielsen, the Danish actress who plays the emperor's much smarter sister. As her father, in the person of Richard Harris, says: ''If only you had been born a man. What a Caesar you would have made!'' - Saturday at 9 p.m., Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:25 a.m. on HBO.

title: 'Ragtime': Broadway to Newark
description: BACK in her junior high and high school days in Monmouth County, Lynn Ahrens was still feeling her way toward a career in theater. She no doubt never could have imagined the high-profile roller-coaster ride she has been experiencing in the last couple of weeks.

title: A Bronze Age for Einstein
description: It's not often someone leaps up in a council meeting and thanks each council member for a vote, but that's what Melvin Benarde did Tuesday night after the Princeton Borough Council authorized placement of a bronze bust of Albert Einstein.

title: Winner of the Open
description: Local Jersey (of course) boy makes good. To most people, safecracking is a crime. But for Jeff Sitar of Clifton, it's a living -- and a sport. Mr. Sitar, 39, won the Lockmaster's International Safecracking Competition in St. Louis this month, his seventh title in as many tries. The challenge was to crack two safes -- without tools like electronic stethoscopes or magnifying devices -- in the shortest combined time. Mr. Sitar, owner of Superior Safe Company in Clifton, was the only competitor to open the second one (a combined time of 73 minutes). At his business, opening and repairing safes, it usually takes him 15 or 20 minutes to open one. Mr. Sitar says his senses of touch and hearing are not particularly keen. The secret: ''Patience.''

description: Long Island fourth graders continued to score higher than the state average on reading tests, but the pace of improvement slowed, according to data released this month by the state.

title: Suited for Orchard Beach
description: The Brazilian-inspired tropicalia on last year's swimwear have been replaced this summer by suits bearing fruit. Following the lead of the sellout Chlo maillot, with a pineapple strategically silk-screened on the bottom, designers are raiding the orchards and splashing their graphic harvest on bikinis, one-pieces, coverups and beach gear. In a three-cherry jackpot, bikinis by Shoshanna (bottoms for $50 and halter-style tops for $57 at Olive & Bette), Moschino ($130 at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Marc by Marc Jacobs ($158 at Barneys New York) all put the spotlight on cherries. Rosa Cha offers a white bikini ornamented with four puffy strawberry appliqus ($110), as well as a black one printed with pears, apples and bananas ($130, both at Bergdorf Goodman). And for those who could not get their hands on the popular Chlo pineapple number, Chlo's coverup T-shirts are available at Saks Fifth Avenue ($615), with butterflied sleeves and a large image of a single upright banana curving to point at the dcolletage. Now that's fresh produce.

title: A Greek Daily Based in Queens Looks to Greece For Talent
description: When a valued sportswriter and editor left Ethnikos Kirix, an 86-year-old Greek daily newspaper, two years ago, the editors sat in their office in Long Island City, Queens, and pondered the future. It was becoming difficult, said Harilaos Daskalothanassis, the managing editor, to find reporters in New York who could both speak fluent Greek and write it with flair.

title: Personal Business; When Safety Is an Option, Sticker Prices Grow
description: WITH a few exceptions, most automakers did little to promote their vehicles' safety features in the past, preferring to focus on style, performance or comfort -- the flashier side. But safety options are all the rage these days as the industry tries to capitalize on growing concerns about traffic, vehicle rollovers and tire recalls. At few times are those concerns more prevalent than during the Memorial Day weekend, as an estimated 28.5 million Americans hit the roads.

title: A Shadow Is Falling Over a Bowery Landmark

title: Sizing Up a Changed Capital
description: At first, the changed world due to arrive in Washington with a Democratic-controlled Senate may not look very different from the old. Senator Tom Daschle, soon to be majority leader, is sensibly cautioning against dramatic changes. Slowly and over time, however, the Senate's altered balance of power could bring significant progress in several areas if Democrats are selective in their fights and President Bush and the Republican Congressional leaders moderate their own positions. They should try for progress on increased school spending, energy, patients' rights and prescription drugs for the elderly, steps that could even lead to new attempts to reform Social Security and Medicare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOLEDES, NANCY NEIDHARDT
description: SCOLEDES-Nancy Neidhardt. Beloved wife of Jim Scoledes and loving mother of Amanda Scoledes, on May 25, 2001. Born in Philadelphia, PA. She was a graduate of Temple University and the City College of New York. Nancy enjoyed a career that spanned 31 years with United Airlines. Her most recent position was as Manager of Marketing, Latin America and Miami. Nancy, Jim and their daughter Amanda relocated to Miami in 1998 after having resided in Franklin Lakes, NJ for 17 years. Nancy spear-headed United Airlines extensive community involvement in the New York and South Florida communities. Nancy will be remembered for her extraordinary courage and love of life, which enriched the lives of her family, colleagues and many friends. Her indomitable spirit and integrity will be missed by all. She was predeceased by her parents Earl and Connie Neidhardt and is survived by her sister Susan (Neidhardt) and brother-in-law Steve D'Orio as well as her brother David Neidhardt and his wife Debbie, along with nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the Oncology Dept. at Mt. Sinai Cancer Center in Miami Beach, FL. Visitation will be held at Caballero Rivero Woodlawn Funeral Home (305) 238-3672, 11655 SW 117th Ave. on Monday, May 28, 2001 from 6-8 PM. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, May 29, 2001 at 10 AM in Saint Sophia Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 2401 SW 3rd Ave. Interment will be thereafter at Woodlawn Park South Cemetery, 11655 SW 117th Ave.

For Mr. Dawson is a home inspector, whose daily workplace often includes a stygian attic and dank cellar, and whose basic workaday tools are far different than a paint brush or loupe.

title: Corrections
description: A classical music listing on Page 30 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the phone number for information about a concert this afternoon by the pianist Frederic Chiu at Pro Piano Hall, 85 Jane Street in the West Village. It is (212) 206-8794.

title: Up, Down and Around Ronda
description: WE were running late the morning a friend and I drove to Ronda, a small town in Andalusia, and we had made a few wrong turns -- an inevitable occurrence in southern Spain, where one finds accurate road signs about as often as one finds a green vegetable on one's dinner plate.

title: Uncommon Talent And Common Bonds
description: Of course Martin Brodeur remembers the first time he met Patrick Roy. Brodeur was 16. His father was the photographer for the Montreal Canadiens and Roy was the team's star. Brodeur worked as his father's assistant. ''Probably my last job before playing hockey,'' Brodeur said. He was not in awe of Roy, Brodeur said, but he was ''really intrigued'' because ''meeting him in person was fun.''

title: New Airline-Owned Site To Go Online in June
description: SOMETIME next month -- it will not say precisely when -- Orbitz, the new online travel agency that is owned by the country's five largest airlines, will officially open its virtual front door for business. Then the world will finally begin to find out whether Orbitz is the Standard Oil of online travel, as its critics have charged, or just another Web site that sells airplane tickets.

title: Stop & Shop Expands To 10 Stores in County
description: Expanding its presence in Westchester to 10 outlets, Stop & Shop Supermarket Company, based in Quincy, Mass., has taken over Grand Union stores in Dobbs Ferry, Mount Kisco and Eastchester. Cindy Curran, a company spokeswoman, said there are now three Super Stop & Shop stores in the county and seven smaller stores.

title: My Life With Andre
description: FIGHTING GRAVITY

title: Condominium Tower Planned For Downtown White Plains
description: A glass condominium tower, up to 30 stories high, is planned for the former A.&P. site on Main Street in White Plains, said Paul Wood, a spokesman for Mayor Joseph M. Delfino's office. Preliminary plans by Ridgemour Development Company in Manhattan and the Meyer Companies of Palm Beach, Fla., call for up to 200 apartments adjacent to a $250 million retail, entertainment and residential complex recently announced by the developer Louis R. Cappelli. The new building would include a children's museum and a grocery store. Elsa Brenner

title: Excavating the Memories of a Generation's Horrors
description: A LONE shadow glides along the back of the stage. It is the figure of a woman in a long black dress who slowly moves forward into the light. Perhaps it is the ghost of her past, humanity's past, coming to confront the audience, to console it, admonish it and then vanish into the recesses of memory and the dust of time. The world is filled with such shadows. They call out to be remembered from the mass graves in Cambodia, Guatemala, Iraq, Rwanda, East Timor, Bosnia and Kosovo.

title: QUICK BITE/Ocean Grove; Be Nice, or the Ghosts Will Get You
description: Nagle's Apothecary Caf serves breakfast, lunch, dinner, ice cream and ghosts. When someone carved his initials, E Z, into one of the mahogany columns by the ice cream counter, the scratch was kept for posterity. A note from management was posted alongside it: ''To the person who carved their initials in this column -- we would prefer to not have your business. Also when something bad happens to you, know the spirits of this building are positive and vengeful.'' Nagle's has been some combination of pharmacy and ice cream parlor for over a century and now offers eggs, burgers, appetizers, sandwiches and salads as well as specialties like Nagel's egg cream ($1.50), cherry lime rickey ($1.50), malts ($3.75) and hand-drawn cherry Cokes ($1.75). The back of the menu is a reprint of special sales pharmacy (Kolynos toothpaste, normally 50 cents, only 34 cents; Hills Nose Drops, normally 35 cents, only a quarter; cigarettes at two packages for 25 cents), and there's an entire wall as an apothecary. For those who want to get an ice cream and stroll Ocean Grove, there is a sidewalk window. But customers frequently buy a cone and linger outside, where the names of all the pharmacists who ever worked there, along with their years of tenure, are listed on the front window. MAREK FUCHS

title: TOLL-FREE FOURTH
description: Early last week Acting Governor DiFrancesco had proposed making July 4 a toll-free day on the Garden State Parkway. But a few days later, he withdrew the proposal, saying that clearing hurdles like getting permission from the toll collectors union and holding public hearings on safety issues would take too long. The New Jersey Highway Authority projects 900,000 vehicles on the parkway on July 4, bringing in $450,000 in tolls. Anne Ruderman

title: Five Determined Students, Five Unusual Routes to a College Degree: Carthage College; Out of Africa, Ready for Anything
description: Seventeen years ago, Gabriel Carrera was a gang member with a $200-a-day drug habit, in jail for breaking and entering. Fourteen years ago, Scott Stoffel, legally blind since birth and suddenly struck deaf, attempted suicide by running onto a busy highway.

title: Championing Those Who Clean the Office Suites
description: THE screenwriter Paul Laverty was a law student in Glasgow in 1979 when he first visited the United States, going to work in a Long Island factory as part of a summer exchange program and hitchhiking across America with his brother.

title: The World; After a Bailout, a Wedding
description: A CHARMING little deconsecrated convent stands on the edge of Mexico City amid cobblestoned streets. It's the National Museum of Foreign Intervention, and it is on the site of one of Mexico's more important military defeats, at the hands of United States forces in 1847.

title: Modern Art Shows Its Age, Summoning Modern Science
description: IN the Oscar Wilde novel ''The Picture of Dorian Gray,'' a man remains forever young while his painted portrait acquires the blemishes of his increasingly dissipated life. The story exactly reverses our expectations -- that while life is a process of constant change and decay, the masterpieces of art will endure. Any conservator will tell you, however, that things are not so simple. All material objects age, so that often what you see in a museum bears little resemblance to what came out of the artist's studio: paper and silk discolor and turn brittle; painted surfaces crack and pigments darken or fade; even materials as durable as marble and bronze will change color and texture after prolonged contact with the elements.

title: Spotting Opportunity By Thinking Small
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that in a slowing economy, small-capitalization stocks underperform their larger brethren. But not this time.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Amazon.com's efforts to become profitable misidentified the Tennessee town that is headquarters to the Ingram Book Group, a distributor hired by the company to mail books directly to customers. It is La Vergne, not Laverne.

title: Carol Levy, David Bharucha
description: Dr. Carol Joan Levy, an endocrinologist, and Dr. David Behram Bharucha, a cardiologist, are to be married today in Manhattan. Rabbi David Nelson will perform the ceremony at Bridgewaters, a caterer.

title: Enough About Me
description: MY LITTLE

title: Learning History From Woman Who Made It
description: WITH its elegant campus and an average class size of 10, the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury offers a rare venue for young women to learn everything from horseback riding to history. But earlier this month, its 180 students had an even rarer opportunity: History came to them.

title: Syracuse and Princeton Earn Rematch for Title
description: Two storied teams in men's lacrosse defeated two upstarts today, Syracuse the easy way and Princeton in a down-to-the-wire finish. As a result, Syracuse and Princeton, last year's finalists and the dominant teams for more than a decade, will meet Monday morning for the N.C.A.A. championship.

title: Holiday Tomorrow: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: No Swimming? In This Chilly Weather, No Kidding
description: City health officials made two important announcements in advance of the Memorial Day weekend. But yesterday, the first day of the three-day holiday, both seemed to speak to a faraway place.

title: Editorial Notebook; A Knowing Smile on an Unknown Face
description: Earlier this month, The Toronto Globe and Mail revealed that an anonymous Canadian engineer owns a small tempera-on-wood painting passed down to him through 12 generations. The painting depicts the head of a man who is identified in barely legible script on the painting's backing as William Shakespeare in 1603, at age 39. Tests have shown that the materials in this painting, particularly the pigments and the wood, are consistent with the early 17th century. In the visage itself there is nothing remarkably inconsistent, except perhaps a little more hair, with the two most important representations of Shakespeare: the bust on his tomb in Stratford and the Droeshout engraving on the title page of the First Folio edition of Shakespeare's works.

title: PUBLIC HEALTH; County Sends Out Teams To Stop West Nile Virus
description: THEY hunt in pairs, wearing orange vests. One carries a clipboard and a pen. The other has a green shoulder satchel, with a powder blue surgical glove on one hand and a can of fluorescent spray paint in the other. Their quarry: storm drains, catch basins or any other cranny where rainwater pools, creating a nursery for mosquitoes.

title: Amy Feinstein, Seth Levin
description: Amy Feinstein, the chief assistant Brooklyn district attorney, and Seth C. Levin, a publishing consultant in Manhattan, are to be married this evening. Rabbi Steven L. Siegel will perform the ceremony at the Water Club in Manhattan.

title: Old Lifesaving Stations Offer Erosion Glimpse
description: A survey of lifesaving stations built along the South Shore during the 19th century has offered a rare glimpse of historic erosion rates along ocean beaches.

title: Sarah Savino, Colin Adams
description: Sarah Margaret Savino, a daughter of Agnes Savino and Dr. Joseph Savino of Manhasset, N.Y., is to be married today to Colin McNeill Adams, the son of Ann and Clifford Adams of San Francisco. The Rev. Joseph Schaffler is to perform the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City, N.Y.

title: A Low-Key Leader With `Steel in His Spine'
description: WASHINGTON, May 26  His tones are soothing, his language modulated. But Senator Tom Daschle is already drawing lines in the political sand, signaling his determination to show his strength as the Senate's new majority leader.

title: Political Briefing; Democratic Mileage From Energy Crunch
description: Democrats increasingly see the energy crunch not only as a national crisis but also as one of their juiciest opportunities to beat up on Republicans as the clock ticks down on next year's Congressional elections.

title: Private Sector; No Weddings and a Funeral: Mortuary's Demise on Film
description: Many funerals have been held for films buried at the box office. Now Hollywood plans a film about a funeral company buried in bankruptcy court.

title: Anne Kleinman, Thomas Wong
description: Anne Simone Kleinman, the daughter of Joan Kleinman and Prof. Arthur Kleinman of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas Wong, the son of Katherine and Harold Wong of San Jose, Calif. The Rev. Mario Marzocchi, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Our Towns; Dude, Where's Your Board? Locked in the Police Car's Trunk
description: I FEEL like a weirdo walking,'' said Kevin Schmidt, carrying his skateboard as he approached other flat-footed skaters at the Torrington Plaza shopping center, which -- in theory -- is an awesome skating spot.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article in this section last Sunday, about a writer's search for information on his great-great-grandfather, misstated the affiliation of a Brooklyn historian, Richard Rabinowitz. He is president of the American History Workshop, not the American History Project.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUBALIN, HERB
description: LUBALIN-Herb. 1918-1981. Ever loved and cherished. Rhoda Sparber Lubalin

title: Brutes on Blaring Harleys? No, Bikers on Quiet Schwinns
description: Although his thick arms and jutting beard suggest a Harley-Davidson cyclist, Roel Ortega prefers to cruise around the Bronx on his 50's-era Schwinn Jaguar. And he prefers to do so with other members of the Classics Bronx Club, a group of enthusiasts who customize vintage bicycles, mostly Schwinns from the 50's and 60's, with stereo equipment, fur and flags.

title: The Nation; Stars and Stripes for Everywhere
description: ONE of the first things American children are taught to recite mindlessly, hand to heart, is the plejavaleegence to the flag and to one nation under God invisible. It's good training. Most Americans will breeze by thousands of American flags in their lifetimes -- on wall calendars, in sale windows, on beach towels, in art museums, on clotheslines, on hankies.

title: Business; Gulf Coast Oyster Farmers Try Self-Regulation
description: IN the days before his trip to New Orleans last March, Michael Laird could not stop talking about oysters. It had been a long time since Mr. Laird, a professor at the University of Wisconsin at Whitewater, had splurged on the squishy delight of oysters, and he could barely wait to slurp down more. The very idea made his students cringe, but Mr. Laird paid them no mind. Only a select few understood the allure.

title: It Ain't Over Till You Come to the Museum
description: WHEN Yogi Berra was catching for the Yankees, Casey Stengel used to call him ''my assistant manager.'' Berra knew what hitters would swing at, and miss.

title: Name Those New Old Master Faces
description: IN the flesh, the Earl of Albemarle looked more like a young Henry VIII -- a pre-debauchery Henry VIII, to be sure -- than the ascetic Albrecht Drer, whose self-portrait he had been subsumed into. Lord Albemarle, otherwise known as Rufus, practices an air hand kiss so deft it seems coded into his genetic material. Or so he did last Monday night at the Baccarat store on Madison Avenue, where he and other titles -- a baroness and a princess, a Texan and a man named Yogi in a pink paper suit -- gathered for an art opening of sorts. Introductions zipped like bees around the room.

title: Where the Pyrenees Meet the Sea
description: MY husband, Luis, and I have returned repeatedly to the Costa Brava on the northeastern coast of Spain since our first visit some 30 years ago.

title: Courtesy Still Found Among Commuters
description: To the Editor:

title: Focused Jeter Drives Yankees Past Indians
description: Derek Jeter has access to volumes of bound scouting reports and stacks of videotapes to study whatever he needs to know about any pitcher the Yankees will face. He can draw from the knowledge of experienced coaches, and also successful and thoughtful teammates.

title: Kate Ganz, Daniel Belin
description: Kate Ganz, who owns an art gallery in New York, and Daniel N. Belin, a consultant, were married in Putney, Vt., on Friday at the home of Hester Caldwell, a Vermont justice of the peace, who performed the ceremony.

title: May 20-26; Thousands Flee in Macedonia
description: A government offensive against ethnic Albanian rebels in Macedonia's northern hills prompted thousands of ethnic Albanian villagers, many of whom had been hiding in their basements for weeks, to flee. The bombardment of Vaksince and Lojane with shelling and tank and helicopter fire came after Slavic Macedonian leaders denounced a peace deal that Albanian leaders in the government tried to broker with the rebels.

title: Portland, Ore.
description: To the Editor: We spent a few days in Portland last month.

title: Surprisingly, the Padres Make Their Mark in the Tightest Division
description: They went on the road in last place and came home in first. Their first baseman provided the punch and the power in two consecutive victories, hitting four home runs and driving in 9 of 13 runs, and then walked and stole his way to another victory in their six-game winning streak. Their starter with the most victories has the rotation's worst earned run average, and their starter with the most losses has its best.

title: Prefontaine Meet Is Start of High Season Outdoors
description: Track and field's high season begins today with the Prefontaine Classic at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., the first of several International Amateur Athletics Federation Grand Prix meets in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Jack O'Brien, director of the Broadway productions of ''The Invention of Love'' and ''The Full Monty,'' misspelled the surname of one of his mentors. He was Ellis Rabb, not Raab.

title: The World: Surprise!; Don't Try to Predict. This Is Peru.
description: PERU is the kind of place where reality never quite seems real.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY PAPERBACKS
description: FROM DAWN TO DECADENCE: 500 Years of Western Cultural Life, 1500 to the Present, by Jacques Barzun. (Perennial/HarperCollins, $20.) In canvassing the great works of the Western mind over the last 500 years, the eminent French-born scholar creates an iconoclastic gallery of profiles ranging from Mozart to Oliver Wendell Holmes Sr., reserving his gloomiest assessments for the achievements of the 20th century. Last year in the Book Review, William R. Everdell called this ''a great achievement'' that ''will surely survive to provoke and delight readers of the 21st century.''

title: Chairman Mao's Cure for Cancer
description: The use of arsenic for treating leukemias is not new, nor is it exclusively Chinese (Elisabeth Rosenthal, May 6). Arsenic trioxide (Fowler's solution) was a standard treatment for leukemia from the late 19th century until the 1950's. It was gradually displaced by radiation and chemotherapy. The 1910 Encyclopaedia Britannica mentions its use for treating Hodgkin's disease (a lymphoma), and Goodman and Gilman, the standard pharmacology textbook, mentioned its use for leukemia when I took pharmacology back in 1956. It is interesting that it is now undergoing a renaissance.

title: Keeping Up With the Gatsbys
description: Long Island didn't crack the top 10 in Worth magazine's annual list of the 250 richest communities in America, based on median house prices. But with 36 entries, it had the largest contingent in the New York City area and on the East Coast. New Jersey had 19 entries, Westchester 15 and Connecticut 10. But before you brag, consider that Connecticut's 10 communities are home to 142,970 people, according to Worth, while Long Island's 36 entries have a combined population of only 119,120. (The total for Westchester is 134,288 and for New Jersey, 114,373.)

title: Lawyers Report an Uptick in Bankruptcy Filings
description: LAST October, the Island Medical Center in Hempstead filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy law. Under a judge's guidance, the hospital's creditors formed a committee to look after their collective interests. The committee installed a new management team that specializes in turning around troubled hospitals.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Island Park; Homey, Near the Water and Within Reach
description: ON a South Shore islet just barely off the Long Island mainland, Island Park is an eminently homey place, a bit insular-feeling and, for Nassau County, still within reach for people of middle income.

title: Article 2001052791683450969 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Everly Brothers Still in Harmony
description: There are few musical moments that can beat the purity and perfection of sibling harmonies, and Don and Phil Everly's blended voices, dipped in country sugar, have been among the sweetest for over four decades. Their concerts are a pure joy, a mix of heavenly voices and some of the best-loved oldies like ''All I Have to Do Is Dream,'' ''Bye Bye Love,'' ''Wake Up Little Susie'' and so much more. They'll appear Friday at the Atlantic City Hilton and Casino. Robbie Woliver

title: The Breast Offense
description: Most surprising was the story within your story: in this country, it takes almost an act of God to persuade child-protective-service workers to remove a child from a home after neighbors or family members complain that he or she is being beaten, starved or left unattended. Yet government officials swoop in and remove a 5-year-old from his home because his mother is still nursing him and sharing a bed, as most cultures in the rest of the world do!

title: MUSIC; Making Another's Poetry His Own
description: A CALLOW peasant boy falls passionately and hopelessly in love with a sensuous Gypsy girl; he leaves home to run off with her and the child she bore him. A conventional opera plot?

title: A Festival Of Safe Bets On What Is
description: AN international film festival, like the one that concluded in Cannes last week, can offer a glimpse into the future. In an immediate sense, of course, this is always the case. The Cannes International Film Festival offers the chance to see, en masse and in advance, some of the films that will be released in the coming year -- or should be, at any rate. The pleasure a critic feels at the anticipation of sharing his favorite movies with his readers is shadowed by the knowledge that he may end up talking to himself, since the best movies may not find adequate distribution, or any at all. But hope springs eternal. The happy news that films like Danis Tanovic's ''No Man's Land'' and Jacques Rivette's ''Va Savoir'' (''Who Knows?'') -- both shown in the festival's main competition -- were picked up in Cannes by American distributors encourages some cautious optimism about the prospects of Tsai Ming-Liang's ''What Time Is It There?'' and Manoel de Oliveira's ''Vou Para Casa'' (''I'm Going Home'').

title: Document Erases Doubts About a McVeigh Witness
description: One of the newly discovered F.B.I. documents handed over to lawyers in the Oklahoma City bombing case was a report about a witness on the day of the bombing whose testimony at trial was later discredited. The witness's credibility came under attack, in part, because lawyers on both sides did not know about the document, a person familiar with the case said.

title: The Breast Offense
description: There is something seriously wrong with our cultural priorities when breast-feeding mothers like Kym Smythe fear harassment by social-service authorities but celebrities routinely attend nationally televised awards ceremonies wearing designer dresses that essentially scream, ''Look at my breasts!''

title: Fake and Bake
description: Beauty products have always been about creating illusion, but now some of them are doing it in real time. This summer, a number of self-tanning lotions have added sunscreen to their mix, thus allowing wearers to appear as though they were acquiring their golden sheen the natural way. Self-Tanning Milk by Clarins ($24.50 at Bergdorf Goodman), Fluide AutoBronzant by L'Occitane ($24 at Barneys New York) and Natura Bisse's self-tanning cream ($47 at Barneys New York) all chemically activate that healthy-looking glow while warding off unhealthy rays. Self-tanners for the face by Orlane ($75 at Saks Fifth Avenue) and Declor ($35 at Sephora) add both sunblock and ingredients intended to guard against wrinkles. And aprs-sun, tinted moisturizers from Laura Mercier ($38) and Paula Dorf ($34, both at Henri Bendel) are throwing in SPF 20 levels, along with instant temporary color. Just apply evenly and sparingly -- and don't forget to wash your hands.

title: Ethical Humanism: Religion Without God
description: A RELIGION without God? Though some people might dismiss that as an impossibility, for the 250 members of the Ethical Humanist Society in Garden City, that concept is not just a possibility but a solid foundation for building a life.

title: Private Sector; The Pen Is Mightier Than the G.D.P.
description: Montblanc has been marketing its luxury line of writing instruments, a k a pens, for 95 years, mostly to men. Now it is reaching out to women, with a new Bohme line of pens, a handbag collection and plans to double the number of its United States stores to 48 in a year. If the timing of such an expansion sounds economically ill-advised, it doesn't seem to worry Norbert A. Platt, the company's president and chief executive.

title: Five Determined Students, Five Unusual Routes to a College Degree: University of Hartford; Leaving the Old Gang, Starting a New Life
description: Seventeen years ago, Gabriel Carrera was a gang member with a $200-a-day drug habit, in jail for breaking and entering. Fourteen years ago, Scott Stoffel, legally blind since birth and suddenly struck deaf, attempted suicide by running onto a busy highway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEWELL, DANNY (DENNIS EDWARD)
description: SEWELL-Danny (Dennis Edward). On May 18, 2001. An Obie Award-winning actor for ''The Homecoming,'' he was the original Bill Sikes in the West End and Broadway productions of ''Oliver!'' Always deeply loved and always remembered by his wife, Donna; his four children, Laura, Daniel, George and Andrew; his brother, George; their families and his many friends. Memorial celebrations in New York and London this summer. The world is a lot less colorful without him.

title: Holding a Door Open for the Man Who Wants to Mind His Manners
description: WHEN a gentleman is ordering from a florist with whom he has had difficulties in the past, he does not say:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, CARMELA BARBUTO
description: GRIFFIN-Carmela Barbuto. 72, of Marina Del Rey, CA, a former resident of Manhattan and Wallingford, CT, died Thursday, May 24, 2001, in the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles. She was the wife of John I. Griffin, a retired dean of Baruch College and Fairfield University; and the mother of John M. Griffin, a documentary filmmaker in Los Angeles. She held a bachelor's degree in education from Central Connecticut State University and her master's degree in library science from Columbia University. She worked as a librarian and administrator for the New York Public Library for ten years. She also served as a reference librarian for the American Association of Advertising Agencies, and as assistant to the chief librarian at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. Later she obtained a position at the Andrew Mellon Library of Choate Rosemary Hall, and became head of technical services at the Wallingford Public Library, where she worked for eight years. Her family will receive relatives and friends in the Wallingford Funeral Home, 809 North Main St Extension, Wallingford, Tuesday, May 29, 2001, from 5 to 9 PM. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, at 9:30 AM, from the Wallingford Funeral Home, when the funeral cortege will procede to Most Holy Trinity Church, Wallingford, for a Mass of Christian Burial at 10:30 AM. Graveside services will be Wednesday, at 2 PM, in Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. Gifts in memory of Carmela Griffin may be sent to the Wallingford Public Library, 200 North Main St, Wallingford, CT 06492.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIFER, SIDNEY A.
description: LAIFER-Sidney A. The Officers, Trustees, Clergy and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Penske Back at Indy, Stronger Than Ever
description: Roger Penske had built an international automotive empire, but in 1995, for all his rental trucks, service centers and engine accessories worldwide, Penske could not qualify a car for the race that mattered most, the Indianapolis 500. It was a shocking failure for a man whose cars had won 10 Indy 500's, and Penske understood the ramifications immediately.

title: Company Links Kayak Trips To the History of the Hudson
description: When Mark Mykytyn leads kayak trips down the Hudson, he focuses as much on Washington Irving as on how to hold a paddle. His approach reflects the philosophy of Hudson River Recreation, a company that leads guided kayak tours out of New Rochelle, Nyack and Sleepy Hollow.

title: Sentenced in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitching a Ride
description: Lawrence of Arabia had it easy. He only had to cross the Sahara on horseback. If he had come to Wildwood in the summer -- chairs, umbrella, towels, cooler and children in tow -- he would have had to trudge more than a quarter-mile on burning sand from the Boardwalk to the ocean.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPPMAN, BERT J.
description: LIPPMAN-Bert J. 20 years ago today you left us. We think about you and miss you every day. You are always in our hearts. Ruth, Jane, Robin, Chuck, Stefan, Jessica and Bradley

title: The Nation; Taxes: Can't Live With 'Em, Can't Live Without 'Em
description: CONGRESS agreed last week to cut taxes by $1.35 trillion over the next 11 years, and President Bush could hardly wait to put his signature on the legislation.

title: Where the Kitchen Is Mostly a Men's Club
description: BOTH as a woman and as a cook, I am irritated by Bobby Flay's show on the Food Network. It is not the recipes, which are fun and exciting to make. It is not his wisecracking group of friends -- the butcher, the baker and the fishmonger -- who provide interesting bits of trivia about food. It is not even the smug Mr. Flay, whom I consider a genuinely creative cook. No, what bothers me about the show, ''Hot Off the Grill With Bobby Flay,'' is the dynamic between Mr. Flay and his sidekick, Jacqui Malouf.

title: And It's All To the Good
A Battle Plan for the Democrats
description: It's striking and for us Democrats, embarrassing -- that it took a Republican to unmask the Bush agenda. When Jim Jeffords quit the G.O.P., he spoke powerful truths about the truly radical nature of what President Bush is trying to achieve. Too many in our party have been sleepwalking as George W. Bush has audaciously sought to deny the federal government the money and the power to have a positive effect on people's lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, BENJAMIN C.
description: BERLINER-Benjamin C. Died peacefully at home on May 23 in Bloomfield, CT after a long illness. Born on February 1, 1917 to William and Anna Berliner, he was raised in Woodmere, L.I. where he graduated from Woodmere Academy in 1935. He went on to graduate from Yale University in 1939 and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1942. He completed his residency at Cincinnati Children's Hospital and embarked upon a career in pediatrics that spanned 50 years, dedicated to caring for children in need and teaching others to do likewise. He was also a world acclaimed orchidist, avid birder, devoted environmentalist, naturalist and staunch defender of human dignity. He will be missed by all who knew him. Beloved husband of Esther Ann (Skippy); brother of William, Robert and the late Herbert; father of Frank, Charles, Benjamin and Anna; grandfather of Nicholas, Samuel, Zachary, Nathaniel, Christopher and Daniel; great grandfather of little Sasha. We love you Papa Ben. Graveside funeral will be private. A memorial service is planned and will be announced at a later time. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Orchid Conservancy of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: May 20-26; Taliban Troubles
description: Afghanistan's Taliban militia have long seemed in need of some good public relations advice, though never more than this year. As spring crops burst through the soil, it seemed clear that Mullah Muhammad Omar's ban on poppy production was a success. Afghanistan, recently responsible for 75 percent of the world's opium production, had eradicated the plant. But just as the Taliban were due for some good publicity, they demolished two priceless Buddhist statues and then, last week, ordered the nation's few Hindus to wear distinctive badges that reminded many international critics of the gold star imposed on Jews by the Nazis. Barry Bearak

title: Emily Leong, Peter Yu Jr.
description: Emily Wai Sum Leong and Peter Yu Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas N. Synan at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: If You Close Your Eyes and Listen, It's Like Being in Louisiana
description: RED barns and red beans and rice. Cool spring breezes and steamy Cajun love songs. While few would compare Eastern Connecticut with Southwest Louisiana, the Cajun and zydeco music recently played in Preston was as heartfelt, appreciated and, yes, authentic as anything in Gulf Coast dance halls.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 13 about the Chicago lakefront referred incorrectly to the North Avenue Beach House on Lake Michigan. The house, with red smokestacks resembling those of an Art Deco ocean liner, was rebuilt completely in 1998 and 1999, not renovated in 1999.

title: Trash Museum Is, Um, Trashed
description: This is a story about trash, or more precisely, a museum of trash and its uncertain future in this sleepy Warren County town.

title: POSTING: Above a Movie House in Jersey City; St. George And Dragon To Fight Again

title: Women of China, Chasing Their Impossible Dreams
description: ZHANG YIMOU'S new movie, ''The Road Home,'' is a simple, sentimental love story -- told in a long, richly colored flashback from the perspective of the drab, black-and-white present -- about a young girl who falls for the schoolteacher in her rural Chinese village. In the middle of their shy, almost wordless courtship, the teacher is called away to the city because of unspecified political trouble. The girl, played by Zhang Ziyi, has prepared him a breakfast of dumplings, and when he does not show up to eat them she chases after him, running across the hills clutching a covered porcelain bowl. Her beloved is a long way up the road, riding in the bed of a farmer's truck, and it appears objectively impossible that she will ever catch up with him. She doesn't, but her single-minded ferocity creates a momentary suspension of disbelief. Well, you think, maybe a teenage girl with a bowl of dumplings can chase down a vehicle with a half-mile head start. After all, this is a Zhang Yimou film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERTKOV, DR. LISA
description: CHERTKOV-Dr. Lisa. Of New York City, on May 23 at age 38. The winner of the AMES award and the Hoopes Prize, she was a 1985 magna cum laude graduate of Harvard University and a 1994 graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. She completed a dual residency in Internal Medicine and Psychiatry at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in 1999 and was just finishing a fellowship in Psychiatry at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Her life was dedicated to ensuring that her patients received the highest quality care and she will be sorely missed-both as a care provider and advocate for change in our healthcare system. Parents Lynn and Boren, his wife Ann, brother Evan, his wife Cheryl and his daughter Taylor and sons James and Robert, grandmothers Frieda Schoonmaker and Ruth Chertkov, and many friends mourn a cherised women who lived life to its fullest and who deeply cared for all whose paths crossed hers. A light has passed from our lives and we will miss her spirit, her passion and her laughter. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, May 30, 2001 at 12:45 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. (at Amsterdam Ave.) NYC. The interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: Family Learning Solutions, 2403 Esther Court, Silver Spring, Maryland 20910, C/O Dr. Lore Melman.

title: The Prom Date
description: In ''Songcatcher,'' an independent movie nominated for best film in this year's Indie awards, Emmy Rossum, 15, plays an Appalachian orphan who sings Scotch-Irish ballads. In ''Passionada,'' which is now shooting, she's a tough-talking Portuguese biker chick. But on June 7, she will appear in a real-life spectacle -- her first high school prom. For the big event with a date who is graduating from the Collegiate School, Ms. Rossum covered all of this year's prom trends, including vintage looks and mixing silver with gold. ''I really wanted to wear couture,'' she said, ''but I knew I could only afford it by buying secondhand.'' At Michael's, a consignment shop on Madison Avenue, she found a short, flouncy Vicky Tiel dress for $544, with a nude lace bodice studded with rhinestones and seed pearls. ''You think you can see through it, but you can't,'' Ms. Rossum said. ''I call it Jennifer Lopez does 'Swan Lake.' '' To complete the prima doll erina look, Ms. Rossum chose a pair of Stuart Weitzman shoes of oyster silk and crystal ($205) and a matching evening bag ($225). She plans to wear a ''permanent corsage'' made from a gold silk flower pin ($68, from Henri Bendel) attached to an old silver Tiffany bracelet, along with a skinny rhinestone headband. As for what she will don for the after party, she is still undecided. ''It's not going to be a long postprom for me, anyway,'' said Ms. Rossum, who has to be back on the set in Massachusetts the next day. ''They actually put in my contract that I have to be in a car at 3 a.m. driving back. Which kind of stinks, but, hey, I'm working.''

description: Tasted blind, Chateau Benoit's genial '00 riesling, from the Willamette Valley in Oregon, might fool Germanophiles into thinking it came from the Mosel, a riesling Eden.

description: Emily Claire Hoffman, a daughter of Dale and Stephen Hoffman of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married this evening to Brian Scott Stern, a son of Linda and Allan Stern of Westport, Conn. Rabbi Mark S. Golub will officiate at the Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Caring Till It Hurts
description: AS a hospital patient, you have the right to qualified, alert and dedicated nurses and other caregivers at your bedside. But these days you may be cared for by a nurse working her 16th hour, looking after 10 or more patients at a time.

title: He Just Wins, and Wins
description: In September 1999, Phil Jackson closed up his home in Montana for the winter, packed up some clothes and embarked on the long drive to Los Angeles, where the Lakers and his new life awaited.

title: P.S.
description: Sushi Jones's new Summer Bar B-Q package is for urban weekenders who don't flip over burgers. Seaweed-and-rice-wrapped hand rolls hold summer flavors like spicy grilled tuna, blackened yellowtail, roasted maple salmon, shrimp cocktail, barbecued chicken and grilled vegetables with goat cheese. More classic rolls are also available, along with sushi, sashimi, side salads, Japanese gourmet chips and dips, sake and dessert platters. And don't forget peanut-butter-and-jelly maki pinwheels -- rolled in white bread -- for the kids. Prices range from $6.75 to $15.75 a person, depending on the choices, with a six-person minimum. From Sushi Jones, 17 East 17th Street, (212) 406-2900.

title: G.O.P. Issues Warning
description: As the Senate prepares for power to shift to the Democrats, Republicans say the 50-49-1 makeup requires special rules and warn of procedural deadlock unless they receive assurances that the president's nominees will be brought up for votes.

title: Complications
description: After four years on dialysis, with no sign that he was nearing the top of the transplant waiting list, Moshe Tati decided to buy a kidney. This was easier than he had imagined. Several months previous, the name and telephone number of an organ broker had been passed, furtively, around his dialysis group. At the time, Moshe did not think he would use the telephone number. He thought he would wait.

title: A Study Dares to Question the 401(k)
description: AT a time when Congress is considering raising the annual investment limits on 401(k) plans, to $15,000 from $10,500, a new study suggests that many people should invest less, or not at all. For some low- to moderate-income workers, investing in these tax-deferred retirement accounts may actually raise their taxes and reduce the amount of money they have available to spend over their lifetimes.

title: A Driver's History of Modern Europe
description: AGOSTINI AUTO must be one of the most beautifully situated used-car dealerships in the world. The combined garage, showroom and body shop lies at the foot of the steep slope leading up to Todi, a picturesque medieval hill town that is one of the jewels of Umbria in central Italy.

title: Power Takes On Hamm, and the Challenge of Extra Fans
description: There is only one reason for the New York Power to arrange shuttle buses today from the Mineola railroad station on Long Island to the Mitchel Athletic Complex in Uniondale. Mia Hamm must be coming to town.

title: Tom Watson of Old Appears And Makes Third-Round Run
description: As his final putt of the day made the 45-foot journey across the green, it was almost as if Tom Watson had journeyed back in time. After the ball disappeared into the cup, Watson lifted his cap, smiled broadly and celebrated one of the best five-hole runs of his legendary career.

title: Their Future in the Balance, They Dance for High Stakes
description: THE workshop performances of the School of American Ballet are its rites of spring. Held about this time every year, they are showcases for the New York City Ballet academy's advanced students, and, like the overblown scenes they inspired in the film ''Center Stage,'' they attract an excitable insider audience -- the performers' teachers, families and fellow students as well as school alumni and aficionados. But for the teenage dancers, there is a target audience: the representatives of City Ballet and other companies who may offer them jobs.

title: DataBank; Cooling Housing Market Chills Stocks
description: Most stocks retreated last week as a fresh set of economic data showed further weakness in the economy.

description: Seventeen years ago, Gabriel Carrera was a gang member with a $200-a-day drug habit, in jail for breaking and entering. Fourteen years ago, Scott Stoffel, legally blind since birth and suddenly struck deaf, attempted suicide by running onto a busy highway.

description: A list of American casualties from the stand-off with China over a downed EP-3E surveillance plane includes: 24 crew members, detained, now safely home. Their aircraft, which the Chinese have insisted must be disassembled and sent back in boxes. United States-China military exchanges, to be reviewed case-by-case. Diplomatic relations, prognosis uncertain.

description: The artists of the Hudson River School became famous in the 19th century for their romantic images of nature and wilderness, especially along the Hudson River Valley from the Adirondacks to Long Island Sound. Then time moved on, and their old stomping grounds became largely overlooked.

description: The article in our medical issue on a mother who breast-feeds her 4-year-old twins drew appreciative mail. Many readers said that the Massachusetts governor, who is expecting twins, could do more for working families.

title: Family Resort
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''Family Resort in France'' (Q & A, March 18): Pierre et Vacances was not mentioned. Given that it has 21 resorts on the Cte d'Azur and Provence and 35 total in the south of France, it provides a wide choice, both geographically and in terms of the type, level and comfort of accommodation. All are family-oriented and many have Club Enfants. Unlike Club Med, however, participation in the children's clubs will cost a supplement to the basic rental fee.

title: The Olsen Juggernaut
description: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, 14, are on the ground floor of Fred Segal on Melrose Avenue in their hometown, Los Angeles. They have just finished trying on clothes and are in the process of reviewing their potential purchases with Jill Zimmerman, 31, their friend, former on-set nanny and currently an executive in their company, Dualstar Entertainment Group. They are fraternal twins, not identical, but facially similar enough that if you see them side by side -- at, say, a table read for ''So Little Time,'' their coming sitcom, which makes its debut on June 2 on the Fox Family Channel -- you might have more than a little trouble telling them apart. Sitting still and silent, their eyes downcast, concentrating on their scripts, they have the slightly spooky, supernatural and solemn beauty of a Diane Arbus photograph. Their individual allure is not so much doubled by their twinship as amplified, as if they were drawing on some different light source than anyone else in the room.

title: Cheryl Henson, Edwin Finn Jr.
description: Cheryl Lee Henson, a daughter of the puppeteers Jane Henson of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Jim Henson, was married yesterday to Edwin Anthony Finn Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Finn Sr. of South Grafton, Mass. The Rev. Roger Ferlo, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Luke in the Fields in New York.

description: Dr. Carol Joan Levy, an endocrinologist, and Dr. David Behram Bharucha, a cardiologist, are to be married today in Manhattan. Rabbi David Nelson will perform the ceremony at Bridgewaters, a caterer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANSEN, HARRIET C.
description: HANSEN-Harriet C. On May 24, 2001 into her 93rd year. Widow of the late Norbert C. Hansen. Survived by her sister Barbara Cox Emeny, her daughter Leanne Hansen Demarest, her son Stephen C. Hansen and her grandchildren Lee C. Hansen and William and Timothy Taft. Educated at Ethel Walkers and in Florence, Italy. She was a lifelong resident of New York. A prominent interior decorator. Engaged in many charitable and civic endeavors. Chaired a committee for the National Society of Colonial Dames. Dedicated to the preservation of the Van Cortlandt House Museum. Private interment Locust Valley Cemetery. Memorial service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church on 73rd Street, NYC, on Friday, June 1 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Van Cortlandt House Museum C/O NSCD, 215 E. 71 St., NY, NY 10021

title: Work on New Power Plant Begins After Final Approval
description: After receiving final approval late Friday, work began today on a power plant 30 miles south of here, beginning a new generation of power plant construction in a state whose demand for electricity is rising fast.

title: Through-the-Roof House Prices
description: Not too long ago $1 million bought the best in just about any housing market in the country. In many affluent communities today it barely covers a starter home.

title: Laura Krouner, Steven Paradise
description: Laura Jill Krouner, a daughter of Barbara J. Krouner of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Martin Krouner of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Steven Charles Paradise, a son of Camille and Robert Paradise of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. James Borstelmann, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Rabbi Alfred Sturmer at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: 147 Cellists in Need of a Repertory
description: PUT seven cellists in a room together, and you get a keen debate about the virtues of bent endpins (as opposed to straight ones), gut strings (as opposed to steel) and new developments in pizzicato technique. Put 147 cellists on a stage, and you get ''Rapturedux,'' a piece by the American eclectic Christopher Rouse. (Influences: Bruckner, Berlioz and Led Zeppelin.) And when ''Rapturedux'' had its premiere here recently, it provided a numerically impressive if sonically impenetrable climax to five days of talking, playing, learning and exposure to a cavalcade of virtuosity that was the Manchester International Cello Festival, directed by Ralph Kirshbaum in its seventh biennial season.

title: Pamela Balbach, Willis Ryckman IV
description: Pamela Rae Balbach, a daughter of Janet and George A. Balbach of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Willis Garson Ryckman IV, a son of Lois G. Hitchings of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Mr. Ryckman III of Stamford, Conn.

title: LIVES; Swept Away
description: I just graduated from Hoisington High School in Kansas. Some of the smarter kids will go to a university and stuff, but mostly it'll be a tech college or a junior college. It's a nice town. It's quiet, and nothing really ever happens. I didn't think about the prom that much until about a month before. My girlfriend, Amy, and I have been together for a year, so it was just kind of set in stone we were going to go. Most ladies want the prom to be a night they'll never forget. And, well, some of them got one.

title: Waterhouse Group Sets Up Shop in Mount Kisco
description: What prompted a financial services firm to set up shop in a storefront in downtown Mount Kisco, amid stores like Banana Republic, Sam Goody's and, most recently, Victoria's Secret? For TD Waterhouse Group Inc., the decision was deliberate, said a company spokeswoman, Melissa Gitter.

title: Reopening the Case of the Mute Civilization
description: IT is 400 years since the Etruscans were rediscovered by Renaissance Florence, 200 years since ''Etruscomania'' gripped English travelers on their grand tour of Italy, and still an aura of mystery surrounds the civilization that prospered in northwestern Italy between 950 and 300 B.C. For many art historians, however, all this romanticism has gone a tad too far. ''The Etruscans,'' a major exhibition at the Palazzo Grassi here through July 1, sets out to demonstrate that there really is no such enigma.

Some vague warning bell went off in my head, about vines lifting roofs off and such, but I ignored it. This thing was so wimpy, I doubted that it would ever bloom.

title: May 20-26; Sharpton Jailed
description: They've been dubbed the Vieques Four, the Rev. Al Sharpton and three of New York's most prominent Puerto Rican politicians who were unexpectedly jailed by a federal judge in San Juan for their role in a nonviolent protest near the Navy's practice bombing ranges on the island of Vieques. Mr. Sharpton got the stiffest sentence, 90 days; the others got 40 days. All four were transferred to a federal prison in Brooklyn and are appealing the decision. Eric Lipton

title: Inner Harbor
description: To the Editor: Scott Norvell's recounting of his family's trip to Baltimore, ''Inner Harbor, Family Style'' (Frugal Traveler, April 29), evoked memories of a visit 15 years ago. A highlight was the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Museum at 901 West Pratt Street, (410) 752-2490, www .borail.org. I hope that I will make a return visit in 2002 for the museum's festivities in honor of the 175th anniversary of railroading in America.

title: Emerging From the Swamp, All Slick and Shiny
description: EVEN in its heyday, the Swamp never inspired much rapture. Unlike legendary hot spots like Studio 54 or the Mudd Club in Manhattan, the Swamp, the Hamptons' longest running nightclub, isn't the sort of place that hipsters speak about in reverential tones.

title: The Breast Offense
description: Some women have learned to deflect the question ''When are you going to stop nursing?'' with a humorous reply -- something like, ''Oh, in about five minutes'' or ''As soon as he can phone to order takeout.'' The bottom line is that the decision when to wean is up to the individual and should not be a matter of public censure, legality or concern.

title: Irish lands open
description: Having battened down the hatches for 10 long weeks while foot-and-mouth disease ravaged Britain, the Irish are finally breathing easily again. The country managed to escape with just one incident of the disease -- on a remote peninsula -- and is now desperately eager to get on with summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMARY, ERNEST J. CONG
description: TAMARY-Ernest J. Cong. Hope of Israel and its Sisterhood share the grief of our devoted member, Dora Kesten, in the unexpected loss of her son. May his soul find its true resting place amongst the elders of Zion and Israel.

title: Lloyd Shearer, Longtime Celebrity Columnist, Dies at 84
description: Lloyd Shearer, a Hollywood fixture whose Personality Parade column in Parade magazine reached as many as 50 million readers in its heyday, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 84.

title: Hindsight and the Eye of the Beholder
description: WHEN pundits or professors talk about political courage, they often mean some politician has taken a chance with the voters for something the commentator believes in. Consider, for example, the praise heaped on Senator James M. Jeffords by writers who endorsed Democrats last fall. In this case, the risk is not severe. Vermonters seem to like his independence.

title: At 158 Years and Counting, A German Paper Pushes On
description: It is not easy these days for a German-language newspaper to survive in New York. The immigrants it once served have moved or been assimilated. But for The New Yorker Staats-Zeitung, which calls itself the world's oldest German newspaper, recent troubles have made its existence even more tenuous.

title: FOOTNOTES
description: 1. The other Sam Phillips.2. The Sam Phillips who presided over the birth of rock 'n' roll loves his ''gutbucket blues.'' Sun started as a blues label, recording black artists with no opportunity to play anywhere else. ''Some of them had never seen a microphone before,'' Sam says. Without Sam, no Little Milton, no Howlin' Wolf and no Junior Parker, whose ''Mystery Train'' was an Elvis cover tune, a rock book and a 1989 cult film by Jim Jarmusch that Vincent Canby said had ''the kick of a controlled substance.'' Yeah, like Seconal.

title: British Lean Toward Blair, But His Glow Is Long Gone
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair is widely expected to win the June 7 British election in a walk, but his progression toward the predicted large mandate for a second term is proving to be more a slog than a victory lap.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-27-01: The Ethicist; The Race Way
description: A former colleague is African-American, I'm Caucasian and we often discuss race. What I never told my friend is that when he was hired, his race was considered over and above his experience and competence. More than one manager told me they hired him to 'diversify' the all-white office. It disturbs me to keep this secret from my friend. Should I tell him? T.L., Boston

title: A Spectre Eases Its Grip in Britain
description: AT around noon most days, the throng around Buckingham Palace thickens as hundreds of tourists, many from overseas, gather to watch liveried guards on horseback enter the palace grounds. Not too far away, the London Eye -- the gigantic, slow-motion Ferris wheel on the banks of the River Thames -- turns languorously, lofting passengers high above the city. Video cameras purr, shutters click and the people who make a living from Britain's $90 billion tourist business breathe a sigh of relief.

title: A Pair of Unlikely Visitors Waddle Onto a Busy City Street
description: Maria Terrone was crossing 75th Street at 37th Avenue recently when she came across an arctic bird on a boulder. ''It seemed kind of incongruous,'' she said. ''Why is there a penguin in Jackson Heights?''

title: As Whistle Blows for M.T.A., Stores Fear for Future
description: Every weekday at noon, lines of hungry people descend on Luther's Fried Chicken at Jay and Willoughby Streets.

title: First Tour in a While Is Also a Last One
description: IT was America that first set the seal of approval on the Royal Ballet's international reputation. That was more than 50 years ago, and the love affair between Britain's premier company and the United States has continued ever since. Down the decades, the Royal has made fewer regular trans-Atlantic jaunts, but it is about to set that right with two weeks of performances in Washington and Boston. This is not just another visit: it holds a special significance because it will be the last under Anthony Dowell, who is retiring after 15 years as the company's artistic director.

title: In San Diego, Eating Well Not Far From the Sea
description: UNTIL five or six years ago, the notion of going to San Diego for fine dining was like heading to Oklahoma for a vineyard tour. For all of its physical beauty, myriad nautical attractions and spectacular growth (it is now the second largest city in California), it couldn't shake its image as a glorified Navy port.

title: Expecting Big Things
description: I find it ironic that Jane Swift's husband is the primary caregiver in the family, when the parental-leave law in Massachusetts applies only to women. As someone who has landed in hot water for asking her staff to baby-sit, Swift can do better by her constituents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUDMAR, MILTON
description: LUDMAR-Milton. Dear dad, on this, the eighth year since your passing, all my thoughts and prayers are with you. I am honored to have had you as my dad. I miss you a lot. Love, Scott

title: Inflation's Uptick Clouds Outlook for the Bond Market
description: INFLATION is not about to take off. A 5 percent annual rise in the Consumer Price Index is not in the cards. But there are troubling signs of rising costs that are casting a pall over the bond market for the second half of the year.

title: A Love of the Sport Continues
description: DESPITE a devastating motorcycle accident three years ago at the Milford Rider's Club track that left him paralyzed from the neck down, 41-year-old Richard Ruesch said the first thing he would do if he were cured would be to jump back on his bike and start riding again.

title: Canyon Air Tours From Las Vegas Curbed
description: The routes of two sightseeing flights between Las Vegas and the Grand Canyon were changed last month by the Federal Aviation Administration, which acted to reduce noise and improve safety at the canyon, according to officials. The new flights still follow the meandering course of the Colorado River, but they now hew closer to the western edge of the park, away from the central portions of the canyon that include the Havasupai Indian Reservation on the canyon floor.

title: Gilder, a Rookie at 50, in a Dream Come True
description: PARAMUS, N.J., May 26  For Bob Gilder, turning 50 years old has been a reason to celebrate.
