description: To the Editor:

title: May 20-26; French Whines
description: On May 26, 1976 -- just 25 years ago -- a group of unknown California wines went up against a battery of France's best at a blind tasting in Paris -- and won the day.

title: BRIEFING: LABOR; PRINCETON WORKERS
description: In response to months of protests by workers and students, Princeton University announced last week that it would provide about $400,000 to increase salaries of its lowest-paid workers next year. The money will subsidize salaries of workers in the university's janitorial and dining services, and perhaps to library assistants and secretarial workers, according to the Princeton Workers' Rights Organizing Committee, which had said wages should be at ''market rate.'' The janitors now are paid $11.72 an hour and the dining workers get $10.57. How the university money will be distributed will be worked out with the service employees' union. Nathan Kitchens

title: BackTalk; Family Values Challenging the Game
description: EIGHT years ago, a Houston Oilers lineman, David Williams, missed a regular-season National Football League game to be with his wife at the birth of their first child. Feminists hailed him as the quintessential ''liberated man'' in those waning moments of thinking that the term could have some real meaning. Traditionalists were silent; Williams was a football player so they couldn't accuse him of being a henpecked sissy.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for GORDON E. MOORE; Technology Intensifies the Law of Change
description: GORDON E. MOORE and Robert N. Noyce co-founded Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957 and, a decade later, they co-founded the Intel Corporation. In a paper Mr. Moore published in Electronics Magazine in 1965, he articulated the concept that underpins what has become known as Moore's Law: the power of a silicon chip will double every 18 to 24 months, accelerating the pace of technological change.

title: Expecting Big Things
description: In Questions for Jane Swift (Rory Evans, April 29), the governor claims that the ''realities'' of her life (mother of a 2-year-old and pregnant with twins) help her understand issues that Massachusetts families face. However, she has proposed a measure that would force welfare recipients with children ages 2 to 5 to work at least 20 hours a week. Her own reality most likely includes a nanny, while poor families on welfare face the reality of below-standard child care.

title: May 20-26; A Crowd at World's Top
description: In a burst of ascents before the end of the Himalayan climbing season, 94 people made it to Mount Everest's summit, including the first blind climber ever to do so, Erik Weihenmeyer, 32, of Golden, Colo., and the oldest man, Sherman Bull, 64, of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEARER, LLOYD
description: SHEARER-Lloyd. The staff of Parade magazine mourns the loss of a friend and colleague. For more than three decades (1958-1991), Parade editor-at-large Lloyd Shearer educated, entertained and informed millions of Americans through one of the best-read and enduring columns in magazine history: ''Walter Scott's Personality Parade.'' Using that famous pseudonym, Shearer raised gossip to a fine art and was considered the authority on world-wide celebrity. He brought us the very latest in the King of rock-n-roll to the Queen of England-and everyone in between. He was also the author of Parade's weekly ''Intelligence Report,'' another favorite that continues today. His work helped define the magazine and made a mark on America. We will miss him. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Marva, his children and grandchildren. Walter Anderson, Publisher

title: The Breast Offense
description: Many pediatricians tell us to buckle up our children and to immunize them but look upon nursing as a choice and do little to encourage what is clearly the superior food for infants. Part of the problem is that formula companies do their best to encourage doubt in new mothers (by sending free samples and damning advice) and ambivalence in physicians (by providing incentives and funding).

title: The Swiss Celebrate A Heidi Centennial
description: Since she was created in two volumes of stories by Johanna Spyri in 1880-81, Heidi has been a symbol of the Swiss Alps and a magnet pulling tourists to Switzerland. This year her attraction may be stronger than ever, with a series of events commemorating the centennial of Spyri's death on July 7.

title: Portuguese Flavor
description: To the Editor: Your article did not mention the lovely 27-hole Madeira Golf Course in the northeastern part of the island near Funchal. My husband and I decided to play there. The course, over 2,000 feet above sea level in a lush mimosa forest, was in excellent shape. We were able to rent clubs and the services of a caddy. We found the greens fees quite reasonable by American standards. A modern clubhouse and a restaurant were also on the premises.

They've all got it.''

title: 10 MOST THREATENED
description: Traffic is threatening the borough of Allentown in Monmouth County; the Bergen Arches, which carry traffic across a massive railroad cut in the Palisades in Jersey City may be destroyed; and the Colonial-revival Cliffside Park Post Office could be demolished, according to Preservation New Jersey, which announced the 10 most endangered historic sites in the state last week. Other sites on the list are Camp Glen Gray; Roosevelt Hospital in Edison, built during the Depression as the Middlesex County Tuberculosis Sanatorium; the Jockey Hollow section of Morristown National Historical Park, encroached by surrounding development; Kip's Castle estate, built in Verona in 1902; the Trap Rock quarry stone houses in Franklin Township; the Flemington Fairgrounds, opened in 1856; and the remaining grand shore hotels like the Essex and Sussex in Spring Lake and Congress Hall in Cape May. But less than a year after their emotional participation in the 2000 Sydney Olympics, the athletes on the East Timorese national running team are rebuilding a program, empowering themselves and inspiring a future nation.

title: As if They Are Puppets at the Mercy of Tragic Fate
description: A PUPPET is the literal embodiment of theatrical suspense: with the support of strings or rods or human manipulators, a deftly animated object hangs suspended between stage and sky, between mute paralysis and a life of its own. Skilled hands can make a puppet elicit heart-stopping fear that recalls the visceral horrors of Greek tragedy. In ''The Bacchae,'' Euripides created one of the most agonizingly suspenseful scenes in the history of theater when he had Agave march triumphantly into Thebes with a head on a stick that everyone but she knew was her son's.

title: STATE PLAN FOR CAMDEN
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week disclosed the state's latest plan for Camden. By carefully courting local officials and by dangling the prospect of $150 million in new state investment in the city, Mr. DiFrancesco succeeded where former Governor Whitman failed in winning support for the plan from city leaders. Although couched as a rescue package, the plan is clearly also a takeover, since it would vest the power to hire and fire city managers and to raise and spend money in the hands of a new chief officer appointed by the state. The plan foresees a large-scale waterfront development program linked to an expansion of the state aquarium, as well as programs to demolish abandoned buildings and to help attract new businesses and families to the city. Iver Peterson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMINOFF, PAUL
description: SIMINOFF-Paul, 78, immunologist. Paul Siminoff, a leading immunologist who founded the Immunology Department at Bristol Myers, died May 21 after a long illness at his home in Syracuse, New York. Born in New York City on May 8, 1923, he received his doctoral degree from the University of Illinois in 1951 after having served during World War II in the Army Signal Corps where he took part in the Invasion of Normandy. At Bristol Myers he worked on antiviral drugs to treat cancer and in 1977 he created the Immunology Department to pursue pioneering work in interferon as an anti-cancer agent. He also developed drugs for the treatment of asthma. He was a passionate advocate for social justice and worked actively for numerous organizations, including the Union of Concerned Scientists and the United Way. Dr. Siminoff is survived by his wife, Mildred, his daughters, Laura, Faren and Julie Siminoff and two grandsons, Jason and Sasha.

title: May 20-26; 14 Die Crossing Border
description: On average, more than one person dies every day making the illegal crossing into the United States from Mexico, but the death of 14 Mexicans in a southern Arizona desert was, even by those terrible standards, particularly brutal, officials said. More than two dozen Mexicans were led to an isolated stretch of the border by smugglers and then abandoned in one of the most inhospitable deserts in the country, just as temperatures shot up to 115 degrees. Only 12 made it alive to a hospital in Yuma, Ariz., after they were found by the Border Patrol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, DORIS
description: FELDMAN-Doris, 75. Of Boca Raton, FL., died suddenly Wednesday, May 23. Born August 1, 1925, Rockaway, NY. Doris graduated Columbia University as a dental hygienist. She married Hilliard (Hilly) Feldman of Philadelphia, December 15, 1946. Raising her family in Philadelphia, she returned to New York in 1969. Active in Hadassah, she enjoyed the New York art scene. Upon the death of her beloved husband of 39 years in 1986, Doris relocated to Boca Raton. A lover of the arts, Doris was a docent at the Boca Raton Museum of Art. She lived life to the fullest with a passion for boating, travel, dancing, theater, ballet & the arts. Energetic & generous, she had a great sense of humor and keen appreciation for the outrageous and absurd. A wonderful, devoted, loving mother to her daughters, Ellen Goodgold and Nancy Feldman-Saylor, she will be cherished by them always. She was adored by her grandson, Jason Hilliard Goodgold, and sons-in law, Ken Goodgold & John Saylor. Her beloved brother, Harold Schwartz, DDS, predeceased her June 30, 2000. She is survived by sisters-in-law and brother-in-law and their families. We will celebrate the memory of Doris Sunday, June 10, 1:00 PM, at La Fontana, 2003 North Ocean Blvd., Boca Raton. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in memory of Doris Feldman, to the Art Education Program, Boca Raton Museum of Art, 501 Plaza Real, Boca Raton, FL. 33432.

title: CAMP GLEN GRAY SOLD
description: Camp Glen Gray, a Boy Scout camp in Bergen Country that has generated controversy since being put on the block last winter, will be sold to the Trust for Public Land for $5.1 million. The Boy Scout Council of Northern New Jersey accepted the trust's offer earlier this month. The 750-acre camp is the largest remaining piece of undeveloped land in the County and one of the oldest Boy Scout camps in the country Bergen County will buy the bulk of the camp from the trust after the sale is completed. A group of Boy Scout volunteers, called the Friends of Glen Gray, had hoped to buy the tract in order to maintain the camp for scouts, but could not raise as much money as other groups had offered. Debra Galant

title: Strom in the Balance
description: It would be hard to imagine that an airline pilot with presbyopia too advanced to see the runway would be allowed to continue to fly, or that an elderly surgeon with hands too tremulous to suture a wound would be permitted to operate on patients. And yet we have Strom Thurmond (James Bennet, April 29) occupying a seat in arguably the most important legislative body in the world, casting votes at the prodding of his aides, with clearly limited cognitive ability to discharge and attend to the complex duties of his office. We admire his tenacity and patriotism. But isn't it time that a nice seaside retirement home was made available for the senior senator from South Carolina?

In 1989, when he took over the foundation, which sponsors the quadrennial Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth, he knew that such competitions were increasingly considered antithetical to the cause of musical artistry. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, HENRY L.
description: MICHEL-Henry L. The Civil Engineering Research Foundation (CERF) is deeply saddened by the loss of one of its founding fathers Henry L. Michel. Henry's tremendous vision and leadership were instrumental in founding CERF in 1989 and he served as Chairman for five years. His many years of unselfish dedication and commitment to CERF made him a cherished friend and mentor. In 1996 CERF proudly established the Henry L. Michel Award for Industry Advancement of Research. This award served to recognize industry leaders who emulate the extraordinary qualities that Henry possessed. The CERF Board and Staff extend its heartfelt sympathy to Henry's wife, daughters and family. We will miss his special friendship and visionary guidance. Harvey M. Bernstein President and CEO

title: Dysfunctional Famiglia
description: Jimmy Breslin likes to write about ineptitude -- check out his wonderful account of the hapless 1962 Mets, ''Can't Anybody Here Play This Game?'' or his novel ''The Gang That Couldn't Shoot Straight,'' based on the life and times of the gangster Joey Gallo -- and thus the mob has always been right up his alley. In I DON'T WANT TO GO TO JAIL: A Good Novel (Little, Brown, $24.95), Breslin focuses on Fausti the Fist Dellacava, a former boxer who runs a Greenwich Village-based mob family, and his nephew, also named Fausti, who is desperately searching for a way to go legit -- he's looking for a real job. They do have one thing in common, though. Both are doing their best to stay out of prison. The Fist, who bears an uncanny resemblance to the gangster Vincent the Chin Gigante, right down to mumbling inanities and roaming the streets in his pajamas and bathrobe, chooses the insanity route to avoid the slammer, while Fausti goes so far as to change his name legally to Blanfort G. Melton and become a partner in a business offering Mob Star trading cards. Breslin wants to explain why the mob of Lucky Luciano and Meyer Lansky has fallen on such hard times lately -- most of its so-called leaders are languishing in jail -- and, for the most part, he's successful. But as a novel, ''I Don't Want to Go to Jail'' is flawed, often reading more like a series of colorful newspaper columns than a cohesive story. Still, Breslin's trademarks are all here: deft observations, sharp characterizations and wit. Charles Salzberg

title: On Bali Hai, No Ballyhoo
description: Is it possible to take the kitsch out of Tiki culture? That is the concept behind Tiki Room, a new, sleekly modern lounge at 4 West 22nd Street in Manhattan. Nancy Mah, who also designed the interiors of hangouts like Lotus and Sushi Samba, did away with the nostalgic Polynesian staples -- thatched huts, flamethrowing pu pu platters and red-eyed tribal totems -- and replaced them with pared-down references. There are abstract sunsets made of backlighted plexiglass, and plasma television screens play surf videos and have Internet access. The tropical cocktails have lost their dry ice mist and have been given names like the Honolulu Hangover and Hawaii 5-Ohhhh! Instead of servers in Don Ho attire, the waitresses wear midriff-baring Hawaiian-print halter tops. The massive Tiki head that traditionally lords it over the festivities is still there, but its forbidding features have been smoothed away, leaving an 18-foot-tall modernist sculpture with a V.I.P. seating area inside. ''We wanted to do something different,'' said Eddie Dean, co-owner of the lounge with Steve Steckel. Ms. Mah, snacking on jalape~no-glazed pork ribs in front of the sunset, said: ''Kitschy Tiki has been done so well for many years at places like Trader Vic's and the Tonga Room. So there was no point in trying that again.'' JULIA CHAPLIN

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-27-01; Paternal Verities

Though it was just one study, in a field -- schizophrenia research -- that is constantly producing new theories, for some people it was delicious proof that ''men have biological clocks, too.'' Maybe the news would finally puncture what one female reporter termed the ''brazen hubris'' of older dads, who were assumed to be having children mainly to prove to the world that they weren't shooting blanks. Bear in mind that ''older'' in this study meant not just Strom Thurmond or Rupert Murdoch old but also men in their late 40's -- a group we are pretty well accustomed to seeing as first-time fathers, especially given that many of us first-time mothers are kind of long in the tooth ourselves.

title: May 20-26; Ruling on Publishing

The justices ruled, 6 to 3, that the First Amendment did not permit the federal wiretap law to impose liability on news media for publishing illegally intercepted information -- as long as the media received it innocently and the subject was one of real public importance. While this was hardly a green light for the media, publishers were relieved that they would not face lawsuits or even prosecution for the responsible use of important information, however shadowy its origins.

title: MUSIC; He Inspired Jazz in the Concert Hall
description: RALPH ELLISON'S 1952 novel, ''Invisible Man,'' is still required reading in many college English classes. But only the savviest jazz lovers know that starting in the mid-1940's -- in his fiction, essays, letters and published interviews -- Ellison was one of the most broadly learned and eloquent thinkers on that music. Largely through the force of his intellectual leadership, jazz has made its way from smoky clubs and dance halls (which he loved) to the hushed concert halls of Lincoln Center and Carnegie Hall as well as into special collections and exhibits at the Smithsonian and onto college campuses, from Harvard to Howard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAEZ, ALFONSO JR.
description: BAEZ-Alfonso Jr. Of Woodside, Queens, NY, died Wednesday, May 23, at home. He was born January 27, 1930, in Gary, IN, the son of the Rev. Alfonso Baez and Teresa Baez. He received his education throughout the southwestern United States and graduated from Fort Bragg, CA High School in 1948. He served in the US Navy from 1948 to 1952 in the Pacific Theater. He lived his adult life in New York, having graduated from Columbia University with undergraduate and graduate degrees. He worked as Braniff International sales rep for New York, Conneticut, Westchester and Hudson Valley. He later owned the B/V Travel Agency in NYC. He was currently employed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation at its Manhattan office. Mr. Baez was predeceased by his parents and sisters, Teresita Baez and Estela Valdez. He is survived by sisters Ana Marie Bruenger of Fort Bragg, CA; Celia Garcia of Estero, FL; and brothers Paul Baez of Arlington, TX, Samuel Baez of Waterford, CT; several nieces, nephews, grandnieces, and grandnephews. Funeral services will be at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church Chapel, 55 Fifth Ave, NYC, at 2 PM, Wednesday, May 30, with visitation preceeding at 1 PM. Graveside services and burial will be at the Santa Fe New Mexico National Cemetery at 1 PM, June 25, 2001. Donations may be made to the General Scholarship Fund, Menaul School, 301 Menaul Blvd NE, Albuquerque, NM 87107; or to the Candelaria Scholarship Fund, c/o Bank of America NA, NM 1000-01-09, PO Box 27705, Albuquerque, NM 87125-7705.

He had taught and supervised at St. Luke's Hospital and supervised in the doctoral program in psychology at City University. Dr. Ertel was a magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the City College of New York and obtained his Ph.D. from City University. His early interest was in autism and severly disturbed children. He went on to study and write about psychoanalytic theory. He was particulary interested in the development of emotion in infancy and early childhood. He leaves behind his wife, Madeline Lippman, Ph.D., and his son Jacob, and many loving friends. title: Corrections
description: In an April 12 column about a prisoner who was freed after spending 14 years on death row, I referred to a pathologist who was the prosecution's key witness, William Brady. I reported that Dr. Brady was later fired from his job as medical examiner in Oregon and, relying on court papers, noted that an investigation found that he had performed private autopsies using state facilities and had sold human tissue for profit. Dr. Brady subsequently sued his supervisor in connection with the termination. A jury upheld his claim, finding that the improprieties he was charged with in the investigation had not occurred. The verdict was upheld on appeal.

title: A Trap Israel Sets for Itself
description: As it has every year since the Six Day War of 1967, Israel celebrated the anniversary of the unification of Jerusalem last week. This is the last course of our national yearly feast: within one month, we mark Holocaust Day, Memorial Day for the War Dead, Independence Day and Jerusalem Day. And as always, the day was characterized by Jerusalem's favorite salad -- a mix of diced politics, religion and the military. That's how it is. Jerusalem has always preferred occupiers to residents and graves to houses. The city goes on demanding her daily dose, and no leader has yet arisen here -- either Arab or Jew -- who would send her to a rehab program.

Making her entrance at Avery Fisher Hall for the siblings' joint recital on Wednesday evening, she emerged from the wings at a clip that had her brother nearly trotting to keep up and leapt into Copland's Violin Sonata almost too emphatically.

Al Sharpton and the three other men calling themselves the ''Vieques Four'' who are jailed at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Sunset Park. The four men have been jailed for their roles in a demonstration on May 1 near a Navy bombing range in Puerto Rico. Jim Kennedy, Senator Clinton's press secretary, said, ''Obviously she knows these individuals and has always been concerned about the bombings in Vieques.'' The Associated Press reported that Mr. Sharpton said the group discussed a shared commitment to end the Navy's Vieques bombing sessions, and called the meeting ''fruitful.'' Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Stories From Silence
description: Like the veterans of other wars, the veterans of World War II came home from combat with silence on their lips. It was the terseness that war teaches, reinforced by a profound desire to move out of the past and into the future. Those in the fighting generation knew that what had happened to them was not merely personal. They could explain parts of their war, but there were no good words to explain its deeper meaning or its horror, which always hovered just in the realm of the inarticulable. To many veterans, what could be said and what could not be said often seemed too close to tell apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWN, ERNEST
description: CROWN-Ernest. Retired Vice President of Manning, Selvage and Lee, the international public relations agency, and a former journalist in Montreal and New York City, died May 27, 2001, in Lakewood, Washington at the age of 89. Cause of death was heart failure. A native of Montreal, Crown graduated from McGill University and was news editor of the Montreal Herald. He joined Agence Havas, the French news agency, as cable editor in New York in 1936. He was later copy editor at the New York Post and foreign news editor at both P.M. and The New York Star. At the age of 80, Crown retired to Tacoma, Wash. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, the former Fenya Azeman, and two daughters, Joanna Koss of Lakewood, an artist and art historian, and Erna Rheingold, founder and President of Mermaid Seafoods, Inc., Greenwich, CT.

title: Iljaz Sinanoski, Bitola, Macedonia, May 6, 2001
description: he night of April 30, while everybody was asleep, some 50 stores were burned down in Bitola, and some houses, too. It was the Macedonian youth who did it. This did not come out of the blue: two days before, eight security men -- four Macedonian policemen from Bitola and four soldiers -- were killed by Albanian rebels. But these were not only Albanian shops. They were also Muslim Macedonian and Turkish. We are Macedonians too, of Islamic faith. All in all, our family lost three out of seven shops. The people who did this came back the next day, around lunchtime, and then thoroughly looted one of them.

title: VITAL SIGNS: TREATMENT; Use It for Wrinkles or Lower Back Pain
description: A small new study found that botulinum toxin A, the substance known as ''botox'' and used by plastic surgeons to remove wrinkles, was effective in reducing chronic low back pain. The study, by researchers at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, was published last week in the journal Neurology.

title: The Looting of Congo
description: From the depredations of Belgian colonial rule through the cold-war kleptocracy of Mobutu Sese Seko, the vast Central African nation now called Congo has been ransacked by foreigners and their African collaborators. Africans and non-Africans alike have extracted diamonds, gold, copper, timber, elephant tusks and other resources in a lawless commercial culture. As both Secretary of State Colin Powell and members of the United Nations Security Council have crisscrossed Africa in recent days to encourage the withdrawal of foreign troops from Congo, a disturbing U.N. report offers fresh evidence of the degree to which Congo's nearly three-year-old civil war serves the economic interests of some of the West's staunchest African allies and an array of foreign businesses.

title: An Uneasy Democrat Bridles, but Doesn't Bolt

title: Reducing Drug Overdoses, by Packaging

title: The F.B.I. Needs a Manager
description: The failure to turn over documents in the Timothy McVeigh case until just before the scheduled execution date is only the latest in a string of major embarrassments for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In just the past few months, we have learned about Robert Hanssen's 15 years of undetected spying from within the F.B.I., the agency's refusal to give tape recordings in the Birmingham church bombing case to the Alabama state attorney general, and the 33-year wrongful imprisonment of a Boston man after F.B.I. agents decided that helping him was less important than protecting an informant. In a Washington Post/ABC poll published last week, only a bare majority of the American public -- 53 percent -- reports having a favorable impression of the F.B.I., down nearly 30 points from six years ago.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: South Africa Rules On Terror Suspect
description: South Africa's highest court has ruled that a man now on trial in Manhattan on charges that he helped bomb the American Embassy in Tanzania was illegally turned over to United States authorities. The man, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, was arrested in Cape Town in 1999. According to an Associated Press report, the Constitutional Court of South Africa said that Mr. Mohamed should have received assurances that he would not face the death penalty, which is illegal in South Africa. David A. Ruhnke, a lawyer for Mr. Mohamed, said that it was unclear how the ruling would affect the Manhattan trial or any penalty phase. ''We are trying to determine what its overall implications are for the case,'' Mr. Ruhnke said. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Hard Questions on Nuclear Power

In truth, there are good reasons to take a fresh look at this much-maligned source of energy that has been stalled in this country for the past three decades. But it is worrisome that the administration seems to have endorsed a nuclear resurgence with little sustained analysis of its pluses and minuses.

title: Metro Business Briefing | PSE&G Seeks Permanent Increase
description: After receiving approval for temporary rate increases, starting in October, to cover sharply rising wholesale natural gas prices, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company is asking the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to approve a permanent increase of 7 percent for its 1.6 million customers in central and northern New Jersey. The increase would be about $20 a month for the average residential customer. PSE&G needs the increase to offset higher costs since it last raised its base rate in 1993, said Kathy Ellis, a company spokeswoman. John Guinan, a staff lawyer for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a consumer watchdog, conceded that the utility's costs have risen, but he said PSE&G should do more to encourage conservation among its customers through the use of efficient appliances and by conducting home audits to ensure, for example, sufficient insulation. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Machines That Talk Back
description: Citibank has installed talking automated teller machines at five of its New York bank branches, the company has announced. The machines, developed with the help of blind people, allow customers who have difficulty reading an A.T.M. screen to receive information through a headset and give instructions by using a touch screen equipped with Braille buttons. ''I think it's long overdue,'' said Lori Scharff, the president of the American Council of the Blind of New York. The new A.T.M.'s are at 717 Avenue of the Americas, near 23rd Street, 460 Park Avenue, near 57th Street, and 2861 Broadway, near 111th Street, in Manhattan; 181 Montague Street, near Clinton Street, in Brooklyn; and 95-12 63rd Road, near Queens Boulevard, in Rego Park, Queens. Citibank officials say they hope to install one talking A.T.M. at each of their 370 locations across the country in the next 16 months. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Former Lernout Chief Arrested
description: Gaston Bastiaens, former chief executive of the Belgian speech technology company Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, appeared in a federal district court in Boston yesterday after his arrest Saturday in the backyard of his Winchester, Mass., home. Mr. Bastiaens, who is being held without bail, faces possible extradition on a Belgian warrant accusing him of fraud, insider trading, stock market manipulation and accounting law violations, all of which may have contributed to Lernout & Hauspie's bankruptcy filing last November. However, yesterday in court, Mr. Bastiaens's lawyer, Richard Morvillo, suggested that his client might be willing to negotiate with the Belgian government and waive an extradition hearing. Mr. Bastiaens, 54, a Belgian citizen who was Lernout's chief executive from 1996 until last August, filed for personal bankruptcy earlier this month. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Matchmaking as a Civic Duty in Gay Paree
description: Certain eye-catching but insubstantial light comedies and adventure films are sometimes classified as summer movies. So, too, there are comparable summer ballets. One of them is ''The Merry Widow,'' Ronald Hynd's choreographic adaptation of Lehar's classic operetta, which American Ballet Theater has been dancing at the Metropolitan Opera House.

description: JERUSALEM, May 30  Prime Minister Ariel Sharon delivered an unusual address to the Parliament today in which he attacked as self-destructive one of the guiding principles of Israeli life: thou shalt not be a sucker.

title: Go Take a Hike
description: Feeling like you've been stuck in the city for too long? Wish you were somewhere else? Here's a simple solution to what ails you: Go take a hike. Although the city's sprawl might seem endless at times, some truly captivating nature areas can be found nearby, and hiking trails provide some of the best ways to experience them.

title: Omnicom Group Unit Forms TBWA/Connect
description: TBWA Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group, said yesterday that it had formed a unit, TBWA/Connect, that will help clients connect with consumers across all forms of communications, from traditional advertising and beyond.

title: Professed Market Reformer Becomes Ukraine's Prime Minister
description: Ukraine's Parliament confirmed a 46-year-old lobbyist and ally of President Leonid D. Kuchma as prime minister today, quieting for now a political crisis that has steadily sapped Mr. Kuchma's popularity and power.

title: Passion Throbs in Sondheim's Bitter Valentine
description: Hovering like one of the ghosts trailing the show's characters across the stage, Stephen Sondheim's music for ''Follies'' looms silently behind this year's Tony nominations for best Broadway score. Because it opened on Broadway in 1971, ''Follies'' was obviously ineligible to compete in that category again. If eligible, it almost certainly would have trounced the well-made but conventional scores of this year's nominees: ''The Producers,'' ''Jane Eyre,'' ''The Full Monty'' and ''A Class Act.''

title: Tasting Rooms for Wine, Or a Cup of Education
description: SOME tasting rooms are memorable for their classic, picturesque settings, others for the quirky amenities they offer. What follows is a brief list of my favorites in the United States and abroad that are worth visiting, as much for their location and cultural and educational features as for the wines they offer.

title: New Questions After Second Killing Follows Suspect's Release
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the authorities made a mistake last week when they released a murder suspect who, according to the police, two days later killed a second resident of the same Manhattan apartment building.

title: The Assembly on Air
description: The New York State Assembly plans to launch trial television broadcasts of its sessions starting next Monday afternoon. The Assembly's televised sessions could lead to far broader coverage than that provided by the State Senate, which began transmitting live pictures of its sessions via the Internet this week. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, announced yesterday that on four days next month his chamber's proceedings would be aired live on cable and public television channels across the state.

title: New Microchip Design Is Introduced by Intel
description: With a barrage of news releases, Intel, most major computer manufacturers and several leading software vendors yesterday inaugurated the commercial era of Itanium, the first in a new family of microchips that Intel hopes will make it a powerhouse in the world of big computers.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Microsoft Pursues AOL Opportunity
description: Microsoft will spend an estimated $50 million beginning this week to advertise a new price promotion intended to persuade America Online customers to switch to Microsoft's MSN Internet access. The advertising campaign, which comes after America Online, now part of AOL Time Warner, said it would increase the price of its online service by 9 percent, to $23.90 a month, on July 1, will include television spots as well as print and online ads. The promotion offers consumers who switch to MSN by June 30 three months of free service and a $21.95-a-month rate until Jan. 1, 2003. Bob Visse, group product manager at MSN in Redmond, Wash., said MSN call centers had received 50 percent more inquiries from consumers looking for an alternative to AOL since it announced the price increase last week. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: After a Meek Start, Mean Streak Returns
description: The bad blood flowed from the cut faces of Colorado's Eric Messier and the Devils' Ken Daneyko. The close-ups on the television screen showed various other players spitting curses at one another and shoving gloves into one another's faces. What a difference a game makes. The first match of the Stanley Cup finals, a 5-0 Avalanche victory Saturday, had seemed like some strange flashback from the preseason, including all the gratuitous rough stuff after the outcome was decided.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Firefighters Wanted
description: With the fire season starting around the West, Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said local governments were still short several thousand firefighters to reach the desired level of 9,000 to 10,000. ''We have about two-thirds and need another one-third,'' she said in Denver, where Gov. Bill Owens announced a new program to improve firefighting efforts in Colorado. Across the country, the summer of 2000 was the worst for wildfires in 50 years, with 93,000 fires burning 7.4 million acres. Officials have called the shortage of adequately trained firefighters a major reason for the magnitude of destruction. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Live (With Interruptions) From Albany, the Senate at Work
description: For the first time, New Yorkers today were able with a little patience and luck -- to watch the Legislature live from their homes and offices, as the State Senate began broadcasting its meetings on its Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, JUDITH SKLUTH
description: WEINBERG-Judith Skluth. The Alumni Association of Hunter College mourns the passing of a former Alumni president. Judith was also a member of the Hunter Hall of Fame and a recipient of the Special Award for Alumni service. Her years of devotion to the college were special and we extend our condolences to her family.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Ruling Limits Awarding Of Legal Fees for Plaintiffs
description: The Supreme Court today dealt a setback to civil rights and environmental plaintiffs who for years have counted on being reimbursed by the other side for their legal fees if their lawsuits, brought under any of dozens of federal laws, accomplished their goals.

title: Poetry Soaked In the Personal And Political
description: Eileen Myles has been called ''the last of the New York School poets,'' the seal on a lineage that began with the personalized, speech-based poetry of Frank O'Hara. Her writing also has roots in the visionary, intensely political work of the Beats. At 50, she is a cult figure to a generation of young, post-punk female writer-performers who are creating a niche for poetry in the better-known world of pop music and, in the process, forming a new literary avant-garde.

title: Louima Case Prosecutor to Fill U.S. Attorney Post
description: Alan Vinegrad, the lead prosecutor in the Abner Louima case, was named the interim United States attorney in the Eastern District of New York yesterday.

title: In New Senate, New Scrutiny of Judicial Nominees
description: With Republicans losing control of the Senate as a result of Senator James M. Jeffords's decision to become an independent, the future of President Bush's first batch of judicial nominees is now suddenly uncertain.

title: A New 'Big Brother'
description: The contestants will compete in challenges for food and luxury items; they will vote one another out one by one each week; and in the final episode, the losers will come back to select the ultimate winner.

description: A 17-year-old student at Evander Childs High School in the Bronx was arrested last night in the stabbing of a fellow student in a school stairwell yesterday morning, the police said.

title: After Lucent Bid Fails, Alcatel Stuns Investors With Warning
description: PARIS, May 30  In the wake of the collapsed merger negotiations between Alcatel of France and Lucent Technologies, Alcatel issued an unexpected and severe financial warning today, and investors punished its shares and those of its optical fiber subsidiary.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Paper Purchase
description: The Finnish industrial group UPM-Kymmene said it would buy the German paper manufacturer G. Haindl'sche Papierfabriken for 3.64 billion euros ($3.13 billion). The acquisition of the company, one of Europe's leading producers of publication papers, is expected to allow UPM-Kymmene to raise its annual production capacity of paper from 9.7 tons to 11.6 million tons. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: NATO Is Unyielding On Bush Missile Plan
description: In his first effort to sell President Bush's missile defense plan to allies, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell failed to pierce NATO's opposition.

title: Technology Briefing | Deals: Genomics Concerns To Merge
description: Sequenom Inc. agreed to buy Gemini Genomics for $238 million in stock. It was the latest of a spate of mergers involving genomics companies, whose stocks have fallen since last year as it has become clear they will need a broader array of technologies than they have. Sequenom, based in San Diego, has technology for rapidly analyzing genetic differences among individuals. Gemini Genomics, based in Britain, studies twins and other populations to identify disease-causing genes. By combining the populations and the tools, ''you have all the assets together,'' said Sequenom's chief executive, Toni Schuh. Sequenom will exchange 0.2 newly issued share for each ordinary Gemini share and 0.4 share for each of Gemini's American depository receipts. Paul Kelly, Gemini's chief executive, will become an executive vice president at Sequenom and head a new biotherapeutics division. Sequenom shares fell $1.93, or 11 percent, to $15.75 while the Gemini A.D.R.'s rose 45 cents, to $6.05.

title: U.S. Again Prosecutes Man Cleared of Being Reviled Nazi
description: Eight years after an Israeli appeals court overturned his conviction as the notorious Nazi death camp sadist Ivan the Terrible, John Demjanjuk, an 81-year-old retired Cleveland auto worker, went on trial here today with his American citizenship once more at stake.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Taiwan Businessman Executed
description: China executed a Taiwanese businessman for his role in a big investment scam, state television reported. Cao Yufei was manager of a brokerage firm that collapsed in 1998, taking about $39 million in investors' money with it. The collapse led to protests in Beijing and embarrassed many government leaders who had been photographed in Mr. Cao's company. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: In Boston, Good Grades or Hot Weather Mean Cheap Rooms
description: The Colonnade Hotel, a 285-room property in the Back Bay area of Boston, has two summer discount programs  one based on brain power, the other on the weather. The Colonnade U package, available through Labor Day, is a two-night package at $249 a night, with the first night's rate divided by a high school student's grade point average. If, for example, a student has an A average, the rate is divided by 4, making it $62.25 for the first night, with the second night $249. Students must bring report cards to verify grades. And from July 1 to Sept. 3, the Summer Meltdown package offers a room for Friday and Saturday nights, with the Friday rate being $199 minus the National Weather Service temperature reading for Boston at 5 p.m. that day; Saturday's rate is $199 regardless of how hot it gets. The hotter the better, since the hotel has a rooftop swimming pool. Contact (617) 424-7000 or www.colonnadehotel.com .

title: Disabled Golfer May Use a Cart On the PGA Tour, Justices Affirm
description: The Supreme Court ruled decisively today that Casey Martin, the disabled golfer who has been battling the PGA Tour over its walking rule for the last four years, has the legal right to ride in a golf cart during tournament play.

description: President Askar Akayev outlined a program for cutting poverty in half by 2010 through cooperation between the government and private organizations. The 10-year strategy proposes opening the government to greater scrutiny, reducing external debt, curbing corruption and improving the investment climate to attract foreign investors. title: Metro Business Briefing
description: PSE&G SEEKS PERMANENT INCREASE After receiving approval for temporary rate increases, starting in October, to cover sharply rising wholesale natural gas prices, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company is asking the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to approve a permanent increase of 7 percent for its 1.6 million customers in central and northern New Jersey. The increase would be about $20 a month for the average residential customer. PSE&G needs the increase to offset higher costs since it last raised its base rate in 1993, said Kathy Ellis, a company spokeswoman. John Guinan, a staff lawyer for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, a consumer watchdog, conceded that the utility's costs have risen, but he said PSE&G should do more to encourage conservation among its customers through the use of efficient appliances and by conducting home audits to ensure, for example, sufficient insulation.

title: Chilly Encounter in California
description: President Bush and Gov. Gray Davis, who are deeply at odds on California's energy problems, have one thing in common -- plunging approval ratings among California's aggrieved voters. Yesterday's meeting between the two did little to bridge the gap on energy and may have done even less to improve their political fortunes.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Dunkin' Donuts Strike Threat
description: Unionized workers at a Dunkin' Donuts distribution center in Swedesboro, N.J., have authorized a strike there because of what they call unfair labor practices, the union said yesterday. The union, Local 1360 of the United Food and Commercial Workers, said the employees voted 61 to 2 on Friday night to sanction a strike at the mid-Atlantic distribution center, which could affect supplies for hundreds of Dunkin' Donuts retail outlets, the local said. The announcement did not specify what the asserted unfair practices were. Dunkin' Donuts said the distribution center was a co-op owned by franchisees and was not affiliated with Dunkin' Donuts Inc. or its parent company, Allied Domecq, neither of which, Dunkin' Donuts said, employs the workers or is involved in the labor dispute. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: A Kennedy Has His Eyes on a Newly Vacant Seat in the House
description: What comes next in the Massachusetts district that lost its beloved longtime congressman, Joe Moakley, to leukemia on Monday? Political analysts summed up the answer today in two words: another Kennedy.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Equity Options For Yahoo Chief
description: Terry Semel, who officially began as Yahoo's chief executive on May 1, was given a compensation package that included options to buy 10 million shares, or just less than 2 percent of the company, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The Internet company named Mr. Semel, a longtime Hollywood executive, its chairman and chief executive on April 17, and that day he bought a million Yahoo shares with his own money. Mr. Semel's options were granted on his first day of employment, when the stock closed at $22.31. Yahoo shares fell $2.13, or 10.2 percent, to $18.79 yesterday. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Bernard H. Mendik, the chairman of the Real Estate Board of New York and a longtime force in the city's commercial real estate market, died Monday at New York Presbyterian Hospital. He was 72 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Hunger-Strike Toll Reaches 23
description: A former prison inmate has starved to death, bringing the death toll to 23 in a hunger strike against changes in Turkish prisons. Ugur Turkmen, a member of a radical leftist organization, continued to fast after being released from prison at the end of a two-year sentence and died at an Ankara hospital, according to Turkey's Human Rights Association. Several hundred prisoners, mostly militant leftists, are protesting new jails with small cells, which they say will put them at greater risk of mistreatment by guards. Doug Frantz (NYT)

In a 1998 survey of its members by the Society of Human Resource Management, 90 percent of respondents said that they had discovered falsified information while checking references.

title: Sports of The Times; The Cart Doesn't Hit The Ball

title: White Asparagus, In All Its Delicacy

But white asparagus, with its ivory color, is also elegant. It has a special delicacy and less herbaceousness than the green, and is less likely to be bitter. Since its season is short, I grab the white when I can.
