Not a bad way to endure another period when his talent is put to the test of finding an outlet willing to take a chance that he will tow prestige, ratings or good publicity behind him.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Job Fair Is Oversubscribed
description: The organizers of a job fair for displaced employees of Latex Foam Products of Ansonia, Conn., which burned down earlier this month, have had to turn away potential employers who want to take part. Nancie Gray, vice president of marketing and special events for the Greater Valley Chamber of Commerce, which is sponsoring the fair, said only 26 out of 100 interested businesses will have tables at the fair, at Ansonia High School, on Saturday. The chamber wanted an intimate setting for the 240 displaced workers, said Ms. Gray, adding, ''We didn't want them to feel overwhelmed with 100 companies waiting to see them.'' Participating businesses include the Bic Corporation of Milford, Conn.; the Custom Bottle Corporation of Naugatuck, Conn.; and the Inline Plastics Corporation and Pitney Bowes Inc., both in Shelton, Conn. Other businesses will be allowed to post job openings at the fair. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIAM, VICTOR K.
description: KIAM-Victor K. Died peacefully on May 27th. Beloved husband of Ellen, loving father of Lisa, Tory and Robin; devoted grandfather of Jenny, Alexander, Sophia, Caleigh and Lia. A service will be held Wednesday, May 30th, 10AM, at the 92nd Street Y, on 92nd St and Lexington Avenue. Donations may be made to: Divison of Cardiology, Weill-Cornell Medical College, 1300 York Ave., New York, N.Y. 10021, attention: Dr. David Blumenthal or the Entrepreneurship Fund of Harvard Business School, Soldiers Field, Boston, MA. 02163, attention: Florence Amoroso, Asst. Director, Fund Office, or 92nd St. Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, New York 10128.

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST</B

title: First Boston Won't Be Giving Midyear Raises to Its Top Tier
description: Signaling that Wall Street firms are still feeling the squeeze from the slowdown in financial markets, Credit Suisse First Boston has told about 5,400 executives of its investment banking operations that they will not receive midyear raises.

title: Escape Route From Sexist Attitudes on Wall St.
description: Anne M. Tatlock will never forget her first business trip.

title: Martin's Case Ends, But Debate Goes On Among Tour Players
description: Casey Martin was never happier to receive a phone call from Tim Finchem.

title: Bertelsmann In Deal to Buy Music Start-Up
description: The media giant Bertelsmann has agreed to acquire the Internet music start-up Myplay for about $30 million, people involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: Yankees Have Martnez's Number
description: It is not enough that Pedro Martnez throws a 96 mile-an-hour fastball or that his curve makes hitters recoil or that he changes speeds and throws strikes. No, Martnez also wages a war of rhythm which, on the face of it, might seem a little silly.

title: Quietly, Police Give Protesters A Night in Jail
description: For more than a decade, most demonstrators arrested at protests on the streets of New York City for minor offenses received summonses and were sent home. But quietly, the Police Department has started requiring that those arrested at protests of more than 20 people spend the night in jail.

title: 4 in Vieques Protest Kept in Jail During Appeal
description: The Justice Department filed court papers yesterday objecting to the release of the Rev. Al Sharpton and three Bronx politicians pending their appeal. As a result, Mr. Sharpton and the others will remain in a federal detention center in Brooklyn at least until a federal appeals court rules on their request for an appeal of their sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHENBERG, BERNICE
description: HOCHENBERG-Bernice. Service Guild, the Auxiliary of Long Island Jewish Medical Center extends heartfelt sympathy to Paul Hochenberg, Executive Director on the loss of his beloved mother Bernice. Our sincerest condolences to the entire family. Florence Hausner, Vivian Jaeger, Co-Presidents, Service Guild, LIJMC

title: HOLDERS SWAP $7.8 BILLION OF AT&T STOCK
description: AT&T said yesterday that its shareholders had swapped about 372.6 million shares of AT&T common stock for 438.2 million shares of the AT&T Wireless Group tracking stock. The shares are worth about $7.8 billion. The exchange brings the company one step closer to completing its plan to separate its wireless telephone arm as an independent company. AT&T plans to announce final results of the exchange on Monday. In October, AT&T said it would split into independent business services, wireless and cable television companies, with tracking shares for its consumer long-distance unit, by 2002. AT&T Wireless will become an independent company by mid-2001. Shares in AT&T Wireless ended down 79 cents, or 4.4 percent, to $17.30. AT&T shares fell 38 cents, to $20.68.

title: W.H.O. Warns Ads for Women Could Raise Rate of Smoking
description: Globally, four times as many men as women are smokers, but aggressive tobacco marketing and promotion could greatly increase the percentage of women who smoke, the World Health Organization has warned.

title: China Bars an AIDS Expert From Going to U.S. for Award
description: BEIJING, May 30  A prominent retired gynecologist who has become one of China's foremost grass-roots AIDS activists has been denied permission to attend an award ceremony in the United States at which she is being honored for her work.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ETTINGER, SIDNEY
description: ETTINGER-Sidney. 2/11/16-5/30/ 86. You've been gone 15 years. I've been gone too. I only look like I'm here. Loving you always, Your Bride

title: Worn Down And Irish, And Moving Over Here
description: The newest building at Battery Park City will be the oldest.

title: IVAX SAYS IT WILL INCREASE OUTPUT OF ITS GENERIC TAXOL
description: Ivax is increasing production of its generic version of the Bristol-Myers Squibb's cancer medicine Taxol after regulators approved an additional raw-materials supplier and manufacturer for Ivax. Ivax has sold $120 million worth of the treatment for breast, lung and ovarian cancer since becoming the first company to market a generic version in October. The approvals let Ivax supply a significantly greater part of the market immediately, the company said. Ivax shares rose $3.31, or 11 percent, to $32.96. Ivax is based in Miami.

title: All for One, And It's All For Sharpton
description: AND you probably thought that the Vieques protests were about the Navy's bombing exercises on that Puerto Rican island. How delusional. Didn't you know they were nothing more than a backdrop to yet another chapter in The Al Sharpton Story?

title: 4 GUILTY IN TERROR BOMBINGS OF 2 U.S. EMBASSIES IN AFRICA; JURY TO WEIGH 2 EXECUTIONS
description: Four men were convicted yesterday of conspiring with Osama bin Laden in a terrorist plot to bomb the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998. The blasts killed 224 people, injured thousands and glaringly exposed the United States' vulnerability abroad.

title: A Gain, and a Loss, for Civil Rights
description: Supreme Court decisions yesterday yielded mixed results for the cause of justice. By a decisive 7-to-2 vote the justices ruled that Casey Martin, the disabled professional golfer, has a legal right under the Americans With Disabilities Act to ride in a golf cart rather than walk the course during P.G.A. Tour events -- thus ending a four-year dispute that has provoked intense debate among golfers and non-golfers alike. Unfortunately, that enlightened ruling was offset when the court, by a closer, 5-to-4 margin, made it substantially harder for plaintiffs who bring successful lawsuits to enforce civil rights and environmental laws to obtain reimbursement for their legal fees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSDEN, BARBARA BALL
description: COSDEN-Barbara Ball. Of Darien on May 25, 2001. Wife of the late Dr. William T. Foley and Joshua S. Cosden, Jr. A memorial service will be held at the Darien Community Association, 274 Middlesex Road, Darien, CT on Friday, June 1, 2001 at 2:30 PM. Interment is private. Memorials may be sent to Save the Children Foundation, 54 Wilton Road, Westport, CT 06880.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, (SAMUEL) LEON
description: PRICE-(Samuel) Leon, 85. Of Boynton Beach, Florida. Formerly of Bronx, Queens & New Rochelle. On May 25. Loving husband of Betty (Sloman Leeds), beloved father of Steven of Orlando, Francine of Boston, and Maureen Tillman of Maplewood, N.J. Stepfather of Wendy Marino and Barbara Leff of Westchester and father-inlaw of Nancy (Rudnick) Price, Wayne Tillman, Gary Leff, and Ames Marino. Devoted brother of the late Rosalind Winant & Terry Stein. Survived by grandchildren, Jonathan, Daniel, David, Nicholas, Michael, Laura, Aliana, Jordan, Juliana. He was also married to the late Joan Maskow.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Cruise Canceled For Sprinkler Repairs
description: Norwegian Cruise Line canceled the weekly cruise on one of its ships, the Norway, after a Coast Guard inspection on Sunday found leaks in the sprinkler system. The 978-foot Norway had been scheduled to leave Miami on Sunday with 2,000 passengers for a seven-day cruise to the western Caribbean. The cruise line said passengers would be offered a full refund as well as a free seven-day cruise later. The company said the repairs should be finished in time for the Norway's next scheduled cruise, this Sunday. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Isuzu Motors Moves to Cut Losses
description: Unable to restore itself to profitability with a more cautious retrenchment plan begun in 1998, Isuzu Motors, the Japanese truck maker 49 percent owned by General Motors, said on Monday that it would take more drastic steps.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICHMAN, ZELDA
description: RICHMAN-Zelda. May 30, 2000. Without you here the sun on our faces is not as warm, the breeze not as gentle and the laughter not as lilting. You gave a nurturing love to our lives. We miss you every day, our sweet Zelda. Faye, Robert and Samanth

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Indonesian Parliament Approves Motion to Impeach President
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 30  Indonesia's Parliament voted today to begin impeachment proceedings against President Abdurrahman Wahid, raising the prospect of another turbulent change of power in this restive Asian archipelago.

title: Trachsel Gets A No-Hitter
description: Steve Trachsel, who accepted a demotion to Class AAA Norfolk after starting the season 1-6 for the Mets, threw a seven-inning no-hitter last night in the host Tides' 3-0 victory over Ottawa, the first game of a doubleheader. In the minors, each game in a doubleheader is seven innings. Trachsel struck out five and walked two, and kept the game ball despite the setting.

title: Horrors of War, Blessings of Bounty
description: To the Editor:

title: Knife, Fork And Camera: Lunch in a Lens
description: Some of the most evocative classic photographs involve dining, and a new exhibition on the Upper East Side narrows the focus even more, to one meal. The more than 30 photographs in ''Let's Have Lunch'' at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery, 52 East 76th Street, feature subjects as diverse as an early 20th-century picnic, in a shot by Jacques Henri Lartigue, and the Automat in 1936, by Berenice Abbott. You can also see Rock Hudson barbecuing for guests in 1952, by Sid Avery, and ''The Diner, 14th Street, 1952,'' by Louis Stettner (right).

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Parliament: U.S. Cleared Of Spying
description: A European Parliament report has not found any concrete evidence that the United States-led spying system known as Echelon has been used in commercial espionage against European companies. The Parliament began an investigation last year after hearing allegations that American companies were gaining a competitive edge with information gathered via the eavesdropping network. But the report found nothing to support the allegations and concluded that the network was not nearly as extensive as believed. Suzanne Daley (NYT)

title: Oil Boom Nears for Alaska, Even if Refuge Isn't Drilled
description: Regardless of what happens to the Bush administration's plans to open Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling, the state is on the verge of the biggest boom in energy development since the Trans-Alaska oil pipeline was built in the mid-1970's.

title: New Jersey Classic Has 4-Horse Entry
description: The 3-1 favorite to win the $500,000 New Jersey Classic at the Meadowlands racetrack on Saturday is a four-horse entry that includes Royal Art and Gunthatwonthewest, a one-two combination trained by Brett Pelling, whose horses have dominated the Classic.

title: More Queries on Insurer's Handling of Its Pensions
description: Internal documents from the New York Life Insurance Company raise more questions about how the company handled the nest egg of its employees and whether it used those funds to bolster its mutual fund business.

title: The Embassy Bombings Verdict
description: Diplomatic sensitivities and legal barriers make it difficult for the American government to prosecute terrorist attacks against United States citizens and installations abroad. But when such cases can be brought to trial fairly, and the evidence of guilt is compelling, the result can be a measure of justice for horrifying crimes. Yesterday's convictions of four men accused of assisting or carrying out the 1998 bombing of two American embassies in East Africa met that test. The case presented by prosecutors was convincing and the verdicts were fully justified.

title: For Two Guilty of Murder, A Question of Life or Death
description: For two of the men convicted yesterday in the embassy bombing case, the trial is only half over. This morning, the trial's second phase is to begin as the jury decides whether Mohamed Rashed Daoud al-'Owhali and Khalfan Khamis Mohamed deserve to be put to death for their crimes.

title: Reckonings; Bad Heir Day
description: There's a scene in the 1966 British comedy ''The Wrong Box'' in which the son of an irascible plutocrat pushes his father's wheelchair along the top of a cliff, responding with a dutiful ''Yes, father'' to each outpouring of verbal abuse. Then the old man waves his hand at the industrial landscape below, and declares, ''When I'm gone, all this will be yours.'' ''Yes, father,'' replies the son -- and pushes him off the cliff.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARDAI, VERA
description: ARDAI-Vera. On May 28th, 2001. Beloved wife of Tibor, devoted mother of Michael and Charles, cherished grandmother of Alyssa, and loving daughter of Martha Gordon. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Wendesday, May 30, 2001, 9:30 am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: One Survivor Is Arrested In Smuggling Of Migrants
description: The Border Patrol has arrested one of the survivors of a botched smuggling effort that left 14 Mexican immigrants dead in the Arizona desert last week, charging that he was one of several ''coyotes,'' or organizers of the illegal crossing.

title: VISX SAYS IT HAS SETTLED PATENT DISPUTE WITH LASERSIGHT
description: Visx, a leading maker of lasers used to correct vision, said yesterday that it had settled a patent dispute with LaserSight, and the companies made a licensing agreement. LaserSight will get a license to Visx patents for equipment used in vision-correction surgery and LaserSight will pay a royalty to Visx each time one of its lasers is used in the United States, the companies said. The agreement ends a lawsuit filed by Visx, based in Santa Clara, Calif., in 1999, claiming that LaserSight made and sold equipment for eye surgery based on Visx's patented invention. LaserSight is based in Winter Park, Fla.

title: Simplicity, Translated Into French
description: YOU might get away with calling blanc-manger a French take on panna cotta, but I wouldn't suggest you try that in France -- or England, Italy or a host of Arab countries, for that matter.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Flake Endorses Hevesi
description: The Rev. Floyd H. Flake, senior pastor at the Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church in Queens and an influential figure among blacks, endorsed City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi for mayor yesterday. Mr. Flake said Mr. Hevesi was the best choice because of ''his demonstrated history of working to improve race relations.'' Mr. Flake added that if Mr. Hevesi won the Democratic primary, he would also support the comptroller in the general election despite their disagreement on issues like school vouchers, which Mr. Flake supports and Mr. Hevesi opposes. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Alcatel and Lucent Call Off Negotiations Toward a Merger
description: Merger negotiations between Alcatel of France and Lucent Technologies collapsed yesterday after the two companies could not agree on how much control the French company would have.

title: Point Given Turns In Quick Workout
description: Point Given, the winner of the Preakness Stakes, breezed five furlongs in 59.60 seconds yesterday at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky., in preparation for the Belmont Stakes on June 9.

title: Oak Bar's Murals Are All Spruced Up
description: RAISE a glass to Everett Shinn. For decades, his most often toasted paintings -- three huge murals in the Oak Bar at the Plaza Hotel -- had struggled for attention beneath a dark and yellowing layer of varnish, nicotine stains and occasional splatters of beer.

title: Opening the Door in Albany
description: Joseph Bruno, the New York State Senate majority leader, proudly declared yesterday that his chamber was the ''first house in the Legislature'' to be televised gavel to gavel. The proceedings did not in fact appear on television but on a ''Webcast'' available to people with high-speed computers. Still, Mr. Bruno and his colleagues have opened the electronic door. Now the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, and Gov. George Pataki should join in taking the next logical step -- making the entire Legislature available to the general public on cable television.

title: Six Killed in Renewed Mideast Violence
description: Three Israeli settlers and three Palestinians were killed today in fresh violence in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and an American-brokered security meeting between Israeli and Palestinian officers ended with no signs of agreement on steps to stem the bloodshed.

title: Benjamin Malcolm, New York City Jail Chief, Dies at 81
description: Benjamin J. Malcolm, who as New York City's commissioner of correction from 1972 to 1977 led its vast jail system through a turbulent six years of riots, demolition and rebuilding, died last Friday. He was 81.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Trial Begins In JonBenet Ramsey Case
description: A lawsuit by Linda Arndt, the first detective to arrive at the house where JonBenet Ramsey was found dead in 1996, has gone to trial in Denver. Ms. Arndt, 40, is suing Boulder police officials who blamed her for mistakes in the case. She is seeking damages from Chief Mark Beckner; his predecessor, Tom Koby; and the city for barring her from publicly challenging media reports that suggested she was responsible for problems in the investigation. So far, the authorities have charged no one in JonBenet's death. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Ex-Minister Gets 6 Months for Corruption in France
description: PARIS, May 30  A Paris court handed down convictions today in a huge corruption case that has transfixed the French public as it offered a rare peek into the lives of some of former President Francois Mitterrand's closest associates, including his foreign minister, Roland Dumas.

title: U.S. Venture Capital Sees Treasure In Europe; But the Welcome for Silicon Valley Is Not Always Friendly Overseas
description: When Charles Muirhead, then a 20-year-old British entrepreneur, was raising money for his first company, a software development firm, in 1996, he tried in vain to catch the ear of prominent venture capital firms in Silicon Valley.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AUSTRALIA<BR AUSTRALIA: BREWER PROFITS

title: Market Place; If, as many analysts thought, Vodafone did everything right, why are things so wrong?
description: ITS share price is down more than 30 percent in the last 12 months. A string of acquisitions and spending on new services contributed to the first loss in the company's history. And price wars in crucial markets are driving down profits even as acquiring new customers has become difficult and costly.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Loss At Publisher
description: The chief executive of Emap, Kevin Hand, resigned as the company reported a 545 million ($774.7 million) write-down of its United States magazine business. Shareholders have blamed Mr. Hand for the two-year-old purchase of Emap USA, publisher of Hot Rod and Guns & Ammo, which has since faced declining advertising that has prompted its parent to look for a buyer. Robin Miller is replacing Mr. Hand. Mr. Miller will give up the chairman's post to return to his previous role as chief executive, which he held for 13 years to 1998. He said he would remain chief executive for two years, during which Adam Broadbent, chairman of the British retailer Arcadia Group, would replace him as chairman. For the year to March 31, Emap said it lost 565 million ($803.2 million) on revenue of 1.13 billion ($1.61 billion), in contrast to a profit of 85 million ($120.8 million) on revenue of 1.09 billion ($1.55 billion) a year earlier. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Alaska Energy Development Surges and Alarms Some

title: Clash on Use of Embryos in Germany Stirs Echoes of Nazi Era
description: A sharp debate clouded by memories of the Third Reich has erupted in Germany over the ethics of research in biotechnology and particularly the use of embryos for genetic inquiry and diagnosis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, JOSEPH
description: FINE-Joseph. Of NYC and Malden-On-Hudson. On May 26, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Anita F. Fine. Dear father of Jamie Fine and Scott Fine. Services Thursday, May 31, 12:45PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Our Towns; DiFrancesco's Wishes Won't Make Tolls Go Away, Even for a Day
description: IT was the kind of nice-guy proposal you would expect from a nice guy like Donald T. DiFrancesco. New Jersey's acting governor wanted to declare a toll holiday for just one day on the Garden State Parkway. He had the perfect day: the Fourth of July. Let freedom ring!

title: Gardens of New York
description: Enjoying summer in New York doesn't require trips to the country. The plant kingdom is holding its own in the city, with a wealth of gardens cared for by a legion of professional and amateur gardeners. Every borough except Manhattan has a well-established botanical garden with an amazing variety of exotic and native trees, plants and flowers. There are also innumerable community, rooftop and sidewalk gardens and numerous greenmarkets, many of which are now selling peak harvest produce along with plants and cut flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, IRVING
description: SCHINDLER-Irving. Age 88, of Fair Lawn, NJ, on May 26, 2001. Predeceased by his wives, Shirley, Ruth and Jessie. Survived by his sons Paul of New York, NY and Robert and wife Teresa of Charlotte, NC; step-sons David, Robert and Mitchell Zeemont; brothers George and the late Stanley; beloved grandfather of Alexandra, Austen and Sarah Schindler. Services are Thursday, 2:30PM graveside at Cedar Park Cemetery, Forest Avenue, Paramus, NJ.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: For the Love of Microphones

title: Judge Is Set to Authorize Bias Settlement With Coke
description: A federal judge said yesterday that he planned to authorize a $192.5 million settlement of a discrimination lawsuit against the Coca-Cola Company, giving the final seal of approval to the largest settlement ever in a racial bias case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, HELEN
description: PRICE-Helen. SHARE mourns the loss of Helen Price, a breast cancer advocate and supporter of SHARE's services to women with breast or ovarian cancer. We will miss our dear friend. Our thoughts are with her family at this time.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Council Hears Workers' Concerns
description: The Security Council met for the first time with representatives of United Nations employees to hear about the dangers facing staff workers around the world. In the last decade, 200 civilians on United Nations assignments have been killed on duty. Barbara Crossette (NYT)

title: Elliott Meets With Jets Officials
description: The Jets finally had a meeting yesterday with the veteran offensive tackle Jumbo Elliott, who is expected to participate in practice today.

title: To Fill Gaps, Cities Seek Wave of Immigrants
description: A small but growing number of cities with declining populations are embracing new strategies to attract immigrants to replenish shrinking neighborhoods, fill labor shortages and inject greater ethnic diversity in their communities.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Outlook At Insurer
description: Munich Re, the world's biggest reinsurer, expects earnings to rise at least 10 percent this year as the company looks for more acquisitions to increase its life insurance business. Munich Re agreed last month to buy the third of Ergo Versicherungsgruppe, Germany's No. 2 insurer, it did not own for 4.3 billion euros ($3.70 billion). Hans-Jrgen Schinzler, chief executive of Munich Re, said it would look for ''good targets'' to increase Ergo's business, particularly outside Germany.

title: Article 2001053093569118275 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Program Finds Success in Reducing Teenage Pregnancy
description: Shannon White used to assume she would become a teenage mother, like her big sister. But at 17, after three years in an experimental afterschool program intended to prevent teenage pregnancy, her expectations are quite different.

title: Article 2001053093871859757 -- No Title
description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: ALLIED-WASTE, A TRASH HAULER, TO ACQUIRE STAR SERVICES
description: Allied-Waste Industries, a leading trash hauler, will acquire the Star Services Group for $34 million in cash and assume long-term debt to increase its presence in Florida. The amount of debt assumed by Allied-Waste will depend on Star Services' working capital and long-term debt at the transaction's close, Allied-Waste said. The transaction is subject to approval by Star Services shareholders. Star Services, which is based in Pompano Beach, Fla., provides waste collection, disposal and recycling services in Miami, Fort Lauderdale and Palm Beach, Fla. Allied-Waste is based in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDIK, BERNARD H.
description: MENDIK-Bernard H. On May 28, 2001 at age 72. Beloved husband of Susan. Loving father of Laurie, Kevin, Todd and Alex. Adoring grandfather of Marty, Gabriel, Dawson, Mary Ashley. Dear brother of Sandy Getz. Devoted uncle of Karen and Shari. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, May 29th, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Services at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65 Street Wednesday, May 30, 10AM. Interment private.

title: To Sit and Sip And Contemplate: Asia in the Flatiron
description: An exotic alternative to the bars in the Flatiron district has opened in Paisley, a shop at 49 East 21st Street, which specializes in Asian furniture and decorative accessories. A new bar and cafe there serves coffee, tea, juices, beer and wine. Seating is on the store's stock of silk-covered settees, benches and chairs, around unusual tables. Ajay Sharma, a co-owner, also plans to start serving Indian snacks soon. The shop opens at 11 a.m. Tuesday through Saturday and at noon Sunday, with varying closing times; closed on Monday.

title: Bell Labs: A Bit Abstract and Always Curious
description: Bell Labs and its parent company, Lucent Technologies, are still giants of innovation despite recent management fumbles and business failures, many industry experts say.

title: ENRON UNIT AND INDIAN GOVERNMENT FAIL TO SQUARE BILL
description: Talks between Enron's unit in India and a government committee failed to resolve a dispute over back payments. The two sides said more meetings were planned but no date was set. The talks are aimed at salvaging a $2.9 billion power project in the western Indian state of Maharashtra, the largest foreign investment ever in India. The Enron unit, the Dabhol Power Company, claimed that the Maharashtra power authority owes it about $64 million and pulled out of the project. The Maharashtra agency, disputing the size of the bill, canceled its agreement to buy power. Enron owns 65 percent of Dabhol. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Consumers Are Confident Even With Job Fears
description: Consumer confidence rose in May as Americans refused to let an eroding job market cloud their expectations that the economy would pick up, a survey by the Conference Board indicated today.

title: Biden Will Try To Broaden Missile Review
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a skeptic of President Bush's plan for a missile defense system, said today that he would seek to broaden the debate over the strategy when he takes over next week as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Who Says Doughnuts Always Die With the Dawn?
description: It was almost noon when I stopped at Spring Street Bakery in Little Italy, long after any respectable doughnut should still taste good. But there they were, plump little custard-filled doughnuts, crullers and fat, ropy bow ties -- twists coated in cinnamon and sugar.

title: Horrors of War, Blessings of Bounty
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Plans to Prolong Trade Benefits for China
description: President Bush said today that he would ask Congress to extend China's ''normal'' trade status with the United States for one more year. Such a stop-gap measure was made necessary because Beijing, having won such status from Congress last year as a step toward entry in the World Trade Organization, is delaying its application.

title: Explosion in Brooklyn Heights Forces Evacuation; One Hurt
description: A pipe bomb exploded in the basement of a Brooklyn Heights apartment building last night, injuring a guest at a party next door and forcing the evacuation of the stately homes on a residential stretch of Montague Street.

title: For Teenagers, a Jury, Judge and Prosecutor of Their Peers
description: The wheels of justice are turning in a small courtroom in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: Mets' Bullpen Declines As Phillies' Improves
description: During the off-season, the Mets' bullpen was regarded as one of the best in baseball, while the Philadelphia Phillies were second-guessed for the free-agent signings for their bullpen.

title: Turkey's Choice: European Union or the Death Penalty
description: On some days, after he was beaten and raw sewage was pumped into his darkened cell in a former morgue, Celalettin Can would cower on the putrid floor and pray for the hangman to call his name.

title: Say 'Cheese' And Try Not to Smile
description: ARTISANAL is a brasserie with a lot of cheese. That doesn't sound especially enticing. So let me put it another way. Artisanal is a big, very good-looking brasserie with more varieties of cheese than most human beings will encounter in a lifetime. Its cheese menu amounts almost to a dare: do you love cheese enough, and do you have the patience, to work your way through nearly 200 cheeses, from cabcou de Rocamadour to the unpronounceable Garrotxa to Sardinia's pride, callu de cabreddu (described on the menu as ''challenging, soft, mouth-numbing'')?

title: To Capture the Cook's Fancy, Not to Mention the Tomato Seeds
description: Even debris, or compost material, is seasonal: corn silk, tomato seeds, bits of herbs and strawberry hulls are some of the annoyances that can clog the sink in summertime. Clearly, such stuff is universal, because the Japanese have a solution: wire mesh strainers, in an array of sizes to fit in the drain.

title: Senator Promises Investigation Into Gasoline Price Rise
description: In a swift display of how a Democratic-run Senate will alter the debate in the capital, one of the newly empowered Democrats announced today that he would open an investigation into the recent increase in gasoline prices.

title: Respected Official Cashiered After Policy Feud Hits the Net : Thai Central Banker Is Dismissed
description: Thailand fired the central-bank governor Tuesday after he got into a spat with the prime minister over interest rates that was played out across the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Hasbro's attempts to revive its G.I. Joe toys misidentified the maker of Elite Force, a competing brand of military action figures. It is the bbi division of Blue Box Toys; Dragon Models is a maker of other military action figures.

title: McVeigh to Decide About Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, May 30  Attorney General John Ashcroft said today that the Justice Department will oppose any possible effort by lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh to postpone his execution because of the F.B.I.'s belated discovery of documents related to the Oklahoma City bombing.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies on Saturday about the Lakers-Spurs playoff game misidentified the computer company whose slogan ''Think Different'' appears in downtown Los Angeles on a mural of great Laker centers. It is Apple Computer, not Microsoft.

title: A Sensible Jury Reform
description: For many years now, judicial reformers in New York State, led by Chief Judge Judith Kaye, have been calling on lawmakers in Albany to end the state's foolish policy of requiring that jurors in all criminal cases involving violent crime be sequestered while they are deliberating, whether they need to be isolated or not. Yesterday the State Legislature finally responded with a sensible reform that will save money, spare jurors needless inconvenience, broaden the pool of jurors able to serve, and improve the quality of justice by preventing juries from rushing to a verdict simply to avoid automatic sequestration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCK, CATHERINE HUDGINS, M.D.
description: TUCK-Catherine Hudgins, M.D. The Department of Medicine mourns the untimely death last Thursday of Dr. Catherine Hudgins Tuck, Irving Assistant Professor of Medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University and Assistant Attending Physician at New YorkPresbyterian Hospital. Dr. Tuck was a cherished member of our faculty, a magnificent physician, and an inspiring and gentle teacher, and in her passing we have lost a radiant, gracious, staunchly courageous, and deeply beloved colleague. Our heartfelt thoughts go out to her husband Edward, her son Hallam, her parents Robert and Cynthia Hudgins, and to all the others of her close and loving family. Myron L. Weisfeldt, M.D. Chairman, Dept of Medicine Columbia University

title: Concerts Rock the Tiny Kingdom of Skullbonia; A Music Park in Rural Tennessee Draws the Stars, Liquor and White Supremacists
description: Touring rock bands are listing a new stop on their itineraries, along with more typical ports of call like Chicago, St. Louis and Nashville. Skullbone, a conservative mile-square hamlet in western Tennessee that derives its peculiar name from a long-ago form of bare-knuckle fighting in which punches were delivered only to the head, has suddenly started drawing major rock and country acts like Lynyrd Skynyrd, George Jones, Eddie Money and the Charlie Daniels Band to what concert promoters are calling the strangest amphitheater in the country.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Immigrant Laborers Win Case
description: Four immigrant laborers, claiming that they were hired for carpentry work in Harlem but not paid, have won a judgment for back wages. The lawyer for the workers, three Mexicans and a Venezuelan, said the verdict was a victory for such workers, many of them illegal immigrants afraid to challenge their employers. The award was announced yesterday by the lawyer, Patricia Ballner, and the Rev. Brian Jordan, the director of a counseling service for immigrants in Manhattan. A Civil Court judge, Doris Ling-Cohan, ruled that the workers were owed $3,290 by a subcontractor, Frank Vasquez, who said he had not hired them. He did not return a call seeking comment. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Power Plant Sale Criticized
description: State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal has urged federal officials to bar the sale of two Connecticut power plants to a Minnesota utility, contending that the utility would then control 80 percent of the market for power in the state. In a brief filed Friday with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which has jurisdiction over the sale, Mr. Blumenthal said such dominance would tempt the utility, NRG Energy Inc. of Minneapolis, to raise prices during peak demand. NRG wants to buy plants in New Haven and Bridgeport from the Wisvest Corporation in Milwaukee.

description: The authorities in New Jersey have charged a registered nurse from Staten Island with killing and dismembering two men in the early 1990's, and said he might be a suspect in other killings in the New York region that ignited fear among gay men and in the bars they frequent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINSTLINGER, JOSEPH NATHAN
description: KINSTLINGER-Joseph Nathan. 33, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died Sunday, May 27, of cardiac arrest while hiking with friends in Boulder, CO. A resident of Denver for the past nine years, Joe was born February 21, 1968, in New Rochelle, NY, the son of Henry Kinstlinger and Julia Pollak Kinstlinger, of New York City, who will miss him dearly. Brother of Felicia Yanger of Tampa, FL, Charlotte Adamis of Kingston, NY, Joyce Kinstlinger of Northfield, VT, and Liz Gale of New York City; grandchild of Anita Pollak, of Maplewood, NJ, and Palm Beach, FL; uncle of Zack, Rachel and Rose Yanger, Max and Harrison Bruhn, and Noah Gale; cousin of Bill Lichtblau, of Vail, CO; and brother-in-law of Bill Yanger, Tony Adamis, and Adam Gale. He recently had introduced to his family Ann Kocourek, of Denver. Joe was active in Metro Denver Partners, an organization that provides at-risk youth with mentors, role models and advocates. He enjoyed being a Big Brother to Stefan for the past five years. Blessed with a broad smile and a quick wit, Joey was known by friends and family for his warmth, generous heart, and delight in the small moments of life. He loved skiing and hiking, and was an avid fan of the New York Yankees, naming his cat, ''Tino'', after the Yankees first baseman, Tino Martinez. He loved to cook and was known to call family members cross-country for favored recipes. He was employed by Qwest Communications. A graduate of Scarsdale High School, he earned a bachelor of arts degree at the University of Vermont and an MBA at the University of Colorado, Denver. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Metro Denver Partners, 303-777-7000, and Colorado Humane Society, 303781-9344. A funeral service will be held 11:45AM on Thursday at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Panel Advises Quarantine for Any Material From Mars

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Profit Up At Fininvest
description: The Italian holding company, Fininvest, which is controlled by Silvio Berlusconi, the newly elected prime minister, reported a 38 percent increase in operating income last year, to 575 million euros ($494.6 million), on a 9 percent revenue increase, to 4.3 billion euros ($3.70 billion), largely on strong results from its TV and financial services businesses. Net income more than doubled to 326 million euros ($280.4 million), from 140 million euros ($120.4 million) in 1999. Fininvest owns a controlling 48 percent share of Italy's biggest commercial TV company, Mediaset, and holds part-ownership of Mediolanum, an insurance and financial services concern. The results were marred only by a 10 percent drop in income at Arnoldo Mondadori Editore, Italy's biggest magazine and book publisher, in which Fininvest owns a 48 percent stake. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Japan: Seeking Trust In Nuclear Power
description: Prime Minis ter Junichiro Koizumi said he would have to work with electricity companies to persuade the public that nuclear power is safe. His statement came after voters in Kariwamura, 185 miles northwest of Tokyo, rejected plans by the country's biggest utility to use a hotly debated new technology at an existing nuclear plant that would allow it to burn a plutonium-uranium mixture created from the enriched spent fuel from other reactors. Howard French (NYT)

title: In the Grip Of Emotion, Even While Sleeping

title: Store-Cut Vegetables Give Busy Cooks a Head Start
description: FOR years I have been subject to puzzled looks at the supermarket checkout as my plastic bags filled with vegetables from the salad bar make their way down the conveyor belt. Curiosity finally overcame one cashier, who asked why I put broccoli florets in one bag, chopped onion in another and diced celery in a third. Why weren't they in a salad tray, she wondered. And where was the dressing?

title: 'Marathon Man' and Root Canals
description: When people hear that I do root canals for a living, the typical reactions are ''I'd rather have a baby'' and ''I'd rather be audited by the I.R.S.'' Endodontics takes a lot of teasing in the public domain so people think they will be screaming in pain when there is hardly any during the procedure.

title: Zen on the Prison Grapevine; Support Network Grows for Inmates' Buddhist Practice
description: In a room where the cinder block walls are painted white, 14 men sit in facing rows, each man on a small, round pillow, his legs folded, his gaze lowered. Nearby sits a robed Buddhist monk, a small altar at his back. The stillness is so profound it seems to muffle the blare of a television in the next room.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Brewer Profits
description: Lion Nathan, one of Australia's biggest brewers, said its profit rose 16 percent, to 89 million Australian dollars ($46.3 million), in the first half of the year despite an increase in beer taxes that softened demand. In the period ended March 31, the company expanded sales of higher-growth premium and light beer and cut costs. Lion Nathan is trying to establish a premium wine business in the Pacific Rim and has acquired 62 percent of New Zealand's largest wine company, the Montana Group.

title: Powell Fails to Persuade NATO on Antimissile Plan
description: In his first effort to sell President Bush's missile defense plan to allies, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell failed today to pierce NATO's sharp opposition. He could not even convince them that a threat of a missile attack against their countries actually exists.

title: Modern Efficiency Displaces Historic Psychiatric Hospital

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Service Disruptions At Pacific Bell
description: Internet users in California who rely on Pacific Bell's network continued to experience problems yesterday after a widespread interruption on Friday of the data network operated by Advanced Solutions Inc., a sister company of Pacific Bell. The interruption, which began Friday morning, affected 22,000 circuits across California, each of which potentially serves hundreds of customers, said a Pacific Bell spokesman, John Britton. Mr. Britton said most service had been restored by Friday, but some customers had problems as late as yesterday. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Iljaz Sinanoski, Bitola, Macedonia, May 6, 2001
description: he night of April 30, while everybody was asleep, some 50 stores were burned down in Bitola, and some houses, too. It was the Macedonian youth who did it. This did not come out of the blue: two days before, eight security men -- four Macedonian policemen from Bitola and four soldiers -- were killed by Albanian rebels. But these were not only Albanian shops. They were also Muslim Macedonian and Turkish. We are Macedonians too, of Islamic faith. All in all, our family lost three out of seven shops. The people who did this came back the next day, around lunchtime, and then thoroughly looted one of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRELL, JAMES EDWARD PATRICK
description: FARRELL-James Edward Patrick, 58, on May 28th. Beloved husband of Kathleen (Kate), loving father of Jeffrey of Glendora, New Jersey, Susan of Buenos Aires, Argentina, Audra of New York City, Brian of Somerdale, NJ, and Casey of Hermosa Beach, California. Cherished grandfather of Sarah, Brittney, Jesse, Tyler, Tomas, and Benjamin James. Son of Anna Valle (Demarchise) and the late James E. Farrell, brother of Kathy Roche of North White Plains, son-in-law of Arthur and Catherine Glesmer, Lehigh, FL. Predeceased by a son, Thomas Moore. At the time of his death Mr. Farrell was vice president and assistant general counsel, Colgate Palmolive Company, and was a former partner in the Law firms of Jones, Day, Reavis and Pogue, Los Angeles and Epstein, Becker, Princeton, NJ. Mr. Farrell was a Vietnam Air Force veteran and a graduate of Manhattan College and the Unversity of Notre Dame Law School. A Mass of Christian burial will be at St. Matthew's Church, Hastings, on Thursday at 10 AM. Interment following at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Imus Ranch for Children with Cancer, the Tomorrow's Children Fund, or the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center pediatric floor are appreciated.

title: City Cuts Hanover's Office Staff and Her Security Detail
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cut in half the office staff of his estranged wife, Donna Hanover, yesterday as police officials announced separately that they had reassigned three members of Ms. Hanover's security detail to other jobs.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.N. And Taliban Still At Odds
description: In the midst of life-imperiling drought, talks failed to resolve differences between the ruling Taliban and United Nations aid officials over a planned survey to assess food distribution. Under the Taliban's interpretations of Islamic law, men cannot enter homes to interview women. The United Nations wants to hire Afghan women to do the work; the Taliban refuse to allow women to work outside the home. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: LEGG MASON IS BUYING INVESTMENT FIRM FOR $1.4 BILLION
description: Legg Mason Inc. agreed yesterday to pay as much as $1.38 billion to buy Private Capital Management L.P., a closely held investment firm in Naples, Fla., that manages more than $8 billion for wealthy people and institutions. Legg Mason will pay $682 million when the purchase closes plus two additional amounts based on the firm's performance three and five years later, Legg Mason said in a statement. The purchase will give the Baltimore-based investment firm an asset management business that has delivered a 24 percent annual return since 1986 as its clients swelled from one family to about 1,500 individuals, families and institutions. In the five years ended Dec. 31, Private Capital's revenue had risen at an annual rate of 48 percent.

title: McVeigh Allows Preparation Of Papers for Execution Stay
description: Timothy J. McVeigh has instructed his lawyers to draft papers seeking a stay of his execution on June 11, but is waiting until later this week to decide whether to file them, his lawyer said today.

title: The Children's Hours
description: About as many children watched television on Saturday mornings this past television season as during the last one -- roughly 9.2 million -- but they did not watch the same networks in the same volume.

title: One Gender Wall Left Standing
description: When Elizabeth Jackson traded her ballet slippers for racing spikes, she had no idea that her dance skills would enable her to set the pace in erasing the last gender barrier in track and field.

title: U.S. and Albany Agree to Provide Health Benefits to Uninsured Poor
description: The Bush and Pataki administrations have reached an agreement that permits New York to begin providing medical coverage to 600,000 uninsured New Yorkers, according to state and federal officials involved in the negotiations.

title: Whacking The Competition
description: Before too severe a case of ''Sopranos'' withdrawal kicks in on Sunday nights at 9, HBO executives want to cement their hold on that time period.

title: Beijing Journal; A Maoist Hero's Ghost Tilts With Falun Gong
description: Lei Feng to the rescue, once again!

title: Once on TV, Now in Law and Order (Seriously)
description: BRIDGET GALE BRENNAN is the kind of woman all mothers wanted their sons to date. She is blessed with telegenic good looks, which she put to use for a while as a television reporter, as well as that sunny attitude that Midwesterners slyly use to humble the rest of us. She has a quick, agile mind. She is determined and committed.

title: Russia's Role in Missile Defense
description: It is not surprising that the Bush administration's new effort to persuade Russia to scrap the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty has received a chilly reception in Moscow. It fails to address Russia's central concern, to ensure there are strict limits -- or at least clearly defined ones -- on the development and deployment of antimissile systems.

title: A Biologist's Choice Gives Priority to Students
description: When Jill Bargonetti was a postdoctoral fellow working on a tumor- suppressing protein, p53, at Columbia University, she was able to publish papers about her work in a leading journal, Cell, and other prestigious publications. Professors she worked with suggested that she continue her work at a research university like Columbia or Princeton.

title: America And Its Trial Seem to Be So Far Away
description: James Oyugi was doing the same thing tonight that he was on Aug. 7, 1998: working at a bus stop at one of the busiest intersections in downtown Nairobi. That day, he heard a huge explosion, from the American Embassy right across the street, then felt the shards from a shattering shop window dig into his scalp.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Director For AARP
description: William D. Novelli has been chosen the next executive director of AARP. Mr. Novelli, who has been director of public affairs for the organization for 17 months, will take over from Horace B. Deets on June 4. Mr. Deets has headed AARP since 1988. AARP is a nonprofit, nonpartisan advocacy group for people 50 and older. It recorded 34.3 million members in 2000.

title: Technology Shares Drop On Concern Over Earnings
description: Shares of large technology companies retreated yesterday as investors began to doubt that corporate earnings growth would justify their recent enthusiasm.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Free Downtown Buses
description: A free bus service is being developed for New York City's financial district. Starting early next year, eight buses will operate on a route with about a dozen stops in the southern tip of Manhattan, said Michael O'Connor, head of operations and planning for the Alliance for Downtown New York, the neighborhood and business improvement group that plans to operate the buses. The stops will include the World Trade Center, the Staten Island Ferry and the South Street Seaport, Mr. O'Connor said. The electricity-powered buses, which have 22 seats and space for 15 standing passengers, will run from midmorning into the evening.

title: Report Links Dancer's Death to Police Scuffle
description: A Pennsylvania pathologist has found that the death of Jose Greco, the flamenco dancer, last December was caused by an infection he developed after breaking his toe in a scuffle with Amtrak police officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALIN, RUSSELL D.
description: PALIN-Russell D. In Waterford, Connecticut. Russell D. Palin of Guilford, Connecticut, formerly of 382 Central Park West, New York. Beloved partner of Wilhelmine Corinth. Brother of Rita Nelmes of Smithfield, IL and Fred Palin of Cuba, IL. He was born in Cuba, on June 20, 1924 son of the late Fred and Laura Palin. He originally started his musical career as a violinist and attended The Juilliard School of Music. Upon completing military service in World War II he made the transition from violin to voice. His New York debut recital was at Carnegie Recital Hall in 1965 and he has appeared with the American Opera Society, Thomas Scherman Concert Opera and the New York Philharmonic. He has appeared on television on such shows as NBC Opera, Hallmark Hall of Fame, Edge of Night, Arthur Murray Party, To Tell the Truth. He also owned and operated his own Ballroom Dance Studio. Funeral service will be held Thursday morning at 11:00 in Christ Church, Park Ave. at 60th St. The W.S. Clancy Memorial Funeral Home, 504 Main St., Branford, CT. See obit @ wsclancy.com.

title: Lamoriello Minimizes the Carryover Effect
description: DENVER, May 29  His team was buried, 5-0, by the Colorado Avalanche in Game 1 of the Stanley Cup finals here last Saturday night. But Devils General Manager Lou Lamoriello did not think there would be a carryover effect heading into tonight's Game 2, or over the rest of the four-of-seven-game series.

title: How to Make 21,000 Classroom Libraries
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a raft of education proposals in his final state-of-the-city speech in January, one in particular seemed to assure him a solid legacy: the creation of small libraries in each of the city's 21,000 elementary and middle school classrooms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALGLEY, WILLIAM
description: BALGLEY-William. Of Ardsley, NY, on May 26, 2001. Beloved husband of Annabelle (nee Kaminetsky). Devoted father of Lynn, Gina Doynow and Jennifer Wells, brother Howard; sons-in-law Robert Cohen, Bruce Doynow and Jay Wells and grandfather of David Cohen. He is also survived by sisters-in-law Paula Balgley and Charlotte Fragakis and brother-inlaw Frank Fragakis. William was an associate publisher for magazines including ''Popular Science,'' ''Outdoor Life'' and ''Argosy.'' He served with the Second and Fifth Marine Divisions. He fought in the battle of Iwo Jima. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Community Hospital of Dobbs Ferry, 128 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, New York 10522.

title: I Feel an Affinity for Youth
description: I still remember the first expensive gadget I bought, a calculator at Radio Shack in the Eastwood Mall in Niles, Ohio. I had saved money from doing yardwork with other members of the high school football team. I am pretty sure that I was the only one who spent the money on a calculator.

title: 'As You Go Forth . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Remains Neutral in Mayoral Race
description: Gov. George E. Pataki declined today to weigh in on the New York mayoral race and instead doled out equal praise for both potential Republican contenders. He did so even though one of his top aides has apparently been working behind the scenes on behalf of Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Dont Believe the Type
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEFARIKI, DEMITRI
description: TEFARIKI-Demitri. May 30, 2001 at age 80. Former husband of Alice. Beloved father of Helen Tefariki Lifgren and Philip Tefariki, cherished grandfather of Philip, Stephany, Sofia, Demitri, Nikolette and Francis. Mr. Tefariki was born and raised in Alexandria, Egypt, immigrated to Greece and later came to the United States where he became a founder and partner of Coffee Associates, Inc. He was a true gentleman who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (at 81st Street) Friday, June 1, 3-5 and 7-9PM. For funeral information call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500

title: McVeigh to Seek Delay of Execution
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  Lawyers for Timothy J. McVeigh said today that the convicted Oklahoma City bomber has now decided to seek a stay of execution after all, "to promote integrity in the criminal justice system."

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Former F.B.I. Agent Pleads Not Guilty in Spy Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 31  Former F.B.I. agent Robert Hanssen pleaded not guilty in federal court here today to charges that he spied for Moscow for more than 15 years.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Strip-Searches Prompt Firings
description: The warden of the city jail and three corrections officers have been fired after complaints by middle school students that they were strip-searched in a tour of the jail. Nine boys, ages 11 to 15, who were taken to the jail by a teacher and a school disciplinary official on May 17, told school officials they were forced to disrobe in front of correctional officers and other students. The employees were fired for violating jail policy. The warden, Patricia Britton, was dismissed for not taking appropriate action after the incident was reported, officials said.

title: 100 Years in Pen and Pencil
description: Their drawings, watercolors, oils and etchings tell a story of exotic places, wars, Main Street, fashions and fables, and some of their work can be seen on the Web site of the Society of Illustrators, which is celebrating its 100th anniversary (www.societyillustrators

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUEN, EDITH C.
description: GRUEN-Edith C. Passed away at age 73 on May 28, 2001 in NYC after many years of enduring Kidney Disease. Survived by her brother Peter also of NYC. Donations in her memory may be made to Selfhelp Community Services, Inc. or The Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Loudeye Signs AOL Contract
description: Loudeye Technologies, which makes software to broadcast audio and video on the Internet, said it had struck a multiyear deal to provide America Online with music samples, music encoding and related digital media services. The Seattle-based company will also provide technology to encode music on spinner.com, an AOL-owned Web site that offers customized audio programming. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The lobster is perhaps one of the only species that's been intensively fished for 150 years and is doing better today than ever.''

title: Bees Buzz A Path To His Hive
description: IT'S swarming time, and Ron Breland, who lost half of his honeybees last year, has captured three new colonies. He has put considerable thought into just where the bees will live next.

title: President Promises to Increase Spending on Backlog of Repairs at the National Parks
description: In his first major speech about the environment since he took office, President Bush stood beneath the ancient sequoias here today and announced plans to increase federal spending to help end a backlog of billions of dollars in repairs to national parks.

title: 800-Pound Trout Better Watch Out
description: Traditionally, spinning reels have been designed to handle midsize game fish or small fry like trout. But the new Van Staal VS400 has brought the casting ease of a spinning reel into the hands of big-game anglers. The company says that the reel, which will be available in July, has the fish-stopping power for an 800-pound tuna or marlin.

title: The Mideast Impasse
description: To the Editor:

title: A Colombian Human Rights Figure Is the New Defense Minister
description: Gustavo Bell, who as Colombia's vice president directed the government's human rights efforts, has been chosen to replace Luis Fernando Ramrez as minister of defense. Mr. Ramrez, who resigned on Friday and may run for president in next year's election, is credited with overseeing the modernization of the Colombian Army, which had suffered a string of battlefield defeats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, CARLTON H., M.D.
description: BLAKE-Carlton H., M.D., Practicing psychiatrist of Amityville, Mercy Hospital and H.I.P. Beloved husband of Carmelita. Devoted father of David. Viewing and service Friday June 1st at I.J. Morris Funeral Home, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, L.I. 1-4 PM, 6-9 PM.

title: Corrections
description: A map on May 22 with an article about plans for a World War II memorial on the Mall in Washington carried an erroneous scale. The line represented 500 feet, not 5,000. Thus the memorial would be about 1,000 feet west of the Washington Monument.

title: A New Palm Under $5 For Those Who Hate Gadgets
description: Unlike previous hand-held computers, a recently released version of the Palm has no memory, no stylus and no screen, and it doesn't sync with a desktop computer. Furthermore, it has no software and no third-party developers, it can't be connected wirelessly to the Internet, and it isn't even made by Palm Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 17 about an exhibition of architectural follies at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, N.Y., misstated the surname of an architect who, with Robert A. M. Stern, designed a gazebo shaped like an armchair. And a correction on this page last Thursday misstated his given name. He is Daniel Lobitz, not Robert and not Lovitz.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Democrat Abandons Race
description: Representative Bob Clement, Democrat of Nashville, has decided against running for governor next year, saying he is not willing to compete in a tough primary against former Mayor Phil Bredesen of Nashville. Mr. Clement said he would shut down an exploratory committee and return donations. Recent polls showed that Mr. Clement, the son of a former governor, would have been competitive with Mr. Bredesen. The leading Republican contender is Representative Van Hilleary. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Kenya, Compensation Is a Priority
description: ''Justice has been done,'' Charles Abiuda said today outside his office, which was damaged when the United States Embassy here was bombed in August 1998. But in the next breath he added: ''There is much which has been left out. And it needs to be taken care of.''

title: State Assembly to Hit Airwaves Starting Monday
description: New Yorkers will be able to watch the State Assembly live on television for the first time on Monday, leaders of the chamber announced today, a day after the State Senate began broadcasting its sessions live on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTARELLI, ANGELO
description: BOTARELLI-Angelo. Age 84. Immigrated from Viterbo, Italy in 1953 on the Andrea Doria. Owner of Angelo's Diamond Touch Barber Shop for 46 years in Boro Park, Brooklyn. A true gentleman. He is survived by his wife Erika and his two children, Anna and Marco. His daughter-in-law Antoinette and two wonderful grandsons Fabio and Stefan who will always remember his passion for life. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Rosalia's R.C. Church, Brooklyn Friday 9:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Churchill School, 212-722-0610 would be appreciated.

title: It's Getting Really Late Early for the Mets
description: Darren Bragg lost the ball as soon as it left Pat Burrell's bat. It was a high pop fly, giving Bragg, the Mets' left fielder, some time to recover. So he drifted to where he thought the ball would go, then looked to the infielders for navigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, KALMAN
description: HOROWITZ-Kalman. A Holocaust survivor. Devoted husband of Celia, cherished father of Florence and Michael Barkan, Leo and Dina and Robert, cherished grandfather of Molly, Matthew, Yael, Ilana and Keren. Services were conducted on Wednesday, May 30.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Webmethods and KPMG Plan Venture
description: WebMethods will team up with KPMG Consulting to provide software and services intended to help companies streamline operations by integrating computer applications, work flow and other business activities, the companies said. The companies will promote technology integration to financial services and manufacturing companies. As part of the alliance, the companies will also create an online course to train employees of KPMG Consulting in effective use of the webMethods offerings. KPMG Consulting, based in McLean, Va., serves more than 2,500 clients; WebMethods of Fairfax, Va., has more than 600 clients. Despite the KPMG deal, webMethods shares fell $2.74, or 9.1 percent, to $27.40.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Inspectors View I.R.A. Arms
description: International monitors disclosed they had carried out their third inspection of secret Irish Republican Army weapons dumps and found them secure and untouched. But David Trimble, the Protestant leader of the power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly, said the move represented no progress on the I.R.A.'s promise to put their arms ''completely and verifiably beyond use.'' Under pressure from hard-liners, he has pledged to resign his leadership position on July 1 unless the I.R.A. begins disarming by then. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: With Phone Headsets, It's So Easy to Gab Away
description: TELEPHONE headsets, once the exclusive domain of switchboard operators and customer service representatives, have become standard gear in many offices, not to mention a necessity for the cell phone users who find them more comfortable or safer than trying to cradle tiny phones on their shoulders when they are driving.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Neighborly Entertainment

title: Corrections
description: A May 3 letter, ''Hitler's 1918 Diagnosis,'' referred incorrectly to a 1943 report about Hitler's mental status. The report cited the findings of Dr. Edmund Forster, who had examined Hitler, but was not based on a ''1943 interview'' with Dr. Forster, who died in 1933.

title: Nets Take a Look At 7-1 Arizona Center
description: The Nets held a workout yesterday for Loren Woods, the 7-foot-1 center from the University of Arizona, and the Nets' president, Rod Thorn, offered this immediate assessment: ''Very tall.''

title: Microsoft to Introduce New Version of Office
description: Discounting an imminent federal court ruling that could limit the company's march toward dominating the commercial Internet, Microsoft plans to introduce on Thursday a new version of its Office program that is the most Internet-connected product yet from the company.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Strikes Down Higher Rent
description: A state judge struck down a higher rent for a Manhattan apartment that was no longer rent-controlled. Both the landlord and tenant groups saw something to dispute in the judge's ruling and are appealing the decision. The case turned on an apartment vacated at 929 West End Avenue and the new tenants, who challenged the $1,050 rent. The State Division of Housing and Community Renewal set an even higher rent. Justice Leland DeGrasse of State Supreme Court, in a decision reported by The New York Law Journal, ruled that the landlord had to first prove entitlement to the increase. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Idaho Senior First In Women's Discus
description: Katja Schreiber of Idaho, a senior from Germany, won the first event of the N.C.A.A. track and field championships in Eugene, Ore., yesterday as she threw the discus 197 feet 11 inches. That was 131/2 feet better than the throw by Liz Toman of Colorado State, who was second.

title: DEBT RATING OF UNITED AIRLINES IS REDUCED BY MOODY'S
description: United Airlines' senior unsecured debt was lowered to junk status by Moody's Investors Service, part of a downgrade affecting $12.9 billion in debt securities for the company, the operating unit of the UAL Corporation. Moody's cut the United debt one notch to Ba-1 from Baa-3, citing continued losses and rising labor costs. The change came one day after Moody's lowered ratings on $5.2 billion in debt at the US Airways Group, which UAL has offered to buy. The downgrade came after UAL posted a first-quarter loss from operations of $305 million, or $5.82 a share. The company reported higher costs from new labor contracts and a drop in business travel.

title: Addenda: Changes at 2 Agencies to Mean Some Layoffs
description: Two agencies are making changes that involve layoffs.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Officers Blamed For Death
description: A state grand jury in Jackson has blamed two law enforcement officers for killing a man in a student protest in 1967. The grand jury concluded that Buddy Kane, a former Jackson police captain, and Lloyd Jones, a former highway patrolman, both now dead, fired shotguns at Ben Brown after demonstrators at Jackson State University threw rocks at officers. Mr. Brown, who was not taking part in the protest, was shot in the back. Kevin Sack (NYT)

description: ROGERS-Adele Langston. Dear Adele, your love of family, education and nature will always inspire us. We will miss you.

title: Rain Clears Some Smoke, But Fires Persist in Florida
description: Despite several days of rain, brush fires that have consumed hundreds of thousands of drought-parched acres in Florida continued to burn today throughout the state.

title: Expos Expected to Dismiss Felipe Alou
description: The foundering Montreal Expos are expected to dismiss Manager Felipe Alou, possibly as early as today, according to an official from a National League team who requested anonymity. The Expos have the third-worst record in the league and the worst attendance figures in the major leagues, but Alou, 66, had been considered one of the jewels of the organization for the last 10 seasons.

description: A federal grand jury indicted a senior police commander yesterday in connection with accusations that he stole money from drug dealers about six years ago, a senior law enforcement official said.

description: Odd as it may seem, George E. Pataki, the Republican governor of New York, appears to be accomplishing one of Hillary Rodham Clinton's most treasured goals.

description: From the White House's aggrieved and somewhat befuddled perspective, President Bush and his aides have always approached Democrats with open arms and simply not gotten proper credit for it.

title: 12-Year Term in Largest Securities Fraud
description: Robert Catoggio, a co-founder of Hanover, Sterling & Company and three other New York brokerage firms that are now defunct, was sentenced to almost 12 years in prison yesterday in a case described by the authorities as the largest securities fraud ever prosecuted.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Down At Grocer
description: J Sainsbury P.L.C. said that profit for the year fell 25 percent, as lower earnings at its Homebase chain of home-improvement stores and losses in Egypt offset improvements in its British supermarkets business. For the year to March 31, earnings fell to 262 million ($373 million), or 13.7 pence a share, compared with 349 million, or 18.2 pence a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales grew 6 percent, to 18.4 billion ($26.2 billion). Sainsbury sold Homebase to a private equity firm for 975 million in December. Sainsbury is also selling its Egyptian supermarkets, which lost 35 million last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Yet Another Reason Why Dogs Need Thumbs
description: Tired of tripping over the dog dish? Mary Douglas Drysdale, an interior designer in Washington, has large Great Danes -- and a handy solution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINDES, ALVIN I.
description: MINDES-Alvin I. Of Tappan, NY. Passed away May 28, 2001. Born 1937 in the Bronx, NY to Rose and Sam Mindes. After serving 4 years in the Navy he went on to become a CPA eventually building a successful accounting practice. His latest project was helping his children build Eagle Drive Golf in Florida NY. He was a dedicated husband, a loving and generous father and will be deeply missed by those who knew, loved and adored him. Beloved husband for 42 years of Joanne, devoted father of Steven, Michael and Haley. Loving brother of Maureen. Cherished grandfather of Jennifer Rei, dear father-in-law of Beth. Services will be held Friday 11:45am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: British-U.S. Plan to Ease Curb On Iraq Seems Stalled for Now
description: A proposal by the United States and Britain to loosen restrictions on trade with Iraq while tightening controls against oil smuggling and illegal arms sales is meeting strong opposition in the Security Council and is unlikely to be adopted soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURROS, JANET
description: BURROS-Janet. Our deepest sympathy goes out to the entire family of Janet Burros. She was a very special lady and we are lucky to have had the privilege of sharing her kindness. We will miss you. Fredda, Drew and David Goldberg

title: This Time, 80's Populist Sounds Capitalist Theme in Peru
description: As the former president Alan Garca campaigned across the Andean highlands, there were flashes of his old populist allure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINZIG, NATHAN
description: GINZIG-Nathan. Age 76, on May 26, 2001. Devoted husband to Iris, loving father to Randy and Amy Krakow, adoring grandfather to Bradley and Courtney, father-inlaw to Carol and Gary. Services were held May 27 in Florida.

title: I.N.S. Proposes Expediting Work Visas for $1,000 Fee
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  In a pilot program aimed at raising money to reduce years-long backlogs for citizenship and permanent legal residency, the Immigration and Naturalization Service will on Friday begin allowing scientists, athletes, celebrities and foreign executives to pay $1,000 to get temporary work visas processed within 15 days instead of two months or more.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Bishop Resigns Over Gay Ban
description: Bishop Paul W. Egertson, whose Lutheran synod covers Los Angeles and a broad swath of coastal Southern California, said he would resign on July 31, a month before his term is to end. He violated church policy by participating in the ordination of a lesbian pastor in St. Paul in April. In an open letter to clergy in his synod, the bishop, who has six sons, one of whom is gay, said he had participated in the event as an act of ''ecclesiastical disobedience.'' His denomination, the 5.1 million-member Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, forbids the ordination of gay clergy who are not celibate. Gustav Niebuhr (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORFMAN, ALEX
description: DORFMAN-Alex, died May 30. Husband of the late Helen Dorfman. He was 98 years old and lived independently until the end. Cherished father of Roslyn Levin and Jerry Dorfman and the late Marcia Dorfman. Beloved fatherin-law of Karen Dorfman. Cherished grandfather of Ava and Jeffrey Dorfman, Michael, Abby, Ruth and Jackie Levin, and greatgrandfather of Jacob, Noah and Andrew Levin. He was a member of the Traditional Synagogue and Brotherhood in Co-op City, the Bronx. Services will be held on Thursday, May 31, at the Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Ave., 914-834-6120, at 12:30 PM.

description: From the very outset of the nostalgia- and memory-drenched ''Vocal Lords,'' a single question hangs in the air: What happened to separate two boyhood friends from Bensonhurst for some 40 years?

title: South Africa Regrets Its Role in a Defendant's Extradition
description: South Africa's role in handing over one defendant in the American embassy bombings trial was harshly criticized today in the wake of a verdict on Tuesday that left that defendant, Khalfan Khamis Mohamed, facing a death penalty.

title: Liquor and Tears and Pain, All Flowing in Abundance
description: Hugh Marriner is that romantic figure, a dissolute young man in need. He needs to sell a story to his film director friend Maurice Hussey, but he'll settle for a 200 loan. (This is London in the summer of 1945, and most of his friends couldn't lend him 2.) He needs some attention from Nigel, his companion of nine years, who is spending his evenings with a wealthy woman who he hopes will finance his dress designing career. Most of all, Hugh needs a drink.

title: Trial Poked Holes in Image Of bin Laden's Terror Group
description: Before the embassy bombings trial, Osama bin Laden loomed large in the American psyche, a villain of unimaginable evil and sophisticated reach. It was an image fed by destruction done and by American law enforcement eager to drive home the reality of his threat. In some ways, though, it was an image created because so little was known about how he worked.

title: 3,000 Job Cuts Are Set by Roche
description: Roche Holding A.G., the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, said today that it would eliminate 3,000 jobs over the next two to three years to cut costs, with the biggest losses to come at its United States headquarters in Nutley, N.J.

title: Food Industry Sets Tougher Labeling Rules for Allergens
description: Racing against the specter of tighter regulation, many of the largest food companies have agreed to specify whether the products they sell contain even tiny amounts of everyday ingredients that can cause potentially fatal allergic reactions.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Connection To Buy Outpost.Com
description: The struggling Internet electronics retailer Outpost.com said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by PC Connection, a direct marketer of PC's, in a stock swap. The exact financial terms of the deal will be determined at a later date, but PC Connection, based in Merrimack, N.H., said it would immediately provide Cyberian Outpost.com, known formally as Cyberian Outpost Inc., with $8 million in credit lines. Each share of Cyberian Outpost common stock will be converted into shares of PC Connection common stock at an exchange ratio that will be based on Cyberian's revenue for June, July and August and on the average closing price of PC Connection shares for the 10 days before the deal's closing. Last month, Outpost laid off 30 percent of its workers and appointed a new chief executive to help refocus its business. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: The A line was eerily quiet and the second line was slumping again. Even so, the Devils could still celebrate in Bob Corkum's hotel room.

description: In the latest of a raft of acquisitions of medical device makers, Tyco International agreed yesterday to buy C. R. Bard, based in Murray Hill, N.J., for $3.13 billion in stock. Separately, Medtronic Inc. said that it planned to buy MiniMed Inc., based in Northridge, Calif., and the allied Medical Research Group Inc. of Sylmar, Calif., for a total of $3.7 billion in cash and stock.
