But what if you wanted to share some of the more than 100 hours of music you could store on the Jukebox with the rest of world? One answer is the PlayDock PD200 from Cambridge Soundworks, a subsidiary of Creative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CERUSSI, MICHAEL A.
description: CERUSSI-Michael A., died on May 30, 2001, after a prolonged illness. He was 77 and lived in Harrison, N.Y. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Anne; sons, Michael A. Jr. of Greenwich, CT and Thomas F. of Stamford, CT; daughters, Rosemary Ferrer of Greenwich, CT and Nancy A. McEnaney of Ridgefield, CT; a sister, Julia Breitenbach of Ft. Lauderdale, FL and eight grandchildren. A son, Ernest, predeceased him in 1994. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Saturday, June 2, 2001 at 10:00 a.m. at Our Lady of Sorrow's Church, Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, New York, Interment Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, New York.

title: In Ravaged English City, Racial Mix Was Volatile
description: The one thing that everyone in this shell-shocked community seems to agree on is that it all began quietly, with a run-of-the-mill argument between two teenage boys -- one white, one a Briton of Pakistani origin -- outside a fish-and-chip shop.

description: The Fort Worth Dallas Ballet is a company in search of an artistic profile. Its return to New York after a decade (to the Joyce Theater, where it opened on Tuesday night for a run through Sunday) seems designed to show it off in a more eclectic phase than in the past.

title: Desperately Seeking Synergy
description: Just before tickets for the United States leg of Madonna's Drowned World Tour went on sale, America Online tried a fail-safe experiment. As the tour's sponsor, it released a large number of tickets ahead of time, making them available only to new subscribers to America Online (with a minimum signup of three months). This drove new members to the service (as well as prompt old members to buy new accounts).

description: William North Jayme, a direct-mail copywriter who elevated magazine subscription solicitations to an art form, died on May 18 at his home in Sonoma, Calif. He was 75.

title: Ex-Aide Guilty As France Ends Big Graft Case
description: A Paris court sentenced the flamboyant former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, to six months in jail today and also convicted four co-defendants in a huge corruption case that has shaken France's political establishment and transfixed the public with its heady revelations of sex, power and greed among the once-revered elite.

description: A panel of experts appointed by Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has recommended that a more demanding high school math curriculum be created for students who want it because, it said, current programs geared to state standards are not rigorous enough to meet the needs of thousands of college-bound students.

title: As Italian Ponders Cabinet, Familiar Rumbling on the Right
description: The Italian Senate elected as its speaker today a lawmaker proposed by the newly elected prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, a step that paves the way for him to form a cabinet, but also illustrates the political tensions simmering within his center-right coalition.

description: The European Commission proposed new restrictions on tobacco advertising today, seven months after a court overturned a previous ban.

title: Charley Pell Is Dead at 60; Ousted as Florida Coach
description: Charley Pell, who coached the University of Florida to football prominence in the 1980's but was fired amid highly publicized violations of N.C.A.A. rules, died Tuesday in Southside, Ala. He was 60.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Help From The Vatican
description: The Vatican sent two envoys to Jerusalem to try to help end violence between the Israelis and the Palestinians. Cardinal Pio Laghi and Msgr. Giovanni d'Anielo expect to meet with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. They will also be carrying a letter to the leaders from John Paul II. Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

title: A Sea Change in Sea Ranch
description: SEA RANCH, Calif. -- Here on the California coast, 110 miles north of San Francisco, a community begun in the spirit of the 1960's struggles to maintain its architectural ideals.

title: Architects Rush to the Ramparts In a Battle Over Creative Credit
description: When does architecture begin?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGGER, LYDIA
description: BRAGGER-Lydia. Died peacefully in her residence in New York on May 23rd. She was 97. Talk show host and advocate for the aging, she founded The New York City Gray Panthers. Memorial service at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 3 P.M. June 8th. Memorial donations to Gray Panthers.

title: Scripps Team Builds a Mouse That Can Get Its Feet Wet
description: When the Scripps Institution of Oceanography acquired last year an ultrasensitive digital camera that can take pictures with just a few photons of light available, it soon ran into a problem. The camera needed a personal computer and a mouse to operate. As a result, the computer remained on board a ship while the lens and light sensor were lowered about 100 feet into the sea.

title: Bush Speaks on Environment
description: In his first major environmental speech since he took office, President Bush announced plans to help end a backlog of billions of dollars in repairs to national parks. Page A25.

title: SARA LEE FORECASTS REDUCED PROFITS NEXT YEAR
description: The Sara Lee Corporation, maker of Jimmy Dean sausages and Hanes underwear, said yesterday that profit might fall in the next fiscal year and that it would reorganize its domestic meat and hosiery businesses and European intimate apparel units in an attempt to cut costs and increase sales. Sara Lee, based in Chicago, will earn $1.25 to $1.35 a share in the fiscal year ending June 30, 2002, because it will spend more on marketing and technology, its chief financial officer, Cary D. McMillan, said during a conference with analysts and investors. In April, Sara Lee said it would earn $1.34 to $1.37 a share in fiscal 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOPLIK, KENNETH E.
description: KOPLIK-Kenneth E. May 31, 1996. Our hearts abound with loving memories that continue to inspire us to live each day in affirmation of your indomitable spirit. David has embraced your legacy with extraordinary grace and wisdom. He is truly your posthumous gift to the world. Diane

title: Bush's Twins Linked to Alcohol Incident
description: The Austin police and the Texas Alcohol Beverage Commission are investigating a report that President Bush's twin 19-year-old daughters tried to buy alcohol illegally at a popular Mexican restaurant on Tuesday night.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Indicted In Girl's Death
description: A maintenance man has been indicted by a Bronx grand jury in the rape and killing of an 11-year girl, the Bronx district attorney said yesterday. Clarence Moss, 44, of 3225 Olinville Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder, two counts of first-degree rape and other crimes for the death of Tamiqua Gutierrez, who died on May 8. He is being held without bail. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Senator Quits To Avoid Trial
description: Rather than face an impeachment trial that could strip him of his political rights for a decade, Antnio Carlos Magalhaes, the all-powerful president of the senate until three months ago, has resigned his seat with a blast at the government alliance he once dominated. Mr. Magalhaes, accused of tampering with the Senate's vote tallying system, complained of being treated unjustly but said he would soon run for office again. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Transcript of Jack Curry's Visit to the Major League Baseball Forum
description: Jack Curry, who covers baseball for The Times, visited the forum on Thursday, May 31, to discuss the season so far. Here is a transcript.

title: NEW LAW RELEASES JURIES IN NEW YORK FROM SEQUESTERING
description: For the first time in more than 100 years, New York jurors deliberating the fate of criminal defendants will no longer have to be sequestered overnight in state-financed hotel rooms, under the watch of armed, uniformed court officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, DAVID ALAN WHITWELL, M.D
description: WILSON-David Alan Whitwell, M.D, May 29, 2001. Of Montpelier, VT, formerly of Rye, NY. Surgeon and President of the Medical Staff at United Hospital, Port Chester, NY. Son of the late Philip Whitwell and Alice Selena Collins Wilson. Devoted husband of the late Madeleine Holden Wilson and of Marjorie Bannon White Wilson. Loving father of Holden Charles Wilson, of New Orleans, LA, Prudence Wilson Barton of Lanesborough, MA, David M. Wilson, of Duxbury, VT, Mary Alice Williams, of Warren, VT, and stepfather of Jill Keating of Wolcott, VT., Jeffrey White of Georgia, VT. Janice Porter, of Putnam Lake, NY., and their spouses. Also survived by sixteen grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Memorial service at Christ Church, Montpelier, at 2:00 PM, June 1, 2001 . Gifts in Dr. Wilson's memory may be made to Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Teenagers, Guns and Wal-Mart
description: A Rockland County Wal-Mart store has agreed to consider a request by town officials to add a layer of safety measures to its policies on firearm sales to teenagers. At a meeting last week with Suffern school officials, students and the police, Wal-Mart representatives said they were open to requiring 18- and 19-year-olds to take a gun-safety seminar before buying a gun, and to sponsoring so-called character education classes at local schools. The programs would have to be detailed by the town before Wal-Mart agreed, said Keith Morris, Wal-Mart's community affairs manager. A proposal to move the firearms counter away from the toy department might be too costly, but store officials will look into it, he said. If adopted, the measures, which were first reported in The Journal News, would affect only that particular store, Mr. Morris said.

title: Webdenda
description: Marietta Benevento, vice president and creative director at FCBi, New York, part of the FCB Worldwide unit of True North Communications, was promoted to senior vice president.

title: Serbian Town's Deadly Secret Points the Finger at Milosevic
description: KLADOVO, Serbia, May 29  For two years the people of this Danube River town kept the dark secret that has now led  after a decade of Balkan death and destruction largely attributed to Slobodan Milosevic  to the first move by Serbia's new democratic authorities to charge him with war crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARDAI, VERA

title: In a Worldwide Pairs Slam and Sill Wanting an Overtrick
description: The Worldwide Pairs, organized by the World Bridge Federation, had mixed reviews a year ago. New technology made it possible to score all players around the world on the Internet at local, national and international levels. Analysis of the deals was also available in similar fashion, but many players, particularly those without computers, were disappointed not to receive the traditional booklet. However, it will be provided this year.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Airport Tower Reopens
description: Nearly three months after an earthquake caused heavy damage at the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, air-traffic controllers were finally able to move back into their regular tower. While the tower was repaired, the controllers worked out of makeshift quarters erected atop cargo containers on a hill overlooking the runways. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | $5.5 Million Theft Charged
description: An advertising executive with the Syms Corporation, the clothing discounter, was charged yesterday with stealing more than $5.5 million in an elaborate scheme of overbilling and false invoices, said the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. The executive, Douglas C. Meyer, the vice president for marketing at Syms Advertising, a subsidiary, funneled the money to sham corporations he established with the help of two accomplices, who were also charged with grand larceny, Mr. Morgenthau said. A lawyer for Mr. Meyer did not return a call seeking comment.

description: The politician was exaggerating, but not by much.

title: Complicated Portrait of a Suspect in Killings of Gay Men
description: On the day after Richard W. Rogers Jr. was charged with killing and dismembering two men in the early 1990's, people who knew the Staten Island nurse described him as a reliable worker who liked to surround himself with fashionable gay men, but largely kept to himself.

title: I Am Set for Life
description: Like most Americans, I've had my share of hard knocks, but that's all about to change. Yes, my ship has finally come in. According to the tax plan that Congress just passed, my family is going to receive a tax rebate of $600.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Building Contractor Criticized
description: A City Councilman criticized the State Dormitory Authority yesterday for continuing to do business with Trataros Construction Inc., a city building contractor that has a history of safety violations and was responsible for shoddy construction work recently at two public schools in Brooklyn. Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, a Democrat from Brooklyn, said that the state should have restricted new bids by the company, as the city has done. A state official said the Dormitory Authority was satisfied with the company's work at Baruch College and Queens College. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: Mets Fire Blanks in Pivotal Showdown
description: Edgardo Alfonzo looked as if he had a pizza box wrapped around his back yesterday, but it was just lots of ice. Enough ice to get a family through a barbecue. Alfonzo was seeking relief from his sore back, another thing that has gone awry in a vanishing season where everything keeps going awry for the Mets. Everything.

title: Origami That Takes a Step Beyond Storks and Swans
description: Mix origami, paper-cutting and pop-up books and one result is ''Origamic Architecture,'' a show of 100 works at the American Craft Museum through Sept. 2. Masahiro Chatani, a Tokyo architect, originated the art form in 1981 and has 40 works in the show. Takaaki Kihara made the Sydney Opera House, left. Marivi Garrido, an Argentine architect who has nine pieces in the show, uses them to teach mathematics to high school students. ''We study symmetry and we study planes,'' she said. ''It's all geometry.'' At 40 West 53rd Street. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Playing Games Gets Serious (and Painful)
description: VIDEO game consoles are continually reaching new levels of sophistication, as Sony's PlayStation 2 and the soon-to-be-released machines from Nintendo and Microsoft attest. But game controllers, those button-laden pads used to play the games on these consoles, are fairly standard stuff, having long ago lost any cutting-edge charm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: 50 Sickened By Stomach Ailment
description: The Nassau County Health Department is investigating an outbreak of fever, diarrhea and stomach pain among 50 people who ate food from the Shish-Kebab Snack Bar and Restaurant in Port Washington, or Ayhan's Shish-Kebab in Plainview, between May 23 and yesterday. The two restaurants are under the same ownership. A health department spokeswoman said the source of the contamination had not been identified. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Gifts That Can Warp a Museum
description: Early this month the Smithsonian Institution announced a $38 million gift from the Catherine B. Reynolds Foundation to create a permanent exhibition in the National Museum of American History devoted to the lives of American achievers. Ms. Reynolds, a pioneer in private education lending, has said that the 10,000-square-foot exhibition her gift sponsors, called ''The Spirit of America,'' will ''focus on current living people who are very much 21st century to inspire young people to be the best they can be.'' Some of the people whose stories might be told include, according to Ms. Reynolds, Martin Luther King Jr., Jonas Salk, Oprah Winfrey, Martha Stewart, Dorothy Hamill and Steven Case.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Losing Candidates Arrested
description: The six candidates who lost in last week's disputed presidential election were arrested on charges of civil disobedience after trying to organize a rally to mark the death of a supporter. The candidates, who were briefly detained earlier this week, are challenging the legitimacy of the victory by President Idriss Deby. Chad will soon start producing oil in a World Bank-backed project. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: And All It Has to Do Is Act Naturally
description: ''The Anniversary Party,'' a film that opens next week, stars Alan Cumming and Jennifer Jason Leigh, left, who also wrote and directed it together. It's a kind of ''Big Chill'' get-together revolving around a movie director (Mr. Cumming) who reunites with his wife (Ms. Leigh), a fading movie star. While there are many other notable actors -- Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Kline and Phoebe Cates -- the film's unacknowledged star is the Schaarman house. Built for F. W. Schaarman in 1953 by Richard Neutra in the Hollywood Hills, the house has remained virtually unaltered since its construction. It is used in every scene in the movie except one. ''It took us six weeks to find the house,'' Ms. Leigh said. ''It was the main character because it was a true reflection of the couple -- exposed and beautiful, but also precarious, as all Neutra houses are, because they are made of glass.''

title: Second Golfer Heartened by Cart Ruling
description: Ford Olinger has made a new promise to himself: go out and practice harder. It is a resolution that is less than two days old. It came about only after the Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that the PGA Tour had to let Casey Martin use a cart in tournaments.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Metlife To Cross (East) River
description: MetLife announced yesterday at City Hall that it would move 962 office workers from its headquarters in Manhattan to a converted warehouse in Queens, taking advantage of $30.8 million in tax incentives and grants to keep office workers in New York. MetLife, the No. 1 insurer by assets in the United States, is vacating much of its building at 1 Madison Avenue. MetLife chose Long Island City, a former warehouse district where the city wants to create a commercial center, after considering sites in New Jersey and Westchester. MetLife leased the 404,000 square-foot BridgePlaza, a six-story warehouse at the foot of the Queensboro Bridge.

title: Europeans Revoke Patent on Enzyme
description: The European Patent Office revoked a patent yesterday held by Roche on an enzyme crucial to one of the biotechnology industry's fundamental processes, executives said. The enzyme, known as Taq DNA polymerase, is used in the polymerase chain reaction, a technique to amplify minuscule amounts of DNA for use in medical diagnosis and DNA fingerprinting.

title: Essay; Needed: Freedom's Caucus
description: Before the Jeffords Jump, the biggest surprise to hit the Bush administration was the decision by 53 nations in the U.N. to throw the bothersome U.S. off the Human Rights Commission.

description: Beating a deadline to avoid defaulting on some debt agreements, the Xerox Corporation filed a report today indicating that its auditor had certified the company's financial statements for the last three years.

description: Two agencies are making changes that involve layoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANGER, WESLEY A. JR.
description: STANGER-Wesley A. Jr. On Wednesday, May 23, 2001, age 92 of Summit, NJ. Husband of Natalie Williams Stanger and the late Sarah McKee Stanger. Father of William M. Stanger of Summit, NJ and Robert A. Stanger of Little Silver, NJ. Brother of Rhys L. Stanger of Jacksonville, Fl. Survived by 7 grandchildren and 7 great grandchildren. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend the memorial service at the Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Ave (corner of Morris Ave), Summit, NJ on Saturday, June 16th at 3:00 PM. Please omit flowers, but a donation to the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA, 19104, in his memory would be appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Government Lifts Censorship
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga has ordered an immediate end to news media censorship, which has hamstrung reporting about the nation's civil strife for the better part of three years. No reason for the change was given but the ban has been severely criticized by international news media groups and human rights organizations. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Renewed Jitters on Profits Set Back Technology Issues
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, a day after Sun Microsystems warned that its earnings in the current quarter would fall below Wall Street estimates, reviving investors' concerns that the technology sector faces more profit pressures.

title: American Flight Attendants Reject Offer of Arbitration
description: The union representing flight attendants at American Airlines rejected an offer of arbitration from federal mediators yesterday, assuring the start of a 30-day cooling-off period after which its members will be legally free to strike.

title: Robots Square Off For Firefighting Title
description: TO Jacob E. Mendelssohn, who teaches engineering at Trinity College in Hartford, the smoke detector is a fine piece of technology. But it is a limited one -- while it can tell if a fire has started, it can't do anything to stop it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the efforts of an American transportation expert, Robert R. Kiley, to reorganize London's subway system referred incorrectly in some copies to a pending court ruling. A High Court judge ruled yesterday that the British government had the right to impose its plan. The ruling did not concern an injunction barring the release of critical studies by consultants. Details appear today in the World Briefing column, on Page A10. An obituary of the former Polish leader Edward Gierek yesterday misidentified his successor as head of the Communist Party. The successor was Stanislaw Kania, not Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. el-.2gfbulletel-.2us98 An obituary on Sunday about Alan Green, former ambassador to Romania, was reprinted in error. Mr. Green died on March 23, not last Friday; the obituary was published on March 27.us100 el-.2gfbulletel-.2 A front-page article on Monday about measures in Congress to block Mexican trucks from entering the United States misstated the affiliation of Joan Claybrook, a consumer safety advocate who commented on Teamster lobbying against the trucking. She is the president of Public Citizen, not Common Cause. Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about the financial results of cobiJDS Uniphasecoei, the maker of components for telecommunications networks, misstated the name of a company bought by JDS Uniphase in 1999. It was the Optical Coating Laboratory, not Coding. The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, as well as information about errors that call for correction. Messages may be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left at this toll-free number: 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). For comments on an editorial: letters@nytimes.com. For newspaper delivery questions: 1-800-NYTIMES (1-800-698-4637).

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Montvale: Unclaimed Lottery Millions
description: A $46 million jackpot is waiting for the person or persons who bought a Big Game lottery ticket. The catch: there are only 10 days left to claim it. The ticket, sold at Krauszers convenience store in Montvale on June 9, 2000, becomes worthless a year after the purchase date, and the jackpot is then divided among the five lottery states. The potential winners include New Yorkers, even though New York does not participate in the Big Game, because Montvale is near the Rockland County line and the buyer may have crossed the border. Winning numbers were 6, 7, 25, 34 and 45, plus a Big Money Ball number of 2.

title: Agriculture Nominee's Comments on Race Delay Hearings
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee is putting off hearings for a top Agriculture Department nominee who has been criticized by several civil rights groups for saying that the success of three Iowa farming counties was based on their homogenous background.

title: An Eclectic Riff on What Makes a Home
description: THE American industrial designer Raymond Loewy once said, ''Never leave well enough alone.'' Jim Budman, 57, subscribes to that philosophy, especially when it comes to his unconventional, ever changing loft-studio on Lafayette Street in SoHo. Unconventional? The place has no kitchen or bathroom. (He showers at the gym, orders in meals and uses a bathroom down the hall.) When his brother was in town recently, staying at the new hotel 60 Thompson, Mr. Budman said he went over ''to take a five-minute shower.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COGAN, RABBI MARCUS M.
description: COGAN-Rabbi Marcus M. Of Baltimore, MD., died on May 27, 2001 at the age of 88. Beloved husband of Selma, loving father of Chava Rosen, Miriam Landsberg-Silverman and Shlomo Cogan, beloved father-in-law of Rabbi Velvel Rosen, Eliezer Silverman and Chavi Cogan, loving grandfather and great-grandfather of many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Loving brother of Sarah Silverman and Rabbi Leo J. Cogan. Former principal and rebbe of Yeshiva Torah V'Daath, Chaplain in the US Army in WWII. The funeral was held in Baltimore on May 27, Erev Shavous.

title: Harper's Bazaar Editor Ousted; Hearst Names Her Successor
description: Kate Betts, the successor to the celebrated editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, Liz Tilberis, was asked to resign this afternoon, a full year before her three-year contract is due to expire, executives at Hearst Magazines said.

title: The Flat Future
description: I've always enjoyed watching Apple Computer; part of the reason is that the rest of the industry generally imitates whatever Apple does. Apple introduced the mouse, standardized the CD-ROM drive and eliminated the floppy drive (a change that other manufacturers are only slowly beginning to adopt).

title: Snow Carries the Sixers on His Fractured Ankle
description: Two days after Allen Iverson shook off a bruised tailbone and bloody mouth to lead Philadelphia to a comeback victory, Eric Snow's performance tonight will be added to 76ers lore.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Internet Election Challenge
description: Federal officals have charged a British Columbia man with breaking the law by posting results of last November's elections on the internet before polls closed in every province. Paul Bryan said he ignored the restriction in order to challenge the law, which he said violates his right to free speech and is outdated. Canadian broadcasters reported election results only where polls had closed. If convicted, Mr. Bryan could be fined up to $16,000. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Distribution Deal For Dragon
description: The popular computer dictation program Dragon NaturallySpeaking will be distributed in the United States and Canada by the Learning Company, the software publisher based in Novato, Calif. Pending a bankruptcy court's approval of the contract, the Learning Company will take exclusive retail responsibility for Dragon and for L&H Voice Xpress, which between them account for the majority of the $35 million retail market for speech recognition software. Both programs are developed by L&H Holdings, formerly Dragon Systems, which together with its troubled Belgian parent, the speech technology company Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V., filed for bankruptcy protection in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOND, SIMON
description: BOND-Simon. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the demise of a warm and sympathetic friend and honorary alumnus who with his late wife, Tekla, was a Benefactor whose generosity paralleled his longevity. Mr. Bond's life stretched over three centuries-from 1897 in his native Poland to the United States in 2001-during which he exhibited remarkable verve and wisdom till almost the last day of his life. A success in the business world, his interest in Jewish education, the synagogue, Israel, and scientific research endeared him to many. We shall miss him sorely and remember him fondly. Heartfelt condolences are extended to all members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman, Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Bernard H. Mendik, a New York City real estate executive, misstated the name of a group of which he was a trustee. It is the Citizens Budget Commission, not committee. The obituary also misidentified the law school from which he graduated. It was New York Law School, not New York University.

title: Dinosaur Fossil Found in Egypt, Ranks as Second Biggest
description: Digging at an oasis in the Egyptian desert, paleontologists have found huge fossil bones of what they say appears to have been the second most massive dinosaur that ever lived.

title: When the Glaze Is Off the Bathroom
description: ''We provide a new bathroom without ripping anything out of the old one -- and at about one-ninetieth of the cost,'' said Paul Echavarria, an owner of Premium Reglazing in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Reglazing is a sprayed-on new skin of acrylic urethane that covers tubs, sinks, tile walls, even tile floors. The porcelainlike finish, which comes in 100 solid colors and 15 with granite texture, also hides chips, scratches, rust and small holes (right, pink before and white after). Mr. Echavarria guarantees his finish for 10 years; he said ordinary tile paint will peel. A tub alone starts at $285; reglazing an entire bathroom -- tub, tiles, floor and sink -- is $700 to $1,800. Allow a day for the work, plus 24 hours to dry. Premium Reglazing is at 300 Atlantic Avenue: www.premiumreglazing.com or (888) 404-8827. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Sharon Scolds His Nation Over Calamity
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon delivered an unusual address to Parliament today in which he attacked as self-destructive a guiding principle of Israeli life -- thou shalt not be a sucker.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: U.S. Judge Dismisses Suit Against Texaco
description: A federal judge in Manhattan has dismissed a nearly eight-year-old lawsuit brought by Ecuadorean Indians against Texaco. In a ruling yesterday, Judge Jed S. Rakoff dismissed the suit, which accused Texaco of polluting the Indians' land in the Amazon rain forest, on the ground that it should have been brought in Ecuador and not in the United States. Last September, Judge Rakoff denied a motion by the Indians' lawyers to recuse himself from the case after he confirmed he had attended an expenses-paid seminar in 1998 at which a former Texaco chairman spoke.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: No Sentence For Man Frisked By Whitman
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday overturned the sentence of a black man whom Gov. Christie Whitman frisked during a 1996 drug sweep. The court's decision was unrelated to the frisk, however, and turned on a four-year sentence imposed on the man, Sherron Rolax, when he failed to show up at his sentencing, thereby violating a plea agreement for an 18-month sentence. The court sent the case back to the trial judge to determine if sentencing guidelines for no-show defendants were applied uniformly. The Camden prosecutor said he would not appeal. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Kia Stake Trimmed

A 13 percent block of Kia stock will go to a trust company set up by Hanvit Bank, which will resell shares to overseas investors. Hyundai Motor said it expected to reap 420 billion won ($326 million), a 22 percent discount to Kia's stock price yesterday. It will retain 34.47 percent of Kia. Hyundai and Kia together have about 75 percent of the domestic car market. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: LARGE MANUFACTURER OF DENTAL SUPPLIES TO BUY A RIVAL
description: Dentsply International Inc., a leading maker of dental products, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a rival, the dental unit of Degussa A.G. of Germany, for about $494 million to continue its global expansion. The acquisition, expected to be completed in July, would be Dentsply's third this year. It would make Dentsply the biggest dental supply company in Europe and third largest in Japan. For Degussa, the sale would be the fifth in a divestment program focusing the company on its main business, producing specialty chemicals.

title: PROFIT WARNING SENDS SHARES OF RADIOSHACK TUMBLING
description: Shares in the RadioShack Corporation fell 18 percent after the company, an electronics retailer, said its second-quarter profit would fall more than expected because of slowing sales of wireless telephones and computers. The shares fell $5.92, to $26.93. They had dropped 37 percent in the last 12 months. The chief executive, Leonard H. Roberts, said on Tuesday that sales of cell phones and services from Verizon Wireless Inc. and the Sprint Corporation and of personal computers from the Compaq Computer Corporation lagged forecasts. Consumers are also curbing spending as the economy slows and as businesses cut jobs.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Free Call, Cheaper Interest
description: A toll-free telephone line is being set up to encourage prospective homeowners in minority neighborhoods to seek conventional financing and avoid so-called predatory lenders, Senator Charles E. Nine New York banks and the Federal National Mortgage Association are participating in the pilot program, the House Equity Lending Project, along with the Allen A.M.E. Cathedral in Queens and the Bridge Street Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. The number, starting in July, will be (877) 297-7179. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDIK, BERNARD H.
description: MENDIK - Bernard H. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of NYU Medical Center mourn the passing of Bernard H. Mendik, our cherished friend, devoted supporter and generous benefactor over many years. The Department of Otolaryngology received its first advanced operating microscope in the 1980s, thanks to Mr. Mendik's farsightedness and generosity. A Professorship was endowed in his name in 1998-a major contribution that has enhanced the Medical Center's reputation and its outstanding achievements in the field of Otolaryngology. As a Trustee on the Foundation Board of NYU School of Medicine, he took his commitment to our institution to an even higher level, bringing a spirit of joyful leadership to his new role. A successful attorney, dynamic real estate entrepreneur, avid philanthropist, skier, tennis player and fly fisherman, Mr. Mendik was that rare, multifaceted individual who brought joy and zest to every aspect of life. He will be missed by all whose lives he touched. We send our deepest condolences to his family and loved ones. Kenneth Langone, Chairman NYU School of Medicine Foundation Board of Trustees Robert M. Glickman, M.D., Dean NYU School of Medicine Theresa A. Bischoff, President NYU Hospitals Center Noel L. Cohen, M.D. Bernard H. Mendik Professor and Chairman, Department of Otolaryngology, NYU Medical Center

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Disappointment For Steel Maker
description: Germany's largest steel maker, ThyssenKrupp A.G., reported lower-than-expected pretax profit of 102 million euros ($87.1 million) for the second quarter. The company also cut its full-year profit forecast because of lower steel prices and slowing growth in the United States and Europe. Its automotive business was also hurt in Europe. ThyssenKrupp said it expected pretax profit to drop about 27 percent compared with last fiscal year's income of 1.1 billion euros, not including a one-time gain of 300 million euros from the sale of a unit. It was the second time this year that ThyssenKrupp cut its forecast. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Record Haunts Indian Leader
description: Russell Means, a leader of the American Indian Movement, said he planned to run for governor next year as a Libertarian, but a felony conviction 26 years ago in South Dakota could prevent him. A New Mexico law bars anyone convicted of a felony from seeking election unless the candidate has received a pardon from the governor. The state's current governor, Gary E. Johnson, said he did not believe he had the power to pardon someone who had been convicted in another state. Mr. Means was sent to prison for a year for obstruction of justice and rioting. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Power Dispute
description: The Dabhol Power Company, the Enron Corporation's unit in India, stopped generating electricity at its $3 billion power plant after its sole customer, the utility of the Indian state of Maharashtra, stopped buying power on Tuesday. The halt in power generation was the latest move in a months-long dispute that has cast doubt on the future of Dabhol's $2.9 billion power project in India, the largest foreign investment ever in India. Jimmy Mogul, a spokesman for Enron, which owns 65 percent of Dabhol, said the company remained open to discussions in the dispute, which involves overdue payments for power. Dabhol had issued a preliminary termination notice on May 19 saying it was pulling out of the Indian project. Final termination requires a contractual six-month cooling-off period.

title: Taking Risks, Opposites Attract Inspiration

Mr. Lovano, the saxophonist, has four musicians behind him, including Idris Muhammad and Joey Baron, drummers of wildly different stripes. In the week's first set, on Tuesday, the drummers -- and the others -- drifted in and out at the bandleader's invitation. Sometimes the drummers played together, sometimes they switched off between choruses, sometimes one just watched and listened. The different palettes of the pieces could accommodate two clarinets and bass, or saxophone and drums alone, or all five players at once.

''The Woman in Black,'' a modestly conceived tourist perennial adapted by Stephen Mallatratt from Susan Hill's 1983 novel, was originally intended as a three-and-a-half-week Christmas show in Yorkshire.

title: Four MetroStars Tapped for U.S. Team
description: Four players for the MetroStars were among only five members of Major League Soccer teams named to the United States national team roster yesterday by Coach Bruce Arena for the friendly match against Ecuador next Friday in Columbus, Ohio.

title: CNN Hires A New Anchor From ABC
description: For 20 years, Bernard Shaw was the face of CNN-TV, a leading anchor and correspondent when major news broke -- the Persian Gulf war, the presidential election race between George W. Bush and Al Gore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUMMINGS, EILEEN P.
description: CUMMINGS-Eileen P., on May 25, 2001. Aunt of John, Jay and Reverend Donald Harrington, C.M. Services private.

title: Jailed Vieques Protesters Remain Unbowed
description: After a week in jails, first in San Juan and then in Brooklyn, the three Bronx Democratic officials who were imprisoned for participating in a protest in Puerto Rico seem a little worn and slightly haggard. But despite daily strip searches and other hardships, they described their experience behind bars as necessary to call attention to the Navy bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Magritte, Living Large in Miami
description: What has the Miami Design District needed? Why, a gigantic outdoor living room, of course. Roberto Behar and Rosario Marquardt, two Miami Beach architects, took a warehouse and tacked on 42-foot-high walls, a stucco sofa, two 15-foot lamps and a 40-foot curtain. The Living Room Building (photograph above), at 4000 North Miami Avenue, explores ''where public and private space collide and become one,'' Mr. Behar said. Locals seem happy to plunk down on the street-level sofa and read the paper.

title: A Surprise as Safety Commission Votes to Draft Bath-Seat Rules
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission voted unanimously yesterday to begin drafting new safety standards for bath seats, after the only Republican member modified her longstanding opposition.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: AD EXEC CHARGED WITH $5.5 MILLION THEFT An advertising executive with the Syms Corporation , the clothing discounter, was charged yesterday with stealing more than $5.5 million in an elaborate scheme of overbilling and false invoices, said the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. The executive, Douglas C. Meyer, the vice president for marketing at Syms Advertising, a subsidiary, funneled the money to sham corporations he established with the help of two accomplices, who were also charged with grand larceny, Mr. Morgenthau said. A lawyer for Mr. Meyer did not return a call seeking comment.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Gateway Wades Into Price Wars
description: Gateway Inc., the second-largest direct seller of personal computers, said it would match the lowest prices offered by competitors in a response to price cuts by its rivals Dell Computer and Compaq Computer. Gateway said it might see a decline in gross margins as a result of the price cuts, but reiterated its forecast of break-even earnings for the first half of 2001. Dell, the biggest direct seller of PC's, and Compaq have cut prices to increase market share as the economy has slowed. Gateway had previously offered extra features rather than reduced prices to avoid lowering its profit. Gateway said the low-price offer would be available in Gateway stores, by telephone and online.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALENTI, FRANK A.
description: VALENTI-Frank A., 89, of Queensbury, NY, May 20. Son of the late Antonino and Lena. Born and raised in NYC; graduated from Alfred Univ. and Master's from Columbia Univ. WW II Army veteran, taught Special Education, John Jay HS, Brooklyn, over 30 years. His first wife Olga died in 1966. Survived by Elaine Murphy (married 1967), two sons, Frank (Andrea) and Richard (Maryann), four grandchildren, Frank, Alexandra, Danielle and Amanda, and his sister, Alfonsina Valenti. Burial was at Long Island National Veterans Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: No Shipbuilding Deal
description: Three days of talks meant to defuse a trade dispute over shipbuilding ended without the European Union and South Korea agreeing on anything but a date for new talks. The union has threatened to seek punitive action by the World Trade Organization unless South Korea agrees to raise its ship prices by 15 percent, to offset what the Europeans say is unfair government support for the Korean shipyards. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Article 2001053192931495353 -- No Title
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNITED AUTO GROUP INC., Detroit, the nation's third-biggest publicly held auto retailer, bought two dealerships in Nanuet, N.Y., to expand its customer base in the New York area.

title: Article 2001053190753013198 -- No Title
description: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom

title: U.S. Is Pessimistic Over Its Mideast Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, May 31  After more than a week of shuttle diplomacy by the American official William J. Burns, the Bush administration is increasingly pessimistic about being able to bring a halt to the Israeli-Palestinian violence any time soon.

title: Roddick Conquers Cramps, and Childhood Hero
description: Well into the third hour of Andy Roddick's rite of passage this evening, when the muscle cramps left him using his racket as a cane, while the plummeting sun was coloring the clay burnt red, a film reel began rolling in his head.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 13 about Sebastian Snow, an eccentric English explorer who helped confirm the source of the Amazon River, referred erroneously to an encounter he had with animals during a trek north from Tierra del Fuego. Tigers are not found in the wild in the Western Hemisphere.

title: One of Suspects in Killing of Tenant Was Charged in '98 Fatal Shooting
description: One of the men arrested in the killing and dismemberment of a Manhattan tenant last weekend had previously been charged in an unrelated killing in Staten Island three years ago, officials said yesterday.

title: Pataki Says Budget Impasse Could Mean No Spending Plan
description: ALBANY, May 30  With the state budget already two months overdue, negotiations have become so deadlocked over the health of the economy that Gov. George E. Pataki today raised the possibility the state may fail to pass a budget at all this year.

title: Competition Sprouts One-Stop Law Firms; Diversification Means Higher Profits But Opens Door to Ethical Concerns
description: Need a private investigator? Try H & K Investigative Solutions. Want advice on how to win government subsidies for environmentally sound real estate projects? Turn to H & K Conservation Solutions. How about money management advice, a real estate feasibility study, evaluation of a merger or acquisition or documents translated into virtually any language in the world? H & K has business units to meet the need.

title: Battered Stocks Edge Higher as Investors Hunt for Bargains
description: Stock prices posted modest gains today as investors, fresh from a sharp sell-off of technology stocks Wednesday, spent the day bargain-hunting and nudged equities higher.

title: Casey Martin, Striving for Par
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A May 25 Op-Ed article incorrectly identified Trent Lott as being majority whip in the House in 1983. He was the minority whip.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Unionization Urged At Yale
description: A delegation of religious leaders delivered a petition to Yale yesterday that calls on the university not to oppose a unionization drive by several hundred graduate teaching assistants. The petition, signed by more than 280 members of the clergy, also urged the university's teaching hospital, Yale-New Haven Hospital, not to fight a drive to unionize more than 2,000 clerical and other workers. The petition also asked Yale to let those employees show their support for a union by signing union membership cards, rather than by voting. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Threat Puts U.S. Force in Bahrain on Alert
description: American military forces in Bahrain have been placed on a heightened state of alert after a threat of a terrorist attack, a Defense Department official said today.

title: In America; It Hasn't Gone Away
description: The scourge came upon us rather quietly. In the late spring of 1981 a new president, Ronald Reagan, was rounding up votes for his tax-cut package. Americans were fascinated by Prince Charles's fairy-tale courtship of Lady Diana Spencer, who was routinely referred to as the next queen of England. Al Pacino was starring in David Mamet's ''American Buffalo'' at the Circle in the Square. And an enormous ad campaign was touting a new movie from the creators of ''Jaws'' and ''Star Wars,'' an old-fashioned cliffhanger called ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.''

title: 'Full Monty' Composer's Tony Anxiety Is Pell-Mel
description: ALL this Tony Awards dementia is frittering away at the composer David Yazbek's carefully cultivated -- we're talking eight years of spirituality lessons and cross-legged meditation! -- Zen frame of mind. Unable to escape his obsession with beating his ex-idol Mel Brooks (''The Producers'') for the best score award for ''The Full Monty,'' the underdog show about underdog men who sing in their underwear, he's become a real-life clone of the blabbering, blubbering character who forgets his mantra in ''Annie Hall.''

title: INSIDE
description: China Curbs AIDS Fighter

title: You Can't Keep Them Down On the Farm
description: Taking a cue from people who sit all day and don't get many Snapple breaks, Freecell used an actual perch of the kind found on tractors and harvesters in its molded-foam Tractor chair. (Achille Castiglione did something similar in his 1957 Mezzadro seat.) ''Built into it is the idea of comfort through 10-plus hours of hard labor, in any conditions,'' said Troy Ostrander, one of three partners in Freecell, which is known for inventive uses of industrial products. ''It's meant to be rained on.'' You can park the Tractor chair ($170) at the computer for its lumbar support -- or in the backyard (it won't rust). Freecell is at 147 Essex Street (Stanton Street), (212) 529-6950 or www.frcll.com. AMY GOLDWASSER

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hevesi Wins Endorsements
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, a Democratic candidate for mayor, will be endorsed today by five local members of Congress: Representatives Anthony D. Weiner, Nita M. Lowey, Gary L. Ackerman, Joseph Crowley and Eliot L. Engel. Why is Mr. Ackerman endorsing him? ''He gave me $20,'' the congressman joked, adding that he had known Mr. Hevesi for 35 years and found him hard working and smart. But alluding to frequent comments about Mr. Hevesi, Mr. Ackerman declared, ''I don't think he's boring at all.'' Elisabeth Bumiller (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Downe: Man Drowns In Boat Accident
description: A 71-year-old man fishing with two friends in Delaware Bay yesterday, drowned in what officials said was an attempt to lift anchor in choppy seas that swamped their power boat before they could grab life preservers. The three men -- the victim, Leslie Miller, of Kirkwood; the boat owner, Harry Lombardo, 66, of Gibbstown, and his son, Andrew Lombardo, 38 -- were anchored off Downe Township in Cumberland County about 10:30 a.m., the police said. The anchor snagged, turning the boat's stern in the direction of the rising waves, causing it to take on water and capsize. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Mom Always Liked You Better . . . And Other Eternal Verities
description: If the mysterious comic chemistry between two performers who have been working together for more than four decades can be kept fresh, why fiddle with the formula? That's one of the reassuring pleasures of the Smothers Brothers' act, which arrived at Feinstein's at the Regency on Tuesday evening.

title: Avalanche Shrugs Off Poor Play on Devils' Ice
description: Fresh off its frustrating 2-1 loss to the Devils on Tuesday night in Game 2 of the Stanley Cup finals, the Colorado Avalanche was confronted with a troubling statistic today as the four-of-seven-game series shifted to New Jersey for Games 3 and 4.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Power Rates Rise
description: For the third time this year, Seattle's public utility has raised electric rates for its customers, citing the huge increases it is forced to pay as it buys power on the open market during a continuing drought in the region. Seattle City Light will charge its customers an average increase of 9.3 percent beginning in July, in addition to average increases of 10 percent imposed in January and 18 percent in March. The new increases will result in a monthly increase of $4.21, to about $57, for a typical family's electric bill. That bill is about $15 more than last year's average. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Last Chapter: Berlin to Pay Slave Workers Held by Nazis
description: After more than two years of often bitter negotiations, Parliament approved a motion today that opens the way for payment of $4.5 billion to laborers forced to work by the Nazis.

title: Metro Matters; His Pique Helps Expose Her Perks
description: THE question of the week is not why the mayor halved his estranged wife's staff. We know why, and at least one New Yorker -- this one -- has to wish that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had just left things alone instead of launching another retaliatory round in the couple's bitter divorce. He's only got seven months left in office, after all. Why further humiliate his wife and expose his children to more ridicule?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDAL, JUDITH S.
description: RANDAL-Judith S. Died peacefully on May 27, 2001 at the age of 95. Survived by her daughter Judith Hines of Lovettsville, VA. Her son, Jonathan Randal of Paris, France and her brother, Richard Stern of Kansas City, MO. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Putin Puts His Man in Charge at Gazprom
description: In a move to rid Russia of a major obstacle to his economic overhaul program, President Vladimir V. Putin has engineered the replacement of the head of Gazprom, the huge natural gas monopoly, with a close Putin ally.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Foreign Minister On The Carpet
description: Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer told a parliamentary committee investigating the leak of a secret cable that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, did not admit involvement in terrorist crimes during a meeting in March with a German envoy. The cable, from the German Embassy in Washington, suggested that Mr. Qaddafi had admitted to the envoy that he played a role in the bombing of a discotheque in Berlin in 1986 and in the downing of a Pan Am jet over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988. The envoy, Michael Steiner, chief diplomatic aide to Chancellor Gerhard Schrder, has been under pressure to quit since publication of the cable this month embarrassed the government. Roger Cohen (NYT)

title: Faisal Husseini, Key Official of Palestinians, Is Dead at 60
description: JERUSALEM, May 31  Faisal Husseini, the senior Palestinian official in Jerusalem and a political prisoner turned peace advocate whose family history was entwined with the Palestinian cause, died in Kuwait today. He was 60.

title: Article 2001053191507834287 -- No Title
description: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

title: Broncos Sign Beuerlein as a Backup
description: The Denver Broncos signed the free-agent quarterback Steve Beuerlein to a multiyear contract, the team announced today.

title: What's Next: For Efficiency, Light-Emitting Diodes May Turn to Carbon
description: THE current color flat-panel displays do everything backward. First, the screen is lighted to its full brightness by a battery-draining lamp. Then a series of color filters and tiny liquid crystal displays, or L.C.D.'s, block most of that light to create on-screen images.

title: Two Aides to Hanover Resign; She Then Hires One Privately
description: Two aides to Donna Hanover resigned yesterday in Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's escalating divorce battle rather than be reassigned by City Hall to new jobs. But Ms. Hanover, the mayor's increasingly estranged wife, immediately rehired one of the aides, Joannie Danielides, whose $60,000-a-year salary as press secretary is now to be paid directly by Ms. Hanover.

title: Move to Oust President Runs Smooth Course in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 31  Indonesia is on course to oust its third leader in three years. But unlike previous political upheavals, which were chaotic and violent, this one is unfolding with remarkable order.
